<b>5 </b>¶ And Joseph dreamed a dream, and he told <i>it</i> his brethren: and they hated him yet the more.

<b>6 </b>And he said unto them, Hear, I pray you, this dream which I have dreamed:

<b>7 </b>For, behold, we <i>were</i> binding sheaves in the field, and, lo, my sheaf arose, and also stood upright; and, behold, your sheaves stood round about, and made obeisance to my sheaf.

<b>8 </b>And his brethren said to him, Shalt thou indeed reign over us? or shalt thou indeed have dominion over us? And they hated him yet the more for his dreams, and for his words.

<b>9 </b>¶ And he dreamed yet another dream, and told it his brethren, and said, Behold, I have dreamed a dream more; and, behold, the sun and the moon and the eleven stars made obeisance to me.

<b>10 </b>And he told <i>it</i> to his father, and to his brethren: and his father rebuked him, and said unto him, What <i>is</i> this dream that thou hast dreamed? Shall I and thy mother and thy brethren indeed come to bow down ourselves to thee to the earth?

<b>11 </b>And his brethren envied him; but his father observed the saying.

<b>12 </b>¶ And his brethren went to feed their father’s flock in Shechem.

<b>13 </b>And Israel said unto Joseph, Do not thy brethren feed <i>the flock</i> in Shechem? come, and I will send thee unto them. And he said to him, Here <i>am I.</i>

<b>14 </b>And he said to him, Go, I pray thee, see whether it be well with thy brethren, and well with the flocks; and bring me word again. So he sent him out of the vale of Hebron, and he came to Shechem.

<b>15 </b>¶ And a certain man found him, and, behold, <i>he was</i> wandering in the field: and the man asked him, saying, What seekest thou?

<b>16 </b>And he said, I seek my brethren: tell me, I pray thee, where they feed <i>their flocks.</i>

<b>17 </b>And the man said, They are departed hence; for I heard them say, Let us go to Dothan. And Joseph went after his brethren, and found them in Dothan.

<b>18 </b>And when they saw him afar off, even before he came near unto them, they conspired against him to slay him.

<b>19 </b>And they said one to another, Behold, this dreamer cometh.

<b>20 </b>Come now therefore, and let us slay him, and cast him into some pit, and we will say, Some evil beast hath devoured him: and we shall see what will become of his dreams.

<b>21 </b>And Reuben heard <i>it,</i> and he delivered him out of their hands; and said, Let us not kill him.

<b>22 </b>And Reuben said unto them, Shed no blood, <i>but</i> cast him into this pit that <i>is</i> in the wilderness, and lay no hand upon him; that he might rid him out of their hands, to deliver him to his father again.

<b>23 </b>¶ And it came to pass, when Joseph was come unto his brethren, that they stript Joseph out of his coat, <i>his</i> coat of <i>many</i> colours that <i>was</i> on him;

<b>24 </b>And they took him, and cast him into a pit: and the pit <i>was</i> empty, <i>there was</i> no water in it.

<b>25 </b>And they sat down to eat bread: and they lifted up their eyes and looked, and, behold, a company of Ishmeelites came from Gilead with their camels bearing spicery and balm and myrrh, going to carry <i>it</i> down to Egypt.

<b>26 </b>And Judah said unto his brethren, What profit <i>is it</i> if we slay our brother, and conceal his blood?

<b>27 </b>Come, and let us sell him to the Ishmeelites, and let not our hand be upon him; for he <i>is</i> our brother <i>and</i> our flesh. And his brethren were content.

<b>28 </b>Then there passed by Midianites merchantmen; and they drew and lifted up Joseph out of the pit, and sold Joseph to the Ishmeelites for twenty <i>pieces</i> of silver: and they brought Joseph into Egypt.

<b>29 </b>¶ And Reuben returned unto the pit; and, behold, Joseph <i>was</i> not in the pit; and he rent his clothes.

<b>30 </b>And he returned unto his brethren, and said, The child <i>is</i> not; and I, whither shall I go?

<b>31 </b>And they took Joseph’s coat, and killed a kid of the goats, and dipped the coat in the blood;

<b>32 </b>And they sent the coat of <i>many</i> colours, and they brought <i>it</i> to their father; and said, This have we found: know now whether it <i>be</i> thy son’s coat or no.

<b>33 </b>And he knew it, and said, <i>It is</i> my son’s coat; an evil beast hath devoured him; Joseph is without doubt rent in pieces.

<b>34 </b>And Jacob rent his clothes, and put sackcloth upon his loins, and mourned for his son many days.

<b>35 </b>And all his sons and all his daughters rose up to comfort him; but he refused to be comforted; and he said, For I will go down into the grave unto my son mourning. Thus his father wept for him.

<b>36 </b>And the Midianites sold him into Egypt unto Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh’s, <i>and</i> captain of the guard.


--------------------

CHAPTER 38

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass at that time, that Judah went down from his brethren, and turned in to a certain Adullamite, whose name <i>was</i> Hirah.

<b>2 </b>And Judah saw there a daughter of a certain Canaanite, whose name <i>was</i> Shuah; and he took her, and went in unto her.

<b>3 </b>And she conceived, and bare a son; and he called his name Er.

<b>4 </b>And she conceived again, and bare a son; and she called his name Onan.

<b>5 </b>And she yet again conceived, and bare a son; and called his name Shelah: and he was at Chezib, when she bare him.

<b>6 </b>And Judah took a wife for Er his firstborn, whose name <i>was</i> Tamar.

<b>7 </b>And Er, Judah’s firstborn, was wicked in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> slew him.

<b>8 </b>And Judah said unto Onan, Go in unto thy brother’s wife, and marry her, and raise up seed to thy brother.

<b>9 </b>And Onan knew that the seed should not be his; and it came to pass, when he went in unto his brother’s wife, that he spilled <i>it</i> on the ground, lest that he should give seed to his brother.

<b>10 </b>And the thing which he did displeased the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: wherefore he slew him also.

<b>11 </b>Then said Judah to Tamar his daughter in law, Remain a widow at thy father’s house, till Shelah my son be grown: for he said, Lest peradventure he die also, as his brethren <i>did.</i> And Tamar went and dwelt in her father’s house.

<b>12 </b>¶ And in process of time the daughter of Shuah Judah’s wife died; and Judah was comforted, and went up unto his sheepshearers to Timnath, he and his friend Hirah the Adullamite.

<b>13 </b>And it was told Tamar, saying, Behold thy father in law goeth up to Timnath to shear his sheep.

<b>14 </b>And she put her widow’s garments off from her, and covered her with a veil, and wrapped herself, and sat in an open place, which <i>is</i> by the way to Timnath; for she saw that Shelah was grown, and she was not given unto him to wife.

<b>15 </b>When Judah saw her, he thought her <i>to be</i> an harlot; because she had covered her face.

<b>16 </b>And he turned unto her by the way, and said, Go to, I pray thee, let me come in unto thee; (for he knew not that she <i>was</i> his daughter in law.) And she said, What wilt thou give me, that thou mayest come in unto me?

<b>17 </b>And he said, I will send <i>thee</i> a kid from the flock. And she said, Wilt thou give <i>me</i> a pledge, till thou send <i>it?</i>

<b>18 </b>And he said, What pledge shall I give thee? And she said, Thy signet, and thy bracelets, and thy staff that <i>is</i> in thine hand. And he gave <i>it</i> her, and came in unto her, and she conceived by him.

<b>19 </b>And she arose, and went away, and laid by her veil from her, and put on the garments of her widowhood.

<b>20 </b>And Judah sent the kid by the hand of his friend the Adullamite, to receive <i>his</i> pledge from the woman’s hand: but he found her not.

<b>21 </b>Then he asked the men of that place, saying, Where <i>is</i> the harlot, that <i>was</i> openly by the way side? And they said, There was no harlot in this <i>place.</i>

<b>22 </b>And he returned to Judah, and said, I cannot find her; and also the men of the place said, <i>that</i> there was no harlot in this <i>place.</i>

<b>23 </b>And Judah said, Let her take <i>it</i> to her, lest we be shamed: behold, I sent this kid, and thou hast not found her.

<b>24 </b>¶ And it came to pass about three months after, that it was told Judah, saying, Tamar thy daughter in law hath played the harlot; and also, behold, she <i>is</i> with child by whoredom. And Judah said, Bring her forth, and let her be burnt.

<b>25 </b>When she <i>was</i> brought forth, she sent to her father in law, saying, By the man, whose these <i>are, am</i> I with child: and she said, Discern, I pray thee, whose <i>are</i> these, the signet, and bracelets, and staff.

<b>26 </b>And Judah acknowledged <i>them,</i> and said, She hath been more righteous than I; because that I gave her not to Shelah my son. And he knew her again no more.

<b>27 </b>¶ And it came to pass in the time of her travail, that, behold, twins <i>were</i> in her womb.

<b>28 </b>And it came to pass, when she travailed, that <i>the one</i> put out <i>his</i> hand: and the midwife took and bound upon his hand a scarlet thread, saying, This came out first.

<b>29 </b>And it came to pass, as he drew back his hand, that, behold, his brother came out: and she said, How hast thou broken forth? <i>this</i> breach <i>be</i> upon thee: therefore his name was called Pharez.

<b>30 </b>And afterward came out his brother, that had the scarlet thread upon his hand: and his name was called Zarah.


--------------------

CHAPTER 39

<b>1 </b>And Joseph was brought down to Egypt; and Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh, captain of the guard, an Egyptian, bought him of the hands of the Ishmeelites, which had brought him down thither.

<b>2 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was with Joseph, and he was a prosperous man; and he was in the house of his master the Egyptian.

<b>3 </b>And his master saw that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>was</i> with him, and that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> made all that he did to prosper in his hand.

<b>4 </b>And Joseph found grace in his sight, and he served him: and he made him overseer over his house, and all <i>that</i> he had he put into his hand.

<b>5 </b>And it came to pass from the time <i>that</i> he had made him overseer in his house, and over all that he had, that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> blessed the Egyptian’s house for Joseph’s sake; and the blessing of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was upon all that he had in the house, and in the field.

<b>6 </b>And he left all that he had in Joseph’s hand; and he knew not ought he had, save the bread which he did eat. And Joseph was <i>a</i> goodly <i>person,</i> and well favoured.

<b>7 </b>¶ And it came to pass after these things, that his master’s wife cast her eyes upon Joseph; and she said, Lie with me.

<b>8 </b>But he refused, and said unto his master’s wife, Behold, my master wotteth not what <i>is</i> with me in the house, and he hath committed all that he hath to my hand;

<b>9 </b><i>There is</i> none greater in this house than I; neither hath he kept back any thing from me but thee, because thou <i>art</i> his wife: how then can I do this great wickedness, and sin against God?

<b>10 </b>And it came to pass, as she spake to Joseph day by day, that he hearkened not unto her, to lie by her, <i>or</i> to be with her.

<b>11 </b>And it came to pass about this time, that <i>Joseph</i> went into the house to do his business; and <i>there was</i> none of the men of the house there within.

<b>12 </b>And she caught him by his garment, saying, Lie with me: and he left his garment in her hand, and fled, and got him out.

<b>13 </b>And it came to pass, when she saw that he had left his garment in her hand, and was fled forth,

<b>14 </b>That she called unto the men of her house, and spake unto them, saying, See, he hath brought in an Hebrew unto us to mock us; he came in unto me to lie with me, and I cried with a loud voice:

<b>15 </b>And it came to pass, when he heard that I lifted up my voice and cried, that he left his garment with me, and fled, and got him out.

<b>16 </b>And she laid up his garment by her, until his lord came home.

<b>17 </b>And she spake unto him according to these words, saying, The Hebrew servant, which thou hast brought unto us, came in unto me to mock me:

<b>18 </b>And it came to pass, as I lifted up my voice and cried, that he left his garment with me, and fled out.

<b>19 </b>And it came to pass, when his master heard the words of his wife, which she spake unto him, saying, After this manner did thy servant to me; that his wrath was kindled.

<b>20 </b>And Joseph’s master took him, and put him into the prison, a place where the king’s prisoners <i>were</i> bound: and he was there in the prison.

<b>21 </b>¶ But the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was with Joseph, and shewed him mercy, and gave him favour in the sight of the keeper of the prison.

<b>22 </b>And the keeper of the prison committed to Joseph’s hand all the prisoners that <i>were</i> in the prison; and whatsoever they did there, he was the doer <i>of it.</i>

<b>23 </b>The keeper of the prison looked not to any thing <i>that was</i> under his hand; because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was with him, and <i>that</i> which he did, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> made <i>it</i> to prosper.


--------------------

CHAPTER 40

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass after these things, <i>that</i> the butler of the king of Egypt and <i>his</i> baker had offended their lord the king of Egypt.

<b>2 </b>And Pharaoh was wroth against two <i>of</i> his officers, against the chief of the butlers, and against the chief of the bakers.

<b>3 </b>And he put them in ward in the house of the captain of the guard, into the prison, the place where Joseph <i>was</i> bound.

<b>4 </b>And the captain of the guard charged Joseph with them, and he served them: and they continued a season in ward.

<b>5 </b>¶ And they dreamed a dream both of them, each man his dream in one night, each man according to the interpretation of his dream, the butler and the baker of the king of Egypt, which <i>were</i> bound in the prison.

<b>6 </b>And Joseph came in unto them in the morning, and looked upon them, and, behold, they <i>were</i> sad.

<b>7 </b>And he asked Pharaoh’s officers that <i>were</i> with him in the ward of his lord’s house, saying, Wherefore look ye <i>so</i> sadly to day?

<b>8 </b>And they said unto him, We have dreamed a dream, and <i>there is</i> no interpreter of it. And Joseph said unto them, <i>Do</i> not interpretations <i>belong</i> to God? tell me <i>them,</i> I pray you.

<b>9 </b>And the chief butler told his dream to Joseph, and said to him, In my dream, behold, a vine <i>was</i> before me;

<b>10 </b>And in the vine <i>were</i> three branches: and it <i>was</i> as though it budded, <i>and</i> her blossoms shot forth; and the clusters thereof brought forth ripe grapes:

<b>11 </b>And Pharaoh’s cup <i>was</i> in my hand: and I took the grapes, and pressed them into Pharaoh’s cup, and I gave the cup into Pharaoh’s hand.

<b>12 </b>And Joseph said unto him, This <i>is</i> the interpretation of it: The three branches <i>are</i> three days:

<b>13 </b>Yet within three days shall Pharaoh lift up thine head, and restore thee unto thy place: and thou shalt deliver Pharaoh’s cup into his hand, after the former manner when thou wast his butler.

<b>14 </b>But think on me when it shall be well with thee, and shew kindness, I pray thee, unto me, and make mention of me unto Pharaoh, and bring me out of this house:

<b>15 </b>For indeed I was stolen away out of the land of the Hebrews: and here also have I done nothing that they should put me into the dungeon.

<b>16 </b>When the chief baker saw that the interpretation was good, he said unto Joseph, I also <i>was</i> in my dream, and, behold, <i>I had</i> three white baskets on my head:

<b>17 </b>And in the uppermost basket <i>there was</i> of all manner of bakemeats for Pharaoh; and the birds did eat them out of the basket upon my head.

<b>18 </b>And Joseph answered and said, This <i>is</i> the interpretation thereof: The three baskets <i>are</i> three days:

<b>19 </b>Yet within three days shall Pharaoh lift up thy head from off thee, and shall hang thee on a tree; and the birds shall eat thy flesh from off thee.

<b>20 </b>¶ And it came to pass the third day, <i>which was</i> Pharaoh’s birthday, that he made a feast unto all his servants: and he lifted up the head of the chief butler and of the chief baker among his servants.

<b>21 </b>And he restored the chief butler unto his butlership again; and he gave the cup into Pharaoh’s hand:

<b>22 </b>But he hanged the chief baker: as Joseph had interpreted to them.

<b>23 </b>Yet did not the chief butler remember Joseph, but forgat him.


--------------------

CHAPTER 41

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass at the end of two full years, that Pharaoh dreamed: and, behold, he stood by the river.

<b>2 </b>And, behold, there came up out of the river seven well favoured kine and fatfleshed; and they fed in a meadow.

<b>3 </b>And, behold, seven other kine came up after them out of the river, ill favoured and leanfleshed; and stood by the <i>other</i> kine upon the brink of the river.

<b>4 </b>And the ill favoured and leanfleshed kine did eat up the seven well favoured and fat kine. So Pharaoh awoke.

<b>5 </b>And he slept and dreamed the second time: and, behold, seven ears of corn came up upon one stalk, rank and good.

<b>6 </b>And, behold, seven thin ears and blasted with the east wind sprung up after them.

<b>7 </b>And the seven thin ears devoured the seven rank and full ears. And Pharaoh awoke, and, behold, <i>it was</i> a dream.

<b>8 </b>And it came to pass in the morning that his spirit was troubled; and he sent and called for all the magicians of Egypt, and all the wise men thereof: and Pharaoh told them his dream; but <i>there was</i> none that could interpret them unto Pharaoh.

<b>9 </b>¶ Then spake the chief butler unto Pharaoh, saying, I do remember my faults this day:

<b>10 </b>Pharaoh was wroth with his servants, and put me in ward in the captain of the guard’s house, <i>both</i> me and the chief baker:

<b>11 </b>And we dreamed a dream in one night, I and he; we dreamed each man according to the interpretation of his dream.

<b>12 </b>And <i>there was</i> there with us a young man, an Hebrew, servant to the captain of the guard; and we told him, and he interpreted to us our dreams; to each man according to his dream he did interpret.

<b>13 </b>And it came to pass, as he interpreted to us, so it was; me he restored unto mine office, and him he hanged.

<b>14 </b>¶ Then Pharaoh sent and called Joseph, and they brought him hastily out of the dungeon: and he shaved <i>himself,</i> and changed his raiment, and came in unto Pharaoh.

<b>15 </b>And Pharaoh said unto Joseph, I have dreamed a dream, and <i>there is</i> none that can interpret it: and I have heard say of thee, <i>that</i> thou canst understand a dream to interpret it.

<b>16 </b>And Joseph answered Pharaoh, saying, <i>It is</i> not in me: God shall give Pharaoh an answer of peace.

<b>17 </b>And Pharaoh said unto Joseph, In my dream, behold, I stood upon the bank of the river:

<b>18 </b>And, behold, there came up out of the river seven kine, fatfleshed and well favoured; and they fed in a meadow:

<b>19 </b>And, behold, seven other kine came up after them, poor and very ill favoured and leanfleshed, such as I never saw in all the land of Egypt for badness:

<b>20 </b>And the lean and the ill favoured kine did eat up the first seven fat kine:

<b>21 </b>And when they had eaten them up, it could not be known that they had eaten them; but they <i>were</i> still ill favoured, as at the beginning. So I awoke.

<b>22 </b>And I saw in my dream, and, behold, seven ears came up in one stalk, full and good:

<b>23 </b>And, behold, seven ears, withered, thin, <i>and</i> blasted with the east wind, sprung up after them:

<b>24 </b>And the thin ears devoured the seven good ears: and I told <i>this</i> unto the magicians; but <i>there was</i> none that could declare <i>it</i> to me.

<b>25 </b>¶ And Joseph said unto Pharaoh, The dream of Pharaoh <i>is</i> one: God hath shewed Pharaoh what he <i>is</i> about to do.

<b>26 </b>The seven good kine <i>are</i> seven years; and the seven good ears <i>are</i> seven years: the dream <i>is</i> one.

<b>27 </b>And the seven thin and ill favoured kine that came up after them <i>are</i> seven years; and the seven empty ears blasted with the east wind shall be seven years of famine.

<b>28 </b>This <i>is</i> the thing which I have spoken unto Pharaoh: What God <i>is</i> about to do he sheweth unto Pharaoh.

<b>29 </b>Behold, there come seven years of great plenty throughout all the land of Egypt:

<b>30 </b>And there shall arise after them seven years of famine; and all the plenty shall be forgotten in the land of Egypt; and the famine shall consume the land;

<b>31 </b>And the plenty shall not be known in the land by reason of that famine following; for it <i>shall be</i> very grievous.

<b>32 </b>And for that the dream was doubled unto Pharaoh twice; <i>it is</i> because the thing <i>is</i> established by God, and God will shortly bring it to pass.

<b>33 </b>Now therefore let Pharaoh look out a man discreet and wise, and set him over the land of Egypt.

<b>34 </b>Let Pharaoh do <i>this,</i> and let him appoint officers over the land, and take up the fifth part of the land of Egypt in the seven plenteous years.

<b>35 </b>And let them gather all the food of those good years that come, and lay up corn under the hand of Pharaoh, and let them keep food in the cities.

<b>36 </b>And that food shall be for store to the land against the seven years of famine, which shall be in the land of Egypt; that the land perish not through the famine.

<b>37 </b>¶ And the thing was good in the eyes of Pharaoh, and in the eyes of all his servants.

<b>38 </b>And Pharaoh said unto his servants, Can we find <i>such a one</i> as this <i>is,</i> a man in whom the Spirit of God <i>is?</i>

<b>39 </b>And Pharaoh said unto Joseph, Forasmuch as God hath shewed thee all this, <i>there is</i> none so discreet and wise as thou <i>art:</i>

<b>40 </b>Thou shalt be over my house, and according unto thy word shall all my people be ruled: only in the throne will I be greater than thou.

<b>41 </b>And Pharaoh said unto Joseph, See, I have set thee over all the land of Egypt.

<b>42 </b>And Pharaoh took off his ring from his hand, and put it upon Joseph’s hand, and arrayed him in vestures of fine linen, and put a gold chain about his neck;

<b>43 </b>And he made him to ride in the second chariot which he had; and they cried before him, Bow the knee: and he made him <i>ruler</i> over all the land of Egypt.

<b>44 </b>And Pharaoh said unto Joseph, I <i>am</i> Pharaoh, and without thee shall no man lift up his hand or foot in all the land of Egypt.

<b>45 </b>And Pharaoh called Joseph’s name Zaphnath-paaneah; and he gave him to wife Asenath the daughter of Poti-pherah priest of On. And Joseph went out over <i>all</i> the land of Egypt.

<b>46 </b>¶ And Joseph <i>was</i> thirty years old when he stood before Pharaoh king of Egypt. And Joseph went out from the presence of Pharaoh, and went throughout all the land of Egypt.

<b>47 </b>And in the seven plenteous years the earth brought forth by handfuls.

<b>48 </b>And he gathered up all the food of the seven years, which were in the land of Egypt, and laid up the food in the cities: the food of the field, which <i>was</i> round about every city, laid he up in the same.

<b>49 </b>And Joseph gathered corn as the sand of the sea, very much, until he left numbering; for <i>it was</i> without number.

<b>50 </b>And unto Joseph were born two sons before the years of famine came, which Asenath the daughter of Poti-pherah priest of On bare unto him.

<b>51 </b>And Joseph called the name of the firstborn Manasseh: For God, <i>said he,</i> hath made me forget all my toil, and all my father’s house.

<b>52 </b>And the name of the second called he Ephraim: For God hath caused me to be fruitful in the land of my affliction.

<b>53 </b>¶ And the seven years of plenteousness, that was in the land of Egypt, were ended.

<b>54 </b>And the seven years of dearth began to come, according as Joseph had said: and the dearth was in all lands; but in all the land of Egypt there was bread.

<b>55 </b>And when all the land of Egypt was famished, the people cried to Pharaoh for bread: and Pharaoh said unto all the Egyptians, Go unto Joseph; what he saith to you, do.

<b>56 </b>And the famine was over all the face of the earth: And Joseph opened all the storehouses, and sold unto the Egyptians; and the famine waxed sore in the land of Egypt.

<b>57 </b>And all countries came into Egypt to Joseph for to buy <i>corn;</i> because that the famine was <i>so</i> sore in all lands.


--------------------

CHAPTER 42

<b>1 </b>Now when Jacob saw that there was corn in Egypt, Jacob said unto his sons, Why do ye look one upon another?

<b>2 </b>And he said, Behold, I have heard that there is corn in Egypt: get you down thither, and buy for us from thence; that we may live, and not die.

<b>3 </b>¶ And Joseph’s ten brethren went down to buy corn in Egypt.

<b>4 </b>But Benjamin, Joseph’s brother, Jacob sent not with his brethren; for he said, Lest peradventure mischief befall him.

<b>5 </b>And the sons of Israel came to buy <i>corn</i> among those that came: for the famine was in the land of Canaan.

<b>6 </b>And Joseph <i>was</i> the governor over the land, <i>and</i> he <i>it was</i> that sold to all the people of the land: and Joseph’s brethren came, and bowed down themselves before him <i>with</i> their faces to the earth.

<b>7 </b>And Joseph saw his brethren, and he knew them, but made himself strange unto them, and spake roughly unto them; and he said unto them, Whence come ye? And they said, From the land of Canaan to buy food.

<b>8 </b>And Joseph knew his brethren, but they knew not him.

<b>9 </b>And Joseph remembered the dreams which he dreamed of them, and said unto them, Ye <i>are</i> spies; to see the nakedness of the land ye are come.

<b>10 </b>And they said unto him, Nay, my lord, but to buy food are thy servants come.

<b>11 </b>We <i>are</i> all one man’s sons; we <i>are</i> true <i>men,</i> thy servants are no spies.

<b>12 </b>And he said unto them, Nay, but to see the nakedness of the land ye are come.

<b>13 </b>And they said, Thy servants <i>are</i> twelve brethren, the sons of one man in the land of Canaan; and, behold, the youngest <i>is</i> this day with our father, and one <i>is</i> not.

<b>14 </b>And Joseph said unto them, That <i>is it</i> that I spake unto you, saying, Ye <i>are</i> spies:

<b>15 </b>Hereby ye shall be proved: By the life of Pharaoh ye shall not go forth hence, except your youngest brother come hither.

<b>16 </b>Send one of you, and let him fetch your brother, and ye shall be kept in prison, that your words may be proved, whether <i>there be any</i> truth in you: or else by the life of Pharaoh surely ye <i>are</i> spies.

<b>17 </b>And he put them all together into ward three days.

<b>18 </b>And Joseph said unto them the third day, This do, and live; <i>for</i> I fear God:

<b>19 </b>If ye <i>be</i> true <i>men,</i> let one of your brethren be bound in the house of your prison: go ye, carry corn for the famine of your houses:

<b>20 </b>But bring your youngest brother unto me; so shall your words be verified, and ye shall not die. And they did so.

<b>21 </b>¶ And they said one to another, We <i>are</i> verily guilty concerning our brother, in that we saw the anguish of his soul, when he besought us, and we would not hear; therefore is this distress come upon us.

<b>22 </b>And Reuben answered them, saying, Spake I not unto you, saying, Do not sin against the child; and ye would not hear? therefore, behold, also his blood is required.

<b>23 </b>And they knew not that Joseph understood <i>them;</i> for he spake unto them by an interpreter.

<b>24 </b>And he turned himself about from them, and wept; and returned to them again, and communed with them, and took from them Simeon, and bound him before their eyes.

<b>25 </b>¶ Then Joseph commanded to fill their sacks with corn, and to restore every man’s money into his sack, and to give them provision for the way: and thus did he unto them.

<b>26 </b>And they laded their asses with the corn, and departed thence.

<b>27 </b>And as one of them opened his sack to give his ass provender in the inn, he espied his money; for, behold, it <i>was</i> in his sack’s mouth.

<b>28 </b>And he said unto his brethren, My money is restored; and, lo, <i>it is</i> even in my sack: and their heart failed <i>them,</i> and they were afraid, saying one to another, What <i>is</i> this <i>that</i> God hath done unto us?

<b>29 </b>¶ And they came unto Jacob their father unto the land of Canaan, and told him all that befell unto them; saying,

<b>30 </b>The man, <i>who is</i> the lord of the land, spake roughly to us, and took us for spies of the country.

<b>31 </b>And we said unto him, We <i>are</i> true <i>men;</i> we are no spies:

<b>32 </b>We <i>be</i> twelve brethren, sons of our father; one <i>is</i> not, and the youngest <i>is</i> this day with our father in the land of Canaan.

<b>33 </b>And the man, the lord of the country, said unto us, Hereby shall I know that ye <i>are</i> true <i>men;</i> leave one of your brethren <i>here</i> with me, and take <i>food for</i> the famine of your households, and be gone:

<b>34 </b>And bring your youngest brother unto me: then shall I know that ye <i>are</i> no spies, but <i>that</i> ye <i>are</i> true <i>men: so</i> will I deliver you your brother, and ye shall traffick in the land.

<b>35 </b>¶ And it came to pass as they emptied their sacks, that, behold, every man’s bundle of money <i>was</i> in his sack: and when <i>both</i> they and their father saw the bundles of money, they were afraid.

<b>36 </b>And Jacob their father said unto them, Me have ye bereaved <i>of my children:</i> Joseph <i>is</i> not, and Simeon <i>is</i> not, and ye will take Benjamin <i>away:</i> all these things are against me.

<b>37 </b>And Reuben spake unto his father, saying, Slay my two sons, if I bring him not to thee: deliver him into my hand, and I will bring him to thee again.

<b>38 </b>And he said, My son shall not go down with you; for his brother is dead, and he is left alone: if mischief befall him by the way in the which ye go, then shall ye bring down my gray hairs with sorrow to the grave.


--------------------

CHAPTER 43

<b>1 </b>And the famine <i>was</i> sore in the land.

<b>2 </b>And it came to pass, when they had eaten up the corn which they had brought out of Egypt, their father said unto them, Go again, buy us a little food.

<b>3 </b>And Judah spake unto him, saying, The man did solemnly protest unto us, saying, Ye shall not see my face, except your brother <i>be</i> with you.

<b>4 </b>If thou wilt send our brother with us, we will go down and buy thee food:

<b>5 </b>But if thou wilt not send <i>him,</i> we will not go down: for the man said unto us, Ye shall not see my face, except your brother <i>be</i> with you.

<b>6 </b>And Israel said, Wherefore dealt ye <i>so</i> ill with me, <i>as</i> to tell the man whether ye had yet a brother?

<b>7 </b>And they said, The man asked us straitly of our state, and of our kindred, saying, <i>Is</i> your father yet alive? have ye <i>another</i> brother? and we told him according to the tenor of these words: could we certainly know that he would say, Bring your brother down?

<b>8 </b>And Judah said unto Israel his father, Send the lad with me, and we will arise and go; that we may live, and not die, both we, and thou, <i>and</i> also our little ones.

<b>9 </b>I will be surety for him; of my hand shalt thou require him: if I bring him not unto thee, and set him before thee, then let me bear the blame for ever:

<b>10 </b>For except we had lingered, surely now we had returned this second time.

<b>11 </b>And their father Israel said unto them, If <i>it must be</i> so now, do this; take of the best fruits in the land in your vessels, and carry down the man a present, a little balm, and a little honey, spices, and myrrh, nuts, and almonds:

<b>12 </b>And take double money in your hand; and the money that was brought again in the mouth of your sacks, carry <i>it</i> again in your hand; peradventure it <i>was</i> an oversight:

<b>13 </b>Take also your brother, and arise, go again unto the man:

<b>14 </b>And God Almighty give you mercy before the man, that he may send away your other brother, and Benjamin. If I be bereaved <i>of my children,</i> I am bereaved.

<b>15 </b>¶ And the men took that present, and they took double money in their hand, and Benjamin; and rose up, and went down to Egypt, and stood before Joseph.

<b>16 </b>And when Joseph saw Benjamin with them, he said to the ruler of his house, Bring <i>these</i> men home, and slay, and make ready; for <i>these</i> men shall dine with me at noon.

<b>17 </b>And the man did as Joseph bade; and the man brought the men into Joseph’s house.

<b>18 </b>And the men were afraid, because they were brought into Joseph’s house; and they said, Because of the money that was returned in our sacks at the first time are we brought in; that he may seek occasion against us, and fall upon us, and take us for bondmen, and our asses.

<b>19 </b>And they came near to the steward of Joseph’s house, and they communed with him at the door of the house,

<b>20 </b>And said, O sir, we came indeed down at the first time to buy food:

<b>21 </b>And it came to pass, when we came to the inn, that we opened our sacks, and, behold, <i>every</i> man’s money <i>was</i> in the mouth of his sack, our money in full weight: and we have brought it again in our hand.

<b>22 </b>And other money have we brought down in our hands to buy food: we cannot tell who put our money in our sacks.

<b>23 </b>And he said, Peace <i>be</i> to you, fear not: your God, and the God of your father, hath given you treasure in your sacks: I had your money. And he brought Simeon out unto them.

<b>24 </b>And the man brought the men into Joseph’s house, and gave <i>them</i> water, and they washed their feet; and he gave their asses provender.

<b>25 </b>And they made ready the present against Joseph came at noon: for they heard that they should eat bread there.

<b>26 </b>¶ And when Joseph came home, they brought him the present which <i>was</i> in their hand into the house, and bowed themselves to him to the earth.

<b>27 </b>And he asked them of <i>their</i> welfare, and said, <i>Is</i> your father well, the old man of whom ye spake? <i>Is</i> he yet alive?

<b>28 </b>And they answered, Thy servant our father <i>is</i> in good health, he <i>is</i> yet alive. And they bowed down their heads, and made obeisance.

<b>29 </b>And he lifted up his eyes, and saw his brother Benjamin, his mother’s son, and said, <i>Is</i> this your younger brother, of whom ye spake unto me? And he said, God be gracious unto thee, my son.

<b>30 </b>And Joseph made haste; for his bowels did yearn upon his brother: and he sought <i>where</i> to weep; and he entered into <i>his</i> chamber, and wept there.

<b>31 </b>And he washed his face, and went out, and refrained himself, and said, Set on bread.

<b>32 </b>And they set on for him by himself, and for them by themselves, and for the Egyptians, which did eat with him, by themselves: because the Egyptians might not eat bread with the Hebrews; for that <i>is</i> an abomination unto the Egyptians.

<b>33 </b>And they sat before him, the firstborn according to his birthright, and the youngest according to his youth: and the men marvelled one at another.

<b>34 </b>And he took <i>and sent</i> messes unto them from before him: but Benjamin’s mess was five times so much as any of theirs. And they drank, and were merry with him.


--------------------

CHAPTER 44

<b>1 </b>And he commanded the steward of his house, saying, Fill the men’s sacks <i>with</i> food, as much as they can carry, and put every man’s money in his sack’s mouth.

<b>2 </b>And put my cup, the silver cup, in the sack’s mouth of the youngest, and his corn money. And he did according to the word that Joseph had spoken.

<b>3 </b>As soon as the morning was light, the men were sent away, they and their asses.

<b>4 </b><i>And</i> when they were gone out of the city, <i>and</i> not <i>yet</i> far off, Joseph said unto his steward, Up, follow after the men; and when thou dost overtake them, say unto them, Wherefore have ye rewarded evil for good?

<b>5 </b><i>Is</i> not this <i>it</i> in which my lord drinketh, and whereby indeed he divineth? ye have done evil in so doing.

<b>6 </b>¶ And he overtook them, and he spake unto them these same words.

<b>7 </b>And they said unto him, Wherefore saith my lord these words? God forbid that thy servants should do according to this thing:

<b>8 </b>Behold, the money, which we found in our sacks’ mouths, we brought again unto thee out of the land of Canaan: how then should we steal out of thy lord’s house silver or gold?

<b>9 </b>With whomsoever of thy servants it be found, both let him die, and we also will be my lord’s bondmen.

<b>10 </b>And he said, Now also <i>let</i> it <i>be</i> according unto your words: he with whom it is found shall be my servant; and ye shall be blameless.

<b>11 </b>Then they speedily took down every man his sack to the ground, and opened every man his sack.

<b>12 </b>And he searched, <i>and</i> began at the eldest, and left at the youngest: and the cup was found in Benjamin’s sack.

<b>13 </b>Then they rent their clothes, and laded every man his ass, and returned to the city.

<b>14 </b>¶ And Judah and his brethren came to Joseph’s house; for he <i>was</i> yet there: and they fell before him on the ground.

<b>15 </b>And Joseph said unto them, What deed <i>is</i> this that ye have done? wot ye not that such a man as I can certainly divine?

<b>16 </b>And Judah said, What shall we say unto my lord? what shall we speak? or how shall we clear ourselves? God hath found out the iniquity of thy servants: behold, we <i>are</i> my lord’s servants, both we, and <i>he</i> also with whom the cup is found.

<b>17 </b>And he said, God forbid that I should do so: <i>but</i> the man in whose hand the cup is found, he shall be my servant; and as for you, get you up in peace unto your father.

<b>18 </b>¶ Then Judah came near unto him, and said, Oh my lord, let thy servant, I pray thee, speak a word in my lord’s ears, and let not thine anger burn against thy servant: for thou <i>art</i> even as Pharaoh.

<b>19 </b>My lord asked his servants, saying, Have ye a father, or a brother?

<b>20 </b>And we said unto my lord, We have a father, an old man, and a child of his old age, a little one; and his brother is dead, and he alone is left of his mother, and his father loveth him.

<b>21 </b>And thou saidst unto thy servants, Bring him down unto me, that I may set mine eyes upon him.

<b>22 </b>And we said unto my lord, The lad cannot leave his father: for <i>if</i> he should leave his father, <i>his father</i> would die.

<b>23 </b>And thou saidst unto thy servants, Except your youngest brother come down with you, ye shall see my face no more.

<b>24 </b>And it came to pass when we came up unto thy servant my father, we told him the words of my lord.

<b>25 </b>And our father said, Go again, <i>and</i> buy us a little food.

<b>26 </b>And we said, We cannot go down: if our youngest brother be with us, then will we go down: for we may not see the man’s face, except our youngest brother <i>be</i> with us.

<b>27 </b>And thy servant my father said unto us, Ye know that my wife bare me two <i>sons:</i>

<b>28 </b>And the one went out from me, and I said, Surely he is torn in pieces; and I saw him not since:

<b>29 </b>And if ye take this also from me, and mischief befall him, ye shall bring down my gray hairs with sorrow to the grave.

<b>30 </b>Now therefore when I come to thy servant my father, and the lad <i>be</i> not with us; seeing that his life is bound up in the lad’s life;

<b>31 </b>It shall come to pass, when he seeth that the lad <i>is</i> not <i>with us,</i> that he will die: and thy servants shall bring down the gray hairs of thy servant our father with sorrow to the grave.

<b>32 </b>For thy servant became surety for the lad unto my father, saying, If I bring him not unto thee, then I shall bear the blame to my father for ever.

<b>33 </b>Now therefore, I pray thee, let thy servant abide instead of the lad a bondman to my lord; and let the lad go up with his brethren.

<b>34 </b>For how shall I go up to my father, and the lad <i>be</i> not with me? lest peradventure I see the evil that shall come on my father.


--------------------

CHAPTER 45

<b>1 </b>Then Joseph could not refrain himself before all them that stood by him; and he cried, Cause every man to go out from me. And there stood no man with him, while Joseph made himself known unto his brethren.

<b>2 </b>And he wept aloud: and the Egyptians and the house of Pharaoh heard.

<b>3 </b>And Joseph said unto his brethren, I <i>am</i> Joseph; doth my father yet live? And his brethren could not answer him; for they were troubled at his presence.

<b>4 </b>And Joseph said unto his brethren, Come near to me, I pray you. And they came near. And he said, I <i>am</i> Joseph your brother, whom ye sold into Egypt.

<b>5 </b>Now therefore be not grieved, nor angry with yourselves, that ye sold me hither: for God did send me before you to preserve life.

<b>6 </b>For these two years <i>hath</i> the famine <i>been</i> in the land: and yet <i>there are</i> five years, in the which <i>there shall</i> neither <i>be</i> earing nor harvest.

<b>7 </b>And God sent me before you to preserve you a posterity in the earth, and to save your lives by a great deliverance.

<b>8 </b>So now <i>it was</i> not you <i>that</i> sent me hither, but God: and he hath made me a father to Pharaoh, and lord of all his house, and a ruler throughout all the land of Egypt.

<b>9 </b>Haste ye, and go up to my father, and say unto him, Thus saith thy son Joseph, God hath made me lord of all Egypt: come down unto me, tarry not:

<b>10 </b>And thou shalt dwell in the land of Goshen, and thou shalt be near unto me, thou, and thy children, and thy children’s children, and thy flocks, and thy herds, and all that thou hast:

<b>11 </b>And there will I nourish thee; for yet <i>there are</i> five years of famine; lest thou, and thy household, and all that thou hast, come to poverty.

<b>12 </b>And, behold, your eyes see, and the eyes of my brother Benjamin, that <i>it is</i> my mouth that speaketh unto you.

<b>13 </b>And ye shall tell my father of all my glory in Egypt, and of all that ye have seen; and ye shall haste and bring down my father hither.

<b>14 </b>And he fell upon his brother Benjamin’s neck, and wept; and Benjamin wept upon his neck.

<b>15 </b>Moreover he kissed all his brethren, and wept upon them: and after that his brethren talked with him.

<b>16 </b>¶ And the fame thereof was heard in Pharaoh’s house, saying, Joseph’s brethren are come: and it pleased Pharaoh well, and his servants.

<b>17 </b>And Pharaoh said unto Joseph, Say unto thy brethren, This do ye; lade your beasts, and go, get you unto the land of Canaan;

<b>18 </b>And take your father and your households, and come unto me: and I will give you the good of the land of Egypt, and ye shall eat the fat of the land.

<b>19 </b>Now thou art commanded, this do ye; take you wagons out of the land of Egypt for your little ones, and for your wives, and bring your father, and come.

<b>20 </b>Also regard not your stuff; for the good of all the land of Egypt <i>is</i> yours.

<b>21 </b>And the children of Israel did so: and Joseph gave them wagons, according to the commandment of Pharaoh, and gave them provision for the way.

<b>22 </b>To all of them he gave each man changes of raiment; but to Benjamin he gave three hundred <i>pieces</i> of silver, and five changes of raiment.

<b>23 </b>And to his father he sent after this <i>manner;</i> ten asses laden with the good things of Egypt, and ten she asses laden with corn and bread and meat for his father by the way.

<b>24 </b>So he sent his brethren away, and they departed: and he said unto them, See that ye fall not out by the way.

<b>25 </b>¶ And they went up out of Egypt, and came into the land of Canaan unto Jacob their father,

<b>26 </b>And told him, saying, Joseph <i>is</i> yet alive, and he <i>is</i> governor over all the land of Egypt. And Jacob’s heart fainted, for he believed them not.

<b>27 </b>And they told him all the words of Joseph, which he had said unto them: and when he saw the wagons which Joseph had sent to carry him, the spirit of Jacob their father revived:

<b>28 </b>And Israel said, <i>It is</i> enough; Joseph my son <i>is</i> yet alive: I will go and see him before I die.


--------------------

CHAPTER 46

<b>1 </b>And Israel took his journey with all that he had, and came to Beer-sheba, and offered sacrifices unto the God of his father Isaac.

<b>2 </b>And God spake unto Israel in the visions of the night, and said, Jacob, Jacob. And he said, Here <i>am</i> I.

<b>3 </b>And he said, I <i>am</i> God, the God of thy father: fear not to go down into Egypt; for I will there make of thee a great nation:

<b>4 </b>I will go down with thee into Egypt; and I will also surely bring thee up <i>again:</i> and Joseph shall put his hand upon thine eyes.

<b>5 </b>And Jacob rose up from Beer-sheba: and the sons of Israel carried Jacob their father, and their little ones, and their wives, in the wagons which Pharaoh had sent to carry him.

<b>6 </b>And they took their cattle, and their goods, which they had gotten in the land of Canaan, and came into Egypt, Jacob, and all his seed with him:

<b>7 </b>His sons, and his sons’ sons with him, his daughters, and his sons’ daughters, and all his seed brought he with him into Egypt.

<b>8 </b>¶ And these <i>are</i> the names of the children of Israel, which came into Egypt, Jacob and his sons: Reuben, Jacob’s firstborn.

<b>9 </b>And the sons of Reuben; Hanoch, and Phallu, and Hezron, and Carmi.

<b>10 </b>¶ And the sons of Simeon; Jemuel, and Jamin, and Ohad, and Jachin, and Zohar, and Shaul the son of a Canaanitish woman.

<b>11 </b>¶ And the sons of Levi; Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.

<b>12 </b>¶ And the sons of Judah; Er, and Onan, and Shelah, and Pharez, and Zerah: but Er and Onan died in the land of Canaan. And the sons of Pharez were Hezron and Hamul.

<b>13 </b>¶ And the sons of Issachar; Tola, and Phuvah, and Job, and Shimron.

<b>14 </b>¶ And the sons of Zebulun; Sered, and Elon, and Jahleel.

<b>15 </b>These <i>be</i> the sons of Leah, which she bare unto Jacob in Padan-aram, with his daughter Dinah: all the souls of his sons and his daughters <i>were</i> thirty and three.

<b>16 </b>¶ And the sons of Gad; Ziphion, and Haggi, Shuni, and Ezbon, Eri, and Arodi, and Areli.

<b>17 </b>¶ And the sons of Asher; Jimnah, and Ishuah, and Isui, and Beriah, and Serah their sister: and the sons of Beriah; Heber, and Malchiel.

<b>18 </b>These <i>are</i> the sons of Zilpah, whom Laban gave to Leah his daughter, and these she bare unto Jacob, <i>even</i> sixteen souls.

<b>19 </b>The sons of Rachel Jacob’s wife; Joseph, and Benjamin.

<b>20 </b>¶ And unto Joseph in the land of Egypt were born Manasseh and Ephraim, which Asenath the daughter of Poti-pherah priest of On bare unto him.

<b>21 </b>¶ And the sons of Benjamin <i>were</i> Belah, and Becher, and Ashbel, Gera, and Naaman, Ehi, and Rosh, Muppim, and Huppim, and Ard.

<b>22 </b>These <i>are</i> the sons of Rachel, which were born to Jacob: all the souls <i>were</i> fourteen.

<b>23 </b>¶ And the sons of Dan; Hushim.

<b>24 </b>¶ And the sons of Naphtali; Jahzeel, and Guni, and Jezer, and Shillem.

<b>25 </b>These <i>are</i> the sons of Bilhah, which Laban gave unto Rachel his daughter, and she bare these unto Jacob: all the souls <i>were</i> seven.

<b>26 </b>All the souls that came with Jacob into Egypt, which came out of his loins, besides Jacob’s sons’ wives, all the souls <i>were</i> threescore and six;

<b>27 </b>And the sons of Joseph, which were born him in Egypt, <i>were</i> two souls: all the souls of the house of Jacob, which came into Egypt, <i>were</i> threescore and ten.

<b>28 </b>¶ And he sent Judah before him unto Joseph, to direct his face unto Goshen; and they came into the land of Goshen.

<b>29 </b>And Joseph made ready his chariot, and went up to meet Israel his father, to Goshen, and presented himself unto him; and he fell on his neck, and wept on his neck a good while.

<b>30 </b>And Israel said unto Joseph, Now let me die, since I have seen thy face, because thou <i>art</i> yet alive.

<b>31 </b>And Joseph said unto his brethren, and unto his father’s house, I will go up, and shew Pharaoh, and say unto him, My brethren, and my father’s house, which <i>were</i> in the land of Canaan, are come unto me;

<b>32 </b>And the men <i>are</i> shepherds, for their trade hath been to feed cattle; and they have brought their flocks, and their herds, and all that they have.

<b>33 </b>And it shall come to pass, when Pharaoh shall call you, and shall say, What <i>is</i> your occupation?

<b>34 </b>That ye shall say, Thy servants’ trade hath been about cattle from our youth even until now, both we, <i>and</i> also our fathers: that ye may dwell in the land of Goshen; for every shepherd <i>is</i> an abomination unto the Egyptians.


--------------------

CHAPTER 47

<b>1 </b>Then Joseph came and told Pharaoh, and said, My father and my brethren, and their flocks, and their herds, and all that they have, are come out of the land of Canaan; and, behold, they <i>are</i> in the land of Goshen.

<b>2 </b>And he took some of his brethren, <i>even</i> five men, and presented them unto Pharaoh.

<b>3 </b>And Pharaoh said unto his brethren, What <i>is</i> your occupation? And they said unto Pharaoh, Thy servants <i>are</i> shepherds, both we, <i>and</i> also our fathers.

<b>4 </b>They said moreover unto Pharaoh, For to sojourn in the land are we come; for thy servants have no pasture for their flocks; for the famine <i>is</i> sore in the land of Canaan: now therefore, we pray thee, let thy servants dwell in the land of Goshen.

<b>5 </b>And Pharaoh spake unto Joseph, saying, Thy father and thy brethren are come unto thee:

<b>6 </b>The land of Egypt <i>is</i> before thee; in the best of the land make thy father and brethren to dwell; in the land of Goshen let them dwell: and if thou knowest <i>any</i> men of activity among them, then make them rulers over my cattle.

<b>7 </b>And Joseph brought in Jacob his father, and set him before Pharaoh: and Jacob blessed Pharaoh.

<b>8 </b>And Pharaoh said unto Jacob, How old <i>art</i> thou?

<b>9 </b>And Jacob said unto Pharaoh, The days of the years of my pilgrimage <i>are</i> an hundred and thirty years: few and evil have the days of the years of my life been, and have not attained unto the days of the years of the life of my fathers in the days of their pilgrimage.

<b>10 </b>And Jacob blessed Pharaoh, and went out from before Pharaoh.

<b>11 </b>¶ And Joseph placed his father and his brethren, and gave them a possession in the land of Egypt, in the best of the land, in the land of Rameses, as Pharaoh had commanded.

<b>12 </b>And Joseph nourished his father, and his brethren, and all his father’s household, with bread, according to <i>their</i> families.

<b>13 </b>¶ And <i>there was</i> no bread in all the land; for the famine <i>was</i> very sore, so that the land of Egypt and <i>all</i> the land of Canaan fainted by reason of the famine.

<b>14 </b>And Joseph gathered up all the money that was found in the land of Egypt, and in the land of Canaan, for the corn which they bought: and Joseph brought the money into Pharaoh’s house.

<b>15 </b>And when money failed in the land of Egypt, and in the land of Canaan, all the Egyptians came unto Joseph, and said, Give us bread: for why should we die in thy presence? for the money faileth.

<b>16 </b>And Joseph said, Give your cattle; and I will give you for your cattle, if money fail.

<b>17 </b>And they brought their cattle unto Joseph: and Joseph gave them bread <i>in exchange</i> for horses, and for the flocks, and for the cattle of the herds, and for the asses: and he fed them with bread for all their cattle for that year.

<b>18 </b>When that year was ended, they came unto him the second year, and said unto him, We will not hide <i>it</i> from my lord, how that our money is spent; my lord also hath our herds of cattle; there is not ought left in the sight of my lord, but our bodies, and our lands:

<b>19 </b>Wherefore shall we die before thine eyes, both we and our land? buy us and our land for bread, and we and our land will be servants unto Pharaoh: and give <i>us</i> seed, that we may live, and not die, that the land be not desolate.

<b>20 </b>And Joseph bought all the land of Egypt for Pharaoh; for the Egyptians sold every man his field, because the famine prevailed over them: so the land became Pharaoh’s.

<b>21 </b>And as for the people, he removed them to cities from <i>one</i> end of the borders of Egypt even to the <i>other</i> end thereof.

<b>22 </b>Only the land of the priests bought he not; for the priests had a portion <i>assigned them</i> of Pharaoh, and did eat their portion which Pharaoh gave them: wherefore they sold not their lands.

<b>23 </b>Then Joseph said unto the people, Behold, I have bought you this day and your land for Pharaoh: lo, <i>here is</i> seed for you, and ye shall sow the land.

<b>24 </b>And it shall come to pass in the increase, that ye shall give the fifth <i>part</i> unto Pharaoh, and four parts shall be your own, for seed of the field, and for your food, and for them of your households, and for food for your little ones.

<b>25 </b>And they said, Thou hast saved our lives: let us find grace in the sight of my lord, and we will be Pharaoh’s servants.

<b>26 </b>And Joseph made it a law over the land of Egypt unto this day, <i>that</i> Pharaoh should have the fifth <i>part;</i> except the land of the priests only, <i>which</i> became not Pharaoh’s.

<b>27 </b>¶ And Israel dwelt in the land of Egypt, in the country of Goshen; and they had possessions therein, and grew, and multiplied exceedingly.

<b>28 </b>And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt seventeen years: so the whole age of Jacob was an hundred forty and seven years.

<b>29 </b>And the time drew nigh that Israel must die: and he called his son Joseph, and said unto him, If now I have found grace in thy sight, put, I pray thee, thy hand under my thigh, and deal kindly and truly with me; bury me not, I pray thee, in Egypt:

<b>30 </b>But I will lie with my fathers, and thou shalt carry me out of Egypt, and bury me in their buryingplace. And he said, I will do as thou hast said.

<b>31 </b>And he said, Swear unto me. And he sware unto him. And Israel bowed himself upon the bed’s head.


--------------------

CHAPTER 48

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass after these things, that <i>one</i> told Joseph, Behold, thy father <i>is</i> sick: and he took with him his two sons, Manasseh and Ephraim.

<b>2 </b>And <i>one</i> told Jacob, and said, Behold, thy son Joseph cometh unto thee: and Israel strengthened himself, and sat upon the bed.

<b>3 </b>And Jacob said unto Joseph, God Almighty appeared unto me at Luz in the land of Canaan, and blessed me,

<b>4 </b>And said unto me, Behold, I will make thee fruitful, and multiply thee, and I will make of thee a multitude of people; and will give this land to thy seed after thee <i>for</i> an everlasting possession.

<b>5 </b>¶ And now thy two sons, Ephraim and Manasseh, which were born unto thee in the land of Egypt before I came unto thee into Egypt, <i>are</i> mine; as Reuben and Simeon, they shall be mine.

<b>6 </b>And thy issue, which thou begettest after them, shall be thine, <i>and</i> shall be called after the name of their brethren in their inheritance.

<b>7 </b>And as for me, when I came from Padan, Rachel died by me in the land of Canaan in the way, when yet <i>there was</i> but a little way to come unto Ephrath: and I buried her there in the way of Ephrath; the same <i>is</i> Beth-lehem.

<b>8 </b>And Israel beheld Joseph’s sons, and said, Who <i>are</i> these?

<b>9 </b>And Joseph said unto his father, They <i>are</i> my sons, whom God hath given me in this <i>place.</i> And he said, Bring them, I pray thee, unto me, and I will bless them.

<b>10 </b>Now the eyes of Israel were dim for age, <i>so that</i> he could not see. And he brought them near unto him; and he kissed them, and embraced them.

<b>11 </b>And Israel said unto Joseph, I had not thought to see thy face: and, lo, God hath shewed me also thy seed.

<b>12 </b>And Joseph brought them out from between his knees, and he bowed himself with his face to the earth.

<b>13 </b>And Joseph took them both, Ephraim in his right hand toward Israel’s left hand, and Manasseh in his left hand toward Israel’s right hand, and brought <i>them</i> near unto him.

<b>14 </b>And Israel stretched out his right hand, and laid <i>it</i> upon Ephraim’s head, who <i>was</i> the younger, and his left hand upon Manasseh’s head, guiding his hands wittingly; for Manasseh <i>was</i> the firstborn.

<b>15 </b>¶ And he blessed Joseph, and said, God, before whom my fathers Abraham and Isaac did walk, the God which fed me all my life long unto this day,

<b>16 </b>The Angel which redeemed me from all evil, bless the lads; and let my name be named on them, and the name of my fathers Abraham and Isaac; and let them grow into a multitude in the midst of the earth.

<b>17 </b>And when Joseph saw that his father laid his right hand upon the head of Ephraim, it displeased him: and he held up his father’s hand, to remove it from Ephraim’s head unto Manasseh’s head.

<b>18 </b>And Joseph said unto his father, Not so, my father: for this <i>is</i> the firstborn; put thy right hand upon his head.

<b>19 </b>And his father refused, and said, I know <i>it,</i> my son, I know <i>it:</i> he also shall become a people, and he also shall be great: but truly his younger brother shall be greater than he, and his seed shall become a multitude of nations.

<b>20 </b>And he blessed them that day, saying, In thee shall Israel bless, saying, God make thee as Ephraim and as Manasseh: and he set Ephraim before Manasseh.

<b>21 </b>And Israel said unto Joseph, Behold, I die: but God shall be with you, and bring you again unto the land of your fathers.

<b>22 </b>Moreover I have given to thee one portion above thy brethren, which I took out of the hand of the Amorite with my sword and with my bow.


--------------------

CHAPTER 49

<b>1 </b>And Jacob called unto his sons, and said, Gather yourselves together, that I may tell you <i>that</i> which shall befall you in the last days.

<b>2 </b>Gather yourselves together, and hear, ye sons of Jacob; and hearken unto Israel your father.

<b>3 </b>¶ Reuben, thou <i>art</i> my firstborn, my might, and the beginning of my strength, the excellency of dignity, and the excellency of power:

<b>4 </b>Unstable as water, thou shalt not excel; because thou wentest up to thy father’s bed; then defiledst thou <i>it:</i> he went up to my couch.

<b>5 </b>¶ Simeon and Levi <i>are</i> brethren; instruments of cruelty <i>are in</i> their habitations.

<b>6 </b>O my soul, come not thou into their secret; unto their assembly, mine honour, be not thou united: for in their anger they slew a man, and in their selfwill they digged down a wall.

<b>7 </b>Cursed <i>be</i> their anger, for <i>it was</i> fierce; and their wrath, for it was cruel: I will divide them in Jacob, and scatter them in Israel.

<b>8 </b>¶ Judah, thou <i>art he</i> whom thy brethren shall praise: thy hand <i>shall be</i> in the neck of thine enemies; thy father’s children shall bow down before thee.

<b>9 </b>Judah <i>is</i> a lion’s whelp: from the prey, my son, thou art gone up: he stooped down, he couched as a lion, and as an old lion; who shall rouse him up?

<b>10 </b>The sceptre shall not depart from Judah, nor a lawgiver from between his feet, until Shiloh come; and unto him <i>shall</i> the gathering of the people <i>be.</i>

<b>11 </b>Binding his foal unto the vine, and his ass’s colt unto the choice vine; he washed his garments in wine, and his clothes in the blood of grapes:

<b>12 </b>His eyes <i>shall be</i> red with wine, and his teeth white with milk.

<b>13 </b>¶ Zebulun shall dwell at the haven of the sea; and he <i>shall be</i> for an haven of ships; and his border <i>shall be</i> unto Zidon.

<b>14 </b>¶ Issachar <i>is</i> a strong ass couching down between two burdens:

<b>15 </b>And he saw that rest <i>was</i> good, and the land that <i>it was</i> pleasant; and bowed his shoulder to bear, and became a servant unto tribute.

<b>16 </b>¶ Dan shall judge his people, as one of the tribes of Israel.

<b>17 </b>Dan shall be a serpent by the way, an adder in the path, that biteth the horse heels, so that his rider shall fall backward.

<b>18 </b>I have waited for thy salvation, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>19 </b>¶ Gad, a troop shall overcome him: but he shall overcome at the last.

<b>20 </b>¶ Out of Asher his bread <i>shall be</i> fat, and he shall yield royal dainties.

<b>21 </b>¶ Naphtali <i>is</i> a hind let loose: he giveth goodly words.

<b>22 </b>¶ Joseph <i>is</i> a fruitful bough, <i>even</i> a fruitful bough by a well; <i>whose</i> branches run over the wall:

<b>23 </b>The archers have sorely grieved him, and shot <i>at him,</i> and hated him:

<b>24 </b>But his bow abode in strength, and the arms of his hands were made strong by the hands of the mighty <i>God</i> of Jacob; (from thence <i>is</i> the shepherd, the stone of Israel:)

<b>25 </b><i>Even</i> by the God of thy father, who shall help thee; and by the Almighty, who shall bless thee with blessings of heaven above, blessings of the deep that lieth under, blessings of the breasts, and of the womb:

<b>26 </b>The blessings of thy father have prevailed above the blessings of my progenitors unto the utmost bound of the everlasting hills: they shall be on the head of Joseph, and on the crown of the head of him that was separate from his brethren.

<b>27 </b>¶ Benjamin shall ravin <i>as</i> a wolf: in the morning he shall devour the prey, and at night he shall divide the spoil.

<b>28 </b>¶ All these <i>are</i> the twelve tribes of Israel: and this <i>is it</i> that their father spake unto them, and blessed them; every one according to his blessing he blessed them.

<b>29 </b>And he charged them, and said unto them, I am to be gathered unto my people: bury me with my fathers in the cave that <i>is</i> in the field of Ephron the Hittite,

<b>30 </b>In the cave that <i>is</i> in the field of Machpelah, which <i>is</i> before Mamre, in the land of Canaan, which Abraham bought with the field of Ephron the Hittite for a possession of a buryingplace.

<b>31 </b>There they buried Abraham and Sarah his wife; there they buried Isaac and Rebekah his wife; and there I buried Leah.

<b>32 </b>The purchase of the field and of the cave that <i>is</i> therein <i>was</i> from the children of Heth.

<b>33 </b>And when Jacob had made an end of commanding his sons, he gathered up his feet into the bed, and yielded up the ghost, and was gathered unto his people.


--------------------

CHAPTER 50

<b>1 </b>And Joseph fell upon his father’s face, and wept upon him, and kissed him.

<b>2 </b>And Joseph commanded his servants the physicians to embalm his father: and the physicians embalmed Israel.

<b>3 </b>And forty days were fulfilled for him; for so are fulfilled the days of those which are embalmed: and the Egyptians mourned for him threescore and ten days.

<b>4 </b>And when the days of his mourning were past, Joseph spake unto the house of Pharaoh, saying, If now I have found grace in your eyes, speak, I pray you, in the ears of Pharaoh, saying,

<b>5 </b>My father made me swear, saying, Lo, I die: in my grave which I have digged for me in the land of Canaan, there shalt thou bury me. Now therefore let me go up, I pray thee, and bury my father, and I will come again.

<b>6 </b>And Pharaoh said, Go up, and bury thy father, according as he made thee swear.

<b>7 </b>¶ And Joseph went up to bury his father: and with him went up all the servants of Pharaoh, the elders of his house, and all the elders of the land of Egypt,

<b>8 </b>And all the house of Joseph, and his brethren, and his father’s house: only their little ones, and their flocks, and their herds, they left in the land of Goshen.

<b>9 </b>And there went up with him both chariots and horsemen: and it was a very great company.

<b>10 </b>And they came to the threshingfloor of Atad, which <i>is</i> beyond Jordan, and there they mourned with a great and very sore lamentation: and he made a mourning for his father seven days.

<b>11 </b>And when the inhabitants of the land, the Canaanites, saw the mourning in the floor of Atad, they said, This <i>is</i> a grievous mourning to the Egyptians: wherefore the name of it was called Abel-mizraim, which <i>is</i> beyond Jordan.

<b>12 </b>And his sons did unto him according as he commanded them:

<b>13 </b>For his sons carried him into the land of Canaan, and buried him in the cave of the field of Machpelah, which Abraham bought with the field for a possession of a buryingplace of Ephron the Hittite, before Mamre.

<b>14 </b>¶ And Joseph returned into Egypt, he, and his brethren, and all that went up with him to bury his father, after he had buried his father.

<b>15 </b>¶ And when Joseph’s brethren saw that their father was dead, they said, Joseph will peradventure hate us, and will certainly requite us all the evil which we did unto him.

<b>16 </b>And they sent a messenger unto Joseph, saying, Thy father did command before he died, saying,

<b>17 </b>So shall ye say unto Joseph, Forgive, I pray thee now, the trespass of thy brethren, and their sin; for they did unto thee evil: and now, we pray thee, forgive the trespass of the servants of the God of thy father. And Joseph wept when they spake unto him.

<b>18 </b>And his brethren also went and fell down before his face; and they said, Behold, we <i>be</i> thy servants.

<b>19 </b>And Joseph said unto them, Fear not: for <i>am</i> I in the place of God?

<b>20 </b>But as for you, ye thought evil against me; <i>but</i> God meant it unto good, to bring to pass, as <i>it is</i> this day, to save much people alive.

<b>21 </b>Now therefore fear ye not: I will nourish you, and your little ones. And he comforted them, and spake kindly unto them.

<b>22 </b>¶ And Joseph dwelt in Egypt, he, and his father’s house: and Joseph lived an hundred and ten years.

<b>23 </b>And Joseph saw Ephraim’s children of the third <i>generation:</i> the children also of Machir the son of Manasseh were brought up upon Joseph’s knees.

<b>24 </b>And Joseph said unto his brethren, I die: and God will surely visit you, and bring you out of this land unto the land which he sware to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob.

<b>25 </b>And Joseph took an oath of the children of Israel, saying, God will surely visit you, and ye shall carry up my bones from hence.

<b>26 </b>So Joseph died, <i>being</i> an hundred and ten years old: and they embalmed him, and he was put in a coffin in Egypt.


--------------------

<small>The Second Book of Moses </small><small>Called </small>Exodus

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>Now these <i>are</i> the names of the children of Israel, which came into Egypt; every man and his household came with Jacob.

<b>2 </b>Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah,

<b>3 </b>Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin,

<b>4 </b>Dan, and Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.

<b>5 </b>And all the souls that came out of the loins of Jacob were seventy souls: for Joseph was in Egypt <i>already.</i>

<b>6 </b>And Joseph died, and all his brethren, and all that generation.

<b>7 </b>¶ And the children of Israel were fruitful, and increased abundantly, and multiplied, and waxed exceeding mighty; and the land was filled with them.

<b>8 </b>Now there arose up a new king over Egypt, which knew not Joseph.

<b>9 </b>And he said unto his people, Behold, the people of the children of Israel <i>are</i> more and mightier than we:

<b>10 </b>Come on, let us deal wisely with them; lest they multiply, and it come to pass, that, when there falleth out any war, they join also unto our enemies, and fight against us, and <i>so</i> get them up out of the land.

<b>11 </b>Therefore they did set over them taskmasters to afflict them with their burdens. And they built for Pharaoh treasure cities, Pithom and Raamses.

<b>12 </b>But the more they afflicted them, the more they multiplied and grew. And they were grieved because of the children of Israel.

<b>13 </b>And the Egyptians made the children of Israel to serve with rigour:

<b>14 </b>And they made their lives bitter with hard bondage, in mortar, and in brick, and in all manner of service in the field: all their service, wherein they made them serve, <i>was</i> with rigour.

<b>15 </b>¶ And the king of Egypt spake to the Hebrew midwives, of which the name of the one <i>was</i> Shiphrah, and the name of the other Puah:

<b>16 </b>And he said, When ye do the office of a midwife to the Hebrew women, and see <i>them</i> upon the stools; if it <i>be</i> a son, then ye shall kill him: but if it <i>be</i> a daughter, then she shall live.

<b>17 </b>But the midwives feared God, and did not as the king of Egypt commanded them, but saved the men children alive.

<b>18 </b>And the king of Egypt called for the midwives, and said unto them, Why have ye done this thing, and have saved the men children alive?

<b>19 </b>And the midwives said unto Pharaoh, Because the Hebrew women <i>are</i> not as the Egyptian women; for they <i>are</i> lively, and are delivered ere the midwives come in unto them.

<b>20 </b>Therefore God dealt well with the midwives: and the people multiplied, and waxed very mighty.

<b>21 </b>And it came to pass, because the midwives feared God, that he made them houses.

<b>22 </b>And Pharaoh charged all his people, saying, Every son that is born ye shall cast into the river, and every daughter ye shall save alive.


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>And there went a man of the house of Levi, and took <i>to wife</i> a daughter of Levi.

<b>2 </b>And the woman conceived, and bare a son: and when she saw him that he <i>was a</i> goodly <i>child,</i> she hid him three months.

<b>3 </b>And when she could not longer hide him, she took for him an ark of bulrushes, and daubed it with slime and with pitch, and put the child therein; and she laid <i>it</i> in the flags by the river’s brink.

<b>4 </b>And his sister stood afar off, to wit what would be done to him.

<b>5 </b>¶ And the daughter of Pharaoh came down to wash <i>herself</i> at the river; and her maidens walked along by the river’s side; and when she saw the ark among the flags, she sent her maid to fetch it.

<b>6 </b>And when she had opened <i>it,</i> she saw the child: and, behold, the babe wept. And she had compassion on him, and said, This <i>is one</i> of the Hebrews’ children.

<b>7 </b>Then said his sister to Pharaoh’s daughter, Shall I go and call to thee a nurse of the Hebrew women, that she may nurse the child for thee?

<b>8 </b>And Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, Go. And the maid went and called the child’s mother.

<b>9 </b>And Pharaoh’s daughter said unto her, Take this child away, and nurse it for me, and I will give <i>thee</i> thy wages. And the woman took the child, and nursed it.

<b>10 </b>And the child grew, and she brought him unto Pharaoh’s daughter, and he became her son. And she called his name Moses: and she said, Because I drew him out of the water.

<b>11 </b>¶ And it came to pass in those days, when Moses was grown, that he went out unto his brethren, and looked on their burdens: and he spied an Egyptian smiting an Hebrew, one of his brethren.

<b>12 </b>And he looked this way and that way, and when he saw that <i>there was</i> no man, he slew the Egyptian, and hid him in the sand.

<b>13 </b>And when he went out the second day, behold, two men of the Hebrews strove together: and he said to him that did the wrong, Wherefore smitest thou thy fellow?

<b>14 </b>And he said, Who made thee a prince and a judge over us? intendest thou to kill me, as thou killedst the Egyptian? And Moses feared, and said, Surely this thing is known.

<b>15 </b>Now when Pharaoh heard this thing, he sought to slay Moses. But Moses fled from the face of Pharaoh, and dwelt in the land of Midian: and he sat down by a well.

<b>16 </b>Now the priest of Midian had seven daughters: and they came and drew <i>water,</i> and filled the troughs to water their father’s flock.

<b>17 </b>And the shepherds came and drove them away: but Moses stood up and helped them, and watered their flock.

<b>18 </b>And when they came to Reuel their father, he said, How <i>is it that</i> ye are come so soon to day?

<b>19 </b>And they said, An Egyptian delivered us out of the hand of the shepherds, and also drew <i>water</i> enough for us, and watered the flock.

<b>20 </b>And he said unto his daughters, And where <i>is</i> he? why <i>is</i> it <i>that</i> ye have left the man? call him, that he may eat bread.

<b>21 </b>And Moses was content to dwell with the man: and he gave Moses Zipporah his daughter.

<b>22 </b>And she bare <i>him</i> a son, and he called his name Gershom: for he said, I have been a stranger in a strange land.

<b>23 </b>¶ And it came to pass in process of time, that the king of Egypt died: and the children of Israel sighed by reason of the bondage, and they cried, and their cry came up unto God by reason of the bondage.

<b>24 </b>And God heard their groaning, and God remembered his covenant with Abraham, with Isaac, and with Jacob.

<b>25 </b>And God looked upon the children of Israel, and God had respect unto <i>them.</i>


--------------------

CHAPTER 3

<b>1 </b>Now Moses kept the flock of Jethro his father in law, the priest of Midian: and he led the flock to the backside of the desert, and came to the mountain of God, <i>even</i> to Horeb.

<b>2 </b>And the angel of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> appeared unto him in a flame of fire out of the midst of a bush: and he looked, and, behold, the bush burned with fire, and the bush <i>was</i> not consumed.

<b>3 </b>And Moses said, I will now turn aside, and see this great sight, why the bush is not burnt.

<b>4 </b>And when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> saw that he turned aside to see, God called unto him out of the midst of the bush, and said, Moses, Moses. And he said, Here <i>am</i> I.

<b>5 </b>And he said, Draw not nigh hither: put off thy shoes from off thy feet, for the place whereon thou standest <i>is</i> holy ground.

<b>6 </b>Moreover he said, I <i>am</i> the God of thy father, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob. And Moses hid his face; for he was afraid to look upon God.

<b>7 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said, I have surely seen the affliction of my people which <i>are</i> in Egypt, and have heard their cry by reason of their taskmasters; for I know their sorrows;

<b>8 </b>And I am come down to deliver them out of the hand of the Egyptians, and to bring them up out of that land unto a good land and a large, unto a land flowing with milk and honey; unto the place of the Canaanites, and the Hittites, and the Amorites, and the Perizzites, and the Hivites, and the Jebusites.

<b>9 </b>Now therefore, behold, the cry of the children of Israel is come unto me: and I have also seen the oppression wherewith the Egyptians oppress them.

<b>10 </b>Come now therefore, and I will send thee unto Pharaoh, that thou mayest bring forth my people the children of Israel out of Egypt.

<b>11 </b>¶ And Moses said unto God, Who <i>am</i> I, that I should go unto Pharaoh, and that I should bring forth the children of Israel out of Egypt?

<b>12 </b>And he said, Certainly I will be with thee; and this <i>shall be</i> a token unto thee, that I have sent thee: When thou hast brought forth the people out of Egypt, ye shall serve God upon this mountain.

<b>13 </b>And Moses said unto God, Behold, <i>when</i> I come unto the children of Israel, and shall say unto them, The God of your fathers hath sent me unto you; and they shall say to me, What <i>is</i> his name? what shall I say unto them?

<b>14 </b>And God said unto Moses, <span class="uppercase">I Am That I Am</span>: and he said, Thus shalt thou say unto the children of Israel, <span class="uppercase">I Am</span> hath sent me unto you.

<b>15 </b>And God said moreover unto Moses, Thus shalt thou say unto the children of Israel, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, hath sent me unto you: this <i>is</i> my name for ever, and this <i>is</i> my memorial unto all generations.

<b>16 </b>Go, and gather the elders of Israel together, and say unto them, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, of Isaac, and of Jacob, appeared unto me, saying, I have surely visited you, and <i>seen</i> that which is done to you in Egypt:

<b>17 </b>And I have said, I will bring you up out of the affliction of Egypt unto the land of the Canaanites, and the Hittites, and the Amorites, and the Perizzites, and the Hivites, and the Jebusites, unto a land flowing with milk and honey.

<b>18 </b>And they shall hearken to thy voice: and thou shalt come, thou and the elders of Israel, unto the king of Egypt, and ye shall say unto him, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of the Hebrews hath met with us: and now let us go, we beseech thee, three days’ journey into the wilderness, that we may sacrifice to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God.

<b>19 </b>¶ And I am sure that the king of Egypt will not let you go, no, not by a mighty hand.

<b>20 </b>And I will stretch out my hand, and smite Egypt with all my wonders which I will do in the midst thereof: and after that he will let you go.

<b>21 </b>And I will give this people favour in the sight of the Egyptians: and it shall come to pass, that, when ye go, ye shall not go empty:

<b>22 </b>But every woman shall borrow of her neighbour, and of her that sojourneth in her house, jewels of silver, and jewels of gold, and raiment: and ye shall put <i>them</i> upon your sons, and upon your daughters; and ye shall spoil the Egyptians.


--------------------

CHAPTER 4

<b>1 </b>And Moses answered and said, But, behold, they will not believe me, nor hearken unto my voice: for they will say, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath not appeared unto thee.

<b>2 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto him, What <i>is</i> that in thine hand? And he said, A rod.

<b>3 </b>And he said, Cast it on the ground. And he cast it on the ground, and it became a serpent; and Moses fled from before it.

<b>4 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Put forth thine hand, and take it by the tail. And he put forth his hand, and caught it, and it became a rod in his hand:
