<b>5 </b>That they may believe that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of their fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, hath appeared unto thee.

<b>6 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said furthermore unto him, Put now thine hand into thy bosom. And he put his hand into his bosom: and when he took it out, behold, his hand <i>was</i> leprous as snow.

<b>7 </b>And he said, Put thine hand into thy bosom again. And he put his hand into his bosom again; and plucked it out of his bosom, and, behold, it was turned again as his <i>other</i> flesh.

<b>8 </b>And it shall come to pass, if they will not believe thee, neither hearken to the voice of the first sign, that they will believe the voice of the latter sign.

<b>9 </b>And it shall come to pass, if they will not believe also these two signs, neither hearken unto thy voice, that thou shalt take of the water of the river, and pour <i>it</i> upon the dry <i>land:</i> and the water which thou takest out of the river shall become blood upon the dry <i>land.</i>

<b>10 </b>¶ And Moses said unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, O my Lord, I <i>am</i> not eloquent, neither heretofore, nor since thou hast spoken unto thy servant: but I <i>am</i> slow of speech, and of a slow tongue.

<b>11 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto him, Who hath made man’s mouth? or who maketh the dumb, or deaf, or the seeing, or the blind? have not I the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>?

<b>12 </b>Now therefore go, and I will be with thy mouth, and teach thee what thou shalt say.

<b>13 </b>And he said, O my Lord, send, I pray thee, by the hand <i>of him whom</i> thou wilt send.

<b>14 </b>And the anger of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was kindled against Moses, and he said, <i>Is</i> not Aaron the Levite thy brother? I know that he can speak well. And also, behold, he cometh forth to meet thee: and when he seeth thee, he will be glad in his heart.

<b>15 </b>And thou shalt speak unto him, and put words in his mouth: and I will be with thy mouth, and with his mouth, and will teach you what ye shall do.

<b>16 </b>And he shall be thy spokesman unto the people: and he shall be, <i>even</i> he shall be to thee instead of a mouth, and thou shalt be to him instead of God.

<b>17 </b>And thou shalt take this rod in thine hand, wherewith thou shalt do signs.

<b>18 </b>¶ And Moses went and returned to Jethro his father in law, and said unto him, Let me go, I pray thee, and return unto my brethren which <i>are</i> in Egypt, and see whether they be yet alive. And Jethro said to Moses, Go in peace.

<b>19 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses in Midian, Go, return into Egypt: for all the men are dead which sought thy life.

<b>20 </b>And Moses took his wife and his sons, and set them upon an ass, and he returned to the land of Egypt: and Moses took the rod of God in his hand.

<b>21 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, When thou goest to return into Egypt, see that thou do all those wonders before Pharaoh, which I have put in thine hand: but I will harden his heart, that he shall not let the people go.

<b>22 </b>And thou shalt say unto Pharaoh, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Israel <i>is</i> my son, <i>even</i> my firstborn:

<b>23 </b>And I say unto thee, Let my son go, that he may serve me: and if thou refuse to let him go, behold, I will slay thy son, <i>even</i> thy firstborn.

<b>24 </b>¶ And it came to pass by the way in the inn, that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> met him, and sought to kill him.

<b>25 </b>Then Zipporah took a sharp stone, and cut off the foreskin of her son, and cast <i>it</i> at his feet, and said, Surely a bloody husband <i>art</i> thou to me.

<b>26 </b>So he let him go: then she said, A bloody husband <i>thou art,</i> because of the circumcision.

<b>27 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said to Aaron, Go into the wilderness to meet Moses. And he went, and met him in the mount of God, and kissed him.

<b>28 </b>And Moses told Aaron all the words of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> who had sent him, and all the signs which he had commanded him.

<b>29 </b>¶ And Moses and Aaron went and gathered together all the elders of the children of Israel:

<b>30 </b>And Aaron spake all the words which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had spoken unto Moses, and did the signs in the sight of the people.

<b>31 </b>And the people believed: and when they heard that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had visited the children of Israel, and that he had looked upon their affliction, then they bowed their heads and worshipped.


--------------------

CHAPTER 5

<b>1 </b>And afterward Moses and Aaron went in, and told Pharaoh, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, Let my people go, that they may hold a feast unto me in the wilderness.

<b>2 </b>And Pharaoh said, Who <i>is</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that I should obey his voice to let Israel go? I know not the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, neither will I let Israel go.

<b>3 </b>And they said, The God of the Hebrews hath met with us: let us go, we pray thee, three days’ journey into the desert, and sacrifice unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God; lest he fall upon us with pestilence, or with the sword.

<b>4 </b>And the king of Egypt said unto them, Wherefore do ye, Moses and Aaron, let the people from their works? get you unto your burdens.

<b>5 </b>And Pharaoh said, Behold, the people of the land now <i>are</i> many, and ye make them rest from their burdens.

<b>6 </b>And Pharaoh commanded the same day the taskmasters of the people, and their officers, saying,

<b>7 </b>Ye shall no more give the people straw to make brick, as heretofore: let them go and gather straw for themselves.

<b>8 </b>And the tale of the bricks, which they did make heretofore, ye shall lay upon them; ye shall not diminish <i>ought</i> thereof: for they <i>be</i> idle; therefore they cry, saying, Let us go <i>and</i> sacrifice to our God.

<b>9 </b>Let there more work be laid upon the men, that they may labour therein; and let them not regard vain words.

<b>10 </b>¶ And the taskmasters of the people went out, and their officers, and they spake to the people, saying, Thus saith Pharaoh, I will not give you straw.

<b>11 </b>Go ye, get you straw where ye can find it: yet not ought of your work shall be diminished.

<b>12 </b>So the people were scattered abroad throughout all the land of Egypt to gather stubble instead of straw.

<b>13 </b>And the taskmasters hasted <i>them,</i> saying, Fulfil your works, <i>your</i> daily tasks, as when there was straw.

<b>14 </b>And the officers of the children of Israel, which Pharaoh’s taskmasters had set over them, were beaten, <i>and</i> demanded, Wherefore have ye not fulfilled your task in making brick both yesterday and to day, as heretofore?

<b>15 </b>¶ Then the officers of the children of Israel came and cried unto Pharaoh, saying, Wherefore dealest thou thus with thy servants?

<b>16 </b>There is no straw given unto thy servants, and they say to us, Make brick: and, behold, thy servants <i>are</i> beaten; but the fault <i>is</i> in thine own people.

<b>17 </b>But he said, Ye <i>are</i> idle, <i>ye are</i> idle: therefore ye say, Let us go <i>and</i> do sacrifice to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>18 </b>Go therefore now, <i>and</i> work; for there shall no straw be given you, yet shall ye deliver the tale of bricks.

<b>19 </b>And the officers of the children of Israel did see <i>that</i> they <i>were</i> in evil <i>case</i><i>,</i> after it was said, Ye shall not minish <i>ought</i> from your bricks of your daily task.

<b>20 </b>¶ And they met Moses and Aaron, who stood in the way, as they came forth from Pharaoh:

<b>21 </b>And they said unto them, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> look upon you, and judge; because ye have made our savour to be abhorred in the eyes of Pharaoh, and in the eyes of his servants, to put a sword in their hand to slay us.

<b>22 </b>And Moses returned unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and said, Lord, wherefore hast thou <i>so</i> evil entreated this people? why <i>is</i> it <i>that</i> thou hast sent me?

<b>23 </b>For since I came to Pharaoh to speak in thy name, he hath done evil to this people; neither hast thou delivered thy people at all.


--------------------

CHAPTER 6

<b>1 </b>Then the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Now shalt thou see what I will do to Pharaoh: for with a strong hand shall he let them go, and with a strong hand shall he drive them out of his land.

<b>2 </b>And God spake unto Moses, and said unto him, I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>:

<b>3 </b>And I appeared unto Abraham, unto Isaac, and unto Jacob, by <i>the name of</i> God Almighty, but by my name <span class="uppercase">Jehovah</span> was I not known to them.

<b>4 </b>And I have also established my covenant with them, to give them the land of Canaan, the land of their pilgrimage, wherein they were strangers.

<b>5 </b>And I have also heard the groaning of the children of Israel, whom the Egyptians keep in bondage; and I have remembered my covenant.

<b>6 </b>Wherefore say unto the children of Israel, I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and I will bring you out from under the burdens of the Egyptians, and I will rid you out of their bondage, and I will redeem you with a stretched out arm, and with great judgments:

<b>7 </b>And I will take you to me for a people, and I will be to you a God: and ye shall know that I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, which bringeth you out from under the burdens of the Egyptians.

<b>8 </b>And I will bring you in unto the land, concerning the which I did swear to give it to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob; and I will give it you for an heritage: I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>9 </b>¶ And Moses spake so unto the children of Israel: but they hearkened not unto Moses for anguish of spirit, and for cruel bondage.

<b>10 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>11 </b>Go in, speak unto Pharaoh king of Egypt, that he let the children of Israel go out of his land.

<b>12 </b>And Moses spake before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying, Behold, the children of Israel have not hearkened unto me; how then shall Pharaoh hear me, who <i>am</i> of uncircumcised lips?

<b>13 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses and unto Aaron, and gave them a charge unto the children of Israel, and unto Pharaoh king of Egypt, to bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt.

<b>14 </b>¶ These <i>be</i> the heads of their fathers’ houses: The sons of Reuben the firstborn of Israel; Hanoch, and Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi: these <i>be</i> the families of Reuben.

<b>15 </b>And the sons of Simeon; Jemuel, and Jamin, and Ohad, and Jachin, and Zohar, and Shaul the son of a Canaanitish woman: these <i>are</i> the families of Simeon.

<b>16 </b>¶ And these <i>are</i> the names of the sons of Levi according to their generations; Gershon, and Kohath, and Merari: and the years of the life of Levi <i>were</i> an hundred thirty and seven years.

<b>17 </b>The sons of Gershon; Libni, and Shimi, according to their families.

<b>18 </b>And the sons of Kohath; Amram, and Izhar, and Hebron, and Uzziel: and the years of the life of Kohath <i>were</i> an hundred thirty and three years.

<b>19 </b>And the sons of Merari; Mahali and Mushi: these <i>are</i> the families of Levi according to their generations.

<b>20 </b>And Amram took him Jochebed his father’s sister to wife; and she bare him Aaron and Moses: and the years of the life of Amram <i>were</i> an hundred and thirty and seven years.

<b>21 </b>¶ And the sons of Izhar; Korah, and Nepheg, and Zichri.

<b>22 </b>And the sons of Uzziel; Mishael, and Elzaphan, and Zithri.

<b>23 </b>And Aaron took him Elisheba, daughter of Amminadab, sister of Naashon, to wife; and she bare him Nadab, and Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.

<b>24 </b>And the sons of Korah; Assir, and Elkanah, and Abiasaph: these <i>are</i> the families of the Korhites.

<b>25 </b>And Eleazar Aaron’s son took him <i>one</i> of the daughters of Putiel to wife; and she bare him Phinehas: these <i>are</i> the heads of the fathers of the Levites according to their families.

<b>26 </b>These <i>are</i> that Aaron and Moses, to whom the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said, Bring out the children of Israel from the land of Egypt according to their armies.

<b>27 </b>These <i>are</i> they which spake to Pharaoh king of Egypt, to bring out the children of Israel from Egypt: these <i>are</i> that Moses and Aaron.

<b>28 </b>¶ And it came to pass on the day <i>when</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses in the land of Egypt,

<b>29 </b>That the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying, I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: speak thou unto Pharaoh king of Egypt all that I say unto thee.

<b>30 </b>And Moses said before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Behold, I <i>am</i> of uncircumcised lips, and how shall Pharaoh hearken unto me?


--------------------

CHAPTER 7

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, See, I have made thee a god to Pharaoh: and Aaron thy brother shall be thy prophet.

<b>2 </b>Thou shalt speak all that I command thee: and Aaron thy brother shall speak unto Pharaoh, that he send the children of Israel out of his land.

<b>3 </b>And I will harden Pharaoh’s heart, and multiply my signs and my wonders in the land of Egypt.

<b>4 </b>But Pharaoh shall not hearken unto you, that I may lay my hand upon Egypt, and bring forth mine armies, <i>and</i> my people the children of Israel, out of the land of Egypt by great judgments.

<b>5 </b>And the Egyptians shall know that I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, when I stretch forth mine hand upon Egypt, and bring out the children of Israel from among them.

<b>6 </b>And Moses and Aaron did as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded them, so did they.

<b>7 </b>And Moses <i>was</i> fourscore years old, and Aaron fourscore and three years old, when they spake unto Pharaoh.

<b>8 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses and unto Aaron, saying,

<b>9 </b>When Pharaoh shall speak unto you, saying, Shew a miracle for you: then thou shalt say unto Aaron, Take thy rod, and cast <i>it</i> before Pharaoh, <i>and</i> it shall become a serpent.

<b>10 </b>¶ And Moses and Aaron went in unto Pharaoh, and they did so as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had commanded: and Aaron cast down his rod before Pharaoh, and before his servants, and it became a serpent.

<b>11 </b>Then Pharaoh also called the wise men and the sorcerers: now the magicians of Egypt, they also did in like manner with their enchantments.

<b>12 </b>For they cast down every man his rod, and they became serpents: but Aaron’s rod swallowed up their rods.

<b>13 </b>And he hardened Pharaoh’s heart, that he hearkened not unto them; as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had said.

<b>14 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Pharaoh’s heart <i>is</i> hardened, he refuseth to let the people go.

<b>15 </b>Get thee unto Pharaoh in the morning; lo, he goeth out unto the water; and thou shalt stand by the river’s brink against he come; and the rod which was turned to a serpent shalt thou take in thine hand.

<b>16 </b>And thou shalt say unto him, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of the Hebrews hath sent me unto thee, saying, Let my people go, that they may serve me in the wilderness: and, behold, hitherto thou wouldest not hear.

<b>17 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, In this thou shalt know that I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: behold, I will smite with the rod that <i>is</i> in mine hand upon the waters which <i>are</i> in the river, and they shall be turned to blood.

<b>18 </b>And the fish that <i>is</i> in the river shall die, and the river shall stink; and the Egyptians shall lothe to drink of the water of the river.

<b>19 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, Say unto Aaron, Take thy rod, and stretch out thine hand upon the waters of Egypt, upon their streams, upon their rivers, and upon their ponds, and upon all their pools of water, that they may become blood; and <i>that</i> there may be blood throughout all the land of Egypt, both in <i>vessels of</i> wood, and in <i>vessels of</i> stone.

<b>20 </b>And Moses and Aaron did so, as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded; and he lifted up the rod, and smote the waters that <i>were</i> in the river, in the sight of Pharaoh, and in the sight of his servants; and all the waters that <i>were</i> in the river were turned to blood.

<b>21 </b>And the fish that <i>was</i> in the river died; and the river stank, and the Egyptians could not drink of the water of the river; and there was blood throughout all the land of Egypt.

<b>22 </b>And the magicians of Egypt did so with their enchantments: and Pharaoh’s heart was hardened, neither did he hearken unto them; as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had said.

<b>23 </b>And Pharaoh turned and went into his house, neither did he set his heart to this also.

<b>24 </b>And all the Egyptians digged round about the river for water to drink; for they could not drink of the water of the river.

<b>25 </b>And seven days were fulfilled, after that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had smitten the river.


--------------------

CHAPTER 8

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, Go unto Pharaoh, and say unto him, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Let my people go, that they may serve me.

<b>2 </b>And if thou refuse to let <i>them</i> go, behold, I will smite all thy borders with frogs:

<b>3 </b>And the river shall bring forth frogs abundantly, which shall go up and come into thine house, and into thy bedchamber, and upon thy bed, and into the house of thy servants, and upon thy people, and into thine ovens, and into thy kneadingtroughs:

<b>4 </b>And the frogs shall come up both on thee, and upon thy people, and upon all thy servants.

<b>5 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, Say unto Aaron, Stretch forth thine hand with thy rod over the streams, over the rivers, and over the ponds, and cause frogs to come up upon the land of Egypt.

<b>6 </b>And Aaron stretched out his hand over the waters of Egypt; and the frogs came up, and covered the land of Egypt.

<b>7 </b>And the magicians did so with their enchantments, and brought up frogs upon the land of Egypt.

<b>8 </b>¶ Then Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron, and said, Entreat the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that he may take away the frogs from me, and from my people; and I will let the people go, that they may do sacrifice unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>9 </b>And Moses said unto Pharaoh, Glory over me: when shall I entreat for thee, and for thy servants, and for thy people, to destroy the frogs from thee and thy houses, <i>that</i> they may remain in the river only?

<b>10 </b>And he said, To morrow. And he said, <i>Be it</i> according to thy word: that thou mayest know that <i>there is</i> none like unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God.

<b>11 </b>And the frogs shall depart from thee, and from thy houses, and from thy servants, and from thy people; they shall remain in the river only.

<b>12 </b>And Moses and Aaron went out from Pharaoh: and Moses cried unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> because of the frogs which he had brought against Pharaoh.

<b>13 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> did according to the word of Moses; and the frogs died out of the houses, out of the villages, and out of the fields.

<b>14 </b>And they gathered them together upon heaps: and the land stank.

<b>15 </b>But when Pharaoh saw that there was respite, he hardened his heart, and hearkened not unto them; as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had said.

<b>16 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Say unto Aaron, Stretch out thy rod, and smite the dust of the land, that it may become lice throughout all the land of Egypt.

<b>17 </b>And they did so; for Aaron stretched out his hand with his rod, and smote the dust of the earth, and it became lice in man, and in beast; all the dust of the land became lice throughout all the land of Egypt.

<b>18 </b>And the magicians did so with their enchantments to bring forth lice, but they could not: so there were lice upon man, and upon beast.

<b>19 </b>Then the magicians said unto Pharaoh, This <i>is</i> the finger of God: and Pharaoh’s heart was hardened, and he hearkened not unto them; as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had said.

<b>20 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Rise up early in the morning, and stand before Pharaoh; lo, he cometh forth to the water; and say unto him, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Let my people go, that they may serve me.

<b>21 </b>Else, if thou wilt not let my people go, behold, I will send swarms <i>of flies</i> upon thee, and upon thy servants, and upon thy people, and into thy houses: and the houses of the Egyptians shall be full of swarms <i>of flies,</i> and also the ground whereon they <i>are.</i>

<b>22 </b>And I will sever in that day the land of Goshen, in which my people dwell, that no swarms <i>of flies</i> shall be there; to the end thou mayest know that I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in the midst of the earth.

<b>23 </b>And I will put a division between my people and thy people: to morrow shall this sign be.

<b>24 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> did so; and there came a grievous swarm <i>of flies</i> into the house of Pharaoh, and <i>into</i> his servants’ houses, and into all the land of Egypt: the land was corrupted by reason of the swarm <i>of flies.</i>

<b>25 </b>¶ And Pharaoh called for Moses and for Aaron, and said, Go ye, sacrifice to your God in the land.

<b>26 </b>And Moses said, It is not meet so to do; for we shall sacrifice the abomination of the Egyptians to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God: lo, shall we sacrifice the abomination of the Egyptians before their eyes, and will they not stone us?

<b>27 </b>We will go three days’ journey into the wilderness, and sacrifice to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God, as he shall command us.

<b>28 </b>And Pharaoh said, I will let you go, that ye may sacrifice to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God in the wilderness; only ye shall not go very far away: entreat for me.

<b>29 </b>And Moses said, Behold, I go out from thee, and I will entreat the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that the swarms <i>of flies</i> may depart from Pharaoh, from his servants, and from his people, to morrow: but let not Pharaoh deal deceitfully any more in not letting the people go to sacrifice to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>30 </b>And Moses went out from Pharaoh, and entreated the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>31 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> did according to the word of Moses; and he removed the swarms <i>of flies</i> from Pharaoh, from his servants, and from his people; there remained not one.

<b>32 </b>And Pharaoh hardened his heart at this time also, neither would he let the people go.


--------------------

CHAPTER 9

<b>1 </b>Then the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Go in unto Pharaoh, and tell him, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of the Hebrews, Let my people go, that they may serve me.

<b>2 </b>For if thou refuse to let <i>them</i> go, and wilt hold them still,

<b>3 </b>Behold, the hand of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> is upon thy cattle which <i>is</i> in the field, upon the horses, upon the asses, upon the camels, upon the oxen, and upon the sheep: <i>there shall be</i> a very grievous murrain.

<b>4 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall sever between the cattle of Israel and the cattle of Egypt: and there shall nothing die of all <i>that is</i> the children’s of Israel.

<b>5 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> appointed a set time, saying, To morrow the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall do this thing in the land.

<b>6 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> did that thing on the morrow, and all the cattle of Egypt died: but of the cattle of the children of Israel died not one.

<b>7 </b>And Pharaoh sent, and, behold, there was not one of the cattle of the Israelites dead. And the heart of Pharaoh was hardened, and he did not let the people go.

<b>8 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses and unto Aaron, Take to you handfuls of ashes of the furnace, and let Moses sprinkle it toward the heaven in the sight of Pharaoh.

<b>9 </b>And it shall become small dust in all the land of Egypt, and shall be a boil breaking forth <i>with</i> blains upon man, and upon beast, throughout all the land of Egypt.

<b>10 </b>And they took ashes of the furnace, and stood before Pharaoh; and Moses sprinkled it up toward heaven; and it became a boil breaking forth <i>with</i> blains upon man, and upon beast.

<b>11 </b>And the magicians could not stand before Moses because of the boils; for the boil was upon the magicians, and upon all the Egyptians.

<b>12 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hardened the heart of Pharaoh, and he hearkened not unto them; as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had spoken unto Moses.

<b>13 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Rise up early in the morning, and stand before Pharaoh, and say unto him, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of the Hebrews, Let my people go, that they may serve me.

<b>14 </b>For I will at this time send all my plagues upon thine heart, and upon thy servants, and upon thy people; that thou mayest know that <i>there is</i> none like me in all the earth.

<b>15 </b>For now I will stretch out my hand, that I may smite thee and thy people with pestilence; and thou shalt be cut off from the earth.

<b>16 </b>And in very deed for this <i>cause</i> have I raised thee up, for to shew <i>in</i> thee my power; and that my name may be declared throughout all the earth.

<b>17 </b>As yet exaltest thou thyself against my people, that thou wilt not let them go?

<b>18 </b>Behold, to morrow about this time I will cause it to rain a very grievous hail, such as hath not been in Egypt since the foundation thereof even until now.

<b>19 </b>Send therefore now, <i>and</i> gather thy cattle, and all that thou hast in the field; <i>for upon</i> every man and beast which shall be found in the field, and shall not be brought home, the hail shall come down upon them, and they shall die.

<b>20 </b>He that feared the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> among the servants of Pharaoh made his servants and his cattle flee into the houses:

<b>21 </b>And he that regarded not the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> left his servants and his cattle in the field.

<b>22 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Stretch forth thine hand toward heaven, that there may be hail in all the land of Egypt, upon man, and upon beast, and upon every herb of the field, throughout the land of Egypt.

<b>23 </b>And Moses stretched forth his rod toward heaven: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sent thunder and hail, and the fire ran along upon the ground; and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> rained hail upon the land of Egypt.

<b>24 </b>So there was hail, and fire mingled with the hail, very grievous, such as there was none like it in all the land of Egypt since it became a nation.

<b>25 </b>And the hail smote throughout all the land of Egypt all that <i>was</i> in the field, both man and beast; and the hail smote every herb of the field, and brake every tree of the field.

<b>26 </b>Only in the land of Goshen, where the children of Israel <i>were,</i> was there no hail.

<b>27 </b>¶ And Pharaoh sent, and called for Moses and Aaron, and said unto them, I have sinned this time: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> righteous, and I and my people <i>are</i> wicked.

<b>28 </b>Entreat the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> (for <i>it is</i> enough) that there be no <i>more</i> mighty thunderings and hail; and I will let you go, and ye shall stay no longer.

<b>29 </b>And Moses said unto him, As soon as I am gone out of the city, I will spread abroad my hands unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; <i>and</i> the thunder shall cease, neither shall there be any more hail; that thou mayest know how that the earth <i>is</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s.

<b>30 </b>But as for thee and thy servants, I know that ye will not yet fear the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God.

<b>31 </b>And the flax and the barley was smitten: for the barley <i>was</i> in the ear, and the flax <i>was</i> bolled.

<b>32 </b>But the wheat and the rie were not smitten: for they <i>were</i> not grown up.

<b>33 </b>And Moses went out of the city from Pharaoh, and spread abroad his hands unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and the thunders and hail ceased, and the rain was not poured upon the earth.

<b>34 </b>And when Pharaoh saw that the rain and the hail and the thunders were ceased, he sinned yet more, and hardened his heart, he and his servants.

<b>35 </b>And the heart of Pharaoh was hardened, neither would he let the children of Israel go; as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had spoken by Moses.


--------------------

CHAPTER 10

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Go in unto Pharaoh: for I have hardened his heart, and the heart of his servants, that I might shew these my signs before him:

<b>2 </b>And that thou mayest tell in the ears of thy son, and of thy son’s son, what things I have wrought in Egypt, and my signs which I have done among them; that ye may know how that I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>3 </b>And Moses and Aaron came in unto Pharaoh, and said unto him, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of the Hebrews, How long wilt thou refuse to humble thyself before me? let my people go, that they may serve me.

<b>4 </b>Else, if thou refuse to let my people go, behold, to morrow will I bring the locusts into thy coast:

<b>5 </b>And they shall cover the face of the earth, that one cannot be able to see the earth: and they shall eat the residue of that which is escaped, which remaineth unto you from the hail, and shall eat every tree which groweth for you out of the field:

<b>6 </b>And they shall fill thy houses, and the houses of all thy servants, and the houses of all the Egyptians; which neither thy fathers, nor thy fathers’ fathers have seen, since the day that they were upon the earth unto this day. And he turned himself, and went out from Pharaoh.

<b>7 </b>And Pharaoh’s servants said unto him, How long shall this man be a snare unto us? let the men go, that they may serve the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> their God: knowest thou not yet that Egypt is destroyed?

<b>8 </b>And Moses and Aaron were brought again unto Pharaoh: and he said unto them, Go, serve the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God: <i>but</i> who <i>are</i> they that shall go?

<b>9 </b>And Moses said, We will go with our young and with our old, with our sons and with our daughters, with our flocks and with our herds will we go; for we <i>must hold</i> a feast unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>10 </b>And he said unto them, Let the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> be so with you, as I will let you go, and your little ones: look <i>to it;</i> for evil <i>is</i> before you.

<b>11 </b>Not so: go now ye <i>that are</i> men, and serve the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for that ye did desire. And they were driven out from Pharaoh’s presence.

<b>12 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Stretch out thine hand over the land of Egypt for the locusts, that they may come up upon the land of Egypt, and eat every herb of the land, <i>even</i> all that the hail hath left.

<b>13 </b>And Moses stretched forth his rod over the land of Egypt, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> brought an east wind upon the land all that day, and all <i>that</i> night; <i>and</i> when it was morning, the east wind brought the locusts.

<b>14 </b>And the locusts went up over all the land of Egypt, and rested in all the coasts of Egypt: very grievous <i>were they;</i> before them there were no such locusts as they, neither after them shall be such.

<b>15 </b>For they covered the face of the whole earth, so that the land was darkened; and they did eat every herb of the land, and all the fruit of the trees which the hail had left: and there remained not any green thing in the trees, or in the herbs of the field, through all the land of Egypt.

<b>16 </b>¶ Then Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron in haste; and he said, I have sinned against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, and against you.

<b>17 </b>Now therefore forgive, I pray thee, my sin only this once, and entreat the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, that he may take away from me this death only.

<b>18 </b>And he went out from Pharaoh, and entreated the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>19 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> turned a mighty strong west wind, which took away the locusts, and cast them into the Red sea; there remained not one locust in all the coasts of Egypt.

<b>20 </b>But the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hardened Pharaoh’s heart, so that he would not let the children of Israel go.

<b>21 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Stretch out thine hand toward heaven, that there may be darkness over the land of Egypt, even darkness <i>which</i> may be felt.

<b>22 </b>And Moses stretched forth his hand toward heaven; and there was a thick darkness in all the land of Egypt three days:

<b>23 </b>They saw not one another, neither rose any from his place for three days: but all the children of Israel had light in their dwellings.

<b>24 </b>¶ And Pharaoh called unto Moses, and said, Go ye, serve the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; only let your flocks and your herds be stayed: let your little ones also go with you.

<b>25 </b>And Moses said, Thou must give us also sacrifices and burnt offerings, that we may sacrifice unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God.

<b>26 </b>Our cattle also shall go with us; there shall not an hoof be left behind; for thereof must we take to serve the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God; and we know not with what we must serve the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, until we come thither.

<b>27 </b>¶ But the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he would not let them go.

<b>28 </b>And Pharaoh said unto him, Get thee from me, take heed to thyself, see my face no more; for in <i>that</i> day thou seest my face thou shalt die.

<b>29 </b>And Moses said, Thou hast spoken well, I will see thy face again no more.


--------------------

CHAPTER 11

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Yet will I bring one plague <i>more</i> upon Pharaoh, and upon Egypt; afterwards he will let you go hence: when he shall let <i>you</i> go, he shall surely thrust you out hence altogether.

<b>2 </b>Speak now in the ears of the people, and let every man borrow of his neighbour, and every woman of her neighbour, jewels of silver, and jewels of gold.

<b>3 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> gave the people favour in the sight of the Egyptians. Moreover the man Moses <i>was</i> very great in the land of Egypt, in the sight of Pharaoh’s servants, and in the sight of the people.

<b>4 </b>And Moses said, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, About midnight will I go out into the midst of Egypt:

<b>5 </b>And all the firstborn in the land of Egypt shall die, from the firstborn of Pharaoh that sitteth upon his throne, even unto the firstborn of the maidservant that <i>is</i> behind the mill; and all the firstborn of beasts.

<b>6 </b>And there shall be a great cry throughout all the land of Egypt, such as there was none like it, nor shall be like it any more.

<b>7 </b>But against any of the children of Israel shall not a dog move his tongue, against man or beast: that ye may know how that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> doth put a difference between the Egyptians and Israel.

<b>8 </b>And all these thy servants shall come down unto me, and bow down themselves unto me, saying, Get thee out, and all the people that follow thee: and after that I will go out. And he went out from Pharaoh in a great anger.

<b>9 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Pharaoh shall not hearken unto you; that my wonders may be multiplied in the land of Egypt.

<b>10 </b>And Moses and Aaron did all these wonders before Pharaoh: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hardened Pharaoh’s heart, so that he would not let the children of Israel go out of his land.


--------------------

CHAPTER 12

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses and Aaron in the land of Egypt, saying,

<b>2 </b>This month <i>shall be</i> unto you the beginning of months: it <i>shall be</i> the first month of the year to you.

<b>3 </b>¶ Speak ye unto all the congregation of Israel, saying, In the tenth <i>day</i> of this month they shall take to them every man a lamb, according to the house of <i>their</i> fathers, a lamb for an house:

<b>4 </b>And if the household be too little for the lamb, let him and his neighbour next unto his house take <i>it</i> according to the number of the souls; every man according to his eating shall make your count for the lamb.

<b>5 </b>Your lamb shall be without blemish, a male of the first year: ye shall take <i>it</i> out from the sheep, or from the goats:

<b>6 </b>And ye shall keep it up until the fourteenth day of the same month: and the whole assembly of the congregation of Israel shall kill it in the evening.

<b>7 </b>And they shall take of the blood, and strike <i>it</i> on the two side posts and on the upper door post of the houses, wherein they shall eat it.

<b>8 </b>And they shall eat the flesh in that night, roast with fire, and unleavened bread; <i>and</i> with bitter <i>herbs</i> they shall eat it.

<b>9 </b>Eat not of it raw, nor sodden at all with water, but roast <i>with</i> fire; his head with his legs, and with the purtenance thereof.

<b>10 </b>And ye shall let nothing of it remain until the morning; and that which remaineth of it until the morning ye shall burn with fire.

<b>11 </b>¶ And thus shall ye eat it; <i>with</i> your loins girded, your shoes on your feet, and your staff in your hand; and ye shall eat it in haste: it <i>is</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s passover.

<b>12 </b>For I will pass through the land of Egypt this night, and will smite all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, both man and beast; and against all the gods of Egypt I will execute judgment: I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>13 </b>And the blood shall be to you for a token upon the houses where ye <i>are:</i> and when I see the blood, I will pass over you, and the plague shall not be upon you to destroy <i>you,</i> when I smite the land of Egypt.

<b>14 </b>And this day shall be unto you for a memorial; and ye shall keep it a feast to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> throughout your generations; ye shall keep it a feast by an ordinance for ever.

<b>15 </b>Seven days shall ye eat unleavened bread; even the first day ye shall put away leaven out of your houses: for whosoever eateth leavened bread from the first day until the seventh day, that soul shall be cut off from Israel.

<b>16 </b>And in the first day <i>there shall be</i> an holy convocation, and in the seventh day there shall be an holy convocation to you; no manner of work shall be done in them, save <i>that</i> which every man must eat, that only may be done of you.

<b>17 </b>And ye shall observe <i>the feast of</i> unleavened bread; for in this selfsame day have I brought your armies out of the land of Egypt: therefore shall ye observe this day in your generations by an ordinance for ever.

<b>18 </b>¶ In the first <i>month,</i> on the fourteenth day of the month at even, ye shall eat unleavened bread, until the one and twentieth day of the month at even.

<b>19 </b>Seven days shall there be no leaven found in your houses: for whosoever eateth that which is leavened, even that soul shall be cut off from the congregation of Israel, whether he be a stranger, or born in the land.

<b>20 </b>Ye shall eat nothing leavened; in all your habitations shall ye eat unleavened bread.

<b>21 </b>¶ Then Moses called for all the elders of Israel, and said unto them, Draw out and take you a lamb according to your families, and kill the passover.

<b>22 </b>And ye shall take a bunch of hyssop, and dip <i>it</i> in the blood that <i>is</i> in the basin, and strike the lintel and the two side posts with the blood that <i>is</i> in the basin; and none of you shall go out at the door of his house until the morning.

<b>23 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will pass through to smite the Egyptians; and when he seeth the blood upon the lintel, and on the two side posts, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will pass over the door, and will not suffer the destroyer to come in unto your houses to smite <i>you.</i>

<b>24 </b>And ye shall observe this thing for an ordinance to thee and to thy sons for ever.

<b>25 </b>And it shall come to pass, when ye be come to the land which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will give you, according as he hath promised, that ye shall keep this service.

<b>26 </b>And it shall come to pass, when your children shall say unto you, What mean ye by this service?

<b>27 </b>That ye shall say, It <i>is</i> the sacrifice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s passover, who passed over the houses of the children of Israel in Egypt, when he smote the Egyptians, and delivered our houses. And the people bowed the head and worshipped.

<b>28 </b>And the children of Israel went away, and did as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had commanded Moses and Aaron, so did they.

<b>29 </b>¶ And it came to pass, that at midnight the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> smote all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, from the firstborn of Pharaoh that sat on his throne unto the firstborn of the captive that <i>was</i> in the dungeon; and all the firstborn of cattle.

<b>30 </b>And Pharaoh rose up in the night, he, and all his servants, and all the Egyptians; and there was a great cry in Egypt; for <i>there was</i> not a house where <i>there was</i> not one dead.

<b>31 </b>¶ And he called for Moses and Aaron by night, and said, Rise up, <i>and</i> get you forth from among my people, both ye and the children of Israel; and go, serve the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, as ye have said.

<b>32 </b>Also take your flocks and your herds, as ye have said, and be gone; and bless me also.

<b>33 </b>And the Egyptians were urgent upon the people, that they might send them out of the land in haste; for they said, We <i>be</i> all dead <i>men.</i>

<b>34 </b>And the people took their dough before it was leavened, their kneadingtroughs being bound up in their clothes upon their shoulders.

<b>35 </b>And the children of Israel did according to the word of Moses; and they borrowed of the Egyptians jewels of silver, and jewels of gold, and raiment:

<b>36 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> gave the people favour in the sight of the Egyptians, so that they lent unto them <i>such things as they required.</i> And they spoiled the Egyptians.

<b>37 </b>¶ And the children of Israel journeyed from Rameses to Succoth, about six hundred thousand on foot <i>that were</i> men, beside children.

<b>38 </b>And a mixed multitude went up also with them; and flocks, and herds, <i>even</i> very much cattle.

<b>39 </b>And they baked unleavened cakes of the dough which they brought forth out of Egypt, for it was not leavened; because they were thrust out of Egypt, and could not tarry, neither had they prepared for themselves any victual.

<b>40 </b>¶ Now the sojourning of the children of Israel, who dwelt in Egypt, <i>was</i> four hundred and thirty years.

<b>41 </b>And it came to pass at the end of the four hundred and thirty years, even the selfsame day it came to pass, that all the hosts of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> went out from the land of Egypt.

<b>42 </b>It <i>is</i> a night to be much observed unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> for bringing them out from the land of Egypt: this <i>is</i> that night of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> to be observed of all the children of Israel in their generations.

<b>43 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses and Aaron, This <i>is</i> the ordinance of the passover: There shall no stranger eat thereof:

<b>44 </b>But every man’s servant that is bought for money, when thou hast circumcised him, then shall he eat thereof.

<b>45 </b>A foreigner and an hired servant shall not eat thereof.

<b>46 </b>In one house shall it be eaten; thou shalt not carry forth ought of the flesh abroad out of the house; neither shall ye break a bone thereof.

<b>47 </b>All the congregation of Israel shall keep it.

<b>48 </b>And when a stranger shall sojourn with thee, and will keep the passover to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, let all his males be circumcised, and then let him come near and keep it; and he shall be as one that is born in the land: for no uncircumcised person shall eat thereof.

<b>49 </b>One law shall be to him that is homeborn, and unto the stranger that sojourneth among you.

<b>50 </b>Thus did all the children of Israel; as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded Moses and Aaron, so did they.

<b>51 </b>And it came to pass the selfsame day, <i>that</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> did bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt by their armies.


--------------------

CHAPTER 13

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>2 </b>Sanctify unto me all the firstborn, whatsoever openeth the womb among the children of Israel, <i>both</i> of man and of beast: it <i>is</i> mine.

<b>3 </b>¶ And Moses said unto the people, Remember this day, in which ye came out from Egypt, out of the house of bondage; for by strength of hand the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> brought you out from this <i>place:</i> there shall no leavened bread be eaten.

<b>4 </b>This day came ye out in the month Abib.

<b>5 </b>¶ And it shall be when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall bring thee into the land of the Canaanites, and the Hittites, and the Amorites, and the Hivites, and the Jebusites, which he sware unto thy fathers to give thee, a land flowing with milk and honey, that thou shalt keep this service in this month.

<b>6 </b>Seven days thou shalt eat unleavened bread, and in the seventh day <i>shall be</i> a feast to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>7 </b>Unleavened bread shall be eaten seven days; and there shall no leavened bread be seen with thee, neither shall there be leaven seen with thee in all thy quarters.

<b>8 </b>¶ And thou shalt shew thy son in that day, saying, <i>This is done</i> because of that <i>which</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> did unto me when I came forth out of Egypt.

<b>9 </b>And it shall be for a sign unto thee upon thine hand, and for a memorial between thine eyes, that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s law may be in thy mouth: for with a strong hand hath the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> brought thee out of Egypt.

<b>10 </b>Thou shalt therefore keep this ordinance in his season from year to year.

<b>11 </b>¶ And it shall be when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall bring thee into the land of the Canaanites, as he sware unto thee and to thy fathers, and shall give it thee,

<b>12 </b>That thou shalt set apart unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> all that openeth the matrix, and every firstling that cometh of a beast which thou hast; the males <i>shall be</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s.

<b>13 </b>And every firstling of an ass thou shalt redeem with a lamb; and if thou wilt not redeem it, then thou shalt break his neck: and all the firstborn of man among thy children shalt thou redeem.

<b>14 </b>¶ And it shall be when thy son asketh thee in time to come, saying, What <i>is</i> this? that thou shalt say unto him, By strength of hand the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> brought us out from Egypt, from the house of bondage:

<b>15 </b>And it came to pass, when Pharaoh would hardly let us go, that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> slew all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, both the firstborn of man, and the firstborn of beast: therefore I sacrifice to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> all that openeth the matrix, being males; but all the firstborn of my children I redeem.

<b>16 </b>And it shall be for a token upon thine hand, and for frontlets between thine eyes: for by strength of hand the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> brought us forth out of Egypt.

<b>17 </b>¶ And it came to pass, when Pharaoh had let the people go, that God led them not <i>through</i> the way of the land of the Philistines, although that <i>was</i> near; for God said, Lest peradventure the people repent when they see war, and they return to Egypt:

<b>18 </b>But God led the people about, <i>through</i> the way of the wilderness of the Red sea: and the children of Israel went up harnessed out of the land of Egypt.

<b>19 </b>And Moses took the bones of Joseph with him: for he had straitly sworn the children of Israel, saying, God will surely visit you; and ye shall carry up my bones away hence with you.

<b>20 </b>¶ And they took their journey from Succoth, and encamped in Etham, in the edge of the wilderness.

<b>21 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> went before them by day in a pillar of a cloud, to lead them the way; and by night in a pillar of fire, to give them light; to go by day and night:

<b>22 </b>He took not away the pillar of the cloud by day, nor the pillar of fire by night, <i>from</i> before the people.


--------------------

CHAPTER 14

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>2 </b>Speak unto the children of Israel, that they turn and encamp before Pi-hahiroth, between Migdol and the sea, over against Baal-zephon: before it shall ye encamp by the sea.

<b>3 </b>For Pharaoh will say of the children of Israel, They <i>are</i> entangled in the land, the wilderness hath shut them in.

<b>4 </b>And I will harden Pharaoh’s heart, that he shall follow after them; and I will be honoured upon Pharaoh, and upon all his host; that the Egyptians may know that I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. And they did so.

<b>5 </b>¶ And it was told the king of Egypt that the people fled: and the heart of Pharaoh and of his servants was turned against the people, and they said, Why have we done this, that we have let Israel go from serving us?

<b>6 </b>And he made ready his chariot, and took his people with him:

<b>7 </b>And he took six hundred chosen chariots, and all the chariots of Egypt, and captains over every one of them.

<b>8 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hardened the heart of Pharaoh king of Egypt, and he pursued after the children of Israel: and the children of Israel went out with an high hand.

<b>9 </b>But the Egyptians pursued after them, all the horses <i>and</i> chariots of Pharaoh, and his horsemen, and his army, and overtook them encamping by the sea, beside Pi-hahiroth, before Baal-zephon.

<b>10 </b>¶ And when Pharaoh drew nigh, the children of Israel lifted up their eyes, and, behold, the Egyptians marched after them; and they were sore afraid: and the children of Israel cried out unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>11 </b>And they said unto Moses, Because <i>there were</i> no graves in Egypt, hast thou taken us away to die in the wilderness? wherefore hast thou dealt thus with us, to carry us forth out of Egypt?

<b>12 </b><i>Is</i> not this the word that we did tell thee in Egypt, saying, Let us alone, that we may serve the Egyptians? For <i>it had been</i> better for us to serve the Egyptians, than that we should die in the wilderness.

<b>13 </b>¶ And Moses said unto the people, Fear ye not, stand still, and see the salvation of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which he will shew to you to day: for the Egyptians whom ye have seen to day, ye shall see them again no more for ever.

<b>14 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall fight for you, and ye shall hold your peace.

<b>15 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Wherefore criest thou unto me? speak unto the children of Israel, that they go forward:

<b>16 </b>But lift thou up thy rod, and stretch out thine hand over the sea, and divide it: and the children of Israel shall go on dry <i>ground</i> through the midst of the sea.

<b>17 </b>And I, behold, I will harden the hearts of the Egyptians, and they shall follow them: and I will get me honour upon Pharaoh, and upon all his host, upon his chariots, and upon his horsemen.

<b>18 </b>And the Egyptians shall know that I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, when I have gotten me honour upon Pharaoh, upon his chariots, and upon his horsemen.

<b>19 </b>¶ And the angel of God, which went before the camp of Israel, removed and went behind them; and the pillar of the cloud went from before their face, and stood behind them:

<b>20 </b>And it came between the camp of the Egyptians and the camp of Israel; and it was a cloud and darkness <i>to them,</i> but it gave light by night <i>to these:</i> so that the one came not near the other all the night.

<b>21 </b>And Moses stretched out his hand over the sea; and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> caused the sea to go <i>back</i> by a strong east wind all that night, and made the sea dry <i>land,</i> and the waters were divided.

<b>22 </b>And the children of Israel went into the midst of the sea upon the dry <i>ground:</i> and the waters <i>were</i> a wall unto them on their right hand, and on their left.

<b>23 </b>¶ And the Egyptians pursued, and went in after them to the midst of the sea, <i>even</i> all Pharaoh’s horses, his chariots, and his horsemen.

<b>24 </b>And it came to pass, that in the morning watch the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> looked unto the host of the Egyptians through the pillar of fire and of the cloud, and troubled the host of the Egyptians,

<b>25 </b>And took off their chariot wheels, that they drave them heavily: so that the Egyptians said, Let us flee from the face of Israel; for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> fighteth for them against the Egyptians.

<b>26 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Stretch out thine hand over the sea, that the waters may come again upon the Egyptians, upon their chariots, and upon their horsemen.

<b>27 </b>And Moses stretched forth his hand over the sea, and the sea returned to his strength when the morning appeared; and the Egyptians fled against it; and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> overthrew the Egyptians in the midst of the sea.

<b>28 </b>And the waters returned, and covered the chariots, and the horsemen, <i>and</i> all the host of Pharaoh that came into the sea after them; there remained not so much as one of them.

<b>29 </b>But the children of Israel walked upon dry <i>land</i> in the midst of the sea; and the waters <i>were</i> a wall unto them on their right hand, and on their left.

<b>30 </b>Thus the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> saved Israel that day out of the hand of the Egyptians; and Israel saw the Egyptians dead upon the sea shore.

<b>31 </b>And Israel saw that great work which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> did upon the Egyptians: and the people feared the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and believed the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and his servant Moses.


--------------------

CHAPTER 15

<b>1 </b>Then sang Moses and the children of Israel this song unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and spake, saying, I will sing unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, for he hath triumphed gloriously: the horse and his rider hath he thrown into the sea.

<b>2 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> my strength and song, and he is become my salvation: he <i>is</i> my God, and I will prepare him an habitation; my father’s God, and I will exalt him.

<b>3 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> a man of war: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> his name.

<b>4 </b>Pharaoh’s chariots and his host hath he cast into the sea: his chosen captains also are drowned in the Red sea.

<b>5 </b>The depths have covered them: they sank into the bottom as a stone.

<b>6 </b>Thy right hand, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, is become glorious in power: thy right hand, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, hath dashed in pieces the enemy.

<b>7 </b>And in the greatness of thine excellency thou hast overthrown them that rose up against thee: thou sentest forth thy wrath, <i>which</i> consumed them as stubble.

<b>8 </b>And with the blast of thy nostrils the waters were gathered together, the floods stood upright as an heap, <i>and</i> the depths were congealed in the heart of the sea.

<b>9 </b>The enemy said, I will pursue, I will overtake, I will divide the spoil; my lust shall be satisfied upon them; I will draw my sword, my hand shall destroy them.

<b>10 </b>Thou didst blow with thy wind, the sea covered them: they sank as lead in the mighty waters.

<b>11 </b>Who <i>is</i> like unto thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, among the gods? who <i>is</i> like thee, glorious in holiness, fearful <i>in</i> praises, doing wonders?

<b>12 </b>Thou stretchedst out thy right hand, the earth swallowed them.

<b>13 </b>Thou in thy mercy hast led forth the people <i>which</i> thou hast redeemed: thou hast guided <i>them</i> in thy strength unto thy holy habitation.

<b>14 </b>The people shall hear, <i>and</i> be afraid: sorrow shall take hold on the inhabitants of Palestina.

<b>15 </b>Then the dukes of Edom shall be amazed; the mighty men of Moab, trembling shall take hold upon them; all the inhabitants of Canaan shall melt away.

<b>16 </b>Fear and dread shall fall upon them; by the greatness of thine arm they shall be <i>as</i> still as a stone; till thy people pass over, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, till the people pass over, <i>which</i> thou hast purchased.

<b>17 </b>Thou shalt bring them in, and plant them in the mountain of thine inheritance, <i>in</i> the place, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>which</i> thou hast made for thee to dwell in, <i>in</i> the Sanctuary, O Lord, <i>which</i> thy hands have established.

<b>18 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall reign for ever and ever.

<b>19 </b>For the horse of Pharaoh went in with his chariots and with his horsemen into the sea, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> brought again the waters of the sea upon them; but the children of Israel went on dry <i>land</i> in the midst of the sea.

<b>20 </b>¶ And Miriam the prophetess, the sister of Aaron, took a timbrel in her hand; and all the women went out after her with timbrels and with dances.

<b>21 </b>And Miriam answered them, Sing ye to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, for he hath triumphed gloriously; the horse and his rider hath he thrown into the sea.

<b>22 </b>So Moses brought Israel from the Red sea, and they went out into the wilderness of Shur; and they went three days in the wilderness, and found no water.

<b>23 </b>¶ And when they came to Marah, they could not drink of the waters of Marah, for they <i>were</i> bitter: therefore the name of it was called Marah.

<b>24 </b>And the people murmured against Moses, saying, What shall we drink?

<b>25 </b>And he cried unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shewed him a tree, <i>which</i> when he had cast into the waters, the waters were made sweet: there he made for them a statute and an ordinance, and there he proved them,

<b>26 </b>And said, If thou wilt diligently hearken to the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, and wilt do that which is right in his sight, and wilt give ear to his commandments, and keep all his statutes, I will put none of these diseases upon thee, which I have brought upon the Egyptians: for I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that healeth thee.

<b>27 </b>¶ And they came to Elim, where <i>were</i> twelve wells of water, and threescore and ten palm trees: and they encamped there by the waters.


--------------------

CHAPTER 16

<b>1 </b>And they took their journey from Elim, and all the congregation of the children of Israel came unto the wilderness of Sin, which <i>is</i> between Elim and Sinai, on the fifteenth day of the second month after their departing out of the land of Egypt.

<b>2 </b>And the whole congregation of the children of Israel murmured against Moses and Aaron in the wilderness:

<b>3 </b>And the children of Israel said unto them, Would to God we had died by the hand of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in the land of Egypt, when we sat by the flesh pots, <i>and</i> when we did eat bread to the full; for ye have brought us forth into this wilderness, to kill this whole assembly with hunger.

<b>4 </b>¶ Then said the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto Moses, Behold, I will rain bread from heaven for you; and the people shall go out and gather a certain rate every day, that I may prove them, whether they will walk in my law, or no.

<b>5 </b>And it shall come to pass, that on the sixth day they shall prepare <i>that</i> which they bring in; and it shall be twice as much as they gather daily.

<b>6 </b>And Moses and Aaron said unto all the children of Israel, At even, then ye shall know that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath brought you out from the land of Egypt:

<b>7 </b>And in the morning, then ye shall see the glory of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for that he heareth your murmurings against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and what <i>are</i> we, that ye murmur against us?

<b>8 </b>And Moses said, <i>This shall be,</i> when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall give you in the evening flesh to eat, and in the morning bread to the full; for that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> heareth your murmurings which ye murmur against him: and what <i>are</i> we? your murmurings <i>are</i> not against us, but against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>9 </b>¶ And Moses spake unto Aaron, Say unto all the congregation of the children of Israel, Come near before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for he hath heard your murmurings.

<b>10 </b>And it came to pass, as Aaron spake unto the whole congregation of the children of Israel, that they looked toward the wilderness, and, behold, the glory of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> appeared in the cloud.

<b>11 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>12 </b>I have heard the murmurings of the children of Israel: speak unto them, saying, At even ye shall eat flesh, and in the morning ye shall be filled with bread; and ye shall know that I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God.

<b>13 </b>And it came to pass, that at even the quails came up, and covered the camp: and in the morning the dew lay round about the host.

<b>14 </b>And when the dew that lay was gone up, behold, upon the face of the wilderness <i>there lay</i> a small round thing, <i>as</i> small as the hoar frost on the ground.

<b>15 </b>And when the children of Israel saw <i>it,</i> they said one to another, It <i>is</i> manna: for they wist not what it <i>was.</i> And Moses said unto them, This <i>is</i> the bread which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath given you to eat.

<b>16 </b>¶ This <i>is</i> the thing which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath commanded, Gather of it every man according to his eating, an omer for every man, <i>according to</i> the number of your persons; take ye every man for <i>them</i> which <i>are</i> in his tents.

<b>17 </b>And the children of Israel did so, and gathered, some more, some less.

<b>18 </b>And when they did mete <i>it</i> with an omer, he that gathered much had nothing over, and he that gathered little had no lack; they gathered every man according to his eating.

<b>19 </b>And Moses said, Let no man leave of it till the morning.

<b>20 </b>Notwithstanding they hearkened not unto Moses; but some of them left of it until the morning, and it bred worms, and stank: and Moses was wroth with them.

<b>21 </b>And they gathered it every morning, every man according to his eating: and when the sun waxed hot, it melted.

<b>22 </b>¶ And it came to pass, <i>that</i> on the sixth day they gathered twice as much bread, two omers for one <i>man:</i> and all the rulers of the congregation came and told Moses.

<b>23 </b>And he said unto them, This <i>is that</i> which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath said, To morrow <i>is</i> the rest of the holy sabbath unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: bake <i>that</i> which ye will bake <i>to day,</i> and seethe that ye will seethe; and that which remaineth over lay up for you to be kept until the morning.

<b>24 </b>And they laid it up till the morning, as Moses bade: and it did not stink, neither was there any worm therein.

<b>25 </b>And Moses said, Eat that to day; for to day <i>is</i> a sabbath unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: to day ye shall not find it in the field.

<b>26 </b>Six days ye shall gather it; but on the seventh day, <i>which is</i> the sabbath, in it there shall be none.

<b>27 </b>¶ And it came to pass, <i>that</i> there went out <i>some</i> of the people on the seventh day for to gather, and they found none.

<b>28 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, How long refuse ye to keep my commandments and my laws?

<b>29 </b>See, for that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath given you the sabbath, therefore he giveth you on the sixth day the bread of two days; abide ye every man in his place, let no man go out of his place on the seventh day.

<b>30 </b>So the people rested on the seventh day.

<b>31 </b>And the house of Israel called the name thereof Manna: and it <i>was</i> like coriander seed, white; and the taste of it <i>was</i> like wafers <i>made</i> with honey.

<b>32 </b>¶ And Moses said, This <i>is</i> the thing which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commandeth, Fill an omer of it to be kept for your generations; that they may see the bread wherewith I have fed you in the wilderness, when I brought you forth from the land of Egypt.

<b>33 </b>And Moses said unto Aaron, Take a pot, and put an omer full of manna therein, and lay it up before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to be kept for your generations.

<b>34 </b>As the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded Moses, so Aaron laid it up before the Testimony, to be kept.

<b>35 </b>And the children of Israel did eat manna forty years, until they came to a land inhabited; they did eat manna, until they came unto the borders of the land of Canaan.

<b>36 </b>Now an omer <i>is</i> the tenth <i>part</i> of an ephah.


--------------------

CHAPTER 17

<b>1 </b>And all the congregation of the children of Israel journeyed from the wilderness of Sin, after their journeys, according to the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and pitched in Rephidim: and <i>there was</i> no water for the people to drink.

<b>2 </b>Wherefore the people did chide with Moses, and said, Give us water that we may drink. And Moses said unto them, Why chide ye with me? wherefore do ye tempt the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>?

<b>3 </b>And the people thirsted there for water; and the people murmured against Moses, and said, Wherefore <i>is</i> this <i>that</i> thou hast brought us up out of Egypt, to kill us and our children and our cattle with thirst?

<b>4 </b>And Moses cried unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying, What shall I do unto this people? they be almost ready to stone me.

<b>5 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Go on before the people, and take with thee of the elders of Israel; and thy rod, wherewith thou smotest the river, take in thine hand, and go.

<b>6 </b>Behold, I will stand before thee there upon the rock in Horeb; and thou shalt smite the rock, and there shall come water out of it, that the people may drink. And Moses did so in the sight of the elders of Israel.

<b>7 </b>And he called the name of the place Massah, and Meribah, because of the chiding of the children of Israel, and because they tempted the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying, Is the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> among us, or not?

<b>8 </b>¶ Then came Amalek, and fought with Israel in Rephidim.

<b>9 </b>And Moses said unto Joshua, Choose us out men, and go out, fight with Amalek: to morrow I will stand on the top of the hill with the rod of God in mine hand.

<b>10 </b>So Joshua did as Moses had said to him, and fought with Amalek: and Moses, Aaron, and Hur went up to the top of the hill.

<b>11 </b>And it came to pass, when Moses held up his hand, that Israel prevailed: and when he let down his hand, Amalek prevailed.

<b>12 </b>But Moses’ hands <i>were</i> heavy; and they took a stone, and put <i>it</i> under him, and he sat thereon; and Aaron and Hur stayed up his hands, the one on the one side, and the other on the other side; and his hands were steady until the going down of the sun.

<b>13 </b>And Joshua discomfited Amalek and his people with the edge of the sword.

<b>14 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Write this <i>for</i> a memorial in a book, and rehearse <i>it</i> in the ears of Joshua: for I will utterly put out the remembrance of Amalek from under heaven.

<b>15 </b>And Moses built an altar, and called the name of it Jehovah-nissi:

<b>16 </b>For he said, Because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath sworn <i>that</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>will have</i> war with Amalek from generation to generation.


--------------------

CHAPTER 18

<b>1 </b>When Jethro, the priest of Midian, Moses’ father in law, heard of all that God had done for Moses, and for Israel his people, <i>and</i> that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had brought Israel out of Egypt;

<b>2 </b>Then Jethro, Moses’ father in law, took Zipporah, Moses’ wife, after he had sent her back,

<b>3 </b>And her two sons; of which the name of the one <i>was</i> Gershom; for he said, I have been an alien in a strange land:

<b>4 </b>And the name of the other <i>was</i> Eliezer; for the God of my father, <i>said he, was</i> mine help, and delivered me from the sword of Pharaoh:

<b>5 </b>And Jethro, Moses’ father in law, came with his sons and his wife unto Moses into the wilderness, where he encamped at the mount of God:

<b>6 </b>And he said unto Moses, I thy father in law Jethro am come unto thee, and thy wife, and her two sons with her.

<b>7 </b>¶ And Moses went out to meet his father in law, and did obeisance, and kissed him; and they asked each other of <i>their</i> welfare; and they came into the tent.

<b>8 </b>And Moses told his father in law all that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had done unto Pharaoh and to the Egyptians for Israel’s sake, <i>and</i> all the travail that had come upon them by the way, and <i>how</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> delivered them.

<b>9 </b>And Jethro rejoiced for all the goodness which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had done to Israel, whom he had delivered out of the hand of the Egyptians.

<b>10 </b>And Jethro said, Blessed <i>be</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, who hath delivered you out of the hand of the Egyptians, and out of the hand of Pharaoh, who hath delivered the people from under the hand of the Egyptians.

<b>11 </b>Now I know that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> greater than all gods: for in the thing wherein they dealt proudly <i>he was</i> above them.

<b>12 </b>And Jethro, Moses’ father in law, took a burnt offering and sacrifices for God: and Aaron came, and all the elders of Israel, to eat bread with Moses’ father in law before God.

<b>13 </b>¶ And it came to pass on the morrow, that Moses sat to judge the people: and the people stood by Moses from the morning unto the evening.

<b>14 </b>And when Moses’ father in law saw all that he did to the people, he said, What <i>is</i> this thing that thou doest to the people? why sittest thou thyself alone, and all the people stand by thee from morning unto even?

<b>15 </b>And Moses said unto his father in law, Because the people come unto me to inquire of God:

<b>16 </b>When they have a matter, they come unto me; and I judge between one and another, and I do make <i>them</i> know the statutes of God, and his laws.

<b>17 </b>And Moses’ father in law said unto him, The thing that thou doest <i>is</i> not good.

<b>18 </b>Thou wilt surely wear away, both thou, and this people that <i>is</i> with thee: for this thing <i>is</i> too heavy for thee; thou art not able to perform it thyself alone.

<b>19 </b>Hearken now unto my voice, I will give thee counsel, and God shall be with thee: Be thou for the people to God-ward, that thou mayest bring the causes unto God:

<b>20 </b>And thou shalt teach them ordinances and laws, and shalt shew them the way wherein they must walk, and the work that they must do.

<b>21 </b>Moreover thou shalt provide out of all the people able men, such as fear God, men of truth, hating covetousness; and place <i>such</i> over them, <i>to be</i> rulers of thousands, <i>and</i> rulers of hundreds, rulers of fifties, and rulers of tens:

<b>22 </b>And let them judge the people at all seasons: and it shall be, <i>that</i> every great matter they shall bring unto thee, but every small matter they shall judge: so shall it be easier for thyself, and they shall bear <i>the burden</i> with thee.

<b>23 </b>If thou shalt do this thing, and God command thee <i>so,</i> then thou shalt be able to endure, and all this people shall also go to their place in peace.

<b>24 </b>So Moses hearkened to the voice of his father in law, and did all that he had said.

<b>25 </b>And Moses chose able men out of all Israel, and made them heads over the people, rulers of thousands, rulers of hundreds, rulers of fifties, and rulers of tens.

<b>26 </b>And they judged the people at all seasons: the hard causes they brought unto Moses, but every small matter they judged themselves.

<b>27 </b>¶ And Moses let his father in law depart; and he went his way into his own land.


--------------------

CHAPTER 19

<b>1 </b>In the third month, when the children of Israel were gone forth out of the land of Egypt, the same day came they <i>into</i> the wilderness of Sinai.

<b>2 </b>For they were departed from Rephidim, and were come <i>to</i> the desert of Sinai, and had pitched in the wilderness; and there Israel camped before the mount.

<b>3 </b>And Moses went up unto God, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> called unto him out of the mountain, saying, Thus shalt thou say to the house of Jacob, and tell the children of Israel;

<b>4 </b>Ye have seen what I did unto the Egyptians, and <i>how</i> I bare you on eagles’ wings, and brought you unto myself.

<b>5 </b>Now therefore, if ye will obey my voice indeed, and keep my covenant, then ye shall be a peculiar treasure unto me above all people: for all the earth <i>is</i> mine:

<b>6 </b>And ye shall be unto me a kingdom of priests, and an holy nation. These <i>are</i> the words which thou shalt speak unto the children of Israel.

<b>7 </b>¶ And Moses came and called for the elders of the people, and laid before their faces all these words which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded him.

<b>8 </b>And all the people answered together, and said, All that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath spoken we will do. And Moses returned the words of the people unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>9 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Lo, I come unto thee in a thick cloud, that the people may hear when I speak with thee, and believe thee for ever. And Moses told the words of the people unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>10 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Go unto the people, and sanctify them to day and to morrow, and let them wash their clothes,

<b>11 </b>And be ready against the third day: for the third day the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will come down in the sight of all the people upon mount Sinai.

<b>12 </b>And thou shalt set bounds unto the people round about, saying, Take heed to yourselves, <i>that ye</i> go <i>not</i> up into the mount, or touch the border of it: whosoever toucheth the mount shall be surely put to death:

<b>13 </b>There shall not an hand touch it, but he shall surely be stoned, or shot through; whether <i>it be</i> beast or man, it shall not live: when the trumpet soundeth long, they shall come up to the mount.

<b>14 </b>¶ And Moses went down from the mount unto the people, and sanctified the people; and they washed their clothes.

<b>15 </b>And he said unto the people, Be ready against the third day: come not at <i>your</i> wives.

<b>16 </b>¶ And it came to pass on the third day in the morning, that there were thunders and lightnings, and a thick cloud upon the mount, and the voice of the trumpet exceeding loud; so that all the people that <i>was</i> in the camp trembled.

<b>17 </b>And Moses brought forth the people out of the camp to meet with God; and they stood at the nether part of the mount.

<b>18 </b>And mount Sinai was altogether on a smoke, because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> descended upon it in fire: and the smoke thereof ascended as the smoke of a furnace, and the whole mount quaked greatly.
