<b>19 </b>And when the voice of the trumpet sounded long, and waxed louder and louder, Moses spake, and God answered him by a voice.

<b>20 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came down upon mount Sinai, on the top of the mount: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> called Moses <i>up</i> to the top of the mount; and Moses went up.

<b>21 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Go down, charge the people, lest they break through unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> to gaze, and many of them perish.

<b>22 </b>And let the priests also, which come near to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, sanctify themselves, lest the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> break forth upon them.

<b>23 </b>And Moses said unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, The people cannot come up to mount Sinai: for thou chargedst us, saying, Set bounds about the mount, and sanctify it.

<b>24 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto him, Away, get thee down, and thou shalt come up, thou, and Aaron with thee: but let not the priests and the people break through to come up unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, lest he break forth upon them.

<b>25 </b>So Moses went down unto the people, and spake unto them.


--------------------

CHAPTER 20

<b>1 </b>And God spake all these words, saying,

<b>2 </b>I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, which have brought thee out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of bondage.

<b>3 </b>Thou shalt have no other gods before me.

<b>4 </b>Thou shalt not make unto thee any graven image, or any likeness <i>of any thing</i> that <i>is</i> in heaven above, or that <i>is</i> in the earth beneath, or that <i>is</i> in the water under the earth:

<b>5 </b>Thou shalt not bow down thyself to them, nor serve them: for I the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God <i>am</i> a jealous God, visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children unto the third and fourth <i>generation</i> of them that hate me;

<b>6 </b>And shewing mercy unto thousands of them that love me, and keep my commandments.

<b>7 </b>Thou shalt not take the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God in vain; for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will not hold him guiltless that taketh his name in vain.

<b>8 </b>Remember the sabbath day, to keep it holy.

<b>9 </b>Six days shalt thou labour, and do all thy work:

<b>10 </b>But the seventh day <i>is</i> the sabbath of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God: <i>in it</i> thou shalt not do any work, thou, nor thy son, nor thy daughter, thy manservant, nor thy maidservant, nor thy cattle, nor thy stranger that <i>is</i> within thy gates:

<b>11 </b>For <i>in</i> six days the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> made heaven and earth, the sea, and all that in them <i>is,</i> and rested the seventh day: wherefore the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> blessed the sabbath day, and hallowed it.

<b>12 </b>¶ Honour thy father and thy mother: that thy days may be long upon the land which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God giveth thee.

<b>13 </b>Thou shalt not kill.

<b>14 </b>Thou shalt not commit adultery.

<b>15 </b>Thou shalt not steal.

<b>16 </b>Thou shalt not bear false witness against thy neighbour.

<b>17 </b>Thou shalt not covet thy neighbour’s house, thou shalt not covet thy neighbour’s wife, nor his manservant, nor his maidservant, nor his ox, nor his ass, nor any thing that <i>is</i> thy neighbour’s.

<b>18 </b>¶ And all the people saw the thunderings, and the lightnings, and the noise of the trumpet, and the mountain smoking: and when the people saw <i>it,</i> they removed, and stood afar off.

<b>19 </b>And they said unto Moses, Speak thou with us, and we will hear: but let not God speak with us, lest we die.

<b>20 </b>And Moses said unto the people, Fear not: for God is come to prove you, and that his fear may be before your faces, that ye sin not.

<b>21 </b>And the people stood afar off, and Moses drew near unto the thick darkness where God <i>was.</i>

<b>22 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Thus thou shalt say unto the children of Israel, Ye have seen that I have talked with you from heaven.

<b>23 </b>Ye shall not make with me gods of silver, neither shall ye make unto you gods of gold.

<b>24 </b>¶ An altar of earth thou shalt make unto me, and shalt sacrifice thereon thy burnt offerings, and thy peace offerings, thy sheep, and thine oxen: in all places where I record my name I will come unto thee, and I will bless thee.

<b>25 </b>And if thou wilt make me an altar of stone, thou shalt not build it of hewn stone: for if thou lift up thy tool upon it, thou hast polluted it.

<b>26 </b>Neither shalt thou go up by steps unto mine altar, that thy nakedness be not discovered thereon.


--------------------

CHAPTER 21

<b>1 </b>Now these <i>are</i> the judgments which thou shalt set before them.

<b>2 </b>If thou buy an Hebrew servant, six years he shall serve: and in the seventh he shall go out free for nothing.

<b>3 </b>If he came in by himself, he shall go out by himself: if he were married, then his wife shall go out with him.

<b>4 </b>If his master have given him a wife, and she have born him sons or daughters; the wife and her children shall be her master’s, and he shall go out by himself.

<b>5 </b>And if the servant shall plainly say, I love my master, my wife, and my children; I will not go out free:

<b>6 </b>Then his master shall bring him unto the judges; he shall also bring him to the door, or unto the door post; and his master shall bore his ear through with an awl; and he shall serve him for ever.

<b>7 </b>¶ And if a man sell his daughter to be a maidservant, she shall not go out as the menservants do.

<b>8 </b>If she please not her master, who hath betrothed her to himself, then shall he let her be redeemed: to sell her unto a strange nation he shall have no power, seeing he hath dealt deceitfully with her.

<b>9 </b>And if he have betrothed her unto his son, he shall deal with her after the manner of daughters.

<b>10 </b>If he take him another <i>wife;</i> her food, her raiment, and her duty of marriage, shall he not diminish.

<b>11 </b>And if he do not these three unto her, then shall she go out free without money.

<b>12 </b>¶ He that smiteth a man, so that he die, shall be surely put to death.

<b>13 </b>And if a man lie not in wait, but God deliver <i>him</i> into his hand; then I will appoint thee a place whither he shall flee.

<b>14 </b>But if a man come presumptuously upon his neighbour, to slay him with guile; thou shalt take him from mine altar, that he may die.

<b>15 </b>¶ And he that smiteth his father, or his mother, shall be surely put to death.

<b>16 </b>¶ And he that stealeth a man, and selleth him, or if he be found in his hand, he shall surely be put to death.

<b>17 </b>¶ And he that curseth his father, or his mother, shall surely be put to death.

<b>18 </b>¶ And if men strive together, and one smite another with a stone, or with <i>his</i> fist, and he die not, but keepeth <i>his</i> bed:

<b>19 </b>If he rise again, and walk abroad upon his staff, then shall he that smote <i>him</i> be quit: only he shall pay <i>for</i> the loss of his time, and shall cause <i>him</i> to be thoroughly healed.

<b>20 </b>¶ And if a man smite his servant, or his maid, with a rod, and he die under his hand; he shall be surely punished.

<b>21 </b>Notwithstanding, if he continue a day or two, he shall not be punished: for he <i>is</i> his money.

<b>22 </b>¶ If men strive, and hurt a woman with child, so that her fruit depart <i>from her,</i> and yet no mischief follow: he shall be surely punished, according as the woman’s husband will lay upon him; and he shall pay as the judges <i>determine.</i>

<b>23 </b>And if <i>any</i> mischief follow, then thou shalt give life for life,

<b>24 </b>Eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot,

<b>25 </b>Burning for burning, wound for wound, stripe for stripe.

<b>26 </b>¶ And if a man smite the eye of his servant, or the eye of his maid, that it perish; he shall let him go free for his eye’s sake.

<b>27 </b>And if he smite out his manservant’s tooth, or his maidservant’s tooth; he shall let him go free for his tooth’s sake.

<b>28 </b>¶ If an ox gore a man or a woman, that they die: then the ox shall be surely stoned, and his flesh shall not be eaten; but the owner of the ox <i>shall be</i> quit.

<b>29 </b>But if the ox were wont to push with his horn in time past, and it hath been testified to his owner, and he hath not kept him in, but that he hath killed a man or a woman; the ox shall be stoned, and his owner also shall be put to death.

<b>30 </b>If there be laid on him a sum of money, then he shall give for the ransom of his life whatsoever is laid upon him.

<b>31 </b>Whether he have gored a son, or have gored a daughter, according to this judgment shall it be done unto him.

<b>32 </b>If the ox shall push a manservant or a maidservant; he shall give unto their master thirty shekels of silver, and the ox shall be stoned.

<b>33 </b>¶ And if a man shall open a pit, or if a man shall dig a pit, and not cover it, and an ox or an ass fall therein;

<b>34 </b>The owner of the pit shall make <i>it</i> good, <i>and</i> give money unto the owner of them; and the dead <i>beast</i> shall be his.

<b>35 </b>¶ And if one man’s ox hurt another’s, that he die; then they shall sell the live ox, and divide the money of it; and the dead <i>ox</i> also they shall divide.

<b>36 </b>Or if it be known that the ox hath used to push in time past, and his owner hath not kept him in; he shall surely pay ox for ox; and the dead shall be his own.


--------------------

CHAPTER 22

<b>1 </b>If a man shall steal an ox, or a sheep, and kill it, or sell it; he shall restore five oxen for an ox, and four sheep for a sheep.

<b>2 </b>¶ If a thief be found breaking up, and be smitten that he die, <i>there shall</i> no blood <i>be shed</i> for him.

<b>3 </b>If the sun be risen upon him, <i>there shall be</i> blood <i>shed</i> for him; <i>for</i> he should make full restitution; if he have nothing, then he shall be sold for his theft.

<b>4 </b>If the theft be certainly found in his hand alive, whether it be ox, or ass, or sheep; he shall restore double.

<b>5 </b>¶ If a man shall cause a field or vineyard to be eaten, and shall put in his beast, and shall feed in another man’s field; of the best of his own field, and of the best of his own vineyard, shall he make restitution.

<b>6 </b>¶ If fire break out, and catch in thorns, so that the stacks of corn, or the standing corn, or the field, be consumed <i>therewith;</i> he that kindled the fire shall surely make restitution.

<b>7 </b>¶ If a man shall deliver unto his neighbour money or stuff to keep, and it be stolen out of the man’s house; if the thief be found, let him pay double.

<b>8 </b>If the thief be not found, then the master of the house shall be brought unto the judges, <i>to see</i> whether he have put his hand unto his neighbour’s goods.

<b>9 </b>For all manner of trespass, <i>whether it be</i> for ox, for ass, for sheep, for raiment, <i>or</i> for any manner of lost thing, which <i>another</i> challengeth to be his, the cause of both parties shall come before the judges; <i>and</i> whom the judges shall condemn, he shall pay double unto his neighbour.

<b>10 </b>If a man deliver unto his neighbour an ass, or an ox, or a sheep, or any beast, to keep; and it die, or be hurt, or driven away, no man seeing <i>it:</i>

<b>11 </b><i>Then</i> shall an oath of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> be between them both, that he hath not put his hand unto his neighbour’s goods; and the owner of it shall accept <i>thereof,</i> and he shall not make <i>it</i> good.

<b>12 </b>And if it be stolen from him, he shall make restitution unto the owner thereof.

<b>13 </b>If it be torn in pieces, <i>then</i> let him bring it <i>for</i> witness, <i>and</i> he shall not make good that which was torn.

<b>14 </b>¶ And if a man borrow <i>ought</i> of his neighbour, and it be hurt, or die, the owner thereof <i>being</i> not with it, he shall surely make <i>it</i> good.

<b>15 </b><i>But</i> if the owner thereof <i>be</i> with it, he shall not make <i>it</i> good: if it <i>be</i> an hired <i>thing,</i> it came for his hire.

<b>16 </b>¶ And if a man entice a maid that is not betrothed, and lie with her, he shall surely endow her to be his wife.

<b>17 </b>If her father utterly refuse to give her unto him, he shall pay money according to the dowry of virgins.

<b>18 </b>¶ Thou shalt not suffer a witch to live.

<b>19 </b>¶ Whosoever lieth with a beast shall surely be put to death.

<b>20 </b>¶ He that sacrificeth unto <i>any</i> god, save unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> only, he shall be utterly destroyed.

<b>21 </b>¶ Thou shalt neither vex a stranger, nor oppress him: for ye were strangers in the land of Egypt.

<b>22 </b>¶ Ye shall not afflict any widow, or fatherless child.

<b>23 </b>If thou afflict them in any wise, and they cry at all unto me, I will surely hear their cry;

<b>24 </b>And my wrath shall wax hot, and I will kill you with the sword; and your wives shall be widows, and your children fatherless.

<b>25 </b>¶ If thou lend money to <i>any of</i> my people <i>that is</i> poor by thee, thou shalt not be to him as an usurer, neither shalt thou lay upon him usury.

<b>26 </b>If thou at all take thy neighbour’s raiment to pledge, thou shalt deliver it unto him by that the sun goeth down:

<b>27 </b>For that <i>is</i> his covering only, it <i>is</i> his raiment for his skin: wherein shall he sleep? and it shall come to pass, when he crieth unto me, that I will hear; for I <i>am</i> gracious.

<b>28 </b>¶ Thou shalt not revile the gods, nor curse the ruler of thy people.

<b>29 </b>¶ Thou shalt not delay <i>to offer</i> the first of thy ripe fruits, and of thy liquors: the firstborn of thy sons shalt thou give unto me.

<b>30 </b>Likewise shalt thou do with thine oxen, <i>and</i> with thy sheep: seven days it shall be with his dam; on the eighth day thou shalt give it me.

<b>31 </b>¶ And ye shall be holy men unto me: neither shall ye eat <i>any</i> flesh <i>that is</i> torn of beasts in the field; ye shall cast it to the dogs.


--------------------

CHAPTER 23

<b>1 </b>Thou shalt not raise a false report: put not thine hand with the wicked to be an unrighteous witness.

<b>2 </b>¶ Thou shalt not follow a multitude to <i>do</i> evil; neither shalt thou speak in a cause to decline after many to wrest <i>judgment:</i>

<b>3 </b>¶ Neither shalt thou countenance a poor man in his cause.

<b>4 </b>¶ If thou meet thine enemy’s ox or his ass going astray, thou shalt surely bring it back to him again.

<b>5 </b>If thou see the ass of him that hateth thee lying under his burden, and wouldest forbear to help him, thou shalt surely help with him.

<b>6 </b>Thou shalt not wrest the judgment of thy poor in his cause.

<b>7 </b>Keep thee far from a false matter; and the innocent and righteous slay thou not: for I will not justify the wicked.

<b>8 </b>¶ And thou shalt take no gift: for the gift blindeth the wise, and perverteth the words of the righteous.

<b>9 </b>¶ Also thou shalt not oppress a stranger: for ye know the heart of a stranger, seeing ye were strangers in the land of Egypt.

<b>10 </b>And six years thou shalt sow thy land, and shalt gather in the fruits thereof:

<b>11 </b>But the seventh <i>year</i> thou shalt let it rest and lie still; that the poor of thy people may eat: and what they leave the beasts of the field shall eat. In like manner thou shalt deal with thy vineyard, <i>and</i> with thy oliveyard.

<b>12 </b>Six days thou shalt do thy work, and on the seventh day thou shalt rest: that thine ox and thine ass may rest, and the son of thy handmaid, and the stranger, may be refreshed.

<b>13 </b>And in all <i>things</i> that I have said unto you be circumspect: and make no mention of the name of other gods, neither let it be heard out of thy mouth.

<b>14 </b>¶ Three times thou shalt keep a feast unto me in the year.

<b>15 </b>Thou shalt keep the feast of unleavened bread: (thou shalt eat unleavened bread seven days, as I commanded thee, in the time appointed of the month Abib; for in it thou camest out from Egypt: and none shall appear before me empty:)

<b>16 </b>And the feast of harvest, the firstfruits of thy labours, which thou hast sown in the field: and the feast of ingathering, <i>which is</i> in the end of the year, when thou hast gathered in thy labours out of the field.

<b>17 </b>Three times in the year all thy males shall appear before the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>.

<b>18 </b>Thou shalt not offer the blood of my sacrifice with leavened bread; neither shall the fat of my sacrifice remain until the morning.

<b>19 </b>The first of the firstfruits of thy land thou shalt bring into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God. Thou shalt not seethe a kid in his mother’s milk.

<b>20 </b>¶ Behold, I send an Angel before thee, to keep thee in the way, and to bring thee into the place which I have prepared.

<b>21 </b>Beware of him, and obey his voice, provoke him not; for he will not pardon your transgressions: for my name <i>is</i> in him.

<b>22 </b>But if thou shalt indeed obey his voice, and do all that I speak; then I will be an enemy unto thine enemies, and an adversary unto thine adversaries.

<b>23 </b>For mine Angel shall go before thee, and bring thee in unto the Amorites, and the Hittites, and the Perizzites, and the Canaanites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites: and I will cut them off.

<b>24 </b>Thou shalt not bow down to their gods, nor serve them, nor do after their works: but thou shalt utterly overthrow them, and quite break down their images.

<b>25 </b>And ye shall serve the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, and he shall bless thy bread, and thy water; and I will take sickness away from the midst of thee.

<b>26 </b>¶ There shall nothing cast their young, nor be barren, in thy land: the number of thy days I will fulfil.

<b>27 </b>I will send my fear before thee, and will destroy all the people to whom thou shalt come, and I will make all thine enemies turn their backs unto thee.

<b>28 </b>And I will send hornets before thee, which shall drive out the Hivite, the Canaanite, and the Hittite, from before thee.

<b>29 </b>I will not drive them out from before thee in one year; lest the land become desolate, and the beast of the field multiply against thee.

<b>30 </b>By little and little I will drive them out from before thee, until thou be increased, and inherit the land.

<b>31 </b>And I will set thy bounds from the Red sea even unto the sea of the Philistines, and from the desert unto the river: for I will deliver the inhabitants of the land into your hand; and thou shalt drive them out before thee.

<b>32 </b>Thou shalt make no covenant with them, nor with their gods.

<b>33 </b>They shall not dwell in thy land, lest they make thee sin against me: for if thou serve their gods, it will surely be a snare unto thee.


--------------------

CHAPTER 24

<b>1 </b>And he said unto Moses, Come up unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, thou, and Aaron, Nadab, and Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel; and worship ye afar off.

<b>2 </b>And Moses alone shall come near the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: but they shall not come nigh; neither shall the people go up with him.

<b>3 </b>¶ And Moses came and told the people all the words of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and all the judgments: and all the people answered with one voice, and said, All the words which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath said will we do.

<b>4 </b>And Moses wrote all the words of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and rose up early in the morning, and builded an altar under the hill, and twelve pillars, according to the twelve tribes of Israel.

<b>5 </b>And he sent young men of the children of Israel, which offered burnt offerings, and sacrificed peace offerings of oxen unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>6 </b>And Moses took half of the blood, and put <i>it</i> in basins; and half of the blood he sprinkled on the altar.

<b>7 </b>And he took the book of the covenant, and read in the audience of the people: and they said, All that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath said will we do, and be obedient.

<b>8 </b>And Moses took the blood, and sprinkled <i>it</i> on the people, and said, Behold the blood of the covenant, which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath made with you concerning all these words.

<b>9 </b>¶ Then went up Moses, and Aaron, Nadab, and Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel:

<b>10 </b>And they saw the God of Israel: and <i>there was</i> under his feet as it were a paved work of a sapphire stone, and as it were the body of heaven in <i>his</i> clearness.

<b>11 </b>And upon the nobles of the children of Israel he laid not his hand: also they saw God, and did eat and drink.

<b>12 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Come up to me into the mount, and be there: and I will give thee tables of stone, and a law, and commandments which I have written; that thou mayest teach them.

<b>13 </b>And Moses rose up, and his minister Joshua: and Moses went up into the mount of God.

<b>14 </b>And he said unto the elders, Tarry ye here for us, until we come again unto you: and, behold, Aaron and Hur <i>are</i> with you: if any man have any matters to do, let him come unto them.

<b>15 </b>And Moses went up into the mount, and a cloud covered the mount.

<b>16 </b>And the glory of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> abode upon mount Sinai, and the cloud covered it six days: and the seventh day he called unto Moses out of the midst of the cloud.

<b>17 </b>And the sight of the glory of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>was</i> like devouring fire on the top of the mount in the eyes of the children of Israel.

<b>18 </b>And Moses went into the midst of the cloud, and gat him up into the mount: and Moses was in the mount forty days and forty nights.


--------------------

CHAPTER 25

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>2 </b>Speak unto the children of Israel, that they bring me an offering: of every man that giveth it willingly with his heart ye shall take my offering.

<b>3 </b>And this <i>is</i> the offering which ye shall take of them; gold, and silver, and brass,

<b>4 </b>And blue, and purple, and scarlet, and fine linen, and goats’ <i>hair,</i>

<b>5 </b>And rams’ skins dyed red, and badgers’ skins, and shittim wood,

<b>6 </b>Oil for the light, spices for anointing oil, and for sweet incense,

<b>7 </b>Onyx stones, and stones to be set in the ephod, and in the breastplate.

<b>8 </b>And let them make me a sanctuary; that I may dwell among them.

<b>9 </b>According to all that I shew thee, <i>after</i> the pattern of the tabernacle, and the pattern of all the instruments thereof, even so shall ye make <i>it.</i>

<b>10 </b>¶ And they shall make an ark <i>of</i> shittim wood: two cubits and a half <i>shall be</i> the length thereof, and a cubit and a half the breadth thereof, and a cubit and a half the height thereof.

<b>11 </b>And thou shalt overlay it with pure gold, within and without shalt thou overlay it, and shalt make upon it a crown of gold round about.

<b>12 </b>And thou shalt cast four rings of gold for it, and put <i>them</i> in the four corners thereof; and two rings <i>shall be</i> in the one side of it, and two rings in the other side of it.

<b>13 </b>And thou shalt make staves <i>of</i> shittim wood, and overlay them with gold.

<b>14 </b>And thou shalt put the staves into the rings by the sides of the ark, that the ark may be borne with them.

<b>15 </b>The staves shall be in the rings of the ark: they shall not be taken from it.

<b>16 </b>And thou shalt put into the ark the testimony which I shall give thee.

<b>17 </b>And thou shalt make a mercy seat <i>of</i> pure gold: two cubits and a half <i>shall be</i> the length thereof, and a cubit and a half the breadth thereof.

<b>18 </b>And thou shalt make two cherubims <i>of</i> gold, <i>of</i> beaten work shalt thou make them, in the two ends of the mercy seat.

<b>19 </b>And make one cherub on the one end, and the other cherub on the other end: <i>even</i> of the mercy seat shall ye make the cherubims on the two ends thereof.

<b>20 </b>And the cherubims shall stretch forth <i>their</i> wings on high, covering the mercy seat with their wings, and their faces <i>shall look</i> one to another; toward the mercy seat shall the faces of the cherubims be.

<b>21 </b>And thou shalt put the mercy seat above upon the ark; and in the ark thou shalt put the testimony that I shall give thee.

<b>22 </b>And there I will meet with thee, and I will commune with thee from above the mercy seat, from between the two cherubims which <i>are</i> upon the ark of the testimony, of all <i>things</i> which I will give thee in commandment unto the children of Israel.

<b>23 </b>¶ Thou shalt also make a table <i>of</i> shittim wood: two cubits <i>shall be</i> the length thereof, and a cubit the breadth thereof, and a cubit and a half the height thereof.

<b>24 </b>And thou shalt overlay it with pure gold, and make thereto a crown of gold round about.

<b>25 </b>And thou shalt make unto it a border of an hand breadth round about, and thou shalt make a golden crown to the border thereof round about.

<b>26 </b>And thou shalt make for it four rings of gold, and put the rings in the four corners that <i>are</i> on the four feet thereof.

<b>27 </b>Over against the border shall the rings be for places of the staves to bear the table.

<b>28 </b>And thou shalt make the staves <i>of</i> shittim wood, and overlay them with gold, that the table may be borne with them.

<b>29 </b>And thou shalt make the dishes thereof, and spoons thereof, and covers thereof, and bowls thereof, to cover withal: <i>of</i> pure gold shalt thou make them.

<b>30 </b>And thou shalt set upon the table shewbread before me alway.

<b>31 </b>¶ And thou shalt make a candlestick <i>of</i> pure gold: <i>of</i> beaten work shall the candlestick be made: his shaft, and his branches, his bowls, his knops, and his flowers, shall be of the same.

<b>32 </b>And six branches shall come out of the sides of it; three branches of the candlestick out of the one side, and three branches of the candlestick out of the other side:

<b>33 </b>Three bowls made like unto almonds, <i>with</i> a knop and a flower in one branch; and three bowls made like almonds in the other branch, <i>with</i> a knop and a flower: so in the six branches that come out of the candlestick.

<b>34 </b>And in the candlestick <i>shall be</i> four bowls made like unto almonds, <i>with</i> their knops and their flowers.

<b>35 </b>And <i>there shall be</i> a knop under two branches of the same, and a knop under two branches of the same, and a knop under two branches of the same, according to the six branches that proceed out of the candlestick.

<b>36 </b>Their knops and their branches shall be of the same: all it <i>shall be</i> one beaten work <i>of</i> pure gold.

<b>37 </b>And thou shalt make the seven lamps thereof: and they shall light the lamps thereof, that they may give light over against it.

<b>38 </b>And the tongs thereof, and the snuffdishes thereof, <i>shall be of</i> pure gold.

<b>39 </b><i>Of</i> a talent of pure gold shall he make it, with all these vessels.

<b>40 </b>And look that thou make <i>them</i> after their pattern, which was shewed thee in the mount.


--------------------

CHAPTER 26

<b>1 </b>Moreover thou shalt make the tabernacle <i>with</i> ten curtains <i>of</i> fine twined linen, and blue, and purple, and scarlet: <i>with</i> cherubims of cunning work shalt thou make them.

<b>2 </b>The length of one curtain <i>shall be</i> eight and twenty cubits, and the breadth of one curtain four cubits: and every one of the curtains shall have one measure.

<b>3 </b>The five curtains shall be coupled together one to another; and <i>other</i> five curtains <i>shall be</i> coupled one to another.

<b>4 </b>And thou shalt make loops of blue upon the edge of the one curtain from the selvedge in the coupling; and likewise shalt thou make in the uttermost edge of <i>another</i> curtain, in the coupling of the second.

<b>5 </b>Fifty loops shalt thou make in the one curtain, and fifty loops shalt thou make in the edge of the curtain that <i>is</i> in the coupling of the second; that the loops may take hold one of another.

<b>6 </b>And thou shalt make fifty taches of gold, and couple the curtains together with the taches: and it shall be one tabernacle.

<b>7 </b>¶ And thou shalt make curtains <i>of</i> goats’ <i>hair</i> to be a covering upon the tabernacle: eleven curtains shalt thou make.

<b>8 </b>The length of one curtain <i>shall be</i> thirty cubits, and the breadth of one curtain four cubits: and the eleven curtains <i>shall be all</i> of one measure.

<b>9 </b>And thou shalt couple five curtains by themselves, and six curtains by themselves, and shalt double the sixth curtain in the forefront of the tabernacle.

<b>10 </b>And thou shalt make fifty loops on the edge of the one curtain <i>that is</i> outmost in the coupling, and fifty loops in the edge of the curtain which coupleth the second.

<b>11 </b>And thou shalt make fifty taches of brass, and put the taches into the loops, and couple the tent together, that it may be one.

<b>12 </b>And the remnant that remaineth of the curtains of the tent, the half curtain that remaineth, shall hang over the backside of the tabernacle.

<b>13 </b>And a cubit on the one side, and a cubit on the other side of that which remaineth in the length of the curtains of the tent, it shall hang over the sides of the tabernacle on this side and on that side, to cover it.

<b>14 </b>And thou shalt make a covering for the tent <i>of</i> rams’ skins dyed red, and a covering above <i>of</i> badgers’ skins.

<b>15 </b>¶ And thou shalt make boards for the tabernacle <i>of</i> shittim wood standing up.

<b>16 </b>Ten cubits <i>shall be</i> the length of a board, and a cubit and a half <i>shall be</i> the breadth of one board.

<b>17 </b>Two tenons <i>shall there be</i> in one board, set in order one against another: thus shalt thou make for all the boards of the tabernacle.

<b>18 </b>And thou shalt make the boards for the tabernacle, twenty boards on the south side southward.

<b>19 </b>And thou shalt make forty sockets of silver under the twenty boards; two sockets under one board for his two tenons, and two sockets under another board for his two tenons.

<b>20 </b>And for the second side of the tabernacle on the north side <i>there shall be</i> twenty boards:

<b>21 </b>And their forty sockets <i>of</i> silver; two sockets under one board, and two sockets under another board.

<b>22 </b>And for the sides of the tabernacle westward thou shalt make six boards.

<b>23 </b>And two boards shalt thou make for the corners of the tabernacle in the two sides.

<b>24 </b>And they shall be coupled together beneath, and they shall be coupled together above the head of it unto one ring: thus shall it be for them both; they shall be for the two corners.

<b>25 </b>And they shall be eight boards, and their sockets <i>of</i> silver, sixteen sockets; two sockets under one board, and two sockets under another board.

<b>26 </b>¶ And thou shalt make bars <i>of</i> shittim wood; five for the boards of the one side of the tabernacle,

<b>27 </b>And five bars for the boards of the other side of the tabernacle, and five bars for the boards of the side of the tabernacle, for the two sides westward.

<b>28 </b>And the middle bar in the midst of the boards shall reach from end to end.

<b>29 </b>And thou shalt overlay the boards with gold, and make their rings <i>of</i> gold <i>for</i> places for the bars: and thou shalt overlay the bars with gold.

<b>30 </b>And thou shalt rear up the tabernacle according to the fashion thereof which was shewed thee in the mount.

<b>31 </b>¶ And thou shalt make a veil <i>of</i> blue, and purple, and scarlet, and fine twined linen of cunning work: with cherubims shall it be made:

<b>32 </b>And thou shalt hang it upon four pillars of shittim <i>wood</i> overlaid with gold: their hooks <i>shall be of</i> gold, upon the four sockets of silver.

<b>33 </b>¶ And thou shalt hang up the veil under the taches, that thou mayest bring in thither within the veil the ark of the testimony: and the veil shall divide unto you between the holy <i>place</i> and the most holy.

<b>34 </b>And thou shalt put the mercy seat upon the ark of the testimony in the most holy <i>place.</i>

<b>35 </b>And thou shalt set the table without the veil, and the candlestick over against the table on the side of the tabernacle toward the south: and thou shalt put the table on the north side.

<b>36 </b>And thou shalt make an hanging for the door of the tent, <i>of</i> blue, and purple, and scarlet, and fine twined linen, wrought with needlework.

<b>37 </b>And thou shalt make for the hanging five pillars <i>of</i> shittim <i>wood,</i> and overlay them with gold, <i>and</i> their hooks <i>shall be of</i> gold: and thou shalt cast five sockets of brass for them.


--------------------

CHAPTER 27

<b>1 </b>And thou shalt make an altar <i>of</i> shittim wood, five cubits long, and five cubits broad; the altar shall be foursquare: and the height thereof <i>shall be</i> three cubits.

<b>2 </b>And thou shalt make the horns of it upon the four corners thereof: his horns shall be of the same: and thou shalt overlay it with brass.

<b>3 </b>And thou shalt make his pans to receive his ashes, and his shovels, and his basins, and his fleshhooks, and his firepans: all the vessels thereof thou shalt make <i>of</i> brass.

<b>4 </b>And thou shalt make for it a grate of network <i>of</i> brass; and upon the net shalt thou make four brasen rings in the four corners thereof.

<b>5 </b>And thou shalt put it under the compass of the altar beneath, that the net may be even to the midst of the altar.

<b>6 </b>And thou shalt make staves for the altar, staves <i>of</i> shittim wood, and overlay them with brass.

<b>7 </b>And the staves shall be put into the rings, and the staves shall be upon the two sides of the altar, to bear it.

<b>8 </b>Hollow with boards shalt thou make it: as it was shewed thee in the mount, so shall they make <i>it.</i>

<b>9 </b>¶ And thou shalt make the court of the tabernacle: for the south side southward <i>there shall be</i> hangings for the court <i>of</i> fine twined linen of an hundred cubits long for one side:

<b>10 </b>And the twenty pillars thereof and their twenty sockets <i>shall be of</i> brass; the hooks of the pillars and their fillets <i>shall be of</i> silver.

<b>11 </b>And likewise for the north side in length <i>there shall be</i> hangings of an hundred <i>cubits</i> long, and his twenty pillars and their twenty sockets <i>of</i> brass; the hooks of the pillars and their fillets <i>of</i> silver.

<b>12 </b>¶ And <i>for</i> the breadth of the court on the west side <i>shall be</i> hangings of fifty cubits: their pillars ten, and their sockets ten.

<b>13 </b>And the breadth of the court on the east side eastward <i>shall be</i> fifty cubits.

<b>14 </b>The hangings of one side <i>of the gate shall be</i> fifteen cubits: their pillars three, and their sockets three.

<b>15 </b>And on the other side <i>shall be</i> hangings fifteen <i>cubits:</i> their pillars three, and their sockets three.

<b>16 </b>¶ And for the gate of the court <i>shall be</i> an hanging of twenty cubits, <i>of</i> blue, and purple, and scarlet, and fine twined linen, wrought with needlework: <i>and</i> their pillars <i>shall be</i> four, and their sockets four.

<b>17 </b>All the pillars round about the court <i>shall be</i> filleted with silver; their hooks <i>shall be of</i> silver, and their sockets <i>of</i> brass.

<b>18 </b>¶ The length of the court <i>shall be</i> an hundred cubits, and the breadth fifty every where, and the height five cubits <i>of</i> fine twined linen, and their sockets <i>of</i> brass.

<b>19 </b>All the vessels of the tabernacle in all the service thereof, and all the pins thereof, and all the pins of the court, <i>shall be of</i> brass.

<b>20 </b>¶ And thou shalt command the children of Israel, that they bring thee pure oil olive beaten for the light, to cause the lamp to burn always.

<b>21 </b>In the tabernacle of the congregation without the veil, which <i>is</i> before the testimony, Aaron and his sons shall order it from evening to morning before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: <i>it shall be</i> a statute for ever unto their generations on the behalf of the children of Israel.


--------------------

CHAPTER 28

<b>1 </b>And take thou unto thee Aaron thy brother, and his sons with him, from among the children of Israel, that he may minister unto me in the priest’s office, <i>even</i> Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar, Aaron’s sons.

<b>2 </b>And thou shalt make holy garments for Aaron thy brother for glory and for beauty.

<b>3 </b>And thou shalt speak unto all <i>that are</i> wise hearted, whom I have filled with the spirit of wisdom, that they may make Aaron’s garments to consecrate him, that he may minister unto me in the priest’s office.

<b>4 </b>And these <i>are</i> the garments which they shall make; a breastplate, and an ephod, and a robe, and a broidered coat, a mitre, and a girdle: and they shall make holy garments for Aaron thy brother, and his sons, that he may minister unto me in the priest’s office.

<b>5 </b>And they shall take gold, and blue, and purple, and scarlet, and fine linen.

<b>6 </b>¶ And they shall make the ephod <i>of</i> gold, <i>of</i> blue, and <i>of</i> purple, <i>of</i> scarlet, and fine twined linen, with cunning work.

<b>7 </b>It shall have the two shoulderpieces thereof joined at the two edges thereof; and <i>so</i> it shall be joined together.

<b>8 </b>And the curious girdle of the ephod, which <i>is</i> upon it, shall be of the same, according to the work thereof; <i>even of</i> gold, <i>of</i> blue, and purple, and scarlet, and fine twined linen.

<b>9 </b>And thou shalt take two onyx stones, and grave on them the names of the children of Israel:

<b>10 </b>Six of their names on one stone, and <i>the other</i> six names of the rest on the other stone, according to their birth.

<b>11 </b>With the work of an engraver in stone, <i>like</i> the engravings of a signet, shalt thou engrave the two stones with the names of the children of Israel: thou shalt make them to be set in ouches of gold.

<b>12 </b>And thou shalt put the two stones upon the shoulders of the ephod <i>for</i> stones of memorial unto the children of Israel: and Aaron shall bear their names before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> upon his two shoulders for a memorial.

<b>13 </b>¶ And thou shalt make ouches <i>of</i> gold;

<b>14 </b>And two chains <i>of</i> pure gold at the ends; <i>of</i> wreathen work shalt thou make them, and fasten the wreathen chains to the ouches.

<b>15 </b>¶ And thou shalt make the breastplate of judgment with cunning work; after the work of the ephod thou shalt make it; <i>of</i> gold, <i>of</i> blue, and <i>of</i> purple, and <i>of</i> scarlet, and <i>of</i> fine twined linen, shalt thou make it.

<b>16 </b>Foursquare it shall be <i>being</i> doubled; a span <i>shall be</i> the length thereof, and a span <i>shall be</i> the breadth thereof.

<b>17 </b>And thou shalt set in it settings of stones, <i>even</i> four rows of stones: <i>the first</i> row <i>shall be</i> a sardius, a topaz, and a carbuncle: <i>this shall be</i> the first row.

<b>18 </b>And the second row <i>shall be</i> an emerald, a sapphire, and a diamond.

<b>19 </b>And the third row a ligure, an agate, and an amethyst.

<b>20 </b>And the fourth row a beryl, and an onyx, and a jasper: they shall be set in gold in their inclosings.

<b>21 </b>And the stones shall be with the names of the children of Israel, twelve, according to their names, <i>like</i> the engravings of a signet; every one with his name shall they be according to the twelve tribes.

<b>22 </b>¶ And thou shalt make upon the breastplate chains at the ends <i>of</i> wreathen work <i>of</i> pure gold.

<b>23 </b>And thou shalt make upon the breastplate two rings of gold, and shalt put the two rings on the two ends of the breastplate.

<b>24 </b>And thou shalt put the two wreathen <i>chains</i> of gold in the two rings <i>which are</i> on the ends of the breastplate.

<b>25 </b>And <i>the other</i> two ends of the two wreathen <i>chains</i> thou shalt fasten in the two ouches, and put <i>them</i> on the shoulderpieces of the ephod before it.

<b>26 </b>¶ And thou shalt make two rings of gold, and thou shalt put them upon the two ends of the breastplate in the border thereof, which <i>is</i> in the side of the ephod inward.

<b>27 </b>And two <i>other</i> rings of gold thou shalt make, and shalt put them on the two sides of the ephod underneath, toward the forepart thereof, over against the <i>other</i> coupling thereof, above the curious girdle of the ephod.

<b>28 </b>And they shall bind the breastplate by the rings thereof unto the rings of the ephod with a lace of blue, that <i>it</i> may be above the curious girdle of the ephod, and that the breastplate be not loosed from the ephod.

<b>29 </b>And Aaron shall bear the names of the children of Israel in the breastplate of judgment upon his heart, when he goeth in unto the holy <i>place,</i> for a memorial before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> continually.

<b>30 </b>¶ And thou shalt put in the breastplate of judgment the Urim and the Thummim; and they shall be upon Aaron’s heart, when he goeth in before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and Aaron shall bear the judgment of the children of Israel upon his heart before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> continually.

<b>31 </b>¶ And thou shalt make the robe of the ephod all <i>of</i> blue.

<b>32 </b>And there shall be an hole in the top of it, in the midst thereof: it shall have a binding of woven work round about the hole of it, as it were the hole of an habergeon, that it be not rent.

<b>33 </b>¶ And <i>beneath</i> upon the hem of it thou shalt make pomegranates <i>of</i> blue, and <i>of</i> purple, and <i>of</i> scarlet, round about the hem thereof; and bells of gold between them round about:

<b>34 </b>A golden bell and a pomegranate, a golden bell and a pomegranate, upon the hem of the robe round about.

<b>35 </b>And it shall be upon Aaron to minister: and his sound shall be heard when he goeth in unto the holy <i>place</i> before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and when he cometh out, that he die not.

<b>36 </b>¶ And thou shalt make a plate <i>of</i> pure gold, and grave upon it, <i>like</i> the engravings of a signet, <span class="uppercase">Holiness to the Lord</span>.

<b>37 </b>And thou shalt put it on a blue lace, that it may be upon the mitre; upon the forefront of the mitre it shall be.

<b>38 </b>And it shall be upon Aaron’s forehead, that Aaron may bear the iniquity of the holy things, which the children of Israel shall hallow in all their holy gifts; and it shall be always upon his forehead, that they may be accepted before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>39 </b>¶ And thou shalt embroider the coat of fine linen, and thou shalt make the mitre <i>of</i> fine linen, and thou shalt make the girdle <i>of</i> needlework.

<b>40 </b>¶ And for Aaron’s sons thou shalt make coats, and thou shalt make for them girdles, and bonnets shalt thou make for them, for glory and for beauty.

<b>41 </b>And thou shalt put them upon Aaron thy brother, and his sons with him; and shalt anoint them, and consecrate them, and sanctify them, that they may minister unto me in the priest’s office.

<b>42 </b>And thou shalt make them linen breeches to cover their nakedness; from the loins even unto the thighs they shall reach:

<b>43 </b>And they shall be upon Aaron, and upon his sons, when they come in unto the tabernacle of the congregation, or when they come near unto the altar to minister in the holy <i>place;</i> that they bear not iniquity, and die: <i>it shall be</i> a statute for ever unto him and his seed after him.


--------------------

CHAPTER 29

<b>1 </b>And this <i>is</i> the thing that thou shalt do unto them to hallow them, to minister unto me in the priest’s office: Take one young bullock, and two rams without blemish,

<b>2 </b>And unleavened bread, and cakes unleavened tempered with oil, and wafers unleavened anointed with oil: <i>of</i> wheaten flour shalt thou make them.

<b>3 </b>And thou shalt put them into one basket, and bring them in the basket, with the bullock and the two rams.

<b>4 </b>And Aaron and his sons thou shalt bring unto the door of the tabernacle of the congregation, and shalt wash them with water.

<b>5 </b>And thou shalt take the garments, and put upon Aaron the coat, and the robe of the ephod, and the ephod, and the breastplate, and gird him with the curious girdle of the ephod:

<b>6 </b>And thou shalt put the mitre upon his head, and put the holy crown upon the mitre.

<b>7 </b>Then shalt thou take the anointing oil, and pour <i>it</i> upon his head, and anoint him.

<b>8 </b>And thou shalt bring his sons, and put coats upon them.

<b>9 </b>And thou shalt gird them with girdles, Aaron and his sons, and put the bonnets on them: and the priest’s office shall be theirs for a perpetual statute: and thou shalt consecrate Aaron and his sons.

<b>10 </b>And thou shalt cause a bullock to be brought before the tabernacle of the congregation: and Aaron and his sons shall put their hands upon the head of the bullock.

<b>11 </b>And thou shalt kill the bullock before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>by</i> the door of the tabernacle of the congregation.

<b>12 </b>And thou shalt take of the blood of the bullock, and put <i>it</i> upon the horns of the altar with thy finger, and pour all the blood beside the bottom of the altar.

<b>13 </b>And thou shalt take all the fat that covereth the inwards, and the caul <i>that is</i> above the liver, and the two kidneys, and the fat that <i>is</i> upon them, and burn <i>them</i> upon the altar.

<b>14 </b>But the flesh of the bullock, and his skin, and his dung, shalt thou burn with fire without the camp: it <i>is</i> a sin offering.

<b>15 </b>¶ Thou shalt also take one ram; and Aaron and his sons shall put their hands upon the head of the ram.

<b>16 </b>And thou shalt slay the ram, and thou shalt take his blood, and sprinkle <i>it</i> round about upon the altar.

<b>17 </b>And thou shalt cut the ram in pieces, and wash the inwards of him, and his legs, and put <i>them</i> unto his pieces, and unto his head.

<b>18 </b>And thou shalt burn the whole ram upon the altar: it <i>is</i> a burnt offering unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: it <i>is</i> a sweet savour, an offering made by fire unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>19 </b>¶ And thou shalt take the other ram; and Aaron and his sons shall put their hands upon the head of the ram.

<b>20 </b>Then shalt thou kill the ram, and take of his blood, and put <i>it</i> upon the tip of the right ear of Aaron, and upon the tip of the right ear of his sons, and upon the thumb of their right hand, and upon the great toe of their right foot, and sprinkle the blood upon the altar round about.

<b>21 </b>And thou shalt take of the blood that <i>is</i> upon the altar, and of the anointing oil, and sprinkle <i>it</i> upon Aaron, and upon his garments, and upon his sons, and upon the garments of his sons with him: and he shall be hallowed, and his garments, and his sons, and his sons’ garments with him.

<b>22 </b>Also thou shalt take of the ram the fat and the rump, and the fat that covereth the inwards, and the caul <i>above</i> the liver, and the two kidneys, and the fat that <i>is</i> upon them, and the right shoulder; for it <i>is</i> a ram of consecration:

<b>23 </b>And one loaf of bread, and one cake of oiled bread, and one wafer out of the basket of the unleavened bread that <i>is</i> before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>:

<b>24 </b>And thou shalt put all in the hands of Aaron, and in the hands of his sons; and shalt wave them <i>for</i> a wave offering before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>25 </b>And thou shalt receive them of their hands, and burn <i>them</i> upon the altar for a burnt offering, for a sweet savour before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: it <i>is</i> an offering made by fire unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>26 </b>And thou shalt take the breast of the ram of Aaron’s consecration, and wave it <i>for</i> a wave offering before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and it shall be thy part.

<b>27 </b>And thou shalt sanctify the breast of the wave offering, and the shoulder of the heave offering, which is waved, and which is heaved up, of the ram of the consecration, <i>even</i> of <i>that</i> which <i>is</i> for Aaron, and of <i>that</i> which is for his sons:

<b>28 </b>And it shall be Aaron’s and his sons’ by a statute for ever from the children of Israel: for it <i>is</i> an heave offering: and it shall be an heave offering from the children of Israel of the sacrifice of their peace offerings, <i>even</i> their heave offering unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>29 </b>¶ And the holy garments of Aaron shall be his sons’ after him, to be anointed therein, and to be consecrated in them.

<b>30 </b><i>And</i> that son that is priest in his stead shall put them on seven days, when he cometh into the tabernacle of the congregation to minister in the holy <i>place.</i>

<b>31 </b>¶ And thou shalt take the ram of the consecration, and seethe his flesh in the holy place.

<b>32 </b>And Aaron and his sons shall eat the flesh of the ram, and the bread that <i>is</i> in the basket, <i>by</i> the door of the tabernacle of the congregation.

<b>33 </b>And they shall eat those things wherewith the atonement was made, to consecrate <i>and</i> to sanctify them: but a stranger shall not eat <i>thereof,</i> because they <i>are</i> holy.

<b>34 </b>And if ought of the flesh of the consecrations, or of the bread, remain unto the morning, then thou shalt burn the remainder with fire: it shall not be eaten, because it <i>is</i> holy.

<b>35 </b>And thus shalt thou do unto Aaron, and to his sons, according to all <i>things</i> which I have commanded thee: seven days shalt thou consecrate them.

<b>36 </b>And thou shalt offer every day a bullock <i>for</i> a sin offering for atonement: and thou shalt cleanse the altar, when thou hast made an atonement for it, and thou shalt anoint it, to sanctify it.

<b>37 </b>Seven days thou shalt make an atonement for the altar, and sanctify it; and it shall be an altar most holy: whatsoever toucheth the altar shall be holy.

<b>38 </b>¶ Now this <i>is that</i> which thou shalt offer upon the altar; two lambs of the first year day by day continually.

<b>39 </b>The one lamb thou shalt offer in the morning; and the other lamb thou shalt offer at even:

<b>40 </b>And with the one lamb a tenth deal of flour mingled with the fourth part of an hin of beaten oil; and the fourth part of an hin of wine <i>for</i> a drink offering.

<b>41 </b>And the other lamb thou shalt offer at even, and shalt do thereto according to the meat offering of the morning, and according to the drink offering thereof, for a sweet savour, an offering made by fire unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>42 </b><i>This shall be</i> a continual burnt offering throughout your generations <i>at</i> the door of the tabernacle of the congregation before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: where I will meet you, to speak there unto thee.

<b>43 </b>And there I will meet with the children of Israel, and <i>the tabernacle</i> shall be sanctified by my glory.

<b>44 </b>And I will sanctify the tabernacle of the congregation, and the altar: I will sanctify also both Aaron and his sons, to minister to me in the priest’s office.

<b>45 </b>¶ And I will dwell among the children of Israel, and will be their God.

<b>46 </b>And they shall know that I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> their God, that brought them forth out of the land of Egypt, that I may dwell among them: I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> their God.


--------------------

CHAPTER 30

<b>1 </b>And thou shalt make an altar to burn incense upon: <i>of</i> shittim wood shalt thou make it.

<b>2 </b>A cubit <i>shall be</i> the length thereof, and a cubit the breadth thereof; foursquare shall it be: and two cubits <i>shall be</i> the height thereof: the horns thereof <i>shall be</i> of the same.

<b>3 </b>And thou shalt overlay it with pure gold, the top thereof, and the sides thereof round about, and the horns thereof; and thou shalt make unto it a crown of gold round about.

<b>4 </b>And two golden rings shalt thou make to it under the crown of it, by the two corners thereof, upon the two sides of it shalt thou make <i>it;</i> and they shall be for places for the staves to bear it withal.

<b>5 </b>And thou shalt make the staves <i>of</i> shittim wood, and overlay them with gold.

<b>6 </b>And thou shalt put it before the veil that <i>is</i> by the ark of the testimony, before the mercy seat that <i>is</i> over the testimony, where I will meet with thee.

<b>7 </b>And Aaron shall burn thereon sweet incense every morning: when he dresseth the lamps, he shall burn incense upon it.

<b>8 </b>And when Aaron lighteth the lamps at even, he shall burn incense upon it, a perpetual incense before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> throughout your generations.

<b>9 </b>Ye shall offer no strange incense thereon, nor burnt sacrifice, nor meat offering; neither shall ye pour drink offering thereon.

<b>10 </b>And Aaron shall make an atonement upon the horns of it once in a year with the blood of the sin offering of atonements: once in the year shall he make atonement upon it throughout your generations: it <i>is</i> most holy unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>11 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>12 </b>When thou takest the sum of the children of Israel after their number, then shall they give every man a ransom for his soul unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, when thou numberest them; that there be no plague among them, when <i>thou</i> numberest them.

<b>13 </b>This they shall give, every one that passeth among them that are numbered, half a shekel after the shekel of the sanctuary: (a shekel <i>is</i> twenty gerahs:) an half shekel <i>shall be</i> the offering of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>14 </b>Every one that passeth among them that are numbered, from twenty years old and above, shall give an offering unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>15 </b>The rich shall not give more, and the poor shall not give less than half a shekel, when <i>they</i> give an offering unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to make an atonement for your souls.

<b>16 </b>And thou shalt take the atonement money of the children of Israel, and shalt appoint it for the service of the tabernacle of the congregation; that it may be a memorial unto the children of Israel before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to make an atonement for your souls.

<b>17 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>18 </b>Thou shalt also make a laver <i>of</i> brass, and his foot <i>also of</i> brass, to wash <i>withal:</i> and thou shalt put it between the tabernacle of the congregation and the altar, and thou shalt put water therein.

<b>19 </b>For Aaron and his sons shall wash their hands and their feet thereat:

<b>20 </b>When they go into the tabernacle of the congregation, they shall wash with water, that they die not; or when they come near to the altar to minister, to burn offering made by fire unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>:

<b>21 </b>So they shall wash their hands and their feet, that they die not: and it shall be a statute for ever to them, <i>even</i> to him and to his seed throughout their generations.

<b>22 </b>¶ Moreover the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>23 </b>Take thou also unto thee principal spices, of pure myrrh five hundred <i>shekels,</i> and of sweet cinnamon half so much, <i>even</i> two hundred and fifty <i>shekels,</i> and of sweet calamus two hundred and fifty <i>shekels,</i>

<b>24 </b>And of cassia five hundred <i>shekels,</i> after the shekel of the sanctuary, and of oil olive an hin:

<b>25 </b>And thou shalt make it an oil of holy ointment, an ointment compound after the art of the apothecary: it shall be an holy anointing oil.

<b>26 </b>And thou shalt anoint the tabernacle of the congregation therewith, and the ark of the testimony,

<b>27 </b>And the table and all his vessels, and the candlestick and his vessels, and the altar of incense,

<b>28 </b>And the altar of burnt offering with all his vessels, and the laver and his foot.

<b>29 </b>And thou shalt sanctify them, that they may be most holy: whatsoever toucheth them shall be holy.

<b>30 </b>And thou shalt anoint Aaron and his sons, and consecrate them, that <i>they</i> may minister unto me in the priest’s office.

<b>31 </b>And thou shalt speak unto the children of Israel, saying, This shall be an holy anointing oil unto me throughout your generations.

<b>32 </b>Upon man’s flesh shall it not be poured, neither shall ye make <i>any other</i> like it, after the composition of it: it <i>is</i> holy, <i>and</i> it shall be holy unto you.

<b>33 </b>Whosoever compoundeth <i>any</i> like it, or whosoever putteth <i>any</i> of it upon a stranger, shall even be cut off from his people.

<b>34 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Take unto thee sweet spices, stacte, and onycha, and galbanum; <i>these</i> sweet spices with pure frankincense: of each shall there be a like <i>weight:</i>

<b>35 </b>And thou shalt make it a perfume, a confection after the art of the apothecary, tempered together, pure <i>and</i> holy:

<b>36 </b>And thou shalt beat <i>some</i> of it very small, and put of it before the testimony in the tabernacle of the congregation, where I will meet with thee: it shall be unto you most holy.

<b>37 </b>And <i>as for</i> the perfume which thou shalt make, ye shall not make to yourselves according to the composition thereof: it shall be unto thee holy for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>38 </b>Whosoever shall make like unto that, to smell thereto, shall even be cut off from his people.


--------------------

CHAPTER 31

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>2 </b>See, I have called by name Bezaleel the son of Uri, the son of Hur, of the tribe of Judah:

<b>3 </b>And I have filled him with the spirit of God, in wisdom, and in understanding, and in knowledge, and in all manner of workmanship,

<b>4 </b>To devise cunning works, to work in gold, and in silver, and in brass,

<b>5 </b>And in cutting of stones, to set <i>them,</i> and in carving of timber, to work in all manner of workmanship.

<b>6 </b>And I, behold, I have given with him Aholiab, the son of Ahisamach, of the tribe of Dan: and in the hearts of all that are wise hearted I have put wisdom, that they may make all that I have commanded thee;

<b>7 </b>The tabernacle of the congregation, and the ark of the testimony, and the mercy seat that <i>is</i> thereupon, and all the furniture of the tabernacle,

<b>8 </b>And the table and his furniture, and the pure candlestick with all his furniture, and the altar of incense,

<b>9 </b>And the altar of burnt offering with all his furniture, and the laver and his foot,

<b>10 </b>And the cloths of service, and the holy garments for Aaron the priest, and the garments of his sons, to minister in the priest’s office,

<b>11 </b>And the anointing oil, and sweet incense for the holy <i>place:</i> according to all that I have commanded thee shall they do.

<b>12 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>13 </b>Speak thou also unto the children of Israel, saying, Verily my sabbaths ye shall keep: for it <i>is</i> a sign between me and you throughout your generations; that <i>ye</i> may know that I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that doth sanctify you.

<b>14 </b>Ye shall keep the sabbath therefore; for it <i>is</i> holy unto you: every one that defileth it shall surely be put to death: for whosoever doeth <i>any</i> work therein, that soul shall be cut off from among his people.

<b>15 </b>Six days may work be done; but in the seventh <i>is</i> the sabbath of rest, holy to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: whosoever doeth <i>any</i> work in the sabbath day, he shall surely be put to death.

<b>16 </b>Wherefore the children of Israel shall keep the sabbath, to observe the sabbath throughout their generations, <i>for</i> a perpetual covenant.

<b>17 </b>It <i>is</i> a sign between me and the children of Israel for ever: for <i>in</i> six days the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> made heaven and earth, and on the seventh day he rested, and was refreshed.

<b>18 </b>¶ And he gave unto Moses, when he had made an end of communing with him upon mount Sinai, two tables of testimony, tables of stone, written with the finger of God.


--------------------

CHAPTER 32

<b>1 </b>And when the people saw that Moses delayed to come down out of the mount, the people gathered themselves together unto Aaron, and said unto him, Up, make us gods, which shall go before us; for <i>as for</i> this Moses, the man that brought us up out of the land of Egypt, we wot not what is become of him.

<b>2 </b>And Aaron said unto them, Break off the golden earrings, which <i>are</i> in the ears of your wives, of your sons, and of your daughters, and bring <i>them</i> unto me.

<b>3 </b>And all the people brake off the golden earrings which <i>were</i> in their ears, and brought <i>them</i> unto Aaron.

<b>4 </b>And he received <i>them</i> at their hand, and fashioned it with a graving tool, after he had made it a molten calf: and they said, These <i>be</i> thy gods, O Israel, which brought thee up out of the land of Egypt.

<b>5 </b>And when Aaron saw <i>it,</i> he built an altar before it; and Aaron made proclamation, and said, To morrow <i>is</i> a feast to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>6 </b>And they rose up early on the morrow, and offered burnt offerings, and brought peace offerings; and the people sat down to eat and to drink, and rose up to play.

<b>7 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Go, get thee down; for thy people, which thou broughtest out of the land of Egypt, have corrupted <i>themselves:</i>

<b>8 </b>They have turned aside quickly out of the way which I commanded them: they have made them a molten calf, and have worshipped it, and have sacrificed thereunto, and said, These <i>be</i> thy gods, O Israel, which have brought thee up out of the land of Egypt.

<b>9 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, I have seen this people, and, behold, it <i>is</i> a stiffnecked people:

<b>10 </b>Now therefore let me alone, that my wrath may wax hot against them, and that I may consume them: and I will make of thee a great nation.

<b>11 </b>And Moses besought the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his God, and said, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, why doth thy wrath wax hot against thy people, which thou hast brought forth out of the land of Egypt with great power, and with a mighty hand?

<b>12 </b>Wherefore should the Egyptians speak, and say, For mischief did he bring them out, to slay them in the mountains, and to consume them from the face of the earth? Turn from thy fierce wrath, and repent of this evil against thy people.

<b>13 </b>Remember Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, thy servants, to whom thou swarest by thine own self, and saidst unto them, I will multiply your seed as the stars of heaven, and all this land that I have spoken of will I give unto your seed, and they shall inherit <i>it</i> for ever.

<b>14 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> repented of the evil which he thought to do unto his people.

<b>15 </b>¶ And Moses turned, and went down from the mount, and the two tables of the testimony <i>were</i> in his hand: the tables <i>were</i> written on both their sides; on the one side and on the other <i>were</i> they written.

<b>16 </b>And the tables <i>were</i> the work of God, and the writing <i>was</i> the writing of God, graven upon the tables.

<b>17 </b>And when Joshua heard the noise of the people as they shouted, he said unto Moses, <i>There is</i> a noise of war in the camp.

<b>18 </b>And he said, <i>It is</i> not the voice of <i>them that</i> shout for mastery, neither <i>is it</i> the voice of <i>them that</i> cry for being overcome: <i>but</i> the noise of <i>them that</i> sing do I hear.

<b>19 </b>¶ And it came to pass, as soon as he came nigh unto the camp, that he saw the calf, and the dancing: and Moses’ anger waxed hot, and he cast the tables out of his hands, and brake them beneath the mount.

<b>20 </b>And he took the calf which they had made, and burnt <i>it</i> in the fire, and ground <i>it</i> to powder, and strawed <i>it</i> upon the water, and made the children of Israel drink <i>of it.</i>

<b>21 </b>And Moses said unto Aaron, What did this people unto thee, that thou hast brought so great a sin upon them?

<b>22 </b>And Aaron said, Let not the anger of my lord wax hot: thou knowest the people, that they <i>are set</i> on mischief.

<b>23 </b>For they said unto me, Make us gods, which shall go before us: for <i>as for</i> this Moses, the man that brought us up out of the land of Egypt, we wot not what is become of him.

<b>24 </b>And I said unto them, Whosoever hath any gold, let them break <i>it</i> off. So they gave <i>it</i> me: then I cast it into the fire, and there came out this calf.

<b>25 </b>¶ And when Moses saw that the people <i>were</i> naked; (for Aaron had made them naked unto <i>their</i> shame among their enemies:)

<b>26 </b>Then Moses stood in the gate of the camp, and said, Who <i>is</i> on the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s side? <i>let him come</i> unto me. And all the sons of Levi gathered themselves together unto him.

<b>27 </b>And he said unto them, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, Put every man his sword by his side, <i>and</i> go in and out from gate to gate throughout the camp, and slay every man his brother, and every man his companion, and every man his neighbour.

<b>28 </b>And the children of Levi did according to the word of Moses: and there fell of the people that day about three thousand men.

<b>29 </b>For Moses had said, Consecrate yourselves to day to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, even every man upon his son, and upon his brother; that he may bestow upon you a blessing this day.

<b>30 </b>¶ And it came to pass on the morrow, that Moses said unto the people, Ye have sinned a great sin: and now I will go up unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; peradventure I shall make an atonement for your sin.

<b>31 </b>And Moses returned unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and said, Oh, this people have sinned a great sin, and have made them gods of gold.

<b>32 </b>Yet now, if thou wilt forgive their sin—; and if not, blot me, I pray thee, out of thy book which thou hast written.

<b>33 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Whosoever hath sinned against me, him will I blot out of my book.

<b>34 </b>Therefore now go, lead the people unto <i>the place</i> of which I have spoken unto thee: behold, mine Angel shall go before thee: nevertheless in the day when I visit I will visit their sin upon them.

<b>35 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> plagued the people, because they made the calf, which Aaron made.


--------------------

CHAPTER 33

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Depart, <i>and</i> go up hence, thou and the people which thou hast brought up out of the land of Egypt, unto the land which I sware unto Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob, saying, Unto thy seed will I give it:

<b>2 </b>And I will send an angel before thee; and I will drive out the Canaanite, the Amorite, and the Hittite, and the Perizzite, the Hivite, and the Jebusite:

<b>3 </b>Unto a land flowing with milk and honey: for I will not go up in the midst of thee; for thou <i>art</i> a stiffnecked people: lest I consume thee in the way.

<b>4 </b>¶ And when the people heard these evil tidings, they mourned: and no man did put on him his ornaments.

<b>5 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had said unto Moses, Say unto the children of Israel, Ye <i>are</i> a stiffnecked people: I will come up into the midst of thee in a moment, and consume thee: therefore now put off thy ornaments from thee, that I may know what to do unto thee.

<b>6 </b>And the children of Israel stripped themselves of their ornaments by the mount Horeb.

<b>7 </b>And Moses took the tabernacle, and pitched it without the camp, afar off from the camp, and called it the Tabernacle of the congregation. And it came to pass, <i>that</i> every one which sought the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> went out unto the tabernacle of the congregation, which <i>was</i> without the camp.

<b>8 </b>And it came to pass, when Moses went out unto the tabernacle, <i>that</i> all the people rose up, and stood every man <i>at</i> his tent door, and looked after Moses, until he was gone into the tabernacle.

<b>9 </b>And it came to pass, as Moses entered into the tabernacle, the cloudy pillar descended, and stood <i>at</i> the door of the tabernacle, and <i>the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span></i> talked with Moses.

<b>10 </b>And all the people saw the cloudy pillar stand <i>at</i> the tabernacle door: and all the people rose up and worshipped, every man <i>in</i> his tent door.

<b>11 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses face to face, as a man speaketh unto his friend. And he turned again into the camp: but his servant Joshua, the son of Nun, a young man, departed not out of the tabernacle.

<b>12 </b>¶ And Moses said unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, See, thou sayest unto me, Bring up this people: and thou hast not let me know whom thou wilt send with me. Yet thou hast said, I know thee by name, and thou hast also found grace in my sight.

<b>13 </b>Now therefore, I pray thee, if I have found grace in thy sight, shew me now thy way, that I may know thee, that I may find grace in thy sight: and consider that this nation <i>is</i> thy people.

<b>14 </b>And he said, My presence shall go <i>with thee,</i> and I will give thee rest.

<b>15 </b>And he said unto him, If thy presence go not <i>with me,</i> carry us not up hence.

<b>16 </b>For wherein shall it be known here that I and thy people have found grace in thy sight? <i>is it</i> not in that thou goest with us? so shall we be separated, I and thy people, from all the people that <i>are</i> upon the face of the earth.

<b>17 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, I will do this thing also that thou hast spoken: for thou hast found grace in my sight, and I know thee by name.

<b>18 </b>And he said, I beseech thee, shew me thy glory.

<b>19 </b>And he said, I will make all my goodness pass before thee, and I will proclaim the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> before thee; and will be gracious to whom I will be gracious, and will shew mercy on whom I will shew mercy.

<b>20 </b>And he said, Thou canst not see my face: for there shall no man see me, and live.

<b>21 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said, Behold, <i>there is</i> a place by me, and thou shalt stand upon a rock:

<b>22 </b>And it shall come to pass, while my glory passeth by, that I will put thee in a clift of the rock, and will cover thee with my hand while I pass by:

<b>23 </b>And I will take away mine hand, and thou shalt see my back parts: but my face shall not be seen.


--------------------

CHAPTER 34

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Hew thee two tables of stone like unto the first: and I will write upon <i>these</i> tables the words that were in the first tables, which thou brakest.

<b>2 </b>And be ready in the morning, and come up in the morning unto mount Sinai, and present thyself there to me in the top of the mount.

<b>3 </b>And no man shall come up with thee, neither let any man be seen throughout all the mount; neither let the flocks nor herds feed before that mount.

<b>4 </b>¶ And he hewed two tables of stone like unto the first; and Moses rose up early in the morning, and went up unto mount Sinai, as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had commanded him, and took in his hand the two tables of stone.

<b>5 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> descended in the cloud, and stood with him there, and proclaimed the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>6 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> passed by before him, and proclaimed, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God, merciful and gracious, longsuffering, and abundant in goodness and truth,

<b>7 </b>Keeping mercy for thousands, forgiving iniquity and transgression and sin, and that will by no means clear <i>the guilty;</i> visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children, and upon the children’s children, unto the third and to the fourth <i>generation.</i>

<b>8 </b>And Moses made haste, and bowed his head toward the earth, and worshipped.

<b>9 </b>And he said, If now I have found grace in thy sight, O Lord, let my Lord, I pray thee, go among us; for it <i>is</i> a stiffnecked people; and pardon our iniquity and our sin, and take us for thine inheritance.

<b>10 </b>¶ And he said, Behold, I make a covenant: before all thy people I will do marvels, such as have not been done in all the earth, nor in any nation: and all the people among which thou <i>art</i> shall see the work of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for it <i>is</i> a terrible thing that I will do with thee.

<b>11 </b>Observe thou that which I command thee this day: behold, I drive out before thee the Amorite, and the Canaanite, and the Hittite, and the Perizzite, and the Hivite, and the Jebusite.

<b>12 </b>Take heed to thyself, lest thou make a covenant with the inhabitants of the land whither thou goest, lest it be for a snare in the midst of thee:

<b>13 </b>But ye shall destroy their altars, break their images, and cut down their groves:

<b>14 </b>For thou shalt worship no other god: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, whose name <i>is</i> Jealous, <i>is</i> a jealous God:

<b>15 </b>Lest thou make a covenant with the inhabitants of the land, and they go a whoring after their gods, and do sacrifice unto their gods, and <i>one</i> call thee, and thou eat of his sacrifice;

<b>16 </b>And thou take of their daughters unto thy sons, and their daughters go a whoring after their gods, and make thy sons go a whoring after their gods.

<b>17 </b>Thou shalt make thee no molten gods.

<b>18 </b>¶ The feast of unleavened bread shalt thou keep. Seven days thou shalt eat unleavened bread, as I commanded thee, in the time of the month Abib: for in the month Abib thou camest out from Egypt.

<b>19 </b>All that openeth the matrix <i>is</i> mine; and every firstling among thy cattle, <i>whether</i> ox or sheep, <i>that is male.</i>

<b>20 </b>But the firstling of an ass thou shalt redeem with a lamb: and if thou redeem <i>him</i> not, then shalt thou break his neck. All the firstborn of thy sons thou shalt redeem. And none shall appear before me empty.

<b>21 </b>¶ Six days thou shalt work, but on the seventh day thou shalt rest: in earing time and in harvest thou shalt rest.

<b>22 </b>¶ And thou shalt observe the feast of weeks, of the firstfruits of wheat harvest, and the feast of ingathering at the year’s end.

<b>23 </b>¶ Thrice in the year shall all your men children appear before the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>, the God of Israel.

<b>24 </b>For I will cast out the nations before thee, and enlarge thy borders: neither shall any man desire thy land, when thou shalt go up to appear before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God thrice in the year.

<b>25 </b>Thou shalt not offer the blood of my sacrifice with leaven; neither shall the sacrifice of the feast of the passover be left unto the morning.

<b>26 </b>The first of the firstfruits of thy land thou shalt bring unto the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God. Thou shalt not seethe a kid in his mother’s milk.

<b>27 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Write thou these words: for after the tenor of these words I have made a covenant with thee and with Israel.

<b>28 </b>And he was there with the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> forty days and forty nights; he did neither eat bread, nor drink water. And he wrote upon the tables the words of the covenant, the ten commandments.

<b>29 </b>¶ And it came to pass, when Moses came down from mount Sinai with the two tables of testimony in Moses’ hand, when he came down from the mount, that Moses wist not that the skin of his face shone while he talked with him.

<b>30 </b>And when Aaron and all the children of Israel saw Moses, behold, the skin of his face shone; and they were afraid to come nigh him.

<b>31 </b>And Moses called unto them; and Aaron and all the rulers of the congregation returned unto him: and Moses talked with them.

<b>32 </b>And afterward all the children of Israel came nigh: and he gave them in commandment all that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had spoken with him in mount Sinai.

<b>33 </b>And <i>till</i> Moses had done speaking with them, he put a veil on his face.

<b>34 </b>But when Moses went in before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> to speak with him, he took the veil off, until he came out. And he came out, and spake unto the children of Israel <i>that</i> which he was commanded.

<b>35 </b>And the children of Israel saw the face of Moses, that the skin of Moses’ face shone: and Moses put the veil upon his face again, until he went in to speak with him.


--------------------

CHAPTER 35

<b>1 </b>And Moses gathered all the congregation of the children of Israel together, and said unto them, These <i>are</i> the words which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath commanded, that <i>ye</i> should do them.

<b>2 </b>Six days shall work be done, but on the seventh day there shall be to you an holy day, a sabbath of rest to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: whosoever doeth work therein shall be put to death.

<b>3 </b>Ye shall kindle no fire throughout your habitations upon the sabbath day.
