<b>7 </b>And thus shalt thou do unto them, to cleanse them: Sprinkle water of purifying upon them, and let them shave all their flesh, and let them wash their clothes, and <i>so</i> make themselves clean.

<b>8 </b>Then let them take a young bullock with his meat offering, <i>even</i> fine flour mingled with oil, and another young bullock shalt thou take for a sin offering.

<b>9 </b>And thou shalt bring the Levites before the tabernacle of the congregation: and thou shalt gather the whole assembly of the children of Israel together:

<b>10 </b>And thou shalt bring the Levites before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and the children of Israel shall put their hands upon the Levites:

<b>11 </b>And Aaron shall offer the Levites before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>for</i> an offering of the children of Israel, that they may execute the service of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>12 </b>And the Levites shall lay their hands upon the heads of the bullocks: and thou shalt offer the one <i>for</i> a sin offering, and the other <i>for</i> a burnt offering, unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to make an atonement for the Levites.

<b>13 </b>And thou shalt set the Levites before Aaron, and before his sons, and offer them <i>for</i> an offering unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>14 </b>Thus shalt thou separate the Levites from among the children of Israel: and the Levites shall be mine.

<b>15 </b>And after that shall the Levites go in to do the service of the tabernacle of the congregation: and thou shalt cleanse them, and offer them <i>for</i> an offering.

<b>16 </b>For they <i>are</i> wholly given unto me from among the children of Israel; instead of such as open every womb, <i>even instead of</i> the firstborn of all the children of Israel, have I taken them unto me.

<b>17 </b>For all the firstborn of the children of Israel <i>are</i> mine, <i>both</i> man and beast: on the day that I smote every firstborn in the land of Egypt I sanctified them for myself.

<b>18 </b>And I have taken the Levites for all the firstborn of the children of Israel.

<b>19 </b>And I have given the Levites <i>as</i> a gift to Aaron and to his sons from among the children of Israel, to do the service of the children of Israel in the tabernacle of the congregation, and to make an atonement for the children of Israel: that there be no plague among the children of Israel, when the children of Israel come nigh unto the sanctuary.

<b>20 </b>And Moses, and Aaron, and all the congregation of the children of Israel, did to the Levites according unto all that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded Moses concerning the Levites, so did the children of Israel unto them.

<b>21 </b>And the Levites were purified, and they washed their clothes; and Aaron offered them <i>as</i> an offering before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and Aaron made an atonement for them to cleanse them.

<b>22 </b>And after that went the Levites in to do their service in the tabernacle of the congregation before Aaron, and before his sons: as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had commanded Moses concerning the Levites, so did they unto them.

<b>23 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>24 </b>This <i>is it</i> that <i>belongeth</i> unto the Levites: from twenty and five years old and upward they shall go in to wait upon the service of the tabernacle of the congregation:

<b>25 </b>And from the age of fifty years they shall cease waiting upon the service <i>thereof,</i> and shall serve no more:

<b>26 </b>But shall minister with their brethren in the tabernacle of the congregation, to keep the charge, and shall do no service. Thus shalt thou do unto the Levites touching their charge.


--------------------

CHAPTER 9

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses in the wilderness of Sinai, in the first month of the second year after they were come out of the land of Egypt, saying,

<b>2 </b>Let the children of Israel also keep the passover at his appointed season.

<b>3 </b>In the fourteenth day of this month, at even, ye shall keep it in his appointed season: according to all the rites of it, and according to all the ceremonies thereof, shall ye keep it.

<b>4 </b>And Moses spake unto the children of Israel, that they should keep the passover.

<b>5 </b>And they kept the passover on the fourteenth day of the first month at even in the wilderness of Sinai: according to all that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded Moses, so did the children of Israel.

<b>6 </b>¶ And there were certain men, who were defiled by the dead body of a man, that they could not keep the passover on that day: and they came before Moses and before Aaron on that day:

<b>7 </b>And those men said unto him, We <i>are</i> defiled by the dead body of a man: wherefore are we kept back, that we may not offer an offering of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in his appointed season among the children of Israel?

<b>8 </b>And Moses said unto them, Stand still, and I will hear what the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will command concerning you.

<b>9 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>10 </b>Speak unto the children of Israel, saying, If any man of you or of your posterity shall be unclean by reason of a dead body, or <i>be</i> in a journey afar off, yet he shall keep the passover unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>11 </b>The fourteenth day of the second month at even they shall keep it, <i>and</i> eat it with unleavened bread and bitter <i>herbs.</i>

<b>12 </b>They shall leave none of it unto the morning, nor break any bone of it: according to all the ordinances of the passover they shall keep it.

<b>13 </b>But the man that <i>is</i> clean, and is not in a journey, and forbeareth to keep the passover, even the same soul shall be cut off from among his people: because he brought not the offering of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in his appointed season, that man shall bear his sin.

<b>14 </b>And if a stranger shall sojourn among you, and will keep the passover unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; according to the ordinance of the passover, and according to the manner thereof, so shall he do: ye shall have one ordinance, both for the stranger, and for him that was born in the land.

<b>15 </b>¶ And on the day that the tabernacle was reared up the cloud covered the tabernacle, <i>namely,</i> the tent of the testimony: and at even there was upon the tabernacle as it were the appearance of fire, until the morning.

<b>16 </b>So it was alway: the cloud covered it <i>by day,</i> and the appearance of fire by night.

<b>17 </b>And when the cloud was taken up from the tabernacle, then after that the children of Israel journeyed: and in the place where the cloud abode, there the children of Israel pitched their tents.

<b>18 </b>At the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> the children of Israel journeyed, and at the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> they pitched: as long as the cloud abode upon the tabernacle they rested in their tents.

<b>19 </b>And when the cloud tarried long upon the tabernacle many days, then the children of Israel kept the charge of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and journeyed not.

<b>20 </b>And <i>so</i> it was, when the cloud was a few days upon the tabernacle; according to the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> they abode in their tents, and according to the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> they journeyed.

<b>21 </b>And <i>so</i> it was, when the cloud abode from even unto the morning, and <i>that</i> the cloud was taken up in the morning, then they journeyed: whether <i>it was</i> by day or by night that the cloud was taken up, they journeyed.

<b>22 </b>Or <i>whether it were</i> two days, or a month, or a year, that the cloud tarried upon the tabernacle, remaining thereon, the children of Israel abode in their tents, and journeyed not: but when it was taken up, they journeyed.

<b>23 </b>At the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> they rested in the tents, and at the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> they journeyed: they kept the charge of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, at the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> by the hand of Moses.


--------------------

CHAPTER 10

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>2 </b>Make thee two trumpets of silver; of a whole piece shalt thou make them: that thou mayest use them for the calling of the assembly, and for the journeying of the camps.

<b>3 </b>And when they shall blow with them, all the assembly shall assemble themselves to thee at the door of the tabernacle of the congregation.

<b>4 </b>And if they blow <i>but</i> with one <i>trumpet,</i> then the princes, <i>which are</i> heads of the thousands of Israel, shall gather themselves unto thee.

<b>5 </b>When ye blow an alarm, then the camps that lie on the east parts shall go forward.

<b>6 </b>When ye blow an alarm the second time, then the camps that lie on the south side shall take their journey: they shall blow an alarm for their journeys.

<b>7 </b>But when the congregation is to be gathered together, ye shall blow, but ye shall not sound an alarm.

<b>8 </b>And the sons of Aaron, the priests, shall blow with the trumpets; and they shall be to you for an ordinance for ever throughout your generations.

<b>9 </b>And if ye go to war in your land against the enemy that oppresseth you, then ye shall blow an alarm with the trumpets; and ye shall be remembered before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, and ye shall be saved from your enemies.

<b>10 </b>Also in the day of your gladness, and in your solemn days, and in the beginnings of your months, ye shall blow with the trumpets over your burnt offerings, and over the sacrifices of your peace offerings; that they may be to you for a memorial before your God: I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God.

<b>11 </b>¶ And it came to pass on the twentieth <i>day</i> of the second month, in the second year, that the cloud was taken up from off the tabernacle of the testimony.

<b>12 </b>And the children of Israel took their journeys out of the wilderness of Sinai; and the cloud rested in the wilderness of Paran.

<b>13 </b>And they first took their journey according to the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> by the hand of Moses.

<b>14 </b>¶ In the first <i>place</i> went the standard of the camp of the children of Judah according to their armies: and over his host <i>was</i> Nahshon the son of Amminadab.

<b>15 </b>And over the host of the tribe of the children of Issachar <i>was</i> Nethaneel the son of Zuar.

<b>16 </b>And over the host of the tribe of the children of Zebulun <i>was</i> Eliab the son of Helon.

<b>17 </b>And the tabernacle was taken down; and the sons of Gershon and the sons of Merari set forward, bearing the tabernacle.

<b>18 </b>¶ And the standard of the camp of Reuben set forward according to their armies: and over his host <i>was</i> Elizur the son of Shedeur.

<b>19 </b>And over the host of the tribe of the children of Simeon <i>was</i> Shelumiel the son of Zurishaddai.

<b>20 </b>And over the host of the tribe of the children of Gad <i>was</i> Eliasaph the son of Deuel.

<b>21 </b>And the Kohathites set forward, bearing the sanctuary: and <i>the other</i> did set up the tabernacle against they came.

<b>22 </b>¶ And the standard of the camp of the children of Ephraim set forward according to their armies: and over his host <i>was</i> Elishama the son of Ammihud.

<b>23 </b>And over the host of the tribe of the children of Manasseh <i>was</i> Gamaliel the son of Pedahzur.

<b>24 </b>And over the host of the tribe of the children of Benjamin <i>was</i> Abidan the son of Gideoni.

<b>25 </b>¶ And the standard of the camp of the children of Dan set forward, <i>which was</i> the rearward of all the camps throughout their hosts: and over his host <i>was</i> Ahiezer the son of Ammishaddai.

<b>26 </b>And over the host of the tribe of the children of Asher <i>was</i> Pagiel the son of Ocran.

<b>27 </b>And over the host of the tribe of the children of Naphtali <i>was</i> Ahira the son of Enan.

<b>28 </b>Thus <i>were</i> the journeyings of the children of Israel according to their armies, when they set forward.

<b>29 </b>¶ And Moses said unto Hobab, the son of Raguel the Midianite, Moses’ father in law, We are journeying unto the place of which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said, I will give it you: come thou with us, and we will do thee good: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath spoken good concerning Israel.

<b>30 </b>And he said unto him, I will not go; but I will depart to mine own land, and to my kindred.

<b>31 </b>And he said, Leave us not, I pray thee; forasmuch as thou knowest how we are to encamp in the wilderness, and thou mayest be to us instead of eyes.

<b>32 </b>And it shall be, if thou go with us, yea, it shall be, that what goodness the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall do unto us, the same will we do unto thee.

<b>33 </b>¶ And they departed from the mount of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> three days’ journey: and the ark of the covenant of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> went before them in the three days’ journey, to search out a resting place for them.

<b>34 </b>And the cloud of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>was</i> upon them by day, when they went out of the camp.

<b>35 </b>And it came to pass, when the ark set forward, that Moses said, Rise up, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and let thine enemies be scattered; and let them that hate thee flee before thee.

<b>36 </b>And when it rested, he said, Return, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, unto the many thousands of Israel.


--------------------

CHAPTER 11

<b>1 </b>And <i>when</i> the people complained, it displeased the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> heard <i>it;</i> and his anger was kindled; and the fire of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> burnt among them, and consumed <i>them that were</i> in the uttermost parts of the camp.

<b>2 </b>And the people cried unto Moses; and when Moses prayed unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the fire was quenched.

<b>3 </b>And he called the name of the place Taberah: because the fire of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> burnt among them.

<b>4 </b>¶ And the mixed multitude that <i>was</i> among them fell a lusting: and the children of Israel also wept again, and said, Who shall give us flesh to eat?

<b>5 </b>We remember the fish, which we did eat in Egypt freely; the cucumbers, and the melons, and the leeks, and the onions, and the garlick:

<b>6 </b>But now our soul <i>is</i> dried away: <i>there is</i> nothing at all, beside this manna, <i>before</i> our eyes.

<b>7 </b>And the manna <i>was</i> as coriander seed, and the colour thereof as the colour of bdellium.

<b>8 </b><i>And</i> the people went about, and gathered <i>it,</i> and ground <i>it</i> in mills, or beat <i>it</i> in a mortar, and baked <i>it</i> in pans, and made cakes of it: and the taste of it was as the taste of fresh oil.

<b>9 </b>And when the dew fell upon the camp in the night, the manna fell upon it.

<b>10 </b>¶ Then Moses heard the people weep throughout their families, every man in the door of his tent: and the anger of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was kindled greatly; Moses also was displeased.

<b>11 </b>And Moses said unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Wherefore hast thou afflicted thy servant? and wherefore have I not found favour in thy sight, that thou layest the burden of all this people upon me?

<b>12 </b>Have I conceived all this people? have I begotten them, that thou shouldest say unto me, Carry them in thy bosom, as a nursing father beareth the sucking child, unto the land which thou swarest unto their fathers?

<b>13 </b>Whence should I have flesh to give unto all this people? for they weep unto me, saying, Give us flesh, that we may eat.

<b>14 </b>I am not able to bear all this people alone, because <i>it is</i> too heavy for me.

<b>15 </b>And if thou deal thus with me, kill me, I pray thee, out of hand, if I have found favour in thy sight; and let me not see my wretchedness.

<b>16 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Gather unto me seventy men of the elders of Israel, whom thou knowest to be the elders of the people, and officers over them; and bring them unto the tabernacle of the congregation, that they may stand there with thee.

<b>17 </b>And I will come down and talk with thee there: and I will take of the spirit which <i>is</i> upon thee, and will put <i>it</i> upon them; and they shall bear the burden of the people with thee, that thou bear <i>it</i> not thyself alone.

<b>18 </b>And say thou unto the people, Sanctify yourselves against to morrow, and ye shall eat flesh: for ye have wept in the ears of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying, Who shall give us flesh to eat? for <i>it was</i> well with us in Egypt: therefore the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will give you flesh, and ye shall eat.

<b>19 </b>Ye shall not eat one day, nor two days, nor five days, neither ten days, nor twenty days;

<b>20 </b><i>But</i> even a whole month, until it come out at your nostrils, and it be loathsome unto you: because that ye have despised the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> which <i>is</i> among you, and have wept before him, saying, Why came we forth out of Egypt?

<b>21 </b>And Moses said, The people, among whom I <i>am, are</i> six hundred thousand footmen; and thou hast said, I will give them flesh, that they may eat a whole month.

<b>22 </b>Shall the flocks and the herds be slain for them, to suffice them? or shall all the fish of the sea be gathered together for them, to suffice them?

<b>23 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Is the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s hand waxed short? thou shalt see now whether my word shall come to pass unto thee or not.

<b>24 </b>¶ And Moses went out, and told the people the words of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and gathered the seventy men of the elders of the people, and set them round about the tabernacle.

<b>25 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came down in a cloud, and spake unto him, and took of the spirit that <i>was</i> upon him, and gave <i>it</i> unto the seventy elders: and it came to pass, <i>that,</i> when the spirit rested upon them, they prophesied, and did not cease.

<b>26 </b>But there remained two <i>of the</i> men in the camp, the name of the one <i>was</i> Eldad, and the name of the other Medad: and the spirit rested upon them; and they <i>were</i> of them that were written, but went not out unto the tabernacle: and they prophesied in the camp.

<b>27 </b>And there ran a young man, and told Moses, and said, Eldad and Medad do prophesy in the camp.

<b>28 </b>And Joshua the son of Nun, the servant of Moses, <i>one</i> of his young men, answered and said, My lord Moses, forbid them.

<b>29 </b>And Moses said unto him, Enviest thou for my sake? would God that all the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s people were prophets, <i>and</i> that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> would put his spirit upon them!

<b>30 </b>And Moses gat him into the camp, he and the elders of Israel.

<b>31 </b>¶ And there went forth a wind from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and brought quails from the sea, and let <i>them</i> fall by the camp, as it were a day’s journey on this side, and as it were a day’s journey on the other side, round about the camp, and as it were two cubits <i>high</i> upon the face of the earth.

<b>32 </b>And the people stood up all that day, and all <i>that</i> night, and all the next day, and they gathered the quails: he that gathered least gathered ten homers: and they spread <i>them</i> all abroad for themselves round about the camp.

<b>33 </b>And while the flesh <i>was</i> yet between their teeth, ere it was chewed, the wrath of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was kindled against the people, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> smote the people with a very great plague.

<b>34 </b>And he called the name of that place Kibroth-hattaavah: because there they buried the people that lusted.

<b>35 </b><i>And</i> the people journeyed from Kibroth-hattaavah unto Hazeroth; and abode at Hazeroth.


--------------------

CHAPTER 12

<b>1 </b>And Miriam and Aaron spake against Moses because of the Ethiopian woman whom he had married: for he had married an Ethiopian woman.

<b>2 </b>And they said, Hath the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> indeed spoken only by Moses? hath he not spoken also by us? And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> heard <i>it.</i>

<b>3 </b>(Now the man Moses <i>was</i> very meek, above all the men which <i>were</i> upon the face of the earth.)

<b>4 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake suddenly unto Moses, and unto Aaron, and unto Miriam, Come out ye three unto the tabernacle of the congregation. And they three came out.

<b>5 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came down in the pillar of the cloud, and stood <i>in</i> the door of the tabernacle, and called Aaron and Miriam: and they both came forth.

<b>6 </b>And he said, Hear now my words: If there be a prophet among you, <i>I</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will make myself known unto him in a vision, <i>and</i> will speak unto him in a dream.

<b>7 </b>My servant Moses <i>is</i> not so, who <i>is</i> faithful in all mine house.

<b>8 </b>With him will I speak mouth to mouth, even apparently, and not in dark speeches; and the similitude of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall he behold: wherefore then were ye not afraid to speak against my servant Moses?

<b>9 </b>And the anger of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was kindled against them; and he departed.

<b>10 </b>And the cloud departed from off the tabernacle; and, behold, Miriam <i>became</i> leprous, <i>white</i> as snow: and Aaron looked upon Miriam, and, behold, <i>she was</i> leprous.

<b>11 </b>And Aaron said unto Moses, Alas, my lord, I beseech thee, lay not the sin upon us, wherein we have done foolishly, and wherein we have sinned.

<b>12 </b>Let her not be as one dead, of whom the flesh is half consumed when he cometh out of his mother’s womb.

<b>13 </b>And Moses cried unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying, Heal her now, O God, I beseech thee.

<b>14 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, If her father had but spit in her face, should she not be ashamed seven days? let her be shut out from the camp seven days, and after that let her be received in <i>again.</i>

<b>15 </b>And Miriam was shut out from the camp seven days: and the people journeyed not till Miriam was brought in <i>again.</i>

<b>16 </b>And afterward the people removed from Hazeroth, and pitched in the wilderness of Paran.


--------------------

CHAPTER 13

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>2 </b>Send thou men, that they may search the land of Canaan, which I give unto the children of Israel: of every tribe of their fathers shall ye send a man, every one a ruler among them.

<b>3 </b>And Moses by the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sent them from the wilderness of Paran: all those men <i>were</i> heads of the children of Israel.

<b>4 </b>And these <i>were</i> their names: of the tribe of Reuben, Shammua the son of Zaccur.

<b>5 </b>Of the tribe of Simeon, Shaphat the son of Hori.

<b>6 </b>Of the tribe of Judah, Caleb the son of Jephunneh.

<b>7 </b>Of the tribe of Issachar, Igal the son of Joseph.

<b>8 </b>Of the tribe of Ephraim, Oshea the son of Nun.

<b>9 </b>Of the tribe of Benjamin, Palti the son of Raphu.

<b>10 </b>Of the tribe of Zebulun, Gaddiel the son of Sodi.

<b>11 </b>Of the tribe of Joseph, <i>namely,</i> of the tribe of Manasseh, Gaddi the son of Susi.

<b>12 </b>Of the tribe of Dan, Ammiel the son of Gemalli.

<b>13 </b>Of the tribe of Asher, Sethur the son of Michael.

<b>14 </b>Of the tribe of Naphtali, Nahbi the son of Vophsi.

<b>15 </b>Of the tribe of Gad, Geuel the son of Machi.

<b>16 </b>These <i>are</i> the names of the men which Moses sent to spy out the land. And Moses called Oshea the son of Nun Jehoshua.

<b>17 </b>¶ And Moses sent them to spy out the land of Canaan, and said unto them, Get you up this <i>way</i> southward, and go up into the mountain:

<b>18 </b>And see the land, what it <i>is;</i> and the people that dwelleth therein, whether they <i>be</i> strong or weak, few or many;

<b>19 </b>And what the land <i>is</i> that they dwell in, whether it <i>be</i> good or bad; and what cities <i>they be</i> that they dwell in, whether in tents, or in strong holds;

<b>20 </b>And what the land <i>is,</i> whether it <i>be</i> fat or lean, whether there be wood therein, or not. And be ye of good courage, and bring of the fruit of the land. Now the time <i>was</i> the time of the firstripe grapes.

<b>21 </b>¶ So they went up, and searched the land from the wilderness of Zin unto Rehob, as men come to Hamath.

<b>22 </b>And they ascended by the south, and came unto Hebron; where Ahiman, Sheshai, and Talmai, the children of Anak, <i>were.</i> (Now Hebron was built seven years before Zoan in Egypt.)

<b>23 </b>And they came unto the brook of Eshcol, and cut down from thence a branch with one cluster of grapes, and they bare it between two upon a staff; and <i>they brought</i> of the pomegranates, and of the figs.

<b>24 </b>The place was called the brook Eshcol, because of the cluster of grapes which the children of Israel cut down from thence.

<b>25 </b>And they returned from searching of the land after forty days.

<b>26 </b>¶ And they went and came to Moses, and to Aaron, and to all the congregation of the children of Israel, unto the wilderness of Paran, to Kadesh; and brought back word unto them, and unto all the congregation, and shewed them the fruit of the land.

<b>27 </b>And they told him, and said, We came unto the land whither thou sentest us, and surely it floweth with milk and honey; and this <i>is</i> the fruit of it.

<b>28 </b>Nevertheless the people <i>be</i> strong that dwell in the land, and the cities <i>are</i> walled, <i>and</i> very great: and moreover we saw the children of Anak there.

<b>29 </b>The Amalekites dwell in the land of the south: and the Hittites, and the Jebusites, and the Amorites, dwell in the mountains: and the Canaanites dwell by the sea, and by the coast of Jordan.

<b>30 </b>And Caleb stilled the people before Moses, and said, Let us go up at once, and possess it; for we are well able to overcome it.

<b>31 </b>But the men that went up with him said, We be not able to go up against the people; for they <i>are</i> stronger than we.

<b>32 </b>And they brought up an evil report of the land which they had searched unto the children of Israel, saying, The land, through which we have gone to search it, <i>is</i> a land that eateth up the inhabitants thereof; and all the people that we saw in it <i>are</i> men of a great stature.

<b>33 </b>And there we saw the giants, the sons of Anak, <i>which come</i> of the giants: and we were in our own sight as grasshoppers, and so we were in their sight.


--------------------

CHAPTER 14

<b>1 </b>And all the congregation lifted up their voice, and cried; and the people wept that night.

<b>2 </b>And all the children of Israel murmured against Moses and against Aaron: and the whole congregation said unto them, Would God that we had died in the land of Egypt! or would God we had died in this wilderness!

<b>3 </b>And wherefore hath the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> brought us unto this land, to fall by the sword, that our wives and our children should be a prey? were it not better for us to return into Egypt?

<b>4 </b>And they said one to another, Let us make a captain, and let us return into Egypt.

<b>5 </b>Then Moses and Aaron fell on their faces before all the assembly of the congregation of the children of Israel.

<b>6 </b>¶ And Joshua the son of Nun, and Caleb the son of Jephunneh, <i>which were</i> of them that searched the land, rent their clothes:

<b>7 </b>And they spake unto all the company of the children of Israel, saying, The land, which we passed through to search it, <i>is</i> an exceeding good land.

<b>8 </b>If the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> delight in us, then he will bring us into this land, and give it us; a land which floweth with milk and honey.

<b>9 </b>Only rebel not ye against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, neither fear ye the people of the land; for they <i>are</i> bread for us: their defence is departed from them, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> with us: fear them not.

<b>10 </b>But all the congregation bade stone them with stones. And the glory of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> appeared in the tabernacle of the congregation before all the children of Israel.

<b>11 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, How long will this people provoke me? and how long will it be ere they believe me, for all the signs which I have shewed among them?

<b>12 </b>I will smite them with the pestilence, and disinherit them, and will make of thee a greater nation and mightier than they.

<b>13 </b>¶ And Moses said unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Then the Egyptians shall hear <i>it,</i> (for thou broughtest up this people in thy might from among them;)

<b>14 </b>And they will tell <i>it</i> to the inhabitants of this land: <i>for</i> they have heard that thou <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>art</i> among this people, that thou <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> art seen face to face, and <i>that</i> thy cloud standeth over them, and <i>that</i> thou goest before them, by day time in a pillar of a cloud, and in a pillar of fire by night.

<b>15 </b>¶ Now <i>if</i> thou shalt kill <i>all</i> this people as one man, then the nations which have heard the fame of thee will speak, saying,

<b>16 </b>Because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was not able to bring this people into the land which he sware unto them, therefore he hath slain them in the wilderness.

<b>17 </b>And now, I beseech thee, let the power of my Lord be great, according as thou hast spoken, saying,

<b>18 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> longsuffering, and of great mercy, forgiving iniquity and transgression, and by no means clearing <i>the guilty,</i> visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children unto the third and fourth <i>generation.</i>

<b>19 </b>Pardon, I beseech thee, the iniquity of this people according unto the greatness of thy mercy, and as thou hast forgiven this people, from Egypt even until now.

<b>20 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said, I have pardoned according to thy word:

<b>21 </b>But <i>as</i> truly <i>as</i> I live, all the earth shall be filled with the glory of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>22 </b>Because all those men which have seen my glory, and my miracles, which I did in Egypt and in the wilderness, and have tempted me now these ten times, and have not hearkened to my voice;

<b>23 </b>Surely they shall not see the land which I sware unto their fathers, neither shall any of them that provoked me see it:

<b>24 </b>But my servant Caleb, because he had another spirit with him, and hath followed me fully, him will I bring into the land whereinto he went; and his seed shall possess it.

<b>25 </b>(Now the Amalekites and the Canaanites dwelt in the valley.) To morrow turn you, and get you into the wilderness by the way of the Red sea.

<b>26 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses and unto Aaron, saying,

<b>27 </b>How long <i>shall I bear with</i> this evil congregation, which murmur against me? I have heard the murmurings of the children of Israel, which they murmur against me.

<b>28 </b>Say unto them, <i>As truly as</i> I live, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, as ye have spoken in mine ears, so will I do to you:

<b>29 </b>Your carcases shall fall in this wilderness; and all that were numbered of you, according to your whole number, from twenty years old and upward, which have murmured against me,

<b>30 </b>Doubtless ye shall not come into the land, <i>concerning</i> which I sware to make you dwell therein, save Caleb the son of Jephunneh, and Joshua the son of Nun.

<b>31 </b>But your little ones, which ye said should be a prey, them will I bring in, and they shall know the land which ye have despised.

<b>32 </b>But <i>as for</i> you, your carcases, they shall fall in this wilderness.

<b>33 </b>And your children shall wander in the wilderness forty years, and bear your whoredoms, until your carcases be wasted in the wilderness.

<b>34 </b>After the number of the days in which ye searched the land, <i>even</i> forty days, each day for a year, shall ye bear your iniquities, <i>even</i> forty years, and ye shall know my breach of promise.

<b>35 </b>I the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> have said, I will surely do it unto all this evil congregation, that are gathered together against me: in this wilderness they shall be consumed, and there they shall die.

<b>36 </b>And the men, which Moses sent to search the land, who returned, and made all the congregation to murmur against him, by bringing up a slander upon the land,

<b>37 </b>Even those men that did bring up the evil report upon the land, died by the plague before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>38 </b>But Joshua the son of Nun, and Caleb the son of Jephunneh, <i>which were</i> of the men that went to search the land, lived <i>still.</i>

<b>39 </b>And Moses told these sayings unto all the children of Israel: and the people mourned greatly.

<b>40 </b>¶ And they rose up early in the morning, and gat them up into the top of the mountain, saying, Lo, we <i>be here,</i> and will go up unto the place which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath promised: for we have sinned.

<b>41 </b>And Moses said, Wherefore now do ye transgress the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>? but it shall not prosper.

<b>42 </b>Go not up, for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> not among you; that ye be not smitten before your enemies.

<b>43 </b>For the Amalekites and the Canaanites <i>are</i> there before you, and ye shall fall by the sword: because ye are turned away from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, therefore the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will not be with you.

<b>44 </b>But they presumed to go up unto the hill top: nevertheless the ark of the covenant of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and Moses, departed not out of the camp.

<b>45 </b>Then the Amalekites came down, and the Canaanites which dwelt in that hill, and smote them, and discomfited them, <i>even</i> unto Hormah.


--------------------

CHAPTER 15

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>2 </b>Speak unto the children of Israel, and say unto them, When ye be come into the land of your habitations, which I give unto you,

<b>3 </b>And will make an offering by fire unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, a burnt offering, or a sacrifice in performing a vow, or in a freewill offering, or in your solemn feasts, to make a sweet savour unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, of the herd, or of the flock:

<b>4 </b>Then shall he that offereth his offering unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> bring a meat offering of a tenth deal of flour mingled with the fourth <i>part</i> of an hin of oil.

<b>5 </b>And the fourth <i>part</i> of an hin of wine for a drink offering shalt thou prepare with the burnt offering or sacrifice, for one lamb.

<b>6 </b>Or for a ram, thou shalt prepare <i>for</i> a meat offering two tenth deals of flour mingled with the third <i>part</i> of an hin of oil.

<b>7 </b>And for a drink offering thou shalt offer the third <i>part</i> of an hin of wine, <i>for</i> a sweet savour unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>8 </b>And when thou preparest a bullock <i>for</i> a burnt offering, or <i>for</i> a sacrifice in performing a vow, or peace offerings unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>:

<b>9 </b>Then shall he bring with a bullock a meat offering of three tenth deals of flour mingled with half an hin of oil.

<b>10 </b>And thou shalt bring for a drink offering half an hin of wine, <i>for</i> an offering made by fire, of a sweet savour unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>11 </b>Thus shall it be done for one bullock, or for one ram, or for a lamb, or a kid.

<b>12 </b>According to the number that ye shall prepare, so shall ye do to every one according to their number.

<b>13 </b>All that are born of the country shall do these things after this manner, in offering an offering made by fire, of a sweet savour unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>14 </b>And if a stranger sojourn with you, or whosoever <i>be</i> among you in your generations, and will offer an offering made by fire, of a sweet savour unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; as ye do, so he shall do.

<b>15 </b>One ordinance <i>shall be both</i> for you of the congregation, and also for the stranger that sojourneth <i>with you,</i> an ordinance for ever in your generations: as ye <i>are,</i> so shall the stranger be before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>16 </b>One law and one manner shall be for you, and for the stranger that sojourneth with you.

<b>17 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>18 </b>Speak unto the children of Israel, and say unto them, When ye come into the land whither I bring you,

<b>19 </b>Then it shall be, that, when ye eat of the bread of the land, ye shall offer up an heave offering unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>20 </b>Ye shall offer up a cake of the first of your dough <i>for</i> an heave offering: as <i>ye do</i> the heave offering of the threshingfloor, so shall ye heave it.

<b>21 </b>Of the first of your dough ye shall give unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> an heave offering in your generations.

<b>22 </b>¶ And if ye have erred, and not observed all these commandments, which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath spoken unto Moses,

<b>23 </b><i>Even</i> all that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath commanded you by the hand of Moses, from the day that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded <i>Moses,</i> and henceforward among your generations;

<b>24 </b>Then it shall be, if <i>ought</i> be committed by ignorance without the knowledge of the congregation, that all the congregation shall offer one young bullock for a burnt offering, for a sweet savour unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, with his meat offering, and his drink offering, according to the manner, and one kid of the goats for a sin offering.

<b>25 </b>And the priest shall make an atonement for all the congregation of the children of Israel, and it shall be forgiven them; for it <i>is</i> ignorance: and they shall bring their offering, a sacrifice made by fire unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and their sin offering before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, for their ignorance:

<b>26 </b>And it shall be forgiven all the congregation of the children of Israel, and the stranger that sojourneth among them; seeing all the people <i>were</i> in ignorance.

<b>27 </b>¶ And if any soul sin through ignorance, then he shall bring a she goat of the first year for a sin offering.

<b>28 </b>And the priest shall make an atonement for the soul that sinneth ignorantly, when he sinneth by ignorance before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to make an atonement for him; and it shall be forgiven him.

<b>29 </b>Ye shall have one law for him that sinneth through ignorance, <i>both for</i> him that is born among the children of Israel, and for the stranger that sojourneth among them.

<b>30 </b>¶ But the soul that doeth <i>ought</i> presumptuously, <i>whether he be</i> born in the land, or a stranger, the same reproacheth the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and that soul shall be cut off from among his people.

<b>31 </b>Because he hath despised the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and hath broken his commandment, that soul shall utterly be cut off; his iniquity <i>shall be</i> upon him.

<b>32 </b>¶ And while the children of Israel were in the wilderness, they found a man that gathered sticks upon the sabbath day.

<b>33 </b>And they that found him gathering sticks brought him unto Moses and Aaron, and unto all the congregation.

<b>34 </b>And they put him in ward, because it was not declared what should be done to him.

<b>35 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, The man shall be surely put to death: all the congregation shall stone him with stones without the camp.

<b>36 </b>And all the congregation brought him without the camp, and stoned him with stones, and he died; as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded Moses.

<b>37 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>38 </b>Speak unto the children of Israel, and bid them that they make them fringes in the borders of their garments throughout their generations, and that they put upon the fringe of the borders a ribband of blue:

<b>39 </b>And it shall be unto you for a fringe, that ye may look upon it, and remember all the commandments of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and do them; and that ye seek not after your own heart and your own eyes, after which ye use to go a whoring:

<b>40 </b>That ye may remember, and do all my commandments, and be holy unto your God.

<b>41 </b>I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, which brought you out of the land of Egypt, to be your God: I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God.


--------------------

CHAPTER 16

<b>1 </b>Now Korah, the son of Izhar, the son of Kohath, the son of Levi, and Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, and On, the son of Peleth, sons of Reuben, took <i>men:</i>

<b>2 </b>And they rose up before Moses, with certain of the children of Israel, two hundred and fifty princes of the assembly, famous in the congregation, men of renown:

<b>3 </b>And they gathered themselves together against Moses and against Aaron, and said unto them, <i>Ye take</i> too much upon you, seeing all the congregation <i>are</i> holy, every one of them, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> among them: wherefore then lift ye up yourselves above the congregation of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>?

<b>4 </b>And when Moses heard <i>it,</i> he fell upon his face:

<b>5 </b>And he spake unto Korah and unto all his company, saying, Even to morrow the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will shew who <i>are</i> his, and <i>who is</i> holy; and will cause <i>him</i> to come near unto him: even <i>him</i> whom he hath chosen will he cause to come near unto him.

<b>6 </b>This do; Take you censers, Korah, and all his company;

<b>7 </b>And put fire therein, and put incense in them before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> to morrow: and it shall be <i>that</i> the man whom the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> doth choose, he <i>shall be</i> holy: <i>ye take</i> too much upon you, ye sons of Levi.

<b>8 </b>And Moses said unto Korah, Hear, I pray you, ye sons of Levi:

<b>9 </b><i>Seemeth it but</i> a small thing unto you, that the God of Israel hath separated you from the congregation of Israel, to bring you near to himself to do the service of the tabernacle of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and to stand before the congregation to minister unto them?

<b>10 </b>And he hath brought thee near <i>to him,</i> and all thy brethren the sons of Levi with thee: and seek ye the priesthood also?

<b>11 </b>For which cause <i>both</i> thou and all thy company <i>are</i> gathered together against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and what <i>is</i> Aaron, that ye murmur against him?

<b>12 </b>¶ And Moses sent to call Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab: which said, We will not come up:

<b>13 </b><i>Is it</i> a small thing that thou hast brought us up out of a land that floweth with milk and honey, to kill us in the wilderness, except thou make thyself altogether a prince over us?

<b>14 </b>Moreover thou hast not brought us into a land that floweth with milk and honey, or given us inheritance of fields and vineyards: wilt thou put out the eyes of these men? we will not come up.

<b>15 </b>And Moses was very wroth, and said unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Respect not thou their offering: I have not taken one ass from them, neither have I hurt one of them.

<b>16 </b>And Moses said unto Korah, Be thou and all thy company before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, thou, and they, and Aaron, to morrow:

<b>17 </b>And take every man his censer, and put incense in them, and bring ye before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> every man his censer, two hundred and fifty censers; thou also, and Aaron, each <i>of you</i> his censer.

<b>18 </b>And they took every man his censer, and put fire in them, and laid incense thereon, and stood in the door of the tabernacle of the congregation with Moses and Aaron.

<b>19 </b>And Korah gathered all the congregation against them unto the door of the tabernacle of the congregation: and the glory of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> appeared unto all the congregation.

<b>20 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses and unto Aaron, saying,

<b>21 </b>Separate yourselves from among this congregation, that I may consume them in a moment.

<b>22 </b>And they fell upon their faces, and said, O God, the God of the spirits of all flesh, shall one man sin, and wilt thou be wroth with all the congregation?

<b>23 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>24 </b>Speak unto the congregation, saying, Get you up from about the tabernacle of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram.

<b>25 </b>And Moses rose up and went unto Dathan and Abiram; and the elders of Israel followed him.

<b>26 </b>And he spake unto the congregation, saying, Depart, I pray you, from the tents of these wicked men, and touch nothing of theirs, lest ye be consumed in all their sins.

<b>27 </b>So they gat up from the tabernacle of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram, on every side: and Dathan and Abiram came out, and stood in the door of their tents, and their wives, and their sons, and their little children.

<b>28 </b>And Moses said, Hereby ye shall know that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath sent me to do all these works; for <i>I have</i> not <i>done them</i> of mine own mind.

<b>29 </b>If these men die the common death of all men, or if they be visited after the visitation of all men; <i>then</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath not sent me.

<b>30 </b>But if the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> make a new thing, and the earth open her mouth, and swallow them up, with all that <i>appertain</i> unto them, and they go down quick into the pit; then ye shall understand that these men have provoked the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>31 </b>¶ And it came to pass, as he had made an end of speaking all these words, that the ground clave asunder that <i>was</i> under them:

<b>32 </b>And the earth opened her mouth, and swallowed them up, and their houses, and all the men that <i>appertained</i> unto Korah, and all <i>their</i> goods.

<b>33 </b>They, and all that <i>appertained</i> to them, went down alive into the pit, and the earth closed upon them: and they perished from among the congregation.

<b>34 </b>And all Israel that <i>were</i> round about them fled at the cry of them: for they said, Lest the earth swallow us up <i>also.</i>

<b>35 </b>And there came out a fire from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and consumed the two hundred and fifty men that offered incense.

<b>36 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>37 </b>Speak unto Eleazar the son of Aaron the priest, that he take up the censers out of the burning, and scatter thou the fire yonder; for they are hallowed.

<b>38 </b>The censers of these sinners against their own souls, let them make them broad plates <i>for</i> a covering of the altar: for they offered them before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, therefore they are hallowed: and they shall be a sign unto the children of Israel.

<b>39 </b>And Eleazar the priest took the brasen censers, wherewith they that were burnt had offered; and they were made broad <i>plates for</i> a covering of the altar:

<b>40 </b><i>To be</i> a memorial unto the children of Israel, that no stranger, which <i>is</i> not of the seed of Aaron, come near to offer incense before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; that he be not as Korah, and as his company: as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said to him by the hand of Moses.

<b>41 </b>¶ But on the morrow all the congregation of the children of Israel murmured against Moses and against Aaron, saying, Ye have killed the people of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>42 </b>And it came to pass, when the congregation was gathered against Moses and against Aaron, that they looked toward the tabernacle of the congregation: and, behold, the cloud covered it, and the glory of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> appeared.

<b>43 </b>And Moses and Aaron came before the tabernacle of the congregation.

<b>44 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>45 </b>Get you up from among this congregation, that I may consume them as in a moment. And they fell upon their faces.

<b>46 </b>¶ And Moses said unto Aaron, Take a censer, and put fire therein from off the altar, and put on incense, and go quickly unto the congregation, and make an atonement for them: for there is wrath gone out from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; the plague is begun.

<b>47 </b>And Aaron took as Moses commanded, and ran into the midst of the congregation; and, behold, the plague was begun among the people: and he put on incense, and made an atonement for the people.

<b>48 </b>And he stood between the dead and the living; and the plague was stayed.

<b>49 </b>Now they that died in the plague were fourteen thousand and seven hundred, beside them that died about the matter of Korah.

<b>50 </b>And Aaron returned unto Moses unto the door of the tabernacle of the congregation: and the plague was stayed.


--------------------

CHAPTER 17

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>2 </b>Speak unto the children of Israel, and take of every one of them a rod according to the house of <i>their</i> fathers, of all their princes according to the house of their fathers twelve rods: write thou every man’s name upon his rod.

<b>3 </b>And thou shalt write Aaron’s name upon the rod of Levi: for one rod <i>shall be</i> for the head of the house of their fathers.

<b>4 </b>And thou shalt lay them up in the tabernacle of the congregation before the testimony, where I will meet with you.

<b>5 </b>And it shall come to pass, <i>that</i> the man’s rod, whom I shall choose, shall blossom: and I will make to cease from me the murmurings of the children of Israel, whereby they murmur against you.

<b>6 </b>¶ And Moses spake unto the children of Israel, and every one of their princes gave him a rod apiece, for each prince one, according to their fathers’ houses, <i>even</i> twelve rods: and the rod of Aaron <i>was</i> among their rods.

<b>7 </b>And Moses laid up the rods before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in the tabernacle of witness.

<b>8 </b>And it came to pass, that on the morrow Moses went into the tabernacle of witness; and, behold, the rod of Aaron for the house of Levi was budded, and brought forth buds, and bloomed blossoms, and yielded almonds.

<b>9 </b>And Moses brought out all the rods from before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto all the children of Israel: and they looked, and took every man his rod.

<b>10 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Bring Aaron’s rod again before the testimony, to be kept for a token against the rebels; and thou shalt quite take away their murmurings from me, that they die not.

<b>11 </b>And Moses did <i>so:</i> as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded him, so did he.

<b>12 </b>And the children of Israel spake unto Moses, saying, Behold, we die, we perish, we all perish.

<b>13 </b>Whosoever cometh any thing near unto the tabernacle of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall die: shall we be consumed with dying?


--------------------

CHAPTER 18

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Aaron, Thou and thy sons and thy father’s house with thee shall bear the iniquity of the sanctuary: and thou and thy sons with thee shall bear the iniquity of your priesthood.

<b>2 </b>And thy brethren also of the tribe of Levi, the tribe of thy father, bring thou with thee, that they may be joined unto thee, and minister unto thee: but thou and thy sons with thee <i>shall minister</i> before the tabernacle of witness.

<b>3 </b>And they shall keep thy charge, and the charge of all the tabernacle: only they shall not come nigh the vessels of the sanctuary and the altar, that neither they, nor ye also, die.

<b>4 </b>And they shall be joined unto thee, and keep the charge of the tabernacle of the congregation, for all the service of the tabernacle: and a stranger shall not come nigh unto you.

<b>5 </b>And ye shall keep the charge of the sanctuary, and the charge of the altar: that there be no wrath any more upon the children of Israel.

<b>6 </b>And I, behold, I have taken your brethren the Levites from among the children of Israel: to you <i>they are</i> given <i>as</i> a gift for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to do the service of the tabernacle of the congregation.

<b>7 </b>Therefore thou and thy sons with thee shall keep your priest’s office for every thing of the altar, and within the veil; and ye shall serve: I have given your priest’s office <i>unto you as</i> a service of gift: and the stranger that cometh nigh shall be put to death.

<b>8 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Aaron, Behold, I also have given thee the charge of mine heave offerings of all the hallowed things of the children of Israel; unto thee have I given them by reason of the anointing, and to thy sons, by an ordinance for ever.

<b>9 </b>This shall be thine of the most holy things, <i>reserved</i> from the fire: every oblation of theirs, every meat offering of theirs, and every sin offering of theirs, and every trespass offering of theirs, which they shall render unto me, <i>shall be</i> most holy for thee and for thy sons.

<b>10 </b>In the most holy <i>place</i> shalt thou eat it; every male shall eat it: it shall be holy unto thee.

<b>11 </b>And this <i>is</i> thine; the heave offering of their gift, with all the wave offerings of the children of Israel: I have given them unto thee, and to thy sons and to thy daughters with thee, by a statute for ever: every one that is clean in thy house shall eat of it.

<b>12 </b>All the best of the oil, and all the best of the wine, and of the wheat, the firstfruits of them which they shall offer unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, them have I given thee.

<b>13 </b><i>And</i> whatsoever is first ripe in the land, which they shall bring unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, shall be thine; every one that is clean in thine house shall eat <i>of</i> it.

<b>14 </b>Every thing devoted in Israel shall be thine.

<b>15 </b>Every thing that openeth the matrix in all flesh, which they bring unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>whether it be</i> of men or beasts, shall be thine: nevertheless the firstborn of man shalt thou surely redeem, and the firstling of unclean beasts shalt thou redeem.

<b>16 </b>And those that are to be redeemed from a month old shalt thou redeem, according to thine estimation, for the money of five shekels, after the shekel of the sanctuary, which <i>is</i> twenty gerahs.

<b>17 </b>But the firstling of a cow, or the firstling of a sheep, or the firstling of a goat, thou shalt not redeem; they <i>are</i> holy: thou shalt sprinkle their blood upon the altar, and shalt burn their fat <i>for</i> an offering made by fire, for a sweet savour unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>18 </b>And the flesh of them shall be thine, as the wave breast and as the right shoulder are thine.

<b>19 </b>All the heave offerings of the holy things, which the children of Israel offer unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, have I given thee, and thy sons and thy daughters with thee, by a statute for ever: it <i>is</i> a covenant of salt for ever before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto thee and to thy seed with thee.

<b>20 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Aaron, Thou shalt have no inheritance in their land, neither shalt thou have any part among them: I <i>am</i> thy part and thine inheritance among the children of Israel.

<b>21 </b>And, behold, I have given the children of Levi all the tenth in Israel for an inheritance, for their service which they serve, <i>even</i> the service of the tabernacle of the congregation.

<b>22 </b>Neither must the children of Israel henceforth come nigh the tabernacle of the congregation, lest they bear sin, and die.

<b>23 </b>But the Levites shall do the service of the tabernacle of the congregation, and they shall bear their iniquity: <i>it shall be</i> a statute for ever throughout your generations, that among the children of Israel they have no inheritance.

<b>24 </b>But the tithes of the children of Israel, which they offer <i>as</i> an heave offering unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, I have given to the Levites to inherit: therefore I have said unto them, Among the children of Israel they shall have no inheritance.

<b>25 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>26 </b>Thus speak unto the Levites, and say unto them, When ye take of the children of Israel the tithes which I have given you from them for your inheritance, then ye shall offer up an heave offering of it for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>even</i> a tenth <i>part</i> of the tithe.

<b>27 </b>And <i>this</i> your heave offering shall be reckoned unto you, as though <i>it were</i> the corn of the threshingfloor, and as the fulness of the winepress.

<b>28 </b>Thus ye also shall offer an heave offering unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of all your tithes, which ye receive of the children of Israel; and ye shall give thereof the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s heave offering to Aaron the priest.

<b>29 </b>Out of all your gifts ye shall offer every heave offering of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, of all the best thereof, <i>even</i> the hallowed part thereof out of it.

<b>30 </b>Therefore thou shalt say unto them, When ye have heaved the best thereof from it, then it shall be counted unto the Levites as the increase of the threshingfloor, and as the increase of the winepress.

<b>31 </b>And ye shall eat it in every place, ye and your households: for it <i>is</i> your reward for your service in the tabernacle of the congregation.

<b>32 </b>And ye shall bear no sin by reason of it, when ye have heaved from it the best of it: neither shall ye pollute the holy things of the children of Israel, lest ye die.


--------------------

CHAPTER 19

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses and unto Aaron, saying,

<b>2 </b>This <i>is</i> the ordinance of the law which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath commanded, saying, Speak unto the children of Israel, that they bring thee a red heifer without spot, wherein <i>is</i> no blemish, <i>and</i> upon which never came yoke:

<b>3 </b>And ye shall give her unto Eleazar the priest, that he may bring her forth without the camp, and <i>one</i> shall slay her before his face:

<b>4 </b>And Eleazar the priest shall take of her blood with his finger, and sprinkle of her blood directly before the tabernacle of the congregation seven times:

<b>5 </b>And <i>one</i> shall burn the heifer in his sight; her skin, and her flesh, and her blood, with her dung, shall he burn:

<b>6 </b>And the priest shall take cedar wood, and hyssop, and scarlet, and cast <i>it</i> into the midst of the burning of the heifer.

<b>7 </b>Then the priest shall wash his clothes, and he shall bathe his flesh in water, and afterward he shall come into the camp, and the priest shall be unclean until the even.

<b>8 </b>And he that burneth her shall wash his clothes in water, and bathe his flesh in water, and shall be unclean until the even.

<b>9 </b>And a man <i>that is</i> clean shall gather up the ashes of the heifer, and lay <i>them</i> up without the camp in a clean place, and it shall be kept for the congregation of the children of Israel for a water of separation: it <i>is</i> a purification for sin.

<b>10 </b>And he that gathereth the ashes of the heifer shall wash his clothes, and be unclean until the even: and it shall be unto the children of Israel, and unto the stranger that sojourneth among them, for a statute for ever.

<b>11 </b>¶ He that toucheth the dead body of any man shall be unclean seven days.

<b>12 </b>He shall purify himself with it on the third day, and on the seventh day he shall be clean: but if he purify not himself the third day, then the seventh day he shall not be clean.

<b>13 </b>Whosoever toucheth the dead body of any man that is dead, and purifieth not himself, defileth the tabernacle of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and that soul shall be cut off from Israel: because the water of separation was not sprinkled upon him, he shall be unclean; his uncleanness <i>is</i> yet upon him.

<b>14 </b>This <i>is</i> the law, when a man dieth in a tent: all that come into the tent, and all that <i>is</i> in the tent, shall be unclean seven days.

<b>15 </b>And every open vessel, which hath no covering bound upon it, <i>is</i> unclean.

<b>16 </b>And whosoever toucheth one that is slain with a sword in the open fields, or a dead body, or a bone of a man, or a grave, shall be unclean seven days.

<b>17 </b>And for an unclean <i>person</i> they shall take of the ashes of the burnt heifer of purification for sin, and running water shall be put thereto in a vessel:

<b>18 </b>And a clean person shall take hyssop, and dip <i>it</i> in the water, and sprinkle <i>it</i> upon the tent, and upon all the vessels, and upon the persons that were there, and upon him that touched a bone, or one slain, or one dead, or a grave:

<b>19 </b>And the clean <i>person</i> shall sprinkle upon the unclean on the third day, and on the seventh day: and on the seventh day he shall purify himself, and wash his clothes, and bathe himself in water, and shall be clean at even.

<b>20 </b>But the man that shall be unclean, and shall not purify himself, that soul shall be cut off from among the congregation, because he hath defiled the sanctuary of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: the water of separation hath not been sprinkled upon him; he <i>is</i> unclean.

<b>21 </b>And it shall be a perpetual statute unto them, that he that sprinkleth the water of separation shall wash his clothes; and he that toucheth the water of separation shall be unclean until even.

<b>22 </b>And whatsoever the unclean <i>person</i> toucheth shall be unclean; and the soul that toucheth <i>it</i> shall be unclean until even.


--------------------

CHAPTER 20

<b>1 </b>Then came the children of Israel, <i>even</i> the whole congregation, into the desert of Zin in the first month: and the people abode in Kadesh; and Miriam died there, and was buried there.

<b>2 </b>And there was no water for the congregation: and they gathered themselves together against Moses and against Aaron.

<b>3 </b>And the people chode with Moses, and spake, saying, Would God that we had died when our brethren died before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>!

<b>4 </b>And why have ye brought up the congregation of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> into this wilderness, that we and our cattle should die there?

<b>5 </b>And wherefore have ye made us to come up out of Egypt, to bring us in unto this evil place? it <i>is</i> no place of seed, or of figs, or of vines, or of pomegranates; neither <i>is</i> there any water to drink.

<b>6 </b>And Moses and Aaron went from the presence of the assembly unto the door of the tabernacle of the congregation, and they fell upon their faces: and the glory of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> appeared unto them.

<b>7 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, saying,

<b>8 </b>Take the rod, and gather thou the assembly together, thou, and Aaron thy brother, and speak ye unto the rock before their eyes; and it shall give forth his water, and thou shalt bring forth to them water out of the rock: so thou shalt give the congregation and their beasts drink.

<b>9 </b>And Moses took the rod from before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, as he commanded him.

<b>10 </b>And Moses and Aaron gathered the congregation together before the rock, and he said unto them, Hear now, ye rebels; must we fetch you water out of this rock?

<b>11 </b>And Moses lifted up his hand, and with his rod he smote the rock twice: and the water came out abundantly, and the congregation drank, and their beasts <i>also.</i>

<b>12 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses and Aaron, Because ye believed me not, to sanctify me in the eyes of the children of Israel, therefore ye shall not bring this congregation into the land which I have given them.

<b>13 </b>This <i>is</i> the water of Meribah; because the children of Israel strove with the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and he was sanctified in them.

<b>14 </b>¶ And Moses sent messengers from Kadesh unto the king of Edom, Thus saith thy brother Israel, Thou knowest all the travail that hath befallen us:

<b>15 </b>How our fathers went down into Egypt, and we have dwelt in Egypt a long time; and the Egyptians vexed us, and our fathers:

<b>16 </b>And when we cried unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, he heard our voice, and sent an angel, and hath brought us forth out of Egypt: and, behold, we <i>are</i> in Kadesh, a city in the uttermost of thy border:

<b>17 </b>Let us pass, I pray thee, through thy country: we will not pass through the fields, or through the vineyards, neither will we drink <i>of</i> the water of the wells: we will go by the king’s <i>high</i> way, we will not turn to the right hand nor to the left, until we have passed thy borders.

<b>18 </b>And Edom said unto him, Thou shalt not pass by me, lest I come out against thee with the sword.

<b>19 </b>And the children of Israel said unto him, We will go by the high way: and if I and my cattle drink of thy water, then I will pay for it: I will only, without <i>doing</i> any thing <i>else,</i> go through on my feet.

<b>20 </b>And he said, Thou shalt not go through. And Edom came out against him with much people, and with a strong hand.

<b>21 </b>Thus Edom refused to give Israel passage through his border: wherefore Israel turned away from him.

<b>22 </b>¶ And the children of Israel, <i>even</i> the whole congregation, journeyed from Kadesh, and came unto mount Hor.

<b>23 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses and Aaron in mount Hor, by the coast of the land of Edom, saying,

<b>24 </b>Aaron shall be gathered unto his people: for he shall not enter into the land which I have given unto the children of Israel, because ye rebelled against my word at the water of Meribah.

<b>25 </b>Take Aaron and Eleazar his son, and bring them up unto mount Hor:

<b>26 </b>And strip Aaron of his garments, and put them upon Eleazar his son: and Aaron shall be gathered <i>unto his people,</i> and shall die there.

<b>27 </b>And Moses did as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded: and they went up into mount Hor in the sight of all the congregation.

<b>28 </b>And Moses stripped Aaron of his garments, and put them upon Eleazar his son; and Aaron died there in the top of the mount: and Moses and Eleazar came down from the mount.

<b>29 </b>And when all the congregation saw that Aaron was dead, they mourned for Aaron thirty days, <i>even</i> all the house of Israel.


--------------------

CHAPTER 21

<b>1 </b>And <i>when</i> king Arad the Canaanite, which dwelt in the south, heard tell that Israel came by the way of the spies; then he fought against Israel, and took <i>some</i> of them prisoners.

<b>2 </b>And Israel vowed a vow unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and said, If thou wilt indeed deliver this people into my hand, then I will utterly destroy their cities.

<b>3 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hearkened to the voice of Israel, and delivered up the Canaanites; and they utterly destroyed them and their cities: and he called the name of the place Hormah.

<b>4 </b>¶ And they journeyed from mount Hor by the way of the Red sea, to compass the land of Edom: and the soul of the people was much discouraged because of the way.

<b>5 </b>And the people spake against God, and against Moses, Wherefore have ye brought us up out of Egypt to die in the wilderness? for <i>there is</i> no bread, neither <i>is there any</i> water; and our soul loatheth this light bread.

<b>6 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sent fiery serpents among the people, and they bit the people; and much people of Israel died.

<b>7 </b>¶ Therefore the people came to Moses, and said, We have sinned, for we have spoken against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and against thee; pray unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that he take away the serpents from us. And Moses prayed for the people.

<b>8 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Make thee a fiery serpent, and set it upon a pole: and it shall come to pass, that every one that is bitten, when he looketh upon it, shall live.

<b>9 </b>And Moses made a serpent of brass, and put it upon a pole, and it came to pass, that if a serpent had bitten any man, when he beheld the serpent of brass, he lived.

<b>10 </b>¶ And the children of Israel set forward, and pitched in Oboth.

<b>11 </b>And they journeyed from Oboth, and pitched at Ije-abarim, in the wilderness which <i>is</i> before Moab, toward the sunrising.

<b>12 </b>¶ From thence they removed, and pitched in the valley of Zared.

<b>13 </b>From thence they removed, and pitched on the other side of Arnon, which <i>is</i> in the wilderness that cometh out of the coasts of the Amorites: for Arnon <i>is</i> the border of Moab, between Moab and the Amorites.

<b>14 </b>Wherefore it is said in the book of the wars of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, What he did in the Red sea, and in the brooks of Arnon,

<b>15 </b>And at the stream of the brooks that goeth down to the dwelling of Ar, and lieth upon the border of Moab.

<b>16 </b>And from thence <i>they went</i> to Beer: that <i>is</i> the well whereof the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto Moses, Gather the people together, and I will give them water.

<b>17 </b>¶ Then Israel sang this song, Spring up, O well; sing ye unto it:

<b>18 </b>The princes digged the well, the nobles of the people digged it, by <i>the direction of</i> the lawgiver, with their staves. And from the wilderness <i>they went</i> to Mattanah:

<b>19 </b>And from Mattanah to Nahaliel: and from Nahaliel to Bamoth:

<b>20 </b>And from Bamoth <i>in</i> the valley, that <i>is</i> in the country of Moab, to the top of Pisgah, which looketh toward Jeshimon.

<b>21 </b>¶ And Israel sent messengers unto Sihon king of the Amorites, saying,

<b>22 </b>Let me pass through thy land: we will not turn into the fields, or into the vineyards; we will not drink <i>of</i> the waters of the well: <i>but</i> we will go along by the king’s <i>high</i> way, until we be past thy borders.

<b>23 </b>And Sihon would not suffer Israel to pass through his border: but Sihon gathered all his people together, and went out against Israel into the wilderness: and he came to Jahaz, and fought against Israel.

<b>24 </b>And Israel smote him with the edge of the sword, and possessed his land from Arnon unto Jabbok, even unto the children of Ammon: for the border of the children of Ammon <i>was</i> strong.

<b>25 </b>And Israel took all these cities: and Israel dwelt in all the cities of the Amorites, in Heshbon, and in all the villages thereof.

<b>26 </b>For Heshbon <i>was</i> the city of Sihon the king of the Amorites, who had fought against the former king of Moab, and taken all his land out of his hand, even unto Arnon.

<b>27 </b>Wherefore they that speak in proverbs say, Come into Heshbon, let the city of Sihon be built and prepared:

<b>28 </b>For there is a fire gone out of Heshbon, a flame from the city of Sihon: it hath consumed Ar of Moab, <i>and</i> the lords of the high places of Arnon.

<b>29 </b>Woe to thee, Moab! thou art undone, O people of Chemosh: he hath given his sons that escaped, and his daughters, into captivity unto Sihon king of the Amorites.

<b>30 </b>We have shot at them; Heshbon is perished even unto Dibon, and we have laid them waste even unto Nophah, which <i>reacheth</i> unto Medeba.

<b>31 </b>¶ Thus Israel dwelt in the land of the Amorites.

<b>32 </b>And Moses sent to spy out Jaazer, and they took the villages thereof, and drove out the Amorites that <i>were</i> there.

<b>33 </b>¶ And they turned and went up by the way of Bashan: and Og the king of Bashan went out against them, he, and all his people, to the battle at Edrei.

<b>34 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Moses, Fear him not: for I have delivered him into thy hand, and all his people, and his land; and thou shalt do to him as thou didst unto Sihon king of the Amorites, which dwelt at Heshbon.

<b>35 </b>So they smote him, and his sons, and all his people, until there was none left him alive: and they possessed his land.


--------------------

CHAPTER 22

<b>1 </b>And the children of Israel set forward, and pitched in the plains of Moab on this side Jordan <i>by</i> Jericho.

<b>2 </b>¶ And Balak the son of Zippor saw all that Israel had done to the Amorites.

<b>3 </b>And Moab was sore afraid of the people, because they <i>were</i> many: and Moab was distressed because of the children of Israel.

<b>4 </b>And Moab said unto the elders of Midian, Now shall this company lick up all <i>that are</i> round about us, as the ox licketh up the grass of the field. And Balak the son of Zippor <i>was</i> king of the Moabites at that time.

<b>5 </b>He sent messengers therefore unto Balaam the son of Beor to Pethor, which <i>is</i> by the river of the land of the children of his people, to call him, saying, Behold, there is a people come out from Egypt: behold, they cover the face of the earth, and they abide over against me:

<b>6 </b>Come now therefore, I pray thee, curse me this people; for they <i>are</i> too mighty for me: peradventure I shall prevail, <i>that</i> we may smite them, and <i>that</i> I may drive them out of the land: for I wot that he whom thou blessest <i>is</i> blessed, and he whom thou cursest is cursed.

<b>7 </b>And the elders of Moab and the elders of Midian departed with the rewards of divination in their hand; and they came unto Balaam, and spake unto him the words of Balak.

<b>8 </b>And he said unto them, Lodge here this night, and I will bring you word again, as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall speak unto me: and the princes of Moab abode with Balaam.

<b>9 </b>And God came unto Balaam, and said, What men <i>are</i> these with thee?

<b>10 </b>And Balaam said unto God, Balak the son of Zippor, king of Moab, hath sent unto me, <i>saying,</i>

<b>11 </b>Behold, <i>there is</i> a people come out of Egypt, which covereth the face of the earth: come now, curse me them; peradventure I shall be able to overcome them, and drive them out.

<b>12 </b>And God said unto Balaam, Thou shalt not go with them; thou shalt not curse the people: for they <i>are</i> blessed.

<b>13 </b>And Balaam rose up in the morning, and said unto the princes of Balak, Get you into your land: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> refuseth to give me leave to go with you.

<b>14 </b>And the princes of Moab rose up, and they went unto Balak, and said, Balaam refuseth to come with us.

<b>15 </b>¶ And Balak sent yet again princes, more, and more honourable than they.

<b>16 </b>And they came to Balaam, and said to him, Thus saith Balak the son of Zippor, Let nothing, I pray thee, hinder thee from coming unto me:

<b>17 </b>For I will promote thee unto very great honour, and I will do whatsoever thou sayest unto me: come therefore, I pray thee, curse me this people.

<b>18 </b>And Balaam answered and said unto the servants of Balak, If Balak would give me his house full of silver and gold, I cannot go beyond the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God, to do less or more.

<b>19 </b>Now therefore, I pray you, tarry ye also here this night, that I may know what the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will say unto me more.

<b>20 </b>And God came unto Balaam at night, and said unto him, If the men come to call thee, rise up, <i>and</i> go with them; but yet the word which I shall say unto thee, that shalt thou do.

<b>21 </b>And Balaam rose up in the morning, and saddled his ass, and went with the princes of Moab.

<b>22 </b>¶ And God’s anger was kindled because he went: and the angel of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> stood in the way for an adversary against him. Now he was riding upon his ass, and his two servants <i>were</i> with him.

<b>23 </b>And the ass saw the angel of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> standing in the way, and his sword drawn in his hand: and the ass turned aside out of the way, and went into the field: and Balaam smote the ass, to turn her into the way.

<b>24 </b>But the angel of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> stood in a path of the vineyards, a wall <i>being</i> on this side, and a wall on that side.

<b>25 </b>And when the ass saw the angel of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, she thrust herself unto the wall, and crushed Balaam’s foot against the wall: and he smote her again.
