<b>25 </b>And they took of the fruit of the land in their hands, and brought <i>it</i> down unto us, and brought us word again, and said, <i>It is</i> a good land which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God doth give us.

<b>26 </b>Notwithstanding ye would not go up, but rebelled against the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God:

<b>27 </b>And ye murmured in your tents, and said, Because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hated us, he hath brought us forth out of the land of Egypt, to deliver us into the hand of the Amorites, to destroy us.

<b>28 </b>Whither shall we go up? our brethren have discouraged our heart, saying, The people <i>is</i> greater and taller than we; the cities <i>are</i> great and walled up to heaven; and moreover we have seen the sons of the Anakims there.

<b>29 </b>Then I said unto you, Dread not, neither be afraid of them.

<b>30 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God which goeth before you, he shall fight for you, according to all that he did for you in Egypt before your eyes;

<b>31 </b>And in the wilderness, where thou hast seen how that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God bare thee, as a man doth bear his son, in all the way that ye went, until ye came into this place.

<b>32 </b>Yet in this thing ye did not believe the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God,

<b>33 </b>Who went in the way before you, to search you out a place to pitch your tents <i>in,</i> in fire by night, to shew you by what way ye should go, and in a cloud by day.

<b>34 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> heard the voice of your words, and was wroth, and sware, saying,

<b>35 </b>Surely there shall not one of these men of this evil generation see that good land, which I sware to give unto your fathers,

<b>36 </b>Save Caleb the son of Jephunneh; he shall see it, and to him will I give the land that he hath trodden upon, and to his children, because he hath wholly followed the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>37 </b>Also the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was angry with me for your sakes, saying, Thou also shalt not go in thither.

<b>38 </b><i>But</i> Joshua the son of Nun, which standeth before thee, he shall go in thither: encourage him: for he shall cause Israel to inherit it.

<b>39 </b>Moreover your little ones, which ye said should be a prey, and your children, which in that day had no knowledge between good and evil, they shall go in thither, and unto them will I give it, and they shall possess it.

<b>40 </b>But <i>as for</i> you, turn you, and take your journey into the wilderness by the way of the Red sea.

<b>41 </b>Then ye answered and said unto me, We have sinned against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, we will go up and fight, according to all that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God commanded us. And when ye had girded on every man his weapons of war, ye were ready to go up into the hill.

<b>42 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, Say unto them, Go not up, neither fight; for I <i>am</i> not among you; lest ye be smitten before your enemies.

<b>43 </b>So I spake unto you; and ye would not hear, but rebelled against the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and went presumptuously up into the hill.

<b>44 </b>And the Amorites, which dwelt in that mountain, came out against you, and chased you, as bees do, and destroyed you in Seir, <i>even</i> unto Hormah.

<b>45 </b>And ye returned and wept before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; but the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> would not hearken to your voice, nor give ear unto you.

<b>46 </b>So ye abode in Kadesh many days, according unto the days that ye abode <i>there.</i>


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>Then we turned, and took our journey into the wilderness by the way of the Red sea, as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto me: and we compassed mount Seir many days.

<b>2 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto me, saying,

<b>3 </b>Ye have compassed this mountain long enough: turn you northward.

<b>4 </b>And command thou the people, saying, Ye <i>are</i> to pass through the coast of your brethren the children of Esau, which dwell in Seir; and they shall be afraid of you: take ye good heed unto yourselves therefore:

<b>5 </b>Meddle not with them; for I will not give you of their land, no, not so much as a foot breadth; because I have given mount Seir unto Esau <i>for</i> a possession.

<b>6 </b>Ye shall buy meat of them for money, that ye may eat; and ye shall also buy water of them for money, that ye may drink.

<b>7 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God hath blessed thee in all the works of thy hand: he knoweth thy walking through this great wilderness: these forty years the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God <i>hath been</i> with thee; thou hast lacked nothing.

<b>8 </b>And when we passed by from our brethren the children of Esau, which dwelt in Seir, through the way of the plain from Elath, and from Ezion-gaber, we turned and passed by the way of the wilderness of Moab.

<b>9 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, Distress not the Moabites, neither contend with them in battle: for I will not give thee of their land <i>for</i> a possession; because I have given Ar unto the children of Lot <i>for</i> a possession.

<b>10 </b>The Emims dwelt therein in times past, a people great, and many, and tall, as the Anakims;

<b>11 </b>Which also were accounted giants, as the Anakims; but the Moabites call them Emims.

<b>12 </b>The Horims also dwelt in Seir beforetime; but the children of Esau succeeded them, when they had destroyed them from before them, and dwelt in their stead; as Israel did unto the land of his possession, which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> gave unto them.

<b>13 </b>Now rise up, <i>said I,</i> and get you over the brook Zered. And we went over the brook Zered.

<b>14 </b>And the space in which we came from Kadesh-barnea, until we were come over the brook Zered, <i>was</i> thirty and eight years; until all the generation of the men of war were wasted out from among the host, as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sware unto them.

<b>15 </b>For indeed the hand of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was against them, to destroy them from among the host, until they were consumed.

<b>16 </b>¶ So it came to pass, when all the men of war were consumed and dead from among the people,

<b>17 </b>That the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto me, saying,

<b>18 </b>Thou art to pass over through Ar, the coast of Moab, this day:

<b>19 </b>And <i>when</i> thou comest nigh over against the children of Ammon, distress them not, nor meddle with them: for I will not give thee of the land of the children of Ammon <i>any</i> possession; because I have given it unto the children of Lot <i>for</i> a possession.

<b>20 </b>(That also was accounted a land of giants: giants dwelt therein in old time; and the Ammonites call them Zamzummims;

<b>21 </b>A people great, and many, and tall, as the Anakims; but the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> destroyed them before them; and they succeeded them, and dwelt in their stead:

<b>22 </b>As he did to the children of Esau, which dwelt in Seir, when he destroyed the Horims from before them; and they succeeded them, and dwelt in their stead even unto this day:

<b>23 </b>And the Avims which dwelt in Hazerim, <i>even</i> unto Azzah, the Caphtorims, which came forth out of Caphtor, destroyed them, and dwelt in their stead.)

<b>24 </b>¶ Rise ye up, take your journey, and pass over the river Arnon: behold, I have given into thine hand Sihon the Amorite, king of Heshbon, and his land: begin to possess <i>it,</i> and contend with him in battle.

<b>25 </b>This day will I begin to put the dread of thee and the fear of thee upon the nations <i>that are</i> under the whole heaven, who shall hear report of thee, and shall tremble, and be in anguish because of thee.

<b>26 </b>¶ And I sent messengers out of the wilderness of Kedemoth unto Sihon king of Heshbon with words of peace, saying,

<b>27 </b>Let me pass through thy land: I will go along by the high way, I will neither turn unto the right hand nor to the left.

<b>28 </b>Thou shalt sell me meat for money, that I may eat; and give me water for money, that I may drink: only I will pass through on my feet;

<b>29 </b>(As the children of Esau which dwell in Seir, and the Moabites which dwell in Ar, did unto me;) until I shall pass over Jordan into the land which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God giveth us.

<b>30 </b>But Sihon king of Heshbon would not let us pass by him: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God hardened his spirit, and made his heart obstinate, that he might deliver him into thy hand, as <i>appeareth</i> this day.

<b>31 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, Behold, I have begun to give Sihon and his land before thee: begin to possess, that thou mayest inherit his land.

<b>32 </b>Then Sihon came out against us, he and all his people, to fight at Jahaz.

<b>33 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God delivered him before us; and we smote him, and his sons, and all his people.

<b>34 </b>And we took all his cities at that time, and utterly destroyed the men, and the women, and the little ones, of every city, we left none to remain:

<b>35 </b>Only the cattle we took for a prey unto ourselves, and the spoil of the cities which we took.

<b>36 </b>From Aroer, which <i>is</i> by the brink of the river of Arnon, and <i>from</i> the city that <i>is</i> by the river, even unto Gilead, there was not one city too strong for us: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God delivered all unto us:

<b>37 </b>Only unto the land of the children of Ammon thou camest not, <i>nor</i> unto any place of the river Jabbok, nor unto the cities in the mountains, nor unto whatsoever the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God forbad us.


--------------------

CHAPTER 3

<b>1 </b>Then we turned, and went up the way to Bashan: and Og the king of Bashan came out against us, he and all his people, to battle at Edrei.

<b>2 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, Fear him not: for I will deliver him, and all his people, and his land, into thy hand; and thou shalt do unto him as thou didst unto Sihon king of the Amorites, which dwelt at Heshbon.

<b>3 </b>So the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God delivered into our hands Og also, the king of Bashan, and all his people: and we smote him until none was left to him remaining.

<b>4 </b>And we took all his cities at that time, there was not a city which we took not from them, threescore cities, all the region of Argob, the kingdom of Og in Bashan.

<b>5 </b>All these cities <i>were</i> fenced with high walls, gates, and bars; beside unwalled towns a great many.

<b>6 </b>And we utterly destroyed them, as we did unto Sihon king of Heshbon, utterly destroying the men, women, and children, of every city.

<b>7 </b>But all the cattle, and the spoil of the cities, we took for a prey to ourselves.

<b>8 </b>And we took at that time out of the hand of the two kings of the Amorites the land that <i>was</i> on this side Jordan, from the river of Arnon unto mount Hermon;

<b>9 </b>(<i>Which</i> Hermon the Sidonians call Sirion; and the Amorites call it Shenir;)

<b>10 </b>All the cities of the plain, and all Gilead, and all Bashan, unto Salchah and Edrei, cities of the kingdom of Og in Bashan.

<b>11 </b>For only Og king of Bashan remained of the remnant of giants; behold, his bedstead <i>was</i> a bedstead of iron; <i>is</i> it not in Rabbath of the children of Ammon? nine cubits <i>was</i> the length thereof, and four cubits the breadth of it, after the cubit of a man.

<b>12 </b>And this land, <i>which</i> we possessed at that time, from Aroer, which <i>is</i> by the river Arnon, and half mount Gilead, and the cities thereof, gave I unto the Reubenites and to the Gadites.

<b>13 </b>And the rest of Gilead, and all Bashan, <i>being</i> the kingdom of Og, gave I unto the half tribe of Manasseh; all the region of Argob, with all Bashan, which was called the land of giants.

<b>14 </b>Jair the son of Manasseh took all the country of Argob unto the coasts of Geshuri and Maachathi; and called them after his own name, Bashan-havoth-jair, unto this day.

<b>15 </b>And I gave Gilead unto Machir.

<b>16 </b>And unto the Reubenites and unto the Gadites I gave from Gilead even unto the river Arnon half the valley, and the border even unto the river Jabbok, <i>which is</i> the border of the children of Ammon;

<b>17 </b>The plain also, and Jordan, and the coast <i>thereof,</i> from Chinnereth even unto the sea of the plain, <i>even</i> the salt sea, under Ashdoth-pisgah eastward.

<b>18 </b>¶ And I commanded you at that time, saying, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God hath given you this land to possess it: ye shall pass over armed before your brethren the children of Israel, all <i>that are</i> meet for the war.

<b>19 </b>But your wives, and your little ones, and your cattle, (<i>for</i> I know that ye have much cattle,) shall abide in your cities which I have given you;

<b>20 </b>Until the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> have given rest unto your brethren, as well as unto you, and <i>until</i> they also possess the land which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God hath given them beyond Jordan: and <i>then</i> shall ye return every man unto his possession, which I have given you.

<b>21 </b>¶ And I commanded Joshua at that time, saying, Thine eyes have seen all that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God hath done unto these two kings: so shall the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> do unto all the kingdoms whither thou passest.

<b>22 </b>Ye shall not fear them: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God he shall fight for you.

<b>23 </b>And I besought the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> at that time, saying,

<b>24 </b>O Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>, thou hast begun to shew thy servant thy greatness, and thy mighty hand: for what God <i>is there</i> in heaven or in earth, that can do according to thy works, and according to thy might?

<b>25 </b>I pray thee, let me go over, and see the good land that <i>is</i> beyond Jordan, that goodly mountain, and Lebanon.

<b>26 </b>But the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was wroth with me for your sakes, and would not hear me: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, Let it suffice thee; speak no more unto me of this matter.

<b>27 </b>Get thee up into the top of Pisgah, and lift up thine eyes westward, and northward, and southward, and eastward, and behold <i>it</i> with thine eyes: for thou shalt not go over this Jordan.

<b>28 </b>But charge Joshua, and encourage him, and strengthen him: for he shall go over before this people, and he shall cause them to inherit the land which thou shalt see.

<b>29 </b>So we abode in the valley over against Beth-peor.


--------------------

CHAPTER 4

<b>1 </b>Now therefore hearken, O Israel, unto the statutes and unto the judgments, which I teach you, for to do <i>them,</i> that ye may live, and go in and possess the land which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of your fathers giveth you.

<b>2 </b>Ye shall not add unto the word which I command you, neither shall ye diminish <i>ought</i> from it, that ye may keep the commandments of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God which I command you.

<b>3 </b>Your eyes have seen what the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> did because of Baal-peor: for all the men that followed Baal-peor, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God hath destroyed them from among you.

<b>4 </b>But ye that did cleave unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God <i>are</i> alive every one of you this day.

<b>5 </b>Behold, I have taught you statutes and judgments, even as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God commanded me, that ye should do so in the land whither ye go to possess it.

<b>6 </b>Keep therefore and do <i>them;</i> for this <i>is</i> your wisdom and your understanding in the sight of the nations, which shall hear all these statutes, and say, Surely this great nation <i>is</i> a wise and understanding people.

<b>7 </b>For what nation <i>is there so</i> great, who <i>hath</i> God <i>so</i> nigh unto them, as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God <i>is</i> in all <i>things that</i> we call upon him <i>for?</i>

<b>8 </b>And what nation <i>is there so</i> great, that hath statutes and judgments <i>so</i> righteous as all this law, which I set before you this day?

<b>9 </b>Only take heed to thyself, and keep thy soul diligently, lest thou forget the things which thine eyes have seen, and lest they depart from thy heart all the days of thy life: but teach them thy sons, and thy sons’ sons;

<b>10 </b><i>Specially</i> the day that thou stoodest before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God in Horeb, when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, Gather me the people together, and I will make them hear my words, that they may learn to fear me all the days that they shall live upon the earth, and <i>that</i> they may teach their children.

<b>11 </b>And ye came near and stood under the mountain; and the mountain burned with fire unto the midst of heaven, with darkness, clouds, and thick darkness.

<b>12 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto you out of the midst of the fire: ye heard the voice of the words, but saw no similitude; only <i>ye heard</i> a voice.

<b>13 </b>And he declared unto you his covenant, which he commanded you to perform, <i>even</i> ten commandments; and he wrote them upon two tables of stone.

<b>14 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded me at that time to teach you statutes and judgments, that ye might do them in the land whither ye go over to possess it.

<b>15 </b>Take ye therefore good heed unto yourselves; for ye saw no manner of similitude on the day <i>that</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto you in Horeb out of the midst of the fire:

<b>16 </b>Lest ye corrupt <i>yourselves,</i> and make you a graven image, the similitude of any figure, the likeness of male or female,

<b>17 </b>The likeness of any beast that <i>is</i> on the earth, the likeness of any winged fowl that flieth in the air,

<b>18 </b>The likeness of any thing that creepeth on the ground, the likeness of any fish that <i>is</i> in the waters beneath the earth:

<b>19 </b>And lest thou lift up thine eyes unto heaven, and when thou seest the sun, and the moon, and the stars, <i>even</i> all the host of heaven, shouldest be driven to worship them, and serve them, which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God hath divided unto all nations under the whole heaven.

<b>20 </b>But the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath taken you, and brought you forth out of the iron furnace, <i>even</i> out of Egypt, to be unto him a people of inheritance, as <i>ye are</i> this day.

<b>21 </b>Furthermore the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was angry with me for your sakes, and sware that I should not go over Jordan, and that I should not go in unto that good land, which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God giveth thee <i>for</i> an inheritance:

<b>22 </b>But I must die in this land, I must not go over Jordan: but ye shall go over, and possess that good land.

<b>23 </b>Take heed unto yourselves, lest ye forget the covenant of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, which he made with you, and make you a graven image, <i>or</i> the likeness of any <i>thing,</i> which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God hath forbidden thee.

<b>24 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God <i>is</i> a consuming fire, <i>even</i> a jealous God.

<b>25 </b>¶ When thou shalt beget children, and children’s children, and ye shall have remained long in the land, and shall corrupt <i>yourselves,</i> and make a graven image, <i>or</i> the likeness of any <i>thing,</i> and shall do evil in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, to provoke him to anger:

<b>26 </b>I call heaven and earth to witness against you this day, that ye shall soon utterly perish from off the land whereunto ye go over Jordan to possess it; ye shall not prolong <i>your</i> days upon it, but shall utterly be destroyed.

<b>27 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall scatter you among the nations, and ye shall be left few in number among the heathen, whither the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall lead you.

<b>28 </b>And there ye shall serve gods, the work of men’s hands, wood and stone, which neither see, nor hear, nor eat, nor smell.

<b>29 </b>But if from thence thou shalt seek the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, thou shalt find <i>him,</i> if thou seek him with all thy heart and with all thy soul.

<b>30 </b>When thou art in tribulation, and all these things are come upon thee, <i>even</i> in the latter days, if thou turn to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, and shalt be obedient unto his voice;

<b>31 </b>(For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God <i>is</i> a merciful God;) he will not forsake thee, neither destroy thee, nor forget the covenant of thy fathers which he sware unto them.

<b>32 </b>For ask now of the days that are past, which were before thee, since the day that God created man upon the earth, and <i>ask</i> from the one side of heaven unto the other, whether there hath been <i>any such thing</i> as this great thing <i>is,</i> or hath been heard like it?

<b>33 </b>Did <i>ever</i> people hear the voice of God speaking out of the midst of the fire, as thou hast heard, and live?

<b>34 </b>Or hath God assayed to go <i>and</i> take him a nation from the midst of <i>another</i> nation, by temptations, by signs, and by wonders, and by war, and by a mighty hand, and by a stretched out arm, and by great terrors, according to all that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God did for you in Egypt before your eyes?

<b>35 </b>Unto thee it was shewed, that thou mightest know that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> he <i>is</i> God; <i>there is</i> none else beside him.

<b>36 </b>Out of heaven he made thee to hear his voice, that he might instruct thee: and upon earth he shewed thee his great fire; and thou heardest his words out of the midst of the fire.

<b>37 </b>And because he loved thy fathers, therefore he chose their seed after them, and brought thee out in his sight with his mighty power out of Egypt;

<b>38 </b>To drive out nations from before thee greater and mightier than thou <i>art,</i> to bring thee in, to give thee their land <i>for</i> an inheritance, as <i>it is</i> this day.

<b>39 </b>Know therefore this day, and consider <i>it</i> in thine heart, that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> he <i>is</i> God in heaven above, and upon the earth beneath: <i>there is</i> none else.

<b>40 </b>Thou shalt keep therefore his statutes, and his commandments, which I command thee this day, that it may go well with thee, and with thy children after thee, and that thou mayest prolong <i>thy</i> days upon the earth, which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God giveth thee, for ever.

<b>41 </b>¶ Then Moses severed three cities on this side Jordan toward the sunrising;

<b>42 </b>That the slayer might flee thither, which should kill his neighbour unawares, and hated him not in times past; and that fleeing unto one of these cities he might live:

<b>43 </b><i>Namely,</i> Bezer in the wilderness, in the plain country, of the Reubenites; and Ramoth in Gilead, of the Gadites; and Golan in Bashan, of the Manassites.

<b>44 </b>¶ And this <i>is</i> the law which Moses set before the children of Israel:

<b>45 </b>These <i>are</i> the testimonies, and the statutes, and the judgments, which Moses spake unto the children of Israel, after they came forth out of Egypt,

<b>46 </b>On this side Jordan, in the valley over against Beth-peor, in the land of Sihon king of the Amorites, who dwelt at Heshbon, whom Moses and the children of Israel smote, after they were come forth out of Egypt:

<b>47 </b>And they possessed his land, and the land of Og king of Bashan, two kings of the Amorites, which <i>were</i> on this side Jordan toward the sunrising;

<b>48 </b>From Aroer, which <i>is</i> by the bank of the river Arnon, even unto mount Sion, which <i>is</i> Hermon,

<b>49 </b>And all the plain on this side Jordan eastward, even unto the sea of the plain, under the springs of Pisgah.


--------------------

CHAPTER 5

<b>1 </b>And Moses called all Israel, and said unto them, Hear, O Israel, the statutes and judgments which I speak in your ears this day, that ye may learn them, and keep, and do them.

<b>2 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God made a covenant with us in Horeb.

<b>3 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> made not this covenant with our fathers, but with us, <i>even</i> us, who <i>are</i> all of us here alive this day.

<b>4 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> talked with you face to face in the mount out of the midst of the fire,

<b>5 </b>(I stood between the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> and you at that time, to shew you the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for ye were afraid by reason of the fire, and went not up into the mount;) saying,

<b>6 </b>¶ I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, which brought thee out of the land of Egypt, from the house of bondage.

<b>7 </b>Thou shalt have none other gods before me.

<b>8 </b>Thou shalt not make thee <i>any</i> graven image, <i>or</i> any likeness <i>of any thing</i> that <i>is</i> in heaven above, or that <i>is</i> in the earth beneath, or that <i>is</i> in the waters beneath the earth:

<b>9 </b>Thou shalt not bow down thyself unto them, nor serve them: for I the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God <i>am</i> a jealous God, visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children unto the third and fourth <i>generation</i> of them that hate me,

<b>10 </b>And shewing mercy unto thousands of them that love me and keep my commandments.

<b>11 </b>Thou shalt not take the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God in vain: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will not hold <i>him</i> guiltless that taketh his name in vain.

<b>12 </b>Keep the sabbath day to sanctify it, as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God hath commanded thee.

<b>13 </b>Six days thou shalt labour, and do all thy work:

<b>14 </b>But the seventh day <i>is</i> the sabbath of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God: <i>in it</i> thou shalt not do any work, thou, nor thy son, nor thy daughter, nor thy manservant, nor thy maidservant, nor thine ox, nor thine ass, nor any of thy cattle, nor thy stranger that <i>is</i> within thy gates; that thy manservant and thy maidservant may rest as well as thou.

<b>15 </b>And remember that thou wast a servant in the land of Egypt, and <i>that</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God brought thee out thence through a mighty hand and by a stretched out arm: therefore the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God commanded thee to keep the sabbath day.

<b>16 </b>¶ Honour thy father and thy mother, as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God hath commanded thee; that thy days may be prolonged, and that it may go well with thee, in the land which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God giveth thee.

<b>17 </b>Thou shalt not kill.

<b>18 </b>Neither shalt thou commit adultery.

<b>19 </b>Neither shalt thou steal.

<b>20 </b>Neither shalt thou bear false witness against thy neighbour.

<b>21 </b>Neither shalt thou desire thy neighbour’s wife, neither shalt thou covet thy neighbour’s house, his field, or his manservant, or his maidservant, his ox, or his ass, or any <i>thing</i> that <i>is</i> thy neighbour’s.

<b>22 </b>¶ These words the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto all your assembly in the mount out of the midst of the fire, of the cloud, and of the thick darkness, with a great voice: and he added no more. And he wrote them in two tables of stone, and delivered them unto me.

<b>23 </b>And it came to pass, when ye heard the voice out of the midst of the darkness, (for the mountain did burn with fire,) that ye came near unto me, <i>even</i> all the heads of your tribes, and your elders;

<b>24 </b>And ye said, Behold, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God hath shewed us his glory and his greatness, and we have heard his voice out of the midst of the fire: we have seen this day that God doth talk with man, and he liveth.

<b>25 </b>Now therefore why should we die? for this great fire will consume us: if we hear the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God any more, then we shall die.

<b>26 </b>For who <i>is there of</i> all flesh, that hath heard the voice of the living God speaking out of the midst of the fire, as we <i>have,</i> and lived?

<b>27 </b>Go thou near, and hear all that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God shall say: and speak thou unto us all that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God shall speak unto thee; and we will hear <i>it,</i> and do <i>it.</i>

<b>28 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> heard the voice of your words, when ye spake unto me; and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, I have heard the voice of the words of this people, which they have spoken unto thee: they have well said all that they have spoken.

<b>29 </b>O that there were such an heart in them, that they would fear me, and keep all my commandments always, that it might be well with them, and with their children for ever!

<b>30 </b>Go say to them, Get you into your tents again.

<b>31 </b>But as for thee, stand thou here by me, and I will speak unto thee all the commandments, and the statutes, and the judgments, which thou shalt teach them, that they may do <i>them</i> in the land which I give them to possess it.

<b>32 </b>Ye shall observe to do therefore as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God hath commanded you: ye shall not turn aside to the right hand or to the left.

<b>33 </b>Ye shall walk in all the ways which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God hath commanded you, that ye may live, and <i>that it may be</i> well with you, and <i>that</i> ye may prolong <i>your</i> days in the land which ye shall possess.


--------------------

CHAPTER 6

<b>1 </b>Now these <i>are</i> the commandments, the statutes, and the judgments, which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God commanded to teach you, that ye might do <i>them</i> in the land whither ye go to possess it:

<b>2 </b>That thou mightest fear the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, to keep all his statutes and his commandments, which I command thee, thou, and thy son, and thy son’s son, all the days of thy life; and that thy days may be prolonged.

<b>3 </b>¶ Hear therefore, O Israel, and observe to do <i>it;</i> that it may be well with thee, and that ye may increase mightily, as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of thy fathers hath promised thee, in the land that floweth with milk and honey.

<b>4 </b>Hear, O Israel: The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God <i>is</i> one <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>:

<b>5 </b>And thou shalt love the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God with all thine heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy might.

<b>6 </b>And these words, which I command thee this day, shall be in thine heart:

<b>7 </b>And thou shalt teach them diligently unto thy children, and shalt talk of them when thou sittest in thine house, and when thou walkest by the way, and when thou liest down, and when thou risest up.

<b>8 </b>And thou shalt bind them for a sign upon thine hand, and they shall be as frontlets between thine eyes.

<b>9 </b>And thou shalt write them upon the posts of thy house, and on thy gates.

<b>10 </b>And it shall be, when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God shall have brought thee into the land which he sware unto thy fathers, to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob, to give thee great and goodly cities, which thou buildedst not,

<b>11 </b>And houses full of all good <i>things,</i> which thou filledst not, and wells digged, which thou diggedst not, vineyards and olive trees, which thou plantedst not; when thou shalt have eaten and be full;

<b>12 </b><i>Then</i> beware lest thou forget the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which brought thee forth out of the land of Egypt, from the house of bondage.

<b>13 </b>Thou shalt fear the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, and serve him, and shalt swear by his name.

<b>14 </b>Ye shall not go after other gods, of the gods of the people which <i>are</i> round about you;

<b>15 </b>(For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God <i>is</i> a jealous God among you) lest the anger of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God be kindled against thee, and destroy thee from off the face of the earth.

<b>16 </b>¶ Ye shall not tempt the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, as ye tempted <i>him</i> in Massah.

<b>17 </b>Ye shall diligently keep the commandments of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, and his testimonies, and his statutes, which he hath commanded thee.

<b>18 </b>And thou shalt do <i>that which is</i> right and good in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: that it may be well with thee, and that thou mayest go in and possess the good land which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sware unto thy fathers,

<b>19 </b>To cast out all thine enemies from before thee, as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath spoken.

<b>20 </b><i>And</i> when thy son asketh thee in time to come, saying, What <i>mean</i> the testimonies, and the statutes, and the judgments, which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God hath commanded you?

<b>21 </b>Then thou shalt say unto thy son, We were Pharaoh’s bondmen in Egypt; and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> brought us out of Egypt with a mighty hand:

<b>22 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shewed signs and wonders, great and sore, upon Egypt, upon Pharaoh, and upon all his household, before our eyes:

<b>23 </b>And he brought us out from thence, that he might bring us in, to give us the land which he sware unto our fathers.

<b>24 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded us to do all these statutes, to fear the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God, for our good always, that he might preserve us alive, as <i>it is</i> at this day.

<b>25 </b>And it shall be our righteousness, if we observe to do all these commandments before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God, as he hath commanded us.


--------------------

CHAPTER 7

<b>1 </b>When the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God shall bring thee into the land whither thou goest to possess it, and hath cast out many nations before thee, the Hittites, and the Girgashites, and the Amorites, and the Canaanites, and the Perizzites, and the Hivites, and the Jebusites, seven nations greater and mightier than thou;

<b>2 </b>And when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God shall deliver them before thee; thou shalt smite them, <i>and</i> utterly destroy them; thou shalt make no covenant with them, nor shew mercy unto them:

<b>3 </b>Neither shalt thou make marriages with them; thy daughter thou shalt not give unto his son, nor his daughter shalt thou take unto thy son.

<b>4 </b>For they will turn away thy son from following me, that they may serve other gods: so will the anger of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> be kindled against you, and destroy thee suddenly.

<b>5 </b>But thus shall ye deal with them; ye shall destroy their altars, and break down their images, and cut down their groves, and burn their graven images with fire.

<b>6 </b>For thou <i>art</i> an holy people unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God hath chosen thee to be a special people unto himself, above all people that <i>are</i> upon the face of the earth.

<b>7 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> did not set his love upon you, nor choose you, because ye were more in number than any people; for ye <i>were</i> the fewest of all people:

<b>8 </b>But because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> loved you, and because he would keep the oath which he had sworn unto your fathers, hath the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> brought you out with a mighty hand, and redeemed you out of the house of bondmen, from the hand of Pharaoh king of Egypt.

<b>9 </b>Know therefore that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, he <i>is</i> God, the faithful God, which keepeth covenant and mercy with them that love him and keep his commandments to a thousand generations;

<b>10 </b>And repayeth them that hate him to their face, to destroy them: he will not be slack to him that hateth him, he will repay him to his face.

<b>11 </b>Thou shalt therefore keep the commandments, and the statutes, and the judgments, which I command thee this day, to do them.

<b>12 </b>¶ Wherefore it shall come to pass, if ye hearken to these judgments, and keep, and do them, that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God shall keep unto thee the covenant and the mercy which he sware unto thy fathers:

<b>13 </b>And he will love thee, and bless thee, and multiply thee: he will also bless the fruit of thy womb, and the fruit of thy land, thy corn, and thy wine, and thine oil, the increase of thy kine, and the flocks of thy sheep, in the land which he sware unto thy fathers to give thee.

<b>14 </b>Thou shalt be blessed above all people: there shall not be male or female barren among you, or among your cattle.

<b>15 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will take away from thee all sickness, and will put none of the evil diseases of Egypt, which thou knowest, upon thee; but will lay them upon all <i>them</i> that hate thee.

<b>16 </b>And thou shalt consume all the people which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God shall deliver thee; thine eye shall have no pity upon them: neither shalt thou serve their gods; for that <i>will be</i> a snare unto thee.

<b>17 </b>If thou shalt say in thine heart, These nations <i>are</i> more than I; how can I dispossess them?

<b>18 </b>Thou shalt not be afraid of them: <i>but</i> shalt well remember what the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God did unto Pharaoh, and unto all Egypt;

<b>19 </b>The great temptations which thine eyes saw, and the signs, and the wonders, and the mighty hand, and the stretched out arm, whereby the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God brought thee out: so shall the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God do unto all the people of whom thou art afraid.

<b>20 </b>Moreover the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God will send the hornet among them, until they that are left, and hide themselves from thee, be destroyed.

<b>21 </b>Thou shalt not be affrighted at them: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God <i>is</i> among you, a mighty God and terrible.

<b>22 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God will put out those nations before thee by little and little: thou mayest not consume them at once, lest the beasts of the field increase upon thee.

<b>23 </b>But the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God shall deliver them unto thee, and shall destroy them with a mighty destruction, until they be destroyed.

<b>24 </b>And he shall deliver their kings into thine hand, and thou shalt destroy their name from under heaven: there shall no man be able to stand before thee, until thou have destroyed them.

<b>25 </b>The graven images of their gods shall ye burn with fire: thou shalt not desire the silver or gold <i>that is</i> on them, nor take <i>it</i> unto thee, lest thou be snared therein: for it <i>is</i> an abomination to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God.

<b>26 </b>Neither shalt thou bring an abomination into thine house, lest thou be a cursed thing like it: <i>but</i> thou shalt utterly detest it, and thou shalt utterly abhor it; for it <i>is</i> a cursed thing.


--------------------

CHAPTER 8

<b>1 </b>All the commandments which I command thee this day shall ye observe to do, that ye may live, and multiply, and go in and possess the land which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sware unto your fathers.

<b>2 </b>And thou shalt remember all the way which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God led thee these forty years in the wilderness, to humble thee, <i>and</i> to prove thee, to know what <i>was</i> in thine heart, whether thou wouldest keep his commandments, or no.

<b>3 </b>And he humbled thee, and suffered thee to hunger, and fed thee with manna, which thou knewest not, neither did thy fathers know; that he might make thee know that man doth not live by bread only, but by every <i>word</i> that proceedeth out of the mouth of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> doth man live.

<b>4 </b>Thy raiment waxed not old upon thee, neither did thy foot swell, these forty years.

<b>5 </b>Thou shalt also consider in thine heart, that, as a man chasteneth his son, <i>so</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God chasteneth thee.

<b>6 </b>Therefore thou shalt keep the commandments of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, to walk in his ways, and to fear him.

<b>7 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God bringeth thee into a good land, a land of brooks of water, of fountains and depths that spring out of valleys and hills;

<b>8 </b>A land of wheat, and barley, and vines, and fig trees, and pomegranates; a land of oil olive, and honey;

<b>9 </b>A land wherein thou shalt eat bread without scarceness, thou shalt not lack any <i>thing</i> in it; a land whose stones <i>are</i> iron, and out of whose hills thou mayest dig brass.

<b>10 </b>When thou hast eaten and art full, then thou shalt bless the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God for the good land which he hath given thee.

<b>11 </b>Beware that thou forget not the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, in not keeping his commandments, and his judgments, and his statutes, which I command thee this day:

<b>12 </b>Lest <i>when</i> thou hast eaten and art full, and hast built goodly houses, and dwelt <i>therein;</i>

<b>13 </b>And <i>when</i> thy herds and thy flocks multiply, and thy silver and thy gold is multiplied, and all that thou hast is multiplied;

<b>14 </b>Then thine heart be lifted up, and thou forget the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, which brought thee forth out of the land of Egypt, from the house of bondage;

<b>15 </b>Who led thee through that great and terrible wilderness, <i>wherein were</i> fiery serpents, and scorpions, and drought, where <i>there was</i> no water; who brought thee forth water out of the rock of flint;

<b>16 </b>Who fed thee in the wilderness with manna, which thy fathers knew not, that he might humble thee, and that he might prove thee, to do thee good at thy latter end;

<b>17 </b>And thou say in thine heart, My power and the might of <i>mine</i> hand hath gotten me this wealth.

<b>18 </b>But thou shalt remember the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God: for <i>it is</i> he that giveth thee power to get wealth, that he may establish his covenant which he sware unto thy fathers, as <i>it is</i> this day.

<b>19 </b>And it shall be, if thou do at all forget the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, and walk after other gods, and serve them, and worship them, I testify against you this day that ye shall surely perish.

<b>20 </b>As the nations which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> destroyeth before your face, so shall ye perish; because ye would not be obedient unto the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God.


--------------------

CHAPTER 9

<b>1 </b>Hear, O Israel: Thou <i>art</i> to pass over Jordan this day, to go in to possess nations greater and mightier than thyself, cities great and fenced up to heaven,

<b>2 </b>A people great and tall, the children of the Anakims, whom thou knowest, and <i>of whom</i> thou hast heard <i>say,</i> Who can stand before the children of Anak!

<b>3 </b>Understand therefore this day, that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God <i>is</i> he which goeth over before thee; <i>as</i> a consuming fire he shall destroy them, and he shall bring them down before thy face: so shalt thou drive them out, and destroy them quickly, as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath said unto thee.

<b>4 </b>Speak not thou in thine heart, after that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God hath cast them out from before thee, saying, For my righteousness the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath brought me in to possess this land: but for the wickedness of these nations the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> doth drive them out from before thee.

<b>5 </b>Not for thy righteousness, or for the uprightness of thine heart, dost thou go to possess their land: but for the wickedness of these nations the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God doth drive them out from before thee, and that he may perform the word which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sware unto thy fathers, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.

<b>6 </b>Understand therefore, that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God giveth thee not this good land to possess it for thy righteousness; for thou <i>art</i> a stiffnecked people.

<b>7 </b>¶ Remember, <i>and</i> forget not, how thou provokedst the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God to wrath in the wilderness: from the day that thou didst depart out of the land of Egypt, until ye came unto this place, ye have been rebellious against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>8 </b>Also in Horeb ye provoked the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> to wrath, so that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was angry with you to have destroyed you.

<b>9 </b>When I was gone up into the mount to receive the tables of stone, <i>even</i> the tables of the covenant which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> made with you, then I abode in the mount forty days and forty nights, I neither did eat bread nor drink water:

<b>10 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> delivered unto me two tables of stone written with the finger of God; and on them <i>was written</i> according to all the words, which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake with you in the mount out of the midst of the fire in the day of the assembly.

<b>11 </b>And it came to pass at the end of forty days and forty nights, <i>that</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> gave me the two tables of stone, <i>even</i> the tables of the covenant.

<b>12 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, Arise, get thee down quickly from hence; for thy people which thou hast brought forth out of Egypt have corrupted <i>themselves;</i> they are quickly turned aside out of the way which I commanded them; they have made them a molten image.

<b>13 </b>Furthermore the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto me, saying, I have seen this people, and, behold, it <i>is</i> a stiffnecked people:

<b>14 </b>Let me alone, that I may destroy them, and blot out their name from under heaven: and I will make of thee a nation mightier and greater than they.

<b>15 </b>So I turned and came down from the mount, and the mount burned with fire: and the two tables of the covenant <i>were</i> in my two hands.

<b>16 </b>And I looked, and, behold, ye had sinned against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, <i>and</i> had made you a molten calf: ye had turned aside quickly out of the way which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had commanded you.

<b>17 </b>And I took the two tables, and cast them out of my two hands, and brake them before your eyes.

<b>18 </b>And I fell down before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, as at the first, forty days and forty nights: I did neither eat bread, nor drink water, because of all your sins which ye sinned, in doing wickedly in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to provoke him to anger.

<b>19 </b>For I was afraid of the anger and hot displeasure, wherewith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was wroth against you to destroy you. But the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hearkened unto me at that time also.

<b>20 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was very angry with Aaron to have destroyed him: and I prayed for Aaron also the same time.

<b>21 </b>And I took your sin, the calf which ye had made, and burnt it with fire, and stamped it, <i>and</i> ground <i>it</i> very small, <i>even</i> until it was as small as dust: and I cast the dust thereof into the brook that descended out of the mount.

<b>22 </b>And at Taberah, and at Massah, and at Kibroth-hattaavah, ye provoked the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> to wrath.

<b>23 </b>Likewise when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sent you from Kadesh-barnea, saying, Go up and possess the land which I have given you; then ye rebelled against the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, and ye believed him not, nor hearkened to his voice.

<b>24 </b>Ye have been rebellious against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> from the day that I knew you.

<b>25 </b>Thus I fell down before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> forty days and forty nights, as I fell down <i>at the first;</i> because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had said he would destroy you.

<b>26 </b>I prayed therefore unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and said, O Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>, destroy not thy people and thine inheritance, which thou hast redeemed through thy greatness, which thou hast brought forth out of Egypt with a mighty hand.

<b>27 </b>Remember thy servants, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob; look not unto the stubbornness of this people, nor to their wickedness, nor to their sin:

<b>28 </b>Lest the land whence thou broughtest us out say, Because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was not able to bring them into the land which he promised them, and because he hated them, he hath brought them out to slay them in the wilderness.

<b>29 </b>Yet they <i>are</i> thy people and thine inheritance, which thou broughtest out by thy mighty power and by thy stretched out arm.


--------------------

CHAPTER 10

<b>1 </b>At that time the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, Hew thee two tables of stone like unto the first, and come up unto me into the mount, and make thee an ark of wood.

<b>2 </b>And I will write on the tables the words that were in the first tables which thou brakest, and thou shalt put them in the ark.

<b>3 </b>And I made an ark <i>of</i> shittim wood, and hewed two tables of stone like unto the first, and went up into the mount, having the two tables in mine hand.

<b>4 </b>And he wrote on the tables, according to the first writing, the ten commandments, which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto you in the mount out of the midst of the fire in the day of the assembly: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> gave them unto me.

<b>5 </b>And I turned myself and came down from the mount, and put the tables in the ark which I had made; and there they be, as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded me.

<b>6 </b>¶ And the children of Israel took their journey from Beeroth of the children of Jaakan to Mosera: there Aaron died, and there he was buried; and Eleazar his son ministered in the priest’s office in his stead.

<b>7 </b>From thence they journeyed unto Gudgodah; and from Gudgodah to Jotbath, a land of rivers of waters.

<b>8 </b>¶ At that time the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> separated the tribe of Levi, to bear the ark of the covenant of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to stand before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> to minister unto him, and to bless in his name, unto this day.

<b>9 </b>Wherefore Levi hath no part nor inheritance with his brethren; the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> his inheritance, according as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God promised him.

<b>10 </b>And I stayed in the mount, according to the first time, forty days and forty nights; and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hearkened unto me at that time also, <i>and</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> would not destroy thee.

<b>11 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, Arise, take <i>thy</i> journey before the people, that they may go in and possess the land, which I sware unto their fathers to give unto them.

<b>12 </b>¶ And now, Israel, what doth the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God require of thee, but to fear the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, to walk in all his ways, and to love him, and to serve the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God with all thy heart and with all thy soul,

<b>13 </b>To keep the commandments of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and his statutes, which I command thee this day for thy good?

<b>14 </b>Behold, the heaven and the heaven of heavens <i>is</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s thy God, the earth <i>also,</i> with all that therein <i>is.</i>

<b>15 </b>Only the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had a delight in thy fathers to love them, and he chose their seed after them, <i>even</i> you above all people, as <i>it is</i> this day.

<b>16 </b>Circumcise therefore the foreskin of your heart, and be no more stiffnecked.

<b>17 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God <i>is</i> God of gods, and Lord of lords, a great God, a mighty, and a terrible, which regardeth not persons, nor taketh reward:

<b>18 </b>He doth execute the judgment of the fatherless and widow, and loveth the stranger, in giving him food and raiment.

<b>19 </b>Love ye therefore the stranger: for ye were strangers in the land of Egypt.

<b>20 </b>Thou shalt fear the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God; him shalt thou serve, and to him shalt thou cleave, and swear by his name.

<b>21 </b>He <i>is</i> thy praise, and he <i>is</i> thy God, that hath done for thee these great and terrible things, which thine eyes have seen.

<b>22 </b>Thy fathers went down into Egypt with threescore and ten persons; and now the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God hath made thee as the stars of heaven for multitude.


--------------------

CHAPTER 11

<b>1 </b>Therefore thou shalt love the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, and keep his charge, and his statutes, and his judgments, and his commandments, alway.

<b>2 </b>And know ye this day: for <i>I speak</i> not with your children which have not known, and which have not seen the chastisement of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, his greatness, his mighty hand, and his stretched out arm,

<b>3 </b>And his miracles, and his acts, which he did in the midst of Egypt unto Pharaoh the king of Egypt, and unto all his land;

<b>4 </b>And what he did unto the army of Egypt, unto their horses, and to their chariots; how he made the water of the Red sea to overflow them as they pursued after you, and <i>how</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath destroyed them unto this day;

<b>5 </b>And what he did unto you in the wilderness, until ye came into this place;

<b>6 </b>And what he did unto Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, the son of Reuben: how the earth opened her mouth, and swallowed them up, and their households, and their tents, and all the substance that <i>was</i> in their possession, in the midst of all Israel:

<b>7 </b>But your eyes have seen all the great acts of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> which he did.

<b>8 </b>Therefore shall ye keep all the commandments which I command you this day, that ye may be strong, and go in and possess the land, whither ye go to possess it;

<b>9 </b>And that ye may prolong <i>your</i> days in the land, which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sware unto your fathers to give unto them and to their seed, a land that floweth with milk and honey.

<b>10 </b>¶ For the land, whither thou goest in to possess it, <i>is</i> not as the land of Egypt, from whence ye came out, where thou sowedst thy seed, and wateredst <i>it</i> with thy foot, as a garden of herbs:

<b>11 </b>But the land, whither ye go to possess it, <i>is</i> a land of hills and valleys, <i>and</i> drinketh water of the rain of heaven:

<b>12 </b>A land which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God careth for: the eyes of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God <i>are</i> always upon it, from the beginning of the year even unto the end of the year.

<b>13 </b>¶ And it shall come to pass, if ye shall hearken diligently unto my commandments which I command you this day, to love the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, and to serve him with all your heart and with all your soul,

<b>14 </b>That I will give <i>you</i> the rain of your land in his due season, the first rain and the latter rain, that thou mayest gather in thy corn, and thy wine, and thine oil.

<b>15 </b>And I will send grass in thy fields for thy cattle, that thou mayest eat and be full.

<b>16 </b>Take heed to yourselves, that your heart be not deceived, and ye turn aside, and serve other gods, and worship them;

<b>17 </b>And <i>then</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s wrath be kindled against you, and he shut up the heaven, that there be no rain, and that the land yield not her fruit; and <i>lest</i> ye perish quickly from off the good land which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> giveth you.

<b>18 </b>¶ Therefore shall ye lay up these my words in your heart and in your soul, and bind them for a sign upon your hand, that they may be as frontlets between your eyes.

<b>19 </b>And ye shall teach them your children, speaking of them when thou sittest in thine house, and when thou walkest by the way, when thou liest down, and when thou risest up.

<b>20 </b>And thou shalt write them upon the door posts of thine house, and upon thy gates:

<b>21 </b>That your days may be multiplied, and the days of your children, in the land which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sware unto your fathers to give them, as the days of heaven upon the earth.

<b>22 </b>¶ For if ye shall diligently keep all these commandments which I command you, to do them, to love the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, to walk in all his ways, and to cleave unto him;

<b>23 </b>Then will the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> drive out all these nations from before you, and ye shall possess greater nations and mightier than yourselves.

<b>24 </b>Every place whereon the soles of your feet shall tread shall be yours: from the wilderness and Lebanon, from the river, the river Euphrates, even unto the uttermost sea shall your coast be.

<b>25 </b>There shall no man be able to stand before you: <i>for</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God shall lay the fear of you and the dread of you upon all the land that ye shall tread upon, as he hath said unto you.

<b>26 </b>¶ Behold, I set before you this day a blessing and a curse;

<b>27 </b>A blessing, if ye obey the commandments of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, which I command you this day:

<b>28 </b>And a curse, if ye will not obey the commandments of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, but turn aside out of the way which I command you this day, to go after other gods, which ye have not known.

<b>29 </b>And it shall come to pass, when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God hath brought thee in unto the land whither thou goest to possess it, that thou shalt put the blessing upon mount Gerizim, and the curse upon mount Ebal.

<b>30 </b><i>Are</i> they not on the other side Jordan, by the way where the sun goeth down, in the land of the Canaanites, which dwell in the champaign over against Gilgal, beside the plains of Moreh?

<b>31 </b>For ye shall pass over Jordan to go in to possess the land which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God giveth you, and ye shall possess it, and dwell therein.

<b>32 </b>And ye shall observe to do all the statutes and judgments which I set before you this day.


--------------------

CHAPTER 12

<b>1 </b>These <i>are</i> the statutes and judgments, which ye shall observe to do in the land, which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of thy fathers giveth thee to possess it, all the days that ye live upon the earth.

<b>2 </b>Ye shall utterly destroy all the places, wherein the nations which ye shall possess served their gods, upon the high mountains, and upon the hills, and under every green tree:

<b>3 </b>And ye shall overthrow their altars, and break their pillars, and burn their groves with fire; and ye shall hew down the graven images of their gods, and destroy the names of them out of that place.

<b>4 </b>Ye shall not do so unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God.

<b>5 </b>But unto the place which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God shall choose out of all your tribes to put his name there, <i>even</i> unto his habitation shall ye seek, and thither thou shalt come:

<b>6 </b>And thither ye shall bring your burnt offerings, and your sacrifices, and your tithes, and heave offerings of your hand, and your vows, and your freewill offerings, and the firstlings of your herds and of your flocks:

<b>7 </b>And there ye shall eat before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, and ye shall rejoice in all that ye put your hand unto, ye and your households, wherein the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God hath blessed thee.

<b>8 </b>Ye shall not do after all <i>the things</i> that we do here this day, every man whatsoever <i>is</i> right in his own eyes.

<b>9 </b>For ye are not as yet come to the rest and to the inheritance, which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God giveth you.

<b>10 </b>But <i>when</i> ye go over Jordan, and dwell in the land which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God giveth you to inherit, and <i>when</i> he giveth you rest from all your enemies round about, so that ye dwell in safety;

<b>11 </b>Then there shall be a place which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God shall choose to cause his name to dwell there; thither shall ye bring all that I command you; your burnt offerings, and your sacrifices, your tithes, and the heave offering of your hand, and all your choice vows which ye vow unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>:

<b>12 </b>And ye shall rejoice before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, ye, and your sons, and your daughters, and your menservants, and your maidservants, and the Levite that <i>is</i> within your gates; forasmuch as he hath no part nor inheritance with you.

<b>13 </b>Take heed to thyself that thou offer not thy burnt offerings in every place that thou seest:

<b>14 </b>But in the place which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall choose in one of thy tribes, there thou shalt offer thy burnt offerings, and there thou shalt do all that I command thee.

<b>15 </b>Notwithstanding thou mayest kill and eat flesh in all thy gates, whatsoever thy soul lusteth after, according to the blessing of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God which he hath given thee: the unclean and the clean may eat thereof, as of the roebuck, and as of the hart.

<b>16 </b>Only ye shall not eat the blood; ye shall pour it upon the earth as water.

<b>17 </b>¶ Thou mayest not eat within thy gates the tithe of thy corn, or of thy wine, or of thy oil, or the firstlings of thy herds or of thy flock, nor any of thy vows which thou vowest, nor thy freewill offerings, or heave offering of thine hand:

<b>18 </b>But thou must eat them before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God in the place which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God shall choose, thou, and thy son, and thy daughter, and thy manservant, and thy maidservant, and the Levite that <i>is</i> within thy gates: and thou shalt rejoice before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God in all that thou puttest thine hands unto.

<b>19 </b>Take heed to thyself that thou forsake not the Levite as long as thou livest upon the earth.

<b>20 </b>¶ When the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God shall enlarge thy border, as he hath promised thee, and thou shalt say, I will eat flesh, because thy soul longeth to eat flesh; thou mayest eat flesh, whatsoever thy soul lusteth after.

<b>21 </b>If the place which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God hath chosen to put his name there be too far from thee, then thou shalt kill of thy herd and of thy flock, which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath given thee, as I have commanded thee, and thou shalt eat in thy gates whatsoever thy soul lusteth after.

<b>22 </b>Even as the roebuck and the hart is eaten, so thou shalt eat them: the unclean and the clean shall eat <i>of</i> them alike.

<b>23 </b>Only be sure that thou eat not the blood: for the blood <i>is</i> the life; and thou mayest not eat the life with the flesh.

<b>24 </b>Thou shalt not eat it; thou shalt pour it upon the earth as water.

<b>25 </b>Thou shalt not eat it; that it may go well with thee, and with thy children after thee, when thou shalt do <i>that which is</i> right in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>26 </b>Only thy holy things which thou hast, and thy vows, thou shalt take, and go unto the place which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall choose:

<b>27 </b>And thou shalt offer thy burnt offerings, the flesh and the blood, upon the altar of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God: and the blood of thy sacrifices shall be poured out upon the altar of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, and thou shalt eat the flesh.

<b>28 </b>Observe and hear all these words which I command thee, that it may go well with thee, and with thy children after thee for ever, when thou doest <i>that which is</i> good and right in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God.

<b>29 </b>¶ When the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God shall cut off the nations from before thee, whither thou goest to possess them, and thou succeedest them, and dwellest in their land;

<b>30 </b>Take heed to thyself that thou be not snared by following them, after that they be destroyed from before thee; and that thou inquire not after their gods, saying, How did these nations serve their gods? even so will I do likewise.

<b>31 </b>Thou shalt not do so unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God: for every abomination to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which he hateth, have they done unto their gods; for even their sons and their daughters they have burnt in the fire to their gods.

<b>32 </b>What thing soever I command you, observe to do it: thou shalt not add thereto, nor diminish from it.


--------------------

CHAPTER 13

<b>1 </b>If there arise among you a prophet, or a dreamer of dreams, and giveth thee a sign or a wonder,

<b>2 </b>And the sign or the wonder come to pass, whereof he spake unto thee, saying, Let us go after other gods, which thou hast not known, and let us serve them;

<b>3 </b>Thou shalt not hearken unto the words of that prophet, or that dreamer of dreams: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God proveth you, to know whether ye love the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God with all your heart and with all your soul.

<b>4 </b>Ye shall walk after the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, and fear him, and keep his commandments, and obey his voice, and ye shall serve him, and cleave unto him.

<b>5 </b>And that prophet, or that dreamer of dreams, shall be put to death; because he hath spoken to turn <i>you</i> away from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, which brought you out of the land of Egypt, and redeemed you out of the house of bondage, to thrust thee out of the way which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God commanded thee to walk in. So shalt thou put the evil away from the midst of thee.

<b>6 </b>¶ If thy brother, the son of thy mother, or thy son, or thy daughter, or the wife of thy bosom, or thy friend, which <i>is</i> as thine own soul, entice thee secretly, saying, Let us go and serve other gods, which thou hast not known, thou, nor thy fathers;

<b>7 </b><i>Namely,</i> of the gods of the people which <i>are</i> round about you, nigh unto thee, or far off from thee, from the <i>one</i> end of the earth even unto the <i>other</i> end of the earth;

<b>8 </b>Thou shalt not consent unto him, nor hearken unto him; neither shall thine eye pity him, neither shalt thou spare, neither shalt thou conceal him:

<b>9 </b>But thou shalt surely kill him; thine hand shall be first upon him to put him to death, and afterwards the hand of all the people.

<b>10 </b>And thou shalt stone him with stones, that he die; because he hath sought to thrust thee away from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, which brought thee out of the land of Egypt, from the house of bondage.

<b>11 </b>And all Israel shall hear, and fear, and shall do no more any such wickedness as this is among you.

<b>12 </b>¶ If thou shalt hear <i>say</i> in one of thy cities, which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God hath given thee to dwell there, saying,

<b>13 </b><i>Certain</i> men, the children of Belial, are gone out from among you, and have withdrawn the inhabitants of their city, saying, Let us go and serve other gods, which ye have not known;

<b>14 </b>Then shalt thou inquire, and make search, and ask diligently; and, behold, <i>if it be</i> truth, <i>and</i> the thing certain, <i>that</i> such abomination is wrought among you;

<b>15 </b>Thou shalt surely smite the inhabitants of that city with the edge of the sword, destroying it utterly, and all that <i>is</i> therein, and the cattle thereof, with the edge of the sword.

<b>16 </b>And thou shalt gather all the spoil of it into the midst of the street thereof, and shalt burn with fire the city, and all the spoil thereof every whit, for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God: and it shall be an heap for ever; it shall not be built again.

<b>17 </b>And there shall cleave nought of the cursed thing to thine hand: that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> may turn from the fierceness of his anger, and shew thee mercy, and have compassion upon thee, and multiply thee, as he hath sworn unto thy fathers;

<b>18 </b>When thou shalt hearken to the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, to keep all his commandments which I command thee this day, to do <i>that which is</i> right in the eyes of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God.


--------------------

CHAPTER 14

<b>1 </b>Ye <i>are</i> the children of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God: ye shall not cut yourselves, nor make any baldness between your eyes for the dead.

<b>2 </b>For thou <i>art</i> an holy people unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath chosen thee to be a peculiar people unto himself, above all the nations that <i>are</i> upon the earth.

<b>3 </b>¶ Thou shalt not eat any abominable thing.

<b>4 </b>These <i>are</i> the beasts which ye shall eat: the ox, the sheep, and the goat,

<b>5 </b>The hart, and the roebuck, and the fallow deer, and the wild goat, and the pygarg, and the wild ox, and the chamois.

<b>6 </b>And every beast that parteth the hoof, and cleaveth the cleft into two claws, <i>and</i> cheweth the cud among the beasts, that ye shall eat.

<b>7 </b>Nevertheless these ye shall not eat of them that chew the cud, or of them that divide the cloven hoof; <i>as</i> the camel, and the hare, and the coney: for they chew the cud, but divide not the hoof; <i>therefore</i> they <i>are</i> unclean unto you.

<b>8 </b>And the swine, because it divideth the hoof, yet cheweth not the cud, it <i>is</i> unclean unto you: ye shall not eat of their flesh, nor touch their dead carcase.

<b>9 </b>¶ These ye shall eat of all that <i>are</i> in the waters: all that have fins and scales shall ye eat:

<b>10 </b>And whatsoever hath not fins and scales ye may not eat; it <i>is</i> unclean unto you.

<b>11 </b>¶ <i>Of</i> all clean birds ye shall eat.

<b>12 </b>But these <i>are they</i> of which ye shall not eat: the eagle, and the ossifrage, and the ospray,

<b>13 </b>And the glede, and the kite, and the vulture after his kind,

<b>14 </b>And every raven after his kind,

<b>15 </b>And the owl, and the night hawk, and the cuckow, and the hawk after his kind,

<b>16 </b>The little owl, and the great owl, and the swan,

<b>17 </b>And the pelican, and the gier eagle, and the cormorant,

<b>18 </b>And the stork, and the heron after her kind, and the lapwing, and the bat.

<b>19 </b>And every creeping thing that flieth <i>is</i> unclean unto you: they shall not be eaten.

<b>20 </b><i>But of</i> all clean fowls ye may eat.

<b>21 </b>¶ Ye shall not eat <i>of</i> any thing that dieth of itself: thou shalt give it unto the stranger that <i>is</i> in thy gates, that he may eat it; or thou mayest sell it unto an alien: for thou <i>art</i> an holy people unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God. Thou shalt not seethe a kid in his mother’s milk.

<b>22 </b>Thou shalt truly tithe all the increase of thy seed, that the field bringeth forth year by year.

<b>23 </b>And thou shalt eat before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, in the place which he shall choose to place his name there, the tithe of thy corn, of thy wine, and of thine oil, and the firstlings of thy herds and of thy flocks; that thou mayest learn to fear the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God always.

<b>24 </b>And if the way be too long for thee, so that thou art not able to carry it; <i>or</i> if the place be too far from thee, which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God shall choose to set his name there, when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God hath blessed thee:

<b>25 </b>Then shalt thou turn <i>it</i> into money, and bind up the money in thine hand, and shalt go unto the place which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God shall choose:

<b>26 </b>And thou shalt bestow that money for whatsoever thy soul lusteth after, for oxen, or for sheep, or for wine, or for strong drink, or for whatsoever thy soul desireth: and thou shalt eat there before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, and thou shalt rejoice, thou, and thine household,

<b>27 </b>And the Levite that <i>is</i> within thy gates; thou shalt not forsake him; for he hath no part nor inheritance with thee.

<b>28 </b>¶ At the end of three years thou shalt bring forth all the tithe of thine increase the same year, and shalt lay <i>it</i> up within thy gates:

<b>29 </b>And the Levite, (because he hath no part nor inheritance with thee,) and the stranger, and the fatherless, and the widow, which <i>are</i> within thy gates, shall come, and shall eat and be satisfied; that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God may bless thee in all the work of thine hand which thou doest.


--------------------

CHAPTER 15

<b>1 </b>At the end of <i>every</i> seven years thou shalt make a release.

<b>2 </b>And this <i>is</i> the manner of the release: Every creditor that lendeth <i>ought</i> unto his neighbour shall release <i>it;</i> he shall not exact <i>it</i> of his neighbour, or of his brother; because it is called the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s release.

<b>3 </b>Of a foreigner thou mayest exact <i>it again:</i> but <i>that</i> which is thine with thy brother thine hand shall release;

<b>4 </b>Save when there shall be no poor among you; for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall greatly bless thee in the land which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God giveth thee <i>for</i> an inheritance to possess it:

<b>5 </b>Only if thou carefully hearken unto the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, to observe to do all these commandments which I command thee this day.

<b>6 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God blesseth thee, as he promised thee: and thou shalt lend unto many nations, but thou shalt not borrow; and thou shalt reign over many nations, but they shall not reign over thee.

<b>7 </b>¶ If there be among you a poor man of one of thy brethren within any of thy gates in thy land which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God giveth thee, thou shalt not harden thine heart, nor shut thine hand from thy poor brother:

<b>8 </b>But thou shalt open thine hand wide unto him, and shalt surely lend him sufficient for his need, <i>in that</i> which he wanteth.

<b>9 </b>Beware that there be not a thought in thy wicked heart, saying, The seventh year, the year of release, is at hand; and thine eye be evil against thy poor brother, and thou givest him nought; and he cry unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> against thee, and it be sin unto thee.

<b>10 </b>Thou shalt surely give him, and thine heart shall not be grieved when thou givest unto him: because that for this thing the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God shall bless thee in all thy works, and in all that thou puttest thine hand unto.

<b>11 </b>For the poor shall never cease out of the land: therefore I command thee, saying, Thou shalt open thine hand wide unto thy brother, to thy poor, and to thy needy, in thy land.

<b>12 </b>¶ <i>And</i> if thy brother, an Hebrew man, or an Hebrew woman, be sold unto thee, and serve thee six years; then in the seventh year thou shalt let him go free from thee.

<b>13 </b>And when thou sendest him out free from thee, thou shalt not let him go away empty:

<b>14 </b>Thou shalt furnish him liberally out of thy flock, and out of thy floor, and out of thy winepress: <i>of that</i> wherewith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God hath blessed thee thou shalt give unto him.

<b>15 </b>And thou shalt remember that thou wast a bondman in the land of Egypt, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God redeemed thee: therefore I command thee this thing to day.

<b>16 </b>And it shall be, if he say unto thee, I will not go away from thee; because he loveth thee and thine house, because he is well with thee;

<b>17 </b>Then thou shalt take an awl, and thrust <i>it</i> through his ear unto the door, and he shall be thy servant for ever. And also unto thy maidservant thou shalt do likewise.
