<b>2 </b>Saul chose him three thousand <i>men</i> of Israel; <i>whereof</i> two thousand were with Saul in Michmash and in mount Beth-el, and a thousand were with Jonathan in Gibeah of Benjamin: and the rest of the people he sent every man to his tent.

<b>3 </b>And Jonathan smote the garrison of the Philistines that <i>was</i> in Geba, and the Philistines heard <i>of it.</i> And Saul blew the trumpet throughout all the land, saying, Let the Hebrews hear.

<b>4 </b>And all Israel heard say <i>that</i> Saul had smitten a garrison of the Philistines, and <i>that</i> Israel also was had in abomination with the Philistines. And the people were called together after Saul to Gilgal.

<b>5 </b>¶ And the Philistines gathered themselves together to fight with Israel, thirty thousand chariots, and six thousand horsemen, and people as the sand which <i>is</i> on the sea shore in multitude: and they came up, and pitched in Michmash, eastward from Beth-aven.

<b>6 </b>When the men of Israel saw that they were in a strait, (for the people were distressed,) then the people did hide themselves in caves, and in thickets, and in rocks, and in high places, and in pits.

<b>7 </b>And <i>some of</i> the Hebrews went over Jordan to the land of Gad and Gilead. As for Saul, he <i>was</i> yet in Gilgal, and all the people followed him trembling.

<b>8 </b>¶ And he tarried seven days, according to the set time that Samuel <i>had appointed:</i> but Samuel came not to Gilgal; and the people were scattered from him.

<b>9 </b>And Saul said, Bring hither a burnt offering to me, and peace offerings. And he offered the burnt offering.

<b>10 </b>And it came to pass, that as soon as he had made an end of offering the burnt offering, behold, Samuel came; and Saul went out to meet him, that he might salute him.

<b>11 </b>¶ And Samuel said, What hast thou done? And Saul said, Because I saw that the people were scattered from me, and <i>that</i> thou camest not within the days appointed, and <i>that</i> the Philistines gathered themselves together at Michmash;

<b>12 </b>Therefore said I, The Philistines will come down now upon me to Gilgal, and I have not made supplication unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: I forced myself therefore, and offered a burnt offering.

<b>13 </b>And Samuel said to Saul, Thou hast done foolishly: thou hast not kept the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, which he commanded thee: for now would the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> have established thy kingdom upon Israel for ever.

<b>14 </b>But now thy kingdom shall not continue: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath sought him a man after his own heart, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath commanded him <i>to be</i> captain over his people, because thou hast not kept <i>that</i> which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded thee.

<b>15 </b>And Samuel arose, and gat him up from Gilgal unto Gibeah of Benjamin. And Saul numbered the people <i>that were</i> present with him, about six hundred men.

<b>16 </b>And Saul, and Jonathan his son, and the people <i>that were</i> present with them, abode in Gibeah of Benjamin: but the Philistines encamped in Michmash.

<b>17 </b>¶ And the spoilers came out of the camp of the Philistines in three companies: one company turned unto the way <i>that leadeth to</i> Ophrah, unto the land of Shual:

<b>18 </b>And another company turned the way <i>to</i> Beth-horon: and another company turned <i>to</i> the way of the border that looketh to the valley of Zeboim toward the wilderness.

<b>19 </b>¶ Now there was no smith found throughout all the land of Israel: for the Philistines said, Lest the Hebrews make <i>them</i> swords or spears:

<b>20 </b>But all the Israelites went down to the Philistines, to sharpen every man his share, and his coulter, and his axe, and his mattock.

<b>21 </b>Yet they had a file for the mattocks, and for the coulters, and for the forks, and for the axes, and to sharpen the goads.

<b>22 </b>So it came to pass in the day of battle, that there was neither sword nor spear found in the hand of any of the people that <i>were</i> with Saul and Jonathan: but with Saul and with Jonathan his son was there found.

<b>23 </b>And the garrison of the Philistines went out to the passage of Michmash.


--------------------

CHAPTER 14

<b>1 </b>Now it came to pass upon a day, that Jonathan the son of Saul said unto the young man that bare his armour, Come, and let us go over to the Philistines’ garrison, that <i>is</i> on the other side. But he told not his father.

<b>2 </b>And Saul tarried in the uttermost part of Gibeah under a pomegranate tree which <i>is</i> in Migron: and the people that <i>were</i> with him <i>were</i> about six hundred men;

<b>3 </b>And Ahiah, the son of Ahitub, I-chabod’s brother, the son of Phinehas, the son of Eli, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s priest in Shiloh, wearing an ephod. And the people knew not that Jonathan was gone.

<b>4 </b>¶ And between the passages, by which Jonathan sought to go over unto the Philistines’ garrison, <i>there was</i> a sharp rock on the one side, and a sharp rock on the other side: and the name of the one <i>was</i> Bozez, and the name of the other Seneh.

<b>5 </b>The forefront of the one <i>was</i> situate northward over against Michmash, and the other southward over against Gibeah.

<b>6 </b>And Jonathan said to the young man that bare his armour, Come, and let us go over unto the garrison of these uncircumcised: it may be that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will work for us: for <i>there is</i> no restraint to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> to save by many or by few.

<b>7 </b>And his armourbearer said unto him, Do all that <i>is</i> in thine heart: turn thee; behold, I <i>am</i> with thee according to thy heart.

<b>8 </b>Then said Jonathan, Behold, we will pass over unto <i>these</i> men, and we will discover ourselves unto them.

<b>9 </b>If they say thus unto us, Tarry until we come to you; then we will stand still in our place, and will not go up unto them.

<b>10 </b>But if they say thus, Come up unto us; then we will go up: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath delivered them into our hand: and this <i>shall be</i> a sign unto us.

<b>11 </b>And both of them discovered themselves unto the garrison of the Philistines: and the Philistines said, Behold, the Hebrews come forth out of the holes where they had hid themselves.

<b>12 </b>And the men of the garrison answered Jonathan and his armourbearer, and said, Come up to us, and we will shew you a thing. And Jonathan said unto his armourbearer, Come up after me: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath delivered them into the hand of Israel.

<b>13 </b>And Jonathan climbed up upon his hands and upon his feet, and his armourbearer after him: and they fell before Jonathan; and his armourbearer slew after him.

<b>14 </b>And that first slaughter, which Jonathan and his armourbearer made, was about twenty men, within as it were an half acre of land, <i>which</i> a yoke <i>of oxen might plow.</i>

<b>15 </b>And there was trembling in the host, in the field, and among all the people: the garrison, and the spoilers, they also trembled, and the earth quaked: so it was a very great trembling.

<b>16 </b>And the watchmen of Saul in Gibeah of Benjamin looked; and, behold, the multitude melted away, and they went on beating down <i>one another.</i>

<b>17 </b>Then said Saul unto the people that <i>were</i> with him, Number now, and see who is gone from us. And when they had numbered, behold, Jonathan and his armourbearer <i>were</i> not <i>there.</i>

<b>18 </b>And Saul said unto Ahiah, Bring hither the ark of God. For the ark of God was at that time with the children of Israel.

<b>19 </b>¶ And it came to pass, while Saul talked unto the priest, that the noise that <i>was</i> in the host of the Philistines went on and increased: and Saul said unto the priest, Withdraw thine hand.

<b>20 </b>And Saul and all the people that <i>were</i> with him assembled themselves, and they came to the battle: and, behold, every man’s sword was against his fellow, <i>and there was</i> a very great discomfiture.

<b>21 </b>Moreover the Hebrews <i>that</i> were with the Philistines before that time, which went up with them into the camp <i>from the country</i> round about, even they also <i>turned</i> to be with the Israelites that <i>were</i> with Saul and Jonathan.

<b>22 </b>Likewise all the men of Israel which had hid themselves in mount Ephraim, <i>when</i> they heard that the Philistines fled, even they also followed hard after them in the battle.

<b>23 </b>So the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> saved Israel that day: and the battle passed over unto Beth-aven.

<b>24 </b>¶ And the men of Israel were distressed that day: for Saul had adjured the people, saying, Cursed <i>be</i> the man that eateth <i>any</i> food until evening, that I may be avenged on mine enemies. So none of the people tasted <i>any</i> food.

<b>25 </b>And all <i>they of</i> the land came to a wood; and there was honey upon the ground.

<b>26 </b>And when the people were come into the wood, behold, the honey dropped; but no man put his hand to his mouth: for the people feared the oath.

<b>27 </b>But Jonathan heard not when his father charged the people with the oath: wherefore he put forth the end of the rod that <i>was</i> in his hand, and dipped it in an honeycomb, and put his hand to his mouth; and his eyes were enlightened.

<b>28 </b>Then answered one of the people, and said, Thy father straitly charged the people with an oath, saying, Cursed <i>be</i> the man that eateth <i>any</i> food this day. And the people were faint.

<b>29 </b>Then said Jonathan, My father hath troubled the land: see, I pray you, how mine eyes have been enlightened, because I tasted a little of this honey.

<b>30 </b>How much more, if haply the people had eaten freely to day of the spoil of their enemies which they found? for had there not been now a much greater slaughter among the Philistines?

<b>31 </b>And they smote the Philistines that day from Michmash to Aijalon: and the people were very faint.

<b>32 </b>And the people flew upon the spoil, and took sheep, and oxen, and calves, and slew <i>them</i> on the ground: and the people did eat <i>them</i> with the blood.

<b>33 </b>¶ Then they told Saul, saying, Behold, the people sin against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, in that they eat with the blood. And he said, Ye have transgressed: roll a great stone unto me this day.

<b>34 </b>And Saul said, Disperse yourselves among the people, and say unto them, Bring me hither every man his ox, and every man his sheep, and slay <i>them</i> here, and eat; and sin not against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in eating with the blood. And all the people brought every man his ox with him that night, and slew <i>them</i> there.

<b>35 </b>And Saul built an altar unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: the same was the first altar that he built unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>36 </b>¶ And Saul said, Let us go down after the Philistines by night, and spoil them until the morning light, and let us not leave a man of them. And they said, Do whatsoever seemeth good unto thee. Then said the priest, Let us draw near hither unto God.

<b>37 </b>And Saul asked counsel of God, Shall I go down after the Philistines? wilt thou deliver them into the hand of Israel? But he answered him not that day.

<b>38 </b>And Saul said, Draw ye near hither, all the chief of the people: and know and see wherein this sin hath been this day.

<b>39 </b>For, <i>as</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, which saveth Israel, though it be in Jonathan my son, he shall surely die. But <i>there was</i> not a man among all the people <i>that</i> answered him.

<b>40 </b>Then said he unto all Israel, Be ye on one side, and I and Jonathan my son will be on the other side. And the people said unto Saul, Do what seemeth good unto thee.

<b>41 </b>Therefore Saul said unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, Give a perfect <i>lot</i><i>.</i> And Saul and Jonathan were taken: but the people escaped.

<b>42 </b>And Saul said, Cast <i>lots</i> between me and Jonathan my son. And Jonathan was taken.

<b>43 </b>Then Saul said to Jonathan, Tell me what thou hast done. And Jonathan told him, and said, I did but taste a little honey with the end of the rod that <i>was</i> in mine hand, <i>and,</i> lo, I must die.

<b>44 </b>And Saul answered, God do so and more also: for thou shalt surely die, Jonathan.

<b>45 </b>And the people said unto Saul, Shall Jonathan die, who hath wrought this great salvation in Israel? God forbid: <i>as</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, there shall not one hair of his head fall to the ground; for he hath wrought with God this day. So the people rescued Jonathan, that he died not.

<b>46 </b>Then Saul went up from following the Philistines: and the Philistines went to their own place.

<b>47 </b>¶ So Saul took the kingdom over Israel, and fought against all his enemies on every side, against Moab, and against the children of Ammon, and against Edom, and against the kings of Zobah, and against the Philistines: and whithersoever he turned himself, he vexed <i>them.</i>

<b>48 </b>And he gathered an host, and smote the Amalekites, and delivered Israel out of the hands of them that spoiled them.

<b>49 </b>Now the sons of Saul were Jonathan, and Ishui, and Melchi-shua: and the names of his two daughters <i>were these;</i> the name of the firstborn Merab, and the name of the younger Michal:

<b>50 </b>And the name of Saul’s wife <i>was</i> Ahinoam, the daughter of Ahimaaz: and the name of the captain of his host <i>was</i> Abner, the son of Ner, Saul’s uncle.

<b>51 </b>And Kish <i>was</i> the father of Saul; and Ner the father of Abner <i>was</i> the son of Abiel.

<b>52 </b>And there was sore war against the Philistines all the days of Saul: and when Saul saw any strong man, or any valiant man, he took him unto him.


--------------------

CHAPTER 15

<b>1 </b>Samuel also said unto Saul, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sent me to anoint thee <i>to be</i> king over his people, over Israel: now therefore hearken thou unto the voice of the words of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>2 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, I remember <i>that</i> which Amalek did to Israel, how he laid <i>wait</i> for him in the way, when he came up from Egypt.

<b>3 </b>Now go and smite Amalek, and utterly destroy all that they have, and spare them not; but slay both man and woman, infant and suckling, ox and sheep, camel and ass.

<b>4 </b>And Saul gathered the people together, and numbered them in Telaim, two hundred thousand footmen, and ten thousand men of Judah.

<b>5 </b>And Saul came to a city of Amalek, and laid wait in the valley.

<b>6 </b>¶ And Saul said unto the Kenites, Go, depart, get you down from among the Amalekites, lest I destroy you with them: for ye shewed kindness to all the children of Israel, when they came up out of Egypt. So the Kenites departed from among the Amalekites.

<b>7 </b>And Saul smote the Amalekites from Havilah <i>until</i> thou comest to Shur, that <i>is</i> over against Egypt.

<b>8 </b>And he took Agag the king of the Amalekites alive, and utterly destroyed all the people with the edge of the sword.

<b>9 </b>But Saul and the people spared Agag, and the best of the sheep, and of the oxen, and of the fatlings, and the lambs, and all <i>that was</i> good, and would not utterly destroy them: but every thing <i>that was</i> vile and refuse, that they destroyed utterly.

<b>10 </b>¶ Then came the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto Samuel, saying,

<b>11 </b>It repenteth me that I have set up Saul <i>to be</i> king: for he is turned back from following me, and hath not performed my commandments. And it grieved Samuel; and he cried unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> all night.

<b>12 </b>And when Samuel rose early to meet Saul in the morning, it was told Samuel, saying, Saul came to Carmel, and, behold, he set him up a place, and is gone about, and passed on, and gone down to Gilgal.

<b>13 </b>And Samuel came to Saul: and Saul said unto him, Blessed <i>be</i> thou of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: I have performed the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>14 </b>And Samuel said, What <i>meaneth</i> then this bleating of the sheep in mine ears, and the lowing of the oxen which I hear?

<b>15 </b>And Saul said, They have brought them from the Amalekites: for the people spared the best of the sheep and of the oxen, to sacrifice unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God; and the rest we have utterly destroyed.

<b>16 </b>Then Samuel said unto Saul, Stay, and I will tell thee what the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath said to me this night. And he said unto him, Say on.

<b>17 </b>And Samuel said, When thou <i>wast</i> little in thine own sight, <i>wast</i> thou not <i>made</i> the head of the tribes of Israel, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> anointed thee king over Israel?

<b>18 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sent thee on a journey, and said, Go and utterly destroy the sinners the Amalekites, and fight against them until they be consumed.

<b>19 </b>Wherefore then didst thou not obey the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, but didst fly upon the spoil, and didst evil in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>?

<b>20 </b>And Saul said unto Samuel, Yea, I have obeyed the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and have gone the way which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sent me, and have brought Agag the king of Amalek, and have utterly destroyed the Amalekites.

<b>21 </b>But the people took of the spoil, sheep and oxen, the chief of the things which should have been utterly destroyed, to sacrifice unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God in Gilgal.

<b>22 </b>And Samuel said, Hath the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>as great</i> delight in burnt offerings and sacrifices, as in obeying the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>? Behold, to obey <i>is</i> better than sacrifice, <i>and</i> to hearken than the fat of rams.

<b>23 </b>For rebellion <i>is as</i> the sin of witchcraft, and stubbornness <i>is as</i> iniquity and idolatry. Because thou hast rejected the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, he hath also rejected thee from <i>being</i> king.

<b>24 </b>¶ And Saul said unto Samuel, I have sinned: for I have transgressed the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and thy words: because I feared the people, and obeyed their voice.

<b>25 </b>Now therefore, I pray thee, pardon my sin, and turn again with me, that I may worship the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>26 </b>And Samuel said unto Saul, I will not return with thee: for thou hast rejected the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath rejected thee from being king over Israel.

<b>27 </b>And as Samuel turned about to go away, he laid hold upon the skirt of his mantle, and it rent.

<b>28 </b>And Samuel said unto him, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath rent the kingdom of Israel from thee this day, and hath given it to a neighbour of thine, <i>that is</i> better than thou.

<b>29 </b>And also the Strength of Israel will not lie nor repent: for he <i>is</i> not a man, that he should repent.

<b>30 </b>Then he said, I have sinned: <i>yet</i> honour me now, I pray thee, before the elders of my people, and before Israel, and turn again with me, that I may worship the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God.

<b>31 </b>So Samuel turned again after Saul; and Saul worshipped the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>32 </b>¶ Then said Samuel, Bring ye hither to me Agag the king of the Amalekites. And Agag came unto him delicately. And Agag said, Surely the bitterness of death is past.

<b>33 </b>And Samuel said, As thy sword hath made women childless, so shall thy mother be childless among women. And Samuel hewed Agag in pieces before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in Gilgal.

<b>34 </b>¶ Then Samuel went to Ramah; and Saul went up to his house to Gibeah of Saul.

<b>35 </b>And Samuel came no more to see Saul until the day of his death: nevertheless Samuel mourned for Saul: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> repented that he had made Saul king over Israel.


--------------------

CHAPTER 16

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Samuel, How long wilt thou mourn for Saul, seeing I have rejected him from reigning over Israel? fill thine horn with oil, and go, I will send thee to Jesse the Beth-lehemite: for I have provided me a king among his sons.

<b>2 </b>And Samuel said, How can I go? if Saul hear <i>it,</i> he will kill me. And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said, Take an heifer with thee, and say, I am come to sacrifice to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>3 </b>And call Jesse to the sacrifice, and I will shew thee what thou shalt do: and thou shalt anoint unto me <i>him</i> whom I name unto thee.

<b>4 </b>And Samuel did that which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake, and came to Beth-lehem. And the elders of the town trembled at his coming, and said, Comest thou peaceably?

<b>5 </b>And he said, Peaceably: I am come to sacrifice unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: sanctify yourselves, and come with me to the sacrifice. And he sanctified Jesse and his sons, and called them to the sacrifice.

<b>6 </b>¶ And it came to pass, when they were come, that he looked on Eliab, and said, Surely the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s anointed <i>is</i> before him.

<b>7 </b>But the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Samuel, Look not on his countenance, or on the height of his stature; because I have refused him: for <i>the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> seeth</i> not as man seeth; for man looketh on the outward appearance, but the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> looketh on the heart.

<b>8 </b>Then Jesse called Abinadab, and made him pass before Samuel. And he said, Neither hath the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> chosen this.

<b>9 </b>Then Jesse made Shammah to pass by. And he said, Neither hath the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> chosen this.

<b>10 </b>Again, Jesse made seven of his sons to pass before Samuel. And Samuel said unto Jesse, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath not chosen these.

<b>11 </b>And Samuel said unto Jesse, Are here all <i>thy</i> children? And he said, There remaineth yet the youngest, and, behold, he keepeth the sheep. And Samuel said unto Jesse, Send and fetch him: for we will not sit down till he come hither.

<b>12 </b>And he sent, and brought him in. Now he <i>was</i> ruddy, <i>and</i> withal of a beautiful countenance, and goodly to look to. And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said, Arise, anoint him: for this <i>is</i> he.

<b>13 </b>Then Samuel took the horn of oil, and anointed him in the midst of his brethren: and the Spirit of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came upon David from that day forward. So Samuel rose up, and went to Ramah.

<b>14 </b>¶ But the Spirit of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> departed from Saul, and an evil spirit from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> troubled him.

<b>15 </b>And Saul’s servants said unto him, Behold now, an evil spirit from God troubleth thee.

<b>16 </b>Let our lord now command thy servants, <i>which are</i> before thee, to seek out a man, <i>who is</i> a cunning player on an harp: and it shall come to pass, when the evil spirit from God is upon thee, that he shall play with his hand, and thou shalt be well.

<b>17 </b>And Saul said unto his servants, Provide me now a man that can play well, and bring <i>him</i> to me.

<b>18 </b>Then answered one of the servants, and said, Behold, I have seen a son of Jesse the Beth-lehemite, <i>that is</i> cunning in playing, and a mighty valiant man, and a man of war, and prudent in matters, and a comely person, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> with him.

<b>19 </b>¶ Wherefore Saul sent messengers unto Jesse, and said, Send me David thy son, which <i>is</i> with the sheep.

<b>20 </b>And Jesse took an ass <i>laden</i> with bread, and a bottle of wine, and a kid, and sent <i>them</i> by David his son unto Saul.

<b>21 </b>And David came to Saul, and stood before him: and he loved him greatly; and he became his armourbearer.

<b>22 </b>And Saul sent to Jesse, saying, Let David, I pray thee, stand before me; for he hath found favour in my sight.

<b>23 </b>And it came to pass, when the <i>evil</i> spirit from God was upon Saul, that David took an harp, and played with his hand: so Saul was refreshed, and was well, and the evil spirit departed from him.


--------------------

CHAPTER 17

<b>1 </b>Now the Philistines gathered together their armies to battle, and were gathered together at Shochoh, which <i>belongeth</i> to Judah, and pitched between Shochoh and Azekah, in Ephes-dammim.

<b>2 </b>And Saul and the men of Israel were gathered together, and pitched by the valley of Elah, and set the battle in array against the Philistines.

<b>3 </b>And the Philistines stood on a mountain on the one side, and Israel stood on a mountain on the other side: and <i>there was</i> a valley between them.

<b>4 </b>¶ And there went out a champion out of the camp of the Philistines, named Goliath, of Gath, whose height <i>was</i> six cubits and a span.

<b>5 </b>And <i>he had</i> an helmet of brass upon his head, and he <i>was</i> armed with a coat of mail; and the weight of the coat <i>was</i> five thousand shekels of brass.

<b>6 </b>And <i>he had</i> greaves of brass upon his legs, and a target of brass between his shoulders.

<b>7 </b>And the staff of his spear <i>was</i> like a weaver’s beam; and his spear’s head <i>weighed</i> six hundred shekels of iron: and one bearing a shield went before him.

<b>8 </b>And he stood and cried unto the armies of Israel, and said unto them, Why are ye come out to set <i>your</i> battle in array? <i>am</i> not I a Philistine, and ye servants to Saul? choose you a man for you, and let him come down to me.

<b>9 </b>If he be able to fight with me, and to kill me, then will we be your servants: but if I prevail against him, and kill him, then shall ye be our servants, and serve us.

<b>10 </b>And the Philistine said, I defy the armies of Israel this day; give me a man, that we may fight together.

<b>11 </b>When Saul and all Israel heard those words of the Philistine, they were dismayed, and greatly afraid.

<b>12 </b>¶ Now David <i>was</i> the son of that Ephrathite of Beth-lehem-judah, whose name <i>was</i> Jesse; and he had eight sons: and the man went among men <i>for</i> an old man in the days of Saul.

<b>13 </b>And the three eldest sons of Jesse went <i>and</i> followed Saul to the battle: and the names of his three sons that went to the battle <i>were</i> Eliab the firstborn, and next unto him Abinadab, and the third Shammah.

<b>14 </b>And David <i>was</i> the youngest: and the three eldest followed Saul.

<b>15 </b>But David went and returned from Saul to feed his father’s sheep at Beth-lehem.

<b>16 </b>And the Philistine drew near morning and evening, and presented himself forty days.

<b>17 </b>And Jesse said unto David his son, Take now for thy brethren an ephah of this parched <i>corn,</i> and these ten loaves, and run to the camp to thy brethren;

<b>18 </b>And carry these ten cheeses unto the captain of <i>their</i> thousand, and look how thy brethren fare, and take their pledge.

<b>19 </b>Now Saul, and they, and all the men of Israel, <i>were</i> in the valley of Elah, fighting with the Philistines.

<b>20 </b>¶ And David rose up early in the morning, and left the sheep with a keeper, and took, and went, as Jesse had commanded him; and he came to the trench, as the host was going forth to the fight, and shouted for the battle.

<b>21 </b>For Israel and the Philistines had put the battle in array, army against army.

<b>22 </b>And David left his carriage in the hand of the keeper of the carriage, and ran into the army, and came and saluted his brethren.

<b>23 </b>And as he talked with them, behold, there came up the champion, the Philistine of Gath, Goliath by name, out of the armies of the Philistines, and spake according to the same words: and David heard <i>them.</i>

<b>24 </b>And all the men of Israel, when they saw the man, fled from him, and were sore afraid.

<b>25 </b>And the men of Israel said, Have ye seen this man that is come up? surely to defy Israel is he come up: and it shall be, <i>that</i> the man who killeth him, the king will enrich him with great riches, and will give him his daughter, and make his father’s house free in Israel.

<b>26 </b>And David spake to the men that stood by him, saying, What shall be done to the man that killeth this Philistine, and taketh away the reproach from Israel? for who <i>is</i> this uncircumcised Philistine, that he should defy the armies of the living God?

<b>27 </b>And the people answered him after this manner, saying, So shall it be done to the man that killeth him.

<b>28 </b>¶ And Eliab his eldest brother heard when he spake unto the men; and Eliab’s anger was kindled against David, and he said, Why camest thou down hither? and with whom hast thou left those few sheep in the wilderness? I know thy pride, and the naughtiness of thine heart; for thou art come down that thou mightest see the battle.

<b>29 </b>And David said, What have I now done? <i>Is there</i> not a cause?

<b>30 </b>¶ And he turned from him toward another, and spake after the same manner: and the people answered him again after the former manner.

<b>31 </b>And when the words were heard which David spake, they rehearsed <i>them</i> before Saul: and he sent for him.

<b>32 </b>¶ And David said to Saul, Let no man’s heart fail because of him; thy servant will go and fight with this Philistine.

<b>33 </b>And Saul said to David, Thou art not able to go against this Philistine to fight with him: for thou <i>art but</i> a youth, and he a man of war from his youth.

<b>34 </b>And David said unto Saul, Thy servant kept his father’s sheep, and there came a lion, and a bear, and took a lamb out of the flock:

<b>35 </b>And I went out after him, and smote him, and delivered <i>it</i> out of his mouth: and when he arose against me, I caught <i>him</i> by his beard, and smote him, and slew him.

<b>36 </b>Thy servant slew both the lion and the bear: and this uncircumcised Philistine shall be as one of them, seeing he hath defied the armies of the living God.

<b>37 </b>David said moreover, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that delivered me out of the paw of the lion, and out of the paw of the bear, he will deliver me out of the hand of this Philistine. And Saul said unto David, Go, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> be with thee.

<b>38 </b>¶ And Saul armed David with his armour, and he put an helmet of brass upon his head; also he armed him with a coat of mail.

<b>39 </b>And David girded his sword upon his armour, and he assayed to go; for he had not proved <i>it.</i> And David said unto Saul, I cannot go with these; for I have not proved <i>them.</i> And David put them off him.

<b>40 </b>And he took his staff in his hand, and chose him five smooth stones out of the brook, and put them in a shepherd’s bag which he had, even in a scrip; and his sling <i>was</i> in his hand: and he drew near to the Philistine.

<b>41 </b>And the Philistine came on and drew near unto David; and the man that bare the shield <i>went</i> before him.

<b>42 </b>And when the Philistine looked about, and saw David, he disdained him: for he was <i>but</i> a youth, and ruddy, and of a fair countenance.

<b>43 </b>And the Philistine said unto David, <i>Am</i> I a dog, that thou comest to me with staves? And the Philistine cursed David by his gods.

<b>44 </b>And the Philistine said to David, Come to me, and I will give thy flesh unto the fowls of the air, and to the beasts of the field.

<b>45 </b>Then said David to the Philistine, Thou comest to me with a sword, and with a spear, and with a shield: but I come to thee in the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of the armies of Israel, whom thou hast defied.

<b>46 </b>This day will the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> deliver thee into mine hand; and I will smite thee, and take thine head from thee; and I will give the carcases of the host of the Philistines this day unto the fowls of the air, and to the wild beasts of the earth; that all the earth may know that there is a God in Israel.

<b>47 </b>And all this assembly shall know that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> saveth not with sword and spear: for the battle <i>is</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s, and he will give you into our hands.

<b>48 </b>And it came to pass, when the Philistine arose, and came and drew nigh to meet David, that David hasted, and ran toward the army to meet the Philistine.

<b>49 </b>And David put his hand in his bag, and took thence a stone, and slang <i>it,</i> and smote the Philistine in his forehead, that the stone sunk into his forehead; and he fell upon his face to the earth.

<b>50 </b>So David prevailed over the Philistine with a sling and with a stone, and smote the Philistine, and slew him; but <i>there was</i> no sword in the hand of David.

<b>51 </b>Therefore David ran, and stood upon the Philistine, and took his sword, and drew it out of the sheath thereof, and slew him, and cut off his head therewith. And when the Philistines saw their champion was dead, they fled.

<b>52 </b>And the men of Israel and of Judah arose, and shouted, and pursued the Philistines, until thou come to the valley, and to the gates of Ekron. And the wounded of the Philistines fell down by the way to Shaaraim, even unto Gath, and unto Ekron.

<b>53 </b>And the children of Israel returned from chasing after the Philistines, and they spoiled their tents.

<b>54 </b>And David took the head of the Philistine, and brought it to Jerusalem; but he put his armour in his tent.

<b>55 </b>¶ And when Saul saw David go forth against the Philistine, he said unto Abner, the captain of the host, Abner, whose son <i>is</i> this youth? And Abner said, <i>As</i> thy soul liveth, O king, I cannot tell.

<b>56 </b>And the king said, Inquire thou whose son the stripling <i>is.</i>

<b>57 </b>And as David returned from the slaughter of the Philistine, Abner took him, and brought him before Saul with the head of the Philistine in his hand.

<b>58 </b>And Saul said to him, Whose son <i>art</i> thou, <i>thou</i> young man? And David answered, <i>I am</i> the son of thy servant Jesse the Beth-lehemite.


--------------------

CHAPTER 18

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass, when he had made an end of speaking unto Saul, that the soul of Jonathan was knit with the soul of David, and Jonathan loved him as his own soul.

<b>2 </b>And Saul took him that day, and would let him go no more home to his father’s house.

<b>3 </b>Then Jonathan and David made a covenant, because he loved him as his own soul.

<b>4 </b>And Jonathan stripped himself of the robe that <i>was</i> upon him, and gave it to David, and his garments, even to his sword, and to his bow, and to his girdle.

<b>5 </b>¶ And David went out whithersoever Saul sent him, <i>and</i> behaved himself wisely: and Saul set him over the men of war, and he was accepted in the sight of all the people, and also in the sight of Saul’s servants.

<b>6 </b>And it came to pass as they came, when David was returned from the slaughter of the Philistine, that the women came out of all cities of Israel, singing and dancing, to meet king Saul, with tabrets, with joy, and with instruments of musick.

<b>7 </b>And the women answered <i>one another</i> as they played, and said, Saul hath slain his thousands, and David his ten thousands.

<b>8 </b>And Saul was very wroth, and the saying displeased him; and he said, They have ascribed unto David ten thousands, and to me they have ascribed <i>but</i> thousands: and <i>what</i> can he have more but the kingdom?

<b>9 </b>And Saul eyed David from that day and forward.

<b>10 </b>¶ And it came to pass on the morrow, that the evil spirit from God came upon Saul, and he prophesied in the midst of the house: and David played with his hand, as at other times: and <i>there was</i> a javelin in Saul’s hand.

<b>11 </b>And Saul cast the javelin; for he said, I will smite David even to the wall <i>with it.</i> And David avoided out of his presence twice.

<b>12 </b>¶ And Saul was afraid of David, because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was with him, and was departed from Saul.

<b>13 </b>Therefore Saul removed him from him, and made him his captain over a thousand; and he went out and came in before the people.

<b>14 </b>And David behaved himself wisely in all his ways; and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>was</i> with him.

<b>15 </b>Wherefore when Saul saw that he behaved himself very wisely, he was afraid of him.

<b>16 </b>But all Israel and Judah loved David, because he went out and came in before them.

<b>17 </b>¶ And Saul said to David, Behold my elder daughter Merab, her will I give thee to wife: only be thou valiant for me, and fight the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s battles. For Saul said, Let not mine hand be upon him, but let the hand of the Philistines be upon him.

<b>18 </b>And David said unto Saul, Who <i>am</i> I? and what <i>is</i> my life, <i>or</i> my father’s family in Israel, that I should be son in law to the king?

<b>19 </b>But it came to pass at the time when Merab Saul’s daughter should have been given to David, that she was given unto Adriel the Meholathite to wife.

<b>20 </b>And Michal Saul’s daughter loved David: and they told Saul, and the thing pleased him.

<b>21 </b>And Saul said, I will give him her, that she may be a snare to him, and that the hand of the Philistines may be against him. Wherefore Saul said to David, Thou shalt this day be my son in law in <i>the one of</i> the twain.

<b>22 </b>¶ And Saul commanded his servants, <i>saying,</i> Commune with David secretly, and say, Behold, the king hath delight in thee, and all his servants love thee: now therefore be the king’s son in law.

<b>23 </b>And Saul’s servants spake those words in the ears of David. And David said, Seemeth it to you <i>a</i> light <i>thing</i> to be a king’s son in law, seeing that I <i>am</i> a poor man, and lightly esteemed?

<b>24 </b>And the servants of Saul told him, saying, On this manner spake David.

<b>25 </b>And Saul said, Thus shall ye say to David, The king desireth not any dowry, but an hundred foreskins of the Philistines, to be avenged of the king’s enemies. But Saul thought to make David fall by the hand of the Philistines.

<b>26 </b>And when his servants told David these words, it pleased David well to be the king’s son in law: and the days were not expired.

<b>27 </b>Wherefore David arose and went, he and his men, and slew of the Philistines two hundred men; and David brought their foreskins, and they gave them in full tale to the king, that he might be the king’s son in law. And Saul gave him Michal his daughter to wife.

<b>28 </b>¶ And Saul saw and knew that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>was</i> with David, and <i>that</i> Michal Saul’s daughter loved him.

<b>29 </b>And Saul was yet the more afraid of David; and Saul became David’s enemy continually.

<b>30 </b>Then the princes of the Philistines went forth: and it came to pass, after they went forth, <i>that</i> David behaved himself more wisely than all the servants of Saul; so that his name was much set by.


--------------------

CHAPTER 19

<b>1 </b>And Saul spake to Jonathan his son, and to all his servants, that they should kill David.

<b>2 </b>But Jonathan Saul’s son delighted much in David: and Jonathan told David, saying, Saul my father seeketh to kill thee: now therefore, I pray thee, take heed to thyself until the morning, and abide in a secret <i>place,</i> and hide thyself:

<b>3 </b>And I will go out and stand beside my father in the field where thou <i>art,</i> and I will commune with my father of thee; and what I see, that I will tell thee.

<b>4 </b>¶ And Jonathan spake good of David unto Saul his father, and said unto him, Let not the king sin against his servant, against David; because he hath not sinned against thee, and because his works <i>have been</i> to thee-ward very good:

<b>5 </b>For he did put his life in his hand, and slew the Philistine, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> wrought a great salvation for all Israel: thou sawest <i>it,</i> and didst rejoice: wherefore then wilt thou sin against innocent blood, to slay David without a cause?

<b>6 </b>And Saul hearkened unto the voice of Jonathan: and Saul sware, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, he shall not be slain.

<b>7 </b>And Jonathan called David, and Jonathan shewed him all those things. And Jonathan brought David to Saul, and he was in his presence, as in times past.

<b>8 </b>¶ And there was war again: and David went out, and fought with the Philistines, and slew them with a great slaughter; and they fled from him.

<b>9 </b>And the evil spirit from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was upon Saul, as he sat in his house with his javelin in his hand: and David played with <i>his</i> hand.

<b>10 </b>And Saul sought to smite David even to the wall with the javelin; but he slipped away out of Saul’s presence, and he smote the javelin into the wall: and David fled, and escaped that night.

<b>11 </b>Saul also sent messengers unto David’s house, to watch him, and to slay him in the morning: and Michal David’s wife told him, saying, If thou save not thy life to night, to morrow thou shalt be slain.

<b>12 </b>¶ So Michal let David down through a window: and he went, and fled, and escaped.

<b>13 </b>And Michal took an image, and laid <i>it</i> in the bed, and put a pillow of goats’ <i>hair</i> for his bolster, and covered <i>it</i> with a cloth.

<b>14 </b>And when Saul sent messengers to take David, she said, He <i>is</i> sick.

<b>15 </b>And Saul sent the messengers <i>again</i> to see David, saying, Bring him up to me in the bed, that I may slay him.

<b>16 </b>And when the messengers were come in, behold, <i>there was</i> an image in the bed, with a pillow of goats’ <i>hair</i> for his bolster.

<b>17 </b>And Saul said unto Michal, Why hast thou deceived me so, and sent away mine enemy, that he is escaped? And Michal answered Saul, He said unto me, Let me go; why should I kill thee?

<b>18 </b>¶ So David fled, and escaped, and came to Samuel to Ramah, and told him all that Saul had done to him. And he and Samuel went and dwelt in Naioth.

<b>19 </b>And it was told Saul, saying, Behold, David <i>is</i> at Naioth in Ramah.

<b>20 </b>And Saul sent messengers to take David: and when they saw the company of the prophets prophesying, and Samuel standing <i>as</i> appointed over them, the Spirit of God was upon the messengers of Saul, and they also prophesied.

<b>21 </b>And when it was told Saul, he sent other messengers, and they prophesied likewise. And Saul sent messengers again the third time, and they prophesied also.

<b>22 </b>Then went he also to Ramah, and came to a great well that <i>is</i> in Sechu: and he asked and said, Where <i>are</i> Samuel and David? And <i>one</i> said, Behold, <i>they be</i> at Naioth in Ramah.

<b>23 </b>And he went thither to Naioth in Ramah: and the Spirit of God was upon him also, and he went on, and prophesied, until he came to Naioth in Ramah.

<b>24 </b>And he stripped off his clothes also, and prophesied before Samuel in like manner, and lay down naked all that day and all that night. Wherefore they say, <i>Is</i> Saul also among the prophets?


--------------------

CHAPTER 20

<b>1 </b>And David fled from Naioth in Ramah, and came and said before Jonathan, What have I done? what <i>is</i> mine iniquity? and what <i>is</i> my sin before thy father, that he seeketh my life?

<b>2 </b>And he said unto him, God forbid; thou shalt not die: behold, my father will do nothing either great or small, but that he will shew it me: and why should my father hide this thing from me? it <i>is</i> not <i>so.</i>

<b>3 </b>And David sware moreover, and said, Thy father certainly knoweth that I have found grace in thine eyes; and he saith, Let not Jonathan know this, lest he be grieved: but truly <i>as</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, and <i>as</i> thy soul liveth, <i>there is</i> but a step between me and death.

<b>4 </b>Then said Jonathan unto David, Whatsoever thy soul desireth, I will even do <i>it</i> for thee.

<b>5 </b>And David said unto Jonathan, Behold, to morrow <i>is</i> the new moon, and I should not fail to sit with the king at meat: but let me go, that I may hide myself in the field unto the third <i>day</i> at even.

<b>6 </b>If thy father at all miss me, then say, David earnestly asked <i>leave</i> of me that he might run to Beth-lehem his city: for <i>there is</i> a yearly sacrifice there for all the family.

<b>7 </b>If he say thus, <i>It is</i> well; thy servant shall have peace: but if he be very wroth, <i>then</i> be sure that evil is determined by him.

<b>8 </b>Therefore thou shalt deal kindly with thy servant; for thou hast brought thy servant into a covenant of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with thee: notwithstanding, if there be in me iniquity, slay me thyself; for why shouldest thou bring me to thy father?

<b>9 </b>And Jonathan said, Far be it from thee: for if I knew certainly that evil were determined by my father to come upon thee, then would not I tell it thee?

<b>10 </b>Then said David to Jonathan, Who shall tell me? or what <i>if</i> thy father answer thee roughly?

<b>11 </b>¶ And Jonathan said unto David, Come, and let us go out into the field. And they went out both of them into the field.

<b>12 </b>And Jonathan said unto David, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, when I have sounded my father about to morrow any time, <i>or</i> the third <i>day,</i> and, behold, <i>if there be</i> good toward David, and I then send not unto thee, and shew it thee;

<b>13 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> do so and much more to Jonathan: but if it please my father <i>to do</i> thee evil, then I will shew it thee, and send thee away, that thou mayest go in peace: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> be with thee, as he hath been with my father.

<b>14 </b>And thou shalt not only while yet I live shew me the kindness of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that I die not:

<b>15 </b>But <i>also</i> thou shalt not cut off thy kindness from my house for ever: no, not when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath cut off the enemies of David every one from the face of the earth.

<b>16 </b>So Jonathan made <i>a covenant</i> with the house of David, <i>saying,</i> Let the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> even require <i>it</i> at the hand of David’s enemies.

<b>17 </b>And Jonathan caused David to swear again, because he loved him: for he loved him as he loved his own soul.

<b>18 </b>Then Jonathan said to David, To morrow <i>is</i> the new moon: and thou shalt be missed, because thy seat will be empty.

<b>19 </b>And <i>when</i> thou hast stayed three days, <i>then</i> thou shalt go down quickly, and come to the place where thou didst hide thyself when the business was <i>in hand,</i> and shalt remain by the stone Ezel.

<b>20 </b>And I will shoot three arrows on the side <i>thereof,</i> as though I shot at a mark.

<b>21 </b>And, behold, I will send a lad, <i>saying,</i> Go, find out the arrows. If I expressly say unto the lad, Behold, the arrows <i>are</i> on this side of thee, take them; then come thou: for <i>there is</i> peace to thee, and no hurt; <i>as</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth.

<b>22 </b>But if I say thus unto the young man, Behold, the arrows <i>are</i> beyond thee; go thy way: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath sent thee away.

<b>23 </b>And <i>as touching</i> the matter which thou and I have spoken of, behold, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>be</i> between thee and me for ever.

<b>24 </b>¶ So David hid himself in the field: and when the new moon was come, the king sat him down to eat meat.

<b>25 </b>And the king sat upon his seat, as at other times, <i>even</i> upon a seat by the wall: and Jonathan arose, and Abner sat by Saul’s side, and David’s place was empty.

<b>26 </b>Nevertheless Saul spake not any thing that day: for he thought, Something hath befallen him, he <i>is</i> not clean; surely he <i>is</i> not clean.

<b>27 </b>And it came to pass on the morrow, <i>which was</i> the second <i>day</i> of the month, that David’s place was empty: and Saul said unto Jonathan his son, Wherefore cometh not the son of Jesse to meat, neither yesterday, nor to day?

<b>28 </b>And Jonathan answered Saul, David earnestly asked <i>leave</i> of me <i>to go</i> to Beth-lehem:

<b>29 </b>And he said, Let me go, I pray thee; for our family hath a sacrifice in the city; and my brother, he hath commanded me <i>to be there:</i> and now, if I have found favour in thine eyes, let me get away, I pray thee, and see my brethren. Therefore he cometh not unto the king’s table.

<b>30 </b>Then Saul’s anger was kindled against Jonathan, and he said unto him, Thou son of the perverse rebellious <i>woman,</i> do not I know that thou hast chosen the son of Jesse to thine own confusion, and unto the confusion of thy mother’s nakedness?

<b>31 </b>For as long as the son of Jesse liveth upon the ground, thou shalt not be established, nor thy kingdom. Wherefore now send and fetch him unto me, for he shall surely die.

<b>32 </b>And Jonathan answered Saul his father, and said unto him, Wherefore shall he be slain? what hath he done?

<b>33 </b>And Saul cast a javelin at him to smite him: whereby Jonathan knew that it was determined of his father to slay David.

<b>34 </b>So Jonathan arose from the table in fierce anger, and did eat no meat the second day of the month: for he was grieved for David, because his father had done him shame.

<b>35 </b>¶ And it came to pass in the morning, that Jonathan went out into the field at the time appointed with David, and a little lad with him.

<b>36 </b>And he said unto his lad, Run, find out now the arrows which I shoot. <i>And</i> as the lad ran, he shot an arrow beyond him.

<b>37 </b>And when the lad was come to the place of the arrow which Jonathan had shot, Jonathan cried after the lad, and said, <i>Is</i> not the arrow beyond thee?

<b>38 </b>And Jonathan cried after the lad, Make speed, haste, stay not. And Jonathan’s lad gathered up the arrows, and came to his master.

<b>39 </b>But the lad knew not any thing: only Jonathan and David knew the matter.

<b>40 </b>And Jonathan gave his artillery unto his lad, and said unto him, Go, carry <i>them</i> to the city.

<b>41 </b>¶ <i>And</i> as soon as the lad was gone, David arose out of <i>a place</i> toward the south, and fell on his face to the ground, and bowed himself three times: and they kissed one another, and wept one with another, until David exceeded.

<b>42 </b>And Jonathan said to David, Go in peace, forasmuch as we have sworn both of us in the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> be between me and thee, and between my seed and thy seed for ever. And he arose and departed: and Jonathan went into the city.


--------------------

CHAPTER 21

<b>1 </b>Then came David to Nob to Ahimelech the priest: and Ahimelech was afraid at the meeting of David, and said unto him, Why <i>art</i> thou alone, and no man with thee?

<b>2 </b>And David said unto Ahimelech the priest, The king hath commanded me a business, and hath said unto me, Let no man know any thing of the business whereabout I send thee, and what I have commanded thee: and I have appointed <i>my</i> servants to such and such a place.

<b>3 </b>Now therefore what is under thine hand? give <i>me</i> five <i>loaves of</i> bread in mine hand, or what there is present.

<b>4 </b>And the priest answered David, and said, <i>There is</i> no common bread under mine hand, but there is hallowed bread; if the young men have kept themselves at least from women.

<b>5 </b>And David answered the priest, and said unto him, Of a truth women <i>have been</i> kept from us about these three days, since I came out, and the vessels of the young men are holy, and <i>the bread is</i> in a manner common, yea, though it were sanctified this day in the vessel.

<b>6 </b>So the priest gave him hallowed <i>bread:</i> for there was no bread there but the shewbread, that was taken from before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to put hot bread in the day when it was taken away.

<b>7 </b>Now a certain man of the servants of Saul <i>was</i> there that day, detained before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and his name <i>was</i> Doeg, an Edomite, the chiefest of the herdmen that <i>belonged</i> to Saul.

<b>8 </b>¶ And David said unto Ahimelech, And is there not here under thine hand spear or sword? for I have neither brought my sword nor my weapons with me, because the king’s business required haste.

<b>9 </b>And the priest said, The sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom thou slewest in the valley of Elah, behold, it <i>is here</i> wrapped in a cloth behind the ephod: if thou wilt take that, take <i>it:</i> for <i>there is</i> no other save that here. And David said, <i>There is</i> none like that; give it me.

<b>10 </b>¶ And David arose, and fled that day for fear of Saul, and went to Achish the king of Gath.

<b>11 </b>And the servants of Achish said unto him, <i>Is</i> not this David the king of the land? did they not sing one to another of him in dances, saying, Saul hath slain his thousands, and David his ten thousands?

<b>12 </b>And David laid up these words in his heart, and was sore afraid of Achish the king of Gath.

<b>13 </b>And he changed his behaviour before them, and feigned himself mad in their hands, and scrabbled on the doors of the gate, and let his spittle fall down upon his beard.

<b>14 </b>Then said Achish unto his servants, Lo, ye see the man is mad: wherefore <i>then</i> have ye brought him to me?

<b>15 </b>Have I need of mad men, that ye have brought this <i>fellow</i> to play the mad man in my presence? shall this <i>fellow</i> come into my house?


--------------------

CHAPTER 22

<b>1 </b>David therefore departed thence, and escaped to the cave Adullam: and when his brethren and all his father’s house heard <i>it,</i> they went down thither to him.

<b>2 </b>And every one <i>that was</i> in distress, and every one that <i>was</i> in debt, and every one <i>that was</i> discontented, gathered themselves unto him; and he became a captain over them: and there were with him about four hundred men.

<b>3 </b>¶ And David went thence to Mizpeh of Moab: and he said unto the king of Moab, Let my father and my mother, I pray thee, come forth, <i>and be</i> with you, till I know what God will do for me.

<b>4 </b>And he brought them before the king of Moab: and they dwelt with him all the while that David was in the hold.

<b>5 </b>¶ And the prophet Gad said unto David, Abide not in the hold; depart, and get thee into the land of Judah. Then David departed, and came into the forest of Hareth.

<b>6 </b>¶ When Saul heard that David was discovered, and the men that <i>were</i> with him, (now Saul abode in Gibeah under a tree in Ramah, having his spear in his hand, and all his servants <i>were</i> standing about him;)

<b>7 </b>Then Saul said unto his servants that stood about him, Hear now, ye Benjamites; will the son of Jesse give every one of you fields and vineyards, <i>and</i> make you all captains of thousands, and captains of hundreds;

<b>8 </b>That all of you have conspired against me, and <i>there is</i> none that sheweth me that my son hath made a league with the son of Jesse, and <i>there is</i> none of you that is sorry for me, or sheweth unto me that my son hath stirred up my servant against me, to lie in wait, as at this day?

<b>9 </b>¶ Then answered Doeg the Edomite, which was set over the servants of Saul, and said, I saw the son of Jesse coming to Nob, to Ahimelech the son of Ahitub.

<b>10 </b>And he inquired of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> for him, and gave him victuals, and gave him the sword of Goliath the Philistine.

<b>11 </b>Then the king sent to call Ahimelech the priest, the son of Ahitub, and all his father’s house, the priests that <i>were</i> in Nob: and they came all of them to the king.

<b>12 </b>And Saul said, Hear now, thou son of Ahitub. And he answered, Here I <i>am,</i> my lord.

<b>13 </b>And Saul said unto him, Why have ye conspired against me, thou and the son of Jesse, in that thou hast given him bread, and a sword, and hast inquired of God for him, that he should rise against me, to lie in wait, as at this day?

<b>14 </b>Then Ahimelech answered the king, and said, And who <i>is so</i> faithful among all thy servants as David, which is the king’s son in law, and goeth at thy bidding, and is honourable in thine house?

<b>15 </b>Did I then begin to inquire of God for him? be it far from me: let not the king impute <i>any</i> thing unto his servant, <i>nor</i> to all the house of my father: for thy servant knew nothing of all this, less or more.

<b>16 </b>And the king said, Thou shalt surely die, Ahimelech, thou, and all thy father’s house.

<b>17 </b>¶ And the king said unto the footmen that stood about him, Turn, and slay the priests of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; because their hand also <i>is</i> with David, and because they knew when he fled, and did not shew it to me. But the servants of the king would not put forth their hand to fall upon the priests of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>18 </b>And the king said to Doeg, Turn thou, and fall upon the priests. And Doeg the Edomite turned, and he fell upon the priests, and slew on that day fourscore and five persons that did wear a linen ephod.

<b>19 </b>And Nob, the city of the priests, smote he with the edge of the sword, both men and women, children and sucklings, and oxen, and asses, and sheep, with the edge of the sword.

<b>20 </b>¶ And one of the sons of Ahimelech the son of Ahitub, named Abiathar, escaped, and fled after David.

<b>21 </b>And Abiathar shewed David that Saul had slain the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s priests.

<b>22 </b>And David said unto Abiathar, I knew <i>it</i> that day, when Doeg the Edomite <i>was</i> there, that he would surely tell Saul: I have occasioned <i>the death</i> of all the persons of thy father’s house.

<b>23 </b>Abide thou with me, fear not: for he that seeketh my life seeketh thy life: but with me thou <i>shalt be</i> in safeguard.


--------------------

CHAPTER 23

<b>1 </b>Then they told David, saying, Behold, the Philistines fight against Keilah, and they rob the threshingfloors.

<b>2 </b>Therefore David inquired of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying, Shall I go and smite these Philistines? And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto David, Go, and smite the Philistines, and save Keilah.

<b>3 </b>And David’s men said unto him, Behold, we be afraid here in Judah: how much more then if we come to Keilah against the armies of the Philistines?

<b>4 </b>Then David inquired of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> yet again. And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> answered him and said, Arise, go down to Keilah; for I will deliver the Philistines into thine hand.

<b>5 </b>So David and his men went to Keilah, and fought with the Philistines, and brought away their cattle, and smote them with a great slaughter. So David saved the inhabitants of Keilah.

<b>6 </b>And it came to pass, when Abiathar the son of Ahimelech fled to David to Keilah, <i>that</i> he came down <i>with</i> an ephod in his hand.

<b>7 </b>¶ And it was told Saul that David was come to Keilah. And Saul said, God hath delivered him into mine hand; for he is shut in, by entering into a town that hath gates and bars.

<b>8 </b>And Saul called all the people together to war, to go down to Keilah, to besiege David and his men.

<b>9 </b>¶ And David knew that Saul secretly practised mischief against him; and he said to Abiathar the priest, Bring hither the ephod.

<b>10 </b>Then said David, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, thy servant hath certainly heard that Saul seeketh to come to Keilah, to destroy the city for my sake.

<b>11 </b>Will the men of Keilah deliver me up into his hand? will Saul come down, as thy servant hath heard? O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, I beseech thee, tell thy servant. And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said, He will come down.

<b>12 </b>Then said David, Will the men of Keilah deliver me and my men into the hand of Saul? And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said, They will deliver <i>thee</i> up.

<b>13 </b>¶ Then David and his men, <i>which were</i> about six hundred, arose and departed out of Keilah, and went whithersoever they could go. And it was told Saul that David was escaped from Keilah; and he forbare to go forth.

<b>14 </b>And David abode in the wilderness in strong holds, and remained in a mountain in the wilderness of Ziph. And Saul sought him every day, but God delivered him not into his hand.

<b>15 </b>And David saw that Saul was come out to seek his life: and David <i>was</i> in the wilderness of Ziph in a wood.

<b>16 </b>¶ And Jonathan Saul’s son arose, and went to David into the wood, and strengthened his hand in God.

<b>17 </b>And he said unto him, Fear not: for the hand of Saul my father shall not find thee; and thou shalt be king over Israel, and I shall be next unto thee; and that also Saul my father knoweth.

<b>18 </b>And they two made a covenant before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and David abode in the wood, and Jonathan went to his house.

<b>19 </b>¶ Then came up the Ziphites to Saul to Gibeah, saying, Doth not David hide himself with us in strong holds in the wood, in the hill of Hachilah, which <i>is</i> on the south of Jeshimon?

<b>20 </b>Now therefore, O king, come down according to all the desire of thy soul to come down; and our part <i>shall be</i> to deliver him into the king’s hand.

<b>21 </b>And Saul said, Blessed <i>be</i> ye of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for ye have compassion on me.

<b>22 </b>Go, I pray you, prepare yet, and know and see his place where his haunt is, <i>and</i> who hath seen him there: for it is told me <i>that</i> he dealeth very subtilly.

<b>23 </b>See therefore, and take knowledge of all the lurking places where he hideth himself, and come ye again to me with the certainty, and I will go with you: and it shall come to pass, if he be in the land, that I will search him out throughout all the thousands of Judah.

<b>24 </b>And they arose, and went to Ziph before Saul: but David and his men <i>were</i> in the wilderness of Maon, in the plain on the south of Jeshimon.

<b>25 </b>Saul also and his men went to seek <i>him.</i> And they told David: wherefore he came down into a rock, and abode in the wilderness of Maon. And when Saul heard <i>that,</i> he pursued after David in the wilderness of Maon.

<b>26 </b>And Saul went on this side of the mountain, and David and his men on that side of the mountain: and David made haste to get away for fear of Saul; for Saul and his men compassed David and his men round about to take them.

<b>27 </b>¶ But there came a messenger unto Saul, saying, Haste thee, and come; for the Philistines have invaded the land.

<b>28 </b>Wherefore Saul returned from pursuing after David, and went against the Philistines: therefore they called that place Sela-hammahlekoth.

<b>29 </b>¶ And David went up from thence, and dwelt in strong holds at En-gedi.


--------------------

CHAPTER 24

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass, when Saul was returned from following the Philistines, that it was told him, saying, Behold, David <i>is</i> in the wilderness of En-gedi.

<b>2 </b>Then Saul took three thousand chosen men out of all Israel, and went to seek David and his men upon the rocks of the wild goats.

<b>3 </b>And he came to the sheepcotes by the way, where <i>was</i> a cave; and Saul went in to cover his feet: and David and his men remained in the sides of the cave.

<b>4 </b>And the men of David said unto him, Behold the day of which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto thee, Behold, I will deliver thine enemy into thine hand, that thou mayest do to him as it shall seem good unto thee. Then David arose, and cut off the skirt of Saul’s robe privily.

<b>5 </b>And it came to pass afterward, that David’s heart smote him, because he had cut off Saul’s skirt.

<b>6 </b>And he said unto his men, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> forbid that I should do this thing unto my master, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s anointed, to stretch forth mine hand against him, seeing he <i>is</i> the anointed of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>7 </b>So David stayed his servants with these words, and suffered them not to rise against Saul. But Saul rose up out of the cave, and went on <i>his</i> way.

<b>8 </b>David also arose afterward, and went out of the cave, and cried after Saul, saying, My lord the king. And when Saul looked behind him, David stooped with his face to the earth, and bowed himself.

<b>9 </b>¶ And David said to Saul, Wherefore hearest thou men’s words, saying, Behold, David seeketh thy hurt?

<b>10 </b>Behold, this day thine eyes have seen how that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had delivered thee to day into mine hand in the cave: and <i>some</i> bade <i>me</i> kill thee: but <i>mine eye</i> spared thee; and I said, I will not put forth mine hand against my lord; for he <i>is</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s anointed.

<b>11 </b>Moreover, my father, see, yea, see the skirt of thy robe in my hand: for in that I cut off the skirt of thy robe, and killed thee not, know thou and see that <i>there is</i> neither evil nor transgression in mine hand, and I have not sinned against thee; yet thou huntest my soul to take it.

<b>12 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> judge between me and thee, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> avenge me of thee: but mine hand shall not be upon thee.

<b>13 </b>As saith the proverb of the ancients, Wickedness proceedeth from the wicked: but mine hand shall not be upon thee.

<b>14 </b>After whom is the king of Israel come out? after whom dost thou pursue? after a dead dog, after a flea.

<b>15 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> therefore be judge, and judge between me and thee, and see, and plead my cause, and deliver me out of thine hand.

<b>16 </b>¶ And it came to pass, when David had made an end of speaking these words unto Saul, that Saul said, <i>Is</i> this thy voice, my son David? And Saul lifted up his voice, and wept.

<b>17 </b>And he said to David, Thou <i>art</i> more righteous than I: for thou hast rewarded me good, whereas I have rewarded thee evil.

<b>18 </b>And thou hast shewed this day how that thou hast dealt well with me: forasmuch as when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had delivered me into thine hand, thou killedst me not.

<b>19 </b>For if a man find his enemy, will he let him go well away? wherefore the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> reward thee good for that thou hast done unto me this day.

<b>20 </b>And now, behold, I know well that thou shalt surely be king, and that the kingdom of Israel shall be established in thine hand.

<b>21 </b>Swear now therefore unto me by the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that thou wilt not cut off my seed after me, and that thou wilt not destroy my name out of my father’s house.

<b>22 </b>And David sware unto Saul. And Saul went home; but David and his men gat them up unto the hold.


--------------------

CHAPTER 25

<b>1 </b>And Samuel died; and all the Israelites were gathered together, and lamented him, and buried him in his house at Ramah. And David arose, and went down to the wilderness of Paran.

<b>2 </b>And <i>there was</i> a man in Maon, whose possessions <i>were</i> in Carmel; and the man <i>was</i> very great, and he had three thousand sheep, and a thousand goats: and he was shearing his sheep in Carmel.

<b>3 </b>Now the name of the man <i>was</i> Nabal; and the name of his wife Abigail: and <i>she was</i> a woman of good understanding, and of a beautiful countenance: but the man <i>was</i> churlish and evil in his doings; and he <i>was</i> of the house of Caleb.

<b>4 </b>¶ And David heard in the wilderness that Nabal did shear his sheep.

<b>5 </b>And David sent out ten young men, and David said unto the young men, Get you up to Carmel, and go to Nabal, and greet him in my name:

<b>6 </b>And thus shall ye say to him that liveth <i>in prosperity,</i> Peace <i>be</i> both to thee, and peace <i>be</i> to thine house, and peace <i>be</i> unto all that thou hast.

<b>7 </b>And now I have heard that thou hast shearers: now thy shepherds which were with us, we hurt them not, neither was there ought missing unto them, all the while they were in Carmel.

<b>8 </b>Ask thy young men, and they will shew thee. Wherefore let the young men find favour in thine eyes: for we come in a good day: give, I pray thee, whatsoever cometh to thine hand unto thy servants, and to thy son David.

<b>9 </b>And when David’s young men came, they spake to Nabal according to all those words in the name of David, and ceased.

<b>10 </b>¶ And Nabal answered David’s servants, and said, Who <i>is</i> David? and who <i>is</i> the son of Jesse? there be many servants now a days that break away every man from his master.

<b>11 </b>Shall I then take my bread, and my water, and my flesh that I have killed for my shearers, and give <i>it</i> unto men, whom I know not whence they <i>be?</i>

<b>12 </b>So David’s young men turned their way, and went again, and came and told him all those sayings.

<b>13 </b>And David said unto his men, Gird ye on every man his sword. And they girded on every man his sword; and David also girded on his sword: and there went up after David about four hundred men; and two hundred abode by the stuff.

<b>14 </b>¶ But one of the young men told Abigail, Nabal’s wife, saying, Behold, David sent messengers out of the wilderness to salute our master; and he railed on them.

<b>15 </b>But the men <i>were</i> very good unto us, and we were not hurt, neither missed we any thing, as long as we were conversant with them, when we were in the fields:

<b>16 </b>They were a wall unto us both by night and day, all the while we were with them keeping the sheep.

<b>17 </b>Now therefore know and consider what thou wilt do; for evil is determined against our master, and against all his household: for he <i>is such</i> a son of Belial, that <i>a man</i> cannot speak to him.

<b>18 </b>¶ Then Abigail made haste, and took two hundred loaves, and two bottles of wine, and five sheep ready dressed, and five measures of parched <i>corn,</i> and an hundred clusters of raisins, and two hundred cakes of figs, and laid <i>them</i> on asses.

<b>19 </b>And she said unto her servants, Go on before me; behold, I come after you. But she told not her husband Nabal.

<b>20 </b>And it was <i>so, as</i> she rode on the ass, that she came down by the covert of the hill, and, behold, David and his men came down against her; and she met them.

<b>21 </b>Now David had said, Surely in vain have I kept all that this <i>fellow</i> hath in the wilderness, so that nothing was missed of all that <i>pertained</i> unto him: and he hath requited me evil for good.

<b>22 </b>So and more also do God unto the enemies of David, if I leave of all that <i>pertain</i> to him by the morning light any that pisseth against the wall.

<b>23 </b>And when Abigail saw David, she hasted, and lighted off the ass, and fell before David on her face, and bowed herself to the ground,

<b>24 </b>And fell at his feet, and said, Upon me, my lord, <i>upon</i> me <i>let this</i> iniquity <i>be:</i> and let thine handmaid, I pray thee, speak in thine audience, and hear the words of thine handmaid.

<b>25 </b>Let not my lord, I pray thee, regard this man of Belial, <i>even</i> Nabal: for as his name <i>is,</i> so <i>is</i> he; Nabal <i>is</i> his name, and folly <i>is</i> with him: but I thine handmaid saw not the young men of my lord, whom thou didst send.

<b>26 </b>Now therefore, my lord, <i>as</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, and <i>as</i> thy soul liveth, seeing the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath withholden thee from coming to <i>shed</i> blood, and from avenging thyself with thine own hand, now let thine enemies, and they that seek evil to my lord, be as Nabal.

<b>27 </b>And now this blessing which thine handmaid hath brought unto my lord, let it even be given unto the young men that follow my lord.

<b>28 </b>I pray thee, forgive the trespass of thine handmaid: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will certainly make my lord a sure house; because my lord fighteth the battles of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and evil hath not been found in thee <i>all</i> thy days.

<b>29 </b>Yet a man is risen to pursue thee, and to seek thy soul: but the soul of my lord shall be bound in the bundle of life with the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God; and the souls of thine enemies, them shall he sling out, <i>as out</i> of the middle of a sling.

<b>30 </b>And it shall come to pass, when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall have done to my lord according to all the good that he hath spoken concerning thee, and shall have appointed thee ruler over Israel;

<b>31 </b>That this shall be no grief unto thee, nor offence of heart unto my lord, either that thou hast shed blood causeless, or that my lord hath avenged himself: but when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall have dealt well with my lord, then remember thine handmaid.

<b>32 </b>¶ And David said to Abigail, Blessed <i>be</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, which sent thee this day to meet me:

<b>33 </b>And blessed <i>be</i> thy advice, and blessed <i>be</i> thou, which hast kept me this day from coming to <i>shed</i> blood, and from avenging myself with mine own hand.

<b>34 </b>For in very deed, <i>as</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel liveth, which hath kept me back from hurting thee, except thou hadst hasted and come to meet me, surely there had not been left unto Nabal by the morning light any that pisseth against the wall.

<b>35 </b>So David received of her hand <i>that</i> which she had brought him, and said unto her, Go up in peace to thine house; see, I have hearkened to thy voice, and have accepted thy person.

<b>36 </b>¶ And Abigail came to Nabal; and, behold, he held a feast in his house, like the feast of a king; and Nabal’s heart <i>was</i> merry within him, for he <i>was</i> very drunken: wherefore she told him nothing, less or more, until the morning light.

<b>37 </b>But it came to pass in the morning, when the wine was gone out of Nabal, and his wife had told him these things, that his heart died within him, and he became <i>as</i> a stone.

<b>38 </b>And it came to pass about ten days <i>after,</i> that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> smote Nabal, that he died.

<b>39 </b>¶ And when David heard that Nabal was dead, he said, Blessed <i>be</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that hath pleaded the cause of my reproach from the hand of Nabal, and hath kept his servant from evil: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath returned the wickedness of Nabal upon his own head. And David sent and communed with Abigail, to take her to him to wife.

<b>40 </b>And when the servants of David were come to Abigail to Carmel, they spake unto her, saying, David sent us unto thee, to take thee to him to wife.

<b>41 </b>And she arose, and bowed herself on <i>her</i> face to the earth, and said, Behold, <i>let</i> thine handmaid <i>be</i> a servant to wash the feet of the servants of my lord.

<b>42 </b>And Abigail hasted, and arose, and rode upon an ass, with five damsels of hers that went after her; and she went after the messengers of David, and became his wife.

<b>43 </b>David also took Ahinoam of Jezreel; and they were also both of them his wives.

<b>44 </b>¶ But Saul had given Michal his daughter, David’s wife, to Phalti the son of Laish, which <i>was</i> of Gallim.


--------------------

CHAPTER 26

<b>1 </b>And the Ziphites came unto Saul to Gibeah, saying, Doth not David hide himself in the hill of Hachilah, <i>which is</i> before Jeshimon?

<b>2 </b>Then Saul arose, and went down to the wilderness of Ziph, having three thousand chosen men of Israel with him, to seek David in the wilderness of Ziph.

<b>3 </b>And Saul pitched in the hill of Hachilah, which <i>is</i> before Jeshimon, by the way. But David abode in the wilderness, and he saw that Saul came after him into the wilderness.

<b>4 </b>David therefore sent out spies, and understood that Saul was come in very deed.

<b>5 </b>¶ And David arose, and came to the place where Saul had pitched: and David beheld the place where Saul lay, and Abner the son of Ner, the captain of his host: and Saul lay in the trench, and the people pitched round about him.

<b>6 </b>Then answered David and said to Ahimelech the Hittite, and to Abishai the son of Zeruiah, brother to Joab, saying, Who will go down with me to Saul to the camp? And Abishai said, I will go down with thee.

<b>7 </b>So David and Abishai came to the people by night: and, behold, Saul lay sleeping within the trench, and his spear stuck in the ground at his bolster: but Abner and the people lay round about him.

<b>8 </b>Then said Abishai to David, God hath delivered thine enemy into thine hand this day: now therefore let me smite him, I pray thee, with the spear even to the earth at once, and I will not <i>smite</i> him the second time.

<b>9 </b>And David said to Abishai, Destroy him not: for who can stretch forth his hand against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s anointed, and be guiltless?

<b>10 </b>David said furthermore, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall smite him; or his day shall come to die; or he shall descend into battle, and perish.

<b>11 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> forbid that I should stretch forth mine hand against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s anointed: but, I pray thee, take thou now the spear that <i>is</i> at his bolster, and the cruse of water, and let us go.
