<b>12 </b>So David took the spear and the cruse of water from Saul’s bolster; and they gat them away, and no man saw <i>it,</i> nor knew <i>it,</i> neither awaked: for they <i>were</i> all asleep; because a deep sleep from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was fallen upon them.

<b>13 </b>¶ Then David went over to the other side, and stood on the top of an hill afar off; a great space <i>being</i> between them:

<b>14 </b>And David cried to the people, and to Abner the son of Ner, saying, Answerest thou not, Abner? Then Abner answered and said, Who <i>art</i> thou <i>that</i> criest to the king?

<b>15 </b>And David said to Abner, <i>Art</i> not thou a <i>valiant</i> man? and who <i>is</i> like to thee in Israel? wherefore then hast thou not kept thy lord the king? for there came one of the people in to destroy the king thy lord.

<b>16 </b>This thing <i>is</i> not good that thou hast done. <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, ye <i>are</i> worthy to die, because ye have not kept your master, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s anointed. And now see where the king’s spear <i>is,</i> and the cruse of water that <i>was</i> at his bolster.

<b>17 </b>And Saul knew David’s voice, and said, <i>Is</i> this thy voice, my son David? And David said, <i>It is</i> my voice, my lord, O king.

<b>18 </b>And he said, Wherefore doth my lord thus pursue after his servant? for what have I done? or what evil <i>is</i> in mine hand?

<b>19 </b>Now therefore, I pray thee, let my lord the king hear the words of his servant. If the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> have stirred thee up against me, let him accept an offering: but if <i>they be</i> the children of men, cursed <i>be</i> they before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for they have driven me out this day from abiding in the inheritance of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying, Go, serve other gods.

<b>20 </b>Now therefore, let not my blood fall to the earth before the face of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for the king of Israel is come out to seek a flea, as when one doth hunt a partridge in the mountains.

<b>21 </b>¶ Then said Saul, I have sinned: return, my son David: for I will no more do thee harm, because my soul was precious in thine eyes this day: behold, I have played the fool, and have erred exceedingly.

<b>22 </b>And David answered and said, Behold the king’s spear! and let one of the young men come over and fetch it.

<b>23 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> render to every man his righteousness and his faithfulness: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> delivered thee into <i>my</i> hand to day, but I would not stretch forth mine hand against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s anointed.

<b>24 </b>And, behold, as thy life was much set by this day in mine eyes, so let my life be much set by in the eyes of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and let him deliver me out of all tribulation.

<b>25 </b>Then Saul said to David, Blessed <i>be</i> thou, my son David: thou shalt both do great <i>things,</i> and also shalt still prevail. So David went on his way, and Saul returned to his place.


--------------------

CHAPTER 27

<b>1 </b>And David said in his heart, I shall now perish one day by the hand of Saul: <i>there is</i> nothing better for me than that I should speedily escape into the land of the Philistines; and Saul shall despair of me, to seek me any more in any coast of Israel: so shall I escape out of his hand.

<b>2 </b>And David arose, and he passed over with the six hundred men that <i>were</i> with him unto Achish, the son of Maoch, king of Gath.

<b>3 </b>And David dwelt with Achish at Gath, he and his men, every man with his household, <i>even</i> David with his two wives, Ahinoam the Jezreelitess, and Abigail the Carmelitess, Nabal’s wife.

<b>4 </b>And it was told Saul that David was fled to Gath: and he sought no more again for him.

<b>5 </b>¶ And David said unto Achish, If I have now found grace in thine eyes, let them give me a place in some town in the country, that I may dwell there: for why should thy servant dwell in the royal city with thee?

<b>6 </b>Then Achish gave him Ziklag that day: wherefore Ziklag pertaineth unto the kings of Judah unto this day.

<b>7 </b>And the time that David dwelt in the country of the Philistines was a full year and four months.

<b>8 </b>¶ And David and his men went up, and invaded the Geshurites, and the Gezrites, and the Amalekites: for those <i>nations were</i> of old the inhabitants of the land, as thou goest to Shur, even unto the land of Egypt.

<b>9 </b>And David smote the land, and left neither man nor woman alive, and took away the sheep, and the oxen, and the asses, and the camels, and the apparel, and returned, and came to Achish.

<b>10 </b>And Achish said, Whither have ye made a road to day? And David said, Against the south of Judah, and against the south of the Jerahmeelites, and against the south of the Kenites.

<b>11 </b>And David saved neither man nor woman alive, to bring <i>tidings</i> to Gath, saying, Lest they should tell on us, saying, So did David, and so <i>will be</i> his manner all the while he dwelleth in the country of the Philistines.

<b>12 </b>And Achish believed David, saying, He hath made his people Israel utterly to abhor him; therefore he shall be my servant for ever.


--------------------

CHAPTER 28

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass in those days, that the Philistines gathered their armies together for warfare, to fight with Israel. And Achish said unto David, Know thou assuredly, that thou shalt go out with me to battle, thou and thy men.

<b>2 </b>And David said to Achish, Surely thou shalt know what thy servant can do. And Achish said to David, Therefore will I make thee keeper of mine head for ever.

<b>3 </b>¶ Now Samuel was dead, and all Israel had lamented him, and buried him in Ramah, even in his own city. And Saul had put away those that had familiar spirits, and the wizards, out of the land.

<b>4 </b>And the Philistines gathered themselves together, and came and pitched in Shunem: and Saul gathered all Israel together, and they pitched in Gilboa.

<b>5 </b>And when Saul saw the host of the Philistines, he was afraid, and his heart greatly trembled.

<b>6 </b>And when Saul inquired of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> answered him not, neither by dreams, nor by Urim, nor by prophets.

<b>7 </b>¶ Then said Saul unto his servants, Seek me a woman that hath a familiar spirit, that I may go to her, and inquire of her. And his servants said to him, Behold, <i>there is</i> a woman that hath a familiar spirit at En-dor.

<b>8 </b>And Saul disguised himself, and put on other raiment, and he went, and two men with him, and they came to the woman by night: and he said, I pray thee, divine unto me by the familiar spirit, and bring me <i>him</i> up, whom I shall name unto thee.

<b>9 </b>And the woman said unto him, Behold, thou knowest what Saul hath done, how he hath cut off those that have familiar spirits, and the wizards, out of the land: wherefore then layest thou a snare for my life, to cause me to die?

<b>10 </b>And Saul sware to her by the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, there shall no punishment happen to thee for this thing.

<b>11 </b>Then said the woman, Whom shall I bring up unto thee? And he said, Bring me up Samuel.

<b>12 </b>And when the woman saw Samuel, she cried with a loud voice: and the woman spake to Saul, saying, Why hast thou deceived me? for thou <i>art</i> Saul.

<b>13 </b>And the king said unto her, Be not afraid: for what sawest thou? And the woman said unto Saul, I saw gods ascending out of the earth.

<b>14 </b>And he said unto her, What form <i>is</i> he of? And she said, An old man cometh up; and he <i>is</i> covered with a mantle. And Saul perceived that it <i>was</i> Samuel, and he stooped with <i>his</i> face to the ground, and bowed himself.

<b>15 </b>¶ And Samuel said to Saul, Why hast thou disquieted me, to bring me up? And Saul answered, I am sore distressed; for the Philistines make war against me, and God is departed from me, and answereth me no more, neither by prophets, nor by dreams: therefore I have called thee, that thou mayest make known unto me what I shall do.

<b>16 </b>Then said Samuel, Wherefore then dost thou ask of me, seeing the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> is departed from thee, and is become thine enemy?

<b>17 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath done to him, as he spake by me: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath rent the kingdom out of thine hand, and given it to thy neighbour, <i>even</i> to David:

<b>18 </b>Because thou obeyedst not the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, nor executedst his fierce wrath upon Amalek, therefore hath the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> done this thing unto thee this day.

<b>19 </b>Moreover the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will also deliver Israel with thee into the hand of the Philistines: and to morrow <i>shalt</i> thou and thy sons <i>be</i> with me: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> also shall deliver the host of Israel into the hand of the Philistines.

<b>20 </b>Then Saul fell straightway all along on the earth, and was sore afraid, because of the words of Samuel: and there was no strength in him; for he had eaten no bread all the day, nor all the night.

<b>21 </b>¶ And the woman came unto Saul, and saw that he was sore troubled, and said unto him, Behold, thine handmaid hath obeyed thy voice, and I have put my life in my hand, and have hearkened unto thy words which thou spakest unto me.

<b>22 </b>Now therefore, I pray thee, hearken thou also unto the voice of thine handmaid, and let me set a morsel of bread before thee; and eat, that thou mayest have strength, when thou goest on thy way.

<b>23 </b>But he refused, and said, I will not eat. But his servants, together with the woman, compelled him; and he hearkened unto their voice. So he arose from the earth, and sat upon the bed.

<b>24 </b>And the woman had a fat calf in the house; and she hasted, and killed it, and took flour, and kneaded <i>it,</i> and did bake unleavened bread thereof:

<b>25 </b>And she brought <i>it</i> before Saul, and before his servants; and they did eat. Then they rose up, and went away that night.


--------------------

CHAPTER 29

<b>1 </b>Now the Philistines gathered together all their armies to Aphek: and the Israelites pitched by a fountain which <i>is</i> in Jezreel.

<b>2 </b>And the lords of the Philistines passed on by hundreds, and by thousands: but David and his men passed on in the rearward with Achish.

<b>3 </b>Then said the princes of the Philistines, What <i>do</i> these Hebrews <i>here?</i> And Achish said unto the princes of the Philistines, <i>Is</i> not this David, the servant of Saul the king of Israel, which hath been with me these days, or these years, and I have found no fault in him since he fell <i>unto me</i> unto this day?

<b>4 </b>And the princes of the Philistines were wroth with him; and the princes of the Philistines said unto him, Make this fellow return, that he may go again to his place which thou hast appointed him, and let him not go down with us to battle, lest in the battle he be an adversary to us: for wherewith should he reconcile himself unto his master? <i>should it</i> not <i>be</i> with the heads of these men?

<b>5 </b><i>Is</i> not this David, of whom they sang one to another in dances, saying, Saul slew his thousands, and David his ten thousands?

<b>6 </b>¶ Then Achish called David, and said unto him, Surely, <i>as</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, thou hast been upright, and thy going out and thy coming in with me in the host <i>is</i> good in my sight: for I have not found evil in thee since the day of thy coming unto me unto this day: nevertheless the lords favour thee not.

<b>7 </b>Wherefore now return, and go in peace, that thou displease not the lords of the Philistines.

<b>8 </b>¶ And David said unto Achish, But what have I done? and what hast thou found in thy servant so long as I have been with thee unto this day, that I may not go fight against the enemies of my lord the king?

<b>9 </b>And Achish answered and said to David, I know that thou <i>art</i> good in my sight, as an angel of God: notwithstanding the princes of the Philistines have said, He shall not go up with us to the battle.

<b>10 </b>Wherefore now rise up early in the morning with thy master’s servants that are come with thee: and as soon as ye be up early in the morning, and have light, depart.

<b>11 </b>So David and his men rose up early to depart in the morning, to return into the land of the Philistines. And the Philistines went up to Jezreel.


--------------------

CHAPTER 30

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass, when David and his men were come to Ziklag on the third day, that the Amalekites had invaded the south, and Ziklag, and smitten Ziklag, and burned it with fire;

<b>2 </b>And had taken the women captives, that <i>were</i> therein: they slew not any, either great or small, but carried <i>them</i> away, and went on their way.

<b>3 </b>¶ So David and his men came to the city, and, behold, <i>it was</i> burned with fire; and their wives, and their sons, and their daughters, were taken captives.

<b>4 </b>Then David and the people that <i>were</i> with him lifted up their voice and wept, until they had no more power to weep.

<b>5 </b>And David’s two wives were taken captives, Ahinoam the Jezreelitess, and Abigail the wife of Nabal the Carmelite.

<b>6 </b>And David was greatly distressed; for the people spake of stoning him, because the soul of all the people was grieved, every man for his sons and for his daughters: but David encouraged himself in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his God.

<b>7 </b>And David said to Abiathar the priest, Ahimelech’s son, I pray thee, bring me hither the ephod. And Abiathar brought thither the ephod to David.

<b>8 </b>And David inquired at the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying, Shall I pursue after this troop? shall I overtake them? And he answered him, Pursue: for thou shalt surely overtake <i>them,</i> and without fail recover <i>all.</i>

<b>9 </b>So David went, he and the six hundred men that <i>were</i> with him, and came to the brook Besor, where those that were left behind stayed.

<b>10 </b>But David pursued, he and four hundred men: for two hundred abode behind, which were so faint that they could not go over the brook Besor.

<b>11 </b>¶ And they found an Egyptian in the field, and brought him to David, and gave him bread, and he did eat; and they made him drink water;

<b>12 </b>And they gave him a piece of a cake of figs, and two clusters of raisins: and when he had eaten, his spirit came again to him: for he had eaten no bread, nor drunk <i>any</i> water, three days and three nights.

<b>13 </b>And David said unto him, To whom <i>belongest</i> thou? and whence <i>art</i> thou? And he said, I <i>am</i> a young man of Egypt, servant to an Amalekite; and my master left me, because three days agone I fell sick.

<b>14 </b>We made an invasion <i>upon</i> the south of the Cherethites, and upon <i>the coast</i> which <i>belongeth</i> to Judah, and upon the south of Caleb; and we burned Ziklag with fire.

<b>15 </b>And David said to him, Canst thou bring me down to this company? And he said, Swear unto me by God, that thou wilt neither kill me, nor deliver me into the hands of my master, and I will bring thee down to this company.

<b>16 </b>¶ And when he had brought him down, behold, <i>they were</i> spread abroad upon all the earth, eating and drinking, and dancing, because of all the great spoil that they had taken out of the land of the Philistines, and out of the land of Judah.

<b>17 </b>And David smote them from the twilight even unto the evening of the next day: and there escaped not a man of them, save four hundred young men, which rode upon camels, and fled.

<b>18 </b>And David recovered all that the Amalekites had carried away: and David rescued his two wives.

<b>19 </b>And there was nothing lacking to them, neither small nor great, neither sons nor daughters, neither spoil, nor any <i>thing</i> that they had taken to them: David recovered all.

<b>20 </b>And David took all the flocks and the herds, <i>which</i> they drave before those <i>other</i> cattle, and said, This <i>is</i> David’s spoil.

<b>21 </b>¶ And David came to the two hundred men, which were so faint that they could not follow David, whom they had made also to abide at the brook Besor: and they went forth to meet David, and to meet the people that <i>were</i> with him: and when David came near to the people, he saluted them.

<b>22 </b>Then answered all the wicked men and <i>men</i> of Belial, of those that went with David, and said, Because they went not with us, we will not give them <i>ought</i> of the spoil that we have recovered, save to every man his wife and his children, that they may lead <i>them</i> away, and depart.

<b>23 </b>Then said David, Ye shall not do so, my brethren, with that which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath given us, who hath preserved us, and delivered the company that came against us into our hand.

<b>24 </b>For who will hearken unto you in this matter? but as his part <i>is</i> that goeth down to the battle, so <i>shall</i> his part <i>be</i> that tarrieth by the stuff: they shall part alike.

<b>25 </b>And it was <i>so</i> from that day forward, that he made it a statute and an ordinance for Israel unto this day.

<b>26 </b>¶ And when David came to Ziklag, he sent of the spoil unto the elders of Judah, <i>even</i> to his friends, saying, Behold a present for you of the spoil of the enemies of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>;

<b>27 </b>To <i>them</i> which <i>were</i> in Beth-el, and to <i>them</i> which <i>were</i> in south Ramoth, and to <i>them</i> which <i>were</i> in Jattir,

<b>28 </b>And to <i>them</i> which <i>were</i> in Aroer, and to <i>them</i> which <i>were</i> in Siphmoth, and to <i>them</i> which <i>were</i> in Eshtemoa,

<b>29 </b>And to <i>them</i> which <i>were</i> in Rachal, and to <i>them</i> which <i>were</i> in the cities of the Jerahmeelites, and to <i>them</i> which <i>were</i> in the cities of the Kenites,

<b>30 </b>And to <i>them</i> which <i>were</i> in Hormah, and to <i>them</i> which <i>were</i> in Chor-ashan, and to <i>them</i> which <i>were</i> in Athach,

<b>31 </b>And to <i>them</i> which <i>were</i> in Hebron, and to all the places where David himself and his men were wont to haunt.


--------------------

CHAPTER 31

<b>1 </b>Now the Philistines fought against Israel: and the men of Israel fled from before the Philistines, and fell down slain in mount Gilboa.

<b>2 </b>And the Philistines followed hard upon Saul and upon his sons; and the Philistines slew Jonathan, and Abinadab, and Malchi-shua, Saul’s sons.

<b>3 </b>And the battle went sore against Saul, and the archers hit him; and he was sore wounded of the archers.

<b>4 </b>Then said Saul unto his armourbearer, Draw thy sword, and thrust me through therewith; lest these uncircumcised come and thrust me through, and abuse me. But his armourbearer would not; for he was sore afraid. Therefore Saul took a sword, and fell upon it.

<b>5 </b>And when his armourbearer saw that Saul was dead, he fell likewise upon his sword, and died with him.

<b>6 </b>So Saul died, and his three sons, and his armourbearer, and all his men, that same day together.

<b>7 </b>¶ And when the men of Israel that <i>were</i> on the other side of the valley, and <i>they</i> that <i>were</i> on the other side Jordan, saw that the men of Israel fled, and that Saul and his sons were dead, they forsook the cities, and fled; and the Philistines came and dwelt in them.

<b>8 </b>And it came to pass on the morrow, when the Philistines came to strip the slain, that they found Saul and his three sons fallen in mount Gilboa.

<b>9 </b>And they cut off his head, and stripped off his armour, and sent into the land of the Philistines round about, to publish <i>it in</i> the house of their idols, and among the people.

<b>10 </b>And they put his armour in the house of Ashtaroth: and they fastened his body to the wall of Beth-shan.

<b>11 </b>¶ And when the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead heard of that which the Philistines had done to Saul;

<b>12 </b>All the valiant men arose, and went all night, and took the body of Saul and the bodies of his sons from the wall of Beth-shan, and came to Jabesh, and burnt them there.

<b>13 </b>And they took their bones, and buried <i>them</i> under a tree at Jabesh, and fasted seven days.


--------------------

<small>The Second Book of </small>Samuel

Otherwise Called <br/>
the Second Book of the Kings

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>Now it came to pass after the death of Saul, when David was returned from the slaughter of the Amalekites, and David had abode two days in Ziklag;

<b>2 </b>It came even to pass on the third day, that, behold, a man came out of the camp from Saul with his clothes rent, and earth upon his head: and <i>so</i> it was, when he came to David, that he fell to the earth, and did obeisance.

<b>3 </b>And David said unto him, From whence comest thou? And he said unto him, Out of the camp of Israel am I escaped.

<b>4 </b>And David said unto him, How went the matter? I pray thee, tell me. And he answered, That the people are fled from the battle, and many of the people also are fallen and dead; and Saul and Jonathan his son are dead also.

<b>5 </b>And David said unto the young man that told him, How knowest thou that Saul and Jonathan his son be dead?

<b>6 </b>And the young man that told him said, As I happened by chance upon mount Gilboa, behold, Saul leaned upon his spear; and, lo, the chariots and horsemen followed hard after him.

<b>7 </b>And when he looked behind him, he saw me, and called unto me. And I answered, Here <i>am</i> I.

<b>8 </b>And he said unto me, Who <i>art</i> thou? And I answered him, I <i>am</i> an Amalekite.

<b>9 </b>He said unto me again, Stand, I pray thee, upon me, and slay me: for anguish is come upon me, because my life <i>is</i> yet whole in me.

<b>10 </b>So I stood upon him, and slew him, because I was sure that he could not live after that he was fallen: and I took the crown that <i>was</i> upon his head, and the bracelet that <i>was</i> on his arm, and have brought them hither unto my lord.

<b>11 </b>Then David took hold on his clothes, and rent them; and likewise all the men that <i>were</i> with him:

<b>12 </b>And they mourned, and wept, and fasted until even, for Saul, and for Jonathan his son, and for the people of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and for the house of Israel; because they were fallen by the sword.

<b>13 </b>¶ And David said unto the young man that told him, Whence <i>art</i> thou? And he answered, I <i>am</i> the son of a stranger, an Amalekite.

<b>14 </b>And David said unto him, How wast thou not afraid to stretch forth thine hand to destroy the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s anointed?

<b>15 </b>And David called one of the young men, and said, Go near, <i>and</i> fall upon him. And he smote him that he died.

<b>16 </b>And David said unto him, Thy blood <i>be</i> upon thy head; for thy mouth hath testified against thee, saying, I have slain the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s anointed.

<b>17 </b>¶ And David lamented with this lamentation over Saul and over Jonathan his son:

<b>18 </b>(Also he bade them teach the children of Judah <i>the use of</i> the bow: behold, <i>it is</i> written in the book of Jasher.)

<b>19 </b>The beauty of Israel is slain upon thy high places: how are the mighty fallen!

<b>20 </b>Tell <i>it</i> not in Gath, publish <i>it</i> not in the streets of Askelon; lest the daughters of the Philistines rejoice, lest the daughters of the uncircumcised triumph.

<b>21 </b>Ye mountains of Gilboa, <i>let there be</i> no dew, neither <i>let there be</i> rain, upon you, nor fields of offerings: for there the shield of the mighty is vilely cast away, the shield of Saul, <i>as though he had</i> not <i>been</i> anointed with oil.

<b>22 </b>From the blood of the slain, from the fat of the mighty, the bow of Jonathan turned not back, and the sword of Saul returned not empty.

<b>23 </b>Saul and Jonathan <i>were</i> lovely and pleasant in their lives, and in their death they were not divided: they were swifter than eagles, they were stronger than lions.

<b>24 </b>Ye daughters of Israel, weep over Saul, who clothed you in scarlet, with <i>other</i> delights, who put on ornaments of gold upon your apparel.

<b>25 </b>How are the mighty fallen in the midst of the battle! O Jonathan, <i>thou wast</i> slain in thine high places.

<b>26 </b>I am distressed for thee, my brother Jonathan: very pleasant hast thou been unto me: thy love to me was wonderful, passing the love of women.

<b>27 </b>How are the mighty fallen, and the weapons of war perished!


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass after this, that David inquired of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying, Shall I go up into any of the cities of Judah? And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto him, Go up. And David said, Whither shall I go up? And he said, Unto Hebron.

<b>2 </b>So David went up thither, and his two wives also, Ahinoam the Jezreelitess, and Abigail Nabal’s wife the Carmelite.

<b>3 </b>And his men that <i>were</i> with him did David bring up, every man with his household: and they dwelt in the cities of Hebron.

<b>4 </b>And the men of Judah came, and there they anointed David king over the house of Judah. And they told David, saying, <i>That</i> the men of Jabesh-gilead <i>were they</i> that buried Saul.

<b>5 </b>¶ And David sent messengers unto the men of Jabesh-gilead, and said unto them, Blessed <i>be</i> ye of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that ye have shewed this kindness unto your lord, <i>even</i> unto Saul, and have buried him.

<b>6 </b>And now the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shew kindness and truth unto you: and I also will requite you this kindness, because ye have done this thing.

<b>7 </b>Therefore now let your hands be strengthened, and be ye valiant: for your master Saul is dead, and also the house of Judah have anointed me king over them.

<b>8 </b>¶ But Abner the son of Ner, captain of Saul’s host, took Ish-bosheth the son of Saul, and brought him over to Mahanaim;

<b>9 </b>And made him king over Gilead, and over the Ashurites, and over Jezreel, and over Ephraim, and over Benjamin, and over all Israel.

<b>10 </b>Ish-bosheth Saul’s son <i>was</i> forty years old when he began to reign over Israel, and reigned two years. But the house of Judah followed David.

<b>11 </b>And the time that David was king in Hebron over the house of Judah was seven years and six months.

<b>12 </b>¶ And Abner the son of Ner, and the servants of Ish-bosheth the son of Saul, went out from Mahanaim to Gibeon.

<b>13 </b>And Joab the son of Zeruiah, and the servants of David, went out, and met together by the pool of Gibeon: and they sat down, the one on the one side of the pool, and the other on the other side of the pool.

<b>14 </b>And Abner said to Joab, Let the young men now arise, and play before us. And Joab said, Let them arise.

<b>15 </b>Then there arose and went over by number twelve of Benjamin, which <i>pertained</i> to Ish-bosheth the son of Saul, and twelve of the servants of David.

<b>16 </b>And they caught every one his fellow by the head, and <i>thrust</i> his sword in his fellow’s side; so they fell down together: wherefore that place was called Helkath-hazzurim, which <i>is</i> in Gibeon.

<b>17 </b>And there was a very sore battle that day; and Abner was beaten, and the men of Israel, before the servants of David.

<b>18 </b>¶ And there were three sons of Zeruiah there, Joab, and Abishai, and Asahel: and Asahel <i>was as</i> light of foot as a wild roe.

<b>19 </b>And Asahel pursued after Abner; and in going he turned not to the right hand nor to the left from following Abner.

<b>20 </b>Then Abner looked behind him, and said, <i>Art</i> thou Asahel? And he answered, I <i>am.</i>

<b>21 </b>And Abner said to him, Turn thee aside to thy right hand or to thy left, and lay thee hold on one of the young men, and take thee his armour. But Asahel would not turn aside from following of him.

<b>22 </b>And Abner said again to Asahel, Turn thee aside from following me: wherefore should I smite thee to the ground? how then should I hold up my face to Joab thy brother?

<b>23 </b>Howbeit he refused to turn aside: wherefore Abner with the hinder end of the spear smote him under the fifth <i>rib,</i> that the spear came out behind him; and he fell down there, and died in the same place: and it came to pass, <i>that</i> as many as came to the place where Asahel fell down and died stood still.

<b>24 </b>Joab also and Abishai pursued after Abner: and the sun went down when they were come to the hill of Ammah, that <i>lieth</i> before Giah by the way of the wilderness of Gibeon.

<b>25 </b>¶ And the children of Benjamin gathered themselves together after Abner, and became one troop, and stood on the top of an hill.

<b>26 </b>Then Abner called to Joab, and said, Shall the sword devour for ever? knowest thou not that it will be bitterness in the latter end? how long shall it be then, ere thou bid the people return from following their brethren?

<b>27 </b>And Joab said, <i>As</i> God liveth, unless thou hadst spoken, surely then in the morning the people had gone up every one from following his brother.

<b>28 </b>So Joab blew a trumpet, and all the people stood still, and pursued after Israel no more, neither fought they any more.

<b>29 </b>And Abner and his men walked all that night through the plain, and passed over Jordan, and went through all Bithron, and they came to Mahanaim.

<b>30 </b>And Joab returned from following Abner: and when he had gathered all the people together, there lacked of David’s servants nineteen men and Asahel.

<b>31 </b>But the servants of David had smitten of Benjamin, and of Abner’s men, <i>so that</i> three hundred and threescore men died.

<b>32 </b>¶ And they took up Asahel, and buried him in the sepulchre of his father, which <i>was in</i> Beth-lehem. And Joab and his men went all night, and they came to Hebron at break of day.


--------------------

CHAPTER 3

<b>1 </b>Now there was long war between the house of Saul and the house of David: but David waxed stronger and stronger, and the house of Saul waxed weaker and weaker.

<b>2 </b>¶ And unto David were sons born in Hebron: and his firstborn was Amnon, of Ahinoam the Jezreelitess;

<b>3 </b>And his second, Chileab, of Abigail the wife of Nabal the Carmelite; and the third, Absalom the son of Maacah the daughter of Talmai king of Geshur;

<b>4 </b>And the fourth, Adonijah the son of Haggith; and the fifth, Shephatiah the son of Abital;

<b>5 </b>And the sixth, Ithream, by Eglah David’s wife. These were born to David in Hebron.

<b>6 </b>¶ And it came to pass, while there was war between the house of Saul and the house of David, that Abner made himself strong for the house of Saul.

<b>7 </b>And Saul had a concubine, whose name <i>was</i> Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah: and <i>Ish-bosheth</i> said to Abner, Wherefore hast thou gone in unto my father’s concubine?

<b>8 </b>Then was Abner very wroth for the words of Ish-bosheth, and said, <i>Am</i> I a dog’s head, which against Judah do shew kindness this day unto the house of Saul thy father, to his brethren, and to his friends, and have not delivered thee into the hand of David, that thou chargest me to day with a fault concerning this woman?

<b>9 </b>So do God to Abner, and more also, except, as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath sworn to David, even so I do to him;

<b>10 </b>To translate the kingdom from the house of Saul, and to set up the throne of David over Israel and over Judah, from Dan even to Beer-sheba.

<b>11 </b>And he could not answer Abner a word again, because he feared him.

<b>12 </b>¶ And Abner sent messengers to David on his behalf, saying, Whose <i>is</i> the land? saying <i>also,</i> Make thy league with me, and, behold, my hand <i>shall be</i> with thee, to bring about all Israel unto thee.

<b>13 </b>¶ And he said, Well; I will make a league with thee: but one thing I require of thee, that is, Thou shalt not see my face, except thou first bring Michal Saul’s daughter, when thou comest to see my face.

<b>14 </b>And David sent messengers to Ish-bosheth Saul’s son, saying, Deliver <i>me</i> my wife Michal, which I espoused to me for an hundred foreskins of the Philistines.

<b>15 </b>And Ish-bosheth sent, and took her from <i>her</i> husband, <i>even</i> from Phaltiel the son of Laish.

<b>16 </b>And her husband went with her along weeping behind her to Bahurim. Then said Abner unto him, Go, return. And he returned.

<b>17 </b>¶ And Abner had communication with the elders of Israel, saying, Ye sought for David in times past <i>to be</i> king over you:

<b>18 </b>Now then do <i>it:</i> for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath spoken of David, saying, By the hand of my servant David I will save my people Israel out of the hand of the Philistines, and out of the hand of all their enemies.

<b>19 </b>And Abner also spake in the ears of Benjamin: and Abner went also to speak in the ears of David in Hebron all that seemed good to Israel, and that seemed good to the whole house of Benjamin.

<b>20 </b>So Abner came to David to Hebron, and twenty men with him. And David made Abner and the men that <i>were</i> with him a feast.

<b>21 </b>And Abner said unto David, I will arise and go, and will gather all Israel unto my lord the king, that they may make a league with thee, and that thou mayest reign over all that thine heart desireth. And David sent Abner away; and he went in peace.

<b>22 </b>¶ And, behold, the servants of David and Joab came from <i>pursuing</i> a troop, and brought in a great spoil with them: but Abner <i>was</i> not with David in Hebron; for he had sent him away, and he was gone in peace.

<b>23 </b>When Joab and all the host that <i>was</i> with him were come, they told Joab, saying, Abner the son of Ner came to the king, and he hath sent him away, and he is gone in peace.

<b>24 </b>Then Joab came to the king, and said, What hast thou done? behold, Abner came unto thee; why <i>is</i> it <i>that</i> thou hast sent him away, and he is quite gone?

<b>25 </b>Thou knowest Abner the son of Ner, that he came to deceive thee, and to know thy going out and thy coming in, and to know all that thou doest.

<b>26 </b>And when Joab was come out from David, he sent messengers after Abner, which brought him again from the well of Sirah: but David knew <i>it</i> not.

<b>27 </b>And when Abner was returned to Hebron, Joab took him aside in the gate to speak with him quietly, and smote him there under the fifth <i>rib,</i> that he died, for the blood of Asahel his brother.

<b>28 </b>¶ And afterward when David heard <i>it,</i> he said, I and my kingdom <i>are</i> guiltless before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> for ever from the blood of Abner the son of Ner:

<b>29 </b>Let it rest on the head of Joab, and on all his father’s house; and let there not fail from the house of Joab one that hath an issue, or that is a leper, or that leaneth on a staff, or that falleth on the sword, or that lacketh bread.

<b>30 </b>So Joab and Abishai his brother slew Abner, because he had slain their brother Asahel at Gibeon in the battle.

<b>31 </b>¶ And David said to Joab, and to all the people that <i>were</i> with him, Rend your clothes, and gird you with sackcloth, and mourn before Abner. And king David <i>himself</i> followed the bier.

<b>32 </b>And they buried Abner in Hebron: and the king lifted up his voice, and wept at the grave of Abner; and all the people wept.

<b>33 </b>And the king lamented over Abner, and said, Died Abner as a fool dieth?

<b>34 </b>Thy hands <i>were</i> not bound, nor thy feet put into fetters: as a man falleth before wicked men, <i>so</i> fellest thou. And all the people wept again over him.

<b>35 </b>And when all the people came to cause David to eat meat while it was yet day, David sware, saying, So do God to me, and more also, if I taste bread, or ought else, till the sun be down.

<b>36 </b>And all the people took notice <i>of it,</i> and it pleased them: as whatsoever the king did pleased all the people.

<b>37 </b>For all the people and all Israel understood that day that it was not of the king to slay Abner the son of Ner.

<b>38 </b>And the king said unto his servants, Know ye not that there is a prince and a great man fallen this day in Israel?

<b>39 </b>And I <i>am</i> this day weak, though anointed king; and these men the sons of Zeruiah <i>be</i> too hard for me: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall reward the doer of evil according to his wickedness.


--------------------

CHAPTER 4

<b>1 </b>And when Saul’s son heard that Abner was dead in Hebron, his hands were feeble, and all the Israelites were troubled.

<b>2 </b>And Saul’s son had two men <i>that were</i> captains of bands: the name of the one <i>was</i> Baanah, and the name of the other Rechab, the sons of Rimmon a Beerothite, of the children of Benjamin: (for Beeroth also was reckoned to Benjamin:

<b>3 </b>And the Beerothites fled to Gittaim, and were sojourners there until this day.)

<b>4 </b>And Jonathan, Saul’s son, had a son <i>that was</i> lame of <i>his</i> feet. He was five years old when the tidings came of Saul and Jonathan out of Jezreel, and his nurse took him up, and fled: and it came to pass, as she made haste to flee, that he fell, and became lame. And his name <i>was</i> Mephibosheth.

<b>5 </b>And the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, Rechab and Baanah, went, and came about the heat of the day to the house of Ish-bosheth, who lay on a bed at noon.

<b>6 </b>And they came thither into the midst of the house, <i>as though</i> they would have fetched wheat; and they smote him under the fifth <i>rib:</i> and Rechab and Baanah his brother escaped.

<b>7 </b>For when they came into the house, he lay on his bed in his bedchamber, and they smote him, and slew him, and beheaded him, and took his head, and gat them away through the plain all night.

<b>8 </b>And they brought the head of Ish-bosheth unto David to Hebron, and said to the king, Behold the head of Ish-bosheth the son of Saul thine enemy, which sought thy life; and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath avenged my lord the king this day of Saul, and of his seed.

<b>9 </b>¶ And David answered Rechab and Baanah his brother, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, and said unto them, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, who hath redeemed my soul out of all adversity,

<b>10 </b>When one told me, saying, Behold, Saul is dead, thinking to have brought good tidings, I took hold of him, and slew him in Ziklag, who <i>thought</i> that I would have given him a reward for his tidings:

<b>11 </b>How much more, when wicked men have slain a righteous person in his own house upon his bed? shall I not therefore now require his blood of your hand, and take you away from the earth?

<b>12 </b>And David commanded his young men, and they slew them, and cut off their hands and their feet, and hanged <i>them</i> up over the pool in Hebron. But they took the head of Ish-bosheth, and buried <i>it</i> in the sepulchre of Abner in Hebron.


--------------------

CHAPTER 5

<b>1 </b>Then came all the tribes of Israel to David unto Hebron, and spake, saying, Behold, we <i>are</i> thy bone and thy flesh.

<b>2 </b>Also in time past, when Saul was king over us, thou wast he that leddest out and broughtest in Israel: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said to thee, Thou shalt feed my people Israel, and thou shalt be a captain over Israel.

<b>3 </b>So all the elders of Israel came to the king to Hebron; and king David made a league with them in Hebron before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and they anointed David king over Israel.

<b>4 </b>¶ David <i>was</i> thirty years old when he began to reign, <i>and</i> he reigned forty years.

<b>5 </b>In Hebron he reigned over Judah seven years and six months: and in Jerusalem he reigned thirty and three years over all Israel and Judah.

<b>6 </b>¶ And the king and his men went to Jerusalem unto the Jebusites, the inhabitants of the land: which spake unto David, saying, Except thou take away the blind and the lame, thou shalt not come in hither: thinking, David cannot come in hither.

<b>7 </b>Nevertheless David took the strong hold of Zion: the same <i>is</i> the city of David.

<b>8 </b>And David said on that day, Whosoever getteth up to the gutter, and smiteth the Jebusites, and the lame and the blind, <i>that are</i> hated of David’s soul, <i>he shall be chief and captain.</i> Wherefore they said, The blind and the lame shall not come into the house.

<b>9 </b>So David dwelt in the fort, and called it the city of David. And David built round about from Millo and inward.

<b>10 </b>And David went on, and grew great, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of hosts <i>was</i> with him.

<b>11 </b>¶ And Hiram king of Tyre sent messengers to David, and cedar trees, and carpenters, and masons: and they built David an house.

<b>12 </b>And David perceived that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had established him king over Israel, and that he had exalted his kingdom for his people Israel’s sake.

<b>13 </b>¶ And David took <i>him</i> more concubines and wives out of Jerusalem, after he was come from Hebron: and there were yet sons and daughters born to David.

<b>14 </b>And these <i>be</i> the names of those that were born unto him in Jerusalem; Shammua, and Shobab, and Nathan, and Solomon,

<b>15 </b>Ibhar also, and Elishua, and Nepheg, and Japhia,

<b>16 </b>And Elishama, and Eliada, and Eliphalet.

<b>17 </b>¶ But when the Philistines heard that they had anointed David king over Israel, all the Philistines came up to seek David; and David heard <i>of it,</i> and went down to the hold.

<b>18 </b>The Philistines also came and spread themselves in the valley of Rephaim.

<b>19 </b>And David inquired of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying, Shall I go up to the Philistines? wilt thou deliver them into mine hand? And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto David, Go up: for I will doubtless deliver the Philistines into thine hand.

<b>20 </b>And David came to Baal-perazim, and David smote them there, and said, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath broken forth upon mine enemies before me, as the breach of waters. Therefore he called the name of that place Baal-perazim.

<b>21 </b>And there they left their images, and David and his men burned them.

<b>22 </b>¶ And the Philistines came up yet again, and spread themselves in the valley of Rephaim.

<b>23 </b>And when David inquired of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, he said, Thou shalt not go up; <i>but</i> fetch a compass behind them, and come upon them over against the mulberry trees.

<b>24 </b>And let it be, when thou hearest the sound of a going in the tops of the mulberry trees, that then thou shalt bestir thyself: for then shall the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> go out before thee, to smite the host of the Philistines.

<b>25 </b>And David did so, as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had commanded him; and smote the Philistines from Geba until thou come to Gazer.


--------------------

CHAPTER 6

<b>1 </b>Again, David gathered together all <i>the</i> chosen <i>men</i> of Israel, thirty thousand.

<b>2 </b>And David arose, and went with all the people that <i>were</i> with him from Baale of Judah, to bring up from thence the ark of God, whose name is called by the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts that dwelleth <i>between</i> the cherubims.

<b>3 </b>And they set the ark of God upon a new cart, and brought it out of the house of Abinadab that <i>was</i> in Gibeah: and Uzzah and Ahio, the sons of Abinadab, drave the new cart.

<b>4 </b>And they brought it out of the house of Abinadab which <i>was</i> at Gibeah, accompanying the ark of God: and Ahio went before the ark.

<b>5 </b>And David and all the house of Israel played before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> on all manner of <i>instruments made of</i> fir wood, even on harps, and on psalteries, and on timbrels, and on cornets, and on cymbals.

<b>6 </b>¶ And when they came to Nachon’s threshingfloor, Uzzah put forth <i>his hand</i> to the ark of God, and took hold of it; for the oxen shook <i>it.</i>

<b>7 </b>And the anger of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was kindled against Uzzah; and God smote him there for <i>his</i> error; and there he died by the ark of God.

<b>8 </b>And David was displeased, because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had made a breach upon Uzzah: and he called the name of the place Perez-uzzah to this day.

<b>9 </b>And David was afraid of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that day, and said, How shall the ark of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> come to me?

<b>10 </b>So David would not remove the ark of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto him into the city of David: but David carried it aside into the house of Obed-edom the Gittite.

<b>11 </b>And the ark of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> continued in the house of Obed-edom the Gittite three months: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> blessed Obed-edom, and all his household.

<b>12 </b>¶ And it was told king David, saying, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath blessed the house of Obed-edom, and all that <i>pertaineth</i> unto him, because of the ark of God. So David went and brought up the ark of God from the house of Obed-edom into the city of David with gladness.

<b>13 </b>And it was <i>so,</i> that when they that bare the ark of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had gone six paces, he sacrificed oxen and fatlings.

<b>14 </b>And David danced before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with all <i>his</i> might; and David <i>was</i> girded with a linen ephod.

<b>15 </b>So David and all the house of Israel brought up the ark of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with shouting, and with the sound of the trumpet.

<b>16 </b>And as the ark of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came into the city of David, Michal Saul’s daughter looked through a window, and saw king David leaping and dancing before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and she despised him in her heart.

<b>17 </b>¶ And they brought in the ark of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and set it in his place, in the midst of the tabernacle that David had pitched for it: and David offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>18 </b>And as soon as David had made an end of offering burnt offerings and peace offerings, he blessed the people in the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts.

<b>19 </b>And he dealt among all the people, <i>even</i> among the whole multitude of Israel, as well to the women as men, to every one a cake of bread, and a good piece <i>of flesh,</i> and a flagon <i>of wine</i><i>.</i> So all the people departed every one to his house.

<b>20 </b>¶ Then David returned to bless his household. And Michal the daughter of Saul came out to meet David, and said, How glorious was the king of Israel to day, who uncovered himself to day in the eyes of the handmaids of his servants, as one of the vain fellows shamelessly uncovereth himself!

<b>21 </b>And David said unto Michal, <i>It was</i> before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which chose me before thy father, and before all his house, to appoint me ruler over the people of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, over Israel: therefore will I play before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>22 </b>And I will yet be more vile than thus, and will be base in mine own sight: and of the maidservants which thou hast spoken of, of them shall I be had in honour.

<b>23 </b>Therefore Michal the daughter of Saul had no child unto the day of her death.


--------------------

CHAPTER 7

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass, when the king sat in his house, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had given him rest round about from all his enemies;

<b>2 </b>That the king said unto Nathan the prophet, See now, I dwell in an house of cedar, but the ark of God dwelleth within curtains.

<b>3 </b>And Nathan said to the king, Go, do all that <i>is</i> in thine heart; for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> with thee.

<b>4 </b>¶ And it came to pass that night, that the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto Nathan, saying,

<b>5 </b>Go and tell my servant David, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Shalt thou build me an house for me to dwell in?

<b>6 </b>Whereas I have not dwelt in <i>any</i> house since the time that I brought up the children of Israel out of Egypt, even to this day, but have walked in a tent and in a tabernacle.

<b>7 </b>In all <i>the places</i> wherein I have walked with all the children of Israel spake I a word with any of the tribes of Israel, whom I commanded to feed my people Israel, saying, Why build ye not me an house of cedar?

<b>8 </b>Now therefore so shalt thou say unto my servant David, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, I took thee from the sheepcote, from following the sheep, to be ruler over my people, over Israel:

<b>9 </b>And I was with thee whithersoever thou wentest, and have cut off all thine enemies out of thy sight, and have made thee a great name, like unto the name of the great <i>men</i> that <i>are</i> in the earth.

<b>10 </b>Moreover I will appoint a place for my people Israel, and will plant them, that they may dwell in a place of their own, and move no more; neither shall the children of wickedness afflict them any more, as beforetime,

<b>11 </b>And as since the time that I commanded judges <i>to be</i> over my people Israel, and have caused thee to rest from all thine enemies. Also the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> telleth thee that he will make thee an house.

<b>12 </b>¶ And when thy days be fulfilled, and thou shalt sleep with thy fathers, I will set up thy seed after thee, which shall proceed out of thy bowels, and I will establish his kingdom.

<b>13 </b>He shall build an house for my name, and I will stablish the throne of his kingdom for ever.

<b>14 </b>I will be his father, and he shall be my son. If he commit iniquity, I will chasten him with the rod of men, and with the stripes of the children of men:

<b>15 </b>But my mercy shall not depart away from him, as I took <i>it</i> from Saul, whom I put away before thee.

<b>16 </b>And thine house and thy kingdom shall be established for ever before thee: thy throne shall be established for ever.

<b>17 </b>According to all these words, and according to all this vision, so did Nathan speak unto David.

<b>18 </b>¶ Then went king David in, and sat before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and he said, Who <i>am</i> I, O Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>? and what <i>is</i> my house, that thou hast brought me hitherto?

<b>19 </b>And this was yet a small thing in thy sight, O Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>; but thou hast spoken also of thy servant’s house for a great while to come. And <i>is</i> this the manner of man, O Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>?

<b>20 </b>And what can David say more unto thee? for thou, Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>, knowest thy servant.

<b>21 </b>For thy word’s sake, and according to thine own heart, hast thou done all these great things, to make thy servant know <i>them.</i>

<b>22 </b>Wherefore thou art great, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God: for <i>there is</i> none like thee, neither <i>is there any</i> God beside thee, according to all that we have heard with our ears.

<b>23 </b>And what one nation in the earth <i>is</i> like thy people, <i>even</i> like Israel, whom God went to redeem for a people to himself, and to make him a name, and to do for you great things and terrible, for thy land, before thy people, which thou redeemedst to thee from Egypt, <i>from</i> the nations and their gods?

<b>24 </b>For thou hast confirmed to thyself thy people Israel <i>to be</i> a people unto thee for ever: and thou, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, art become their God.

<b>25 </b>And now, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God, the word that thou hast spoken concerning thy servant, and concerning his house, establish <i>it</i> for ever, and do as thou hast said.

<b>26 </b>And let thy name be magnified for ever, saying, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts <i>is</i> the God over Israel: and let the house of thy servant David be established before thee.

<b>27 </b>For thou, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, God of Israel, hast revealed to thy servant, saying, I will build thee an house: therefore hath thy servant found in his heart to pray this prayer unto thee.

<b>28 </b>And now, O Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>, thou <i>art</i> that God, and thy words be true, and thou hast promised this goodness unto thy servant:

<b>29 </b>Therefore now let it please thee to bless the house of thy servant, that it may continue for ever before thee: for thou, O Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>, hast spoken <i>it:</i> and with thy blessing let the house of thy servant be blessed for ever.


--------------------

CHAPTER 8

<b>1 </b>And after this it came to pass, that David smote the Philistines, and subdued them: and David took Metheg-ammah out of the hand of the Philistines.

<b>2 </b>And he smote Moab, and measured them with a line, casting them down to the ground; even with two lines measured he to put to death, and with one full line to keep alive. And <i>so</i> the Moabites became David’s servants, <i>and</i> brought gifts.

<b>3 </b>¶ David smote also Hadadezer, the son of Rehob, king of Zobah, as he went to recover his border at the river Euphrates.

<b>4 </b>And David took from him a thousand <i>chariots,</i> and seven hundred horsemen, and twenty thousand footmen: and David houghed all the chariot <i>horses,</i> but reserved of them <i>for</i> an hundred chariots.

<b>5 </b>And when the Syrians of Damascus came to succour Hadadezer king of Zobah, David slew of the Syrians two and twenty thousand men.

<b>6 </b>Then David put garrisons in Syria of Damascus: and the Syrians became servants to David, <i>and</i> brought gifts. And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> preserved David whithersoever he went.

<b>7 </b>And David took the shields of gold that were on the servants of Hadadezer, and brought them to Jerusalem.

<b>8 </b>And from Betah, and from Berothai, cities of Hadadezer, king David took exceeding much brass.

<b>9 </b>¶ When Toi king of Hamath heard that David had smitten all the host of Hadadezer,

<b>10 </b>Then Toi sent Joram his son unto king David, to salute him, and to bless him, because he had fought against Hadadezer, and smitten him: for Hadadezer had wars with Toi. And <i>Joram</i> brought with him vessels of silver, and vessels of gold, and vessels of brass:

<b>11 </b>Which also king David did dedicate unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, with the silver and gold that he had dedicated of all nations which he subdued;

<b>12 </b>Of Syria, and of Moab, and of the children of Ammon, and of the Philistines, and of Amalek, and of the spoil of Hadadezer, son of Rehob, king of Zobah.

<b>13 </b>And David gat <i>him</i> a name when he returned from smiting of the Syrians in the valley of salt, <i>being</i> eighteen thousand <i>men.</i>

<b>14 </b>¶ And he put garrisons in Edom; throughout all Edom put he garrisons, and all they of Edom became David’s servants. And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> preserved David whithersoever he went.

<b>15 </b>And David reigned over all Israel; and David executed judgment and justice unto all his people.

<b>16 </b>And Joab the son of Zeruiah <i>was</i> over the host; and Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud <i>was</i> recorder;

<b>17 </b>And Zadok the son of Ahitub, and Ahimelech the son of Abiathar, <i>were</i> the priests; and Seraiah <i>was</i> the scribe;

<b>18 </b>And Benaiah the son of Jehoiada <i>was over</i> both the Cherethites and the Pelethites; and David’s sons were chief rulers.


--------------------

CHAPTER 9

<b>1 </b>And David said, Is there yet any that is left of the house of Saul, that I may shew him kindness for Jonathan’s sake?

<b>2 </b>And <i>there was</i> of the house of Saul a servant whose name <i>was</i> Ziba. And when they had called him unto David, the king said unto him, <i>Art</i> thou Ziba? And he said, Thy servant <i>is he.</i>

<b>3 </b>And the king said, <i>Is</i> there not yet any of the house of Saul, that I may shew the kindness of God unto him? And Ziba said unto the king, Jonathan hath yet a son, <i>which is</i> lame on <i>his</i> feet.

<b>4 </b>And the king said unto him, Where <i>is</i> he? And Ziba said unto the king, Behold, he <i>is</i> in the house of Machir, the son of Ammiel, in Lo-debar.

<b>5 </b>¶ Then king David sent, and fetched him out of the house of Machir, the son of Ammiel, from Lo-debar.

<b>6 </b>Now when Mephibosheth, the son of Jonathan, the son of Saul, was come unto David, he fell on his face, and did reverence. And David said, Mephibosheth. And he answered, Behold thy servant!

<b>7 </b>¶ And David said unto him, Fear not: for I will surely shew thee kindness for Jonathan thy father’s sake, and will restore thee all the land of Saul thy father; and thou shalt eat bread at my table continually.

<b>8 </b>And he bowed himself, and said, What <i>is</i> thy servant, that thou shouldest look upon such a dead dog as I <i>am?</i>

<b>9 </b>¶ Then the king called to Ziba, Saul’s servant, and said unto him, I have given unto thy master’s son all that pertained to Saul and to all his house.

<b>10 </b>Thou therefore, and thy sons, and thy servants, shall till the land for him, and thou shalt bring in <i>the fruits,</i> that thy master’s son may have food to eat: but Mephibosheth thy master’s son shall eat bread alway at my table. Now Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.

<b>11 </b>Then said Ziba unto the king, According to all that my lord the king hath commanded his servant, so shall thy servant do. As for Mephibosheth, <i>said the king,</i> he shall eat at my table, as one of the king’s sons.

<b>12 </b>And Mephibosheth had a young son, whose name <i>was</i> Micha. And all that dwelt in the house of Ziba <i>were</i> servants unto Mephibosheth.

<b>13 </b>So Mephibosheth dwelt in Jerusalem: for he did eat continually at the king’s table; and was lame on both his feet.


--------------------

CHAPTER 10

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass after this, that the king of the children of Ammon died, and Hanun his son reigned in his stead.

<b>2 </b>Then said David, I will shew kindness unto Hanun the son of Nahash, as his father shewed kindness unto me. And David sent to comfort him by the hand of his servants for his father. And David’s servants came into the land of the children of Ammon.

<b>3 </b>And the princes of the children of Ammon said unto Hanun their lord, Thinkest thou that David doth honour thy father, that he hath sent comforters unto thee? hath not David <i>rather</i> sent his servants unto thee, to search the city, and to spy it out, and to overthrow it?

<b>4 </b>Wherefore Hanun took David’s servants, and shaved off the one half of their beards, and cut off their garments in the middle, <i>even</i> to their buttocks, and sent them away.

<b>5 </b>When they told <i>it</i> unto David, he sent to meet them, because the men were greatly ashamed: and the king said, Tarry at Jericho until your beards be grown, and <i>then</i> return.

<b>6 </b>¶ And when the children of Ammon saw that they stank before David, the children of Ammon sent and hired the Syrians of Beth-rehob, and the Syrians of Zoba, twenty thousand footmen, and of king Maacah a thousand men, and of Ish-tob twelve thousand men.

<b>7 </b>And when David heard of <i>it,</i> he sent Joab, and all the host of the mighty men.

<b>8 </b>And the children of Ammon came out, and put the battle in array at the entering in of the gate: and the Syrians of Zoba, and of Rehob, and Ish-tob, and Maacah, <i>were</i> by themselves in the field.

<b>9 </b>When Joab saw that the front of the battle was against him before and behind, he chose of all the choice <i>men</i> of Israel, and put <i>them</i> in array against the Syrians:

<b>10 </b>And the rest of the people he delivered into the hand of Abishai his brother, that he might put <i>them</i> in array against the children of Ammon.

<b>11 </b>And he said, If the Syrians be too strong for me, then thou shalt help me: but if the children of Ammon be too strong for thee, then I will come and help thee.

<b>12 </b>Be of good courage, and let us play the men for our people, and for the cities of our God: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> do that which seemeth him good.

<b>13 </b>And Joab drew nigh, and the people that <i>were</i> with him, unto the battle against the Syrians: and they fled before him.

<b>14 </b>And when the children of Ammon saw that the Syrians were fled, then fled they also before Abishai, and entered into the city. So Joab returned from the children of Ammon, and came to Jerusalem.

<b>15 </b>¶ And when the Syrians saw that they were smitten before Israel, they gathered themselves together.

<b>16 </b>And Hadarezer sent, and brought out the Syrians that <i>were</i> beyond the river: and they came to Helam; and Shobach the captain of the host of Hadarezer <i>went</i> before them.

<b>17 </b>And when it was told David, he gathered all Israel together, and passed over Jordan, and came to Helam. And the Syrians set themselves in array against David, and fought with him.

<b>18 </b>And the Syrians fled before Israel; and David slew <i>the men of</i> seven hundred chariots of the Syrians, and forty thousand horsemen, and smote Shobach the captain of their host, who died there.

<b>19 </b>And when all the kings <i>that were</i> servants to Hadarezer saw that they were smitten before Israel, they made peace with Israel, and served them. So the Syrians feared to help the children of Ammon any more.


--------------------

CHAPTER 11

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass, after the year was expired, at the time when kings go forth <i>to battle,</i> that David sent Joab, and his servants with him, and all Israel; and they destroyed the children of Ammon, and besieged Rabbah. But David tarried still at Jerusalem.

<b>2 </b>¶ And it came to pass in an eveningtide, that David arose from off his bed, and walked upon the roof of the king’s house: and from the roof he saw a woman washing herself; and the woman <i>was</i> very beautiful to look upon.

<b>3 </b>And David sent and inquired after the woman. And <i>one</i> said, <i>Is</i> not this Bath-sheba, the daughter of Eliam, the wife of Uriah the Hittite?

<b>4 </b>And David sent messengers, and took her; and she came in unto him, and he lay with her; for she was purified from her uncleanness: and she returned unto her house.

<b>5 </b>And the woman conceived, and sent and told David, and said, I <i>am</i> with child.

<b>6 </b>¶ And David sent to Joab, <i>saying,</i> Send me Uriah the Hittite. And Joab sent Uriah to David.

<b>7 </b>And when Uriah was come unto him, David demanded <i>of him</i> how Joab did, and how the people did, and how the war prospered.

<b>8 </b>And David said to Uriah, Go down to thy house, and wash thy feet. And Uriah departed out of the king’s house, and there followed him a mess <i>of meat</i> from the king.

<b>9 </b>But Uriah slept at the door of the king’s house with all the servants of his lord, and went not down to his house.

<b>10 </b>And when they had told David, saying, Uriah went not down unto his house, David said unto Uriah, Camest thou not from <i>thy</i> journey? why <i>then</i> didst thou not go down unto thine house?

<b>11 </b>And Uriah said unto David, The ark, and Israel, and Judah, abide in tents; and my lord Joab, and the servants of my lord, are encamped in the open fields; shall I then go into mine house, to eat and to drink, and to lie with my wife? <i>as</i> thou livest, and <i>as</i> thy soul liveth, I will not do this thing.

<b>12 </b>And David said to Uriah, Tarry here to day also, and to morrow I will let thee depart. So Uriah abode in Jerusalem that day, and the morrow.

<b>13 </b>And when David had called him, he did eat and drink before him; and he made him drunk: and at even he went out to lie on his bed with the servants of his lord, but went not down to his house.

<b>14 </b>¶ And it came to pass in the morning, that David wrote a letter to Joab, and sent <i>it</i> by the hand of Uriah.

<b>15 </b>And he wrote in the letter, saying, Set ye Uriah in the forefront of the hottest battle, and retire ye from him, that he may be smitten, and die.

<b>16 </b>And it came to pass, when Joab observed the city, that he assigned Uriah unto a place where he knew that valiant men <i>were.</i>

<b>17 </b>And the men of the city went out, and fought with Joab: and there fell <i>some</i> of the people of the servants of David; and Uriah the Hittite died also.

<b>18 </b>¶ Then Joab sent and told David all the things concerning the war;

<b>19 </b>And charged the messenger, saying, When thou hast made an end of telling the matters of the war unto the king,

<b>20 </b>And if so be that the king’s wrath arise, and he say unto thee, Wherefore approached ye so nigh unto the city when ye did fight? knew ye not that they would shoot from the wall?

<b>21 </b>Who smote Abimelech the son of Jerubbesheth? did not a woman cast a piece of a millstone upon him from the wall, that he died in Thebez? why went ye nigh the wall? then say thou, Thy servant Uriah the Hittite is dead also.

<b>22 </b>¶ So the messenger went, and came and shewed David all that Joab had sent him for.

<b>23 </b>And the messenger said unto David, Surely the men prevailed against us, and came out unto us into the field, and we were upon them even unto the entering of the gate.

<b>24 </b>And the shooters shot from off the wall upon thy servants; and <i>some</i> of the king’s servants be dead, and thy servant Uriah the Hittite is dead also.

<b>25 </b>Then David said unto the messenger, Thus shalt thou say unto Joab, Let not this thing displease thee, for the sword devoureth one as well as another: make thy battle more strong against the city, and overthrow it: and encourage thou him.

<b>26 </b>¶ And when the wife of Uriah heard that Uriah her husband was dead, she mourned for her husband.

<b>27 </b>And when the mourning was past, David sent and fetched her to his house, and she became his wife, and bare him a son. But the thing that David had done displeased the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

CHAPTER 12

<b>1 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sent Nathan unto David. And he came unto him, and said unto him, There were two men in one city; the one rich, and the other poor.

<b>2 </b>The rich <i>man</i> had exceeding many flocks and herds:

<b>3 </b>But the poor <i>man</i> had nothing, save one little ewe lamb, which he had bought and nourished up: and it grew up together with him, and with his children; it did eat of his own meat, and drank of his own cup, and lay in his bosom, and was unto him as a daughter.

<b>4 </b>And there came a traveller unto the rich man, and he spared to take of his own flock and of his own herd, to dress for the wayfaring man that was come unto him; but took the poor man’s lamb, and dressed it for the man that was come to him.

<b>5 </b>And David’s anger was greatly kindled against the man; and he said to Nathan, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, the man that hath done this <i>thing</i> shall surely die:

<b>6 </b>And he shall restore the lamb fourfold, because he did this thing, and because he had no pity.

<b>7 </b>¶ And Nathan said to David, Thou <i>art</i> the man. Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, I anointed thee king over Israel, and I delivered thee out of the hand of Saul;

<b>8 </b>And I gave thee thy master’s house, and thy master’s wives into thy bosom, and gave thee the house of Israel and of Judah; and if <i>that had been</i> too little, I would moreover have given unto thee such and such things.

<b>9 </b>Wherefore hast thou despised the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to do evil in his sight? thou hast killed Uriah the Hittite with the sword, and hast taken his wife <i>to be</i> thy wife, and hast slain him with the sword of the children of Ammon.

<b>10 </b>Now therefore the sword shall never depart from thine house; because thou hast despised me, and hast taken the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be thy wife.

<b>11 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Behold, I will raise up evil against thee out of thine own house, and I will take thy wives before thine eyes, and give <i>them</i> unto thy neighbour, and he shall lie with thy wives in the sight of this sun.

<b>12 </b>For thou didst <i>it</i> secretly: but I will do this thing before all Israel, and before the sun.

<b>13 </b>And David said unto Nathan, I have sinned against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. And Nathan said unto David, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> also hath put away thy sin; thou shalt not die.

<b>14 </b>Howbeit, because by this deed thou hast given great occasion to the enemies of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> to blaspheme, the child also <i>that is</i> born unto thee shall surely die.

<b>15 </b>¶ And Nathan departed unto his house. And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> struck the child that Uriah’s wife bare unto David, and it was very sick.

<b>16 </b>David therefore besought God for the child; and David fasted, and went in, and lay all night upon the earth.

<b>17 </b>And the elders of his house arose, <i>and went</i> to him, to raise him up from the earth: but he would not, neither did he eat bread with them.

<b>18 </b>And it came to pass on the seventh day, that the child died. And the servants of David feared to tell him that the child was dead: for they said, Behold, while the child was yet alive, we spake unto him, and he would not hearken unto our voice: how will he then vex himself, if we tell him that the child is dead?

<b>19 </b>But when David saw that his servants whispered, David perceived that the child was dead: therefore David said unto his servants, Is the child dead? And they said, He is dead.

<b>20 </b>Then David arose from the earth, and washed, and anointed <i>himself,</i> and changed his apparel, and came into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and worshipped: then he came to his own house; and when he required, they set bread before him, and he did eat.

<b>21 </b>Then said his servants unto him, What thing <i>is</i> this that thou hast done? thou didst fast and weep for the child, <i>while it was</i> alive; but when the child was dead, thou didst rise and eat bread.

<b>22 </b>And he said, While the child was yet alive, I fasted and wept: for I said, Who can tell <i>whether</i> <span class="small-caps">God</span> will be gracious to me, that the child may live?

<b>23 </b>But now he is dead, wherefore should I fast? can I bring him back again? I shall go to him, but he shall not return to me.

<b>24 </b>¶ And David comforted Bath-sheba his wife, and went in unto her, and lay with her: and she bare a son, and he called his name Solomon: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> loved him.

<b>25 </b>And he sent by the hand of Nathan the prophet; and he called his name Jedidiah, because of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>26 </b>¶ And Joab fought against Rabbah of the children of Ammon, and took the royal city.

<b>27 </b>And Joab sent messengers to David, and said, I have fought against Rabbah, and have taken the city of waters.

<b>28 </b>Now therefore gather the rest of the people together, and encamp against the city, and take it: lest I take the city, and it be called after my name.

<b>29 </b>And David gathered all the people together, and went to Rabbah, and fought against it, and took it.

<b>30 </b>And he took their king’s crown from off his head, the weight whereof <i>was</i> a talent of gold with the precious stones: and it was <i>set</i> on David’s head. And he brought forth the spoil of the city in great abundance.

<b>31 </b>And he brought forth the people that <i>were</i> therein, and put <i>them</i> under saws, and under harrows of iron, and under axes of iron, and made them pass through the brickkiln: and thus did he unto all the cities of the children of Ammon. So David and all the people returned unto Jerusalem.


--------------------

CHAPTER 13

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass after this, that Absalom the son of David had a fair sister, whose name <i>was</i> Tamar; and Amnon the son of David loved her.

<b>2 </b>And Amnon was so vexed, that he fell sick for his sister Tamar; for she <i>was</i> a virgin; and Amnon thought it hard for him to do any thing to her.

<b>3 </b>But Amnon had a friend, whose name <i>was</i> Jonadab, the son of Shimeah David’s brother: and Jonadab <i>was</i> a very subtil man.

<b>4 </b>And he said unto him, Why <i>art</i> thou, <i>being</i> the king’s son, lean from day to day? wilt thou not tell me? And Amnon said unto him, I love Tamar, my brother Absalom’s sister.

<b>5 </b>And Jonadab said unto him, Lay thee down on thy bed, and make thyself sick: and when thy father cometh to see thee, say unto him, I pray thee, let my sister Tamar come, and give me meat, and dress the meat in my sight, that I may see <i>it,</i> and eat <i>it</i> at her hand.

<b>6 </b>¶ So Amnon lay down, and made himself sick: and when the king was come to see him, Amnon said unto the king, I pray thee, let Tamar my sister come, and make me a couple of cakes in my sight, that I may eat at her hand.

<b>7 </b>Then David sent home to Tamar, saying, Go now to thy brother Amnon’s house, and dress him meat.

<b>8 </b>So Tamar went to her brother Amnon’s house; and he was laid down. And she took flour, and kneaded <i>it,</i> and made cakes in his sight, and did bake the cakes.

<b>9 </b>And she took a pan, and poured <i>them</i> out before him; but he refused to eat. And Amnon said, Have out all men from me. And they went out every man from him.

<b>10 </b>And Amnon said unto Tamar, Bring the meat into the chamber, that I may eat of thine hand. And Tamar took the cakes which she had made, and brought <i>them</i> into the chamber to Amnon her brother.

<b>11 </b>And when she had brought <i>them</i> unto him to eat, he took hold of her, and said unto her, Come lie with me, my sister.

<b>12 </b>And she answered him, Nay, my brother, do not force me; for no such thing ought to be done in Israel: do not thou this folly.

<b>13 </b>And I, whither shall I cause my shame to go? and as for thee, thou shalt be as one of the fools in Israel. Now therefore, I pray thee, speak unto the king; for he will not withhold me from thee.

<b>14 </b>Howbeit he would not hearken unto her voice: but, being stronger than she, forced her, and lay with her.

<b>15 </b>¶ Then Amnon hated her exceedingly; so that the hatred wherewith he hated her <i>was</i> greater than the love wherewith he had loved her. And Amnon said unto her, Arise, be gone.

<b>16 </b>And she said unto him, <i>There is</i> no cause: this evil in sending me away <i>is</i> greater than the other that thou didst unto me. But he would not hearken unto her.

<b>17 </b>Then he called his servant that ministered unto him, and said, Put now this <i>woman</i> out from me, and bolt the door after her.

<b>18 </b>And <i>she had</i> a garment of divers colours upon her: for with such robes were the king’s daughters <i>that were</i> virgins apparelled. Then his servant brought her out, and bolted the door after her.

<b>19 </b>¶ And Tamar put ashes on her head, and rent her garment of divers colours that <i>was</i> on her, and laid her hand on her head, and went on crying.

<b>20 </b>And Absalom her brother said unto her, Hath Amnon thy brother been with thee? but hold now thy peace, my sister: he <i>is</i> thy brother; regard not this thing. So Tamar remained desolate in her brother Absalom’s house.

<b>21 </b>¶ But when king David heard of all these things, he was very wroth.

<b>22 </b>And Absalom spake unto his brother Amnon neither good nor bad: for Absalom hated Amnon, because he had forced his sister Tamar.

<b>23 </b>¶ And it came to pass after two full years, that Absalom had sheepshearers in Baal-hazor, which <i>is</i> beside Ephraim: and Absalom invited all the king’s sons.

<b>24 </b>And Absalom came to the king, and said, Behold now, thy servant hath sheepshearers; let the king, I beseech thee, and his servants go with thy servant.

<b>25 </b>And the king said to Absalom, Nay, my son, let us not all now go, lest we be chargeable unto thee. And he pressed him: howbeit he would not go, but blessed him.

<b>26 </b>Then said Absalom, If not, I pray thee, let my brother Amnon go with us. And the king said unto him, Why should he go with thee?

<b>27 </b>But Absalom pressed him, that he let Amnon and all the king’s sons go with him.

<b>28 </b>¶ Now Absalom had commanded his servants, saying, Mark ye now when Amnon’s heart is merry with wine, and when I say unto you, Smite Amnon; then kill him, fear not: have not I commanded you? be courageous, and be valiant.

<b>29 </b>And the servants of Absalom did unto Amnon as Absalom had commanded. Then all the king’s sons arose, and every man gat him up upon his mule, and fled.

<b>30 </b>¶ And it came to pass, while they were in the way, that tidings came to David, saying, Absalom hath slain all the king’s sons, and there is not one of them left.

<b>31 </b>Then the king arose, and tare his garments, and lay on the earth; and all his servants stood by with their clothes rent.

<b>32 </b>And Jonadab, the son of Shimeah David’s brother, answered and said, Let not my lord suppose <i>that</i> they have slain all the young men the king’s sons; for Amnon only is dead: for by the appointment of Absalom this hath been determined from the day that he forced his sister Tamar.

<b>33 </b>Now therefore let not my lord the king take the thing to his heart, to think that all the king’s sons are dead: for Amnon only is dead.

<b>34 </b>But Absalom fled. And the young man that kept the watch lifted up his eyes, and looked, and, behold, there came much people by the way of the hill side behind him.

<b>35 </b>And Jonadab said unto the king, Behold, the king’s sons come: as thy servant said, so it is.

<b>36 </b>And it came to pass, as soon as he had made an end of speaking, that, behold, the king’s sons came, and lifted up their voice and wept: and the king also and all his servants wept very sore.
