<b>37 </b>¶ But Absalom fled, and went to Talmai, the son of Ammihud, king of Geshur. And <i>David</i> mourned for his son every day.

<b>38 </b>So Absalom fled, and went to Geshur, and was there three years.

<b>39 </b>And <i>the soul of</i> king David longed to go forth unto Absalom: for he was comforted concerning Amnon, seeing he was dead.


--------------------

CHAPTER 14

<b>1 </b>Now Joab the son of Zeruiah perceived that the king’s heart <i>was</i> toward Absalom.

<b>2 </b>And Joab sent to Tekoah, and fetched thence a wise woman, and said unto her, I pray thee, feign thyself to be a mourner, and put on now mourning apparel, and anoint not thyself with oil, but be as a woman that had a long time mourned for the dead:

<b>3 </b>And come to the king, and speak on this manner unto him. So Joab put the words in her mouth.

<b>4 </b>¶ And when the woman of Tekoah spake to the king, she fell on her face to the ground, and did obeisance, and said, Help, O king.

<b>5 </b>And the king said unto her, What aileth thee? And she answered, I <i>am</i> indeed a widow woman, and mine husband is dead.

<b>6 </b>And thy handmaid had two sons, and they two strove together in the field, and <i>there was</i> none to part them, but the one smote the other, and slew him.

<b>7 </b>And, behold, the whole family is risen against thine handmaid, and they said, Deliver him that smote his brother, that we may kill him, for the life of his brother whom he slew; and we will destroy the heir also: and so they shall quench my coal which is left, and shall not leave to my husband <i>neither</i> name nor remainder upon the earth.

<b>8 </b>And the king said unto the woman, Go to thine house, and I will give charge concerning thee.

<b>9 </b>And the woman of Tekoah said unto the king, My lord, O king, the iniquity <i>be</i> on me, and on my father’s house: and the king and his throne <i>be</i> guiltless.

<b>10 </b>And the king said, Whosoever saith <i>ought</i> unto thee, bring him to me, and he shall not touch thee any more.

<b>11 </b>Then said she, I pray thee, let the king remember the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, that thou wouldest not suffer the revengers of blood to destroy any more, lest they destroy my son. And he said, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, there shall not one hair of thy son fall to the earth.

<b>12 </b>Then the woman said, Let thine handmaid, I pray thee, speak <i>one</i> word unto my lord the king. And he said, Say on.

<b>13 </b>And the woman said, Wherefore then hast thou thought such a thing against the people of God? for the king doth speak this thing as one which is faulty, in that the king doth not fetch home again his banished.

<b>14 </b>For we must needs die, and <i>are</i> as water spilt on the ground, which cannot be gathered up again; neither doth God respect <i>any</i> person: yet doth he devise means, that his banished be not expelled from him.

<b>15 </b>Now therefore that I am come to speak of this thing unto my lord the king, <i>it is</i> because the people have made me afraid: and thy handmaid said, I will now speak unto the king; it may be that the king will perform the request of his handmaid.

<b>16 </b>For the king will hear, to deliver his handmaid out of the hand of the man <i>that would</i> destroy me and my son together out of the inheritance of God.

<b>17 </b>Then thine handmaid said, The word of my lord the king shall now be comfortable: for as an angel of God, so <i>is</i> my lord the king to discern good and bad: therefore the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God will be with thee.

<b>18 </b>Then the king answered and said unto the woman, Hide not from me, I pray thee, the thing that I shall ask thee. And the woman said, Let my lord the king now speak.

<b>19 </b>And the king said, <i>Is not</i> the hand of Joab with thee in all this? And the woman answered and said, <i>As</i> thy soul liveth, my lord the king, none can turn to the right hand or to the left from ought that my lord the king hath spoken: for thy servant Joab, he bade me, and he put all these words in the mouth of thine handmaid:

<b>20 </b>To fetch about this form of speech hath thy servant Joab done this thing: and my lord <i>is</i> wise, according to the wisdom of an angel of God, to know all <i>things</i> that <i>are</i> in the earth.

<b>21 </b>¶ And the king said unto Joab, Behold now, I have done this thing: go therefore, bring the young man Absalom again.

<b>22 </b>And Joab fell to the ground on his face, and bowed himself, and thanked the king: and Joab said, To day thy servant knoweth that I have found grace in thy sight, my lord, O king, in that the king hath fulfilled the request of his servant.

<b>23 </b>So Joab arose and went to Geshur, and brought Absalom to Jerusalem.

<b>24 </b>And the king said, Let him turn to his own house, and let him not see my face. So Absalom returned to his own house, and saw not the king’s face.

<b>25 </b>¶ But in all Israel there was none to be so much praised as Absalom for his beauty: from the sole of his foot even to the crown of his head there was no blemish in him.

<b>26 </b>And when he polled his head, (for it was at every year’s end that he polled <i>it:</i> because <i>the hair</i> was heavy on him, therefore he polled it:) he weighed the hair of his head at two hundred shekels after the king’s weight.

<b>27 </b>And unto Absalom there were born three sons, and one daughter, whose name <i>was</i> Tamar: she was a woman of a fair countenance.

<b>28 </b>¶ So Absalom dwelt two full years in Jerusalem, and saw not the king’s face.

<b>29 </b>Therefore Absalom sent for Joab, to have sent him to the king; but he would not come to him: and when he sent again the second time, he would not come.

<b>30 </b>Therefore he said unto his servants, See, Joab’s field is near mine, and he hath barley there; go and set it on fire. And Absalom’s servants set the field on fire.

<b>31 </b>Then Joab arose, and came to Absalom unto <i>his</i> house, and said unto him, Wherefore have thy servants set my field on fire?

<b>32 </b>And Absalom answered Joab, Behold, I sent unto thee, saying, Come hither, that I may send thee to the king, to say, Wherefore am I come from Geshur? <i>it had been</i> good for me <i>to have been</i> there still: now therefore let me see the king’s face; and if there be <i>any</i> iniquity in me, let him kill me.

<b>33 </b>So Joab came to the king, and told him: and when he had called for Absalom, he came to the king, and bowed himself on his face to the ground before the king: and the king kissed Absalom.


--------------------

CHAPTER 15

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass after this, that Absalom prepared him chariots and horses, and fifty men to run before him.

<b>2 </b>And Absalom rose up early, and stood beside the way of the gate: and it was <i>so,</i> that when any man that had a controversy came to the king for judgment, then Absalom called unto him, and said, Of what city <i>art</i> thou? And he said, Thy servant <i>is</i> of one of the tribes of Israel.

<b>3 </b>And Absalom said unto him, See, thy matters <i>are</i> good and right; but <i>there is</i> no man <i>deputed</i> of the king to hear thee.

<b>4 </b>Absalom said moreover, Oh that I were made judge in the land, that every man which hath any suit or cause might come unto me, and I would do him justice!

<b>5 </b>And it was <i>so,</i> that when any man came nigh <i>to him</i> to do him obeisance, he put forth his hand, and took him, and kissed him.

<b>6 </b>And on this manner did Absalom to all Israel that came to the king for judgment: so Absalom stole the hearts of the men of Israel.

<b>7 </b>¶ And it came to pass after forty years, that Absalom said unto the king, I pray thee, let me go and pay my vow, which I have vowed unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, in Hebron.

<b>8 </b>For thy servant vowed a vow while I abode at Geshur in Syria, saying, If the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall bring me again indeed to Jerusalem, then I will serve the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>9 </b>And the king said unto him, Go in peace. So he arose, and went to Hebron.

<b>10 </b>¶ But Absalom sent spies throughout all the tribes of Israel, saying, As soon as ye hear the sound of the trumpet, then ye shall say, Absalom reigneth in Hebron.

<b>11 </b>And with Absalom went two hundred men out of Jerusalem, <i>that were</i> called; and they went in their simplicity, and they knew not any thing.

<b>12 </b>And Absalom sent for Ahithophel the Gilonite, David’s counsellor, from his city, <i>even</i> from Giloh, while he offered sacrifices. And the conspiracy was strong; for the people increased continually with Absalom.

<b>13 </b>¶ And there came a messenger to David, saying, The hearts of the men of Israel are after Absalom.

<b>14 </b>And David said unto all his servants that <i>were</i> with him at Jerusalem, Arise, and let us flee; for we shall not <i>else</i> escape from Absalom: make speed to depart, lest he overtake us suddenly, and bring evil upon us, and smite the city with the edge of the sword.

<b>15 </b>And the king’s servants said unto the king, Behold, thy servants <i>are ready to do</i> whatsoever my lord the king shall appoint.

<b>16 </b>And the king went forth, and all his household after him. And the king left ten women, <i>which were</i> concubines, to keep the house.

<b>17 </b>And the king went forth, and all the people after him, and tarried in a place that was far off.

<b>18 </b>And all his servants passed on beside him; and all the Cherethites, and all the Pelethites, and all the Gittites, six hundred men which came after him from Gath, passed on before the king.

<b>19 </b>¶ Then said the king to Ittai the Gittite, Wherefore goest thou also with us? return to thy place, and abide with the king: for thou <i>art</i> a stranger, and also an exile.

<b>20 </b>Whereas thou camest <i>but</i> yesterday, should I this day make thee go up and down with us? seeing I go whither I may, return thou, and take back thy brethren: mercy and truth <i>be</i> with thee.

<b>21 </b>And Ittai answered the king, and said, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, and <i>as</i> my lord the king liveth, surely in what place my lord the king shall be, whether in death or life, even there also will thy servant be.

<b>22 </b>And David said to Ittai, Go and pass over. And Ittai the Gittite passed over, and all his men, and all the little ones that <i>were</i> with him.

<b>23 </b>And all the country wept with a loud voice, and all the people passed over: the king also himself passed over the brook Kidron, and all the people passed over, toward the way of the wilderness.

<b>24 </b>¶ And lo Zadok also, and all the Levites <i>were</i> with him, bearing the ark of the covenant of God: and they set down the ark of God; and Abiathar went up, until all the people had done passing out of the city.

<b>25 </b>And the king said unto Zadok, Carry back the ark of God into the city: if I shall find favour in the eyes of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, he will bring me again, and shew me <i>both</i> it, and his habitation:

<b>26 </b>But if he thus say, I have no delight in thee; behold, <i>here am</i> I, let him do to me as seemeth good unto him.

<b>27 </b>The king said also unto Zadok the priest, <i>Art not</i> thou a seer? return into the city in peace, and your two sons with you, Ahimaaz thy son, and Jonathan the son of Abiathar.

<b>28 </b>See, I will tarry in the plain of the wilderness, until there come word from you to certify me.

<b>29 </b>Zadok therefore and Abiathar carried the ark of God again to Jerusalem: and they tarried there.

<b>30 </b>¶ And David went up by the ascent of <i>mount</i> Olivet, and wept as he went up, and had his head covered, and he went barefoot: and all the people that <i>was</i> with him covered every man his head, and they went up, weeping as they went up.

<b>31 </b>¶ And <i>one</i> told David, saying, Ahithophel <i>is</i> among the conspirators with Absalom. And David said, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, I pray thee, turn the counsel of Ahithophel into foolishness.

<b>32 </b>¶ And it came to pass, that <i>when</i> David was come to the top <i>of the mount,</i> where he worshipped God, behold, Hushai the Archite came to meet him with his coat rent, and earth upon his head:

<b>33 </b>Unto whom David said, If thou passest on with me, then thou shalt be a burden unto me:

<b>34 </b>But if thou return to the city, and say unto Absalom, I will be thy servant, O king; <i>as</i> I <i>have been</i> thy father’s servant hitherto, so <i>will</i> I now also <i>be</i> thy servant: then mayest thou for me defeat the counsel of Ahithophel.

<b>35 </b>And <i>hast thou</i> not there with thee Zadok and Abiathar the priests? therefore it shall be, <i>that</i> what thing soever thou shalt hear out of the king’s house, thou shalt tell <i>it</i> to Zadok and Abiathar the priests.

<b>36 </b>Behold, <i>they have</i> there with them their two sons, Ahimaaz Zadok’s <i>son,</i> and Jonathan Abiathar’s <i>son;</i> and by them ye shall send unto me every thing that ye can hear.

<b>37 </b>So Hushai David’s friend came into the city, and Absalom came into Jerusalem.


--------------------

CHAPTER 16

<b>1 </b>And when David was a little past the top <i>of the hill,</i> behold, Ziba the servant of Mephibosheth met him, with a couple of asses saddled, and upon them two hundred <i>loaves</i> of bread, and an hundred bunches of raisins, and an hundred of summer fruits, and a bottle of wine.

<b>2 </b>And the king said unto Ziba, What meanest thou by these? And Ziba said, The asses <i>be</i> for the king’s household to ride on; and the bread and summer fruit for the young men to eat; and the wine, that such as be faint in the wilderness may drink.

<b>3 </b>And the king said, And where <i>is</i> thy master’s son? And Ziba said unto the king, Behold, he abideth at Jerusalem: for he said, To day shall the house of Israel restore me the kingdom of my father.

<b>4 </b>Then said the king to Ziba, Behold, thine <i>are</i> all that <i>pertained</i> unto Mephibosheth. And Ziba said, I humbly beseech thee <i>that</i> I may find grace in thy sight, my lord, O king.

<b>5 </b>¶ And when king David came to Bahurim, behold, thence came out a man of the family of the house of Saul, whose name <i>was</i> Shimei, the son of Gera: he came forth, and cursed still as he came.

<b>6 </b>And he cast stones at David, and at all the servants of king David: and all the people and all the mighty men <i>were</i> on his right hand and on his left.

<b>7 </b>And thus said Shimei when he cursed, Come out, come out, thou bloody man, and thou man of Belial:

<b>8 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath returned upon thee all the blood of the house of Saul, in whose stead thou hast reigned; and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath delivered the kingdom into the hand of Absalom thy son: and, behold, thou <i>art taken</i> in thy mischief, because thou <i>art</i> a bloody man.

<b>9 </b>¶ Then said Abishai the son of Zeruiah unto the king, Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? let me go over, I pray thee, and take off his head.

<b>10 </b>And the king said, What have I to do with you, ye sons of Zeruiah? so let him curse, because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath said unto him, Curse David. Who shall then say, Wherefore hast thou done so?

<b>11 </b>And David said to Abishai, and to all his servants, Behold, my son, which came forth of my bowels, seeketh my life: how much more now <i>may this</i> Benjamite <i>do it?</i> let him alone, and let him curse; for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath bidden him.

<b>12 </b>It may be that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will look on mine affliction, and that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will requite me good for his cursing this day.

<b>13 </b>And as David and his men went by the way, Shimei went along on the hill’s side over against him, and cursed as he went, and threw stones at him, and cast dust.

<b>14 </b>And the king, and all the people that <i>were</i> with him, came weary, and refreshed themselves there.

<b>15 </b>¶ And Absalom, and all the people the men of Israel, came to Jerusalem, and Ahithophel with him.

<b>16 </b>And it came to pass, when Hushai the Archite, David’s friend, was come unto Absalom, that Hushai said unto Absalom, God save the king, God save the king.

<b>17 </b>And Absalom said to Hushai, <i>Is</i> this thy kindness to thy friend? why wentest thou not with thy friend?

<b>18 </b>And Hushai said unto Absalom, Nay; but whom the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and this people, and all the men of Israel, choose, his will I be, and with him will I abide.

<b>19 </b>And again, whom should I serve? <i>should I</i> not <i>serve</i> in the presence of his son? as I have served in thy father’s presence, so will I be in thy presence.

<b>20 </b>¶ Then said Absalom to Ahithophel, Give counsel among you what we shall do.

<b>21 </b>And Ahithophel said unto Absalom, Go in unto thy father’s concubines, which he hath left to keep the house; and all Israel shall hear that thou art abhorred of thy father: then shall the hands of all that <i>are</i> with thee be strong.

<b>22 </b>So they spread Absalom a tent upon the top of the house; and Absalom went in unto his father’s concubines in the sight of all Israel.

<b>23 </b>And the counsel of Ahithophel, which he counselled in those days, <i>was</i> as if a man had inquired at the oracle of God: so <i>was</i> all the counsel of Ahithophel both with David and with Absalom.


--------------------

CHAPTER 17

<b>1 </b>Moreover Ahithophel said unto Absalom, Let me now choose out twelve thousand men, and I will arise and pursue after David this night:

<b>2 </b>And I will come upon him while he <i>is</i> weary and weak handed, and will make him afraid: and all the people that <i>are</i> with him shall flee; and I will smite the king only:

<b>3 </b>And I will bring back all the people unto thee: the man whom thou seekest <i>is</i> as if all returned: <i>so</i> all the people shall be in peace.

<b>4 </b>And the saying pleased Absalom well, and all the elders of Israel.

<b>5 </b>Then said Absalom, Call now Hushai the Archite also, and let us hear likewise what he saith.

<b>6 </b>And when Hushai was come to Absalom, Absalom spake unto him, saying, Ahithophel hath spoken after this manner: shall we do <i>after</i> his saying? if not; speak thou.

<b>7 </b>And Hushai said unto Absalom, The counsel that Ahithophel hath given <i>is</i> not good at this time.

<b>8 </b>For, said Hushai, thou knowest thy father and his men, that they <i>be</i> mighty men, and they <i>be</i> chafed in their minds, as a bear robbed of her whelps in the field: and thy father <i>is</i> a man of war, and will not lodge with the people.

<b>9 </b>Behold, he is hid now in some pit, or in some <i>other</i> place: and it will come to pass, when some of them be overthrown at the first, that whosoever heareth it will say, There is a slaughter among the people that follow Absalom.

<b>10 </b>And he also <i>that is</i> valiant, whose heart <i>is</i> as the heart of a lion, shall utterly melt: for all Israel knoweth that thy father <i>is</i> a mighty man, and <i>they</i> which <i>be</i> with him <i>are</i> valiant men.

<b>11 </b>Therefore I counsel that all Israel be generally gathered unto thee, from Dan even to Beer-sheba, as the sand that <i>is</i> by the sea for multitude; and that thou go to battle in thine own person.

<b>12 </b>So shall we come upon him in some place where he shall be found, and we will light upon him as the dew falleth on the ground: and of him and of all the men that <i>are</i> with him there shall not be left so much as one.

<b>13 </b>Moreover, if he be gotten into a city, then shall all Israel bring ropes to that city, and we will draw it into the river, until there be not one small stone found there.

<b>14 </b>And Absalom and all the men of Israel said, The counsel of Hushai the Archite <i>is</i> better than the counsel of Ahithophel. For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had appointed to defeat the good counsel of Ahithophel, to the intent that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> might bring evil upon Absalom.

<b>15 </b>¶ Then said Hushai unto Zadok and to Abiathar the priests, Thus and thus did Ahithophel counsel Absalom and the elders of Israel; and thus and thus have I counselled.

<b>16 </b>Now therefore send quickly, and tell David, saying, Lodge not this night in the plains of the wilderness, but speedily pass over; lest the king be swallowed up, and all the people that <i>are</i> with him.

<b>17 </b>Now Jonathan and Ahimaaz stayed by En-rogel; for they might not be seen to come into the city: and a wench went and told them; and they went and told king David.

<b>18 </b>Nevertheless a lad saw them, and told Absalom: but they went both of them away quickly, and came to a man’s house in Bahurim, which had a well in his court; whither they went down.

<b>19 </b>And the woman took and spread a covering over the well’s mouth, and spread ground corn thereon; and the thing was not known.

<b>20 </b>And when Absalom’s servants came to the woman to the house, they said, Where <i>is</i> Ahimaaz and Jonathan? And the woman said unto them, They be gone over the brook of water. And when they had sought and could not find <i>them,</i> they returned to Jerusalem.

<b>21 </b>And it came to pass, after they were departed, that they came up out of the well, and went and told king David, and said unto David, Arise, and pass quickly over the water: for thus hath Ahithophel counselled against you.

<b>22 </b>Then David arose, and all the people that <i>were</i> with him, and they passed over Jordan: by the morning light there lacked not one of them that was not gone over Jordan.

<b>23 </b>¶ And when Ahithophel saw that his counsel was not followed, he saddled <i>his</i> ass, and arose, and gat him home to his house, to his city, and put his household in order, and hanged himself, and died, and was buried in the sepulchre of his father.

<b>24 </b>Then David came to Mahanaim. And Absalom passed over Jordan, he and all the men of Israel with him.

<b>25 </b>¶ And Absalom made Amasa captain of the host instead of Joab: which Amasa <i>was</i> a man’s son, whose name <i>was</i> Ithra an Israelite, that went in to Abigail the daughter of Nahash, sister to Zeruiah Joab’s mother.

<b>26 </b>So Israel and Absalom pitched in the land of Gilead.

<b>27 </b>¶ And it came to pass, when David was come to Mahanaim, that Shobi the son of Nahash of Rabbah of the children of Ammon, and Machir the son of Ammiel of Lo-debar, and Barzillai the Gileadite of Rogelim,

<b>28 </b>Brought beds, and basins, and earthen vessels, and wheat, and barley, and flour, and parched <i>corn,</i> and beans, and lentiles, and parched <i>pulse,</i>

<b>29 </b>And honey, and butter, and sheep, and cheese of kine, for David, and for the people that <i>were</i> with him, to eat: for they said, The people <i>is</i> hungry, and weary, and thirsty, in the wilderness.


--------------------

CHAPTER 18

<b>1 </b>And David numbered the people that <i>were</i> with him, and set captains of thousands and captains of hundreds over them.

<b>2 </b>And David sent forth a third part of the people under the hand of Joab, and a third part under the hand of Abishai the son of Zeruiah, Joab’s brother, and a third part under the hand of Ittai the Gittite. And the king said unto the people, I will surely go forth with you myself also.

<b>3 </b>But the people answered, Thou shalt not go forth: for if we flee away, they will not care for us; neither if half of us die, will they care for us: but now <i>thou art</i> worth ten thousand of us: therefore now <i>it is</i> better that thou succour us out of the city.

<b>4 </b>And the king said unto them, What seemeth you best I will do. And the king stood by the gate side, and all the people came out by hundreds and by thousands.

<b>5 </b>And the king commanded Joab and Abishai and Ittai, saying, <i>Deal</i> gently for my sake with the young man, <i>even</i> with Absalom. And all the people heard when the king gave all the captains charge concerning Absalom.

<b>6 </b>¶ So the people went out into the field against Israel: and the battle was in the wood of Ephraim;

<b>7 </b>Where the people of Israel were slain before the servants of David, and there was there a great slaughter that day of twenty thousand <i>men.</i>

<b>8 </b>For the battle was there scattered over the face of all the country: and the wood devoured more people that day than the sword devoured.

<b>9 </b>¶ And Absalom met the servants of David. And Absalom rode upon a mule, and the mule went under the thick boughs of a great oak, and his head caught hold of the oak, and he was taken up between the heaven and the earth; and the mule that <i>was</i> under him went away.

<b>10 </b>And a certain man saw <i>it,</i> and told Joab, and said, Behold, I saw Absalom hanged in an oak.

<b>11 </b>And Joab said unto the man that told him, And, behold, thou sawest <i>him,</i> and why didst thou not smite him there to the ground? and I would have given thee ten <i>shekels</i> of silver, and a girdle.

<b>12 </b>And the man said unto Joab, Though I should receive a thousand <i>shekels</i> of silver in mine hand, <i>yet</i> would I not put forth mine hand against the king’s son: for in our hearing the king charged thee and Abishai and Ittai, saying, Beware that none <i>touch</i> the young man Absalom.

<b>13 </b>Otherwise I should have wrought falsehood against mine own life: for there is no matter hid from the king, and thou thyself wouldest have set thyself against <i>me.</i>

<b>14 </b>Then said Joab, I may not tarry thus with thee. And he took three darts in his hand, and thrust them through the heart of Absalom, while he <i>was</i> yet alive in the midst of the oak.

<b>15 </b>And ten young men that bare Joab’s armour compassed about and smote Absalom, and slew him.

<b>16 </b>And Joab blew the trumpet, and the people returned from pursuing after Israel: for Joab held back the people.

<b>17 </b>And they took Absalom, and cast him into a great pit in the wood, and laid a very great heap of stones upon him: and all Israel fled every one to his tent.

<b>18 </b>¶ Now Absalom in his lifetime had taken and reared up for himself a pillar, which <i>is</i> in the king’s dale: for he said, I have no son to keep my name in remembrance: and he called the pillar after his own name: and it is called unto this day, Absalom’s place.

<b>19 </b>¶ Then said Ahimaaz the son of Zadok, Let me now run, and bear the king tidings, how that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath avenged him of his enemies.

<b>20 </b>And Joab said unto him, Thou shalt not bear tidings this day, but thou shalt bear tidings another day: but this day thou shalt bear no tidings, because the king’s son is dead.

<b>21 </b>Then said Joab to Cushi, Go tell the king what thou hast seen. And Cushi bowed himself unto Joab, and ran.

<b>22 </b>Then said Ahimaaz the son of Zadok yet again to Joab, But howsoever, let me, I pray thee, also run after Cushi. And Joab said, Wherefore wilt thou run, my son, seeing that thou hast no tidings ready?

<b>23 </b>But howsoever, <i>said he,</i> let me run. And he said unto him, Run. Then Ahimaaz ran by the way of the plain, and overran Cushi.

<b>24 </b>And David sat between the two gates: and the watchman went up to the roof over the gate unto the wall, and lifted up his eyes, and looked, and behold a man running alone.

<b>25 </b>And the watchman cried, and told the king. And the king said, If he <i>be</i> alone, <i>there is</i> tidings in his mouth. And he came apace, and drew near.

<b>26 </b>And the watchman saw another man running: and the watchman called unto the porter, and said, Behold <i>another</i> man running alone. And the king said, He also bringeth tidings.

<b>27 </b>And the watchman said, Me thinketh the running of the foremost is like the running of Ahimaaz the son of Zadok. And the king said, He <i>is</i> a good man, and cometh with good tidings.

<b>28 </b>And Ahimaaz called, and said unto the king, All is well. And he fell down to the earth upon his face before the king, and said, Blessed <i>be</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, which hath delivered up the men that lifted up their hand against my lord the king.

<b>29 </b>And the king said, <i>Is</i> the young man Absalom safe? And Ahimaaz answered, When Joab sent the king’s servant, and <i>me</i> thy servant, I saw a great tumult, but I knew not what <i>it was.</i>

<b>30 </b>And the king said <i>unto him,</i> Turn aside, <i>and</i> stand here. And he turned aside, and stood still.

<b>31 </b>And, behold, Cushi came; and Cushi said, Tidings, my lord the king: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath avenged thee this day of all them that rose up against thee.

<b>32 </b>And the king said unto Cushi, <i>Is</i> the young man Absalom safe? And Cushi answered, The enemies of my lord the king, and all that rise against thee to do <i>thee</i> hurt, be as <i>that</i> young man <i>is.</i>

<b>33 </b>¶ And the king was much moved, and went up to the chamber over the gate, and wept: and as he went, thus he said, O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! would God I had died for thee, O Absalom, my son, my son!


--------------------

CHAPTER 19

<b>1 </b>And it was told Joab, Behold, the king weepeth and mourneth for Absalom.

<b>2 </b>And the victory that day was <i>turned</i> into mourning unto all the people: for the people heard say that day how the king was grieved for his son.

<b>3 </b>And the people gat them by stealth that day into the city, as people being ashamed steal away when they flee in battle.

<b>4 </b>But the king covered his face, and the king cried with a loud voice, O my son Absalom, O Absalom, my son, my son!

<b>5 </b>And Joab came into the house to the king, and said, Thou hast shamed this day the faces of all thy servants, which this day have saved thy life, and the lives of thy sons and of thy daughters, and the lives of thy wives, and the lives of thy concubines;

<b>6 </b>In that thou lovest thine enemies, and hatest thy friends. For thou hast declared this day, that thou regardest neither princes nor servants: for this day I perceive, that if Absalom had lived, and all we had died this day, then it had pleased thee well.

<b>7 </b>Now therefore arise, go forth, and speak comfortably unto thy servants: for I swear by the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, if thou go not forth, there will not tarry one with thee this night: and that will be worse unto thee than all the evil that befell thee from thy youth until now.

<b>8 </b>Then the king arose, and sat in the gate. And they told unto all the people, saying, Behold, the king doth sit in the gate. And all the people came before the king: for Israel had fled every man to his tent.

<b>9 </b>¶ And all the people were at strife throughout all the tribes of Israel, saying, The king saved us out of the hand of our enemies, and he delivered us out of the hand of the Philistines; and now he is fled out of the land for Absalom.

<b>10 </b>And Absalom, whom we anointed over us, is dead in battle. Now therefore why speak ye not a word of bringing the king back?

<b>11 </b>¶ And king David sent to Zadok and to Abiathar the priests, saying, Speak unto the elders of Judah, saying, Why are ye the last to bring the king back to his house? seeing the speech of all Israel is come to the king, <i>even</i> to his house.

<b>12 </b>Ye <i>are</i> my brethren, ye <i>are</i> my bones and my flesh: wherefore then are ye the last to bring back the king?

<b>13 </b>And say ye to Amasa, <i>Art</i> thou not of my bone, and of my flesh? God do so to me, and more also, if thou be not captain of the host before me continually in the room of Joab.

<b>14 </b>And he bowed the heart of all the men of Judah, even as <i>the heart of</i> one man; so that they sent <i>this word</i> unto the king, Return thou, and all thy servants.

<b>15 </b>So the king returned, and came to Jordan. And Judah came to Gilgal, to go to meet the king, to conduct the king over Jordan.

<b>16 </b>¶ And Shimei the son of Gera, a Benjamite, which <i>was</i> of Bahurim, hasted and came down with the men of Judah to meet king David.

<b>17 </b>And <i>there were</i> a thousand men of Benjamin with him, and Ziba the servant of the house of Saul, and his fifteen sons and his twenty servants with him; and they went over Jordan before the king.

<b>18 </b>And there went over a ferry boat to carry over the king’s household, and to do what he thought good. And Shimei the son of Gera fell down before the king, as he was come over Jordan;

<b>19 </b>And said unto the king, Let not my lord impute iniquity unto me, neither do thou remember that which thy servant did perversely the day that my lord the king went out of Jerusalem, that the king should take it to his heart.

<b>20 </b>For thy servant doth know that I have sinned: therefore, behold, I am come the first this day of all the house of Joseph to go down to meet my lord the king.

<b>21 </b>But Abishai the son of Zeruiah answered and said, Shall not Shimei be put to death for this, because he cursed the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s anointed?

<b>22 </b>And David said, What have I to do with you, ye sons of Zeruiah, that ye should this day be adversaries unto me? shall there any man be put to death this day in Israel? for do not I know that I <i>am</i> this day king over Israel?

<b>23 </b>Therefore the king said unto Shimei, Thou shalt not die. And the king sware unto him.

<b>24 </b>¶ And Mephibosheth the son of Saul came down to meet the king, and had neither dressed his feet, nor trimmed his beard, nor washed his clothes, from the day the king departed until the day he came <i>again</i> in peace.

<b>25 </b>And it came to pass, when he was come to Jerusalem to meet the king, that the king said unto him, Wherefore wentest not thou with me, Mephibosheth?

<b>26 </b>And he answered, My lord, O king, my servant deceived me: for thy servant said, I will saddle me an ass, that I may ride thereon, and go to the king; because thy servant <i>is</i> lame.

<b>27 </b>And he hath slandered thy servant unto my lord the king; but my lord the king <i>is</i> as an angel of God: do therefore <i>what is</i> good in thine eyes.

<b>28 </b>For all <i>of</i> my father’s house were but dead men before my lord the king: yet didst thou set thy servant among them that did eat at thine own table. What right therefore have I yet to cry any more unto the king?

<b>29 </b>And the king said unto him, Why speakest thou any more of thy matters? I have said, Thou and Ziba divide the land.

<b>30 </b>And Mephibosheth said unto the king, Yea, let him take all, forasmuch as my lord the king is come again in peace unto his own house.

<b>31 </b>¶ And Barzillai the Gileadite came down from Rogelim, and went over Jordan with the king, to conduct him over Jordan.

<b>32 </b>Now Barzillai was a very aged man, <i>even</i> fourscore years old: and he had provided the king of sustenance while he lay at Mahanaim; for he <i>was</i> a very great man.

<b>33 </b>And the king said unto Barzillai, Come thou over with me, and I will feed thee with me in Jerusalem.

<b>34 </b>And Barzillai said unto the king, How long have I to live, that I should go up with the king unto Jerusalem?

<b>35 </b>I <i>am</i> this day fourscore years old: <i>and</i> can I discern between good and evil? can thy servant taste what I eat or what I drink? can I hear any more the voice of singing men and singing women? wherefore then should thy servant be yet a burden unto my lord the king?

<b>36 </b>Thy servant will go a little way over Jordan with the king: and why should the king recompense it me with such a reward?

<b>37 </b>Let thy servant, I pray thee, turn back again, that I may die in mine own city, <i>and be buried</i> by the grave of my father and of my mother. But behold thy servant Chimham; let him go over with my lord the king; and do to him what shall seem good unto thee.

<b>38 </b>And the king answered, Chimham shall go over with me, and I will do to him that which shall seem good unto thee: and whatsoever thou shalt require of me, <i>that</i> will I do for thee.

<b>39 </b>And all the people went over Jordan. And when the king was come over, the king kissed Barzillai, and blessed him; and he returned unto his own place.

<b>40 </b>Then the king went on to Gilgal, and Chimham went on with him: and all the people of Judah conducted the king, and also half the people of Israel.

<b>41 </b>¶ And, behold, all the men of Israel came to the king, and said unto the king, Why have our brethren the men of Judah stolen thee away, and have brought the king, and his household, and all David’s men with him, over Jordan?

<b>42 </b>And all the men of Judah answered the men of Israel, Because the king <i>is</i> near of kin to us: wherefore then be ye angry for this matter? have we eaten at all of the king’s <i>cost?</i> or hath he given us any gift?

<b>43 </b>And the men of Israel answered the men of Judah, and said, We have ten parts in the king, and we have also more <i>right</i> in David than ye: why then did ye despise us, that our advice should not be first had in bringing back our king? And the words of the men of Judah were fiercer than the words of the men of Israel.


--------------------

CHAPTER 20

<b>1 </b>And there happened to be there a man of Belial, whose name <i>was</i> Sheba, the son of Bichri, a Benjamite: and he blew a trumpet, and said, We have no part in David, neither have we inheritance in the son of Jesse: every man to his tents, O Israel.

<b>2 </b>So every man of Israel went up from after David, <i>and</i> followed Sheba the son of Bichri: but the men of Judah clave unto their king, from Jordan even to Jerusalem.

<b>3 </b>¶ And David came to his house at Jerusalem; and the king took the ten women <i>his</i> concubines, whom he had left to keep the house, and put them in ward, and fed them, but went not in unto them. So they were shut up unto the day of their death, living in widowhood.

<b>4 </b>¶ Then said the king to Amasa, Assemble me the men of Judah within three days, and be thou here present.

<b>5 </b>So Amasa went to assemble <i>the men of</i> Judah: but he tarried longer than the set time which he had appointed him.

<b>6 </b>And David said to Abishai, Now shall Sheba the son of Bichri do us more harm than <i>did</i> Absalom: take thou thy lord’s servants, and pursue after him, lest he get him fenced cities, and escape us.

<b>7 </b>And there went out after him Joab’s men, and the Cherethites, and the Pelethites, and all the mighty men: and they went out of Jerusalem, to pursue after Sheba the son of Bichri.

<b>8 </b>When they <i>were</i> at the great stone which <i>is</i> in Gibeon, Amasa went before them. And Joab’s garment that he had put on was girded unto him, and upon it a girdle <i>with</i> a sword fastened upon his loins in the sheath thereof; and as he went forth it fell out.

<b>9 </b>And Joab said to Amasa, <i>Art</i> thou in health, my brother? And Joab took Amasa by the beard with the right hand to kiss him.

<b>10 </b>But Amasa took no heed to the sword that <i>was</i> in Joab’s hand: so he smote him therewith in the fifth <i>rib,</i> and shed out his bowels to the ground, and struck him not again; and he died. So Joab and Abishai his brother pursued after Sheba the son of Bichri.

<b>11 </b>And one of Joab’s men stood by him, and said, He that favoureth Joab, and he that <i>is</i> for David, <i>let him go</i> after Joab.

<b>12 </b>And Amasa wallowed in blood in the midst of the highway. And when the man saw that all the people stood still, he removed Amasa out of the highway into the field, and cast a cloth upon him, when he saw that every one that came by him stood still.

<b>13 </b>When he was removed out of the highway, all the people went on after Joab, to pursue after Sheba the son of Bichri.

<b>14 </b>¶ And he went through all the tribes of Israel unto Abel, and to Beth-maachah, and all the Berites: and they were gathered together, and went also after him.

<b>15 </b>And they came and besieged him in Abel of Beth-maachah, and they cast up a bank against the city, and it stood in the trench: and all the people that <i>were</i> with Joab battered the wall, to throw it down.

<b>16 </b>¶ Then cried a wise woman out of the city, Hear, hear; say, I pray you, unto Joab, Come near hither, that I may speak with thee.

<b>17 </b>And when he was come near unto her, the woman said, <i>Art</i> thou Joab? And he answered, I <i>am he.</i> Then she said unto him, Hear the words of thine handmaid. And he answered, I do hear.

<b>18 </b>Then she spake, saying, They were wont to speak in old time, saying, They shall surely ask <i>counsel</i> at Abel: and so they ended <i>the matter.</i>

<b>19 </b>I <i>am one of them that are</i> peaceable <i>and</i> faithful in Israel: thou seekest to destroy a city and a mother in Israel: why wilt thou swallow up the inheritance of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>?

<b>20 </b>And Joab answered and said, Far be it, far be it from me, that I should swallow up or destroy.

<b>21 </b>The matter <i>is</i> not so: but a man of mount Ephraim, Sheba the son of Bichri by name, hath lifted up his hand against the king, <i>even</i> against David: deliver him only, and I will depart from the city. And the woman said unto Joab, Behold, his head shall be thrown to thee over the wall.

<b>22 </b>Then the woman went unto all the people in her wisdom. And they cut off the head of Sheba the son of Bichri, and cast <i>it</i> out to Joab. And he blew a trumpet, and they retired from the city, every man to his tent. And Joab returned to Jerusalem unto the king.

<b>23 </b>¶ Now Joab <i>was</i> over all the host of Israel: and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada <i>was</i> over the Cherethites and over the Pelethites:

<b>24 </b>And Adoram <i>was</i> over the tribute: and Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud <i>was</i> recorder:

<b>25 </b>And Sheva <i>was</i> scribe: and Zadok and Abiathar <i>were</i> the priests:

<b>26 </b>And Ira also the Jairite was a chief ruler about David.


--------------------

CHAPTER 21

<b>1 </b>Then there was a famine in the days of David three years, year after year; and David inquired of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> answered, <i>It is</i> for Saul, and for <i>his</i> bloody house, because he slew the Gibeonites.

<b>2 </b>And the king called the Gibeonites, and said unto them; (now the Gibeonites <i>were</i> not of the children of Israel, but of the remnant of the Amorites; and the children of Israel had sworn unto them: and Saul sought to slay them in his zeal to the children of Israel and Judah.)

<b>3 </b>Wherefore David said unto the Gibeonites, What shall I do for you? and wherewith shall I make the atonement, that ye may bless the inheritance of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>?

<b>4 </b>And the Gibeonites said unto him, We will have no silver nor gold of Saul, nor of his house; neither for us shalt thou kill any man in Israel. And he said, What ye shall say, <i>that</i> will I do for you.

<b>5 </b>And they answered the king, The man that consumed us, and that devised against us <i>that</i> we should be destroyed from remaining in any of the coasts of Israel,

<b>6 </b>Let seven men of his sons be delivered unto us, and we will hang them up unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in Gibeah of Saul, <i>whom</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> did choose. And the king said, I will give <i>them.</i>

<b>7 </b>But the king spared Mephibosheth, the son of Jonathan the son of Saul, because of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s oath that <i>was</i> between them, between David and Jonathan the son of Saul.

<b>8 </b>But the king took the two sons of Rizpah the daughter of Aiah, whom she bare unto Saul, Armoni and Mephibosheth; and the five sons of Michal the daughter of Saul, whom she brought up for Adriel the son of Barzillai the Meholathite:

<b>9 </b>And he delivered them into the hands of the Gibeonites, and they hanged them in the hill before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and they fell <i>all</i> seven together, and were put to death in the days of harvest, in the first <i>days,</i> in the beginning of barley harvest.

<b>10 </b>¶ And Rizpah the daughter of Aiah took sackcloth, and spread it for her upon the rock, from the beginning of harvest until water dropped upon them out of heaven, and suffered neither the birds of the air to rest on them by day, nor the beasts of the field by night.

<b>11 </b>And it was told David what Rizpah the daughter of Aiah, the concubine of Saul, had done.

<b>12 </b>¶ And David went and took the bones of Saul and the bones of Jonathan his son from the men of Jabesh-gilead, which had stolen them from the street of Beth-shan, where the Philistines had hanged them, when the Philistines had slain Saul in Gilboa:

<b>13 </b>And he brought up from thence the bones of Saul and the bones of Jonathan his son; and they gathered the bones of them that were hanged.

<b>14 </b>And the bones of Saul and Jonathan his son buried they in the country of Benjamin in Zelah, in the sepulchre of Kish his father: and they performed all that the king commanded. And after that God was entreated for the land.

<b>15 </b>¶ Moreover the Philistines had yet war again with Israel; and David went down, and his servants with him, and fought against the Philistines: and David waxed faint.

<b>16 </b>And Ishbi-benob, which <i>was</i> of the sons of the giant, the weight of whose spear <i>weighed</i> three hundred <i>shekels</i> of brass in weight, he being girded with a new <i>sword,</i> thought to have slain David.

<b>17 </b>But Abishai the son of Zeruiah succoured him, and smote the Philistine, and killed him. Then the men of David sware unto him, saying, Thou shalt go no more out with us to battle, that thou quench not the light of Israel.

<b>18 </b>And it came to pass after this, that there was again a battle with the Philistines at Gob: then Sibbechai the Hushathite slew Saph, which <i>was</i> of the sons of the giant.

<b>19 </b>And there was again a battle in Gob with the Philistines, where Elhanan the son of Jaare-oregim, a Beth-lehemite, slew <i>the brother of</i> Goliath the Gittite, the staff of whose spear <i>was</i> like a weaver’s beam.

<b>20 </b>And there was yet a battle in Gath, where was a man of <i>great</i> stature, that had on every hand six fingers, and on every foot six toes, four and twenty in number; and he also was born to the giant.

<b>21 </b>And when he defied Israel, Jonathan the son of Shimea the brother of David slew him.

<b>22 </b>These four were born to the giant in Gath, and fell by the hand of David, and by the hand of his servants.


--------------------

CHAPTER 22

<b>1 </b>And David spake unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> the words of this song in the day <i>that</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had delivered him out of the hand of all his enemies, and out of the hand of Saul:

<b>2 </b>And he said, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> my rock, and my fortress, and my deliverer;

<b>3 </b>The God of my rock; in him will I trust: <i>he is</i> my shield, and the horn of my salvation, my high tower, and my refuge, my saviour; thou savest me from violence.

<b>4 </b>I will call on the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>who is</i> worthy to be praised: so shall I be saved from mine enemies.

<b>5 </b>When the waves of death compassed me, the floods of ungodly men made me afraid;

<b>6 </b>The sorrows of hell compassed me about; the snares of death prevented me;

<b>7 </b>In my distress I called upon the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and cried to my God: and he did hear my voice out of his temple, and my cry <i>did enter</i> into his ears.

<b>8 </b>Then the earth shook and trembled; the foundations of heaven moved and shook, because he was wroth.

<b>9 </b>There went up a smoke out of his nostrils, and fire out of his mouth devoured: coals were kindled by it.

<b>10 </b>He bowed the heavens also, and came down; and darkness <i>was</i> under his feet.

<b>11 </b>And he rode upon a cherub, and did fly: and he was seen upon the wings of the wind.

<b>12 </b>And he made darkness pavilions round about him, dark waters, <i>and</i> thick clouds of the skies.

<b>13 </b>Through the brightness before him were coals of fire kindled.

<b>14 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thundered from heaven, and the most High uttered his voice.

<b>15 </b>And he sent out arrows, and scattered them; lightning, and discomfited them.

<b>16 </b>And the channels of the sea appeared, the foundations of the world were discovered, at the rebuking of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, at the blast of the breath of his nostrils.

<b>17 </b>He sent from above, he took me; he drew me out of many waters;

<b>18 </b>He delivered me from my strong enemy, <i>and</i> from them that hated me: for they were too strong for me.

<b>19 </b>They prevented me in the day of my calamity: but the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was my stay.

<b>20 </b>He brought me forth also into a large place: he delivered me, because he delighted in me.

<b>21 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> rewarded me according to my righteousness: according to the cleanness of my hands hath he recompensed me.

<b>22 </b>For I have kept the ways of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and have not wickedly departed from my God.

<b>23 </b>For all his judgments <i>were</i> before me: and <i>as for</i> his statutes, I did not depart from them.

<b>24 </b>I was also upright before him, and have kept myself from mine iniquity.

<b>25 </b>Therefore the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath recompensed me according to my righteousness; according to my cleanness in his eye sight.

<b>26 </b>With the merciful thou wilt shew thyself merciful, <i>and</i> with the upright man thou wilt shew thyself upright.

<b>27 </b>With the pure thou wilt shew thyself pure; and with the froward thou wilt shew thyself unsavoury.

<b>28 </b>And the afflicted people thou wilt save: but thine eyes <i>are</i> upon the haughty, <i>that</i> thou mayest bring <i>them</i> down.

<b>29 </b>For thou <i>art</i> my lamp, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will lighten my darkness.

<b>30 </b>For by thee I have run through a troop: by my God have I leaped over a wall.

<b>31 </b><i>As for</i> God, his way <i>is</i> perfect; the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> tried: he <i>is</i> a buckler to all them that trust in him.

<b>32 </b>For who <i>is</i> God, save the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>? and who <i>is</i> a rock, save our God?

<b>33 </b>God <i>is</i> my strength <i>and</i> power: and he maketh my way perfect.

<b>34 </b>He maketh my feet like hinds’ <i>feet:</i> and setteth me upon my high places.

<b>35 </b>He teacheth my hands to war; so that a bow of steel is broken by mine arms.

<b>36 </b>Thou hast also given me the shield of thy salvation: and thy gentleness hath made me great.

<b>37 </b>Thou hast enlarged my steps under me; so that my feet did not slip.

<b>38 </b>I have pursued mine enemies, and destroyed them; and turned not again until I had consumed them.

<b>39 </b>And I have consumed them, and wounded them, that they could not arise: yea, they are fallen under my feet.

<b>40 </b>For thou hast girded me with strength to battle: them that rose up against me hast thou subdued under me.

<b>41 </b>Thou hast also given me the necks of mine enemies, that I might destroy them that hate me.

<b>42 </b>They looked, but <i>there was</i> none to save; <i>even</i> unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, but he answered them not.

<b>43 </b>Then did I beat them as small as the dust of the earth, I did stamp them as the mire of the street, <i>and</i> did spread them abroad.

<b>44 </b>Thou also hast delivered me from the strivings of my people, thou hast kept me <i>to be</i> head of the heathen: a people <i>which</i> I knew not shall serve me.

<b>45 </b>Strangers shall submit themselves unto me: as soon as they hear, they shall be obedient unto me.

<b>46 </b>Strangers shall fade away, and they shall be afraid out of their close places.

<b>47 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth; and blessed <i>be</i> my rock; and exalted be the God of the rock of my salvation.

<b>48 </b>It <i>is</i> God that avengeth me, and that bringeth down the people under me,

<b>49 </b>And that bringeth me forth from mine enemies: thou also hast lifted me up on high above them that rose up against me: thou hast delivered me from the violent man.

<b>50 </b>Therefore I will give thanks unto thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, among the heathen, and I will sing praises unto thy name.

<b>51 </b><i>He is</i> the tower of salvation for his king: and sheweth mercy to his anointed, unto David, and to his seed for evermore.


--------------------

CHAPTER 23

<b>1 </b>Now these <i>be</i> the last words of David. David the son of Jesse said, and the man <i>who was</i> raised up on high, the anointed of the God of Jacob, and the sweet psalmist of Israel, said,

<b>2 </b>The Spirit of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake by me, and his word <i>was</i> in my tongue.

<b>3 </b>The God of Israel said, the Rock of Israel spake to me, He that ruleth over men <i>must be</i> just, ruling in the fear of God.

<b>4 </b>And <i>he shall be</i> as the light of the morning, <i>when</i> the sun riseth, <i>even</i> a morning without clouds; <i>as</i> the tender grass <i>springing</i> out of the earth by clear shining after rain.

<b>5 </b>Although my house <i>be</i> not so with God; yet he hath made with me an everlasting covenant, ordered in all <i>things,</i> and sure: for <i>this is</i> all my salvation, and all <i>my</i> desire, although he make <i>it</i> not to grow.

<b>6 </b>¶ But <i>the sons</i> of Belial <i>shall be</i> all of them as thorns thrust away, because they cannot be taken with hands:

<b>7 </b>But the man <i>that</i> shall touch them must be fenced with iron and the staff of a spear; and they shall be utterly burned with fire in the <i>same</i> place.

<b>8 </b>¶ These <i>be</i> the names of the mighty men whom David had: The Tachmonite that sat in the seat, chief among the captains; the same <i>was</i> Adino the Eznite: <i>he lift up his spear</i> against eight hundred, whom he slew at one time.

<b>9 </b>And after him <i>was</i> Eleazar the son of Dodo the Ahohite, <i>one</i> of the three mighty men with David, when they defied the Philistines <i>that</i> were there gathered together to battle, and the men of Israel were gone away:

<b>10 </b>He arose, and smote the Philistines until his hand was weary, and his hand clave unto the sword: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> wrought a great victory that day; and the people returned after him only to spoil.

<b>11 </b>And after him <i>was</i> Shammah the son of Agee the Hararite. And the Philistines were gathered together into a troop, where was a piece of ground full of lentiles: and the people fled from the Philistines.

<b>12 </b>But he stood in the midst of the ground, and defended it, and slew the Philistines: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> wrought a great victory.

<b>13 </b>And three of the thirty chief went down, and came to David in the harvest time unto the cave of Adullam: and the troop of the Philistines pitched in the valley of Rephaim.

<b>14 </b>And David <i>was</i> then in an hold, and the garrison of the Philistines <i>was</i> then <i>in</i> Beth-lehem.

<b>15 </b>And David longed, and said, Oh that one would give me drink of the water of the well of Beth-lehem, which <i>is</i> by the gate!

<b>16 </b>And the three mighty men brake through the host of the Philistines, and drew water out of the well of Beth-lehem, that <i>was</i> by the gate, and took <i>it,</i> and brought <i>it</i> to David: nevertheless he would not drink thereof, but poured it out unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>17 </b>And he said, Be it far from me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that I should do this: <i>is not this</i> the blood of the men that went in jeopardy of their lives? therefore he would not drink it. These things did these three mighty men.

<b>18 </b>And Abishai, the brother of Joab, the son of Zeruiah, was chief among three. And he lifted up his spear against three hundred, <i>and</i> slew <i>them,</i> and had the name among three.

<b>19 </b>Was he not most honourable of three? therefore he was their captain: howbeit he attained not unto the <i>first</i> three.

<b>20 </b>And Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, the son of a valiant man, of Kabzeel, who had done many acts, he slew two lionlike men of Moab: he went down also and slew a lion in the midst of a pit in time of snow:

<b>21 </b>And he slew an Egyptian, a goodly man: and the Egyptian had a spear in his hand; but he went down to him with a staff, and plucked the spear out of the Egyptian’s hand, and slew him with his own spear.

<b>22 </b>These <i>things</i> did Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and had the name among three mighty men.

<b>23 </b>He was more honourable than the thirty, but he attained not to the <i>first</i> three. And David set him over his guard.

<b>24 </b>Asahel the brother of Joab <i>was</i> one of the thirty; Elhanan the son of Dodo of Beth-lehem,

<b>25 </b>Shammah the Harodite, Elika the Harodite,

<b>26 </b>Helez the Paltite, Ira the son of Ikkesh the Tekoite,

<b>27 </b>Abiezer the Anethothite, Mebunnai the Hushathite,

<b>28 </b>Zalmon the Ahohite, Maharai the Netophathite,

<b>29 </b>Heleb the son of Baanah, a Netophathite, Ittai the son of Ribai out of Gibeah of the children of Benjamin,

<b>30 </b>Benaiah the Pirathonite, Hiddai of the brooks of Gaash,

<b>31 </b>Abi-albon the Arbathite, Azmaveth the Barhumite,

<b>32 </b>Eliahba the Shaalbonite, of the sons of Jashen, Jonathan,

<b>33 </b>Shammah the Hararite, Ahiam the son of Sharar the Hararite,

<b>34 </b>Eliphelet the son of Ahasbai, the son of the Maachathite, Eliam the son of Ahithophel the Gilonite,

<b>35 </b>Hezrai the Carmelite, Paarai the Arbite,

<b>36 </b>Igal the son of Nathan of Zobah, Bani the Gadite,

<b>37 </b>Zelek the Ammonite, Naharai the Beerothite, armourbearer to Joab the son of Zeruiah,

<b>38 </b>Ira an Ithrite, Gareb an Ithrite,

<b>39 </b>Uriah the Hittite: thirty and seven in all.


--------------------

CHAPTER 24

<b>1 </b>And again the anger of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was kindled against Israel, and he moved David against them to say, Go, number Israel and Judah.

<b>2 </b>For the king said to Joab the captain of the host, which <i>was</i> with him, Go now through all the tribes of Israel, from Dan even to Beer-sheba, and number ye the people, that I may know the number of the people.

<b>3 </b>And Joab said unto the king, Now the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God add unto the people, how many soever they be, an hundredfold, and that the eyes of my lord the king may see <i>it:</i> but why doth my lord the king delight in this thing?

<b>4 </b>Notwithstanding the king’s word prevailed against Joab, and against the captains of the host. And Joab and the captains of the host went out from the presence of the king, to number the people of Israel.

<b>5 </b>¶ And they passed over Jordan, and pitched in Aroer, on the right side of the city that <i>lieth</i> in the midst of the river of Gad, and toward Jazer:

<b>6 </b>Then they came to Gilead, and to the land of Tahtim-hodshi; and they came to Dan-jaan, and about to Zidon,

<b>7 </b>And came to the strong hold of Tyre, and to all the cities of the Hivites, and of the Canaanites: and they went out to the south of Judah, <i>even</i> to Beer-sheba.

<b>8 </b>So when they had gone through all the land, they came to Jerusalem at the end of nine months and twenty days.

<b>9 </b>And Joab gave up the sum of the number of the people unto the king: and there were in Israel eight hundred thousand valiant men that drew the sword; and the men of Judah <i>were</i> five hundred thousand men.

<b>10 </b>¶ And David’s heart smote him after that he had numbered the people. And David said unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, I have sinned greatly in that I have done: and now, I beseech thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, take away the iniquity of thy servant; for I have done very foolishly.

<b>11 </b>For when David was up in the morning, the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto the prophet Gad, David’s seer, saying,

<b>12 </b>Go and say unto David, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, I offer thee three <i>things;</i> choose thee one of them, that I may <i>do it</i> unto thee.

<b>13 </b>So Gad came to David, and told him, and said unto him, Shall seven years of famine come unto thee in thy land? or wilt thou flee three months before thine enemies, while they pursue thee? or that there be three days’ pestilence in thy land? now advise, and see what answer I shall return to him that sent me.

<b>14 </b>And David said unto Gad, I am in a great strait: let us fall now into the hand of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for his mercies <i>are</i> great: and let me not fall into the hand of man.

<b>15 </b>¶ So the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sent a pestilence upon Israel from the morning even to the time appointed: and there died of the people from Dan even to Beer-sheba seventy thousand men.

<b>16 </b>And when the angel stretched out his hand upon Jerusalem to destroy it, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> repented him of the evil, and said to the angel that destroyed the people, It is enough: stay now thine hand. And the angel of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was by the threshingplace of Araunah the Jebusite.

<b>17 </b>And David spake unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> when he saw the angel that smote the people, and said, Lo, I have sinned, and I have done wickedly: but these sheep, what have they done? let thine hand, I pray thee, be against me, and against my father’s house.

<b>18 </b>¶ And Gad came that day to David, and said unto him, Go up, rear an altar unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in the threshingfloor of Araunah the Jebusite.

<b>19 </b>And David, according to the saying of Gad, went up as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded.

<b>20 </b>And Araunah looked, and saw the king and his servants coming on toward him: and Araunah went out, and bowed himself before the king on his face upon the ground.

<b>21 </b>And Araunah said, Wherefore is my lord the king come to his servant? And David said, To buy the threshingfloor of thee, to build an altar unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that the plague may be stayed from the people.

<b>22 </b>And Araunah said unto David, Let my lord the king take and offer up what <i>seemeth</i> good unto him: behold, <i>here be</i> oxen for burnt sacrifice, and threshing instruments and <i>other</i> instruments of the oxen for wood.

<b>23 </b>All these <i>things</i> did Araunah, <i>as</i> a king, give unto the king. And Araunah said unto the king, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God accept thee.

<b>24 </b>And the king said unto Araunah, Nay; but I will surely buy <i>it</i> of thee at a price: neither will I offer burnt offerings unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God of that which doth cost me nothing. So David bought the threshingfloor and the oxen for fifty shekels of silver.

<b>25 </b>And David built there an altar unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings. So the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was entreated for the land, and the plague was stayed from Israel.


--------------------

<small>The First Book of the </small>Kings

Commonly Called <br/>
the Third Book of the Kings

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>Now king David was old <i>and</i> stricken in years; and they covered him with clothes, but he gat no heat.

<b>2 </b>Wherefore his servants said unto him, Let there be sought for my lord the king a young virgin: and let her stand before the king, and let her cherish him, and let her lie in thy bosom, that my lord the king may get heat.

<b>3 </b>So they sought for a fair damsel throughout all the coasts of Israel, and found Abishag a Shunammite, and brought her to the king.

<b>4 </b>And the damsel <i>was</i> very fair, and cherished the king, and ministered to him: but the king knew her not.

<b>5 </b>¶ Then Adonijah the son of Haggith exalted himself, saying, I will be king: and he prepared him chariots and horsemen, and fifty men to run before him.

<b>6 </b>And his father had not displeased him at any time in saying, Why hast thou done so? and he also <i>was a</i> very goodly <i>man;</i> and <i>his mother</i> bare him after Absalom.

<b>7 </b>And he conferred with Joab the son of Zeruiah, and with Abiathar the priest: and they following Adonijah helped <i>him.</i>

<b>8 </b>But Zadok the priest, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and Nathan the prophet, and Shimei, and Rei, and the mighty men which <i>belonged</i> to David, were not with Adonijah.

<b>9 </b>And Adonijah slew sheep and oxen and fat cattle by the stone of Zoheleth, which <i>is</i> by En-rogel, and called all his brethren the king’s sons, and all the men of Judah the king’s servants:

<b>10 </b>But Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah, and the mighty men, and Solomon his brother, he called not.

<b>11 </b>¶ Wherefore Nathan spake unto Bath-sheba the mother of Solomon, saying, Hast thou not heard that Adonijah the son of Haggith doth reign, and David our lord knoweth <i>it</i> not?

<b>12 </b>Now therefore come, let me, I pray thee, give thee counsel, that thou mayest save thine own life, and the life of thy son Solomon.

<b>13 </b>Go and get thee in unto king David, and say unto him, Didst not thou, my lord, O king, swear unto thine handmaid, saying, Assuredly Solomon thy son shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne? why then doth Adonijah reign?

<b>14 </b>Behold, while thou yet talkest there with the king, I also will come in after thee, and confirm thy words.

<b>15 </b>¶ And Bath-sheba went in unto the king into the chamber: and the king was very old; and Abishag the Shunammite ministered unto the king.

<b>16 </b>And Bath-sheba bowed, and did obeisance unto the king. And the king said, What wouldest thou?

<b>17 </b>And she said unto him, My lord, thou swarest by the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God unto thine handmaid, <i>saying,</i> Assuredly Solomon thy son shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne.

<b>18 </b>And now, behold, Adonijah reigneth; and now, my lord the king, thou knowest <i>it</i> not:

<b>19 </b>And he hath slain oxen and fat cattle and sheep in abundance, and hath called all the sons of the king, and Abiathar the priest, and Joab the captain of the host: but Solomon thy servant hath he not called.

<b>20 </b>And thou, my lord, O king, the eyes of all Israel <i>are</i> upon thee, that thou shouldest tell them who shall sit on the throne of my lord the king after him.

<b>21 </b>Otherwise it shall come to pass, when my lord the king shall sleep with his fathers, that I and my son Solomon shall be counted offenders.

<b>22 </b>¶ And, lo, while she yet talked with the king, Nathan the prophet also came in.

<b>23 </b>And they told the king, saying, Behold Nathan the prophet. And when he was come in before the king, he bowed himself before the king with his face to the ground.

<b>24 </b>And Nathan said, My lord, O king, hast thou said, Adonijah shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne?

<b>25 </b>For he is gone down this day, and hath slain oxen and fat cattle and sheep in abundance, and hath called all the king’s sons, and the captains of the host, and Abiathar the priest; and, behold, they eat and drink before him, and say, God save king Adonijah.

<b>26 </b>But me, <i>even</i> me thy servant, and Zadok the priest, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and thy servant Solomon, hath he not called.

<b>27 </b>Is this thing done by my lord the king, and thou hast not shewed <i>it</i> unto thy servant, who should sit on the throne of my lord the king after him?

<b>28 </b>¶ Then king David answered and said, Call me Bath-sheba. And she came into the king’s presence, and stood before the king.

<b>29 </b>And the king sware, and said, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, that hath redeemed my soul out of all distress,

<b>30 </b>Even as I sware unto thee by the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, saying, Assuredly Solomon thy son shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne in my stead; even so will I certainly do this day.

<b>31 </b>Then Bath-sheba bowed with <i>her</i> face to the earth, and did reverence to the king, and said, Let my lord king David live for ever.

<b>32 </b>¶ And king David said, Call me Zadok the priest, and Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada. And they came before the king.

<b>33 </b>The king also said unto them, Take with you the servants of your lord, and cause Solomon my son to ride upon mine own mule, and bring him down to Gihon:

<b>34 </b>And let Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet anoint him there king over Israel: and blow ye with the trumpet, and say, God save king Solomon.

<b>35 </b>Then ye shall come up after him, that he may come and sit upon my throne; for he shall be king in my stead: and I have appointed him to be ruler over Israel and over Judah.

<b>36 </b>And Benaiah the son of Jehoiada answered the king, and said, Amen: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of my lord the king say so <i>too.</i>

<b>37 </b>As the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath been with my lord the king, even so be he with Solomon, and make his throne greater than the throne of my lord king David.

<b>38 </b>So Zadok the priest, and Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and the Cherethites, and the Pelethites, went down, and caused Solomon to ride upon king David’s mule, and brought him to Gihon.

<b>39 </b>And Zadok the priest took an horn of oil out of the tabernacle, and anointed Solomon. And they blew the trumpet; and all the people said, God save king Solomon.

<b>40 </b>And all the people came up after him, and the people piped with pipes, and rejoiced with great joy, so that the earth rent with the sound of them.

<b>41 </b>¶ And Adonijah and all the guests that <i>were</i> with him heard <i>it</i> as they had made an end of eating. And when Joab heard the sound of the trumpet, he said, Wherefore <i>is this</i> noise of the city being in an uproar?

<b>42 </b>And while he yet spake, behold, Jonathan the son of Abiathar the priest came: and Adonijah said unto him, Come in; for thou <i>art</i> a valiant man, and bringest good tidings.

<b>43 </b>And Jonathan answered and said to Adonijah, Verily our lord king David hath made Solomon king.

<b>44 </b>And the king hath sent with him Zadok the priest, and Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and the Cherethites, and the Pelethites, and they have caused him to ride upon the king’s mule:

<b>45 </b>And Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet have anointed him king in Gihon: and they are come up from thence rejoicing, so that the city rang again. This <i>is</i> the noise that ye have heard.

<b>46 </b>And also Solomon sitteth on the throne of the kingdom.

<b>47 </b>And moreover the king’s servants came to bless our lord king David, saying, God make the name of Solomon better than thy name, and make his throne greater than thy throne. And the king bowed himself upon the bed.

<b>48 </b>And also thus said the king, Blessed <i>be</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, which hath given <i>one</i> to sit on my throne this day, mine eyes even seeing <i>it.</i>

<b>49 </b>And all the guests that <i>were</i> with Adonijah were afraid, and rose up, and went every man his way.

<b>50 </b>¶ And Adonijah feared because of Solomon, and arose, and went, and caught hold on the horns of the altar.

<b>51 </b>And it was told Solomon, saying, Behold, Adonijah feareth king Solomon: for, lo, he hath caught hold on the horns of the altar, saying, Let king Solomon swear unto me to day that he will not slay his servant with the sword.

<b>52 </b>And Solomon said, If he will shew himself a worthy man, there shall not an hair of him fall to the earth: but if wickedness shall be found in him, he shall die.

<b>53 </b>So king Solomon sent, and they brought him down from the altar. And he came and bowed himself to king Solomon: and Solomon said unto him, Go to thine house.


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>Now the days of David drew nigh that he should die; and he charged Solomon his son, saying,

<b>2 </b>I go the way of all the earth: be thou strong therefore, and shew thyself a man;

<b>3 </b>And keep the charge of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, to walk in his ways, to keep his statutes, and his commandments, and his judgments, and his testimonies, as it is written in the law of Moses, that thou mayest prosper in all that thou doest, and whithersoever thou turnest thyself:

<b>4 </b>That the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> may continue his word which he spake concerning me, saying, If thy children take heed to their way, to walk before me in truth with all their heart and with all their soul, there shall not fail thee (said he) a man on the throne of Israel.

<b>5 </b>Moreover thou knowest also what Joab the son of Zeruiah did to me, <i>and</i> what he did to the two captains of the hosts of Israel, unto Abner the son of Ner, and unto Amasa the son of Jether, whom he slew, and shed the blood of war in peace, and put the blood of war upon his girdle that <i>was</i> about his loins, and in his shoes that <i>were</i> on his feet.

<b>6 </b>Do therefore according to thy wisdom, and let not his hoar head go down to the grave in peace.

<b>7 </b>But shew kindness unto the sons of Barzillai the Gileadite, and let them be of those that eat at thy table: for so they came to me when I fled because of Absalom thy brother.

<b>8 </b>And, behold, <i>thou hast</i> with thee Shimei the son of Gera, a Benjamite of Bahurim, which cursed me with a grievous curse in the day when I went to Mahanaim: but he came down to meet me at Jordan, and I sware to him by the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying, I will not put thee to death with the sword.

<b>9 </b>Now therefore hold him not guiltless: for thou <i>art</i> a wise man, and knowest what thou oughtest to do unto him; but his hoar head bring thou down to the grave with blood.

<b>10 </b>So David slept with his fathers, and was buried in the city of David.

<b>11 </b>And the days that David reigned over Israel <i>were</i> forty years: seven years reigned he in Hebron, and thirty and three years reigned he in Jerusalem.

<b>12 </b>¶ Then sat Solomon upon the throne of David his father; and his kingdom was established greatly.

<b>13 </b>¶ And Adonijah the son of Haggith came to Bath-sheba the mother of Solomon. And she said, Comest thou peaceably? And he said, Peaceably.

<b>14 </b>He said moreover, I have somewhat to say unto thee. And she said, Say on.

<b>15 </b>And he said, Thou knowest that the kingdom was mine, and <i>that</i> all Israel set their faces on me, that I should reign: howbeit the kingdom is turned about, and is become my brother’s: for it was his from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>16 </b>And now I ask one petition of thee, deny me not. And she said unto him, Say on.

<b>17 </b>And he said, Speak, I pray thee, unto Solomon the king, (for he will not say thee nay,) that he give me Abishag the Shunammite to wife.

<b>18 </b>And Bath-sheba said, Well; I will speak for thee unto the king.

<b>19 </b>¶ Bath-sheba therefore went unto king Solomon, to speak unto him for Adonijah. And the king rose up to meet her, and bowed himself unto her, and sat down on his throne, and caused a seat to be set for the king’s mother; and she sat on his right hand.

<b>20 </b>Then she said, I desire one small petition of thee; <i>I pray thee,</i> say me not nay. And the king said unto her, Ask on, my mother: for I will not say thee nay.

<b>21 </b>And she said, Let Abishag the Shunammite be given to Adonijah thy brother to wife.

<b>22 </b>And king Solomon answered and said unto his mother, And why dost thou ask Abishag the Shunammite for Adonijah? ask for him the kingdom also; for he <i>is</i> mine elder brother; even for him, and for Abiathar the priest, and for Joab the son of Zeruiah.

<b>23 </b>Then king Solomon sware by the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying, God do so to me, and more also, if Adonijah have not spoken this word against his own life.

<b>24 </b>Now therefore, <i>as</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, which hath established me, and set me on the throne of David my father, and who hath made me an house, as he promised, Adonijah shall be put to death this day.

<b>25 </b>And king Solomon sent by the hand of Benaiah the son of Jehoiada; and he fell upon him that he died.

<b>26 </b>¶ And unto Abiathar the priest said the king, Get thee to Anathoth, unto thine own fields; for thou <i>art</i> worthy of death: but I will not at this time put thee to death, because thou barest the ark of the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> before David my father, and because thou hast been afflicted in all wherein my father was afflicted.

<b>27 </b>So Solomon thrust out Abiathar from being priest unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; that he might fulfil the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which he spake concerning the house of Eli in Shiloh.

<b>28 </b>¶ Then tidings came to Joab: for Joab had turned after Adonijah, though he turned not after Absalom. And Joab fled unto the tabernacle of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and caught hold on the horns of the altar.

<b>29 </b>And it was told king Solomon that Joab was fled unto the tabernacle of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and, behold, <i>he is</i> by the altar. Then Solomon sent Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, saying, Go, fall upon him.

<b>30 </b>And Benaiah came to the tabernacle of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and said unto him, Thus saith the king, Come forth. And he said, Nay; but I will die here. And Benaiah brought the king word again, saying, Thus said Joab, and thus he answered me.

<b>31 </b>And the king said unto him, Do as he hath said, and fall upon him, and bury him; that thou mayest take away the innocent blood, which Joab shed, from me, and from the house of my father.

<b>32 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall return his blood upon his own head, who fell upon two men more righteous and better than he, and slew them with the sword, my father David not knowing <i>thereof, to wit,</i> Abner the son of Ner, captain of the host of Israel, and Amasa the son of Jether, captain of the host of Judah.
