<b>23 </b>For they also built them high places, and images, and groves, on every high hill, and under every green tree.

<b>24 </b>And there were also sodomites in the land: <i>and</i> they did according to all the abominations of the nations which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> cast out before the children of Israel.

<b>25 </b>¶ And it came to pass in the fifth year of king Rehoboam, <i>that</i> Shishak king of Egypt came up against Jerusalem:

<b>26 </b>And he took away the treasures of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and the treasures of the king’s house; he even took away all: and he took away all the shields of gold which Solomon had made.

<b>27 </b>And king Rehoboam made in their stead brasen shields, and committed <i>them</i> unto the hands of the chief of the guard, which kept the door of the king’s house.

<b>28 </b>And it was <i>so,</i> when the king went into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that the guard bare them, and brought them back into the guard chamber.

<b>29 </b>¶ Now the rest of the acts of Rehoboam, and all that he did, <i>are</i> they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah?

<b>30 </b>And there was war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam all <i>their</i> days.

<b>31 </b>And Rehoboam slept with his fathers, and was buried with his fathers in the city of David. And his mother’s name <i>was</i> Naamah an Ammonitess. And Abijam his son reigned in his stead.


--------------------

CHAPTER 15

<b>1 </b>Now in the eighteenth year of king Jeroboam the son of Nebat reigned Abijam over Judah.

<b>2 </b>Three years reigned he in Jerusalem. And his mother’s name <i>was</i> Maachah, the daughter of Abishalom.

<b>3 </b>And he walked in all the sins of his father, which he had done before him: and his heart was not perfect with the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his God, as the heart of David his father.

<b>4 </b>Nevertheless for David’s sake did the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his God give him a lamp in Jerusalem, to set up his son after him, and to establish Jerusalem:

<b>5 </b>Because David did <i>that which was</i> right in the eyes of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and turned not aside from any <i>thing</i> that he commanded him all the days of his life, save only in the matter of Uriah the Hittite.

<b>6 </b>And there was war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam all the days of his life.

<b>7 </b>Now the rest of the acts of Abijam, and all that he did, <i>are</i> they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah? And there was war between Abijam and Jeroboam.

<b>8 </b>And Abijam slept with his fathers; and they buried him in the city of David: and Asa his son reigned in his stead.

<b>9 </b>¶ And in the twentieth year of Jeroboam king of Israel reigned Asa over Judah.

<b>10 </b>And forty and one years reigned he in Jerusalem. And his mother’s name <i>was</i> Maachah, the daughter of Abishalom.

<b>11 </b>And Asa did <i>that which was</i> right in the eyes of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, as <i>did</i> David his father.

<b>12 </b>And he took away the sodomites out of the land, and removed all the idols that his fathers had made.

<b>13 </b>And also Maachah his mother, even her he removed from <i>being</i> queen, because she had made an idol in a grove; and Asa destroyed her idol, and burnt <i>it</i> by the brook Kidron.

<b>14 </b>But the high places were not removed: nevertheless Asa’s heart was perfect with the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> all his days.

<b>15 </b>And he brought in the things which his father had dedicated, and the things which himself had dedicated, into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, silver, and gold, and vessels.

<b>16 </b>¶ And there was war between Asa and Baasha king of Israel all their days.

<b>17 </b>And Baasha king of Israel went up against Judah, and built Ramah, that he might not suffer any to go out or come in to Asa king of Judah.

<b>18 </b>Then Asa took all the silver and the gold <i>that were</i> left in the treasures of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and the treasures of the king’s house, and delivered them into the hand of his servants: and king Asa sent them to Ben-hadad, the son of Tabrimon, the son of Hezion, king of Syria, that dwelt at Damascus, saying,

<b>19 </b><i>There is</i> a league between me and thee, <i>and</i> between my father and thy father: behold, I have sent unto thee a present of silver and gold; come and break thy league with Baasha king of Israel, that he may depart from me.

<b>20 </b>So Ben-hadad hearkened unto king Asa, and sent the captains of the hosts which he had against the cities of Israel, and smote Ijon, and Dan, and Abel-beth-maachah, and all Cinneroth, with all the land of Naphtali.

<b>21 </b>And it came to pass, when Baasha heard <i>thereof,</i> that he left off building of Ramah, and dwelt in Tirzah.

<b>22 </b>Then king Asa made a proclamation throughout all Judah; none <i>was</i> exempted: and they took away the stones of Ramah, and the timber thereof, wherewith Baasha had builded; and king Asa built with them Geba of Benjamin, and Mizpah.

<b>23 </b>The rest of all the acts of Asa, and all his might, and all that he did, and the cities which he built, <i>are</i> they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah? Nevertheless in the time of his old age he was diseased in his feet.

<b>24 </b>And Asa slept with his fathers, and was buried with his fathers in the city of David his father: and Jehoshaphat his son reigned in his stead.

<b>25 </b>¶ And Nadab the son of Jeroboam began to reign over Israel in the second year of Asa king of Judah, and reigned over Israel two years.

<b>26 </b>And he did evil in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and walked in the way of his father, and in his sin wherewith he made Israel to sin.

<b>27 </b>¶ And Baasha the son of Ahijah, of the house of Issachar, conspired against him; and Baasha smote him at Gibbethon, which <i>belonged</i> to the Philistines; for Nadab and all Israel laid siege to Gibbethon.

<b>28 </b>Even in the third year of Asa king of Judah did Baasha slay him, and reigned in his stead.

<b>29 </b>And it came to pass, when he reigned, <i>that</i> he smote all the house of Jeroboam; he left not to Jeroboam any that breathed, until he had destroyed him, according unto the saying of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which he spake by his servant Ahijah the Shilonite:

<b>30 </b>Because of the sins of Jeroboam which he sinned, and which he made Israel sin, by his provocation wherewith he provoked the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel to anger.

<b>31 </b>¶ Now the rest of the acts of Nadab, and all that he did, <i>are</i> they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?

<b>32 </b>And there was war between Asa and Baasha king of Israel all their days.

<b>33 </b>In the third year of Asa king of Judah began Baasha the son of Ahijah to reign over all Israel in Tirzah, twenty and four years.

<b>34 </b>And he did evil in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and walked in the way of Jeroboam, and in his sin wherewith he made Israel to sin.


--------------------

CHAPTER 16

<b>1 </b>Then the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came to Jehu the son of Hanani against Baasha, saying,

<b>2 </b>Forasmuch as I exalted thee out of the dust, and made thee prince over my people Israel; and thou hast walked in the way of Jeroboam, and hast made my people Israel to sin, to provoke me to anger with their sins;

<b>3 </b>Behold, I will take away the posterity of Baasha, and the posterity of his house; and will make thy house like the house of Jeroboam the son of Nebat.

<b>4 </b>Him that dieth of Baasha in the city shall the dogs eat; and him that dieth of his in the fields shall the fowls of the air eat.

<b>5 </b>Now the rest of the acts of Baasha, and what he did, and his might, <i>are</i> they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?

<b>6 </b>So Baasha slept with his fathers, and was buried in Tirzah: and Elah his son reigned in his stead.

<b>7 </b>And also by the hand of the prophet Jehu the son of Hanani came the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> against Baasha, and against his house, even for all the evil that he did in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, in provoking him to anger with the work of his hands, in being like the house of Jeroboam; and because he killed him.

<b>8 </b>¶ In the twenty and sixth year of Asa king of Judah began Elah the son of Baasha to reign over Israel in Tirzah, two years.

<b>9 </b>And his servant Zimri, captain of half <i>his</i> chariots, conspired against him, as he was in Tirzah, drinking himself drunk in the house of Arza steward of <i>his</i> house in Tirzah.

<b>10 </b>And Zimri went in and smote him, and killed him, in the twenty and seventh year of Asa king of Judah, and reigned in his stead.

<b>11 </b>¶ And it came to pass, when he began to reign, as soon as he sat on his throne, <i>that</i> he slew all the house of Baasha: he left him not one that pisseth against a wall, neither of his kinsfolks, nor of his friends.

<b>12 </b>Thus did Zimri destroy all the house of Baasha, according to the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which he spake against Baasha by Jehu the prophet,

<b>13 </b>For all the sins of Baasha, and the sins of Elah his son, by which they sinned, and by which they made Israel to sin, in provoking the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel to anger with their vanities.

<b>14 </b>Now the rest of the acts of Elah, and all that he did, <i>are</i> they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?

<b>15 </b>¶ In the twenty and seventh year of Asa king of Judah did Zimri reign seven days in Tirzah. And the people <i>were</i> encamped against Gibbethon, which <i>belonged</i> to the Philistines.

<b>16 </b>And the people <i>that were</i> encamped heard say, Zimri hath conspired, and hath also slain the king: wherefore all Israel made Omri, the captain of the host, king over Israel that day in the camp.

<b>17 </b>And Omri went up from Gibbethon, and all Israel with him, and they besieged Tirzah.

<b>18 </b>And it came to pass, when Zimri saw that the city was taken, that he went into the palace of the king’s house, and burnt the king’s house over him with fire, and died,

<b>19 </b>For his sins which he sinned in doing evil in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, in walking in the way of Jeroboam, and in his sin which he did, to make Israel to sin.

<b>20 </b>Now the rest of the acts of Zimri, and his treason that he wrought, <i>are</i> they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?

<b>21 </b>¶ Then were the people of Israel divided into two parts: half of the people followed Tibni the son of Ginath, to make him king; and half followed Omri.

<b>22 </b>But the people that followed Omri prevailed against the people that followed Tibni the son of Ginath: so Tibni died, and Omri reigned.

<b>23 </b>¶ In the thirty and first year of Asa king of Judah began Omri to reign over Israel, twelve years: six years reigned he in Tirzah.

<b>24 </b>And he bought the hill Samaria of Shemer for two talents of silver, and built on the hill, and called the name of the city which he built, after the name of Shemer, owner of the hill, Samaria.

<b>25 </b>¶ But Omri wrought evil in the eyes of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and did worse than all that <i>were</i> before him.

<b>26 </b>For he walked in all the way of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, and in his sin wherewith he made Israel to sin, to provoke the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel to anger with their vanities.

<b>27 </b>Now the rest of the acts of Omri which he did, and his might that he shewed, <i>are</i> they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?

<b>28 </b>So Omri slept with his fathers, and was buried in Samaria: and Ahab his son reigned in his stead.

<b>29 </b>¶ And in the thirty and eighth year of Asa king of Judah began Ahab the son of Omri to reign over Israel: and Ahab the son of Omri reigned over Israel in Samaria twenty and two years.

<b>30 </b>And Ahab the son of Omri did evil in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> above all that <i>were</i> before him.

<b>31 </b>And it came to pass, as if it had been a light thing for him to walk in the sins of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, that he took to wife Jezebel the daughter of Ethbaal king of the Zidonians, and went and served Baal, and worshipped him.

<b>32 </b>And he reared up an altar for Baal in the house of Baal, which he had built in Samaria.

<b>33 </b>And Ahab made a grove; and Ahab did more to provoke the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel to anger than all the kings of Israel that were before him.

<b>34 </b>¶ In his days did Hiel the Beth-elite build Jericho: he laid the foundation thereof in Abiram his firstborn, and set up the gates thereof in his youngest <i>son</i> Segub, according to the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which he spake by Joshua the son of Nun.


--------------------

CHAPTER 17

<b>1 </b>And Elijah the Tishbite, <i>who was</i> of the inhabitants of Gilead, said unto Ahab, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel liveth, before whom I stand, there shall not be dew nor rain these years, but according to my word.

<b>2 </b>And the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto him, saying,

<b>3 </b>Get thee hence, and turn thee eastward, and hide thyself by the brook Cherith, that <i>is</i> before Jordan.

<b>4 </b>And it shall be, <i>that</i> thou shalt drink of the brook; and I have commanded the ravens to feed thee there.

<b>5 </b>So he went and did according unto the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for he went and dwelt by the brook Cherith, that <i>is</i> before Jordan.

<b>6 </b>And the ravens brought him bread and flesh in the morning, and bread and flesh in the evening; and he drank of the brook.

<b>7 </b>And it came to pass after a while, that the brook dried up, because there had been no rain in the land.

<b>8 </b>¶ And the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto him, saying,

<b>9 </b>Arise, get thee to Zarephath, which <i>belongeth</i> to Zidon, and dwell there: behold, I have commanded a widow woman there to sustain thee.

<b>10 </b>So he arose and went to Zarephath. And when he came to the gate of the city, behold, the widow woman <i>was</i> there gathering of sticks: and he called to her, and said, Fetch me, I pray thee, a little water in a vessel, that I may drink.

<b>11 </b>And as she was going to fetch <i>it,</i> he called to her, and said, Bring me, I pray thee, a morsel of bread in thine hand.

<b>12 </b>And she said, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God liveth, I have not a cake, but an handful of meal in a barrel, and a little oil in a cruse: and, behold, I <i>am</i> gathering two sticks, that I may go in and dress it for me and my son, that we may eat it, and die.

<b>13 </b>And Elijah said unto her, Fear not; go <i>and</i> do as thou hast said: but make me thereof a little cake first, and bring <i>it</i> unto me, and after make for thee and for thy son.

<b>14 </b>For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, The barrel of meal shall not waste, neither shall the cruse of oil fail, until the day <i>that</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sendeth rain upon the earth.

<b>15 </b>And she went and did according to the saying of Elijah: and she, and he, and her house, did eat <i>many</i> days.

<b>16 </b><i>And</i> the barrel of meal wasted not, neither did the cruse of oil fail, according to the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which he spake by Elijah.

<b>17 </b>¶ And it came to pass after these things, <i>that</i> the son of the woman, the mistress of the house, fell sick; and his sickness was so sore, that there was no breath left in him.

<b>18 </b>And she said unto Elijah, What have I to do with thee, O thou man of God? art thou come unto me to call my sin to remembrance, and to slay my son?

<b>19 </b>And he said unto her, Give me thy son. And he took him out of her bosom, and carried him up into a loft, where he abode, and laid him upon his own bed.

<b>20 </b>And he cried unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and said, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God, hast thou also brought evil upon the widow with whom I sojourn, by slaying her son?

<b>21 </b>And he stretched himself upon the child three times, and cried unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and said, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God, I pray thee, let this child’s soul come into him again.

<b>22 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> heard the voice of Elijah; and the soul of the child came into him again, and he revived.

<b>23 </b>And Elijah took the child, and brought him down out of the chamber into the house, and delivered him unto his mother: and Elijah said, See, thy son liveth.

<b>24 </b>¶ And the woman said to Elijah, Now by this I know that thou <i>art</i> a man of God, <i>and</i> that the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in thy mouth <i>is</i> truth.


--------------------

CHAPTER 18

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass <i>after</i> many days, that the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came to Elijah in the third year, saying, Go, shew thyself unto Ahab; and I will send rain upon the earth.

<b>2 </b>And Elijah went to shew himself unto Ahab. And <i>there was</i> a sore famine in Samaria.

<b>3 </b>And Ahab called Obadiah, which <i>was</i> the governor of <i>his</i> house. (Now Obadiah feared the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> greatly:

<b>4 </b>For it was <i>so,</i> when Jezebel cut off the prophets of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that Obadiah took an hundred prophets, and hid them by fifty in a cave, and fed them with bread and water.)

<b>5 </b>And Ahab said unto Obadiah, Go into the land, unto all fountains of water, and unto all brooks: peradventure we may find grass to save the horses and mules alive, that we lose not all the beasts.

<b>6 </b>So they divided the land between them to pass throughout it: Ahab went one way by himself, and Obadiah went another way by himself.

<b>7 </b>¶ And as Obadiah was in the way, behold, Elijah met him: and he knew him, and fell on his face, and said, <i>Art</i> thou that my lord Elijah?

<b>8 </b>And he answered him, I <i>am:</i> go, tell thy lord, Behold, Elijah <i>is here.</i>

<b>9 </b>And he said, What have I sinned, that thou wouldest deliver thy servant into the hand of Ahab, to slay me?

<b>10 </b><i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God liveth, there is no nation or kingdom, whither my lord hath not sent to seek thee: and when they said, <i>He is</i> not <i>there;</i> he took an oath of the kingdom and nation, that they found thee not.

<b>11 </b>And now thou sayest, Go, tell thy lord, Behold, Elijah <i>is here.</i>

<b>12 </b>And it shall come to pass, <i>as soon as</i> I am gone from thee, that the Spirit of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall carry thee whither I know not; and <i>so</i> when I come and tell Ahab, and he cannot find thee, he shall slay me: but I thy servant fear the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> from my youth.

<b>13 </b>Was it not told my lord what I did when Jezebel slew the prophets of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, how I hid an hundred men of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s prophets by fifty in a cave, and fed them with bread and water?

<b>14 </b>And now thou sayest, Go, tell thy lord, Behold, Elijah <i>is here:</i> and he shall slay me.

<b>15 </b>And Elijah said, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts liveth, before whom I stand, I will surely shew myself unto him to day.

<b>16 </b>So Obadiah went to meet Ahab, and told him: and Ahab went to meet Elijah.

<b>17 </b>¶ And it came to pass, when Ahab saw Elijah, that Ahab said unto him, <i>Art</i> thou he that troubleth Israel?

<b>18 </b>And he answered, I have not troubled Israel; but thou, and thy father’s house, in that ye have forsaken the commandments of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and thou hast followed Baalim.

<b>19 </b>Now therefore send, <i>and</i> gather to me all Israel unto mount Carmel, and the prophets of Baal four hundred and fifty, and the prophets of the groves four hundred, which eat at Jezebel’s table.

<b>20 </b>So Ahab sent unto all the children of Israel, and gathered the prophets together unto mount Carmel.

<b>21 </b>And Elijah came unto all the people, and said, How long halt ye between two opinions? if the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>be</i> God, follow him: but if Baal, <i>then</i> follow him. And the people answered him not a word.

<b>22 </b>Then said Elijah unto the people, I, <i>even</i> I only, remain a prophet of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; but Baal’s prophets <i>are</i> four hundred and fifty men.

<b>23 </b>Let them therefore give us two bullocks; and let them choose one bullock for themselves, and cut it in pieces, and lay <i>it</i> on wood, and put no fire <i>under:</i> and I will dress the other bullock, and lay <i>it</i> on wood, and put no fire <i>under:</i>

<b>24 </b>And call ye on the name of your gods, and I will call on the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and the God that answereth by fire, let him be God. And all the people answered and said, It is well spoken.

<b>25 </b>And Elijah said unto the prophets of Baal, Choose you one bullock for yourselves, and dress <i>it</i> first; for ye <i>are</i> many; and call on the name of your gods, but put no fire <i>under.</i>

<b>26 </b>And they took the bullock which was given them, and they dressed <i>it,</i> and called on the name of Baal from morning even until noon, saying, O Baal, hear us. But <i>there was</i> no voice, nor any that answered. And they leaped upon the altar which was made.

<b>27 </b>And it came to pass at noon, that Elijah mocked them, and said, Cry aloud: for he <i>is</i> a god; either he is talking, or he is pursuing, or he is in a journey, <i>or</i> peradventure he sleepeth, and must be awaked.

<b>28 </b>And they cried aloud, and cut themselves after their manner with knives and lancets, till the blood gushed out upon them.

<b>29 </b>And it came to pass, when midday was past, and they prophesied until the <i>time</i> of the offering of the <i>evening</i> sacrifice, that <i>there was</i> neither voice, nor any to answer, nor any that regarded.

<b>30 </b>And Elijah said unto all the people, Come near unto me. And all the people came near unto him. And he repaired the altar of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>that was</i> broken down.

<b>31 </b>And Elijah took twelve stones, according to the number of the tribes of the sons of Jacob, unto whom the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came, saying, Israel shall be thy name:

<b>32 </b>And with the stones he built an altar in the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and he made a trench about the altar, as great as would contain two measures of seed.

<b>33 </b>And he put the wood in order, and cut the bullock in pieces, and laid <i>him</i> on the wood, and said, Fill four barrels with water, and pour <i>it</i> on the burnt sacrifice, and on the wood.

<b>34 </b>And he said, Do <i>it</i> the second time. And they did <i>it</i> the second time. And he said, Do <i>it</i> the third time. And they did <i>it</i> the third time.

<b>35 </b>And the water ran round about the altar; and he filled the trench also with water.

<b>36 </b>And it came to pass at <i>the time of</i> the offering of the <i>evening</i> sacrifice, that Elijah the prophet came near, and said, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Abraham, Isaac, and of Israel, let it be known this day that thou <i>art</i> God in Israel, and <i>that</i> I <i>am</i> thy servant, and <i>that</i> I have done all these things at thy word.

<b>37 </b>Hear me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, hear me, that this people may know that thou <i>art</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God, and <i>that</i> thou hast turned their heart back again.

<b>38 </b>Then the fire of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> fell, and consumed the burnt sacrifice, and the wood, and the stones, and the dust, and licked up the water that <i>was</i> in the trench.

<b>39 </b>And when all the people saw <i>it,</i> they fell on their faces: and they said, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, he <i>is</i> the God; the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, he <i>is</i> the God.

<b>40 </b>And Elijah said unto them, Take the prophets of Baal; let not one of them escape. And they took them: and Elijah brought them down to the brook Kishon, and slew them there.

<b>41 </b>¶ And Elijah said unto Ahab, Get thee up, eat and drink; for <i>there is</i> a sound of abundance of rain.

<b>42 </b>So Ahab went up to eat and to drink. And Elijah went up to the top of Carmel; and he cast himself down upon the earth, and put his face between his knees,

<b>43 </b>And said to his servant, Go up now, look toward the sea. And he went up, and looked, and said, <i>There is</i> nothing. And he said, Go again seven times.

<b>44 </b>And it came to pass at the seventh time, that he said, Behold, there ariseth a little cloud out of the sea, like a man’s hand. And he said, Go up, say unto Ahab, Prepare <i>thy chariot,</i> and get thee down, that the rain stop thee not.

<b>45 </b>And it came to pass in the mean while, that the heaven was black with clouds and wind, and there was a great rain. And Ahab rode, and went to Jezreel.

<b>46 </b>And the hand of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was on Elijah; and he girded up his loins, and ran before Ahab to the entrance of Jezreel.


--------------------

CHAPTER 19

<b>1 </b>And Ahab told Jezebel all that Elijah had done, and withal how he had slain all the prophets with the sword.

<b>2 </b>Then Jezebel sent a messenger unto Elijah, saying, So let the gods do <i>to me,</i> and more also, if I make not thy life as the life of one of them by to morrow about this time.

<b>3 </b>And when he saw <i>that,</i> he arose, and went for his life, and came to Beer-sheba, which <i>belongeth</i> to Judah, and left his servant there.

<b>4 </b>¶ But he himself went a day’s journey into the wilderness, and came and sat down under a juniper tree: and he requested for himself that he might die; and said, It is enough; now, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, take away my life; for I <i>am</i> not better than my fathers.

<b>5 </b>And as he lay and slept under a juniper tree, behold, then an angel touched him, and said unto him, Arise <i>and</i> eat.

<b>6 </b>And he looked, and, behold, <i>there was</i> a cake baken on the coals, and a cruse of water at his head. And he did eat and drink, and laid him down again.

<b>7 </b>And the angel of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came again the second time, and touched him, and said, Arise <i>and</i> eat; because the journey <i>is</i> too great for thee.

<b>8 </b>And he arose, and did eat and drink, and went in the strength of that meat forty days and forty nights unto Horeb the mount of God.

<b>9 </b>¶ And he came thither unto a cave, and lodged there; and, behold, the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>came</i> to him, and he said unto him, What doest thou here, Elijah?

<b>10 </b>And he said, I have been very jealous for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of hosts: for the children of Israel have forsaken thy covenant, thrown down thine altars, and slain thy prophets with the sword; and I, <i>even</i> I only, am left; and they seek my life, to take it away.

<b>11 </b>And he said, Go forth, and stand upon the mount before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. And, behold, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> passed by, and a great and strong wind rent the mountains, and brake in pieces the rocks before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; <i>but</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>was</i> not in the wind: and after the wind an earthquake; <i>but</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>was</i> not in the earthquake:

<b>12 </b>And after the earthquake a fire; <i>but</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>was</i> not in the fire: and after the fire a still small voice.

<b>13 </b>And it was <i>so,</i> when Elijah heard <i>it,</i> that he wrapped his face in his mantle, and went out, and stood in the entering in of the cave. And, behold, <i>there came</i> a voice unto him, and said, What doest thou here, Elijah?

<b>14 </b>And he said, I have been very jealous for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of hosts: because the children of Israel have forsaken thy covenant, thrown down thine altars, and slain thy prophets with the sword; and I, <i>even</i> I only, am left; and they seek my life, to take it away.

<b>15 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto him, Go, return on thy way to the wilderness of Damascus: and when thou comest, anoint Hazael <i>to be</i> king over Syria:

<b>16 </b>And Jehu the son of Nimshi shalt thou anoint <i>to be</i> king over Israel: and Elisha the son of Shaphat of Abel-meholah shalt thou anoint <i>to be</i> prophet in thy room.

<b>17 </b>And it shall come to pass, <i>that</i> him that escapeth the sword of Hazael shall Jehu slay: and him that escapeth from the sword of Jehu shall Elisha slay.

<b>18 </b>Yet I have left <i>me</i> seven thousand in Israel, all the knees which have not bowed unto Baal, and every mouth which hath not kissed him.

<b>19 </b>¶ So he departed thence, and found Elisha the son of Shaphat, who <i>was</i> plowing <i>with</i> twelve yoke <i>of oxen</i> before him, and he with the twelfth: and Elijah passed by him, and cast his mantle upon him.

<b>20 </b>And he left the oxen, and ran after Elijah, and said, Let me, I pray thee, kiss my father and my mother, and <i>then</i> I will follow thee. And he said unto him, Go back again: for what have I done to thee?

<b>21 </b>And he returned back from him, and took a yoke of oxen, and slew them, and boiled their flesh with the instruments of the oxen, and gave unto the people, and they did eat. Then he arose, and went after Elijah, and ministered unto him.


--------------------

CHAPTER 20

<b>1 </b>And Ben-hadad the king of Syria gathered all his host together: and <i>there were</i> thirty and two kings with him, and horses, and chariots: and he went up and besieged Samaria, and warred against it.

<b>2 </b>And he sent messengers to Ahab king of Israel into the city, and said unto him, Thus saith Ben-hadad,

<b>3 </b>Thy silver and thy gold <i>is</i> mine; thy wives also and thy children, <i>even</i> the goodliest, <i>are</i> mine.

<b>4 </b>And the king of Israel answered and said, My lord, O king, according to thy saying, I <i>am</i> thine, and all that I have.

<b>5 </b>And the messengers came again, and said, Thus speaketh Ben-hadad, saying, Although I have sent unto thee, saying, Thou shalt deliver me thy silver, and thy gold, and thy wives, and thy children;

<b>6 </b>Yet I will send my servants unto thee to morrow about this time, and they shall search thine house, and the houses of thy servants; and it shall be, <i>that</i> whatsoever is pleasant in thine eyes, they shall put <i>it</i> in their hand, and take <i>it</i> away.

<b>7 </b>Then the king of Israel called all the elders of the land, and said, Mark, I pray you, and see how this <i>man</i> seeketh mischief: for he sent unto me for my wives, and for my children, and for my silver, and for my gold; and I denied him not.

<b>8 </b>And all the elders and all the people said unto him, Hearken not <i>unto him,</i> nor consent.

<b>9 </b>Wherefore he said unto the messengers of Ben-hadad, Tell my lord the king, All that thou didst send for to thy servant at the first I will do: but this thing I may not do. And the messengers departed, and brought him word again.

<b>10 </b>And Ben-hadad sent unto him, and said, The gods do so unto me, and more also, if the dust of Samaria shall suffice for handfuls for all the people that follow me.

<b>11 </b>And the king of Israel answered and said, Tell <i>him,</i> Let not him that girdeth on <i>his harness</i> boast himself as he that putteth it off.

<b>12 </b>And it came to pass, when <i>Ben-hadad</i> heard this message, as he <i>was</i> drinking, he and the kings in the pavilions, that he said unto his servants, Set <i>yourselves in array.</i> And they set <i>themselves in array</i> against the city.

<b>13 </b>¶ And, behold, there came a prophet unto Ahab king of Israel, saying, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Hast thou seen all this great multitude? behold, I will deliver it into thine hand this day; and thou shalt know that I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>14 </b>And Ahab said, By whom? And he said, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>Even</i> by the young men of the princes of the provinces. Then he said, Who shall order the battle? And he answered, Thou.

<b>15 </b>Then he numbered the young men of the princes of the provinces, and they were two hundred and thirty two: and after them he numbered all the people, <i>even</i> all the children of Israel, <i>being</i> seven thousand.

<b>16 </b>And they went out at noon. But Ben-hadad <i>was</i> drinking himself drunk in the pavilions, he and the kings, the thirty and two kings that helped him.

<b>17 </b>And the young men of the princes of the provinces went out first; and Ben-hadad sent out, and they told him, saying, There are men come out of Samaria.

<b>18 </b>And he said, Whether they be come out for peace, take them alive; or whether they be come out for war, take them alive.

<b>19 </b>So these young men of the princes of the provinces came out of the city, and the army which followed them.

<b>20 </b>And they slew every one his man: and the Syrians fled; and Israel pursued them: and Ben-hadad the king of Syria escaped on an horse with the horsemen.

<b>21 </b>And the king of Israel went out, and smote the horses and chariots, and slew the Syrians with a great slaughter.

<b>22 </b>¶ And the prophet came to the king of Israel, and said unto him, Go, strengthen thyself, and mark, and see what thou doest: for at the return of the year the king of Syria will come up against thee.

<b>23 </b>And the servants of the king of Syria said unto him, Their gods <i>are</i> gods of the hills; therefore they were stronger than we; but let us fight against them in the plain, and surely we shall be stronger than they.

<b>24 </b>And do this thing, Take the kings away, every man out of his place, and put captains in their rooms:

<b>25 </b>And number thee an army, like the army that thou hast lost, horse for horse, and chariot for chariot: and we will fight against them in the plain, <i>and</i> surely we shall be stronger than they. And he hearkened unto their voice, and did so.

<b>26 </b>And it came to pass at the return of the year, that Ben-hadad numbered the Syrians, and went up to Aphek, to fight against Israel.

<b>27 </b>And the children of Israel were numbered, and were all present, and went against them: and the children of Israel pitched before them like two little flocks of kids; but the Syrians filled the country.

<b>28 </b>¶ And there came a man of God, and spake unto the king of Israel, and said, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Because the Syrians have said, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> God of the hills, but he <i>is</i> not God of the valleys, therefore will I deliver all this great multitude into thine hand, and ye shall know that I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>29 </b>And they pitched one over against the other seven days. And <i>so</i> it was, that in the seventh day the battle was joined: and the children of Israel slew of the Syrians an hundred thousand footmen in one day.

<b>30 </b>But the rest fled to Aphek, into the city; and <i>there</i> a wall fell upon twenty and seven thousand of the men <i>that were</i> left. And Ben-hadad fled, and came into the city, into an inner chamber.

<b>31 </b>¶ And his servants said unto him, Behold now, we have heard that the kings of the house of Israel <i>are</i> merciful kings: let us, I pray thee, put sackcloth on our loins, and ropes upon our heads, and go out to the king of Israel: peradventure he will save thy life.

<b>32 </b>So they girded sackcloth on their loins, and <i>put</i> ropes on their heads, and came to the king of Israel, and said, Thy servant Ben-hadad saith, I pray thee, let me live. And he said, <i>Is</i> he yet alive? he <i>is</i> my brother.

<b>33 </b>Now the men did diligently observe whether <i>any thing would come</i> from him, and did hastily catch <i>it:</i> and they said, Thy brother Ben-hadad. Then he said, Go ye, bring him. Then Ben-hadad came forth to him; and he caused him to come up into the chariot.

<b>34 </b>And <i>Ben-hadad</i> said unto him, The cities, which my father took from thy father, I will restore; and thou shalt make streets for thee in Damascus, as my father made in Samaria. Then <i>said Ahab,</i> I will send thee away with this covenant. So he made a covenant with him, and sent him away.

<b>35 </b>¶ And a certain man of the sons of the prophets said unto his neighbour in the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Smite me, I pray thee. And the man refused to smite him.

<b>36 </b>Then said he unto him, Because thou hast not obeyed the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, behold, as soon as thou art departed from me, a lion shall slay thee. And as soon as he was departed from him, a lion found him, and slew him.

<b>37 </b>Then he found another man, and said, Smite me, I pray thee. And the man smote him, so that in smiting he wounded <i>him.</i>

<b>38 </b>So the prophet departed, and waited for the king by the way, and disguised himself with ashes upon his face.

<b>39 </b>And as the king passed by, he cried unto the king: and he said, Thy servant went out into the midst of the battle; and, behold, a man turned aside, and brought a man unto me, and said, Keep this man: if by any means he be missing, then shall thy life be for his life, or else thou shalt pay a talent of silver.

<b>40 </b>And as thy servant was busy here and there, he was gone. And the king of Israel said unto him, So <i>shall</i> thy judgment <i>be;</i> thyself hast decided <i>it.</i>

<b>41 </b>And he hasted, and took the ashes away from his face; and the king of Israel discerned him that he <i>was</i> of the prophets.

<b>42 </b>And he said unto him, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Because thou hast let go out of <i>thy</i> hand a man whom I appointed to utter destruction, therefore thy life shall go for his life, and thy people for his people.

<b>43 </b>And the king of Israel went to his house heavy and displeased, and came to Samaria.


--------------------

CHAPTER 21

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass after these things, <i>that</i> Naboth the Jezreelite had a vineyard, which <i>was</i> in Jezreel, hard by the palace of Ahab king of Samaria.

<b>2 </b>And Ahab spake unto Naboth, saying, Give me thy vineyard, that I may have it for a garden of herbs, because it <i>is</i> near unto my house: and I will give thee for it a better vineyard than it; <i>or,</i> if it seem good to thee, I will give thee the worth of it in money.

<b>3 </b>And Naboth said to Ahab, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> forbid it me, that I should give the inheritance of my fathers unto thee.

<b>4 </b>And Ahab came into his house heavy and displeased because of the word which Naboth the Jezreelite had spoken to him: for he had said, I will not give thee the inheritance of my fathers. And he laid him down upon his bed, and turned away his face, and would eat no bread.

<b>5 </b>¶ But Jezebel his wife came to him, and said unto him, Why is thy spirit so sad, that thou eatest no bread?

<b>6 </b>And he said unto her, Because I spake unto Naboth the Jezreelite, and said unto him, Give me thy vineyard for money; or else, if it please thee, I will give thee <i>another</i> vineyard for it: and he answered, I will not give thee my vineyard.

<b>7 </b>And Jezebel his wife said unto him, Dost thou now govern the kingdom of Israel? arise, <i>and</i> eat bread, and let thine heart be merry: I will give thee the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite.

<b>8 </b>So she wrote letters in Ahab’s name, and sealed <i>them</i> with his seal, and sent the letters unto the elders and to the nobles that <i>were</i> in his city, dwelling with Naboth.

<b>9 </b>And she wrote in the letters, saying, Proclaim a fast, and set Naboth on high among the people:

<b>10 </b>And set two men, sons of Belial, before him, to bear witness against him, saying, Thou didst blaspheme God and the king. And <i>then</i> carry him out, and stone him, that he may die.

<b>11 </b>And the men of his city, <i>even</i> the elders and the nobles who were the inhabitants in his city, did as Jezebel had sent unto them, <i>and</i> as it <i>was</i> written in the letters which she had sent unto them.

<b>12 </b>They proclaimed a fast, and set Naboth on high among the people.

<b>13 </b>And there came in two men, children of Belial, and sat before him: and the men of Belial witnessed against him, <i>even</i> against Naboth, in the presence of the people, saying, Naboth did blaspheme God and the king. Then they carried him forth out of the city, and stoned him with stones, that he died.

<b>14 </b>Then they sent to Jezebel, saying, Naboth is stoned, and is dead.

<b>15 </b>¶ And it came to pass, when Jezebel heard that Naboth was stoned, and was dead, that Jezebel said to Ahab, Arise, take possession of the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, which he refused to give thee for money: for Naboth is not alive, but dead.

<b>16 </b>And it came to pass, when Ahab heard that Naboth was dead, that Ahab rose up to go down to the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, to take possession of it.

<b>17 </b>¶ And the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying,

<b>18 </b>Arise, go down to meet Ahab king of Israel, which <i>is</i> in Samaria: behold, <i>he is</i> in the vineyard of Naboth, whither he is gone down to possess it.

<b>19 </b>And thou shalt speak unto him, saying, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Hast thou killed, and also taken possession? And thou shalt speak unto him, saying, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, In the place where dogs licked the blood of Naboth shall dogs lick thy blood, even thine.

<b>20 </b>And Ahab said to Elijah, Hast thou found me, O mine enemy? And he answered, I have found <i>thee:</i> because thou hast sold thyself to work evil in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>21 </b>Behold, I will bring evil upon thee, and will take away thy posterity, and will cut off from Ahab him that pisseth against the wall, and him that is shut up and left in Israel,

<b>22 </b>And will make thine house like the house of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, and like the house of Baasha the son of Ahijah, for the provocation wherewith thou hast provoked <i>me</i> to anger, and made Israel to sin.

<b>23 </b>And of Jezebel also spake the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying, The dogs shall eat Jezebel by the wall of Jezreel.

<b>24 </b>Him that dieth of Ahab in the city the dogs shall eat; and him that dieth in the field shall the fowls of the air eat.

<b>25 </b>¶ But there was none like unto Ahab, which did sell himself to work wickedness in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, whom Jezebel his wife stirred up.

<b>26 </b>And he did very abominably in following idols, according to all <i>things</i> as did the Amorites, whom the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> cast out before the children of Israel.

<b>27 </b>And it came to pass, when Ahab heard those words, that he rent his clothes, and put sackcloth upon his flesh, and fasted, and lay in sackcloth, and went softly.

<b>28 </b>And the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying,

<b>29 </b>Seest thou how Ahab humbleth himself before me? because he humbleth himself before me, I will not bring the evil in his days: <i>but</i> in his son’s days will I bring the evil upon his house.


--------------------

CHAPTER 22

<b>1 </b>And they continued three years without war between Syria and Israel.

<b>2 </b>And it came to pass in the third year, that Jehoshaphat the king of Judah came down to the king of Israel.

<b>3 </b>And the king of Israel said unto his servants, Know ye that Ramoth in Gilead <i>is</i> ours, and we <i>be</i> still, <i>and</i> take it not out of the hand of the king of Syria?

<b>4 </b>And he said unto Jehoshaphat, Wilt thou go with me to battle to Ramoth-gilead? And Jehoshaphat said to the king of Israel, I <i>am</i> as thou <i>art,</i> my people as thy people, my horses as thy horses.

<b>5 </b>And Jehoshaphat said unto the king of Israel, Inquire, I pray thee, at the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> to day.

<b>6 </b>Then the king of Israel gathered the prophets together, about four hundred men, and said unto them, Shall I go against Ramoth-gilead to battle, or shall I forbear? And they said, Go up; for the Lord shall deliver <i>it</i> into the hand of the king.

<b>7 </b>And Jehoshaphat said, <i>Is there</i> not here a prophet of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> besides, that we might inquire of him?

<b>8 </b>And the king of Israel said unto Jehoshaphat, <i>There is</i> yet one man, Micaiah the son of Imlah, by whom we may inquire of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: but I hate him; for he doth not prophesy good concerning me, but evil. And Jehoshaphat said, Let not the king say so.

<b>9 </b>Then the king of Israel called an officer, and said, Hasten <i>hither</i> Micaiah the son of Imlah.

<b>10 </b>And the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat the king of Judah sat each on his throne, having put on their robes, in a void place in the entrance of the gate of Samaria; and all the prophets prophesied before them.

<b>11 </b>And Zedekiah the son of Chenaanah made him horns of iron: and he said, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, With these shalt thou push the Syrians, until thou have consumed them.

<b>12 </b>And all the prophets prophesied so, saying, Go up to Ramoth-gilead, and prosper: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall deliver <i>it</i> into the king’s hand.

<b>13 </b>And the messenger that was gone to call Micaiah spake unto him, saying, Behold now, the words of the prophets <i>declare</i> good unto the king with one mouth: let thy word, I pray thee, be like the word of one of them, and speak <i>that which is</i> good.

<b>14 </b>And Micaiah said, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, what the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> saith unto me, that will I speak.

<b>15 </b>¶ So he came to the king. And the king said unto him, Micaiah, shall we go against Ramoth-gilead to battle, or shall we forbear? And he answered him, Go, and prosper: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall deliver <i>it</i> into the hand of the king.

<b>16 </b>And the king said unto him, How many times shall I adjure thee that thou tell me nothing but <i>that which is</i> true in the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>?

<b>17 </b>And he said, I saw all Israel scattered upon the hills, as sheep that have not a shepherd: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said, These have no master: let them return every man to his house in peace.

<b>18 </b>And the king of Israel said unto Jehoshaphat, Did I not tell thee that he would prophesy no good concerning me, but evil?

<b>19 </b>And he said, Hear thou therefore the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: I saw the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sitting on his throne, and all the host of heaven standing by him on his right hand and on his left.

<b>20 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said, Who shall persuade Ahab, that he may go up and fall at Ramoth-gilead? And one said on this manner, and another said on that manner.

<b>21 </b>And there came forth a spirit, and stood before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and said, I will persuade him.

<b>22 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto him, Wherewith? And he said, I will go forth, and I will be a lying spirit in the mouth of all his prophets. And he said, Thou shalt persuade <i>him,</i> and prevail also: go forth, and do so.

<b>23 </b>Now therefore, behold, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath put a lying spirit in the mouth of all these thy prophets, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath spoken evil concerning thee.

<b>24 </b>But Zedekiah the son of Chenaanah went near, and smote Micaiah on the cheek, and said, Which way went the Spirit of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> from me to speak unto thee?

<b>25 </b>And Micaiah said, Behold, thou shalt see in that day, when thou shalt go into an inner chamber to hide thyself.

<b>26 </b>And the king of Israel said, Take Micaiah, and carry him back unto Amon the governor of the city, and to Joash the king’s son;

<b>27 </b>And say, Thus saith the king, Put this <i>fellow</i> in the prison, and feed him with bread of affliction and with water of affliction, until I come in peace.

<b>28 </b>And Micaiah said, If thou return at all in peace, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath not spoken by me. And he said, Hearken, O people, every one of you.

<b>29 </b>So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat the king of Judah went up to Ramoth-gilead.

<b>30 </b>And the king of Israel said unto Jehoshaphat, I will disguise myself, and enter into the battle; but put thou on thy robes. And the king of Israel disguised himself, and went into the battle.

<b>31 </b>But the king of Syria commanded his thirty and two captains that had rule over his chariots, saying, Fight neither with small nor great, save only with the king of Israel.

<b>32 </b>And it came to pass, when the captains of the chariots saw Jehoshaphat, that they said, Surely it <i>is</i> the king of Israel. And they turned aside to fight against him: and Jehoshaphat cried out.

<b>33 </b>And it came to pass, when the captains of the chariots perceived that it <i>was</i> not the king of Israel, that they turned back from pursuing him.

<b>34 </b>And a <i>certain</i> man drew a bow at a venture, and smote the king of Israel between the joints of the harness: wherefore he said unto the driver of his chariot, Turn thine hand, and carry me out of the host; for I am wounded.

<b>35 </b>And the battle increased that day: and the king was stayed up in his chariot against the Syrians, and died at even: and the blood ran out of the wound into the midst of the chariot.

<b>36 </b>And there went a proclamation throughout the host about the going down of the sun, saying, Every man to his city, and every man to his own country.

<b>37 </b>¶ So the king died, and was brought to Samaria; and they buried the king in Samaria.

<b>38 </b>And <i>one</i> washed the chariot in the pool of Samaria; and the dogs licked up his blood; and they washed his armour; according unto the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> which he spake.

<b>39 </b>Now the rest of the acts of Ahab, and all that he did, and the ivory house which he made, and all the cities that he built, <i>are</i> they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?

<b>40 </b>So Ahab slept with his fathers; and Ahaziah his son reigned in his stead.

<b>41 </b>¶ And Jehoshaphat the son of Asa began to reign over Judah in the fourth year of Ahab king of Israel.

<b>42 </b>Jehoshaphat <i>was</i> thirty and five years old when he began to reign; and he reigned twenty and five years in Jerusalem. And his mother’s name <i>was</i> Azubah the daughter of Shilhi.

<b>43 </b>And he walked in all the ways of Asa his father; he turned not aside from it, doing <i>that which was</i> right in the eyes of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: nevertheless the high places were not taken away; <i>for</i> the people offered and burnt incense yet in the high places.

<b>44 </b>And Jehoshaphat made peace with the king of Israel.

<b>45 </b>Now the rest of the acts of Jehoshaphat, and his might that he shewed, and how he warred, <i>are</i> they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah?

<b>46 </b>And the remnant of the sodomites, which remained in the days of his father Asa, he took out of the land.

<b>47 </b><i>There was</i> then no king in Edom: a deputy <i>was</i> king.

<b>48 </b>Jehoshaphat made ships of Tharshish to go to Ophir for gold: but they went not; for the ships were broken at Ezion-geber.

<b>49 </b>Then said Ahaziah the son of Ahab unto Jehoshaphat, Let my servants go with thy servants in the ships. But Jehoshaphat would not.

<b>50 </b>¶ And Jehoshaphat slept with his fathers, and was buried with his fathers in the city of David his father: and Jehoram his son reigned in his stead.

<b>51 </b>¶ Ahaziah the son of Ahab began to reign over Israel in Samaria the seventeenth year of Jehoshaphat king of Judah, and reigned two years over Israel.

<b>52 </b>And he did evil in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and walked in the way of his father, and in the way of his mother, and in the way of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who made Israel to sin:

<b>53 </b>For he served Baal, and worshipped him, and provoked to anger the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, according to all that his father had done.


--------------------

<small>The Second Book of the </small>Kings

Commonly Called <br/>
the Fourth Book of the Kings

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>Then Moab rebelled against Israel after the death of Ahab.

<b>2 </b>And Ahaziah fell down through a lattice in his upper chamber that <i>was</i> in Samaria, and was sick: and he sent messengers, and said unto them, Go, inquire of Baal-zebub the god of Ekron whether I shall recover of this disease.

<b>3 </b>But the angel of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said to Elijah the Tishbite, Arise, go up to meet the messengers of the king of Samaria, and say unto them, <i>Is it</i> not because <i>there is</i> not a God in Israel, <i>that</i> ye go to inquire of Baal-zebub the god of Ekron?

<b>4 </b>Now therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Thou shalt not come down from that bed on which thou art gone up, but shalt surely die. And Elijah departed.

<b>5 </b>¶ And when the messengers turned back unto him, he said unto them, Why are ye now turned back?

<b>6 </b>And they said unto him, There came a man up to meet us, and said unto us, Go, turn again unto the king that sent you, and say unto him, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>Is it</i> not because <i>there is</i> not a God in Israel, <i>that</i> thou sendest to inquire of Baal-zebub the god of Ekron? therefore thou shalt not come down from that bed on which thou art gone up, but shalt surely die.

<b>7 </b>And he said unto them, What manner of man <i>was he</i> which came up to meet you, and told you these words?

<b>8 </b>And they answered him, <i>He was</i> an hairy man, and girt with a girdle of leather about his loins. And he said, It <i>is</i> Elijah the Tishbite.

<b>9 </b>Then the king sent unto him a captain of fifty with his fifty. And he went up to him: and, behold, he sat on the top of an hill. And he spake unto him, Thou man of God, the king hath said, Come down.

<b>10 </b>And Elijah answered and said to the captain of fifty, If I <i>be</i> a man of God, then let fire come down from heaven, and consume thee and thy fifty. And there came down fire from heaven, and consumed him and his fifty.

<b>11 </b>Again also he sent unto him another captain of fifty with his fifty. And he answered and said unto him, O man of God, thus hath the king said, Come down quickly.

<b>12 </b>And Elijah answered and said unto them, If I <i>be</i> a man of God, let fire come down from heaven, and consume thee and thy fifty. And the fire of God came down from heaven, and consumed him and his fifty.

<b>13 </b>¶ And he sent again a captain of the third fifty with his fifty. And the third captain of fifty went up, and came and fell on his knees before Elijah, and besought him, and said unto him, O man of God, I pray thee, let my life, and the life of these fifty thy servants, be precious in thy sight.

<b>14 </b>Behold, there came fire down from heaven, and burnt up the two captains of the former fifties with their fifties: therefore let my life now be precious in thy sight.

<b>15 </b>And the angel of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Elijah, Go down with him: be not afraid of him. And he arose, and went down with him unto the king.

<b>16 </b>And he said unto him, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Forasmuch as thou hast sent messengers to inquire of Baal-zebub the god of Ekron, <i>is it</i> not because <i>there is</i> no God in Israel to inquire of his word? therefore thou shalt not come down off that bed on which thou art gone up, but shalt surely die.

<b>17 </b>¶ So he died according to the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> which Elijah had spoken. And Jehoram reigned in his stead in the second year of Jehoram the son of Jehoshaphat king of Judah; because he had no son.

<b>18 </b>Now the rest of the acts of Ahaziah which he did, <i>are</i> they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass, when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> would take up Elijah into heaven by a whirlwind, that Elijah went with Elisha from Gilgal.

<b>2 </b>And Elijah said unto Elisha, Tarry here, I pray thee; for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath sent me to Beth-el. And Elisha said <i>unto him, As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, and <i>as</i> thy soul liveth, I will not leave thee. So they went down to Beth-el.

<b>3 </b>And the sons of the prophets that <i>were</i> at Beth-el came forth to Elisha, and said unto him, Knowest thou that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will take away thy master from thy head to day? And he said, Yea, I know <i>it;</i> hold ye your peace.

<b>4 </b>And Elijah said unto him, Elisha, tarry here, I pray thee; for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath sent me to Jericho. And he said, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, and <i>as</i> thy soul liveth, I will not leave thee. So they came to Jericho.

<b>5 </b>And the sons of the prophets that <i>were</i> at Jericho came to Elisha, and said unto him, Knowest thou that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will take away thy master from thy head to day? And he answered, Yea, I know <i>it;</i> hold ye your peace.

<b>6 </b>And Elijah said unto him, Tarry, I pray thee, here; for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath sent me to Jordan. And he said, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, and <i>as</i> thy soul liveth, I will not leave thee. And they two went on.

<b>7 </b>And fifty men of the sons of the prophets went, and stood to view afar off: and they two stood by Jordan.

<b>8 </b>And Elijah took his mantle, and wrapped <i>it</i> together, and smote the waters, and they were divided hither and thither, so that they two went over on dry ground.

<b>9 </b>¶ And it came to pass, when they were gone over, that Elijah said unto Elisha, Ask what I shall do for thee, before I be taken away from thee. And Elisha said, I pray thee, let a double portion of thy spirit be upon me.

<b>10 </b>And he said, Thou hast asked a hard thing: <i>nevertheless,</i> if thou see me <i>when I am</i> taken from thee, it shall be so unto thee; but if not, it shall not be <i>so.</i>

<b>11 </b>And it came to pass, as they still went on, and talked, that, behold, <i>there appeared</i> a chariot of fire, and horses of fire, and parted them both asunder; and Elijah went up by a whirlwind into heaven.

<b>12 </b>¶ And Elisha saw <i>it,</i> and he cried, My father, my father, the chariot of Israel, and the horsemen thereof. And he saw him no more: and he took hold of his own clothes, and rent them in two pieces.

<b>13 </b>He took up also the mantle of Elijah that fell from him, and went back, and stood by the bank of Jordan;

<b>14 </b>And he took the mantle of Elijah that fell from him, and smote the waters, and said, Where <i>is</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Elijah? and when he also had smitten the waters, they parted hither and thither: and Elisha went over.

<b>15 </b>And when the sons of the prophets which <i>were</i> to view at Jericho saw him, they said, The spirit of Elijah doth rest on Elisha. And they came to meet him, and bowed themselves to the ground before him.

<b>16 </b>¶ And they said unto him, Behold now, there be with thy servants fifty strong men; let them go, we pray thee, and seek thy master: lest peradventure the Spirit of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath taken him up, and cast him upon some mountain, or into some valley. And he said, Ye shall not send.

<b>17 </b>And when they urged him till he was ashamed, he said, Send. They sent therefore fifty men; and they sought three days, but found him not.

<b>18 </b>And when they came again to him, (for he tarried at Jericho,) he said unto them, Did I not say unto you, Go not?

<b>19 </b>¶ And the men of the city said unto Elisha, Behold, I pray thee, the situation of this city <i>is</i> pleasant, as my lord seeth: but the water <i>is</i> naught, and the ground barren.

<b>20 </b>And he said, Bring me a new cruse, and put salt therein. And they brought <i>it</i> to him.

<b>21 </b>And he went forth unto the spring of the waters, and cast the salt in there, and said, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, I have healed these waters; there shall not be from thence any more death or barren <i>land.</i>

<b>22 </b>So the waters were healed unto this day, according to the saying of Elisha which he spake.

<b>23 </b>¶ And he went up from thence unto Beth-el: and as he was going up by the way, there came forth little children out of the city, and mocked him, and said unto him, Go up, thou bald head; go up, thou bald head.

<b>24 </b>And he turned back, and looked on them, and cursed them in the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. And there came forth two she bears out of the wood, and tare forty and two children of them.

<b>25 </b>And he went from thence to mount Carmel, and from thence he returned to Samaria.


--------------------

CHAPTER 3

<b>1 </b>Now Jehoram the son of Ahab began to reign over Israel in Samaria the eighteenth year of Jehoshaphat king of Judah, and reigned twelve years.

<b>2 </b>And he wrought evil in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; but not like his father, and like his mother: for he put away the image of Baal that his father had made.

<b>3 </b>Nevertheless he cleaved unto the sins of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, which made Israel to sin; he departed not therefrom.

<b>4 </b>¶ And Mesha king of Moab was a sheepmaster, and rendered unto the king of Israel an hundred thousand lambs, and an hundred thousand rams, with the wool.

<b>5 </b>But it came to pass, when Ahab was dead, that the king of Moab rebelled against the king of Israel.

<b>6 </b>¶ And king Jehoram went out of Samaria the same time, and numbered all Israel.

<b>7 </b>And he went and sent to Jehoshaphat the king of Judah, saying, The king of Moab hath rebelled against me: wilt thou go with me against Moab to battle? And he said, I will go up: I <i>am</i> as thou <i>art,</i> my people as thy people, <i>and</i> my horses as thy horses.

<b>8 </b>And he said, Which way shall we go up? And he answered, The way through the wilderness of Edom.

<b>9 </b>So the king of Israel went, and the king of Judah, and the king of Edom: and they fetched a compass of seven days’ journey: and there was no water for the host, and for the cattle that followed them.

<b>10 </b>And the king of Israel said, Alas! that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath called these three kings together, to deliver them into the hand of Moab!

<b>11 </b>But Jehoshaphat said, <i>Is there</i> not here a prophet of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that we may inquire of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> by him? And one of the king of Israel’s servants answered and said, Here <i>is</i> Elisha the son of Shaphat, which poured water on the hands of Elijah.

<b>12 </b>And Jehoshaphat said, The word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> is with him. So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat and the king of Edom went down to him.

<b>13 </b>And Elisha said unto the king of Israel, What have I to do with thee? get thee to the prophets of thy father, and to the prophets of thy mother. And the king of Israel said unto him, Nay: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath called these three kings together, to deliver them into the hand of Moab.

<b>14 </b>And Elisha said, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts liveth, before whom I stand, surely, were it not that I regard the presence of Jehoshaphat the king of Judah, I would not look toward thee, nor see thee.

<b>15 </b>But now bring me a minstrel. And it came to pass, when the minstrel played, that the hand of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came upon him.

<b>16 </b>And he said, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Make this valley full of ditches.

<b>17 </b>For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Ye shall not see wind, neither shall ye see rain; yet that valley shall be filled with water, that ye may drink, both ye, and your cattle, and your beasts.

<b>18 </b>And this is <i>but</i> a light thing in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: he will deliver the Moabites also into your hand.

<b>19 </b>And ye shall smite every fenced city, and every choice city, and shall fell every good tree, and stop all wells of water, and mar every good piece of land with stones.

<b>20 </b>And it came to pass in the morning, when the meat offering was offered, that, behold, there came water by the way of Edom, and the country was filled with water.

<b>21 </b>¶ And when all the Moabites heard that the kings were come up to fight against them, they gathered all that were able to put on armour, and upward, and stood in the border.

<b>22 </b>And they rose up early in the morning, and the sun shone upon the water, and the Moabites saw the water on the other side <i>as</i> red as blood:

<b>23 </b>And they said, This <i>is</i> blood: the kings are surely slain, and they have smitten one another: now therefore, Moab, to the spoil.

<b>24 </b>And when they came to the camp of Israel, the Israelites rose up and smote the Moabites, so that they fled before them: but they went forward smiting the Moabites, even in <i>their</i> country.

<b>25 </b>And they beat down the cities, and on every good piece of land cast every man his stone, and filled it; and they stopped all the wells of water, and felled all the good trees: only in Kir-haraseth left they the stones thereof; howbeit the slingers went about <i>it,</i> and smote it.

<b>26 </b>¶ And when the king of Moab saw that the battle was too sore for him, he took with him seven hundred men that drew swords, to break through <i>even</i> unto the king of Edom: but they could not.

<b>27 </b>Then he took his eldest son that should have reigned in his stead, and offered him <i>for</i> a burnt offering upon the wall. And there was great indignation against Israel: and they departed from him, and returned to <i>their own</i> land.


--------------------

CHAPTER 4

<b>1 </b>Now there cried a certain woman of the wives of the sons of the prophets unto Elisha, saying, Thy servant my husband is dead; and thou knowest that thy servant did fear the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and the creditor is come to take unto him my two sons to be bondmen.

<b>2 </b>And Elisha said unto her, What shall I do for thee? tell me, what hast thou in the house? And she said, Thine handmaid hath not any thing in the house, save a pot of oil.

<b>3 </b>Then he said, Go, borrow thee vessels abroad of all thy neighbours, <i>even</i> empty vessels; borrow not a few.

<b>4 </b>And when thou art come in, thou shalt shut the door upon thee and upon thy sons, and shalt pour out into all those vessels, and thou shalt set aside that which is full.

<b>5 </b>So she went from him, and shut the door upon her and upon her sons, who brought <i>the vessels</i> to her; and she poured out.

<b>6 </b>And it came to pass, when the vessels were full, that she said unto her son, Bring me yet a vessel. And he said unto her, <i>There is</i> not a vessel more. And the oil stayed.

<b>7 </b>Then she came and told the man of God. And he said, Go, sell the oil, and pay thy debt, and live thou and thy children of the rest.

<b>8 </b>¶ And it fell on a day, that Elisha passed to Shunem, where <i>was</i> a great woman; and she constrained him to eat bread. And <i>so</i> it was, <i>that</i> as oft as he passed by, he turned in thither to eat bread.

<b>9 </b>And she said unto her husband, Behold now, I perceive that this <i>is</i> an holy man of God, which passeth by us continually.

<b>10 </b>Let us make a little chamber, I pray thee, on the wall; and let us set for him there a bed, and a table, and a stool, and a candlestick: and it shall be, when he cometh to us, that he shall turn in thither.

<b>11 </b>And it fell on a day, that he came thither, and he turned into the chamber, and lay there.

<b>12 </b>And he said to Gehazi his servant, Call this Shunammite. And when he had called her, she stood before him.

<b>13 </b>And he said unto him, Say now unto her, Behold, thou hast been careful for us with all this care; what <i>is</i> to be done for thee? wouldest thou be spoken for to the king, or to the captain of the host? And she answered, I dwell among mine own people.

<b>14 </b>And he said, What then <i>is</i> to be done for her? And Gehazi answered, Verily she hath no child, and her husband is old.

<b>15 </b>And he said, Call her. And when he had called her, she stood in the door.

<b>16 </b>And he said, About this season, according to the time of life, thou shalt embrace a son. And she said, Nay, my lord, <i>thou</i> man of God, do not lie unto thine handmaid.

<b>17 </b>And the woman conceived, and bare a son at that season that Elisha had said unto her, according to the time of life.

<b>18 </b>¶ And when the child was grown, it fell on a day, that he went out to his father to the reapers.

<b>19 </b>And he said unto his father, My head, my head. And he said to a lad, Carry him to his mother.

<b>20 </b>And when he had taken him, and brought him to his mother, he sat on her knees till noon, and <i>then</i> died.

<b>21 </b>And she went up, and laid him on the bed of the man of God, and shut <i>the door</i> upon him, and went out.

<b>22 </b>And she called unto her husband, and said, Send me, I pray thee, one of the young men, and one of the asses, that I may run to the man of God, and come again.

<b>23 </b>And he said, Wherefore wilt thou go to him to day? <i>it is</i> neither new moon, nor sabbath. And she said, <i>It shall be</i> well.

<b>24 </b>Then she saddled an ass, and said to her servant, Drive, and go forward; slack not <i>thy</i> riding for me, except I bid thee.

<b>25 </b>So she went and came unto the man of God to mount Carmel. And it came to pass, when the man of God saw her afar off, that he said to Gehazi his servant, Behold, <i>yonder is</i> that Shunammite:

<b>26 </b>Run now, I pray thee, to meet her, and say unto her, <i>Is it</i> well with thee? <i>is it</i> well with thy husband? <i>is it</i> well with the child? And she answered, <i>It is</i> well.

<b>27 </b>And when she came to the man of God to the hill, she caught him by the feet: but Gehazi came near to thrust her away. And the man of God said, Let her alone; for her soul <i>is</i> vexed within her: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath hid <i>it</i> from me, and hath not told me.

<b>28 </b>Then she said, Did I desire a son of my lord? did I not say, Do not deceive me?

<b>29 </b>Then he said to Gehazi, Gird up thy loins, and take my staff in thine hand, and go thy way: if thou meet any man, salute him not; and if any salute thee, answer him not again: and lay my staff upon the face of the child.

<b>30 </b>And the mother of the child said, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, and <i>as</i> thy soul liveth, I will not leave thee. And he arose, and followed her.

<b>31 </b>And Gehazi passed on before them, and laid the staff upon the face of the child; but <i>there was</i> neither voice, nor hearing. Wherefore he went again to meet him, and told him, saying, The child is not awaked.

<b>32 </b>And when Elisha was come into the house, behold, the child was dead, <i>and</i> laid upon his bed.

<b>33 </b>He went in therefore, and shut the door upon them twain, and prayed unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>34 </b>And he went up, and lay upon the child, and put his mouth upon his mouth, and his eyes upon his eyes, and his hands upon his hands: and he stretched himself upon the child; and the flesh of the child waxed warm.

<b>35 </b>Then he returned, and walked in the house to and fro; and went up, and stretched himself upon him: and the child sneezed seven times, and the child opened his eyes.

<b>36 </b>And he called Gehazi, and said, Call this Shunammite. So he called her. And when she was come in unto him, he said, Take up thy son.

<b>37 </b>Then she went in, and fell at his feet, and bowed herself to the ground, and took up her son, and went out.

<b>38 </b>¶ And Elisha came again to Gilgal: and <i>there was</i> a dearth in the land; and the sons of the prophets <i>were</i> sitting before him: and he said unto his servant, Set on the great pot, and seethe pottage for the sons of the prophets.

<b>39 </b>And one went out into the field to gather herbs, and found a wild vine, and gathered thereof wild gourds his lap full, and came and shred <i>them</i> into the pot of pottage: for they knew <i>them</i> not.

<b>40 </b>So they poured out for the men to eat. And it came to pass, as they were eating of the pottage, that they cried out, and said, O <i>thou</i> man of God, <i>there is</i> death in the pot. And they could not eat <i>thereof.</i>

<b>41 </b>But he said, Then bring meal. And he cast <i>it</i> into the pot; and he said, Pour out for the people, that they may eat. And there was no harm in the pot.

<b>42 </b>¶ And there came a man from Baal-shalisha, and brought the man of God bread of the firstfruits, twenty loaves of barley, and full ears of corn in the husk thereof. And he said, Give unto the people, that they may eat.

<b>43 </b>And his servitor said, What, should I set this before an hundred men? He said again, Give the people, that they may eat: for thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, They shall eat, and shall leave <i>thereof.</i>

<b>44 </b>So he set <i>it</i> before them, and they did eat, and left <i>thereof,</i> according to the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

CHAPTER 5

<b>1 </b>Now Naaman, captain of the host of the king of Syria, was a great man with his master, and honourable, because by him the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had given deliverance unto Syria: he was also a mighty man in valour, <i>but he was</i> a leper.

<b>2 </b>And the Syrians had gone out by companies, and had brought away captive out of the land of Israel a little maid; and she waited on Naaman’s wife.

<b>3 </b>And she said unto her mistress, Would God my lord <i>were</i> with the prophet that <i>is</i> in Samaria! for he would recover him of his leprosy.

<b>4 </b>And <i>one</i> went in, and told his lord, saying, Thus and thus said the maid that <i>is</i> of the land of Israel.

<b>5 </b>And the king of Syria said, Go to, go, and I will send a letter unto the king of Israel. And he departed, and took with him ten talents of silver, and six thousand <i>pieces</i> of gold, and ten changes of raiment.

<b>6 </b>And he brought the letter to the king of Israel, saying, Now when this letter is come unto thee, behold, I have <i>therewith</i> sent Naaman my servant to thee, that thou mayest recover him of his leprosy.

<b>7 </b>And it came to pass, when the king of Israel had read the letter, that he rent his clothes, and said, <i>Am</i> I God, to kill and to make alive, that this man doth send unto me to recover a man of his leprosy? wherefore consider, I pray you, and see how he seeketh a quarrel against me.

<b>8 </b>¶ And it was <i>so,</i> when Elisha the man of God had heard that the king of Israel had rent his clothes, that he sent to the king, saying, Wherefore hast thou rent thy clothes? let him come now to me, and he shall know that there is a prophet in Israel.

<b>9 </b>So Naaman came with his horses and with his chariot, and stood at the door of the house of Elisha.

<b>10 </b>And Elisha sent a messenger unto him, saying, Go and wash in Jordan seven times, and thy flesh shall come again to thee, and thou shalt be clean.

<b>11 </b>But Naaman was wroth, and went away, and said, Behold, I thought, He will surely come out to me, and stand, and call on the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his God, and strike his hand over the place, and recover the leper.

<b>12 </b><i>Are</i> not Abana and Pharpar, rivers of Damascus, better than all the waters of Israel? may I not wash in them, and be clean? So he turned and went away in a rage.

<b>13 </b>And his servants came near, and spake unto him, and said, My father, <i>if</i> the prophet had bid thee <i>do some</i> great thing, wouldest thou not have done <i>it?</i> how much rather then, when he saith to thee, Wash, and be clean?

<b>14 </b>Then went he down, and dipped himself seven times in Jordan, according to the saying of the man of God: and his flesh came again like unto the flesh of a little child, and he was clean.

<b>15 </b>¶ And he returned to the man of God, he and all his company, and came, and stood before him: and he said, Behold, now I know that <i>there is</i> no God in all the earth, but in Israel: now therefore, I pray thee, take a blessing of thy servant.

<b>16 </b>But he said, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, before whom I stand, I will receive none. And he urged him to take <i>it;</i> but he refused.

<b>17 </b>And Naaman said, Shall there not then, I pray thee, be given to thy servant two mules’ burden of earth? for thy servant will henceforth offer neither burnt offering nor sacrifice unto other gods, but unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.
