<b>6 </b>And he said unto me, Solomon thy son, he shall build my house and my courts: for I have chosen him <i>to be</i> my son, and I will be his father.

<b>7 </b>Moreover I will establish his kingdom for ever, if he be constant to do my commandments and my judgments, as at this day.

<b>8 </b>Now therefore in the sight of all Israel the congregation of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and in the audience of our God, keep and seek for all the commandments of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God: that ye may possess this good land, and leave <i>it</i> for an inheritance for your children after you for ever.

<b>9 </b>¶ And thou, Solomon my son, know thou the God of thy father, and serve him with a perfect heart and with a willing mind: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> searcheth all hearts, and understandeth all the imaginations of the thoughts: if thou seek him, he will be found of thee; but if thou forsake him, he will cast thee off for ever.

<b>10 </b>Take heed now; for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath chosen thee to build an house for the sanctuary: be strong, and do <i>it.</i>

<b>11 </b>¶ Then David gave to Solomon his son the pattern of the porch, and of the houses thereof, and of the treasuries thereof, and of the upper chambers thereof, and of the inner parlours thereof, and of the place of the mercy seat,

<b>12 </b>And the pattern of all that he had by the spirit, of the courts of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and of all the chambers round about, of the treasuries of the house of God, and of the treasuries of the dedicated things:

<b>13 </b>Also for the courses of the priests and the Levites, and for all the work of the service of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and for all the vessels of service in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>14 </b><i>He gave</i> of gold by weight for <i>things</i> of gold, for all instruments of all manner of service; <i>silver also</i> for all instruments of silver by weight, for all instruments of every kind of service:

<b>15 </b>Even the weight for the candlesticks of gold, and for their lamps of gold, by weight for every candlestick, and for the lamps thereof: and for the candlesticks of silver by weight, <i>both</i> for the candlestick, and <i>also</i> for the lamps thereof, according to the use of every candlestick.

<b>16 </b>And by weight <i>he gave</i> gold for the tables of shewbread, for every table; and <i>likewise</i> silver for the tables of silver:

<b>17 </b>Also pure gold for the fleshhooks, and the bowls, and the cups: and for the golden basins <i>he gave gold</i> by weight for every basin; and <i>likewise silver</i> by weight for every basin of silver:

<b>18 </b>And for the altar of incense refined gold by weight; and gold for the pattern of the chariot of the cherubims, that spread out <i>their wings,</i> and covered the ark of the covenant of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>19 </b>All <i>this, said David,</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> made me understand in writing by <i>his</i> hand upon me, <i>even</i> all the works of this pattern.

<b>20 </b>And David said to Solomon his son, Be strong and of good courage, and do <i>it:</i> fear not, nor be dismayed: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God, <i>even</i> my God, <i>will be</i> with thee; he will not fail thee, nor forsake thee, until thou hast finished all the work for the service of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>21 </b>And, behold, the courses of the priests and the Levites, <i>even they shall be with thee</i> for all the service of the house of God: and <i>there shall be</i> with thee for all manner of workmanship every willing skilful man, for any manner of service: also the princes and all the people <i>will be</i> wholly at thy commandment.


--------------------

CHAPTER 29

<b>1 </b>Furthermore David the king said unto all the congregation, Solomon my son, whom alone God hath chosen, <i>is yet</i> young and tender, and the work <i>is</i> great: for the palace <i>is</i> not for man, but for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God.

<b>2 </b>Now I have prepared with all my might for the house of my God the gold for <i>things to be made</i> of gold, and the silver for <i>things</i> of silver, and the brass for <i>things</i> of brass, the iron for <i>things</i> of iron, and wood for <i>things</i> of wood; onyx stones, and <i>stones</i> to be set, glistering stones, and of divers colours, and all manner of precious stones, and marble stones in abundance.

<b>3 </b>Moreover, because I have set my affection to the house of my God, I have of mine own proper good, of gold and silver, <i>which</i> I have given to the house of my God, over and above all that I have prepared for the holy house,

<b>4 </b><i>Even</i> three thousand talents of gold, of the gold of Ophir, and seven thousand talents of refined silver, to overlay the walls of the houses <i>withal:</i>

<b>5 </b>The gold for <i>things</i> of gold, and the silver for <i>things</i> of silver, and for all manner of work <i>to be made</i> by the hands of artificers. And who <i>then</i> is willing to consecrate his service this day unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>?

<b>6 </b>¶ Then the chief of the fathers and princes of the tribes of Israel, and the captains of thousands and of hundreds, with the rulers of the king’s work, offered willingly,

<b>7 </b>And gave for the service of the house of God of gold five thousand talents and ten thousand drams, and of silver ten thousand talents, and of brass eighteen thousand talents, and one hundred thousand talents of iron.

<b>8 </b>And they with whom <i>precious</i> stones were found gave <i>them</i> to the treasure of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, by the hand of Jehiel the Gershonite.

<b>9 </b>Then the people rejoiced, for that they offered willingly, because with perfect heart they offered willingly to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and David the king also rejoiced with great joy.

<b>10 </b>¶ Wherefore David blessed the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> before all the congregation: and David said, Blessed <i>be</i> thou, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel our father, for ever and ever.

<b>11 </b>Thine, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>is</i> the greatness, and the power, and the glory, and the victory, and the majesty: for all <i>that is</i> in the heaven and in the earth <i>is thine;</i> thine <i>is</i> the kingdom, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and thou art exalted as head above all.

<b>12 </b>Both riches and honour <i>come</i> of thee, and thou reignest over all; and in thine hand <i>is</i> power and might; and in thine hand <i>it is</i> to make great, and to give strength unto all.

<b>13 </b>Now therefore, our God, we thank thee, and praise thy glorious name.

<b>14 </b>But who <i>am</i> I, and what <i>is</i> my people, that we should be able to offer so willingly after this sort? for all things <i>come</i> of thee, and of thine own have we given thee.

<b>15 </b>For we <i>are</i> strangers before thee, and sojourners, as <i>were</i> all our fathers: our days on the earth <i>are</i> as a shadow, and <i>there is</i> none abiding.

<b>16 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God, all this store that we have prepared to build thee an house for thine holy name <i>cometh</i> of thine hand, and <i>is</i> all thine own.

<b>17 </b>I know also, my God, that thou triest the heart, and hast pleasure in uprightness. As for me, in the uprightness of mine heart I have willingly offered all these things: and now have I seen with joy thy people, which are present here, to offer willingly unto thee.

<b>18 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Abraham, Isaac, and of Israel, our fathers, keep this for ever in the imagination of the thoughts of the heart of thy people, and prepare their heart unto thee:

<b>19 </b>And give unto Solomon my son a perfect heart, to keep thy commandments, thy testimonies, and thy statutes, and to do all <i>these things,</i> and to build the palace, <i>for</i> the which I have made provision.

<b>20 </b>¶ And David said to all the congregation, Now bless the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God. And all the congregation blessed the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of their fathers, and bowed down their heads, and worshipped the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and the king.

<b>21 </b>And they sacrificed sacrifices unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and offered burnt offerings unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, on the morrow after that day, <i>even</i> a thousand bullocks, a thousand rams, <i>and</i> a thousand lambs, with their drink offerings, and sacrifices in abundance for all Israel:

<b>22 </b>And did eat and drink before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> on that day with great gladness. And they made Solomon the son of David king the second time, and anointed <i>him</i> unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>to be</i> the chief governor, and Zadok <i>to be</i> priest.

<b>23 </b>Then Solomon sat on the throne of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> as king instead of David his father, and prospered; and all Israel obeyed him.

<b>24 </b>And all the princes, and the mighty men, and all the sons likewise of king David, submitted themselves unto Solomon the king.

<b>25 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> magnified Solomon exceedingly in the sight of all Israel, and bestowed upon him <i>such</i> royal majesty as had not been on any king before him in Israel.

<b>26 </b>¶ Thus David the son of Jesse reigned over all Israel.

<b>27 </b>And the time that he reigned over Israel <i>was</i> forty years; seven years reigned he in Hebron, and thirty and three <i>years</i> reigned he in Jerusalem.

<b>28 </b>And he died in a good old age, full of days, riches, and honour: and Solomon his son reigned in his stead.

<b>29 </b>Now the acts of David the king, first and last, behold, they <i>are</i> written in the book of Samuel the seer, and in the book of Nathan the prophet, and in the book of Gad the seer,

<b>30 </b>With all his reign and his might, and the times that went over him, and over Israel, and over all the kingdoms of the countries.


--------------------

<small>The Second Book of the </small>Chronicles

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>And Solomon the son of David was strengthened in his kingdom, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his God <i>was</i> with him, and magnified him exceedingly.

<b>2 </b>Then Solomon spake unto all Israel, to the captains of thousands and of hundreds, and to the judges, and to every governor in all Israel, the chief of the fathers.

<b>3 </b>So Solomon, and all the congregation with him, went to the high place that <i>was</i> at Gibeon; for there was the tabernacle of the congregation of God, which Moses the servant of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had made in the wilderness.

<b>4 </b>But the ark of God had David brought up from Kirjath-jearim to <i>the place which</i> David had prepared for it: for he had pitched a tent for it at Jerusalem.

<b>5 </b>Moreover the brasen altar, that Bezaleel the son of Uri, the son of Hur, had made, he put before the tabernacle of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and Solomon and the congregation sought unto it.

<b>6 </b>And Solomon went up thither to the brasen altar before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which <i>was</i> at the tabernacle of the congregation, and offered a thousand burnt offerings upon it.

<b>7 </b>¶ In that night did God appear unto Solomon, and said unto him, Ask what I shall give thee.

<b>8 </b>And Solomon said unto God, Thou hast shewed great mercy unto David my father, and hast made me to reign in his stead.

<b>9 </b>Now, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God, let thy promise unto David my father be established: for thou hast made me king over a people like the dust of the earth in multitude.

<b>10 </b>Give me now wisdom and knowledge, that I may go out and come in before this people: for who can judge this thy people, <i>that is so</i> great?

<b>11 </b>And God said to Solomon, Because this was in thine heart, and thou hast not asked riches, wealth, or honour, nor the life of thine enemies, neither yet hast asked long life; but hast asked wisdom and knowledge for thyself, that thou mayest judge my people, over whom I have made thee king:

<b>12 </b>Wisdom and knowledge <i>is</i> granted unto thee; and I will give thee riches, and wealth, and honour, such as none of the kings have had that <i>have been</i> before thee, neither shall there any after thee have the like.

<b>13 </b>¶ Then Solomon came <i>from his journey</i> to the high place that <i>was</i> at Gibeon to Jerusalem, from before the tabernacle of the congregation, and reigned over Israel.

<b>14 </b>And Solomon gathered chariots and horsemen: and he had a thousand and four hundred chariots, and twelve thousand horsemen, which he placed in the chariot cities, and with the king at Jerusalem.

<b>15 </b>And the king made silver and gold at Jerusalem <i>as plenteous</i> as stones, and cedar trees made he as the sycomore trees that <i>are</i> in the vale for abundance.

<b>16 </b>And Solomon had horses brought out of Egypt, and linen yarn: the king’s merchants received the linen yarn at a price.

<b>17 </b>And they fetched up, and brought forth out of Egypt a chariot for six hundred <i>shekels</i> of silver, and an horse for an hundred and fifty: and so brought they out <i>horses</i> for all the kings of the Hittites, and for the kings of Syria, by their means.


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>And Solomon determined to build an house for the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and an house for his kingdom.

<b>2 </b>And Solomon told out threescore and ten thousand men to bear burdens, and fourscore thousand to hew in the mountain, and three thousand and six hundred to oversee them.

<b>3 </b>¶ And Solomon sent to Huram the king of Tyre, saying, As thou didst deal with David my father, and didst send him cedars to build him an house to dwell therein, <i>even so deal with me.</i>

<b>4 </b>Behold, I build an house to the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God, to dedicate <i>it</i> to him, <i>and</i> to burn before him sweet incense, and for the continual shewbread, and for the burnt offerings morning and evening, on the sabbaths, and on the new moons, and on the solemn feasts of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God. This <i>is an ordinance</i> for ever to Israel.

<b>5 </b>And the house which I build <i>is</i> great: for great <i>is</i> our God above all gods.

<b>6 </b>But who is able to build him an house, seeing the heaven and heaven of heavens cannot contain him? who <i>am</i> I then, that I should build him an house, save only to burn sacrifice before him?

<b>7 </b>Send me now therefore a man cunning to work in gold, and in silver, and in brass, and in iron, and in purple, and crimson, and blue, and that can skill to grave with the cunning men that <i>are</i> with me in Judah and in Jerusalem, whom David my father did provide.

<b>8 </b>Send me also cedar trees, fir trees, and algum trees, out of Lebanon: for I know that thy servants can skill to cut timber in Lebanon; and, behold, my servants <i>shall be</i> with thy servants,

<b>9 </b>Even to prepare me timber in abundance: for the house which I am about to build <i>shall be</i> wonderful great.

<b>10 </b>And, behold, I will give to thy servants, the hewers that cut timber, twenty thousand measures of beaten wheat, and twenty thousand measures of barley, and twenty thousand baths of wine, and twenty thousand baths of oil.

<b>11 </b>¶ Then Huram the king of Tyre answered in writing, which he sent to Solomon, Because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath loved his people, he hath made thee king over them.

<b>12 </b>Huram said moreover, Blessed <i>be</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, that made heaven and earth, who hath given to David the king a wise son, endued with prudence and understanding, that might build an house for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and an house for his kingdom.

<b>13 </b>And now I have sent a cunning man, endued with understanding, of Huram my father’s,

<b>14 </b>The son of a woman of the daughters of Dan, and his father <i>was</i> a man of Tyre, skilful to work in gold, and in silver, in brass, in iron, in stone, and in timber, in purple, in blue, and in fine linen, and in crimson; also to grave any manner of graving, and to find out every device which shall be put to him, with thy cunning men, and with the cunning men of my lord David thy father.

<b>15 </b>Now therefore the wheat, and the barley, the oil, and the wine, which my lord hath spoken of, let him send unto his servants:

<b>16 </b>And we will cut wood out of Lebanon, as much as thou shalt need: and we will bring it to thee in floats by sea to Joppa; and thou shalt carry it up to Jerusalem.

<b>17 </b>¶ And Solomon numbered all the strangers that <i>were</i> in the land of Israel, after the numbering wherewith David his father had numbered them; and they were found an hundred and fifty thousand and three thousand and six hundred.

<b>18 </b>And he set threescore and ten thousand of them <i>to be</i> bearers of burdens, and fourscore thousand <i>to be</i> hewers in the mountain, and three thousand and six hundred overseers to set the people a work.


--------------------

CHAPTER 3

<b>1 </b>Then Solomon began to build the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> at Jerusalem in mount Moriah, where <i>the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span></i> appeared unto David his father, in the place that David had prepared in the threshingfloor of Ornan the Jebusite.

<b>2 </b>And he began to build in the second <i>day</i> of the second month, in the fourth year of his reign.

<b>3 </b>¶ Now these <i>are the things wherein</i> Solomon was instructed for the building of the house of God. The length by cubits after the first measure <i>was</i> threescore cubits, and the breadth twenty cubits.

<b>4 </b>And the porch that <i>was</i> in the front <i>of the house,</i> the length <i>of it was</i> according to the breadth of the house, twenty cubits, and the height <i>was</i> an hundred and twenty: and he overlaid it within with pure gold.

<b>5 </b>And the greater house he ceiled with fir tree, which he overlaid with fine gold, and set thereon palm trees and chains.

<b>6 </b>And he garnished the house with precious stones for beauty: and the gold <i>was</i> gold of Parvaim.

<b>7 </b>He overlaid also the house, the beams, the posts, and the walls thereof, and the doors thereof, with gold; and graved cherubims on the walls.

<b>8 </b>And he made the most holy house, the length whereof <i>was</i> according to the breadth of the house, twenty cubits, and the breadth thereof twenty cubits: and he overlaid it with fine gold, <i>amounting</i> to six hundred talents.

<b>9 </b>And the weight of the nails <i>was</i> fifty shekels of gold. And he overlaid the upper chambers with gold.

<b>10 </b>And in the most holy house he made two cherubims of image work, and overlaid them with gold.

<b>11 </b>¶ And the wings of the cherubims <i>were</i> twenty cubits long: one wing <i>of the one cherub was</i> five cubits, reaching to the wall of the house: and the other wing <i>was likewise</i> five cubits, reaching to the wing of the other cherub.

<b>12 </b>And <i>one</i> wing of the other cherub <i>was</i> five cubits, reaching to the wall of the house: and the other wing <i>was</i> five cubits <i>also,</i> joining to the wing of the other cherub.

<b>13 </b>The wings of these cherubims spread themselves forth twenty cubits: and they stood on their feet, and their faces <i>were</i> inward.

<b>14 </b>¶ And he made the veil <i>of</i> blue, and purple, and crimson, and fine linen, and wrought cherubims thereon.

<b>15 </b>Also he made before the house two pillars of thirty and five cubits high, and the chapiter that <i>was</i> on the top of each of them <i>was</i> five cubits.

<b>16 </b>And he made chains, <i>as</i> in the oracle, and put <i>them</i> on the heads of the pillars; and made an hundred pomegranates, and put <i>them</i> on the chains.

<b>17 </b>And he reared up the pillars before the temple, one on the right hand, and the other on the left; and called the name of that on the right hand Jachin, and the name of that on the left Boaz.


--------------------

CHAPTER 4

<b>1 </b>Moreover he made an altar of brass, twenty cubits the length thereof, and twenty cubits the breadth thereof, and ten cubits the height thereof.

<b>2 </b>¶ Also he made a molten sea of ten cubits from brim to brim, round in compass, and five cubits the height thereof; and a line of thirty cubits did compass it round about.

<b>3 </b>And under it <i>was</i> the similitude of oxen, which did compass it round about: ten in a cubit, compassing the sea round about. Two rows of oxen <i>were</i> cast, when it was cast.

<b>4 </b>It stood upon twelve oxen, three looking toward the north, and three looking toward the west, and three looking toward the south, and three looking toward the east: and the sea <i>was set</i> above upon them, and all their hinder parts <i>were</i> inward.

<b>5 </b>And the thickness of it <i>was</i> an handbreadth, and the brim of it like the work of the brim of a cup, with flowers of lilies; <i>and</i> it received and held three thousand baths.

<b>6 </b>¶ He made also ten lavers, and put five on the right hand, and five on the left, to wash in them: such things as they offered for the burnt offering they washed in them; but the sea <i>was</i> for the priests to wash in.

<b>7 </b>And he made ten candlesticks of gold according to their form, and set <i>them</i> in the temple, five on the right hand, and five on the left.

<b>8 </b>He made also ten tables, and placed <i>them</i> in the temple, five on the right side, and five on the left. And he made an hundred basins of gold.

<b>9 </b>¶ Furthermore he made the court of the priests, and the great court, and doors for the court, and overlaid the doors of them with brass.

<b>10 </b>And he set the sea on the right side of the east end, over against the south.

<b>11 </b>And Huram made the pots, and the shovels, and the basins. And Huram finished the work that he was to make for king Solomon for the house of God;

<b>12 </b><i>To wit,</i> the two pillars, and the pommels, and the chapiters <i>which were</i> on the top of the two pillars, and the two wreaths to cover the two pommels of the chapiters which <i>were</i> on the top of the pillars;

<b>13 </b>And four hundred pomegranates on the two wreaths; two rows of pomegranates on each wreath, to cover the two pommels of the chapiters which <i>were</i> upon the pillars.

<b>14 </b>He made also bases, and lavers made he upon the bases;

<b>15 </b>One sea, and twelve oxen under it.

<b>16 </b>The pots also, and the shovels, and the fleshhooks, and all their instruments, did Huram his father make to king Solomon for the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of bright brass.

<b>17 </b>In the plain of Jordan did the king cast them, in the clay ground between Succoth and Zeredathah.

<b>18 </b>Thus Solomon made all these vessels in great abundance: for the weight of the brass could not be found out.

<b>19 </b>¶ And Solomon made all the vessels that <i>were for</i> the house of God, the golden altar also, and the tables whereon the shewbread <i>was set;</i>

<b>20 </b>Moreover the candlesticks with their lamps, that they should burn after the manner before the oracle, of pure gold;

<b>21 </b>And the flowers, and the lamps, and the tongs, <i>made he of</i> gold, <i>and</i> that perfect gold;

<b>22 </b>And the snuffers, and the basins, and the spoons, and the censers, <i>of</i> pure gold: and the entry of the house, the inner doors thereof for the most holy <i>place,</i> and the doors of the house of the temple, <i>were of</i> gold.


--------------------

CHAPTER 5

<b>1 </b>Thus all the work that Solomon made for the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was finished: and Solomon brought in <i>all</i> the things that David his father had dedicated; and the silver, and the gold, and all the instruments, put he among the treasures of the house of God.

<b>2 </b>¶ Then Solomon assembled the elders of Israel, and all the heads of the tribes, the chief of the fathers of the children of Israel, unto Jerusalem, to bring up the ark of the covenant of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> out of the city of David, which <i>is</i> Zion.

<b>3 </b>Wherefore all the men of Israel assembled themselves unto the king in the feast which <i>was</i> in the seventh month.

<b>4 </b>And all the elders of Israel came; and the Levites took up the ark.

<b>5 </b>And they brought up the ark, and the tabernacle of the congregation, and all the holy vessels that <i>were</i> in the tabernacle, these did the priests <i>and</i> the Levites bring up.

<b>6 </b>Also king Solomon, and all the congregation of Israel that were assembled unto him before the ark, sacrificed sheep and oxen, which could not be told nor numbered for multitude.

<b>7 </b>And the priests brought in the ark of the covenant of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto his place, to the oracle of the house, into the most holy <i>place, even</i> under the wings of the cherubims:

<b>8 </b>For the cherubims spread forth <i>their</i> wings over the place of the ark, and the cherubims covered the ark and the staves thereof above.

<b>9 </b>And they drew out the staves <i>of the ark,</i> that the ends of the staves were seen from the ark before the oracle; but they were not seen without. And there it is unto this day.

<b>10 </b><i>There was</i> nothing in the ark save the two tables which Moses put <i>therein</i> at Horeb, when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> made <i>a covenant</i> with the children of Israel, when they came out of Egypt.

<b>11 </b>¶ And it came to pass, when the priests were come out of the holy <i>place:</i> (for all the priests <i>that were</i> present were sanctified, <i>and</i> did not <i>then</i> wait by course:

<b>12 </b>Also the Levites <i>which were</i> the singers, all of them of Asaph, of Heman, of Jeduthun, with their sons and their brethren, <i>being</i> arrayed in white linen, having cymbals and psalteries and harps, stood at the east end of the altar, and with them an hundred and twenty priests sounding with trumpets:)

<b>13 </b>It came even to pass, as the trumpeters and singers <i>were</i> as one, to make one sound to be heard in praising and thanking the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and when they lifted up <i>their</i> voice with the trumpets and cymbals and instruments of musick, and praised the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>saying,</i> For <i>he is</i> good; for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever: that <i>then</i> the house was filled with a cloud, <i>even</i> the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>;

<b>14 </b>So that the priests could not stand to minister by reason of the cloud: for the glory of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had filled the house of God.


--------------------

CHAPTER 6

<b>1 </b>Then said Solomon, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath said that he would dwell in the thick darkness.

<b>2 </b>But I have built an house of habitation for thee, and a place for thy dwelling for ever.

<b>3 </b>And the king turned his face, and blessed the whole congregation of Israel: and all the congregation of Israel stood.

<b>4 </b>And he said, Blessed <i>be</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, who hath with his hands fulfilled <i>that</i> which he spake with his mouth to my father David, saying,

<b>5 </b>Since the day that I brought forth my people out of the land of Egypt I chose no city among all the tribes of Israel to build an house in, that my name might be there; neither chose I any man to be a ruler over my people Israel:

<b>6 </b>But I have chosen Jerusalem, that my name might be there; and have chosen David to be over my people Israel.

<b>7 </b>Now it was in the heart of David my father to build an house for the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel.

<b>8 </b>But the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said to David my father, Forasmuch as it was in thine heart to build an house for my name, thou didst well in that it was in thine heart:

<b>9 </b>Notwithstanding thou shalt not build the house; but thy son which shall come forth out of thy loins, he shall build the house for my name.

<b>10 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> therefore hath performed his word that he hath spoken: for I am risen up in the room of David my father, and am set on the throne of Israel, as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> promised, and have built the house for the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel.

<b>11 </b>And in it have I put the ark, wherein <i>is</i> the covenant of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that he made with the children of Israel.

<b>12 </b>¶ And he stood before the altar of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in the presence of all the congregation of Israel, and spread forth his hands:

<b>13 </b>For Solomon had made a brasen scaffold, of five cubits long, and five cubits broad, and three cubits high, and had set it in the midst of the court: and upon it he stood, and kneeled down upon his knees before all the congregation of Israel, and spread forth his hands toward heaven,

<b>14 </b>And said, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, <i>there is</i> no God like thee in the heaven, nor in the earth; which keepest covenant, and <i>shewest</i> mercy unto thy servants, that walk before thee with all their hearts:

<b>15 </b>Thou which hast kept with thy servant David my father that which thou hast promised him; and spakest with thy mouth, and hast fulfilled <i>it</i> with thine hand, as <i>it is</i> this day.

<b>16 </b>Now therefore, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, keep with thy servant David my father that which thou hast promised him, saying, There shall not fail thee a man in my sight to sit upon the throne of Israel; yet so that thy children take heed to their way to walk in my law, as thou hast walked before me.

<b>17 </b>Now then, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, let thy word be verified, which thou hast spoken unto thy servant David.

<b>18 </b>But will God in very deed dwell with men on the earth? behold, heaven and the heaven of heavens cannot contain thee; how much less this house which I have built!

<b>19 </b>Have respect therefore to the prayer of thy servant, and to his supplication, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God, to hearken unto the cry and the prayer which thy servant prayeth before thee:

<b>20 </b>That thine eyes may be open upon this house day and night, upon the place whereof thou hast said that thou wouldest put thy name there; to hearken unto the prayer which thy servant prayeth toward this place.

<b>21 </b>Hearken therefore unto the supplications of thy servant, and of thy people Israel, which they shall make toward this place: hear thou from thy dwelling place, <i>even</i> from heaven; and when thou hearest, forgive.

<b>22 </b>¶ If a man sin against his neighbour, and an oath be laid upon him to make him swear, and the oath come before thine altar in this house;

<b>23 </b>Then hear thou from heaven, and do, and judge thy servants, by requiting the wicked, by recompensing his way upon his own head; and by justifying the righteous, by giving him according to his righteousness.

<b>24 </b>¶ And if thy people Israel be put to the worse before the enemy, because they have sinned against thee; and shall return and confess thy name, and pray and make supplication before thee in this house;

<b>25 </b>Then hear thou from the heavens, and forgive the sin of thy people Israel, and bring them again unto the land which thou gavest to them and to their fathers.

<b>26 </b>¶ When the heaven is shut up, and there is no rain, because they have sinned against thee; <i>yet</i> if they pray toward this place, and confess thy name, and turn from their sin, when thou dost afflict them;

<b>27 </b>Then hear thou from heaven, and forgive the sin of thy servants, and of thy people Israel, when thou hast taught them the good way, wherein they should walk; and send rain upon thy land, which thou hast given unto thy people for an inheritance.

<b>28 </b>¶ If there be dearth in the land, if there be pestilence, if there be blasting, or mildew, locusts, or caterpillers; if their enemies besiege them in the cities of their land; whatsoever sore or whatsoever sickness <i>there be:</i>

<b>29 </b><i>Then</i> what prayer <i>or</i> what supplication soever shall be made of any man, or of all thy people Israel, when every one shall know his own sore and his own grief, and shall spread forth his hands in this house:

<b>30 </b>Then hear thou from heaven thy dwelling place, and forgive, and render unto every man according unto all his ways, whose heart thou knowest; (for thou only knowest the hearts of the children of men:)

<b>31 </b>That they may fear thee, to walk in thy ways, so long as they live in the land which thou gavest unto our fathers.

<b>32 </b>¶ Moreover concerning the stranger, which is not of thy people Israel, but is come from a far country for thy great name’s sake, and thy mighty hand, and thy stretched out arm; if they come and pray in this house;

<b>33 </b>Then hear thou from the heavens, <i>even</i> from thy dwelling place, and do according to all that the stranger calleth to thee for; that all people of the earth may know thy name, and fear thee, as <i>doth</i> thy people Israel, and may know that this house which I have built is called by thy name.

<b>34 </b>If thy people go out to war against their enemies by the way that thou shalt send them, and they pray unto thee toward this city which thou hast chosen, and the house which I have built for thy name;

<b>35 </b>Then hear thou from the heavens their prayer and their supplication, and maintain their cause.

<b>36 </b>If they sin against thee, (for <i>there is</i> no man which sinneth not,) and thou be angry with them, and deliver them over before <i>their</i> enemies, and they carry them away captives unto a land far off or near;

<b>37 </b>Yet <i>if</i> they bethink themselves in the land whither they are carried captive, and turn and pray unto thee in the land of their captivity, saying, We have sinned, we have done amiss, and have dealt wickedly;

<b>38 </b>If they return to thee with all their heart and with all their soul in the land of their captivity, whither they have carried them captives, and pray toward their land, which thou gavest unto their fathers, and <i>toward</i> the city which thou hast chosen, and toward the house which I have built for thy name:

<b>39 </b>Then hear thou from the heavens, <i>even</i> from thy dwelling place, their prayer and their supplications, and maintain their cause, and forgive thy people which have sinned against thee.

<b>40 </b>Now, my God, let, I beseech thee, thine eyes be open, and <i>let</i> thine ears <i>be</i> attent unto the prayer <i>that is made</i> in this place.

<b>41 </b>Now therefore arise, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God, into thy resting place, thou, and the ark of thy strength: let thy priests, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God, be clothed with salvation, and let thy saints rejoice in goodness.

<b>42 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God, turn not away the face of thine anointed: remember the mercies of David thy servant.


--------------------

CHAPTER 7

<b>1 </b>Now when Solomon had made an end of praying, the fire came down from heaven, and consumed the burnt offering and the sacrifices; and the glory of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> filled the house.

<b>2 </b>And the priests could not enter into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, because the glory of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had filled the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s house.

<b>3 </b>And when all the children of Israel saw how the fire came down, and the glory of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> upon the house, they bowed themselves with their faces to the ground upon the pavement, and worshipped, and praised the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>saying,</i> For <i>he is</i> good; for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever.

<b>4 </b>¶ Then the king and all the people offered sacrifices before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>5 </b>And king Solomon offered a sacrifice of twenty and two thousand oxen, and an hundred and twenty thousand sheep: so the king and all the people dedicated the house of God.

<b>6 </b>And the priests waited on their offices: the Levites also with instruments of musick of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which David the king had made to praise the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, because his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever, when David praised by their ministry; and the priests sounded trumpets before them, and all Israel stood.

<b>7 </b>Moreover Solomon hallowed the middle of the court that <i>was</i> before the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for there he offered burnt offerings, and the fat of the peace offerings, because the brasen altar which Solomon had made was not able to receive the burnt offerings, and the meat offerings, and the fat.

<b>8 </b>¶ Also at the same time Solomon kept the feast seven days, and all Israel with him, a very great congregation, from the entering in of Hamath unto the river of Egypt.

<b>9 </b>And in the eighth day they made a solemn assembly: for they kept the dedication of the altar seven days, and the feast seven days.

<b>10 </b>And on the three and twentieth day of the seventh month he sent the people away into their tents, glad and merry in heart for the goodness that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had shewed unto David, and to Solomon, and to Israel his people.

<b>11 </b>Thus Solomon finished the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and the king’s house: and all that came into Solomon’s heart to make in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and in his own house, he prosperously effected.

<b>12 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> appeared to Solomon by night, and said unto him, I have heard thy prayer, and have chosen this place to myself for an house of sacrifice.

<b>13 </b>If I shut up heaven that there be no rain, or if I command the locusts to devour the land, or if I send pestilence among my people;

<b>14 </b>If my people, which are called by my name, shall humble themselves, and pray, and seek my face, and turn from their wicked ways; then will I hear from heaven, and will forgive their sin, and will heal their land.

<b>15 </b>Now mine eyes shall be open, and mine ears attent unto the prayer <i>that is made</i> in this place.

<b>16 </b>For now have I chosen and sanctified this house, that my name may be there for ever: and mine eyes and mine heart shall be there perpetually.

<b>17 </b>And as for thee, if thou wilt walk before me, as David thy father walked, and do according to all that I have commanded thee, and shalt observe my statutes and my judgments;

<b>18 </b>Then will I stablish the throne of thy kingdom, according as I have covenanted with David thy father, saying, There shall not fail thee a man <i>to be</i> ruler in Israel.

<b>19 </b>But if ye turn away, and forsake my statutes and my commandments, which I have set before you, and shall go and serve other gods, and worship them;

<b>20 </b>Then will I pluck them up by the roots out of my land which I have given them; and this house, which I have sanctified for my name, will I cast out of my sight, and will make it <i>to be</i> a proverb and a byword among all nations.

<b>21 </b>And this house, which is high, shall be an astonishment to every one that passeth by it; so that he shall say, Why hath the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> done thus unto this land, and unto this house?

<b>22 </b>And it shall be answered, Because they forsook the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of their fathers, which brought them forth out of the land of Egypt, and laid hold on other gods, and worshipped them, and served them: therefore hath he brought all this evil upon them.


--------------------

CHAPTER 8

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass at the end of twenty years, wherein Solomon had built the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and his own house,

<b>2 </b>That the cities which Huram had restored to Solomon, Solomon built them, and caused the children of Israel to dwell there.

<b>3 </b>And Solomon went to Hamath-zobah, and prevailed against it.

<b>4 </b>And he built Tadmor in the wilderness, and all the store cities, which he built in Hamath.

<b>5 </b>Also he built Beth-horon the upper, and Beth-horon the nether, fenced cities, with walls, gates, and bars;

<b>6 </b>And Baalath, and all the store cities that Solomon had, and all the chariot cities, and the cities of the horsemen, and all that Solomon desired to build in Jerusalem, and in Lebanon, and throughout all the land of his dominion.

<b>7 </b>¶ <i>As for</i> all the people <i>that were</i> left of the Hittites, and the Amorites, and the Perizzites, and the Hivites, and the Jebusites, which <i>were</i> not of Israel,

<b>8 </b><i>But</i> of their children, who were left after them in the land, whom the children of Israel consumed not, them did Solomon make to pay tribute until this day.

<b>9 </b>But of the children of Israel did Solomon make no servants for his work; but they <i>were</i> men of war, and chief of his captains, and captains of his chariots and horsemen.

<b>10 </b>And these <i>were</i> the chief of king Solomon’s officers, <i>even</i> two hundred and fifty, that bare rule over the people.

<b>11 </b>¶ And Solomon brought up the daughter of Pharaoh out of the city of David unto the house that he had built for her: for he said, My wife shall not dwell in the house of David king of Israel, because <i>the places are</i> holy, whereunto the ark of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath come.

<b>12 </b>¶ Then Solomon offered burnt offerings unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> on the altar of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which he had built before the porch,

<b>13 </b>Even after a certain rate every day, offering according to the commandment of Moses, on the sabbaths, and on the new moons, and on the solemn feasts, three times in the year, <i>even</i> in the feast of unleavened bread, and in the feast of weeks, and in the feast of tabernacles.

<b>14 </b>¶ And he appointed, according to the order of David his father, the courses of the priests to their service, and the Levites to their charges, to praise and minister before the priests, as the duty of every day required: the porters also by their courses at every gate: for so had David the man of God commanded.

<b>15 </b>And they departed not from the commandment of the king unto the priests and Levites concerning any matter, or concerning the treasures.

<b>16 </b>Now all the work of Solomon was prepared unto the day of the foundation of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and until it was finished. <i>So</i> the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was perfected.

<b>17 </b>¶ Then went Solomon to Ezion-geber, and to Eloth, at the sea side in the land of Edom.

<b>18 </b>And Huram sent him by the hands of his servants ships, and servants that had knowledge of the sea; and they went with the servants of Solomon to Ophir, and took thence four hundred and fifty talents of gold, and brought <i>them</i> to king Solomon.


--------------------

CHAPTER 9

<b>1 </b>And when the queen of Sheba heard of the fame of Solomon, she came to prove Solomon with hard questions at Jerusalem, with a very great company, and camels that bare spices, and gold in abundance, and precious stones: and when she was come to Solomon, she communed with him of all that was in her heart.

<b>2 </b>And Solomon told her all her questions: and there was nothing hid from Solomon which he told her not.

<b>3 </b>And when the queen of Sheba had seen the wisdom of Solomon, and the house that he had built,

<b>4 </b>And the meat of his table, and the sitting of his servants, and the attendance of his ministers, and their apparel; his cupbearers also, and their apparel; and his ascent by which he went up into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; there was no more spirit in her.

<b>5 </b>And she said to the king, <i>It was</i> a true report which I heard in mine own land of thine acts, and of thy wisdom:

<b>6 </b>Howbeit I believed not their words, until I came, and mine eyes had seen <i>it:</i> and, behold, the one half of the greatness of thy wisdom was not told me: <i>for</i> thou exceedest the fame that I heard.

<b>7 </b>Happy <i>are</i> thy men, and happy <i>are</i> these thy servants, which stand continually before thee, and hear thy wisdom.

<b>8 </b>Blessed be the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, which delighted in thee to set thee on his throne, <i>to be</i> king for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God: because thy God loved Israel, to establish them for ever, therefore made he thee king over them, to do judgment and justice.

<b>9 </b>And she gave the king an hundred and twenty talents of gold, and of spices great abundance, and precious stones: neither was there any such spice as the queen of Sheba gave king Solomon.

<b>10 </b>And the servants also of Huram, and the servants of Solomon, which brought gold from Ophir, brought algum trees and precious stones.

<b>11 </b>And the king made <i>of</i> the algum trees terraces to the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and to the king’s palace, and harps and psalteries for singers: and there were none such seen before in the land of Judah.

<b>12 </b>And king Solomon gave to the queen of Sheba all her desire, whatsoever she asked, beside <i>that</i> which she had brought unto the king. So she turned, and went away to her own land, she and her servants.

<b>13 </b>¶ Now the weight of gold that came to Solomon in one year was six hundred and threescore and six talents of gold;

<b>14 </b>Beside <i>that which</i> chapmen and merchants brought. And all the kings of Arabia and governors of the country brought gold and silver to Solomon.

<b>15 </b>¶ And king Solomon made two hundred targets <i>of</i> beaten gold: six hundred <i>shekels</i> of beaten gold went to one target.

<b>16 </b>And three hundred shields <i>made he of</i> beaten gold: three hundred <i>shekels</i> of gold went to one shield. And the king put them in the house of the forest of Lebanon.

<b>17 </b>Moreover the king made a great throne of ivory, and overlaid it with pure gold.

<b>18 </b>And <i>there were</i> six steps to the throne, with a footstool of gold, <i>which were</i> fastened to the throne, and stays on each side of the sitting place, and two lions standing by the stays:

<b>19 </b>And twelve lions stood there on the one side and on the other upon the six steps. There was not the like made in any kingdom.

<b>20 </b>¶ And all the drinking vessels of king Solomon <i>were of</i> gold, and all the vessels of the house of the forest of Lebanon <i>were of</i> pure gold: none <i>were of</i> silver; it was <i>not</i> any thing accounted of in the days of Solomon.

<b>21 </b>For the king’s ships went to Tarshish with the servants of Huram: every three years once came the ships of Tarshish bringing gold, and silver, ivory, and apes, and peacocks.

<b>22 </b>And king Solomon passed all the kings of the earth in riches and wisdom.

<b>23 </b>¶ And all the kings of the earth sought the presence of Solomon, to hear his wisdom, that God had put in his heart.

<b>24 </b>And they brought every man his present, vessels of silver, and vessels of gold, and raiment, harness, and spices, horses, and mules, a rate year by year.

<b>25 </b>¶ And Solomon had four thousand stalls for horses and chariots, and twelve thousand horsemen; whom he bestowed in the chariot cities, and with the king at Jerusalem.

<b>26 </b>¶ And he reigned over all the kings from the river even unto the land of the Philistines, and to the border of Egypt.

<b>27 </b>And the king made silver in Jerusalem as stones, and cedar trees made he as the sycomore trees that <i>are</i> in the low plains in abundance.

<b>28 </b>And they brought unto Solomon horses out of Egypt, and out of all lands.

<b>29 </b>¶ Now the rest of the acts of Solomon, first and last, <i>are</i> they not written in the book of Nathan the prophet, and in the prophecy of Ahijah the Shilonite, and in the visions of Iddo the seer against Jeroboam the son of Nebat?

<b>30 </b>And Solomon reigned in Jerusalem over all Israel forty years.

<b>31 </b>And Solomon slept with his fathers, and he was buried in the city of David his father: and Rehoboam his son reigned in his stead.


--------------------

CHAPTER 10

<b>1 </b>And Rehoboam went to Shechem: for to Shechem were all Israel come to make him king.

<b>2 </b>And it came to pass, when Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who <i>was</i> in Egypt, whither he had fled from the presence of Solomon the king, heard <i>it,</i> that Jeroboam returned out of Egypt.

<b>3 </b>And they sent and called him. So Jeroboam and all Israel came and spake to Rehoboam, saying,

<b>4 </b>Thy father made our yoke grievous: now therefore ease thou somewhat the grievous servitude of thy father, and his heavy yoke that he put upon us, and we will serve thee.

<b>5 </b>And he said unto them, Come again unto me after three days. And the people departed.

<b>6 </b>¶ And king Rehoboam took counsel with the old men that had stood before Solomon his father while he yet lived, saying, What counsel give ye <i>me</i> to return answer to this people?

<b>7 </b>And they spake unto him, saying, If thou be kind to this people, and please them, and speak good words to them, they will be thy servants for ever.

<b>8 </b>But he forsook the counsel which the old men gave him, and took counsel with the young men that were brought up with him, that stood before him.

<b>9 </b>And he said unto them, What advice give ye that we may return answer to this people, which have spoken to me, saying, Ease somewhat the yoke that thy father did put upon us?

<b>10 </b>And the young men that were brought up with him spake unto him, saying, Thus shalt thou answer the people that spake unto thee, saying, Thy father made our yoke heavy, but make thou <i>it</i> somewhat lighter for us; thus shalt thou say unto them, My little <i>finger</i> shall be thicker than my father’s loins.

<b>11 </b>For whereas my father put a heavy yoke upon you, I will put more to your yoke: my father chastised you with whips, but I <i>will chastise you</i> with scorpions.

<b>12 </b>So Jeroboam and all the people came to Rehoboam on the third day, as the king bade, saying, Come again to me on the third day.

<b>13 </b>And the king answered them roughly; and king Rehoboam forsook the counsel of the old men,

<b>14 </b>And answered them after the advice of the young men, saying, My father made your yoke heavy, but I will add thereto: my father chastised you with whips, but I <i>will chastise you</i> with scorpions.

<b>15 </b>So the king hearkened not unto the people: for the cause was of God, that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> might perform his word, which he spake by the hand of Ahijah the Shilonite to Jeroboam the son of Nebat.

<b>16 </b>¶ And when all Israel <i>saw</i> that the king would not hearken unto them, the people answered the king, saying, What portion have we in David? and <i>we have</i> none inheritance in the son of Jesse: every man to your tents, O Israel: <i>and</i> now, David, see to thine own house. So all Israel went to their tents.

<b>17 </b>But <i>as for</i> the children of Israel that dwelt in the cities of Judah, Rehoboam reigned over them.

<b>18 </b>Then king Rehoboam sent Hadoram that <i>was</i> over the tribute; and the children of Israel stoned him with stones, that he died. But king Rehoboam made speed to get him up to <i>his</i> chariot, to flee to Jerusalem.

<b>19 </b>And Israel rebelled against the house of David unto this day.


--------------------

CHAPTER 11

<b>1 </b>And when Rehoboam was come to Jerusalem, he gathered of the house of Judah and Benjamin an hundred and fourscore thousand chosen <i>men,</i> which were warriors, to fight against Israel, that he might bring the kingdom again to Rehoboam.

<b>2 </b>But the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came to Shemaiah the man of God, saying,

<b>3 </b>Speak unto Rehoboam the son of Solomon, king of Judah, and to all Israel in Judah and Benjamin, saying,

<b>4 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Ye shall not go up, nor fight against your brethren: return every man to his house: for this thing is done of me. And they obeyed the words of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and returned from going against Jeroboam.

<b>5 </b>¶ And Rehoboam dwelt in Jerusalem, and built cities for defence in Judah.

<b>6 </b>He built even Beth-lehem, and Etam, and Tekoa,

<b>7 </b>And Beth-zur, and Shoco, and Adullam,

<b>8 </b>And Gath, and Mareshah, and Ziph,

<b>9 </b>And Adoraim, and Lachish, and Azekah,

<b>10 </b>And Zorah, and Aijalon, and Hebron, which <i>are</i> in Judah and in Benjamin fenced cities.

<b>11 </b>And he fortified the strong holds, and put captains in them, and store of victual, and of oil and wine.

<b>12 </b>And in every several city <i>he put</i> shields and spears, and made them exceeding strong, having Judah and Benjamin on his side.

<b>13 </b>¶ And the priests and the Levites that <i>were</i> in all Israel resorted to him out of all their coasts.

<b>14 </b>For the Levites left their suburbs and their possession, and came to Judah and Jerusalem: for Jeroboam and his sons had cast them off from executing the priest’s office unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>:

<b>15 </b>And he ordained him priests for the high places, and for the devils, and for the calves which he had made.

<b>16 </b>And after them out of all the tribes of Israel such as set their hearts to seek the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel came to Jerusalem, to sacrifice unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of their fathers.

<b>17 </b>So they strengthened the kingdom of Judah, and made Rehoboam the son of Solomon strong, three years: for three years they walked in the way of David and Solomon.

<b>18 </b>¶ And Rehoboam took him Mahalath the daughter of Jerimoth the son of David to wife, <i>and</i> Abihail the daughter of Eliab the son of Jesse;

<b>19 </b>Which bare him children; Jeush, and Shamariah, and Zaham.

<b>20 </b>And after her he took Maachah the daughter of Absalom; which bare him Abijah, and Attai, and Ziza, and Shelomith.

<b>21 </b>And Rehoboam loved Maachah the daughter of Absalom above all his wives and his concubines: (for he took eighteen wives, and threescore concubines; and begat twenty and eight sons, and threescore daughters.)

<b>22 </b>And Rehoboam made Abijah the son of Maachah the chief, <i>to be</i> ruler among his brethren: for <i>he thought</i> to make him king.

<b>23 </b>And he dealt wisely, and dispersed of all his children throughout all the countries of Judah and Benjamin, unto every fenced city: and he gave them victual in abundance. And he desired many wives.


--------------------

CHAPTER 12

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass, when Rehoboam had established the kingdom, and had strengthened himself, he forsook the law of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and all Israel with him.

<b>2 </b>And it came to pass, <i>that</i> in the fifth year of king Rehoboam Shishak king of Egypt came up against Jerusalem, because they had transgressed against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>,

<b>3 </b>With twelve hundred chariots, and threescore thousand horsemen: and the people <i>were</i> without number that came with him out of Egypt; the Lubims, the Sukkiims, and the Ethiopians.

<b>4 </b>And he took the fenced cities which <i>pertained</i> to Judah, and came to Jerusalem.

<b>5 </b>¶ Then came Shemaiah the prophet to Rehoboam, and <i>to</i> the princes of Judah, that were gathered together to Jerusalem because of Shishak, and said unto them, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Ye have forsaken me, and therefore have I also left you in the hand of Shishak.

<b>6 </b>Whereupon the princes of Israel and the king humbled themselves; and they said, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> righteous.

<b>7 </b>And when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> saw that they humbled themselves, the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came to Shemaiah, saying, They have humbled themselves; <i>therefore</i> I will not destroy them, but I will grant them some deliverance; and my wrath shall not be poured out upon Jerusalem by the hand of Shishak.

<b>8 </b>Nevertheless they shall be his servants; that they may know my service, and the service of the kingdoms of the countries.

<b>9 </b>So Shishak king of Egypt came up against Jerusalem, and took away the treasures of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and the treasures of the king’s house; he took all: he carried away also the shields of gold which Solomon had made.

<b>10 </b>Instead of which king Rehoboam made shields of brass, and committed <i>them</i> to the hands of the chief of the guard, that kept the entrance of the king’s house.

<b>11 </b>And when the king entered into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the guard came and fetched them, and brought them again into the guard chamber.

<b>12 </b>And when he humbled himself, the wrath of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> turned from him, that he would not destroy <i>him</i> altogether: and also in Judah things went well.

<b>13 </b>¶ So king Rehoboam strengthened himself in Jerusalem, and reigned: for Rehoboam <i>was</i> one and forty years old when he began to reign, and he reigned seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had chosen out of all the tribes of Israel, to put his name there. And his mother’s name <i>was</i> Naamah an Ammonitess.

<b>14 </b>And he did evil, because he prepared not his heart to seek the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>15 </b>Now the acts of Rehoboam, first and last, <i>are</i> they not written in the book of Shemaiah the prophet, and of Iddo the seer concerning genealogies? And <i>there were</i> wars between Rehoboam and Jeroboam continually.

<b>16 </b>And Rehoboam slept with his fathers, and was buried in the city of David: and Abijah his son reigned in his stead.


--------------------

CHAPTER 13

<b>1 </b>Now in the eighteenth year of king Jeroboam began Abijah to reign over Judah.

<b>2 </b>He reigned three years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name also <i>was</i> Michaiah the daughter of Uriel of Gibeah. And there was war between Abijah and Jeroboam.

<b>3 </b>And Abijah set the battle in array with an army of valiant men of war, <i>even</i> four hundred thousand chosen men: Jeroboam also set the battle in array against him with eight hundred thousand chosen men, <i>being</i> mighty men of valour.

<b>4 </b>¶ And Abijah stood up upon mount Zemaraim, which <i>is</i> in mount Ephraim, and said, Hear me, thou Jeroboam, and all Israel;

<b>5 </b>Ought ye not to know that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel gave the kingdom over Israel to David for ever, <i>even</i> to him and to his sons by a covenant of salt?

<b>6 </b>Yet Jeroboam the son of Nebat, the servant of Solomon the son of David, is risen up, and hath rebelled against his lord.

<b>7 </b>And there are gathered unto him vain men, the children of Belial, and have strengthened themselves against Rehoboam the son of Solomon, when Rehoboam was young and tenderhearted, and could not withstand them.

<b>8 </b>And now ye think to withstand the kingdom of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in the hand of the sons of David; and ye <i>be</i> a great multitude, and <i>there are</i> with you golden calves, which Jeroboam made you for gods.

<b>9 </b>Have ye not cast out the priests of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the sons of Aaron, and the Levites, and have made you priests after the manner of the nations of <i>other</i> lands? so that whosoever cometh to consecrate himself with a young bullock and seven rams, <i>the same</i> may be a priest of <i>them that are</i> no gods.

<b>10 </b>But as for us, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> our God, and we have not forsaken him; and the priests, which minister unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>are</i> the sons of Aaron, and the Levites <i>wait</i> upon <i>their</i> business:

<b>11 </b>And they burn unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> every morning and every evening burnt sacrifices and sweet incense: the shewbread also <i>set they in order</i> upon the pure table; and the candlestick of gold with the lamps thereof, to burn every evening: for we keep the charge of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God; but ye have forsaken him.

<b>12 </b>And, behold, God himself <i>is</i> with us for <i>our</i> captain, and his priests with sounding trumpets to cry alarm against you. O children of Israel, fight ye not against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of your fathers; for ye shall not prosper.

<b>13 </b>¶ But Jeroboam caused an ambushment to come about behind them: so they were before Judah, and the ambushment <i>was</i> behind them.

<b>14 </b>And when Judah looked back, behold, the battle <i>was</i> before and behind: and they cried unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and the priests sounded with the trumpets.

<b>15 </b>Then the men of Judah gave a shout: and as the men of Judah shouted, it came to pass, that God smote Jeroboam and all Israel before Abijah and Judah.

<b>16 </b>And the children of Israel fled before Judah: and God delivered them into their hand.

<b>17 </b>And Abijah and his people slew them with a great slaughter: so there fell down slain of Israel five hundred thousand chosen men.

<b>18 </b>Thus the children of Israel were brought under at that time, and the children of Judah prevailed, because they relied upon the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of their fathers.

<b>19 </b>And Abijah pursued after Jeroboam, and took cities from him, Beth-el with the towns thereof, and Jeshanah with the towns thereof, and Ephrain with the towns thereof.

<b>20 </b>Neither did Jeroboam recover strength again in the days of Abijah: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> struck him, and he died.

<b>21 </b>¶ But Abijah waxed mighty, and married fourteen wives, and begat twenty and two sons, and sixteen daughters.

<b>22 </b>And the rest of the acts of Abijah, and his ways, and his sayings, <i>are</i> written in the story of the prophet Iddo.


--------------------

CHAPTER 14

<b>1 </b>So Abijah slept with his fathers, and they buried him in the city of David: and Asa his son reigned in his stead. In his days the land was quiet ten years.

<b>2 </b>And Asa did <i>that which was</i> good and right in the eyes of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his God:

<b>3 </b>For he took away the altars of the strange <i>gods,</i> and the high places, and brake down the images, and cut down the groves:

<b>4 </b>And commanded Judah to seek the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of their fathers, and to do the law and the commandment.

<b>5 </b>Also he took away out of all the cities of Judah the high places and the images: and the kingdom was quiet before him.

<b>6 </b>¶ And he built fenced cities in Judah: for the land had rest, and he had no war in those years; because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had given him rest.

<b>7 </b>Therefore he said unto Judah, Let us build these cities, and make about <i>them</i> walls, and towers, gates, and bars, <i>while</i> the land <i>is</i> yet before us; because we have sought the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God, we have sought <i>him,</i> and he hath given us rest on every side. So they built and prospered.

<b>8 </b>And Asa had an army <i>of men</i> that bare targets and spears, out of Judah three hundred thousand; and out of Benjamin, that bare shields and drew bows, two hundred and fourscore thousand: all these <i>were</i> mighty men of valour.

<b>9 </b>¶ And there came out against them Zerah the Ethiopian with an host of a thousand thousand, and three hundred chariots; and came unto Mareshah.

<b>10 </b>Then Asa went out against him, and they set the battle in array in the valley of Zephathah at Mareshah.

<b>11 </b>And Asa cried unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his God, and said, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>it is</i> nothing with thee to help, whether with many, or with them that have no power: help us, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God; for we rest on thee, and in thy name we go against this multitude. O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, thou <i>art</i> our God; let not man prevail against thee.

<b>12 </b>So the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> smote the Ethiopians before Asa, and before Judah; and the Ethiopians fled.

<b>13 </b>And Asa and the people that <i>were</i> with him pursued them unto Gerar: and the Ethiopians were overthrown, that they could not recover themselves; for they were destroyed before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and before his host; and they carried away very much spoil.

<b>14 </b>And they smote all the cities round about Gerar; for the fear of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came upon them: and they spoiled all the cities; for there was exceeding much spoil in them.

<b>15 </b>They smote also the tents of cattle, and carried away sheep and camels in abundance, and returned to Jerusalem.


--------------------

CHAPTER 15

<b>1 </b>And the Spirit of God came upon Azariah the son of Oded:

<b>2 </b>And he went out to meet Asa, and said unto him, Hear ye me, Asa, and all Judah and Benjamin; The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> with you, while ye be with him; and if ye seek him, he will be found of you; but if ye forsake him, he will forsake you.

<b>3 </b>Now for a long season Israel <i>hath been</i> without the true God, and without a teaching priest, and without law.

<b>4 </b>But when they in their trouble did turn unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, and sought him, he was found of them.

<b>5 </b>And in those times <i>there was</i> no peace to him that went out, nor to him that came in, but great vexations <i>were</i> upon all the inhabitants of the countries.

<b>6 </b>And nation was destroyed of nation, and city of city: for God did vex them with all adversity.

<b>7 </b>Be ye strong therefore, and let not your hands be weak: for your work shall be rewarded.

<b>8 </b>And when Asa heard these words, and the prophecy of Oded the prophet, he took courage, and put away the abominable idols out of all the land of Judah and Benjamin, and out of the cities which he had taken from mount Ephraim, and renewed the altar of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that <i>was</i> before the porch of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>9 </b>And he gathered all Judah and Benjamin, and the strangers with them out of Ephraim and Manasseh, and out of Simeon: for they fell to him out of Israel in abundance, when they saw that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his God <i>was</i> with him.

<b>10 </b>So they gathered themselves together at Jerusalem in the third month, in the fifteenth year of the reign of Asa.

<b>11 </b>And they offered unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> the same time, of the spoil <i>which</i> they had brought, seven hundred oxen and seven thousand sheep.

<b>12 </b>And they entered into a covenant to seek the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of their fathers with all their heart and with all their soul;

<b>13 </b>That whosoever would not seek the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel should be put to death, whether small or great, whether man or woman.

<b>14 </b>And they sware unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with a loud voice, and with shouting, and with trumpets, and with cornets.

<b>15 </b>And all Judah rejoiced at the oath: for they had sworn with all their heart, and sought him with their whole desire; and he was found of them: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> gave them rest round about.

<b>16 </b>¶ And also <i>concerning</i> Maachah the mother of Asa the king, he removed her from <i>being</i> queen, because she had made an idol in a grove: and Asa cut down her idol, and stamped <i>it,</i> and burnt <i>it</i> at the brook Kidron.

<b>17 </b>But the high places were not taken away out of Israel: nevertheless the heart of Asa was perfect all his days.

<b>18 </b>¶ And he brought into the house of God the things that his father had dedicated, and that he himself had dedicated, silver, and gold, and vessels.

<b>19 </b>And there was no <i>more</i> war unto the five and thirtieth year of the reign of Asa.


--------------------

CHAPTER 16

<b>1 </b>In the six and thirtieth year of the reign of Asa Baasha king of Israel came up against Judah, and built Ramah, to the intent that he might let none go out or come in to Asa king of Judah.

<b>2 </b>Then Asa brought out silver and gold out of the treasures of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> and of the king’s house, and sent to Ben-hadad king of Syria, that dwelt at Damascus, saying,

<b>3 </b><i>There is</i> a league between me and thee, as <i>there was</i> between my father and thy father: behold, I have sent thee silver and gold; go, break thy league with Baasha king of Israel, that he may depart from me.

<b>4 </b>And Ben-hadad hearkened unto king Asa, and sent the captains of his armies against the cities of Israel; and they smote Ijon, and Dan, and Abel-maim, and all the store cities of Naphtali.

<b>5 </b>And it came to pass, when Baasha heard <i>it,</i> that he left off building of Ramah, and let his work cease.

<b>6 </b>Then Asa the king took all Judah; and they carried away the stones of Ramah, and the timber thereof, wherewith Baasha was building; and he built therewith Geba and Mizpah.

<b>7 </b>¶ And at that time Hanani the seer came to Asa king of Judah, and said unto him, Because thou hast relied on the king of Syria, and not relied on the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, therefore is the host of the king of Syria escaped out of thine hand.

<b>8 </b>Were not the Ethiopians and the Lubims a huge host, with very many chariots and horsemen? yet, because thou didst rely on the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, he delivered them into thine hand.

<b>9 </b>For the eyes of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> run to and fro throughout the whole earth, to shew himself strong in the behalf of <i>them</i> whose heart <i>is</i> perfect toward him. Herein thou hast done foolishly: therefore from henceforth thou shalt have wars.

<b>10 </b>Then Asa was wroth with the seer, and put him in a prison house; for <i>he was</i> in a rage with him because of this <i>thing.</i> And Asa oppressed <i>some</i> of the people the same time.

<b>11 </b>¶ And, behold, the acts of Asa, first and last, lo, they <i>are</i> written in the book of the kings of Judah and Israel.

<b>12 </b>And Asa in the thirty and ninth year of his reign was diseased in his feet, until his disease <i>was</i> exceeding <i>great:</i> yet in his disease he sought not to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, but to the physicians.

<b>13 </b>¶ And Asa slept with his fathers, and died in the one and fortieth year of his reign.

<b>14 </b>And they buried him in his own sepulchres, which he had made for himself in the city of David, and laid him in the bed which was filled with sweet odours and divers kinds <i>of spices</i> prepared by the apothecaries’ art: and they made a very great burning for him.


--------------------

CHAPTER 17

<b>1 </b>And Jehoshaphat his son reigned in his stead, and strengthened himself against Israel.

<b>2 </b>And he placed forces in all the fenced cities of Judah, and set garrisons in the land of Judah, and in the cities of Ephraim, which Asa his father had taken.

<b>3 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was with Jehoshaphat, because he walked in the first ways of his father David, and sought not unto Baalim;

<b>4 </b>But sought to the <i><span class="small-caps">Lord</span></i> God of his father, and walked in his commandments, and not after the doings of Israel.

<b>5 </b>Therefore the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> stablished the kingdom in his hand; and all Judah brought to Jehoshaphat presents; and he had riches and honour in abundance.

<b>6 </b>And his heart was lifted up in the ways of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: moreover he took away the high places and groves out of Judah.

<b>7 </b>¶ Also in the third year of his reign he sent to his princes, <i>even</i> to Ben-hail, and to Obadiah, and to Zechariah, and to Nethaneel, and to Michaiah, to teach in the cities of Judah.

<b>8 </b>And with them <i>he sent</i> Levites, <i>even</i> Shemaiah, and Nethaniah, and Zebadiah, and Asahel, and Shemiramoth, and Jehonathan, and Adonijah, and Tobijah, and Tob-adonijah, Levites; and with them Elishama and Jehoram, priests.

<b>9 </b>And they taught in Judah, and <i>had</i> the book of the law of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with them, and went about throughout all the cities of Judah, and taught the people.

<b>10 </b>¶ And the fear of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> fell upon all the kingdoms of the lands that <i>were</i> round about Judah, so that they made no war against Jehoshaphat.

<b>11 </b>Also <i>some</i> of the Philistines brought Jehoshaphat presents, and tribute silver; and the Arabians brought him flocks, seven thousand and seven hundred rams, and seven thousand and seven hundred he goats.

<b>12 </b>¶ And Jehoshaphat waxed great exceedingly; and he built in Judah castles, and cities of store.

<b>13 </b>And he had much business in the cities of Judah: and the men of war, mighty men of valour, <i>were</i> in Jerusalem.

<b>14 </b>And these <i>are</i> the numbers of them according to the house of their fathers: Of Judah, the captains of thousands; Adnah the chief, and with him mighty men of valour three hundred thousand.

<b>15 </b>And next to him <i>was</i> Jehohanan the captain, and with him two hundred and fourscore thousand.

<b>16 </b>And next him <i>was</i> Amasiah the son of Zichri, who willingly offered himself unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and with him two hundred thousand mighty men of valour.

<b>17 </b>And of Benjamin; Eliada a mighty man of valour, and with him armed men with bow and shield two hundred thousand.

<b>18 </b>And next him <i>was</i> Jehozabad, and with him an hundred and fourscore thousand ready prepared for the war.

<b>19 </b>These waited on the king, beside <i>those</i> whom the king put in the fenced cities throughout all Judah.


--------------------

CHAPTER 18

<b>1 </b>Now Jehoshaphat had riches and honour in abundance, and joined affinity with Ahab.

<b>2 </b>And after <i>certain</i> years he went down to Ahab to Samaria. And Ahab killed sheep and oxen for him in abundance, and for the people that <i>he had</i> with him, and persuaded him to go up <i>with him</i> to Ramoth-gilead.

<b>3 </b>And Ahab king of Israel said unto Jehoshaphat king of Judah, Wilt thou go with me to Ramoth-gilead? And he answered him, I <i>am</i> as thou <i>art,</i> and my people as thy people; and <i>we will be</i> with thee in the war.

<b>4 </b>¶ And Jehoshaphat said unto the king of Israel, Inquire, I pray thee, at the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> to day.

<b>5 </b>Therefore the king of Israel gathered together of prophets four hundred men, and said unto them, Shall we go to Ramoth-gilead to battle, or shall I forbear? And they said, Go up; for God will deliver <i>it</i> into the king’s hand.

<b>6 </b>But Jehoshaphat said, <i>Is there</i> not here a prophet of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> besides, that we might inquire of him?

<b>7 </b>And the king of Israel said unto Jehoshaphat, <i>There is</i> yet one man, by whom we may inquire of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: but I hate him; for he never prophesied good unto me, but always evil: the same <i>is</i> Micaiah the son of Imla. And Jehoshaphat said, Let not the king say so.

<b>8 </b>And the king of Israel called for one <i>of his</i> officers, and said, Fetch quickly Micaiah the son of Imla.

<b>9 </b>And the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat king of Judah sat either of them on his throne, clothed in <i>their</i> robes, and they sat in a void place at the entering in of the gate of Samaria; and all the prophets prophesied before them.

<b>10 </b>And Zedekiah the son of Chenaanah had made him horns of iron, and said, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, With these thou shalt push Syria until they be consumed.

<b>11 </b>And all the prophets prophesied so, saying, Go up to Ramoth-gilead, and prosper: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall deliver <i>it</i> into the hand of the king.

<b>12 </b>And the messenger that went to call Micaiah spake to him, saying, Behold, the words of the prophets <i>declare</i> good to the king with one assent; let thy word therefore, I pray thee, be like one of theirs, and speak thou good.

<b>13 </b>And Micaiah said, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, even what my God saith, that will I speak.

<b>14 </b>And when he was come to the king, the king said unto him, Micaiah, shall we go to Ramoth-gilead to battle, or shall I forbear? And he said, Go ye up, and prosper, and they shall be delivered into your hand.

<b>15 </b>And the king said to him, How many times shall I adjure thee that thou say nothing but the truth to me in the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>?

<b>16 </b>Then he said, I did see all Israel scattered upon the mountains, as sheep that have no shepherd: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said, These have no master; let them return <i>therefore</i> every man to his house in peace.

<b>17 </b>And the king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, Did I not tell thee <i>that</i> he would not prophesy good unto me, but evil?

<b>18 </b>Again he said, Therefore hear the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; I saw the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sitting upon his throne, and all the host of heaven standing on his right hand and <i>on</i> his left.

<b>19 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said, Who shall entice Ahab king of Israel, that he may go up and fall at Ramoth-gilead? And one spake saying after this manner, and another saying after that manner.
