<b>20 </b>Then there came out a spirit, and stood before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and said, I will entice him. And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto him, Wherewith?

<b>21 </b>And he said, I will go out, and be a lying spirit in the mouth of all his prophets. And <i>the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span></i> said, Thou shalt entice <i>him,</i> and thou shalt also prevail: go out, and do <i>even</i> so.

<b>22 </b>Now therefore, behold, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath put a lying spirit in the mouth of these thy prophets, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath spoken evil against thee.

<b>23 </b>Then Zedekiah the son of Chenaanah came near, and smote Micaiah upon the cheek, and said, Which way went the Spirit of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> from me to speak unto thee?

<b>24 </b>And Micaiah said, Behold, thou shalt see on that day when thou shalt go into an inner chamber to hide thyself.

<b>25 </b>Then the king of Israel said, Take ye Micaiah, and carry him back to Amon the governor of the city, and to Joash the king’s son;

<b>26 </b>And say, Thus saith the king, Put this <i>fellow</i> in the prison, and feed him with bread of affliction and with water of affliction, until I return in peace.

<b>27 </b>And Micaiah said, If thou certainly return in peace, <i>then</i> hath not the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spoken by me. And he said, Hearken, all ye people.

<b>28 </b>So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat the king of Judah went up to Ramoth-gilead.

<b>29 </b>And the king of Israel said unto Jehoshaphat, I will disguise myself, and will go to the battle; but put thou on thy robes. So the king of Israel disguised himself; and they went to the battle.

<b>30 </b>Now the king of Syria had commanded the captains of the chariots that <i>were</i> with him, saying, Fight ye not with small or great, save only with the king of Israel.

<b>31 </b>And it came to pass, when the captains of the chariots saw Jehoshaphat, that they said, It <i>is</i> the king of Israel. Therefore they compassed about him to fight: but Jehoshaphat cried out, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> helped him; and God moved them <i>to depart</i> from him.

<b>32 </b>For it came to pass, that, when the captains of the chariots perceived that it was not the king of Israel, they turned back again from pursuing him.

<b>33 </b>And a <i>certain</i> man drew a bow at a venture, and smote the king of Israel between the joints of the harness: therefore he said to his chariot man, Turn thine hand, that thou mayest carry me out of the host; for I am wounded.

<b>34 </b>And the battle increased that day: howbeit the king of Israel stayed <i>himself</i> up in <i>his</i> chariot against the Syrians until the even: and about the time of the sun going down he died.


--------------------

CHAPTER 19

<b>1 </b>And Jehoshaphat the king of Judah returned to his house in peace to Jerusalem.

<b>2 </b>And Jehu the son of Hanani the seer went out to meet him, and said to king Jehoshaphat, Shouldest thou help the ungodly, and love them that hate the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>? therefore <i>is</i> wrath upon thee from before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>3 </b>Nevertheless there are good things found in thee, in that thou hast taken away the groves out of the land, and hast prepared thine heart to seek God.

<b>4 </b>And Jehoshaphat dwelt at Jerusalem: and he went out again through the people from Beer-sheba to mount Ephraim, and brought them back unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of their fathers.

<b>5 </b>¶ And he set judges in the land throughout all the fenced cities of Judah, city by city,

<b>6 </b>And said to the judges, Take heed what ye do: for ye judge not for man, but for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, who <i>is</i> with you in the judgment.

<b>7 </b>Wherefore now let the fear of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> be upon you; take heed and do <i>it:</i> for <i>there is</i> no iniquity with the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God, nor respect of persons, nor taking of gifts.

<b>8 </b>¶ Moreover in Jerusalem did Jehoshaphat set of the Levites, and <i>of</i> the priests, and of the chief of the fathers of Israel, for the judgment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and for controversies, when they returned to Jerusalem.

<b>9 </b>And he charged them, saying, Thus shall ye do in the fear of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, faithfully, and with a perfect heart.

<b>10 </b>And what cause soever shall come to you of your brethren that dwell in their cities, between blood and blood, between law and commandment, statutes and judgments, ye shall even warn them that they trespass not against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and <i>so</i> wrath come upon you, and upon your brethren: this do, and ye shall not trespass.

<b>11 </b>And, behold, Amariah the chief priest <i>is</i> over you in all matters of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and Zebadiah the son of Ishmael, the ruler of the house of Judah, for all the king’s matters: also the Levites <i>shall be</i> officers before you. Deal courageously, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall be with the good.


--------------------

CHAPTER 20

<b>1 </b>It came to pass after this also, <i>that</i> the children of Moab, and the children of Ammon, and with them <i>other</i> beside the Ammonites, came against Jehoshaphat to battle.

<b>2 </b>Then there came some that told Jehoshaphat, saying, There cometh a great multitude against thee from beyond the sea on this side Syria; and, behold, they <i>be</i> in Hazazon-tamar, which <i>is</i> En-gedi.

<b>3 </b>And Jehoshaphat feared, and set himself to seek the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and proclaimed a fast throughout all Judah.

<b>4 </b>And Judah gathered themselves together, to ask <i>help</i> of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: even out of all the cities of Judah they came to seek the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>5 </b>¶ And Jehoshaphat stood in the congregation of Judah and Jerusalem, in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, before the new court,

<b>6 </b>And said, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of our fathers, <i>art</i> not thou God in heaven? and rulest <i>not</i> thou over all the kingdoms of the heathen? and in thine hand <i>is there not</i> power and might, so that none is able to withstand thee?

<b>7 </b><i>Art</i> not thou our God, <i>who</i> didst drive out the inhabitants of this land before thy people Israel, and gavest it to the seed of Abraham thy friend for ever?

<b>8 </b>And they dwelt therein, and have built thee a sanctuary therein for thy name, saying,

<b>9 </b>If, <i>when</i> evil cometh upon us, <i>as</i> the sword, judgment, or pestilence, or famine, we stand before this house, and in thy presence, (for thy name <i>is</i> in this house,) and cry unto thee in our affliction, then thou wilt hear and help.

<b>10 </b>And now, behold, the children of Ammon and Moab and mount Seir, whom thou wouldest not let Israel invade, when they came out of the land of Egypt, but they turned from them, and destroyed them not;

<b>11 </b>Behold, <i>I say, how</i> they reward us, to come to cast us out of thy possession, which thou hast given us to inherit.

<b>12 </b>O our God, wilt thou not judge them? for we have no might against this great company that cometh against us; neither know we what to do: but our eyes <i>are</i> upon thee.

<b>13 </b>And all Judah stood before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, with their little ones, their wives, and their children.

<b>14 </b>¶ Then upon Jahaziel the son of Zechariah, the son of Benaiah, the son of Jeiel, the son of Mattaniah, a Levite of the sons of Asaph, came the Spirit of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in the midst of the congregation;

<b>15 </b>And he said, Hearken ye, all Judah, and ye inhabitants of Jerusalem, and thou king Jehoshaphat, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto you, Be not afraid nor dismayed by reason of this great multitude; for the battle <i>is</i> not yours, but God’s.

<b>16 </b>To morrow go ye down against them: behold, they come up by the cliff of Ziz; and ye shall find them at the end of the brook, before the wilderness of Jeruel.

<b>17 </b>Ye shall not <i>need</i> to fight in this <i>battle:</i> set yourselves, stand ye <i>still,</i> and see the salvation of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with you, O Judah and Jerusalem: fear not, nor be dismayed; to morrow go out against them: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>will be</i> with you.

<b>18 </b>And Jehoshaphat bowed his head with <i>his</i> face to the ground: and all Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem fell before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, worshipping the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>19 </b>And the Levites, of the children of the Kohathites, and of the children of the Korhites, stood up to praise the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel with a loud voice on high.

<b>20 </b>¶ And they rose early in the morning, and went forth into the wilderness of Tekoa: and as they went forth, Jehoshaphat stood and said, Hear me, O Judah, and ye inhabitants of Jerusalem; Believe in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, so shall ye be established; believe his prophets, so shall ye prosper.

<b>21 </b>And when he had consulted with the people, he appointed singers unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and that should praise the beauty of holiness, as they went out before the army, and to say, Praise the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever.

<b>22 </b>¶ And when they began to sing and to praise, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> set ambushments against the children of Ammon, Moab, and mount Seir, which were come against Judah; and they were smitten.

<b>23 </b>For the children of Ammon and Moab stood up against the inhabitants of mount Seir, utterly to slay and destroy <i>them:</i> and when they had made an end of the inhabitants of Seir, every one helped to destroy another.

<b>24 </b>And when Judah came toward the watch tower in the wilderness, they looked unto the multitude, and, behold, they <i>were</i> dead bodies fallen to the earth, and none escaped.

<b>25 </b>And when Jehoshaphat and his people came to take away the spoil of them, they found among them in abundance both riches with the dead bodies, and precious jewels, which they stripped off for themselves, more than they could carry away: and they were three days in gathering of the spoil, it was so much.

<b>26 </b>¶ And on the fourth day they assembled themselves in the valley of Berachah; for there they blessed the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: therefore the name of the same place was called, The valley of Berachah, unto this day.

<b>27 </b>Then they returned, every man of Judah and Jerusalem, and Jehoshaphat in the forefront of them, to go again to Jerusalem with joy; for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had made them to rejoice over their enemies.

<b>28 </b>And they came to Jerusalem with psalteries and harps and trumpets unto the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>29 </b>And the fear of God was on all the kingdoms of <i>those</i> countries, when they had heard that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> fought against the enemies of Israel.

<b>30 </b>So the realm of Jehoshaphat was quiet: for his God gave him rest round about.

<b>31 </b>¶ And Jehoshaphat reigned over Judah: <i>he was</i> thirty and five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned twenty and five years in Jerusalem. And his mother’s name <i>was</i> Azubah the daughter of Shilhi.

<b>32 </b>And he walked in the way of Asa his father, and departed not from it, doing <i>that which was</i> right in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>33 </b>Howbeit the high places were not taken away: for as yet the people had not prepared their hearts unto the God of their fathers.

<b>34 </b>Now the rest of the acts of Jehoshaphat, first and last, behold, they <i>are</i> written in the book of Jehu the son of Hanani, who <i>is</i> mentioned in the book of the kings of Israel.

<b>35 </b>¶ And after this did Jehoshaphat king of Judah join himself with Ahaziah king of Israel, who did very wickedly:

<b>36 </b>And he joined himself with him to make ships to go to Tarshish: and they made the ships in Ezion-geber.

<b>37 </b>Then Eliezer the son of Dodavah of Mareshah prophesied against Jehoshaphat, saying, Because thou hast joined thyself with Ahaziah, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath broken thy works. And the ships were broken, that they were not able to go to Tarshish.


--------------------

CHAPTER 21

<b>1 </b>Now Jehoshaphat slept with his fathers, and was buried with his fathers in the city of David. And Jehoram his son reigned in his stead.

<b>2 </b>And he had brethren the sons of Jehoshaphat, Azariah, and Jehiel, and Zechariah, and Azariah, and Michael, and Shephatiah: all these <i>were</i> the sons of Jehoshaphat king of Israel.

<b>3 </b>And their father gave them great gifts of silver, and of gold, and of precious things, with fenced cities in Judah: but the kingdom gave he to Jehoram; because he <i>was</i> the firstborn.

<b>4 </b>Now when Jehoram was risen up to the kingdom of his father, he strengthened himself, and slew all his brethren with the sword, and <i>divers</i> also of the princes of Israel.

<b>5 </b>¶ Jehoram <i>was</i> thirty and two years old when he began to reign, and he reigned eight years in Jerusalem.

<b>6 </b>And he walked in the way of the kings of Israel, like as did the house of Ahab: for he had the daughter of Ahab to wife: and he wrought <i>that which was</i> evil in the eyes of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>7 </b>Howbeit the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> would not destroy the house of David, because of the covenant that he had made with David, and as he promised to give a light to him and to his sons for ever.

<b>8 </b>¶ In his days the Edomites revolted from under the dominion of Judah, and made themselves a king.

<b>9 </b>Then Jehoram went forth with his princes, and all his chariots with him: and he rose up by night, and smote the Edomites which compassed him in, and the captains of the chariots.

<b>10 </b>So the Edomites revolted from under the hand of Judah unto this day. The same time <i>also</i> did Libnah revolt from under his hand; because he had forsaken the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of his fathers.

<b>11 </b>Moreover he made high places in the mountains of Judah, and caused the inhabitants of Jerusalem to commit fornication, and compelled Judah <i>thereto.</i>

<b>12 </b>¶ And there came a writing to him from Elijah the prophet, saying, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of David thy father, Because thou hast not walked in the ways of Jehoshaphat thy father, nor in the ways of Asa king of Judah,

<b>13 </b>But hast walked in the way of the kings of Israel, and hast made Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem to go a whoring, like to the whoredoms of the house of Ahab, and also hast slain thy brethren of thy father’s house, <i>which were</i> better than thyself:

<b>14 </b>Behold, with a great plague will the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> smite thy people, and thy children, and thy wives, and all thy goods:

<b>15 </b>And thou <i>shalt have</i> great sickness by disease of thy bowels, until thy bowels fall out by reason of the sickness day by day.

<b>16 </b>¶ Moreover the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> stirred up against Jehoram the spirit of the Philistines, and of the Arabians, that <i>were</i> near the Ethiopians:

<b>17 </b>And they came up into Judah, and brake into it, and carried away all the substance that was found in the king’s house, and his sons also, and his wives; so that there was never a son left him, save Jehoahaz, the youngest of his sons.

<b>18 </b>¶ And after all this the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> smote him in his bowels with an incurable disease.

<b>19 </b>And it came to pass, that in process of time, after the end of two years, his bowels fell out by reason of his sickness: so he died of sore diseases. And his people made no burning for him, like the burning of his fathers.

<b>20 </b>Thirty and two years old was he when he began to reign, and he reigned in Jerusalem eight years, and departed without being desired. Howbeit they buried him in the city of David, but not in the sepulchres of the kings.


--------------------

CHAPTER 22

<b>1 </b>And the inhabitants of Jerusalem made Ahaziah his youngest son king in his stead: for the band of men that came with the Arabians to the camp had slain all the eldest. So Ahaziah the son of Jehoram king of Judah reigned.

<b>2 </b>Forty and two years old <i>was</i> Ahaziah when he began to reign, and he reigned one year in Jerusalem. His mother’s name also <i>was</i> Athaliah the daughter of Omri.

<b>3 </b>He also walked in the ways of the house of Ahab: for his mother was his counsellor to do wickedly.

<b>4 </b>Wherefore he did evil in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> like the house of Ahab: for they were his counsellors after the death of his father to his destruction.

<b>5 </b>¶ He walked also after their counsel, and went with Jehoram the son of Ahab king of Israel to war against Hazael king of Syria at Ramoth-gilead: and the Syrians smote Joram.

<b>6 </b>And he returned to be healed in Jezreel because of the wounds which were given him at Ramah, when he fought with Hazael king of Syria. And Azariah the son of Jehoram king of Judah went down to see Jehoram the son of Ahab at Jezreel, because he was sick.

<b>7 </b>And the destruction of Ahaziah was of God by coming to Joram: for when he was come, he went out with Jehoram against Jehu the son of Nimshi, whom the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had anointed to cut off the house of Ahab.

<b>8 </b>And it came to pass, that, when Jehu was executing judgment upon the house of Ahab, and found the princes of Judah, and the sons of the brethren of Ahaziah, that ministered to Ahaziah, he slew them.

<b>9 </b>And he sought Ahaziah: and they caught him, (for he was hid in Samaria,) and brought him to Jehu: and when they had slain him, they buried him: Because, said they, he <i>is</i> the son of Jehoshaphat, who sought the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with all his heart. So the house of Ahaziah had no power to keep still the kingdom.

<b>10 </b>¶ But when Athaliah the mother of Ahaziah saw that her son was dead, she arose and destroyed all the seed royal of the house of Judah.

<b>11 </b>But Jehoshabeath, the daughter of the king, took Joash the son of Ahaziah, and stole him from among the king’s sons that were slain, and put him and his nurse in a bedchamber. So Jehoshabeath, the daughter of king Jehoram, the wife of Jehoiada the priest, (for she was the sister of Ahaziah,) hid him from Athaliah, so that she slew him not.

<b>12 </b>And he was with them hid in the house of God six years: and Athaliah reigned over the land.


--------------------

CHAPTER 23

<b>1 </b>And in the seventh year Jehoiada strengthened himself, and took the captains of hundreds, Azariah the son of Jeroham, and Ishmael the son of Jehohanan, and Azariah the son of Obed, and Maaseiah the son of Adaiah, and Elishaphat the son of Zichri, into covenant with him.

<b>2 </b>And they went about in Judah, and gathered the Levites out of all the cities of Judah, and the chief of the fathers of Israel, and they came to Jerusalem.

<b>3 </b>And all the congregation made a covenant with the king in the house of God. And he said unto them, Behold, the king’s son shall reign, as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath said of the sons of David.

<b>4 </b>This <i>is</i> the thing that ye shall do; A third part of you entering on the sabbath, of the priests and of the Levites, <i>shall be</i> porters of the doors;

<b>5 </b>And a third part <i>shall be</i> at the king’s house; and a third part at the gate of the foundation: and all the people <i>shall be</i> in the courts of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>6 </b>But let none come into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, save the priests, and they that minister of the Levites; they shall go in, for they <i>are</i> holy: but all the people shall keep the watch of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>7 </b>And the Levites shall compass the king round about, every man with his weapons in his hand; and whosoever <i>else</i> cometh into the house, he shall be put to death: but be ye with the king when he cometh in, and when he goeth out.

<b>8 </b>So the Levites and all Judah did according to all things that Jehoiada the priest had commanded, and took every man his men that were to come in on the sabbath, with them that were to go <i>out</i> on the sabbath: for Jehoiada the priest dismissed not the courses.

<b>9 </b>Moreover Jehoiada the priest delivered to the captains of hundreds spears, and bucklers, and shields, that <i>had been</i> king David’s, which <i>were</i> in the house of God.

<b>10 </b>And he set all the people, every man having his weapon in his hand, from the right side of the temple to the left side of the temple, along by the altar and the temple, by the king round about.

<b>11 </b>Then they brought out the king’s son, and put upon him the crown, and <i>gave him</i> the testimony, and made him king. And Jehoiada and his sons anointed him, and said, God save the king.

<b>12 </b>¶ Now when Athaliah heard the noise of the people running and praising the king, she came to the people into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>:

<b>13 </b>And she looked, and, behold, the king stood at his pillar at the entering in, and the princes and the trumpets by the king: and all the people of the land rejoiced, and sounded with trumpets, also the singers with instruments of musick, and such as taught to sing praise. Then Athaliah rent her clothes, and said, Treason, Treason.

<b>14 </b>Then Jehoiada the priest brought out the captains of hundreds that were set over the host, and said unto them, Have her forth of the ranges: and whoso followeth her, let him be slain with the sword. For the priest said, Slay her not in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>15 </b>So they laid hands on her; and when she was come to the entering of the horse gate by the king’s house, they slew her there.

<b>16 </b>¶ And Jehoiada made a covenant between him, and between all the people, and between the king, that they should be the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s people.

<b>17 </b>Then all the people went to the house of Baal, and brake it down, and brake his altars and his images in pieces, and slew Mattan the priest of Baal before the altars.

<b>18 </b>Also Jehoiada appointed the offices of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> by the hand of the priests the Levites, whom David had distributed in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to offer the burnt offerings of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, as <i>it is</i> written in the law of Moses, with rejoicing and with singing, <i>as it was ordained</i> by David.

<b>19 </b>And he set the porters at the gates of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that none <i>which was</i> unclean in any thing should enter in.

<b>20 </b>And he took the captains of hundreds, and the nobles, and the governors of the people, and all the people of the land, and brought down the king from the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and they came through the high gate into the king’s house, and set the king upon the throne of the kingdom.

<b>21 </b>And all the people of the land rejoiced: and the city was quiet, after that they had slain Athaliah with the sword.


--------------------

CHAPTER 24

<b>1 </b>Joash <i>was</i> seven years old when he began to reign, and he reigned forty years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name also <i>was</i> Zibiah of Beer-sheba.

<b>2 </b>And Joash did <i>that which was</i> right in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> all the days of Jehoiada the priest.

<b>3 </b>And Jehoiada took for him two wives; and he begat sons and daughters.

<b>4 </b>¶ And it came to pass after this, <i>that</i> Joash was minded to repair the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>5 </b>And he gathered together the priests and the Levites, and said to them, Go out unto the cities of Judah, and gather of all Israel money to repair the house of your God from year to year, and see that ye hasten the matter. Howbeit the Levites hastened <i>it</i> not.

<b>6 </b>And the king called for Jehoiada the chief, and said unto him, Why hast thou not required of the Levites to bring in out of Judah and out of Jerusalem the collection, <i>according to the commandment</i> of Moses the servant of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and of the congregation of Israel, for the tabernacle of witness?

<b>7 </b>For the sons of Athaliah, that wicked woman, had broken up the house of God; and also all the dedicated things of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> did they bestow upon Baalim.

<b>8 </b>And at the king’s commandment they made a chest, and set it without at the gate of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>9 </b>And they made a proclamation through Judah and Jerusalem, to bring in to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> the collection <i>that</i> Moses the servant of God <i>laid</i> upon Israel in the wilderness.

<b>10 </b>And all the princes and all the people rejoiced, and brought in, and cast into the chest, until they had made an end.

<b>11 </b>Now it came to pass, that at what time the chest was brought unto the king’s office by the hand of the Levites, and when they saw that <i>there was</i> much money, the king’s scribe and the high priest’s officer came and emptied the chest, and took it, and carried it to his place again. Thus they did day by day, and gathered money in abundance.

<b>12 </b>And the king and Jehoiada gave it to such as did the work of the service of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and hired masons and carpenters to repair the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and also such as wrought iron and brass to mend the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>13 </b>So the workmen wrought, and the work was perfected by them, and they set the house of God in his state, and strengthened it.

<b>14 </b>And when they had finished <i>it,</i> they brought the rest of the money before the king and Jehoiada, whereof were made vessels for the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>even</i> vessels to minister, and to offer <i>withal,</i> and spoons, and vessels of gold and silver. And they offered burnt offerings in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> continually all the days of Jehoiada.

<b>15 </b>¶ But Jehoiada waxed old, and was full of days when he died; an hundred and thirty years old <i>was he</i> when he died.

<b>16 </b>And they buried him in the city of David among the kings, because he had done good in Israel, both toward God, and toward his house.

<b>17 </b>Now after the death of Jehoiada came the princes of Judah, and made obeisance to the king. Then the king hearkened unto them.

<b>18 </b>And they left the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of their fathers, and served groves and idols: and wrath came upon Judah and Jerusalem for this their trespass.

<b>19 </b>Yet he sent prophets to them, to bring them again unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and they testified against them: but they would not give ear.

<b>20 </b>And the Spirit of God came upon Zechariah the son of Jehoiada the priest, which stood above the people, and said unto them, Thus saith God, Why transgress ye the commandments of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that ye cannot prosper? because ye have forsaken the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, he hath also forsaken you.

<b>21 </b>And they conspired against him, and stoned him with stones at the commandment of the king in the court of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>22 </b>Thus Joash the king remembered not the kindness which Jehoiada his father had done to him, but slew his son. And when he died, he said, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> look upon <i>it,</i> and require <i>it.</i>

<b>23 </b>¶ And it came to pass at the end of the year, <i>that</i> the host of Syria came up against him: and they came to Judah and Jerusalem, and destroyed all the princes of the people from among the people, and sent all the spoil of them unto the king of Damascus.

<b>24 </b>For the army of the Syrians came with a small company of men, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> delivered a very great host into their hand, because they had forsaken the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of their fathers. So they executed judgment against Joash.

<b>25 </b>And when they were departed from him, (for they left him in great diseases,) his own servants conspired against him for the blood of the sons of Jehoiada the priest, and slew him on his bed, and he died: and they buried him in the city of David, but they buried him not in the sepulchres of the kings.

<b>26 </b>And these are they that conspired against him; Zabad the son of Shimeath an Ammonitess, and Jehozabad the son of Shimrith a Moabitess.

<b>27 </b>¶ Now <i>concerning</i> his sons, and the greatness of the burdens <i>laid</i> upon him, and the repairing of the house of God, behold, they <i>are</i> written in the story of the book of the kings. And Amaziah his son reigned in his stead.


--------------------

CHAPTER 25

<b>1 </b>Amaziah <i>was</i> twenty and five years old <i>when</i> he began to reign, and he reigned twenty and nine years in Jerusalem. And his mother’s name <i>was</i> Jehoaddan of Jerusalem.

<b>2 </b>And he did <i>that which was</i> right in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, but not with a perfect heart.

<b>3 </b>¶ Now it came to pass, when the kingdom was established to him, that he slew his servants that had killed the king his father.

<b>4 </b>But he slew not their children, but <i>did</i> as <i>it is</i> written in the law in the book of Moses, where the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded, saying, The fathers shall not die for the children, neither shall the children die for the fathers, but every man shall die for his own sin.

<b>5 </b>¶ Moreover Amaziah gathered Judah together, and made them captains over thousands, and captains over hundreds, according to the houses of <i>their</i> fathers, throughout all Judah and Benjamin: and he numbered them from twenty years old and above, and found them three hundred thousand choice <i>men, able</i> to go forth to war, that could handle spear and shield.

<b>6 </b>He hired also an hundred thousand mighty men of valour out of Israel for an hundred talents of silver.

<b>7 </b>But there came a man of God to him, saying, O king, let not the army of Israel go with thee; for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> not with Israel, <i>to wit, with</i> all the children of Ephraim.

<b>8 </b>But if thou wilt go, do <i>it,</i> be strong for the battle: God shall make thee fall before the enemy: for God hath power to help, and to cast down.

<b>9 </b>And Amaziah said to the man of God, But what shall we do for the hundred talents which I have given to the army of Israel? And the man of God answered, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> is able to give thee much more than this.

<b>10 </b>Then Amaziah separated them, <i>to wit,</i> the army that was come to him out of Ephraim, to go home again: wherefore their anger was greatly kindled against Judah, and they returned home in great anger.

<b>11 </b>¶ And Amaziah strengthened himself, and led forth his people, and went to the valley of salt, and smote of the children of Seir ten thousand.

<b>12 </b>And <i>other</i> ten thousand <i>left</i> alive did the children of Judah carry away captive, and brought them unto the top of the rock, and cast them down from the top of the rock, that they all were broken in pieces.

<b>13 </b>¶ But the soldiers of the army which Amaziah sent back, that they should not go with him to battle, fell upon the cities of Judah, from Samaria even unto Beth-horon, and smote three thousand of them, and took much spoil.

<b>14 </b>¶ Now it came to pass, after that Amaziah was come from the slaughter of the Edomites, that he brought the gods of the children of Seir, and set them up <i>to be</i> his gods, and bowed down himself before them, and burned incense unto them.

<b>15 </b>Wherefore the anger of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was kindled against Amaziah, and he sent unto him a prophet, which said unto him, Why hast thou sought after the gods of the people, which could not deliver their own people out of thine hand?

<b>16 </b>And it came to pass, as he talked with him, that <i>the king</i> said unto him, Art thou made of the king’s counsel? forbear; why shouldest thou be smitten? Then the prophet forbare, and said, I know that God hath determined to destroy thee, because thou hast done this, and hast not hearkened unto my counsel.

<b>17 </b>¶ Then Amaziah king of Judah took advice, and sent to Joash, the son of Jehoahaz, the son of Jehu, king of Israel, saying, Come, let us see one another in the face.

<b>18 </b>And Joash king of Israel sent to Amaziah king of Judah, saying, The thistle that <i>was</i> in Lebanon sent to the cedar that <i>was</i> in Lebanon, saying, Give thy daughter to my son to wife: and there passed by a wild beast that <i>was</i> in Lebanon, and trode down the thistle.

<b>19 </b>Thou sayest, Lo, thou hast smitten the Edomites; and thine heart lifteth thee up to boast: abide now at home; why shouldest thou meddle to <i>thine</i> hurt, that thou shouldest fall, <i>even</i> thou, and Judah with thee?

<b>20 </b>But Amaziah would not hear; for it <i>came</i> of God, that he might deliver them into the hand <i>of their enemies,</i> because they sought after the gods of Edom.

<b>21 </b>So Joash the king of Israel went up; and they saw one another in the face, <i>both</i> he and Amaziah king of Judah, at Beth-shemesh, which <i>belongeth</i> to Judah.

<b>22 </b>And Judah was put to the worse before Israel, and they fled every man to his tent.

<b>23 </b>And Joash the king of Israel took Amaziah king of Judah, the son of Joash, the son of Jehoahaz, at Beth-shemesh, and brought him to Jerusalem, and brake down the wall of Jerusalem from the gate of Ephraim to the corner gate, four hundred cubits.

<b>24 </b>And <i>he took</i> all the gold and the silver, and all the vessels that were found in the house of God with Obed-edom, and the treasures of the king’s house, the hostages also, and returned to Samaria.

<b>25 </b>¶ And Amaziah the son of Joash king of Judah lived after the death of Joash son of Jehoahaz king of Israel fifteen years.

<b>26 </b>Now the rest of the acts of Amaziah, first and last, behold, <i>are</i> they not written in the book of the kings of Judah and Israel?

<b>27 </b>¶ Now after the time that Amaziah did turn away from following the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> they made a conspiracy against him in Jerusalem; and he fled to Lachish: but they sent to Lachish after him, and slew him there.

<b>28 </b>And they brought him upon horses, and buried him with his fathers in the city of Judah.


--------------------

CHAPTER 26

<b>1 </b>Then all the people of Judah took Uzziah, who <i>was</i> sixteen years old, and made him king in the room of his father Amaziah.

<b>2 </b>He built Eloth, and restored it to Judah, after that the king slept with his fathers.

<b>3 </b>Sixteen years old <i>was</i> Uzziah when he began to reign, and he reigned fifty and two years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name also <i>was</i> Jecoliah of Jerusalem.

<b>4 </b>And he did <i>that which was</i> right in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, according to all that his father Amaziah did.

<b>5 </b>And he sought God in the days of Zechariah, who had understanding in the visions of God: and as long as he sought the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, God made him to prosper.

<b>6 </b>And he went forth and warred against the Philistines, and brake down the wall of Gath, and the wall of Jabneh, and the wall of Ashdod, and built cities about Ashdod, and among the Philistines.

<b>7 </b>And God helped him against the Philistines, and against the Arabians that dwelt in Gur-baal, and the Mehunims.

<b>8 </b>And the Ammonites gave gifts to Uzziah: and his name spread abroad <i>even</i> to the entering in of Egypt; for he strengthened <i>himself</i> exceedingly.

<b>9 </b>Moreover Uzziah built towers in Jerusalem at the corner gate, and at the valley gate, and at the turning <i>of the wall,</i> and fortified them.

<b>10 </b>Also he built towers in the desert, and digged many wells: for he had much cattle, both in the low country, and in the plains: husbandmen <i>also,</i> and vine dressers in the mountains, and in Carmel: for he loved husbandry.

<b>11 </b>Moreover Uzziah had an host of fighting men, that went out to war by bands, according to the number of their account by the hand of Jeiel the scribe and Maaseiah the ruler, under the hand of Hananiah, <i>one</i> of the king’s captains.

<b>12 </b>The whole number of the chief of the fathers of the mighty men of valour <i>were</i> two thousand and six hundred.

<b>13 </b>And under their hand <i>was</i> an army, three hundred thousand and seven thousand and five hundred, that made war with mighty power, to help the king against the enemy.

<b>14 </b>And Uzziah prepared for them throughout all the host shields, and spears, and helmets, and habergeons, and bows, and slings <i>to cast</i> stones.

<b>15 </b>And he made in Jerusalem engines, invented by cunning men, to be on the towers and upon the bulwarks, to shoot arrows and great stones withal. And his name spread far abroad; for he was marvellously helped, till he was strong.

<b>16 </b>¶ But when he was strong, his heart was lifted up to <i>his</i> destruction: for he transgressed against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his God, and went into the temple of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> to burn incense upon the altar of incense.

<b>17 </b>And Azariah the priest went in after him, and with him fourscore priests of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>that were</i> valiant men:

<b>18 </b>And they withstood Uzziah the king, and said unto him, <i>It appertaineth</i> not unto thee, Uzziah, to burn incense unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, but to the priests the sons of Aaron, that are consecrated to burn incense: go out of the sanctuary; for thou hast trespassed; neither <i>shall it be</i> for thine honour from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God.

<b>19 </b>Then Uzziah was wroth, and <i>had</i> a censer in his hand to burn incense: and while he was wroth with the priests, the leprosy even rose up in his forehead before the priests in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, from beside the incense altar.

<b>20 </b>And Azariah the chief priest, and all the priests, looked upon him, and, behold, he <i>was</i> leprous in his forehead, and they thrust him out from thence; yea, himself hasted also to go out, because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had smitten him.

<b>21 </b>And Uzziah the king was a leper unto the day of his death, and dwelt in a several house, <i>being</i> a leper; for he was cut off from the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and Jotham his son <i>was</i> over the king’s house, judging the people of the land.

<b>22 </b>¶ Now the rest of the acts of Uzziah, first and last, did Isaiah the prophet, the son of Amoz, write.

<b>23 </b>So Uzziah slept with his fathers, and they buried him with his fathers in the field of the burial which <i>belonged</i> to the kings; for they said, He <i>is</i> a leper: and Jotham his son reigned in his stead.


--------------------

CHAPTER 27

<b>1 </b>Jotham <i>was</i> twenty and five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned sixteen years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name also <i>was</i> Jerushah, the daughter of Zadok.

<b>2 </b>And he did <i>that which was</i> right in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, according to all that his father Uzziah did: howbeit he entered not into the temple of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. And the people did yet corruptly.

<b>3 </b>He built the high gate of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and on the wall of Ophel he built much.

<b>4 </b>Moreover he built cities in the mountains of Judah, and in the forests he built castles and towers.

<b>5 </b>¶ He fought also with the king of the Ammonites, and prevailed against them. And the children of Ammon gave him the same year an hundred talents of silver, and ten thousand measures of wheat, and ten thousand of barley. So much did the children of Ammon pay unto him, both the second year, and the third.

<b>6 </b>So Jotham became mighty, because he prepared his ways before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his God.

<b>7 </b>¶ Now the rest of the acts of Jotham, and all his wars, and his ways, lo, they <i>are</i> written in the book of the kings of Israel and Judah.

<b>8 </b>He was five and twenty years old when he began to reign, and reigned sixteen years in Jerusalem.

<b>9 </b>¶ And Jotham slept with his fathers, and they buried him in the city of David: and Ahaz his son reigned in his stead.


--------------------

CHAPTER 28

<b>1 </b>Ahaz <i>was</i> twenty years old when he began to reign, and he reigned sixteen years in Jerusalem: but he did not <i>that which was</i> right in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, like David his father:

<b>2 </b>For he walked in the ways of the kings of Israel, and made also molten images for Baalim.

<b>3 </b>Moreover he burnt incense in the valley of the son of Hinnom, and burnt his children in the fire, after the abominations of the heathen whom the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had cast out before the children of Israel.

<b>4 </b>He sacrificed also and burnt incense in the high places, and on the hills, and under every green tree.

<b>5 </b>Wherefore the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his God delivered him into the hand of the king of Syria; and they smote him, and carried away a great multitude of them captives, and brought <i>them</i> to Damascus. And he was also delivered into the hand of the king of Israel, who smote him with a great slaughter.

<b>6 </b>¶ For Pekah the son of Remaliah slew in Judah an hundred and twenty thousand in one day, <i>which were</i> all valiant men; because they had forsaken the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of their fathers.

<b>7 </b>And Zichri, a mighty man of Ephraim, slew Maaseiah the king’s son, and Azrikam the governor of the house, and Elkanah <i>that was</i> next to the king.

<b>8 </b>And the children of Israel carried away captive of their brethren two hundred thousand, women, sons, and daughters, and took also away much spoil from them, and brought the spoil to Samaria.

<b>9 </b>But a prophet of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was there, whose name <i>was</i> Oded: and he went out before the host that came to Samaria, and said unto them, Behold, because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of your fathers was wroth with Judah, he hath delivered them into your hand, and ye have slain them in a rage <i>that</i> reacheth up unto heaven.

<b>10 </b>And now ye purpose to keep under the children of Judah and Jerusalem for bondmen and bondwomen unto you: <i>but are there</i> not with you, even with you, sins against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God?

<b>11 </b>Now hear me therefore, and deliver the captives again, which ye have taken captive of your brethren: for the fierce wrath of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> upon you.

<b>12 </b>Then certain of the heads of the children of Ephraim, Azariah the son of Johanan, Berechiah the son of Meshillemoth, and Jehizkiah the son of Shallum, and Amasa the son of Hadlai, stood up against them that came from the war,

<b>13 </b>And said unto them, Ye shall not bring in the captives hither: for whereas we have offended against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>already,</i> ye intend to add <i>more</i> to our sins and to our trespass: for our trespass is great, and <i>there is</i> fierce wrath against Israel.

<b>14 </b>So the armed men left the captives and the spoil before the princes and all the congregation.

<b>15 </b>And the men which were expressed by name rose up, and took the captives, and with the spoil clothed all that were naked among them, and arrayed them, and shod them, and gave them to eat and to drink, and anointed them, and carried all the feeble of them upon asses, and brought them to Jericho, the city of palm trees, to their brethren: then they returned to Samaria.

<b>16 </b>¶ At that time did king Ahaz send unto the kings of Assyria to help him.

<b>17 </b>For again the Edomites had come and smitten Judah, and carried away captives.

<b>18 </b>The Philistines also had invaded the cities of the low country, and of the south of Judah, and had taken Beth-shemesh, and Ajalon, and Gederoth, and Shocho with the villages thereof, and Timnah with the villages thereof, Gimzo also and the villages thereof: and they dwelt there.

<b>19 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> brought Judah low because of Ahaz king of Israel; for he made Judah naked, and transgressed sore against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>20 </b>And Tilgath-pilneser king of Assyria came unto him, and distressed him, but strengthened him not.

<b>21 </b>For Ahaz took away a portion <i>out</i> of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and <i>out</i> of the house of the king, and of the princes, and gave <i>it</i> unto the king of Assyria: but he helped him not.

<b>22 </b>¶ And in the time of his distress did he trespass yet more against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: this <i>is that</i> king Ahaz.

<b>23 </b>For he sacrificed unto the gods of Damascus, which smote him: and he said, Because the gods of the kings of Syria help them, <i>therefore</i> will I sacrifice to them, that they may help me. But they were the ruin of him, and of all Israel.

<b>24 </b>And Ahaz gathered together the vessels of the house of God, and cut in pieces the vessels of the house of God, and shut up the doors of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and he made him altars in every corner of Jerusalem.

<b>25 </b>And in every several city of Judah he made high places to burn incense unto other gods, and provoked to anger the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of his fathers.

<b>26 </b>¶ Now the rest of his acts and of all his ways, first and last, behold, they <i>are</i> written in the book of the kings of Judah and Israel.

<b>27 </b>And Ahaz slept with his fathers, and they buried him in the city, <i>even</i> in Jerusalem: but they brought him not into the sepulchres of the kings of Israel: and Hezekiah his son reigned in his stead.


--------------------

CHAPTER 29

<b>1 </b>Hezekiah began to reign <i>when he was</i> five and twenty years old, and he reigned nine and twenty years in Jerusalem. And his mother’s name <i>was</i> Abijah, the daughter of Zechariah.

<b>2 </b>And he did <i>that which was</i> right in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, according to all that David his father had done.

<b>3 </b>¶ He in the first year of his reign, in the first month, opened the doors of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and repaired them.

<b>4 </b>And he brought in the priests and the Levites, and gathered them together into the east street,

<b>5 </b>And said unto them, Hear me, ye Levites, sanctify now yourselves, and sanctify the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of your fathers, and carry forth the filthiness out of the holy <i>place.</i>

<b>6 </b>For our fathers have trespassed, and done <i>that which was</i> evil in the eyes of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God, and have forsaken him, and have turned away their faces from the habitation of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and turned <i>their</i> backs.

<b>7 </b>Also they have shut up the doors of the porch, and put out the lamps, and have not burned incense nor offered burnt offerings in the holy <i>place</i> unto the God of Israel.

<b>8 </b>Wherefore the wrath of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was upon Judah and Jerusalem, and he hath delivered them to trouble, to astonishment, and to hissing, as ye see with your eyes.

<b>9 </b>For, lo, our fathers have fallen by the sword, and our sons and our daughters and our wives <i>are</i> in captivity for this.

<b>10 </b>Now <i>it is</i> in mine heart to make a covenant with the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, that his fierce wrath may turn away from us.

<b>11 </b>My sons, be not now negligent: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath chosen you to stand before him, to serve him, and that ye should minister unto him, and burn incense.

<b>12 </b>¶ Then the Levites arose, Mahath the son of Amasai, and Joel the son of Azariah, of the sons of the Kohathites: and of the sons of Merari, Kish the son of Abdi, and Azariah the son of Jehalelel: and of the Gershonites; Joah the son of Zimmah, and Eden the son of Joah:

<b>13 </b>And of the sons of Elizaphan; Shimri, and Jeiel: and of the sons of Asaph; Zechariah, and Mattaniah:

<b>14 </b>And of the sons of Heman; Jehiel, and Shimei: and of the sons of Jeduthun; Shemaiah, and Uzziel.

<b>15 </b>And they gathered their brethren, and sanctified themselves, and came, according to the commandment of the king, by the words of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to cleanse the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>16 </b>And the priests went into the inner part of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to cleanse <i>it,</i> and brought out all the uncleanness that they found in the temple of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> into the court of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. And the Levites took <i>it,</i> to carry <i>it</i> out abroad into the brook Kidron.

<b>17 </b>Now they began on the first <i>day</i> of the first month to sanctify, and on the eighth day of the month came they to the porch of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: so they sanctified the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in eight days; and in the sixteenth day of the first month they made an end.

<b>18 </b>Then they went in to Hezekiah the king, and said, We have cleansed all the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and the altar of burnt offering, with all the vessels thereof, and the shewbread table, with all the vessels thereof.

<b>19 </b>Moreover all the vessels, which king Ahaz in his reign did cast away in his transgression, have we prepared and sanctified, and, behold, they <i>are</i> before the altar of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>20 </b>¶ Then Hezekiah the king rose early, and gathered the rulers of the city, and went up to the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>21 </b>And they brought seven bullocks, and seven rams, and seven lambs, and seven he goats, for a sin offering for the kingdom, and for the sanctuary, and for Judah. And he commanded the priests the sons of Aaron to offer <i>them</i> on the altar of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>22 </b>So they killed the bullocks, and the priests received the blood, and sprinkled <i>it</i> on the altar: likewise, when they had killed the rams, they sprinkled the blood upon the altar: they killed also the lambs, and they sprinkled the blood upon the altar.

<b>23 </b>And they brought forth the he goats <i>for</i> the sin offering before the king and the congregation; and they laid their hands upon them:

<b>24 </b>And the priests killed them, and they made reconciliation with their blood upon the altar, to make an atonement for all Israel: for the king commanded <i>that</i> the burnt offering and the sin offering <i>should be made</i> for all Israel.

<b>25 </b>And he set the Levites in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with cymbals, with psalteries, and with harps, according to the commandment of David, and of Gad the king’s seer, and Nathan the prophet: for <i>so was</i> the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> by his prophets.

<b>26 </b>And the Levites stood with the instruments of David, and the priests with the trumpets.

<b>27 </b>And Hezekiah commanded to offer the burnt offering upon the altar. And when the burnt offering began, the song of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> began <i>also</i> with the trumpets, and with the instruments <i>ordained</i> by David king of Israel.

<b>28 </b>And all the congregation worshipped, and the singers sang, and the trumpeters sounded: <i>and</i> all <i>this continued</i> until the burnt offering was finished.

<b>29 </b>And when they had made an end of offering, the king and all that were present with him bowed themselves, and worshipped.

<b>30 </b>Moreover Hezekiah the king and the princes commanded the Levites to sing praise unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with the words of David, and of Asaph the seer. And they sang praises with gladness, and they bowed their heads and worshipped.

<b>31 </b>Then Hezekiah answered and said, Now ye have consecrated yourselves unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, come near and bring sacrifices and thank offerings into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. And the congregation brought in sacrifices and thank offerings; and as many as were of a free heart burnt offerings.

<b>32 </b>And the number of the burnt offerings, which the congregation brought, was threescore and ten bullocks, an hundred rams, <i>and</i> two hundred lambs: all these <i>were</i> for a burnt offering to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>33 </b>And the consecrated things <i>were</i> six hundred oxen and three thousand sheep.

<b>34 </b>But the priests were too few, so that they could not flay all the burnt offerings: wherefore their brethren the Levites did help them, till the work was ended, and until the <i>other</i> priests had sanctified themselves: for the Levites <i>were</i> more upright in heart to sanctify themselves than the priests.

<b>35 </b>And also the burnt offerings <i>were</i> in abundance, with the fat of the peace offerings, and the drink offerings for <i>every</i> burnt offering. So the service of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was set in order.

<b>36 </b>And Hezekiah rejoiced, and all the people, that God had prepared the people: for the thing was <i>done</i> suddenly.


--------------------

CHAPTER 30

<b>1 </b>And Hezekiah sent to all Israel and Judah, and wrote letters also to Ephraim and Manasseh, that they should come to the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> at Jerusalem, to keep the passover unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel.

<b>2 </b>For the king had taken counsel, and his princes, and all the congregation in Jerusalem, to keep the passover in the second month.

<b>3 </b>For they could not keep it at that time, because the priests had not sanctified themselves sufficiently, neither had the people gathered themselves together to Jerusalem.

<b>4 </b>And the thing pleased the king and all the congregation.

<b>5 </b>So they established a decree to make proclamation throughout all Israel, from Beer-sheba even to Dan, that they should come to keep the passover unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel at Jerusalem: for they had not done <i>it</i> of a long <i>time</i><i> in such sort</i> as it was written.

<b>6 </b>So the posts went with the letters from the king and his princes throughout all Israel and Judah, and according to the commandment of the king, saying, Ye children of Israel, turn again unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, and he will return to the remnant of you, that are escaped out of the hand of the kings of Assyria.

<b>7 </b>And be not ye like your fathers, and like your brethren, which trespassed against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of their fathers, <i>who</i> therefore gave them up to desolation, as ye see.

<b>8 </b>Now be ye not stiffnecked, as your fathers <i>were, but</i> yield yourselves unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and enter into his sanctuary, which he hath sanctified for ever: and serve the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, that the fierceness of his wrath may turn away from you.

<b>9 </b>For if ye turn again unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, your brethren and your children <i>shall find</i> compassion before them that lead them captive, so that they shall come again into this land: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God <i>is</i> gracious and merciful, and will not turn away <i>his</i> face from you, if ye return unto him.

<b>10 </b>So the posts passed from city to city through the country of Ephraim and Manasseh even unto Zebulun: but they laughed them to scorn, and mocked them.

<b>11 </b>Nevertheless divers of Asher and Manasseh and of Zebulun humbled themselves, and came to Jerusalem.

<b>12 </b>Also in Judah the hand of God was to give them one heart to do the commandment of the king and of the princes, by the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>13 </b>¶ And there assembled at Jerusalem much people to keep the feast of unleavened bread in the second month, a very great congregation.

<b>14 </b>And they arose and took away the altars that <i>were</i> in Jerusalem, and all the altars for incense took they away, and cast <i>them</i> into the brook Kidron.

<b>15 </b>Then they killed the passover on the fourteenth <i>day</i> of the second month: and the priests and the Levites were ashamed, and sanctified themselves, and brought in the burnt offerings into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>16 </b>And they stood in their place after their manner, according to the law of Moses the man of God: the priests sprinkled the blood, <i>which they received</i> of the hand of the Levites.

<b>17 </b>For <i>there were</i> many in the congregation that were not sanctified: therefore the Levites had the charge of the killing of the passovers for every one <i>that was</i> not clean, to sanctify <i>them</i> unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>18 </b>For a multitude of the people, <i>even</i> many of Ephraim, and Manasseh, Issachar, and Zebulun, had not cleansed themselves, yet did they eat the passover otherwise than it was written. But Hezekiah prayed for them, saying, The good <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> pardon every one

<b>19 </b><i>That</i> prepareth his heart to seek God, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of his fathers, though <i>he be</i> not <i>cleansed</i> according to the purification of the sanctuary.

<b>20 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hearkened to Hezekiah, and healed the people.

<b>21 </b>And the children of Israel that were present at Jerusalem kept the feast of unleavened bread seven days with great gladness: and the Levites and the priests praised the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> day by day, <i>singing</i> with loud instruments unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>22 </b>And Hezekiah spake comfortably unto all the Levites that taught the good knowledge of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and they did eat throughout the feast seven days, offering peace offerings, and making confession to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of their fathers.

<b>23 </b>And the whole assembly took counsel to keep other seven days: and they kept <i>other</i> seven days with gladness.

<b>24 </b>For Hezekiah king of Judah did give to the congregation a thousand bullocks and seven thousand sheep; and the princes gave to the congregation a thousand bullocks and ten thousand sheep: and a great number of priests sanctified themselves.

<b>25 </b>And all the congregation of Judah, with the priests and the Levites, and all the congregation that came out of Israel, and the strangers that came out of the land of Israel, and that dwelt in Judah, rejoiced.

<b>26 </b>So there was great joy in Jerusalem: for since the time of Solomon the son of David king of Israel <i>there was</i> not the like in Jerusalem.

<b>27 </b>¶ Then the priests the Levites arose and blessed the people: and their voice was heard, and their prayer came <i>up</i> to his holy dwelling place, <i>even</i> unto heaven.


--------------------

CHAPTER 31

<b>1 </b>Now when all this was finished, all Israel that were present went out to the cities of Judah, and brake the images in pieces, and cut down the groves, and threw down the high places and the altars out of all Judah and Benjamin, in Ephraim also and Manasseh, until they had utterly destroyed them all. Then all the children of Israel returned, every man to his possession, into their own cities.

<b>2 </b>¶ And Hezekiah appointed the courses of the priests and the Levites after their courses, every man according to his service, the priests and Levites for burnt offerings and for peace offerings, to minister, and to give thanks, and to praise in the gates of the tents of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>3 </b><i>He appointed</i> also the king’s portion of his substance for the burnt offerings, <i>to wit,</i> for the morning and evening burnt offerings, and the burnt offerings for the sabbaths, and for the new moons, and for the set feasts, as <i>it is</i> written in the law of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>4 </b>Moreover he commanded the people that dwelt in Jerusalem to give the portion of the priests and the Levites, that they might be encouraged in the law of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>5 </b>¶ And as soon as the commandment came abroad, the children of Israel brought in abundance the firstfruits of corn, wine, and oil, and honey, and of all the increase of the field; and the tithe of all <i>things</i> brought they in abundantly.

<b>6 </b>And <i>concerning</i> the children of Israel and Judah, that dwelt in the cities of Judah, they also brought in the tithe of oxen and sheep, and the tithe of holy things which were consecrated unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> their God, and laid <i>them</i> by heaps.

<b>7 </b>In the third month they began to lay the foundation of the heaps, and finished <i>them</i> in the seventh month.

<b>8 </b>And when Hezekiah and the princes came and saw the heaps, they blessed the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and his people Israel.

<b>9 </b>Then Hezekiah questioned with the priests and the Levites concerning the heaps.

<b>10 </b>And Azariah the chief priest of the house of Zadok answered him, and said, Since <i>the people</i> began to bring the offerings into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, we have had enough to eat, and have left plenty: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath blessed his people; and that which is left <i>is</i> this great store.

<b>11 </b>¶ Then Hezekiah commanded to prepare chambers in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and they prepared <i>them,</i>

<b>12 </b>And brought in the offerings and the tithes and the dedicated <i>things</i> faithfully: over which Cononiah the Levite <i>was</i> ruler, and Shimei his brother <i>was</i> the next.

<b>13 </b>And Jehiel, and Azaziah, and Nahath, and Asahel, and Jerimoth, and Jozabad, and Eliel, and Ismachiah, and Mahath, and Benaiah, <i>were</i> overseers under the hand of Cononiah and Shimei his brother, at the commandment of Hezekiah the king, and Azariah the ruler of the house of God.

<b>14 </b>And Kore the son of Imnah the Levite, the porter toward the east, <i>was</i> over the freewill offerings of God, to distribute the oblations of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and the most holy things.

<b>15 </b>And next him <i>were</i> Eden, and Miniamin, and Jeshua, and Shemaiah, Amariah, and Shecaniah, in the cities of the priests, in <i>their</i> set office, to give to their brethren by courses, as well to the great as to the small:

<b>16 </b>Beside their genealogy of males, from three years old and upward, <i>even</i> unto every one that entereth into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, his daily portion for their service in their charges according to their courses;

<b>17 </b>Both to the genealogy of the priests by the house of their fathers, and the Levites from twenty years old and upward, in their charges by their courses;

<b>18 </b>And to the genealogy of all their little ones, their wives, and their sons, and their daughters, through all the congregation: for in their set office they sanctified themselves in holiness:

<b>19 </b>Also of the sons of Aaron the priests, <i>which were</i> in the fields of the suburbs of their cities, in every several city, the men that were expressed by name, to give portions to all the males among the priests, and to all that were reckoned by genealogies among the Levites.

<b>20 </b>¶ And thus did Hezekiah throughout all Judah, and wrought <i>that which was</i> good and right and truth before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his God.

<b>21 </b>And in every work that he began in the service of the house of God, and in the law, and in the commandments, to seek his God, he did <i>it</i> with all his heart, and prospered.


--------------------

CHAPTER 32

<b>1 </b>After these things, and the establishment thereof, Sennacherib king of Assyria came, and entered into Judah, and encamped against the fenced cities, and thought to win them for himself.

<b>2 </b>And when Hezekiah saw that Sennacherib was come, and that he was purposed to fight against Jerusalem,

<b>3 </b>He took counsel with his princes and his mighty men to stop the waters of the fountains which <i>were</i> without the city: and they did help him.

<b>4 </b>So there was gathered much people together, who stopped all the fountains, and the brook that ran through the midst of the land, saying, Why should the kings of Assyria come, and find much water?

<b>5 </b>Also he strengthened himself, and built up all the wall that was broken, and raised <i>it</i> up to the towers, and another wall without, and repaired Millo <i>in</i> the city of David, and made darts and shields in abundance.

<b>6 </b>And he set captains of war over the people, and gathered them together to him in the street of the gate of the city, and spake comfortably to them, saying,

<b>7 </b>Be strong and courageous, be not afraid nor dismayed for the king of Assyria, nor for all the multitude that <i>is</i> with him: for <i>there be</i> more with us than with him:

<b>8 </b>With him <i>is</i> an arm of flesh; but with us <i>is</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God to help us, and to fight our battles. And the people rested themselves upon the words of Hezekiah king of Judah.

<b>9 </b>¶ After this did Sennacherib king of Assyria send his servants to Jerusalem, (but he <i>himself laid siege</i> against Lachish, and all his power with him,) unto Hezekiah king of Judah, and unto all Judah that <i>were</i> at Jerusalem, saying,

<b>10 </b>Thus saith Sennacherib king of Assyria, Whereon do ye trust, that ye abide in the siege in Jerusalem?

<b>11 </b>Doth not Hezekiah persuade you to give over yourselves to die by famine and by thirst, saying, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God shall deliver us out of the hand of the king of Assyria?

<b>12 </b>Hath not the same Hezekiah taken away his high places and his altars, and commanded Judah and Jerusalem, saying, Ye shall worship before one altar, and burn incense upon it?

<b>13 </b>Know ye not what I and my fathers have done unto all the people of <i>other</i> lands? were the gods of the nations of those lands any ways able to deliver their lands out of mine hand?

<b>14 </b>Who <i>was there</i> among all the gods of those nations that my fathers utterly destroyed, that could deliver his people out of mine hand, that your God should be able to deliver you out of mine hand?

<b>15 </b>Now therefore let not Hezekiah deceive you, nor persuade you on this manner, neither yet believe him: for no god of any nation or kingdom was able to deliver his people out of mine hand, and out of the hand of my fathers: how much less shall your God deliver you out of mine hand?

<b>16 </b>And his servants spake yet <i>more</i> against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God, and against his servant Hezekiah.

<b>17 </b>He wrote also letters to rail on the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, and to speak against him, saying, As the gods of the nations of <i>other</i> lands have not delivered their people out of mine hand, so shall not the God of Hezekiah deliver his people out of mine hand.

<b>18 </b>Then they cried with a loud voice in the Jews’ speech unto the people of Jerusalem that <i>were</i> on the wall, to affright them, and to trouble them; that they might take the city.

<b>19 </b>And they spake against the God of Jerusalem, as against the gods of the people of the earth, <i>which were</i> the work of the hands of man.

<b>20 </b>And for this <i>cause</i> Hezekiah the king, and the prophet Isaiah the son of Amoz, prayed and cried to heaven.

<b>21 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sent an angel, which cut off all the mighty men of valour, and the leaders and captains in the camp of the king of Assyria. So he returned with shame of face to his own land. And when he was come into the house of his god, they that came forth of his own bowels slew him there with the sword.

<b>22 </b>Thus the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> saved Hezekiah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem from the hand of Sennacherib the king of Assyria, and from the hand of all <i>other,</i> and guided them on every side.

<b>23 </b>And many brought gifts unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> to Jerusalem, and presents to Hezekiah king of Judah: so that he was magnified in the sight of all nations from thenceforth.

<b>24 </b>¶ In those days Hezekiah was sick to the death, and prayed unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and he spake unto him, and he gave him a sign.

<b>25 </b>But Hezekiah rendered not again according to the benefit <i>done</i> unto him; for his heart was lifted up: therefore there was wrath upon him, and upon Judah and Jerusalem.

<b>26 </b>Notwithstanding Hezekiah humbled himself for the pride of his heart, <i>both</i> he and the inhabitants of Jerusalem, so that the wrath of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came not upon them in the days of Hezekiah.

<b>27 </b>¶ And Hezekiah had exceeding much riches and honour: and he made himself treasuries for silver, and for gold, and for precious stones, and for spices, and for shields, and for all manner of pleasant jewels;

<b>28 </b>Storehouses also for the increase of corn, and wine, and oil; and stalls for all manner of beasts, and cotes for flocks.

<b>29 </b>Moreover he provided him cities, and possessions of flocks and herds in abundance: for God had given him substance very much.

<b>30 </b>This same Hezekiah also stopped the upper watercourse of Gihon, and brought it straight down to the west side of the city of David. And Hezekiah prospered in all his works.

<b>31 </b>¶ Howbeit in <i>the business of</i> the ambassadors of the princes of Babylon, who sent unto him to inquire of the wonder that was <i>done</i> in the land, God left him, to try him, that he might know all <i>that was</i> in his heart.

<b>32 </b>¶ Now the rest of the acts of Hezekiah, and his goodness, behold, they <i>are</i> written in the vision of Isaiah the prophet, the son of Amoz, <i>and</i> in the book of the kings of Judah and Israel.

<b>33 </b>And Hezekiah slept with his fathers, and they buried him in the chiefest of the sepulchres of the sons of David: and all Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem did him honour at his death. And Manasseh his son reigned in his stead.


--------------------

CHAPTER 33

<b>1 </b>Manasseh <i>was</i> twelve years old when he began to reign, and he reigned fifty and five years in Jerusalem:

<b>2 </b>But did <i>that which was</i> evil in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, like unto the abominations of the heathen, whom the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had cast out before the children of Israel.

<b>3 </b>¶ For he built again the high places which Hezekiah his father had broken down, and he reared up altars for Baalim, and made groves, and worshipped all the host of heaven, and served them.

<b>4 </b>Also he built altars in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, whereof the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had said, In Jerusalem shall my name be for ever.

<b>5 </b>And he built altars for all the host of heaven in the two courts of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>6 </b>And he caused his children to pass through the fire in the valley of the son of Hinnom: also he observed times, and used enchantments, and used witchcraft, and dealt with a familiar spirit, and with wizards: he wrought much evil in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to provoke him to anger.

<b>7 </b>And he set a carved image, the idol which he had made, in the house of God, of which God had said to David and to Solomon his son, In this house, and in Jerusalem, which I have chosen before all the tribes of Israel, will I put my name for ever:

<b>8 </b>Neither will I any more remove the foot of Israel from out of the land which I have appointed for your fathers; so that they will take heed to do all that I have commanded them, according to the whole law and the statutes and the ordinances by the hand of Moses.

<b>9 </b>So Manasseh made Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem to err, <i>and</i> to do worse than the heathen, whom the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had destroyed before the children of Israel.

<b>10 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake to Manasseh, and to his people: but they would not hearken.

<b>11 </b>¶ Wherefore the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> brought upon them the captains of the host of the king of Assyria, which took Manasseh among the thorns, and bound him with fetters, and carried him to Babylon.

<b>12 </b>And when he was in affliction, he besought the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his God, and humbled himself greatly before the God of his fathers,

<b>13 </b>And prayed unto him: and he was entreated of him, and heard his supplication, and brought him again to Jerusalem into his kingdom. Then Manasseh knew that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> he <i>was</i> God.

<b>14 </b>Now after this he built a wall without the city of David, on the west side of Gihon, in the valley, even to the entering in at the fish gate, and compassed about Ophel, and raised it up a very great height, and put captains of war in all the fenced cities of Judah.

<b>15 </b>And he took away the strange gods, and the idol out of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and all the altars that he had built in the mount of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and in Jerusalem, and cast <i>them</i> out of the city.

<b>16 </b>And he repaired the altar of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and sacrificed thereon peace offerings and thank offerings, and commanded Judah to serve the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel.

<b>17 </b>Nevertheless the people did sacrifice still in the high places, <i>yet</i> unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> their God only.

<b>18 </b>¶ Now the rest of the acts of Manasseh, and his prayer unto his God, and the words of the seers that spake to him in the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, behold, they <i>are written</i> in the book of the kings of Israel.

<b>19 </b>His prayer also, and <i>how God</i> was entreated of him, and all his sin, and his trespass, and the places wherein he built high places, and set up groves and graven images, before he was humbled: behold, they <i>are</i> written among the sayings of the seers.

<b>20 </b>¶ So Manasseh slept with his fathers, and they buried him in his own house: and Amon his son reigned in his stead.

<b>21 </b>¶ Amon <i>was</i> two and twenty years old when he began to reign, and reigned two years in Jerusalem.

<b>22 </b>But he did <i>that which was</i> evil in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, as did Manasseh his father: for Amon sacrificed unto all the carved images which Manasseh his father had made, and served them;

<b>23 </b>And humbled not himself before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, as Manasseh his father had humbled himself; but Amon trespassed more and more.

<b>24 </b>And his servants conspired against him, and slew him in his own house.

<b>25 </b>¶ But the people of the land slew all them that had conspired against king Amon; and the people of the land made Josiah his son king in his stead.


--------------------

CHAPTER 34

<b>1 </b>Josiah <i>was</i> eight years old when he began to reign, and he reigned in Jerusalem one and thirty years.

<b>2 </b>And he did <i>that which was</i> right in the sight of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and walked in the ways of David his father, and declined <i>neither</i> to the right hand, nor to the left.

<b>3 </b>¶ For in the eighth year of his reign, while he was yet young, he began to seek after the God of David his father: and in the twelfth year he began to purge Judah and Jerusalem from the high places, and the groves, and the carved images, and the molten images.

<b>4 </b>And they brake down the altars of Baalim in his presence; and the images, that <i>were</i> on high above them, he cut down; and the groves, and the carved images, and the molten images, he brake in pieces, and made dust <i>of them,</i> and strowed <i>it</i> upon the graves of them that had sacrificed unto them.

<b>5 </b>And he burnt the bones of the priests upon their altars, and cleansed Judah and Jerusalem.

<b>6 </b>And <i>so did he</i> in the cities of Manasseh, and Ephraim, and Simeon, even unto Naphtali, with their mattocks round about.

<b>7 </b>And when he had broken down the altars and the groves, and had beaten the graven images into powder, and cut down all the idols throughout all the land of Israel, he returned to Jerusalem.

<b>8 </b>¶ Now in the eighteenth year of his reign, when he had purged the land, and the house, he sent Shaphan the son of Azaliah, and Maaseiah the governor of the city, and Joah the son of Joahaz the recorder, to repair the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his God.
