<b>21 </b>If I have lifted up my hand against the fatherless, when I saw my help in the gate:

<b>22 </b><i>Then</i> let mine arm fall from my shoulder blade, and mine arm be broken from the bone.

<b>23 </b>For destruction <i>from</i> God <i>was</i> a terror to me, and by reason of his highness I could not endure.

<b>24 </b>If I have made gold my hope, or have said to the fine gold, <i>Thou art</i> my confidence;

<b>25 </b>If I rejoiced because my wealth <i>was</i> great, and because mine hand had gotten much;

<b>26 </b>If I beheld the sun when it shined, or the moon walking <i>in</i> brightness;

<b>27 </b>And my heart hath been secretly enticed, or my mouth hath kissed my hand:

<b>28 </b>This also <i>were</i> an iniquity <i>to be punished by</i> the judge: for I should have denied the God <i>that is</i> above.

<b>29 </b>If I rejoiced at the destruction of him that hated me, or lifted up myself when evil found him:

<b>30 </b>Neither have I suffered my mouth to sin by wishing a curse to his soul.

<b>31 </b>If the men of my tabernacle said not, Oh that we had of his flesh! we cannot be satisfied.

<b>32 </b>The stranger did not lodge in the street: <i>but</i> I opened my doors to the traveller.

<b>33 </b>If I covered my transgressions as Adam, by hiding mine iniquity in my bosom:

<b>34 </b>Did I fear a great multitude, or did the contempt of families terrify me, that I kept silence, <i>and</i> went not out of the door?

<b>35 </b>Oh that one would hear me! behold, my desire <i>is, that</i> the Almighty would answer me, and <i>that</i> mine adversary had written a book.

<b>36 </b>Surely I would take it upon my shoulder, <i>and</i> bind it <i>as</i> a crown to me.

<b>37 </b>I would declare unto him the number of my steps; as a prince would I go near unto him.

<b>38 </b>If my land cry against me, or that the furrows likewise thereof complain;

<b>39 </b>If I have eaten the fruits thereof without money, or have caused the owners thereof to lose their life:

<b>40 </b>Let thistles grow instead of wheat, and cockle instead of barley. The words of Job are ended.


--------------------

CHAPTER 32

<b>1 </b>So these three men ceased to answer Job, because he <i>was</i> righteous in his own eyes.

<b>2 </b>Then was kindled the wrath of Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite, of the kindred of Ram: against Job was his wrath kindled, because he justified himself rather than God.

<b>3 </b>Also against his three friends was his wrath kindled, because they had found no answer, and <i>yet</i> had condemned Job.

<b>4 </b>Now Elihu had waited till Job had spoken, because they <i>were</i> elder than he.

<b>5 </b>When Elihu saw that <i>there was</i> no answer in the mouth of <i>these</i> three men, then his wrath was kindled.

<b>6 </b>And Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite answered and said, I <i>am</i> young, and ye <i>are</i> very old; wherefore I was afraid, and durst not shew you mine opinion.

<b>7 </b>I said, Days should speak, and multitude of years should teach wisdom.

<b>8 </b>But <i>there is</i> a spirit in man: and the inspiration of the Almighty giveth them understanding.

<b>9 </b>Great men are not <i>always</i> wise: neither do the aged understand judgment.

<b>10 </b>Therefore I said, Hearken to me; I also will shew mine opinion.

<b>11 </b>Behold, I waited for your words; I gave ear to your reasons, whilst ye searched out what to say.

<b>12 </b>Yea, I attended unto you, and, behold, <i>there was</i> none of you that convinced Job, <i>or</i> that answered his words:

<b>13 </b>Lest ye should say, We have found out wisdom: God thrusteth him down, not man.

<b>14 </b>Now he hath not directed <i>his</i> words against me: neither will I answer him with your speeches.

<b>15 </b>They were amazed, they answered no more: they left off speaking.

<b>16 </b>When I had waited, (for they spake not, but stood still, <i>and</i> answered no more;)

<b>17 </b><i>I said,</i> I will answer also my part, I also will shew mine opinion.

<b>18 </b>For I am full of matter, the spirit within me constraineth me.

<b>19 </b>Behold, my belly <i>is</i> as wine <i>which</i> hath no vent; it is ready to burst like new bottles.

<b>20 </b>I will speak, that I may be refreshed: I will open my lips and answer.

<b>21 </b>Let me not, I pray you, accept any man’s person, neither let me give flattering titles unto man.

<b>22 </b>For I know not to give flattering titles; <i>in so doing</i> my maker would soon take me away.


--------------------

CHAPTER 33

<b>1 </b>Wherefore, Job, I pray thee, hear my speeches, and hearken to all my words.

<b>2 </b>Behold, now I have opened my mouth, my tongue hath spoken in my mouth.

<b>3 </b>My words <i>shall be of</i> the uprightness of my heart: and my lips shall utter knowledge clearly.

<b>4 </b>The Spirit of God hath made me, and the breath of the Almighty hath given me life.

<b>5 </b>If thou canst answer me, set <i>thy words</i> in order before me, stand up.

<b>6 </b>Behold, I <i>am</i> according to thy wish in God’s stead: I also am formed out of the clay.

<b>7 </b>Behold, my terror shall not make thee afraid, neither shall my hand be heavy upon thee.

<b>8 </b>Surely thou hast spoken in mine hearing, and I have heard the voice of <i>thy</i> words, <i>saying,</i>

<b>9 </b>I am clean without transgression, I <i>am</i> innocent; neither <i>is there</i> iniquity in me.

<b>10 </b>Behold, he findeth occasions against me, he counteth me for his enemy,

<b>11 </b>He putteth my feet in the stocks, he marketh all my paths.

<b>12 </b>Behold, <i>in</i> this thou art not just: I will answer thee, that God is greater than man.

<b>13 </b>Why dost thou strive against him? for he giveth not account of any of his matters.

<b>14 </b>For God speaketh once, yea twice, <i>yet man</i> perceiveth it not.

<b>15 </b>In a dream, in a vision of the night, when deep sleep falleth upon men, in slumberings upon the bed;

<b>16 </b>Then he openeth the ears of men, and sealeth their instruction,

<b>17 </b>That he may withdraw man <i>from his</i> purpose, and hide pride from man.

<b>18 </b>He keepeth back his soul from the pit, and his life from perishing by the sword.

<b>19 </b>He is chastened also with pain upon his bed, and the multitude of his bones with strong <i>pain:</i>

<b>20 </b>So that his life abhorreth bread, and his soul dainty meat.

<b>21 </b>His flesh is consumed away, that it cannot be seen; and his bones <i>that</i> were not seen stick out.

<b>22 </b>Yea, his soul draweth near unto the grave, and his life to the destroyers.

<b>23 </b>If there be a messenger with him, an interpreter, one among a thousand, to shew unto man his uprightness:

<b>24 </b>Then he is gracious unto him, and saith, Deliver him from going down to the pit: I have found a ransom.

<b>25 </b>His flesh shall be fresher than a child’s: he shall return to the days of his youth:

<b>26 </b>He shall pray unto God, and he will be favourable unto him: and he shall see his face with joy: for he will render unto man his righteousness.

<b>27 </b>He looketh upon men, and <i>if any</i> say, I have sinned, and perverted <i>that which was</i> right, and it profited me not;

<b>28 </b>He will deliver his soul from going into the pit, and his life shall see the light.

<b>29 </b>Lo, all these <i>things</i> worketh God oftentimes with man,

<b>30 </b>To bring back his soul from the pit, to be enlightened with the light of the living.

<b>31 </b>Mark well, O Job, hearken unto me: hold thy peace, and I will speak.

<b>32 </b>If thou hast any thing to say, answer me: speak, for I desire to justify thee.

<b>33 </b>If not, hearken unto me: hold thy peace, and I shall teach thee wisdom.


--------------------

CHAPTER 34

<b>1 </b>Furthermore Elihu answered and said,

<b>2 </b>Hear my words, O ye wise <i>men;</i> and give ear unto me, ye that have knowledge.

<b>3 </b>For the ear trieth words, as the mouth tasteth meat.

<b>4 </b>Let us choose to us judgment: let us know among ourselves what <i>is</i> good.

<b>5 </b>For Job hath said, I am righteous: and God hath taken away my judgment.

<b>6 </b>Should I lie against my right? my wound <i>is</i> incurable without transgression.

<b>7 </b>What man <i>is</i> like Job, <i>who</i> drinketh up scorning like water?

<b>8 </b>Which goeth in company with the workers of iniquity, and walketh with wicked men.

<b>9 </b>For he hath said, It profiteth a man nothing that he should delight himself with God.

<b>10 </b>Therefore hearken unto me, ye men of understanding: far be it from God, <i>that he should do</i> wickedness; and <i>from</i> the Almighty, <i>that he should commit</i> iniquity.

<b>11 </b>For the work of a man shall he render unto him, and cause every man to find according to <i>his</i> ways.

<b>12 </b>Yea, surely God will not do wickedly, neither will the Almighty pervert judgment.

<b>13 </b>Who hath given him a charge over the earth? or who hath disposed the whole world?

<b>14 </b>If he set his heart upon man, <i>if</i> he gather unto himself his spirit and his breath;

<b>15 </b>All flesh shall perish together, and man shall turn again unto dust.

<b>16 </b>If now <i>thou hast</i> understanding, hear this: hearken to the voice of my words.

<b>17 </b>Shall even he that hateth right govern? and wilt thou condemn him that is most just?

<b>18 </b><i>Is it fit</i> to say to a king, <i>Thou art</i> wicked? <i>and</i> to princes, <i>Ye are</i> ungodly?

<b>19 </b><i>How much less to him</i> that accepteth not the persons of princes, nor regardeth the rich more than the poor? for they all <i>are</i> the work of his hands.

<b>20 </b>In a moment shall they die, and the people shall be troubled at midnight, and pass away: and the mighty shall be taken away without hand.

<b>21 </b>For his eyes <i>are</i> upon the ways of man, and he seeth all his goings.

<b>22 </b><i>There is</i> no darkness, nor shadow of death, where the workers of iniquity may hide themselves.

<b>23 </b>For he will not lay upon man more <i>than right;</i> that he should enter into judgment with God.

<b>24 </b>He shall break in pieces mighty men without number, and set others in their stead.

<b>25 </b>Therefore he knoweth their works, and he overturneth <i>them</i> in the night, so that they are destroyed.

<b>26 </b>He striketh them as wicked men in the open sight of others;

<b>27 </b>Because they turned back from him, and would not consider any of his ways:

<b>28 </b>So that they cause the cry of the poor to come unto him, and he heareth the cry of the afflicted.

<b>29 </b>When he giveth quietness, who then can make trouble? and when he hideth <i>his</i> face, who then can behold him? whether <i>it be done</i> against a nation, or against a man only:

<b>30 </b>That the hypocrite reign not, lest the people be ensnared.

<b>31 </b>Surely it is meet to be said unto God, I have borne <i>chastisement,</i> I will not offend <i>any more:</i>

<b>32 </b><i>That which</i> I see not teach thou me: if I have done iniquity, I will do no more.

<b>33 </b><i>Should it be</i> according to thy mind? he will recompense it, whether thou refuse, or whether thou choose; and not I: therefore speak what thou knowest.

<b>34 </b>Let men of understanding tell me, and let a wise man hearken unto me.

<b>35 </b>Job hath spoken without knowledge, and his words <i>were</i> without wisdom.

<b>36 </b>My desire <i>is that</i> Job may be tried unto the end because of <i>his</i> answers for wicked men.

<b>37 </b>For he addeth rebellion unto his sin, he clappeth <i>his hands</i> among us, and multiplieth his words against God.


--------------------

CHAPTER 35

<b>1 </b>Elihu spake moreover, and said,

<b>2 </b>Thinkest thou this to be right, <i>that</i> thou saidst, My righteousness <i>is</i> more than God’s?

<b>3 </b>For thou saidst, What advantage will it be unto thee? <i>and,</i> What profit shall I have, <i>if I be cleansed</i> from my sin?

<b>4 </b>I will answer thee, and thy companions with thee.

<b>5 </b>Look unto the heavens, and see; and behold the clouds <i>which</i> are higher than thou.

<b>6 </b>If thou sinnest, what doest thou against him? or <i>if</i> thy transgressions be multiplied, what doest thou unto him?

<b>7 </b>If thou be righteous, what givest thou him? or what receiveth he of thine hand?

<b>8 </b>Thy wickedness <i>may hurt</i> a man as thou <i>art;</i> and thy righteousness <i>may profit</i> the son of man.

<b>9 </b>By reason of the multitude of oppressions they make <i>the oppressed</i> to cry: they cry out by reason of the arm of the mighty.

<b>10 </b>But none saith, Where <i>is</i> God my maker, who giveth songs in the night;

<b>11 </b>Who teacheth us more than the beasts of the earth, and maketh us wiser than the fowls of heaven?

<b>12 </b>There they cry, but none giveth answer, because of the pride of evil men.

<b>13 </b>Surely God will not hear vanity, neither will the Almighty regard it.

<b>14 </b>Although thou sayest thou shalt not see him, <i>yet</i> judgment <i>is</i> before him; therefore trust thou in him.

<b>15 </b>But now, because <i>it is</i> not <i>so,</i> he hath visited in his anger; yet he knoweth <i>it</i> not in great extremity:

<b>16 </b>Therefore doth Job open his mouth in vain; he multiplieth words without knowledge.


--------------------

CHAPTER 36

<b>1 </b>Elihu also proceeded, and said,

<b>2 </b>Suffer me a little, and I will shew thee that <i>I have</i> yet to speak on God’s behalf.

<b>3 </b>I will fetch my knowledge from afar, and will ascribe righteousness to my Maker.

<b>4 </b>For truly my words <i>shall</i> not <i>be</i> false: he that is perfect in knowledge <i>is</i> with thee.

<b>5 </b>Behold, God <i>is</i> mighty, and despiseth not <i>any: he is</i> mighty in strength <i>and</i> wisdom.

<b>6 </b>He preserveth not the life of the wicked: but giveth right to the poor.

<b>7 </b>He withdraweth not his eyes from the righteous: but with kings <i>are they</i> on the throne; yea, he doth establish them for ever, and they are exalted.

<b>8 </b>And if <i>they be</i> bound in fetters, <i>and</i> be holden in cords of affliction;

<b>9 </b>Then he sheweth them their work, and their transgressions that they have exceeded.

<b>10 </b>He openeth also their ear to discipline, and commandeth that they return from iniquity.

<b>11 </b>If they obey and serve <i>him,</i> they shall spend their days in prosperity, and their years in pleasures.

<b>12 </b>But if they obey not, they shall perish by the sword, and they shall die without knowledge.

<b>13 </b>But the hypocrites in heart heap up wrath: they cry not when he bindeth them.

<b>14 </b>They die in youth, and their life <i>is</i> among the unclean.

<b>15 </b>He delivereth the poor in his affliction, and openeth their ears in oppression.

<b>16 </b>Even so would he have removed thee out of the strait <i>into</i> a broad place, where <i>there is</i> no straitness; and that which should be set on thy table <i>should be</i> full of fatness.

<b>17 </b>But thou hast fulfilled the judgment of the wicked: judgment and justice take hold <i>on thee.</i>

<b>18 </b>Because <i>there is</i> wrath, <i>beware</i> lest he take thee away with <i>his</i> stroke: then a great ransom cannot deliver thee.

<b>19 </b>Will he esteem thy riches? <i>no,</i> not gold, nor all the forces of strength.

<b>20 </b>Desire not the night, when people are cut off in their place.

<b>21 </b>Take heed, regard not iniquity: for this hast thou chosen rather than affliction.

<b>22 </b>Behold, God exalteth by his power: who teacheth like him?

<b>23 </b>Who hath enjoined him his way? or who can say, Thou hast wrought iniquity?

<b>24 </b>Remember that thou magnify his work, which men behold.

<b>25 </b>Every man may see it; man may behold <i>it</i> afar off.

<b>26 </b>Behold, God <i>is</i> great, and we know <i>him</i> not, neither can the number of his years be searched out.

<b>27 </b>For he maketh small the drops of water: they pour down rain according to the vapour thereof:

<b>28 </b>Which the clouds do drop <i>and</i> distil upon man abundantly.

<b>29 </b>Also can <i>any</i> understand the spreadings of the clouds, <i>or</i> the noise of his tabernacle?

<b>30 </b>Behold, he spreadeth his light upon it, and covereth the bottom of the sea.

<b>31 </b>For by them judgeth he the people; he giveth meat in abundance.

<b>32 </b>With clouds he covereth the light; and commandeth it <i>not to shine</i> by <i>the cloud</i> that cometh betwixt.

<b>33 </b>The noise thereof sheweth concerning it, the cattle also concerning the vapour.


--------------------

CHAPTER 37

<b>1 </b>At this also my heart trembleth, and is moved out of his place.

<b>2 </b>Hear attentively the noise of his voice, and the sound <i>that</i> goeth out of his mouth.

<b>3 </b>He directeth it under the whole heaven, and his lightning unto the ends of the earth.

<b>4 </b>After it a voice roareth: he thundereth with the voice of his excellency; and he will not stay them when his voice is heard.

<b>5 </b>God thundereth marvellously with his voice; great things doeth he, which we cannot comprehend.

<b>6 </b>For he saith to the snow, Be thou <i>on</i> the earth; likewise to the small rain, and to the great rain of his strength.

<b>7 </b>He sealeth up the hand of every man; that all men may know his work.

<b>8 </b>Then the beasts go into dens, and remain in their places.

<b>9 </b>Out of the south cometh the whirlwind: and cold out of the north.

<b>10 </b>By the breath of God frost is given: and the breadth of the waters is straitened.

<b>11 </b>Also by watering he wearieth the thick cloud: he scattereth his bright cloud:

<b>12 </b>And it is turned round about by his counsels: that they may do whatsoever he commandeth them upon the face of the world in the earth.

<b>13 </b>He causeth it to come, whether for correction, or for his land, or for mercy.

<b>14 </b>Hearken unto this, O Job: stand still, and consider the wondrous works of God.

<b>15 </b>Dost thou know when God disposed them, and caused the light of his cloud to shine?

<b>16 </b>Dost thou know the balancings of the clouds, the wondrous works of him which is perfect in knowledge?

<b>17 </b>How thy garments <i>are</i> warm, when he quieteth the earth by the south <i>wind?</i>

<b>18 </b>Hast thou with him spread out the sky, <i>which is</i> strong, <i>and</i> as a molten looking glass?

<b>19 </b>Teach us what we shall say unto him; <i>for</i> we cannot order <i>our speech</i> by reason of darkness.

<b>20 </b>Shall it be told him that I speak? if a man speak, surely he shall be swallowed up.

<b>21 </b>And now <i>men</i> see not the bright light which <i>is</i> in the clouds: but the wind passeth, and cleanseth them.

<b>22 </b>Fair weather cometh out of the north: with God <i>is</i> terrible majesty.

<b>23 </b><i>Touching</i> the Almighty, we cannot find him out: <i>he is</i> excellent in power, and in judgment, and in plenty of justice: he will not afflict.

<b>24 </b>Men do therefore fear him: he respecteth not any <i>that are</i> wise of heart.


--------------------

CHAPTER 38

<b>1 </b>Then the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> answered Job out of the whirlwind, and said,

<b>2 </b>Who <i>is</i> this that darkeneth counsel by words without knowledge?

<b>3 </b>Gird up now thy loins like a man; for I will demand of thee, and answer thou me.

<b>4 </b>Where wast thou when I laid the foundations of the earth? declare, if thou hast understanding.

<b>5 </b>Who hath laid the measures thereof, if thou knowest? or who hath stretched the line upon it?

<b>6 </b>Whereupon are the foundations thereof fastened? or who laid the corner stone thereof;

<b>7 </b>When the morning stars sang together, and all the sons of God shouted for joy?

<b>8 </b>Or <i>who</i> shut up the sea with doors, when it brake forth, <i>as if</i> it had issued out of the womb?

<b>9 </b>When I made the cloud the garment thereof, and thick darkness a swaddlingband for it,

<b>10 </b>And brake up for it my decreed <i>place,</i> and set bars and doors,

<b>11 </b>And said, Hitherto shalt thou come, but no further: and here shall thy proud waves be stayed?

<b>12 </b>Hast thou commanded the morning since thy days; <i>and</i> caused the dayspring to know his place;

<b>13 </b>That it might take hold of the ends of the earth, that the wicked might be shaken out of it?

<b>14 </b>It is turned as clay <i>to</i> the seal; and they stand as a garment.

<b>15 </b>And from the wicked their light is withholden, and the high arm shall be broken.

<b>16 </b>Hast thou entered into the springs of the sea? or hast thou walked in the search of the depth?

<b>17 </b>Have the gates of death been opened unto thee? or hast thou seen the doors of the shadow of death?

<b>18 </b>Hast thou perceived the breadth of the earth? declare if thou knowest it all.

<b>19 </b>Where <i>is</i> the way <i>where</i> light dwelleth? and <i>as for</i> darkness, where <i>is</i> the place thereof,

<b>20 </b>That thou shouldest take it to the bound thereof, and that thou shouldest know the paths <i>to</i> the house thereof?

<b>21 </b>Knowest thou <i>it,</i> because thou wast then born? or <i>because</i> the number of thy days <i>is</i> great?

<b>22 </b>Hast thou entered into the treasures of the snow? or hast thou seen the treasures of the hail,

<b>23 </b>Which I have reserved against the time of trouble, against the day of battle and war?

<b>24 </b>By what way is the light parted, <i>which</i> scattereth the east wind upon the earth?

<b>25 </b>Who hath divided a watercourse for the overflowing of waters, or a way for the lightning of thunder;

<b>26 </b>To cause it to rain on the earth, <i>where</i> no man <i>is; on</i> the wilderness, wherein <i>there is</i> no man;

<b>27 </b>To satisfy the desolate and waste <i>ground;</i> and to cause the bud of the tender herb to spring forth?

<b>28 </b>Hath the rain a father? or who hath begotten the drops of dew?

<b>29 </b>Out of whose womb came the ice? and the hoary frost of heaven, who hath gendered it?

<b>30 </b>The waters are hid as <i>with</i> a stone, and the face of the deep is frozen.

<b>31 </b>Canst thou bind the sweet influences of Pleiades, or loose the bands of Orion?

<b>32 </b>Canst thou bring forth Mazzaroth in his season? or canst thou guide Arcturus with his sons?

<b>33 </b>Knowest thou the ordinances of heaven? canst thou set the dominion thereof in the earth?

<b>34 </b>Canst thou lift up thy voice to the clouds, that abundance of waters may cover thee?

<b>35 </b>Canst thou send lightnings, that they may go, and say unto thee, Here we <i>are?</i>

<b>36 </b>Who hath put wisdom in the inward parts? or who hath given understanding to the heart?

<b>37 </b>Who can number the clouds in wisdom? or who can stay the bottles of heaven,

<b>38 </b>When the dust groweth into hardness, and the clods cleave fast together?

<b>39 </b>Wilt thou hunt the prey for the lion? or fill the appetite of the young lions,

<b>40 </b>When they couch in <i>their</i> dens, <i>and</i> abide in the covert to lie in wait?

<b>41 </b>Who provideth for the raven his food? when his young ones cry unto God, they wander for lack of meat.


--------------------

CHAPTER 39

<b>1 </b>Knowest thou the time when the wild goats of the rock bring forth? <i>or</i> canst thou mark when the hinds do calve?

<b>2 </b>Canst thou number the months <i>that</i> they fulfil? or knowest thou the time when they bring forth?

<b>3 </b>They bow themselves, they bring forth their young ones, they cast out their sorrows.

<b>4 </b>Their young ones are in good liking, they grow up with corn; they go forth, and return not unto them.

<b>5 </b>Who hath sent out the wild ass free? or who hath loosed the bands of the wild ass?

<b>6 </b>Whose house I have made the wilderness, and the barren land his dwellings.

<b>7 </b>He scorneth the multitude of the city, neither regardeth he the crying of the driver.

<b>8 </b>The range of the mountains <i>is</i> his pasture, and he searcheth after every green thing.

<b>9 </b>Will the unicorn be willing to serve thee, or abide by thy crib?

<b>10 </b>Canst thou bind the unicorn with his band in the furrow? or will he harrow the valleys after thee?

<b>11 </b>Wilt thou trust him, because his strength <i>is</i> great? or wilt thou leave thy labour to him?

<b>12 </b>Wilt thou believe him, that he will bring home thy seed, and gather <i>it into</i> thy barn?

<b>13 </b><i>Gavest thou</i> the goodly wings unto the peacocks? or wings and feathers unto the ostrich?

<b>14 </b>Which leaveth her eggs in the earth, and warmeth them in dust,

<b>15 </b>And forgetteth that the foot may crush them, or that the wild beast may break them.

<b>16 </b>She is hardened against her young ones, as though <i>they were</i> not hers: her labour is in vain without fear;

<b>17 </b>Because God hath deprived her of wisdom, neither hath he imparted to her understanding.

<b>18 </b>What time she lifteth up herself on high, she scorneth the horse and his rider.

<b>19 </b>Hast thou given the horse strength? hast thou clothed his neck with thunder?

<b>20 </b>Canst thou make him afraid as a grasshopper? the glory of his nostrils <i>is</i> terrible.

<b>21 </b>He paweth in the valley, and rejoiceth in <i>his</i> strength: he goeth on to meet the armed men.

<b>22 </b>He mocketh at fear, and is not affrighted; neither turneth he back from the sword.

<b>23 </b>The quiver rattleth against him, the glittering spear and the shield.

<b>24 </b>He swalloweth the ground with fierceness and rage: neither believeth he that <i>it is</i> the sound of the trumpet.

<b>25 </b>He saith among the trumpets, Ha, ha; and he smelleth the battle afar off, the thunder of the captains, and the shouting.

<b>26 </b>Doth the hawk fly by thy wisdom, <i>and</i> stretch her wings toward the south?

<b>27 </b>Doth the eagle mount up at thy command, and make her nest on high?

<b>28 </b>She dwelleth and abideth on the rock, upon the crag of the rock, and the strong place.

<b>29 </b>From thence she seeketh the prey, <i>and</i> her eyes behold afar off.

<b>30 </b>Her young ones also suck up blood: and where the slain <i>are,</i> there <i>is</i> she.


--------------------

CHAPTER 40

<b>1 </b>Moreover the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> answered Job, and said,

<b>2 </b>Shall he that contendeth with the Almighty instruct <i>him?</i> he that reproveth God, let him answer it.

<b>3 </b>¶ Then Job answered the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and said,

<b>4 </b>Behold, I am vile; what shall I answer thee? I will lay mine hand upon my mouth.

<b>5 </b>Once have I spoken; but I will not answer: yea, twice; but I will proceed no further.

<b>6 </b>¶ Then answered the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto Job out of the whirlwind, and said,

<b>7 </b>Gird up thy loins now like a man: I will demand of thee, and declare thou unto me.

<b>8 </b>Wilt thou also disannul my judgment? wilt thou condemn me, that thou mayest be righteous?

<b>9 </b>Hast thou an arm like God? or canst thou thunder with a voice like him?

<b>10 </b>Deck thyself now <i>with</i> majesty and excellency; and array thyself with glory and beauty.

<b>11 </b>Cast abroad the rage of thy wrath: and behold every one <i>that is</i> proud, and abase him.

<b>12 </b>Look on every one <i>that is</i> proud, <i>and</i> bring him low; and tread down the wicked in their place.

<b>13 </b>Hide them in the dust together; <i>and</i> bind their faces in secret.

<b>14 </b>Then will I also confess unto thee that thine own right hand can save thee.

<b>15 </b>¶ Behold now behemoth, which I made with thee; he eateth grass as an ox.

<b>16 </b>Lo now, his strength <i>is</i> in his loins, and his force <i>is</i> in the navel of his belly.

<b>17 </b>He moveth his tail like a cedar: the sinews of his stones are wrapped together.

<b>18 </b>His bones <i>are as</i> strong pieces of brass; his bones <i>are</i> like bars of iron.

<b>19 </b>He <i>is</i> the chief of the ways of God: he that made him can make his sword to approach <i>unto him.</i>

<b>20 </b>Surely the mountains bring him forth food, where all the beasts of the field play.

<b>21 </b>He lieth under the shady trees, in the covert of the reed, and fens.

<b>22 </b>The shady trees cover him <i>with</i> their shadow; the willows of the brook compass him about.

<b>23 </b>Behold, he drinketh up a river, <i>and</i> hasteth not: he trusteth that he can draw up Jordan into his mouth.

<b>24 </b>He taketh it with his eyes: <i>his</i> nose pierceth through snares.


--------------------

CHAPTER 41

<b>1 </b>Canst thou draw out leviathan with an hook? or his tongue with a cord <i>which</i> thou lettest down?

<b>2 </b>Canst thou put an hook into his nose? or bore his jaw through with a thorn?

<b>3 </b>Will he make many supplications unto thee? will he speak soft <i>words</i> unto thee?

<b>4 </b>Will he make a covenant with thee? wilt thou take him for a servant for ever?

<b>5 </b>Wilt thou play with him as <i>with</i> a bird? or wilt thou bind him for thy maidens?

<b>6 </b>Shall the companions make a banquet of him? shall they part him among the merchants?

<b>7 </b>Canst thou fill his skin with barbed irons? or his head with fish spears?

<b>8 </b>Lay thine hand upon him, remember the battle, do no more.

<b>9 </b>Behold, the hope of him is in vain: shall not <i>one</i> be cast down even at the sight of him?

<b>10 </b>None <i>is so</i> fierce that dare stir him up: who then is able to stand before me?

<b>11 </b>Who hath prevented me, that I should repay <i>him? whatsoever is</i> under the whole heaven is mine.

<b>12 </b>I will not conceal his parts, nor his power, nor his comely proportion.

<b>13 </b>Who can discover the face of his garment? <i>or</i> who can come <i>to him</i> with his double bridle?

<b>14 </b>Who can open the doors of his face? his teeth <i>are</i> terrible round about.

<b>15 </b><i>His</i> scales <i>are his</i> pride, shut up together <i>as with</i> a close seal.

<b>16 </b>One is so near to another, that no air can come between them.

<b>17 </b>They are joined one to another, they stick together, that they cannot be sundered.

<b>18 </b>By his neesings a light doth shine, and his eyes <i>are</i> like the eyelids of the morning.

<b>19 </b>Out of his mouth go burning lamps, <i>and</i> sparks of fire leap out.

<b>20 </b>Out of his nostrils goeth smoke, as <i>out</i> of a seething pot or caldron.

<b>21 </b>His breath kindleth coals, and a flame goeth out of his mouth.

<b>22 </b>In his neck remaineth strength, and sorrow is turned into joy before him.

<b>23 </b>The flakes of his flesh are joined together: they are firm in themselves; they cannot be moved.

<b>24 </b>His heart is as firm as a stone; yea, as hard as a piece of the nether <i>millstone.</i>

<b>25 </b>When he raiseth up himself, the mighty are afraid: by reason of breakings they purify themselves.

<b>26 </b>The sword of him that layeth at him cannot hold: the spear, the dart, nor the habergeon.

<b>27 </b>He esteemeth iron as straw, <i>and</i> brass as rotten wood.

<b>28 </b>The arrow cannot make him flee: slingstones are turned with him into stubble.

<b>29 </b>Darts are counted as stubble: he laugheth at the shaking of a spear.

<b>30 </b>Sharp stones <i>are</i> under him: he spreadeth sharp pointed things upon the mire.

<b>31 </b>He maketh the deep to boil like a pot: he maketh the sea like a pot of ointment.

<b>32 </b>He maketh a path to shine after him; <i>one</i> would think the deep <i>to be</i> hoary.

<b>33 </b>Upon earth there is not his like, who is made without fear.

<b>34 </b>He beholdeth all high <i>things:</i> he <i>is</i> a king over all the children of pride.


--------------------

CHAPTER 42

<b>1 </b>Then Job answered the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and said,

<b>2 </b>I know that thou canst do every <i>thing,</i> and <i>that</i> no thought can be withholden from thee.

<b>3 </b>Who <i>is</i> he that hideth counsel without knowledge? therefore have I uttered that I understood not; things too wonderful for me, which I knew not.

<b>4 </b>Hear, I beseech thee, and I will speak: I will demand of thee, and declare thou unto me.

<b>5 </b>I have heard of thee by the hearing of the ear: but now mine eye seeth thee.

<b>6 </b>Wherefore I abhor <i>myself,</i> and repent in dust and ashes.

<b>7 </b>¶ And it was <i>so,</i> that after the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had spoken these words unto Job, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said to Eliphaz the Temanite, My wrath is kindled against thee, and against thy two friends: for ye have not spoken of me <i>the thing that is</i> right, as my servant Job <i>hath.</i>

<b>8 </b>Therefore take unto you now seven bullocks and seven rams, and go to my servant Job, and offer up for yourselves a burnt offering; and my servant Job shall pray for you: for him will I accept: lest I deal with you <i>after your</i> folly, in that ye have not spoken of me <i>the thing which is</i> right, like my servant Job.

<b>9 </b>So Eliphaz the Temanite and Bildad the Shuhite <i>and</i> Zophar the Naamathite went, and did according as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded them: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> also accepted Job.

<b>10 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> turned the captivity of Job, when he prayed for his friends: also the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> gave Job twice as much as he had before.

<b>11 </b>Then came there unto him all his brethren, and all his sisters, and all they that had been of his acquaintance before, and did eat bread with him in his house: and they bemoaned him, and comforted him over all the evil that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had brought upon him: every man also gave him a piece of money, and every one an earring of gold.

<b>12 </b>So the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> blessed the latter end of Job more than his beginning: for he had fourteen thousand sheep, and six thousand camels, and a thousand yoke of oxen, and a thousand she asses.

<b>13 </b>He had also seven sons and three daughters.

<b>14 </b>And he called the name of the first, Jemima; and the name of the second, Kezia; and the name of the third, Keren-happuch.

<b>15 </b>And in all the land were no women found <i>so</i> fair as the daughters of Job: and their father gave them inheritance among their brethren.

<b>16 </b>After this lived Job an hundred and forty years, and saw his sons, and his sons’ sons, <i>even</i> four generations.

<b>17 </b>So Job died, <i>being</i> old and full of days.


--------------------

<small>The Book of </small>Psalms

PSALM 1

<b>1 </b>Blessed <i>is</i> the man that walketh not in the counsel of the ungodly, nor standeth in the way of sinners, nor sitteth in the seat of the scornful.

<b>2 </b>But his delight <i>is</i> in the law of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and in his law doth he meditate day and night.

<b>3 </b>And he shall be like a tree planted by the rivers of water, that bringeth forth his fruit in his season; his leaf also shall not wither; and whatsoever he doeth shall prosper.

<b>4 </b>The ungodly <i>are</i> not so: but <i>are</i> like the chaff which the wind driveth away.

<b>5 </b>Therefore the ungodly shall not stand in the judgment, nor sinners in the congregation of the righteous.

<b>6 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> knoweth the way of the righteous: but the way of the ungodly shall perish.


--------------------

PSALM 2

<b>1 </b>Why do the heathen rage, and the people imagine a vain thing?

<b>2 </b>The kings of the earth set themselves, and the rulers take counsel together, against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and against his anointed, <i>saying,</i>

<b>3 </b>Let us break their bands asunder, and cast away their cords from us.

<b>4 </b>He that sitteth in the heavens shall laugh: the Lord shall have them in derision.

<b>5 </b>Then shall he speak unto them in his wrath, and vex them in his sore displeasure.

<b>6 </b>Yet have I set my king upon my holy hill of Zion.

<b>7 </b>I will declare the decree: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath said unto me, Thou <i>art</i> my Son; this day have I begotten thee.

<b>8 </b>Ask of me, and I shall give <i>thee</i> the heathen <i>for</i> thine inheritance, and the uttermost parts of the earth <i>for</i> thy possession.

<b>9 </b>Thou shalt break them with a rod of iron; thou shalt dash them in pieces like a potter’s vessel.

<b>10 </b>Be wise now therefore, O ye kings: be instructed, ye judges of the earth.

<b>11 </b>Serve the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with fear, and rejoice with trembling.

<b>12 </b>Kiss the Son, lest he be angry, and ye perish <i>from</i> the way, when his wrath is kindled but a little. Blessed <i>are</i> all they that put their trust in him.


--------------------

PSALM 3

A Psalm of David, when he fled from Absalom his son.

<b>1 </b><span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, how are they increased that trouble me! many <i>are</i> they that rise up against me.

<b>2 </b>Many <i>there be</i> which say of my soul, <i>There is</i> no help for him in God. Selah.

<b>3 </b>But thou, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>art</i> a shield for me; my glory, and the lifter up of mine head.

<b>4 </b>I cried unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with my voice, and he heard me out of his holy hill. Selah.

<b>5 </b>I laid me down and slept; I awaked; for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sustained me.

<b>6 </b>I will not be afraid of ten thousands of people, that have set <i>themselves</i> against me round about.

<b>7 </b>Arise, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; save me, O my God: for thou hast smitten all mine enemies <i>upon</i> the cheek bone; thou hast broken the teeth of the ungodly.

<b>8 </b>Salvation <i>belongeth</i> unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: thy blessing <i>is</i> upon thy people. Selah.


--------------------

PSALM 4

To the chief Musician on Neginoth, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>Hear me when I call, O God of my righteousness: thou hast enlarged me <i>when I was</i> in distress; have mercy upon me, and hear my prayer.

<b>2 </b>O ye sons of men, how long <i>will ye turn</i> my glory into shame? <i>how long</i> will ye love vanity, <i>and</i> seek after leasing? Selah.

<b>3 </b>But know that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath set apart him that is godly for himself: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will hear when I call unto him.

<b>4 </b>Stand in awe, and sin not: commune with your own heart upon your bed, and be still. Selah.

<b>5 </b>Offer the sacrifices of righteousness, and put your trust in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>6 </b><i>There be</i> many that say, Who will shew us <i>any</i> good? <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, lift thou up the light of thy countenance upon us.

<b>7 </b>Thou hast put gladness in my heart, more than in the time <i>that</i> their corn and their wine increased.

<b>8 </b>I will both lay me down in peace, and sleep: for thou, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, only makest me dwell in safety.


--------------------

PSALM 5

To the chief Musician upon Nehiloth, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>Give ear to my words, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, consider my meditation.

<b>2 </b>Hearken unto the voice of my cry, my King, and my God: for unto thee will I pray.

<b>3 </b>My voice shalt thou hear in the morning, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; in the morning will I direct <i>my prayer</i> unto thee, and will look up.

<b>4 </b>For thou <i>art</i> not a God that hath pleasure in wickedness: neither shall evil dwell with thee.

<b>5 </b>The foolish shall not stand in thy sight: thou hatest all workers of iniquity.

<b>6 </b>Thou shalt destroy them that speak leasing: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will abhor the bloody and deceitful man.

<b>7 </b>But as for me, I will come <i>into</i> thy house in the multitude of thy mercy: <i>and</i> in thy fear will I worship toward thy holy temple.

<b>8 </b>Lead me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, in thy righteousness because of mine enemies; make thy way straight before my face.

<b>9 </b>For <i>there is</i> no faithfulness in their mouth; their inward part <i>is</i> very wickedness; their throat <i>is</i> an open sepulchre; they flatter with their tongue.

<b>10 </b>Destroy thou them, O God; let them fall by their own counsels; cast them out in the multitude of their transgressions; for they have rebelled against thee.

<b>11 </b>But let all those that put their trust in thee rejoice: let them ever shout for joy, because thou defendest them: let them also that love thy name be joyful in thee.

<b>12 </b>For thou, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, wilt bless the righteous; with favour wilt thou compass him as <i>with</i> a shield.


--------------------

PSALM 6

To the chief Musician on Neginoth upon Sheminith, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, rebuke me not in thine anger, neither chasten me in thy hot displeasure.

<b>2 </b>Have mercy upon me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for I <i>am</i> weak: O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, heal me; for my bones are vexed.

<b>3 </b>My soul is also sore vexed: but thou, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, how long?

<b>4 </b>Return, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, deliver my soul: oh save me for thy mercies’ sake.

<b>5 </b>For in death <i>there is</i> no remembrance of thee: in the grave who shall give thee thanks?

<b>6 </b>I am weary with my groaning; all the night make I my bed to swim; I water my couch with my tears.

<b>7 </b>Mine eye is consumed because of grief; it waxeth old because of all mine enemies.

<b>8 </b>Depart from me, all ye workers of iniquity; for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath heard the voice of my weeping.

<b>9 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath heard my supplication; the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will receive my prayer.

<b>10 </b>Let all mine enemies be ashamed and sore vexed: let them return <i>and</i> be ashamed suddenly.


--------------------

PSALM 7

Shiggaion of David, which he sang unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, concerning the words of Cush the Benjamite.

<b>1 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God, in thee do I put my trust: save me from all them that persecute me, and deliver me:

<b>2 </b>Lest he tear my soul like a lion, rending <i>it</i> in pieces, while <i>there is</i> none to deliver.

<b>3 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God, if I have done this; if there be iniquity in my hands;

<b>4 </b>If I have rewarded evil unto him that was at peace with me; (yea, I have delivered him that without cause is mine enemy:)

<b>5 </b>Let the enemy persecute my soul, and take <i>it;</i> yea, let him tread down my life upon the earth, and lay mine honour in the dust. Selah.

<b>6 </b>Arise, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, in thine anger, lift up thyself because of the rage of mine enemies: and awake for me <i>to</i> the judgment <i>that</i> thou hast commanded.

<b>7 </b>So shall the congregation of the people compass thee about: for their sakes therefore return thou on high.

<b>8 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall judge the people: judge me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, according to my righteousness, and according to mine integrity <i>that is</i> in me.

<b>9 </b>Oh let the wickedness of the wicked come to an end; but establish the just: for the righteous God trieth the hearts and reins.

<b>10 </b>My defence <i>is</i> of God, which saveth the upright in heart.

<b>11 </b>God judgeth the righteous, and God is angry <i>with the wicked</i> every day.

<b>12 </b>If he turn not, he will whet his sword; he hath bent his bow, and made it ready.

<b>13 </b>He hath also prepared for him the instruments of death; he ordaineth his arrows against the persecutors.

<b>14 </b>Behold, he travaileth with iniquity, and hath conceived mischief, and brought forth falsehood.

<b>15 </b>He made a pit, and digged it, and is fallen into the ditch <i>which</i> he made.

<b>16 </b>His mischief shall return upon his own head, and his violent dealing shall come down upon his own pate.

<b>17 </b>I will praise the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> according to his righteousness: and will sing praise to the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> most high.


--------------------

PSALM 8

To the chief Musician upon Gittith, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our Lord, how excellent <i>is</i> thy name in all the earth! who hast set thy glory above the heavens.

<b>2 </b>Out of the mouth of babes and sucklings hast thou ordained strength because of thine enemies, that thou mightest still the enemy and the avenger.

<b>3 </b>When I consider thy heavens, the work of thy fingers, the moon and the stars, which thou hast ordained;

<b>4 </b>What is man, that thou art mindful of him? and the son of man, that thou visitest him?

<b>5 </b>For thou hast made him a little lower than the angels, and hast crowned him with glory and honour.

<b>6 </b>Thou madest him to have dominion over the works of thy hands; thou hast put all <i>things</i> under his feet:

<b>7 </b>All sheep and oxen, yea, and the beasts of the field;

<b>8 </b>The fowl of the air, and the fish of the sea, <i>and whatsoever</i> passeth through the paths of the seas.

<b>9 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our Lord, how excellent <i>is</i> thy name in all the earth!


--------------------

PSALM 9

To the chief Musician upon Muth-labben, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>I will praise <i>thee,</i> O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, with my whole heart; I will shew forth all thy marvellous works.

<b>2 </b>I will be glad and rejoice in thee: I will sing praise to thy name, O thou most High.

<b>3 </b>When mine enemies are turned back, they shall fall and perish at thy presence.

<b>4 </b>For thou hast maintained my right and my cause; thou satest in the throne judging right.

<b>5 </b>Thou hast rebuked the heathen, thou hast destroyed the wicked, thou hast put out their name for ever and ever.

<b>6 </b>O thou enemy, destructions are come to a perpetual end: and thou hast destroyed cities; their memorial is perished with them.

<b>7 </b>But the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall endure for ever: he hath prepared his throne for judgment.

<b>8 </b>And he shall judge the world in righteousness, he shall minister judgment to the people in uprightness.

<b>9 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> also will be a refuge for the oppressed, a refuge in times of trouble.

<b>10 </b>And they that know thy name will put their trust in thee: for thou, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, hast not forsaken them that seek thee.

<b>11 </b>Sing praises to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which dwelleth in Zion: declare among the people his doings.

<b>12 </b>When he maketh inquisition for blood, he remembereth them: he forgetteth not the cry of the humble.

<b>13 </b>Have mercy upon me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; consider my trouble <i>which I suffer</i> of them that hate me, thou that liftest me up from the gates of death:

<b>14 </b>That I may shew forth all thy praise in the gates of the daughter of Zion: I will rejoice in thy salvation.

<b>15 </b>The heathen are sunk down in the pit <i>that</i> they made: in the net which they hid is their own foot taken.

<b>16 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> is known <i>by</i> the judgment <i>which</i> he executeth: the wicked is snared in the work of his own hands. Higgaion. Selah.

<b>17 </b>The wicked shall be turned into hell, <i>and</i> all the nations that forget God.

<b>18 </b>For the needy shall not alway be forgotten: the expectation of the poor shall <i>not</i> perish for ever.

<b>19 </b>Arise, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; let not man prevail: let the heathen be judged in thy sight.

<b>20 </b>Put them in fear, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: <i>that</i> the nations may know themselves <i>to be but</i> men. Selah.


--------------------

PSALM 10

<b>1 </b>Why standest thou afar off, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>? <i>why</i> hidest thou <i>thyself</i> in times of trouble?

<b>2 </b>The wicked in <i>his</i> pride doth persecute the poor: let them be taken in the devices that they have imagined.

<b>3 </b>For the wicked boasteth of his heart’s desire, and blesseth the covetous, <i>whom</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> abhorreth.

<b>4 </b>The wicked, through the pride of his countenance, will not seek <i>after God:</i> God <i>is</i> not in all his thoughts.

<b>5 </b>His ways are always grievous; thy judgments <i>are</i> far above out of his sight: <i>as for</i> all his enemies, he puffeth at them.

<b>6 </b>He hath said in his heart, I shall not be moved: for <i>I shall</i> never <i>be</i> in adversity.

<b>7 </b>His mouth is full of cursing and deceit and fraud: under his tongue <i>is</i> mischief and vanity.

<b>8 </b>He sitteth in the lurking places of the villages: in the secret places doth he murder the innocent: his eyes are privily set against the poor.

<b>9 </b>He lieth in wait secretly as a lion in his den: he lieth in wait to catch the poor: he doth catch the poor, when he draweth him into his net.

<b>10 </b>He croucheth, <i>and</i> humbleth himself, that the poor may fall by his strong ones.

<b>11 </b>He hath said in his heart, God hath forgotten: he hideth his face; he will never see <i>it.</i>

<b>12 </b>Arise, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; O God, lift up thine hand: forget not the humble.

<b>13 </b>Wherefore doth the wicked contemn God? he hath said in his heart, Thou wilt not require <i>it.</i>

<b>14 </b>Thou hast seen <i>it;</i> for thou beholdest mischief and spite, to requite <i>it</i> with thy hand: the poor committeth himself unto thee; thou art the helper of the fatherless.

<b>15 </b>Break thou the arm of the wicked and the evil <i>man:</i> seek out his wickedness <i>till</i> thou find none.

<b>16 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> King for ever and ever: the heathen are perished out of his land.

<b>17 </b><span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, thou hast heard the desire of the humble: thou wilt prepare their heart, thou wilt cause thine ear to hear:

<b>18 </b>To judge the fatherless and the oppressed, that the man of the earth may no more oppress.


--------------------

PSALM 11

To the chief Musician, <i>A Psalm</i> of David.

<b>1 </b>In the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> put I my trust: how say ye to my soul, Flee <i>as</i> a bird to your mountain?

<b>2 </b>For, lo, the wicked bend <i>their</i> bow, they make ready their arrow upon the string, that they may privily shoot at the upright in heart.

<b>3 </b>If the foundations be destroyed, what can the righteous do?

<b>4 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> in his holy temple, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s throne <i>is</i> in heaven: his eyes behold, his eyelids try, the children of men.

<b>5 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> trieth the righteous: but the wicked and him that loveth violence his soul hateth.

<b>6 </b>Upon the wicked he shall rain snares, fire and brimstone, and an horrible tempest: <i>this shall be</i> the portion of their cup.

<b>7 </b>For the righteous <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> loveth righteousness; his countenance doth behold the upright.


--------------------

PSALM 12

To the chief Musician upon Sheminith, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>Help, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for the godly man ceaseth; for the faithful fail from among the children of men.

<b>2 </b>They speak vanity every one with his neighbour: <i>with</i> flattering lips <i>and</i> with a double heart do they speak.

<b>3 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall cut off all flattering lips, <i>and</i> the tongue that speaketh proud things:

<b>4 </b>Who have said, With our tongue will we prevail; our lips <i>are</i> our own: who <i>is</i> lord over us?

<b>5 </b>For the oppression of the poor, for the sighing of the needy, now will I arise, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; I will set <i>him</i> in safety <i>from him that</i> puffeth at him.

<b>6 </b>The words of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>are</i> pure words: <i>as</i> silver tried in a furnace of earth, purified seven times.

<b>7 </b>Thou shalt keep them, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, thou shalt preserve them from this generation for ever.

<b>8 </b>The wicked walk on every side, when the vilest men are exalted.


--------------------

PSALM 13

To the chief Musician, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>How long wilt thou forget me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>? for ever? how long wilt thou hide thy face from me?

<b>2 </b>How long shall I take counsel in my soul, <i>having</i> sorrow in my heart daily? how long shall mine enemy be exalted over me?

<b>3 </b>Consider <i>and</i> hear me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God: lighten mine eyes, lest I sleep the <i>sleep of</i> death;

<b>4 </b>Lest mine enemy say, I have prevailed against him; <i>and</i> those that trouble me rejoice when I am moved.

<b>5 </b>But I have trusted in thy mercy; my heart shall rejoice in thy salvation.

<b>6 </b>I will sing unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, because he hath dealt bountifully with me.


--------------------

PSALM 14

To the chief Musician, <i>A Psalm</i> of David.

<b>1 </b>The fool hath said in his heart, <i>There is</i> no God. They are corrupt, they have done abominable works, <i>there is</i> none that doeth good.

<b>2 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> looked down from heaven upon the children of men, to see if there were any that did understand, <i>and</i> seek God.

<b>3 </b>They are all gone aside, they are <i>all</i> together become filthy: <i>there is</i> none that doeth good, no, not one.

<b>4 </b>Have all the workers of iniquity no knowledge? who eat up my people <i>as</i> they eat bread, and call not upon the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>5 </b>There were they in great fear: for God <i>is</i> in the generation of the righteous.

<b>6 </b>Ye have shamed the counsel of the poor, because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> his refuge.

<b>7 </b>Oh that the salvation of Israel <i>were come</i> out of Zion! when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> bringeth back the captivity of his people, Jacob shall rejoice, <i>and</i> Israel shall be glad.


--------------------

PSALM 15

A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b><span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, who shall abide in thy tabernacle? who shall dwell in thy holy hill?

<b>2 </b>He that walketh uprightly, and worketh righteousness, and speaketh the truth in his heart.

<b>3 </b><i>He that</i> backbiteth not with his tongue, nor doeth evil to his neighbour, nor taketh up a reproach against his neighbour.

<b>4 </b>In whose eyes a vile person is contemned; but he honoureth them that fear the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. <i>He that</i> sweareth to <i>his own</i> hurt, and changeth not.

<b>5 </b><i>He that</i> putteth not out his money to usury, nor taketh reward against the innocent. He that doeth these <i>things</i> shall never be moved.


--------------------

PSALM 16

Michtam of David.

<b>1 </b>Preserve me, O God: for in thee do I put my trust.

<b>2 </b><i>O my soul,</i> thou hast said unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Thou <i>art</i> my Lord: my goodness <i>extendeth</i> not to thee;

<b>3 </b><i>But</i> to the saints that <i>are</i> in the earth, and <i>to</i> the excellent, in whom <i>is</i> all my delight.

<b>4 </b>Their sorrows shall be multiplied <i>that</i> hasten <i>after</i> another <i>god:</i> their drink offerings of blood will I not offer, nor take up their names into my lips.

<b>5 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> the portion of mine inheritance and of my cup: thou maintainest my lot.

<b>6 </b>The lines are fallen unto me in pleasant <i>places;</i> yea, I have a goodly heritage.

<b>7 </b>I will bless the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, who hath given me counsel: my reins also instruct me in the night seasons.

<b>8 </b>I have set the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> always before me: because <i>he is</i> at my right hand, I shall not be moved.

<b>9 </b>Therefore my heart is glad, and my glory rejoiceth: my flesh also shall rest in hope.

<b>10 </b>For thou wilt not leave my soul in hell; neither wilt thou suffer thine Holy One to see corruption.

<b>11 </b>Thou wilt shew me the path of life: in thy presence <i>is</i> fulness of joy; at thy right hand <i>there are</i> pleasures for evermore.


--------------------

PSALM 17

A Prayer of David.

<b>1 </b>Hear the right, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, attend unto my cry, give ear unto my prayer, <i>that goeth</i> not out of feigned lips.

<b>2 </b>Let my sentence come forth from thy presence; let thine eyes behold the things that are equal.

<b>3 </b>Thou hast proved mine heart; thou hast visited <i>me</i> in the night; thou hast tried me, <i>and</i> shalt find nothing; I am purposed <i>that</i> my mouth shall not transgress.

<b>4 </b>Concerning the works of men, by the word of thy lips I have kept <i>me from</i> the paths of the destroyer.

<b>5 </b>Hold up my goings in thy paths, <i>that</i> my footsteps slip not.

<b>6 </b>I have called upon thee, for thou wilt hear me, O God: incline thine ear unto me, <i>and hear</i> my speech.

<b>7 </b>Shew thy marvellous lovingkindness, O thou that savest by thy right hand them which put their trust <i>in thee</i> from those that rise up <i>against them.</i>

<b>8 </b>Keep me as the apple of the eye, hide me under the shadow of thy wings,

<b>9 </b>From the wicked that oppress me, <i>from</i> my deadly enemies, <i>who</i> compass me about.

<b>10 </b>They are inclosed in their own fat: with their mouth they speak proudly.

<b>11 </b>They have now compassed us in our steps: they have set their eyes bowing down to the earth;

<b>12 </b>Like as a lion <i>that</i> is greedy of his prey, and as it were a young lion lurking in secret places.

<b>13 </b>Arise, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, disappoint him, cast him down: deliver my soul from the wicked, <i>which is</i> thy sword:

<b>14 </b>From men <i>which are</i> thy hand, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, from men of the world, <i>which have</i> their portion in <i>this</i> life, and whose belly thou fillest with thy hid <i>treasure:</i> they are full of children, and leave the rest of their <i>substance</i> to their babes.

<b>15 </b>As for me, I will behold thy face in righteousness: I shall be satisfied, when I awake, with thy likeness.


--------------------

PSALM 18

To the chief Musician, <i>A Psalm</i> of David, the servant of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, who spake unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> the words of this song in the day <i>that</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> delivered him from the hand of all his enemies, and from the hand of Saul: And he said,

<b>1 </b>I will love thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, my strength.

<b>2 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> my rock, and my fortress, and my deliverer; my God, my strength, in whom I will trust; my buckler, and the horn of my salvation, <i>and</i> my high tower.

<b>3 </b>I will call upon the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>who is worthy</i> to be praised: so shall I be saved from mine enemies.

<b>4 </b>The sorrows of death compassed me, and the floods of ungodly men made me afraid.

<b>5 </b>The sorrows of hell compassed me about: the snares of death prevented me.

<b>6 </b>In my distress I called upon the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and cried unto my God: he heard my voice out of his temple, and my cry came before him, <i>even</i> into his ears.

<b>7 </b>Then the earth shook and trembled; the foundations also of the hills moved and were shaken, because he was wroth.

<b>8 </b>There went up a smoke out of his nostrils, and fire out of his mouth devoured: coals were kindled by it.

<b>9 </b>He bowed the heavens also, and came down: and darkness <i>was</i> under his feet.

<b>10 </b>And he rode upon a cherub, and did fly: yea, he did fly upon the wings of the wind.

<b>11 </b>He made darkness his secret place; his pavilion round about him <i>were</i> dark waters <i>and</i> thick clouds of the skies.

<b>12 </b>At the brightness <i>that was</i> before him his thick clouds passed, hail <i>stones</i> and coals of fire.

<b>13 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> also thundered in the heavens, and the Highest gave his voice; hail <i>stones</i> and coals of fire.

<b>14 </b>Yea, he sent out his arrows, and scattered them; and he shot out lightnings, and discomfited them.

<b>15 </b>Then the channels of waters were seen, and the foundations of the world were discovered at thy rebuke, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, at the blast of the breath of thy nostrils.

<b>16 </b>He sent from above, he took me, he drew me out of many waters.

<b>17 </b>He delivered me from my strong enemy, and from them which hated me: for they were too strong for me.

<b>18 </b>They prevented me in the day of my calamity: but the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> was my stay.

<b>19 </b>He brought me forth also into a large place; he delivered me, because he delighted in me.

<b>20 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> rewarded me according to my righteousness; according to the cleanness of my hands hath he recompensed me.

<b>21 </b>For I have kept the ways of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and have not wickedly departed from my God.

<b>22 </b>For all his judgments <i>were</i> before me, and I did not put away his statutes from me.

<b>23 </b>I was also upright before him, and I kept myself from mine iniquity.

<b>24 </b>Therefore hath the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> recompensed me according to my righteousness, according to the cleanness of my hands in his eyesight.

<b>25 </b>With the merciful thou wilt shew thyself merciful; with an upright man thou wilt shew thyself upright;

<b>26 </b>With the pure thou wilt shew thyself pure; and with the froward thou wilt shew thyself froward.

<b>27 </b>For thou wilt save the afflicted people; but wilt bring down high looks.

<b>28 </b>For thou wilt light my candle: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God will enlighten my darkness.

<b>29 </b>For by thee I have run through a troop; and by my God have I leaped over a wall.

<b>30 </b><i>As for</i> God, his way <i>is</i> perfect: the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> is tried: he <i>is</i> a buckler to all those that trust in him.

<b>31 </b>For who <i>is</i> God save the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>? or who <i>is</i> a rock save our God?

<b>32 </b><i>It is</i> God that girdeth me with strength, and maketh my way perfect.

<b>33 </b>He maketh my feet like hinds’ <i>feet</i><i>,</i> and setteth me upon my high places.

<b>34 </b>He teacheth my hands to war, so that a bow of steel is broken by mine arms.

<b>35 </b>Thou hast also given me the shield of thy salvation: and thy right hand hath holden me up, and thy gentleness hath made me great.

<b>36 </b>Thou hast enlarged my steps under me, that my feet did not slip.

<b>37 </b>I have pursued mine enemies, and overtaken them: neither did I turn again till they were consumed.

<b>38 </b>I have wounded them that they were not able to rise: they are fallen under my feet.

<b>39 </b>For thou hast girded me with strength unto the battle: thou hast subdued under me those that rose up against me.

<b>40 </b>Thou hast also given me the necks of mine enemies; that I might destroy them that hate me.

<b>41 </b>They cried, but <i>there was</i> none to save <i>them: even</i> unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, but he answered them not.

<b>42 </b>Then did I beat them small as the dust before the wind: I did cast them out as the dirt in the streets.

<b>43 </b>Thou hast delivered me from the strivings of the people; <i>and</i> thou hast made me the head of the heathen: a people <i>whom</i> I have not known shall serve me.

<b>44 </b>As soon as they hear of me, they shall obey me: the strangers shall submit themselves unto me.

<b>45 </b>The strangers shall fade away, and be afraid out of their close places.

<b>46 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth; and blessed <i>be</i> my rock; and let the God of my salvation be exalted.

<b>47 </b><i>It is</i> God that avengeth me, and subdueth the people under me.

<b>48 </b>He delivereth me from mine enemies: yea, thou liftest me up above those that rise up against me: thou hast delivered me from the violent man.

<b>49 </b>Therefore will I give thanks unto thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, among the heathen, and sing praises unto thy name.

<b>50 </b>Great deliverance giveth he to his king; and sheweth mercy to his anointed, to David, and to his seed for evermore.


--------------------

PSALM 19

To the chief Musician, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>The heavens declare the glory of God; and the firmament sheweth his handywork.

<b>2 </b>Day unto day uttereth speech, and night unto night sheweth knowledge.

<b>3 </b><i>There is</i> no speech nor language, <i>where</i> their voice is not heard.

<b>4 </b>Their line is gone out through all the earth, and their words to the end of the world. In them hath he set a tabernacle for the sun,

<b>5 </b>Which <i>is</i> as a bridegroom coming out of his chamber, <i>and</i> rejoiceth as a strong man to run a race.

<b>6 </b>His going forth <i>is</i> from the end of the heaven, and his circuit unto the ends of it: and there is nothing hid from the heat thereof.

<b>7 </b>The law of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> perfect, converting the soul: the testimony of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> sure, making wise the simple.

<b>8 </b>The statutes of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>are</i> right, rejoicing the heart: the commandment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> pure, enlightening the eyes.

<b>9 </b>The fear of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> clean, enduring for ever: the judgments of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>are</i> true <i>and</i> righteous altogether.

<b>10 </b>More to be desired <i>are they</i> than gold, yea, than much fine gold: sweeter also than honey and the honeycomb.

<b>11 </b>Moreover by them is thy servant warned: <i>and</i> in keeping of them <i>there is</i> great reward.

<b>12 </b>Who can understand <i>his</i> errors? cleanse thou me from secret <i>faults.</i>

<b>13 </b>Keep back thy servant also from presumptuous <i>sins;</i> let them not have dominion over me: then shall I be upright, and I shall be innocent from the great transgression.

<b>14 </b>Let the words of my mouth, and the meditation of my heart, be acceptable in thy sight, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, my strength, and my redeemer.


--------------------

PSALM 20

To the chief Musician, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hear thee in the day of trouble; the name of the God of Jacob defend thee;

<b>2 </b>Send thee help from the sanctuary, and strengthen thee out of Zion;

<b>3 </b>Remember all thy offerings, and accept thy burnt sacrifice; Selah.

<b>4 </b>Grant thee according to thine own heart, and fulfil all thy counsel.

<b>5 </b>We will rejoice in thy salvation, and in the name of our God we will set up <i>our</i> banners: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> fulfil all thy petitions.

<b>6 </b>Now know I that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> saveth his anointed; he will hear him from his holy heaven with the saving strength of his right hand.

<b>7 </b>Some <i>trust</i> in chariots, and some in horses: but we will remember the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God.

<b>8 </b>They are brought down and fallen: but we are risen, and stand upright.

<b>9 </b>Save, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: let the king hear us when we call.


--------------------

PSALM 21

To the chief Musician, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>The king shall joy in thy strength, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and in thy salvation how greatly shall he rejoice!

<b>2 </b>Thou hast given him his heart’s desire, and hast not withholden the request of his lips. Selah.

<b>3 </b>For thou preventest him with the blessings of goodness: thou settest a crown of pure gold on his head.

<b>4 </b>He asked life of thee, <i>and</i> thou gavest <i>it</i> him, <i>even</i> length of days for ever and ever.

<b>5 </b>His glory <i>is</i> great in thy salvation: honour and majesty hast thou laid upon him.

<b>6 </b>For thou hast made him most blessed for ever: thou hast made him exceeding glad with thy countenance.

<b>7 </b>For the king trusteth in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and through the mercy of the most High he shall not be moved.

<b>8 </b>Thine hand shall find out all thine enemies: thy right hand shall find out those that hate thee.

<b>9 </b>Thou shalt make them as a fiery oven in the time of thine anger: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall swallow them up in his wrath, and the fire shall devour them.

<b>10 </b>Their fruit shalt thou destroy from the earth, and their seed from among the children of men.

<b>11 </b>For they intended evil against thee: they imagined a mischievous device, <i>which</i> they are not able <i>to perform.</i>

<b>12 </b>Therefore shalt thou make them turn their back, <i>when</i> thou shalt make ready <i>thine arrows</i> upon thy strings against the face of them.

<b>13 </b>Be thou exalted, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, in thine own strength: <i>so</i> will we sing and praise thy power.


--------------------

PSALM 22

To the chief Musician upon Aijeleth Shahar, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me? <i>why art thou so</i> far from helping me, <i>and from</i> the words of my roaring?

<b>2 </b>O my God, I cry in the daytime, but thou hearest not; and in the night season, and am not silent.

<b>3 </b>But thou <i>art</i> holy, <i>O thou</i> that inhabitest the praises of Israel.

<b>4 </b>Our fathers trusted in thee: they trusted, and thou didst deliver them.

<b>5 </b>They cried unto thee, and were delivered: they trusted in thee, and were not confounded.

<b>6 </b>But I <i>am</i> a worm, and no man; a reproach of men, and despised of the people.

<b>7 </b>All they that see me laugh me to scorn: they shoot out the lip, they shake the head, <i>saying,</i>

<b>8 </b>He trusted on the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>that</i> he would deliver him: let him deliver him, seeing he delighted in him.

<b>9 </b>But thou <i>art</i> he that took me out of the womb: thou didst make me hope <i>when I was</i> upon my mother’s breasts.

<b>10 </b>I was cast upon thee from the womb: thou <i>art</i> my God from my mother’s belly.

<b>11 </b>Be not far from me; for trouble <i>is</i> near; for <i>there is</i> none to help.

<b>12 </b>Many bulls have compassed me: strong <i>bulls</i> of Bashan have beset me round.

<b>13 </b>They gaped upon me <i>with</i> their mouths, <i>as</i> a ravening and a roaring lion.

<b>14 </b>I am poured out like water, and all my bones are out of joint: my heart is like wax; it is melted in the midst of my bowels.

<b>15 </b>My strength is dried up like a potsherd; and my tongue cleaveth to my jaws; and thou hast brought me into the dust of death.

<b>16 </b>For dogs have compassed me: the assembly of the wicked have inclosed me: they pierced my hands and my feet.

<b>17 </b>I may tell all my bones: they look <i>and</i> stare upon me.

<b>18 </b>They part my garments among them, and cast lots upon my vesture.

<b>19 </b>But be not thou far from me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: O my strength, haste thee to help me.

<b>20 </b>Deliver my soul from the sword; my darling from the power of the dog.

<b>21 </b>Save me from the lion’s mouth: for thou hast heard me from the horns of the unicorns.

<b>22 </b>I will declare thy name unto my brethren: in the midst of the congregation will I praise thee.

<b>23 </b>Ye that fear the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, praise him; all ye the seed of Jacob, glorify him; and fear him, all ye the seed of Israel.

<b>24 </b>For he hath not despised nor abhorred the affliction of the afflicted; neither hath he hid his face from him; but when he cried unto him, he heard.

<b>25 </b>My praise <i>shall be</i> of thee in the great congregation: I will pay my vows before them that fear him.

<b>26 </b>The meek shall eat and be satisfied: they shall praise the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that seek him: your heart shall live for ever.

<b>27 </b>All the ends of the world shall remember and turn unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and all the kindreds of the nations shall worship before thee.

<b>28 </b>For the kingdom <i>is</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s: and he <i>is</i> the governor among the nations.

<b>29 </b>All <i>they that be</i> fat upon earth shall eat and worship: all they that go down to the dust shall bow before him: and none can keep alive his own soul.

<b>30 </b>A seed shall serve him; it shall be accounted to the Lord for a generation.

<b>31 </b>They shall come, and shall declare his righteousness unto a people that shall be born, that he hath done <i>this.</i>


--------------------

PSALM 23

A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> my shepherd; I shall not want.

<b>2 </b>He maketh me to lie down in green pastures: he leadeth me beside the still waters.

<b>3 </b>He restoreth my soul: he leadeth me in the paths of righteousness for his name’s sake.

<b>4 </b>Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil: for thou <i>art</i> with me; thy rod and thy staff they comfort me.

<b>5 </b>Thou preparest a table before me in the presence of mine enemies: thou anointest my head with oil; my cup runneth over.

<b>6 </b>Surely goodness and mercy shall follow me all the days of my life: and I will dwell in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> for ever.


--------------------

PSALM 24

A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>The earth <i>is</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s, and the fulness thereof; the world, and they that dwell therein.

<b>2 </b>For he hath founded it upon the seas, and established it upon the floods.

<b>3 </b>Who shall ascend into the hill of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>? or who shall stand in his holy place?

<b>4 </b>He that hath clean hands, and a pure heart; who hath not lifted up his soul unto vanity, nor sworn deceitfully.

<b>5 </b>He shall receive the blessing from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and righteousness from the God of his salvation.

<b>6 </b>This <i>is</i> the generation of them that seek him, that seek thy face, O Jacob. Selah.

<b>7 </b>Lift up your heads, O ye gates; and be ye lift up, ye everlasting doors; and the King of glory shall come in.

<b>8 </b>Who <i>is</i> this King of glory? The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> strong and mighty, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> mighty in battle.

<b>9 </b>Lift up your heads, O ye gates; even lift <i>them</i> up, ye everlasting doors; and the King of glory shall come in.

<b>10 </b>Who is this King of glory? The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, he <i>is</i> the King of glory. Selah.


--------------------

PSALM 25

<i>A Psalm</i> of David.

<b>1 </b>Unto thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, do I lift up my soul.

<b>2 </b>O my God, I trust in thee: let me not be ashamed, let not mine enemies triumph over me.

<b>3 </b>Yea, let none that wait on thee be ashamed: let them be ashamed which transgress without cause.

<b>4 </b>Shew me thy ways, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; teach me thy paths.

<b>5 </b>Lead me in thy truth, and teach me: for thou <i>art</i> the God of my salvation; on thee do I wait all the day.

<b>6 </b>Remember, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, thy tender mercies and thy lovingkindnesses; for they <i>have been</i> ever of old.

<b>7 </b>Remember not the sins of my youth, nor my transgressions: according to thy mercy remember thou me for thy goodness’ sake, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>8 </b>Good and upright <i>is</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: therefore will he teach sinners in the way.

<b>9 </b>The meek will he guide in judgment: and the meek will he teach his way.

<b>10 </b>All the paths of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>are</i> mercy and truth unto such as keep his covenant and his testimonies.

<b>11 </b>For thy name’s sake, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, pardon mine iniquity; for it <i>is</i> great.

<b>12 </b>What man <i>is</i> he that feareth the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>? him shall he teach in the way <i>that</i> he shall choose.

<b>13 </b>His soul shall dwell at ease; and his seed shall inherit the earth.

<b>14 </b>The secret of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> with them that fear him; and he will shew them his covenant.

<b>15 </b>Mine eyes <i>are</i> ever toward the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for he shall pluck my feet out of the net.

<b>16 </b>Turn thee unto me, and have mercy upon me; for I <i>am</i> desolate and afflicted.

<b>17 </b>The troubles of my heart are enlarged: <i>O</i> bring thou me out of my distresses.

<b>18 </b>Look upon mine affliction and my pain; and forgive all my sins.

<b>19 </b>Consider mine enemies; for they are many; and they hate me with cruel hatred.

<b>20 </b>O keep my soul, and deliver me: let me not be ashamed; for I put my trust in thee.

<b>21 </b>Let integrity and uprightness preserve me; for I wait on thee.

<b>22 </b>Redeem Israel, O God, out of all his troubles.


--------------------

PSALM 26

<i>A Psalm</i> of David.

<b>1 </b>Judge me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for I have walked in mine integrity: I have trusted also in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; <i>therefore</i> I shall not slide.

<b>2 </b>Examine me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and prove me; try my reins and my heart.

<b>3 </b>For thy lovingkindness <i>is</i> before mine eyes: and I have walked in thy truth.

<b>4 </b>I have not sat with vain persons, neither will I go in with dissemblers.

<b>5 </b>I have hated the congregation of evil doers; and will not sit with the wicked.

<b>6 </b>I will wash mine hands in innocency: so will I compass thine altar, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>:

<b>7 </b>That I may publish with the voice of thanksgiving, and tell of all thy wondrous works.

<b>8 </b><span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, I have loved the habitation of thy house, and the place where thine honour dwelleth.

<b>9 </b>Gather not my soul with sinners, nor my life with bloody men:

<b>10 </b>In whose hands <i>is</i> mischief, and their right hand is full of bribes.

<b>11 </b>But as for me, I will walk in mine integrity: redeem me, and be merciful unto me.

<b>12 </b>My foot standeth in an even place: in the congregations will I bless the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

PSALM 27

<i>A Psalm</i> of David.
