<b>1 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> my light and my salvation; whom shall I fear? the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> the strength of my life; of whom shall I be afraid?

<b>2 </b>When the wicked, <i>even</i> mine enemies and my foes, came upon me to eat up my flesh, they stumbled and fell.

<b>3 </b>Though an host should encamp against me, my heart shall not fear: though war should rise against me, in this <i>will</i> I <i>be</i> confident.

<b>4 </b>One <i>thing</i> have I desired of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that will I seek after; that I may dwell in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> all the days of my life, to behold the beauty of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and to inquire in his temple.

<b>5 </b>For in the time of trouble he shall hide me in his pavilion: in the secret of his tabernacle shall he hide me; he shall set me up upon a rock.

<b>6 </b>And now shall mine head be lifted up above mine enemies round about me: therefore will I offer in his tabernacle sacrifices of joy; I will sing, yea, I will sing praises unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>7 </b>Hear, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>when</i> I cry with my voice: have mercy also upon me, and answer me.

<b>8 </b><i>When thou saidst,</i> Seek ye my face; my heart said unto thee, Thy face, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, will I seek.

<b>9 </b>Hide not thy face <i>far</i> from me; put not thy servant away in anger: thou hast been my help; leave me not, neither forsake me, O God of my salvation.

<b>10 </b>When my father and my mother forsake me, then the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will take me up.

<b>11 </b>Teach me thy way, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and lead me in a plain path, because of mine enemies.

<b>12 </b>Deliver me not over unto the will of mine enemies: for false witnesses are risen up against me, and such as breathe out cruelty.

<b>13 </b><i>I had fainted,</i> unless I had believed to see the goodness of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in the land of the living.

<b>14 </b>Wait on the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: be of good courage, and he shall strengthen thine heart: wait, I say, on the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

PSALM 28

<i>A Psalm</i> of David.

<b>1 </b>Unto thee will I cry, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my rock; be not silent to me: lest, <i>if</i> thou be silent to me, I become like them that go down into the pit.

<b>2 </b>Hear the voice of my supplications, when I cry unto thee, when I lift up my hands toward thy holy oracle.

<b>3 </b>Draw me not away with the wicked, and with the workers of iniquity, which speak peace to their neighbours, but mischief <i>is</i> in their hearts.

<b>4 </b>Give them according to their deeds, and according to the wickedness of their endeavours: give them after the work of their hands; render to them their desert.

<b>5 </b>Because they regard not the works of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, nor the operation of his hands, he shall destroy them, and not build them up.

<b>6 </b>Blessed <i>be</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, because he hath heard the voice of my supplications.

<b>7 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> my strength and my shield; my heart trusted in him, and I am helped: therefore my heart greatly rejoiceth; and with my song will I praise him.

<b>8 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> their strength, and he <i>is</i> the saving strength of his anointed.

<b>9 </b>Save thy people, and bless thine inheritance: feed them also, and lift them up for ever.


--------------------

PSALM 29

A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>Give unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, O ye mighty, give unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> glory and strength.

<b>2 </b>Give unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> the glory due unto his name; worship the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in the beauty of holiness.

<b>3 </b>The voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> upon the waters: the God of glory thundereth: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> upon many waters.

<b>4 </b>The voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> powerful; the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> full of majesty.

<b>5 </b>The voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> breaketh the cedars; yea, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> breaketh the cedars of Lebanon.

<b>6 </b>He maketh them also to skip like a calf; Lebanon and Sirion like a young unicorn.

<b>7 </b>The voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> divideth the flames of fire.

<b>8 </b>The voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shaketh the wilderness; the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shaketh the wilderness of Kadesh.

<b>9 </b>The voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> maketh the hinds to calve, and discovereth the forests: and in his temple doth every one speak of <i>his</i> glory.

<b>10 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sitteth upon the flood; yea, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sitteth King for ever.

<b>11 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will give strength unto his people; the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will bless his people with peace.


--------------------

PSALM 30

A Psalm <i>and</i> Song <i>at</i> the dedication of the house of David.

<b>1 </b>I will extol thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for thou hast lifted me up, and hast not made my foes to rejoice over me.

<b>2 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God, I cried unto thee, and thou hast healed me.

<b>3 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, thou hast brought up my soul from the grave: thou hast kept me alive, that I should not go down to the pit.

<b>4 </b>Sing unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, O ye saints of his, and give thanks at the remembrance of his holiness.

<b>5 </b>For his anger <i>endureth but</i> a moment; in his favour <i>is</i> life: weeping may endure for a night, but joy <i>cometh</i> in the morning.

<b>6 </b>And in my prosperity I said, I shall never be moved.

<b>7 </b><span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, by thy favour thou hast made my mountain to stand strong: thou didst hide thy face, <i>and</i> I was troubled.

<b>8 </b>I cried to thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> I made supplication.

<b>9 </b>What profit <i>is there</i> in my blood, when I go down to the pit? Shall the dust praise thee? shall it declare thy truth?

<b>10 </b>Hear, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and have mercy upon me: <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, be thou my helper.

<b>11 </b>Thou hast turned for me my mourning into dancing: thou hast put off my sackcloth, and girded me with gladness;

<b>12 </b>To the end that <i>my</i> glory may sing praise to thee, and not be silent. O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God, I will give thanks unto thee for ever.


--------------------

PSALM 31

To the chief Musician, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>In thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, do I put my trust; let me never be ashamed: deliver me in thy righteousness.

<b>2 </b>Bow down thine ear to me; deliver me speedily: be thou my strong rock, for an house of defence to save me.

<b>3 </b>For thou <i>art</i> my rock and my fortress; therefore for thy name’s sake lead me, and guide me.

<b>4 </b>Pull me out of the net that they have laid privily for me: for thou <i>art</i> my strength.

<b>5 </b>Into thine hand I commit my spirit: thou hast redeemed me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of truth.

<b>6 </b>I have hated them that regard lying vanities: but I trust in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>7 </b>I will be glad and rejoice in thy mercy: for thou hast considered my trouble; thou hast known my soul in adversities;

<b>8 </b>And hast not shut me up into the hand of the enemy: thou hast set my feet in a large room.

<b>9 </b>Have mercy upon me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, for I am in trouble: mine eye is consumed with grief, <i>yea,</i> my soul and my belly.

<b>10 </b>For my life is spent with grief, and my years with sighing: my strength faileth because of mine iniquity, and my bones are consumed.

<b>11 </b>I was a reproach among all mine enemies, but especially among my neighbours, and a fear to mine acquaintance: they that did see me without fled from me.

<b>12 </b>I am forgotten as a dead man out of mind: I am like a broken vessel.

<b>13 </b>For I have heard the slander of many: fear <i>was</i> on every side: while they took counsel together against me, they devised to take away my life.

<b>14 </b>But I trusted in thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: I said, Thou <i>art</i> my God.

<b>15 </b>My times <i>are</i> in thy hand: deliver me from the hand of mine enemies, and from them that persecute me.

<b>16 </b>Make thy face to shine upon thy servant: save me for thy mercies’ sake.

<b>17 </b>Let me not be ashamed, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for I have called upon thee: let the wicked be ashamed, <i>and</i> let them be silent in the grave.

<b>18 </b>Let the lying lips be put to silence; which speak grievous things proudly and contemptuously against the righteous.

<b>19 </b><i>Oh</i> how great <i>is</i> thy goodness, which thou hast laid up for them that fear thee; <i>which</i> thou hast wrought for them that trust in thee before the sons of men!

<b>20 </b>Thou shalt hide them in the secret of thy presence from the pride of man: thou shalt keep them secretly in a pavilion from the strife of tongues.

<b>21 </b>Blessed <i>be</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for he hath shewed me his marvellous kindness in a strong city.

<b>22 </b>For I said in my haste, I am cut off from before thine eyes: nevertheless thou heardest the voice of my supplications when I cried unto thee.

<b>23 </b>O love the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, all ye his saints: <i>for</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> preserveth the faithful, and plentifully rewardeth the proud doer.

<b>24 </b>Be of good courage, and he shall strengthen your heart, all ye that hope in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

PSALM 32

<i>A Psalm</i> of David, Maschil.

<b>1 </b>Blessed <i>is he whose</i> transgression <i>is</i> forgiven, <i>whose</i> sin <i>is</i> covered.

<b>2 </b>Blessed <i>is</i> the man unto whom the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> imputeth not iniquity, and in whose spirit <i>there is</i> no guile.

<b>3 </b>When I kept silence, my bones waxed old through my roaring all the day long.

<b>4 </b>For day and night thy hand was heavy upon me: my moisture is turned into the drought of summer. Selah.

<b>5 </b>I acknowledged my sin unto thee, and mine iniquity have I not hid. I said, I will confess my transgressions unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and thou forgavest the iniquity of my sin. Selah.

<b>6 </b>For this shall every one that is godly pray unto thee in a time when thou mayest be found: surely in the floods of great waters they shall not come nigh unto him.

<b>7 </b>Thou <i>art</i> my hiding place; thou shalt preserve me from trouble; thou shalt compass me about with songs of deliverance. Selah.

<b>8 </b>I will instruct thee and teach thee in the way which thou shalt go: I will guide thee with mine eye.

<b>9 </b>Be ye not as the horse, <i>or</i> as the mule, <i>which</i> have no understanding: whose mouth must be held in with bit and bridle, lest they come near unto thee.

<b>10 </b>Many sorrows <i>shall be</i> to the wicked: but he that trusteth in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, mercy shall compass him about.

<b>11 </b>Be glad in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and rejoice, ye righteous: and shout for joy, all <i>ye that are</i> upright in heart.


--------------------

PSALM 33

<b>1 </b>Rejoice in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, O ye righteous: <i>for</i> praise is comely for the upright.

<b>2 </b>Praise the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with harp: sing unto him with the psaltery <i>and</i> an instrument of ten strings.

<b>3 </b>Sing unto him a new song; play skilfully with a loud noise.

<b>4 </b>For the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> right; and all his works <i>are done</i> in truth.

<b>5 </b>He loveth righteousness and judgment: the earth is full of the goodness of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>6 </b>By the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> were the heavens made; and all the host of them by the breath of his mouth.

<b>7 </b>He gathereth the waters of the sea together as an heap: he layeth up the depth in storehouses.

<b>8 </b>Let all the earth fear the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: let all the inhabitants of the world stand in awe of him.

<b>9 </b>For he spake, and it was <i>done;</i> he commanded, and it stood fast.

<b>10 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> bringeth the counsel of the heathen to nought: he maketh the devices of the people of none effect.

<b>11 </b>The counsel of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> standeth for ever, the thoughts of his heart to all generations.

<b>12 </b>Blessed <i>is</i> the nation whose God <i>is</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; <i>and</i> the people <i>whom</i> he hath chosen for his own inheritance.

<b>13 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> looketh from heaven; he beholdeth all the sons of men.

<b>14 </b>From the place of his habitation he looketh upon all the inhabitants of the earth.

<b>15 </b>He fashioneth their hearts alike; he considereth all their works.

<b>16 </b>There is no king saved by the multitude of an host: a mighty man is not delivered by much strength.

<b>17 </b>An horse <i>is</i> a vain thing for safety: neither shall he deliver <i>any</i> by his great strength.

<b>18 </b>Behold, the eye of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> upon them that fear him, upon them that hope in his mercy;

<b>19 </b>To deliver their soul from death, and to keep them alive in famine.

<b>20 </b>Our soul waiteth for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: he <i>is</i> our help and our shield.

<b>21 </b>For our heart shall rejoice in him, because we have trusted in his holy name.

<b>22 </b>Let thy mercy, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, be upon us, according as we hope in thee.


--------------------

PSALM 34

<i>A Psalm</i> of David, when he changed his behaviour before Abimelech; who drove him away, and he departed.

<b>1 </b>I will bless the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> at all times: his praise <i>shall</i> continually <i>be</i> in my mouth.

<b>2 </b>My soul shall make her boast in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: the humble shall hear <i>thereof,</i> and be glad.

<b>3 </b>O magnify the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with me, and let us exalt his name together.

<b>4 </b>I sought the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and he heard me, and delivered me from all my fears.

<b>5 </b>They looked unto him, and were lightened: and their faces were not ashamed.

<b>6 </b>This poor man cried, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> heard <i>him,</i> and saved him out of all his troubles.

<b>7 </b>The angel of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> encampeth round about them that fear him, and delivereth them.

<b>8 </b>O taste and see that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> good: blessed <i>is</i> the man <i>that</i> trusteth in him.

<b>9 </b>O fear the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, ye his saints: for <i>there is</i> no want to them that fear him.

<b>10 </b>The young lions do lack, and suffer hunger: but they that seek the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall not want any good <i>thing.</i>

<b>11 </b>Come, ye children, hearken unto me: I will teach you the fear of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>12 </b>What man <i>is he that</i> desireth life, <i>and</i> loveth <i>many</i> days, that he may see good?

<b>13 </b>Keep thy tongue from evil, and thy lips from speaking guile.

<b>14 </b>Depart from evil, and do good; seek peace, and pursue it.

<b>15 </b>The eyes of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>are</i> upon the righteous, and his ears <i>are open</i> unto their cry.

<b>16 </b>The face of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> against them that do evil, to cut off the remembrance of them from the earth.

<b>17 </b><i>The righteous</i> cry, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> heareth, and delivereth them out of all their troubles.

<b>18 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> nigh unto them that are of a broken heart; and saveth such as be of a contrite spirit.

<b>19 </b>Many <i>are</i> the afflictions of the righteous: but the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> delivereth him out of them all.

<b>20 </b>He keepeth all his bones: not one of them is broken.

<b>21 </b>Evil shall slay the wicked: and they that hate the righteous shall be desolate.

<b>22 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> redeemeth the soul of his servants: and none of them that trust in him shall be desolate.


--------------------

PSALM 35

<i>A Psalm</i> of David.

<b>1 </b>Plead <i>my cause,</i> O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, with them that strive with me: fight against them that fight against me.

<b>2 </b>Take hold of shield and buckler, and stand up for mine help.

<b>3 </b>Draw out also the spear, and stop <i>the way</i> against them that persecute me: say unto my soul, I <i>am</i> thy salvation.

<b>4 </b>Let them be confounded and put to shame that seek after my soul: let them be turned back and brought to confusion that devise my hurt.

<b>5 </b>Let them be as chaff before the wind: and let the angel of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> chase <i>them.</i>

<b>6 </b>Let their way be dark and slippery: and let the angel of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> persecute them.

<b>7 </b>For without cause have they hid for me their net <i>in</i> a pit, <i>which</i> without cause they have digged for my soul.

<b>8 </b>Let destruction come upon him at unawares; and let his net that he hath hid catch himself: into that very destruction let him fall.

<b>9 </b>And my soul shall be joyful in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: it shall rejoice in his salvation.

<b>10 </b>All my bones shall say, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, who <i>is</i> like unto thee, which deliverest the poor from him that is too strong for him, yea, the poor and the needy from him that spoileth him?

<b>11 </b>False witnesses did rise up; they laid to my charge <i>things</i> that I knew not.

<b>12 </b>They rewarded me evil for good <i>to</i> the spoiling of my soul.

<b>13 </b>But as for me, when they were sick, my clothing <i>was</i> sackcloth: I humbled my soul with fasting; and my prayer returned into mine own bosom.

<b>14 </b>I behaved myself as though <i>he had been</i> my friend <i>or</i> brother: I bowed down heavily, as one that mourneth <i>for his</i> mother.

<b>15 </b>But in mine adversity they rejoiced, and gathered themselves together: <i>yea,</i> the abjects gathered themselves together against me, and I knew <i>it</i> not; they did tear <i>me,</i> and ceased not:

<b>16 </b>With hypocritical mockers in feasts, they gnashed upon me with their teeth.

<b>17 </b>Lord, how long wilt thou look on? rescue my soul from their destructions, my darling from the lions.

<b>18 </b>I will give thee thanks in the great congregation: I will praise thee among much people.

<b>19 </b>Let not them that are mine enemies wrongfully rejoice over me: <i>neither</i> let them wink with the eye that hate me without a cause.

<b>20 </b>For they speak not peace: but they devise deceitful matters against <i>them that are</i> quiet in the land.

<b>21 </b>Yea, they opened their mouth wide against me, <i>and</i> said, Aha, aha, our eye hath seen <i>it.</i>

<b>22 </b><i>This</i> thou hast seen, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: keep not silence: O Lord, be not far from me.

<b>23 </b>Stir up thyself, and awake to my judgment, <i>even</i> unto my cause, my God and my Lord.

<b>24 </b>Judge me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God, according to thy righteousness; and let them not rejoice over me.

<b>25 </b>Let them not say in their hearts, Ah, so would we have it: let them not say, We have swallowed him up.

<b>26 </b>Let them be ashamed and brought to confusion together that rejoice at mine hurt: let them be clothed with shame and dishonour that magnify <i>themselves</i> against me.

<b>27 </b>Let them shout for joy, and be glad, that favour my righteous cause: yea, let them say continually, Let the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> be magnified, which hath pleasure in the prosperity of his servant.

<b>28 </b>And my tongue shall speak of thy righteousness <i>and</i> of thy praise all the day long.


--------------------

PSALM 36

To the chief Musician, <i>A Psalm</i> of David the servant of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>1 </b>The transgression of the wicked saith within my heart, <i>that there is</i> no fear of God before his eyes.

<b>2 </b>For he flattereth himself in his own eyes, until his iniquity be found to be hateful.

<b>3 </b>The words of his mouth <i>are</i> iniquity and deceit: he hath left off to be wise, <i>and</i> to do good.

<b>4 </b>He deviseth mischief upon his bed; he setteth himself in a way <i>that is</i> not good; he abhorreth not evil.

<b>5 </b>Thy mercy, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>is</i> in the heavens; <i>and</i> thy faithfulness <i>reacheth</i> unto the clouds.

<b>6 </b>Thy righteousness <i>is</i> like the great mountains; thy judgments <i>are</i> a great deep: O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, thou preservest man and beast.

<b>7 </b>How excellent <i>is</i> thy lovingkindness, O God! therefore the children of men put their trust under the shadow of thy wings.

<b>8 </b>They shall be abundantly satisfied with the fatness of thy house; and thou shalt make them drink of the river of thy pleasures.

<b>9 </b>For with thee <i>is</i> the fountain of life: in thy light shall we see light.

<b>10 </b>O continue thy lovingkindness unto them that know thee; and thy righteousness to the upright in heart.

<b>11 </b>Let not the foot of pride come against me, and let not the hand of the wicked remove me.

<b>12 </b>There are the workers of iniquity fallen: they are cast down, and shall not be able to rise.


--------------------

PSALM 37

<i>A Psalm</i> of David.

<b>1 </b>Fret not thyself because of evildoers, neither be thou envious against the workers of iniquity.

<b>2 </b>For they shall soon be cut down like the grass, and wither as the green herb.

<b>3 </b>Trust in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and do good; <i>so</i> shalt thou dwell in the land, and verily thou shalt be fed.

<b>4 </b>Delight thyself also in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and he shall give thee the desires of thine heart.

<b>5 </b>Commit thy way unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; trust also in him; and he shall bring <i>it</i> to pass.

<b>6 </b>And he shall bring forth thy righteousness as the light, and thy judgment as the noonday.

<b>7 </b>Rest in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and wait patiently for him: fret not thyself because of him who prospereth in his way, because of the man who bringeth wicked devices to pass.

<b>8 </b>Cease from anger, and forsake wrath: fret not thyself in any wise to do evil.

<b>9 </b>For evildoers shall be cut off: but those that wait upon the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, they shall inherit the earth.

<b>10 </b>For yet a little while, and the wicked <i>shall</i> not <i>be:</i> yea, thou shalt diligently consider his place, and it <i>shall</i> not <i>be.</i>

<b>11 </b>But the meek shall inherit the earth; and shall delight themselves in the abundance of peace.

<b>12 </b>The wicked plotteth against the just, and gnasheth upon him with his teeth.

<b>13 </b>The Lord shall laugh at him: for he seeth that his day is coming.

<b>14 </b>The wicked have drawn out the sword, and have bent their bow, to cast down the poor and needy, <i>and</i> to slay such as be of upright conversation.

<b>15 </b>Their sword shall enter into their own heart, and their bows shall be broken.

<b>16 </b>A little that a righteous man hath <i>is</i> better than the riches of many wicked.

<b>17 </b>For the arms of the wicked shall be broken: but the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> upholdeth the righteous.

<b>18 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> knoweth the days of the upright: and their inheritance shall be for ever.

<b>19 </b>They shall not be ashamed in the evil time: and in the days of famine they shall be satisfied.

<b>20 </b>But the wicked shall perish, and the enemies of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>shall be</i> as the fat of lambs: they shall consume; into smoke shall they consume away.

<b>21 </b>The wicked borroweth, and payeth not again: but the righteous sheweth mercy, and giveth.

<b>22 </b>For <i>such as be</i> blessed of him shall inherit the earth; and <i>they that be</i> cursed of him shall be cut off.

<b>23 </b>The steps of a <i>good</i> man are ordered by the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and he delighteth in his way.

<b>24 </b>Though he fall, he shall not be utterly cast down: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> upholdeth <i>him with</i> his hand.

<b>25 </b>I have been young, and <i>now</i> am old; yet have I not seen the righteous forsaken, nor his seed begging bread.

<b>26 </b><i>He is</i> ever merciful, and lendeth; and his seed <i>is</i> blessed.

<b>27 </b>Depart from evil, and do good; and dwell for evermore.

<b>28 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> loveth judgment, and forsaketh not his saints; they are preserved for ever: but the seed of the wicked shall be cut off.

<b>29 </b>The righteous shall inherit the land, and dwell therein for ever.

<b>30 </b>The mouth of the righteous speaketh wisdom, and his tongue talketh of judgment.

<b>31 </b>The law of his God <i>is</i> in his heart; none of his steps shall slide.

<b>32 </b>The wicked watcheth the righteous, and seeketh to slay him.

<b>33 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will not leave him in his hand, nor condemn him when he is judged.

<b>34 </b>Wait on the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and keep his way, and he shall exalt thee to inherit the land: when the wicked are cut off, thou shalt see <i>it.</i>

<b>35 </b>I have seen the wicked in great power, and spreading himself like a green bay tree.

<b>36 </b>Yet he passed away, and, lo, he <i>was</i> not: yea, I sought him, but he could not be found.

<b>37 </b>Mark the perfect <i>man,</i> and behold the upright: for the end of <i>that</i> man <i>is</i> peace.

<b>38 </b>But the transgressors shall be destroyed together: the end of the wicked shall be cut off.

<b>39 </b>But the salvation of the righteous <i>is</i> of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: <i>he is</i> their strength in the time of trouble.

<b>40 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall help them, and deliver them: he shall deliver them from the wicked, and save them, because they trust in him.


--------------------

PSALM 38

A Psalm of David, to bring to remembrance.

<b>1 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, rebuke me not in thy wrath: neither chasten me in thy hot displeasure.

<b>2 </b>For thine arrows stick fast in me, and thy hand presseth me sore.

<b>3 </b><i>There is</i> no soundness in my flesh because of thine anger; neither <i>is there any</i> rest in my bones because of my sin.

<b>4 </b>For mine iniquities are gone over mine head: as an heavy burden they are too heavy for me.

<b>5 </b>My wounds stink <i>and</i> are corrupt because of my foolishness.

<b>6 </b>I am troubled; I am bowed down greatly; I go mourning all the day long.

<b>7 </b>For my loins are filled with a loathsome <i>disease:</i> and <i>there is</i> no soundness in my flesh.

<b>8 </b>I am feeble and sore broken: I have roared by reason of the disquietness of my heart.

<b>9 </b>Lord, all my desire <i>is</i> before thee; and my groaning is not hid from thee.

<b>10 </b>My heart panteth, my strength faileth me: as for the light of mine eyes, it also is gone from me.

<b>11 </b>My lovers and my friends stand aloof from my sore; and my kinsmen stand afar off.

<b>12 </b>They also that seek after my life lay snares <i>for me:</i> and they that seek my hurt speak mischievous things, and imagine deceits all the day long.

<b>13 </b>But I, as a deaf <i>man,</i> heard not; and <i>I was</i> as a dumb man <i>that</i> openeth not his mouth.

<b>14 </b>Thus I was as a man that heareth not, and in whose mouth <i>are</i> no reproofs.

<b>15 </b>For in thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, do I hope: thou wilt hear, O Lord my God.

<b>16 </b>For I said, <i>Hear me,</i> lest <i>otherwise</i> they should rejoice over me: when my foot slippeth, they magnify <i>themselves</i> against me.

<b>17 </b>For I <i>am</i> ready to halt, and my sorrow <i>is</i> continually before me.

<b>18 </b>For I will declare mine iniquity; I will be sorry for my sin.

<b>19 </b>But mine enemies <i>are</i> lively, <i>and</i> they are strong: and they that hate me wrongfully are multiplied.

<b>20 </b>They also that render evil for good are mine adversaries; because I follow <i>the thing that</i> good <i>is.</i>

<b>21 </b>Forsake me not, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: O my God, be not far from me.

<b>22 </b>Make haste to help me, O Lord my salvation.


--------------------

PSALM 39

To the chief Musician, <i>even</i> to Jeduthun, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>I said, I will take heed to my ways, that I sin not with my tongue: I will keep my mouth with a bridle, while the wicked is before me.

<b>2 </b>I was dumb with silence, I held my peace, <i>even</i> from good; and my sorrow was stirred.

<b>3 </b>My heart was hot within me, while I was musing the fire burned: <i>then</i> spake I with my tongue,

<b>4 </b><span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, make me to know mine end, and the measure of my days, what it <i>is; that</i> I may know how frail I <i>am.</i>

<b>5 </b>Behold, thou hast made my days <i>as</i> an handbreadth; and mine age <i>is</i> as nothing before thee: verily every man at his best state <i>is</i> altogether vanity. Selah.

<b>6 </b>Surely every man walketh in a vain shew: surely they are disquieted in vain: he heapeth up <i>riches,</i> and knoweth not who shall gather them.

<b>7 </b>And now, Lord, what wait I for? my hope <i>is</i> in thee.

<b>8 </b>Deliver me from all my transgressions: make me not the reproach of the foolish.

<b>9 </b>I was dumb, I opened not my mouth; because thou didst <i>it.</i>

<b>10 </b>Remove thy stroke away from me: I am consumed by the blow of thine hand.

<b>11 </b>When thou with rebukes dost correct man for iniquity, thou makest his beauty to consume away like a moth: surely every man <i>is</i> vanity. Selah.

<b>12 </b>Hear my prayer, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and give ear unto my cry; hold not thy peace at my tears: for I <i>am</i> a stranger with thee, <i>and</i> a sojourner, as all my fathers <i>were.</i>

<b>13 </b>O spare me, that I may recover strength, before I go hence, and be no more.


--------------------

PSALM 40

To the chief Musician, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>I waited patiently for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and he inclined unto me, and heard my cry.

<b>2 </b>He brought me up also out of an horrible pit, out of the miry clay, and set my feet upon a rock, <i>and</i> established my goings.

<b>3 </b>And he hath put a new song in my mouth, <i>even</i> praise unto our God: many shall see <i>it,</i> and fear, and shall trust in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>4 </b>Blessed <i>is</i> that man that maketh the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his trust, and respecteth not the proud, nor such as turn aside to lies.

<b>5 </b>Many, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God, <i>are</i> thy wonderful works <i>which</i> thou hast done, and thy thoughts <i>which are</i> to us-ward: they cannot be reckoned up in order unto thee: <i>if</i> I would declare and speak <i>of them,</i> they are more than can be numbered.

<b>6 </b>Sacrifice and offering thou didst not desire; mine ears hast thou opened: burnt offering and sin offering hast thou not required.

<b>7 </b>Then said I, Lo, I come: in the volume of the book <i>it is</i> written of me,

<b>8 </b>I delight to do thy will, O my God: yea, thy law <i>is</i> within my heart.

<b>9 </b>I have preached righteousness in the great congregation: lo, I have not refrained my lips, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, thou knowest.

<b>10 </b>I have not hid thy righteousness within my heart; I have declared thy faithfulness and thy salvation: I have not concealed thy lovingkindness and thy truth from the great congregation.

<b>11 </b>Withhold not thou thy tender mercies from me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: let thy lovingkindness and thy truth continually preserve me.

<b>12 </b>For innumerable evils have compassed me about: mine iniquities have taken hold upon me, so that I am not able to look up; they are more than the hairs of mine head: therefore my heart faileth me.

<b>13 </b>Be pleased, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to deliver me: O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, make haste to help me.

<b>14 </b>Let them be ashamed and confounded together that seek after my soul to destroy it; let them be driven backward and put to shame that wish me evil.

<b>15 </b>Let them be desolate for a reward of their shame that say unto me, Aha, aha.

<b>16 </b>Let all those that seek thee rejoice and be glad in thee: let such as love thy salvation say continually, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> be magnified.

<b>17 </b>But I <i>am</i> poor and needy; <i>yet</i> the Lord thinketh upon me: thou <i>art</i> my help and my deliverer; make no tarrying, O my God.


--------------------

PSALM 41

To the chief Musician, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>Blessed <i>is</i> he that considereth the poor: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will deliver him in time of trouble.

<b>2 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will preserve him, and keep him alive; <i>and</i> he shall be blessed upon the earth: and thou wilt not deliver him unto the will of his enemies.

<b>3 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will strengthen him upon the bed of languishing: thou wilt make all his bed in his sickness.

<b>4 </b>I said, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, be merciful unto me: heal my soul; for I have sinned against thee.

<b>5 </b>Mine enemies speak evil of me, When shall he die, and his name perish?

<b>6 </b>And if he come to see <i>me,</i> he speaketh vanity: his heart gathereth iniquity to itself; <i>when</i> he goeth abroad, he telleth <i>it.</i>

<b>7 </b>All that hate me whisper together against me: against me do they devise my hurt.

<b>8 </b>An evil disease, <i>say they,</i> cleaveth fast unto him: and <i>now</i> that he lieth he shall rise up no more.

<b>9 </b>Yea, mine own familiar friend, in whom I trusted, which did eat of my bread, hath lifted up <i>his</i> heel against me.

<b>10 </b>But thou, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, be merciful unto me, and raise me up, that I may requite them.

<b>11 </b>By this I know that thou favourest me, because mine enemy doth not triumph over me.

<b>12 </b>And as for me, thou upholdest me in mine integrity, and settest me before thy face for ever.

<b>13 </b>Blessed <i>be</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel from everlasting, and to everlasting. Amen, and Amen.


--------------------

PSALM 42

To the chief Musician, Maschil, for the sons of Korah.

<b>1 </b>As the hart panteth after the water brooks, so panteth my soul after thee, O God.

<b>2 </b>My soul thirsteth for God, for the living God: when shall I come and appear before God?

<b>3 </b>My tears have been my meat day and night, while they continually say unto me, Where <i>is</i> thy God?

<b>4 </b>When I remember these <i>things,</i> I pour out my soul in me: for I had gone with the multitude, I went with them to the house of God, with the voice of joy and praise, with a multitude that kept holyday.

<b>5 </b>Why art thou cast down, O my soul? and <i>why</i> art thou disquieted in me? hope thou in God: for I shall yet praise him <i>for</i> the help of his countenance.

<b>6 </b>O my God, my soul is cast down within me: therefore will I remember thee from the land of Jordan, and of the Hermonites, from the hill Mizar.

<b>7 </b>Deep calleth unto deep at the noise of thy waterspouts: all thy waves and thy billows are gone over me.

<b>8 </b><i>Yet</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will command his lovingkindness in the daytime, and in the night his song <i>shall be</i> with me, <i>and</i> my prayer unto the God of my life.

<b>9 </b>I will say unto God my rock, Why hast thou forgotten me? why go I mourning because of the oppression of the enemy?

<b>10 </b><i>As</i> with a sword in my bones, mine enemies reproach me; while they say daily unto me, Where <i>is</i> thy God?

<b>11 </b>Why art thou cast down, O my soul? and why art thou disquieted within me? hope thou in God: for I shall yet praise him, <i>who is</i> the health of my countenance, and my God.


--------------------

PSALM 43

<b>1 </b>Judge me, O God, and plead my cause against an ungodly nation: O deliver me from the deceitful and unjust man.

<b>2 </b>For thou <i>art</i> the God of my strength: why dost thou cast me off? why go I mourning because of the oppression of the enemy?

<b>3 </b>O send out thy light and thy truth: let them lead me; let them bring me unto thy holy hill, and to thy tabernacles.

<b>4 </b>Then will I go unto the altar of God, unto God my exceeding joy: yea, upon the harp will I praise thee, O God my God.

<b>5 </b>Why art thou cast down, O my soul? and why art thou disquieted within me? hope in God: for I shall yet praise him, <i>who is</i> the health of my countenance, and my God.


--------------------

PSALM 44

To the chief Musician for the sons of Korah, Maschil.

<b>1 </b>We have heard with our ears, O God, our fathers have told us, <i>what</i> work thou didst in their days, in the times of old.

<b>2 </b><i>How</i> thou didst drive out the heathen with thy hand, and plantedst them; <i>how</i> thou didst afflict the people, and cast them out.

<b>3 </b>For they got not the land in possession by their own sword, neither did their own arm save them: but thy right hand, and thine arm, and the light of thy countenance, because thou hadst a favour unto them.

<b>4 </b>Thou art my King, O God: command deliverances for Jacob.

<b>5 </b>Through thee will we push down our enemies: through thy name will we tread them under that rise up against us.

<b>6 </b>For I will not trust in my bow, neither shall my sword save me.

<b>7 </b>But thou hast saved us from our enemies, and hast put them to shame that hated us.

<b>8 </b>In God we boast all the day long, and praise thy name for ever. Selah.

<b>9 </b>But thou hast cast off, and put us to shame; and goest not forth with our armies.

<b>10 </b>Thou makest us to turn back from the enemy: and they which hate us spoil for themselves.

<b>11 </b>Thou hast given us like sheep <i>appointed</i> for meat; and hast scattered us among the heathen.

<b>12 </b>Thou sellest thy people for nought, and dost not increase <i>thy wealth</i> by their price.

<b>13 </b>Thou makest us a reproach to our neighbours, a scorn and a derision to them that are round about us.

<b>14 </b>Thou makest us a byword among the heathen, a shaking of the head among the people.

<b>15 </b>My confusion <i>is</i> continually before me, and the shame of my face hath covered me,

<b>16 </b>For the voice of him that reproacheth and blasphemeth; by reason of the enemy and avenger.

<b>17 </b>All this is come upon us; yet have we not forgotten thee, neither have we dealt falsely in thy covenant.

<b>18 </b>Our heart is not turned back, neither have our steps declined from thy way;

<b>19 </b>Though thou hast sore broken us in the place of dragons, and covered us with the shadow of death.

<b>20 </b>If we have forgotten the name of our God, or stretched out our hands to a strange god;

<b>21 </b>Shall not God search this out? for he knoweth the secrets of the heart.

<b>22 </b>Yea, for thy sake are we killed all the day long; we are counted as sheep for the slaughter.

<b>23 </b>Awake, why sleepest thou, O Lord? arise, cast <i>us</i> not off for ever.

<b>24 </b>Wherefore hidest thou thy face, <i>and</i> forgettest our affliction and our oppression?

<b>25 </b>For our soul is bowed down to the dust: our belly cleaveth unto the earth.

<b>26 </b>Arise for our help, and redeem us for thy mercies’ sake.


--------------------

PSALM 45

To the chief Musician upon Shoshannim, for the sons of Korah, Maschil, A Song of loves.

<b>1 </b>My heart is inditing a good matter: I speak of the things which I have made touching the king: my tongue <i>is</i> the pen of a ready writer.

<b>2 </b>Thou art fairer than the children of men: grace is poured into thy lips: therefore God hath blessed thee for ever.

<b>3 </b>Gird thy sword upon <i>thy</i> thigh, O <i>most</i> mighty, with thy glory and thy majesty.

<b>4 </b>And in thy majesty ride prosperously because of truth and meekness <i>and</i> righteousness; and thy right hand shall teach thee terrible things.

<b>5 </b>Thine arrows <i>are</i> sharp in the heart of the king’s enemies; <i>whereby</i> the people fall under thee.

<b>6 </b>Thy throne, O God, <i>is</i> for ever and ever: the sceptre of thy kingdom <i>is</i> a right sceptre.

<b>7 </b>Thou lovest righteousness, and hatest wickedness: therefore God, thy God, hath anointed thee with the oil of gladness above thy fellows.

<b>8 </b>All thy garments <i>smell</i> of myrrh, and aloes, <i>and</i> cassia, out of the ivory palaces, whereby they have made thee glad.

<b>9 </b>Kings’ daughters <i>were</i> among thy honourable women: upon thy right hand did stand the queen in gold of Ophir.

<b>10 </b>Hearken, O daughter, and consider, and incline thine ear; forget also thine own people, and thy father’s house;

<b>11 </b>So shall the king greatly desire thy beauty: for he <i>is</i> thy Lord; and worship thou him.

<b>12 </b>And the daughter of Tyre <i>shall be there</i> with a gift; <i>even</i> the rich among the people shall entreat thy favour.

<b>13 </b>The king’s daughter <i>is</i> all glorious within: her clothing <i>is</i> of wrought gold.

<b>14 </b>She shall be brought unto the king in raiment of needlework: the virgins her companions that follow her shall be brought unto thee.

<b>15 </b>With gladness and rejoicing shall they be brought: they shall enter into the king’s palace.

<b>16 </b>Instead of thy fathers shall be thy children, whom thou mayest make princes in all the earth.

<b>17 </b>I will make thy name to be remembered in all generations: therefore shall the people praise thee for ever and ever.


--------------------

PSALM 46

To the chief Musician for the sons of Korah, A Song upon Alamoth.

<b>1 </b>God <i>is</i> our refuge and strength, a very present help in trouble.

<b>2 </b>Therefore will not we fear, though the earth be removed, and though the mountains be carried into the midst of the sea;

<b>3 </b><i>Though</i> the waters thereof roar <i>and</i> be troubled, <i>though</i> the mountains shake with the swelling thereof. Selah.

<b>4 </b><i>There is</i> a river, the streams whereof shall make glad the city of God, the holy <i>place</i> of the tabernacles of the most High.

<b>5 </b>God <i>is</i> in the midst of her; she shall not be moved: God shall help her, <i>and that</i> right early.

<b>6 </b>The heathen raged, the kingdoms were moved: he uttered his voice, the earth melted.

<b>7 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts <i>is</i> with us; the God of Jacob <i>is</i> our refuge. Selah.

<b>8 </b>Come, behold the works of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, what desolations he hath made in the earth.

<b>9 </b>He maketh wars to cease unto the end of the earth; he breaketh the bow, and cutteth the spear in sunder; he burneth the chariot in the fire.

<b>10 </b>Be still, and know that I <i>am</i> God: I will be exalted among the heathen, I will be exalted in the earth.

<b>11 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts <i>is</i> with us; the God of Jacob <i>is</i> our refuge. Selah.


--------------------

PSALM 47

To the chief Musician, A Psalm for the sons of Korah.

<b>1 </b>O clap your hands, all ye people; shout unto God with the voice of triumph.

<b>2 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> most high <i>is</i> terrible; <i>he is</i> a great King over all the earth.

<b>3 </b>He shall subdue the people under us, and the nations under our feet.

<b>4 </b>He shall choose our inheritance for us, the excellency of Jacob whom he loved. Selah.

<b>5 </b>God is gone up with a shout, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with the sound of a trumpet.

<b>6 </b>Sing praises to God, sing praises: sing praises unto our King, sing praises.

<b>7 </b>For God <i>is</i> the King of all the earth: sing ye praises with understanding.

<b>8 </b>God reigneth over the heathen: God sitteth upon the throne of his holiness.

<b>9 </b>The princes of the people are gathered together, <i>even</i> the people of the God of Abraham: for the shields of the earth <i>belong</i> unto God: he is greatly exalted.


--------------------

PSALM 48

A Song <i>and</i> Psalm for the sons of Korah.

<b>1 </b>Great <i>is</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and greatly to be praised in the city of our God, <i>in</i> the mountain of his holiness.

<b>2 </b>Beautiful for situation, the joy of the whole earth, <i>is</i> mount Zion, <i>on</i> the sides of the north, the city of the great King.

<b>3 </b>God is known in her palaces for a refuge.

<b>4 </b>For, lo, the kings were assembled, they passed by together.

<b>5 </b>They saw <i>it, and</i> so they marvelled; they were troubled, <i>and</i> hasted away.

<b>6 </b>Fear took hold upon them there, <i>and</i> pain, as of a woman in travail.

<b>7 </b>Thou breakest the ships of Tarshish with an east wind.

<b>8 </b>As we have heard, so have we seen in the city of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, in the city of our God: God will establish it for ever. Selah.

<b>9 </b>We have thought of thy lovingkindness, O God, in the midst of thy temple.

<b>10 </b>According to thy name, O God, so <i>is</i> thy praise unto the ends of the earth: thy right hand is full of righteousness.

<b>11 </b>Let mount Zion rejoice, let the daughters of Judah be glad, because of thy judgments.

<b>12 </b>Walk about Zion, and go round about her: tell the towers thereof.

<b>13 </b>Mark ye well her bulwarks, consider her palaces; that ye may tell <i>it</i> to the generation following.

<b>14 </b>For this God <i>is</i> our God for ever and ever: he will be our guide <i>even</i> unto death.


--------------------

PSALM 49

To the chief Musician, A Psalm for the sons of Korah.

<b>1 </b>Hear this, all <i>ye</i> people; give ear, all <i>ye</i> inhabitants of the world:

<b>2 </b>Both low and high, rich and poor, together.

<b>3 </b>My mouth shall speak of wisdom; and the meditation of my heart <i>shall be</i> of understanding.

<b>4 </b>I will incline mine ear to a parable: I will open my dark saying upon the harp.

<b>5 </b>Wherefore should I fear in the days of evil, <i>when</i> the iniquity of my heels shall compass me about?

<b>6 </b>They that trust in their wealth, and boast themselves in the multitude of their riches;

<b>7 </b>None <i>of them</i> can by any means redeem his brother, nor give to God a ransom for him:

<b>8 </b>(For the redemption of their soul <i>is</i> precious, and it ceaseth for ever:)

<b>9 </b>That he should still live for ever, <i>and</i> not see corruption.

<b>10 </b>For he seeth <i>that</i> wise men die, likewise the fool and the brutish person perish, and leave their wealth to others.

<b>11 </b>Their inward thought <i>is, that</i> their houses <i>shall continue</i> for ever, <i>and</i> their dwelling places to all generations; they call <i>their</i> lands after their own names.

<b>12 </b>Nevertheless man <i>being</i> in honour abideth not: he is like the beasts <i>that</i> perish.

<b>13 </b>This their way <i>is</i> their folly: yet their posterity approve their sayings. Selah.

<b>14 </b>Like sheep they are laid in the grave; death shall feed on them; and the upright shall have dominion over them in the morning; and their beauty shall consume in the grave from their dwelling.

<b>15 </b>But God will redeem my soul from the power of the grave: for he shall receive me. Selah.

<b>16 </b>Be not thou afraid when one is made rich, when the glory of his house is increased;

<b>17 </b>For when he dieth he shall carry nothing away: his glory shall not descend after him.

<b>18 </b>Though while he lived he blessed his soul: and <i>men</i> will praise thee, when thou doest well to thyself.

<b>19 </b>He shall go to the generation of his fathers; they shall never see light.

<b>20 </b>Man <i>that is</i> in honour, and understandeth not, is like the beasts <i>that</i> perish.


--------------------

PSALM 50

A Psalm of Asaph.

<b>1 </b>The mighty God, <i>even</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, hath spoken, and called the earth from the rising of the sun unto the going down thereof.

<b>2 </b>Out of Zion, the perfection of beauty, God hath shined.

<b>3 </b>Our God shall come, and shall not keep silence: a fire shall devour before him, and it shall be very tempestuous round about him.

<b>4 </b>He shall call to the heavens from above, and to the earth, that he may judge his people.

<b>5 </b>Gather my saints together unto me; those that have made a covenant with me by sacrifice.

<b>6 </b>And the heavens shall declare his righteousness: for God <i>is</i> judge himself. Selah.

<b>7 </b>Hear, O my people, and I will speak; O Israel, and I will testify against thee: I <i>am</i> God, <i>even</i> thy God.

<b>8 </b>I will not reprove thee for thy sacrifices or thy burnt offerings, <i>to have been</i> continually before me.

<b>9 </b>I will take no bullock out of thy house, <i>nor</i> he goats out of thy folds.

<b>10 </b>For every beast of the forest <i>is</i> mine, <i>and</i> the cattle upon a thousand hills.

<b>11 </b>I know all the fowls of the mountains: and the wild beasts of the field <i>are</i> mine.

<b>12 </b>If I were hungry, I would not tell thee: for the world <i>is</i> mine, and the fulness thereof.

<b>13 </b>Will I eat the flesh of bulls, or drink the blood of goats?

<b>14 </b>Offer unto God thanksgiving; and pay thy vows unto the most High:

<b>15 </b>And call upon me in the day of trouble: I will deliver thee, and thou shalt glorify me.

<b>16 </b>But unto the wicked God saith, What hast thou to do to declare my statutes, or <i>that</i> thou shouldest take my covenant in thy mouth?

<b>17 </b>Seeing thou hatest instruction, and castest my words behind thee.

<b>18 </b>When thou sawest a thief, then thou consentedst with him, and hast been partaker with adulterers.

<b>19 </b>Thou givest thy mouth to evil, and thy tongue frameth deceit.

<b>20 </b>Thou sittest <i>and</i> speakest against thy brother; thou slanderest thine own mother’s son.

<b>21 </b>These <i>things</i> hast thou done, and I kept silence; thou thoughtest that I was altogether <i>such an one</i> as thyself: <i>but</i> I will reprove thee, and set <i>them</i> in order before thine eyes.

<b>22 </b>Now consider this, ye that forget God, lest I tear <i>you</i> in pieces, and <i>there be</i> none to deliver.

<b>23 </b>Whoso offereth praise glorifieth me: and to him that ordereth <i>his</i> conversation <i>aright</i> will I shew the salvation of God.


--------------------

PSALM 51

To the chief Musician, A Psalm of David, when Nathan the prophet came unto him, after he had gone in to Bath-sheba.

<b>1 </b>Have mercy upon me, O God, according to thy lovingkindness: according unto the multitude of thy tender mercies blot out my transgressions.

<b>2 </b>Wash me throughly from mine iniquity, and cleanse me from my sin.

<b>3 </b>For I acknowledge my transgressions: and my sin <i>is</i> ever before me.

<b>4 </b>Against thee, thee only, have I sinned, and done <i>this</i> evil in thy sight: that thou mightest be justified when thou speakest, <i>and</i> be clear when thou judgest.

<b>5 </b>Behold, I was shapen in iniquity; and in sin did my mother conceive me.

<b>6 </b>Behold, thou desirest truth in the inward parts: and in the hidden <i>part</i> thou shalt make me to know wisdom.

<b>7 </b>Purge me with hyssop, and I shall be clean: wash me, and I shall be whiter than snow.

<b>8 </b>Make me to hear joy and gladness; <i>that</i> the bones <i>which</i> thou hast broken may rejoice.

<b>9 </b>Hide thy face from my sins, and blot out all mine iniquities.

<b>10 </b>Create in me a clean heart, O God; and renew a right spirit within me.

<b>11 </b>Cast me not away from thy presence; and take not thy holy spirit from me.

<b>12 </b>Restore unto me the joy of thy salvation; and uphold me <i>with thy</i> free spirit.

<b>13 </b><i>Then</i> will I teach transgressors thy ways; and sinners shall be converted unto thee.

<b>14 </b>Deliver me from bloodguiltiness, O God, thou God of my salvation: <i>and</i> my tongue shall sing aloud of thy righteousness.

<b>15 </b>O Lord, open thou my lips; and my mouth shall shew forth thy praise.

<b>16 </b>For thou desirest not sacrifice; else would I give <i>it:</i> thou delightest not in burnt offering.

<b>17 </b>The sacrifices of God <i>are</i> a broken spirit: a broken and a contrite heart, O God, thou wilt not despise.

<b>18 </b>Do good in thy good pleasure unto Zion: build thou the walls of Jerusalem.

<b>19 </b>Then shalt thou be pleased with the sacrifices of righteousness, with burnt offering and whole burnt offering: then shall they offer bullocks upon thine altar.


--------------------

PSALM 52

To the chief Musician, Maschil, <i>A Psalm</i> of David, when Doeg the Edomite came and told Saul, and said unto him, David is come to the house of Ahimelech.

<b>1 </b>Why boastest thou thyself in mischief, O mighty man? the goodness of God <i>endureth</i> continually.

<b>2 </b>Thy tongue deviseth mischiefs; like a sharp razor, working deceitfully.

<b>3 </b>Thou lovest evil more than good; <i>and</i> lying rather than to speak righteousness. Selah.

<b>4 </b>Thou lovest all devouring words, O <i>thou</i> deceitful tongue.

<b>5 </b>God shall likewise destroy thee for ever, he shall take thee away, and pluck thee out of <i>thy</i> dwelling place, and root thee out of the land of the living. Selah.

<b>6 </b>The righteous also shall see, and fear, and shall laugh at him:

<b>7 </b>Lo, <i>this is</i> the man <i>that</i> made not God his strength; but trusted in the abundance of his riches, <i>and</i> strengthened himself in his wickedness.

<b>8 </b>But I <i>am</i> like a green olive tree in the house of God: I trust in the mercy of God for ever and ever.

<b>9 </b>I will praise thee for ever, because thou hast done <i>it:</i> and I will wait on thy name; for <i>it is</i> good before thy saints.


--------------------

PSALM 53

To the chief Musician upon Mahalath, Maschil, <i>A Psalm</i> of David.

<b>1 </b>The fool hath said in his heart, <i>There is</i> no God. Corrupt are they, and have done abominable iniquity: <i>there is</i> none that doeth good.

<b>2 </b>God looked down from heaven upon the children of men, to see if there were <i>any</i> that did understand, that did seek God.

<b>3 </b>Every one of them is gone back: they are altogether become filthy; <i>there is</i> none that doeth good, no, not one.

<b>4 </b>Have the workers of iniquity no knowledge? who eat up my people <i>as</i> they eat bread: they have not called upon God.

<b>5 </b>There were they in great fear, <i>where</i> no fear was: for God hath scattered the bones of him that encampeth <i>against</i> thee: thou hast put <i>them</i> to shame, because God hath despised them.

<b>6 </b>Oh that the salvation of Israel <i>were come</i> out of Zion! When God bringeth back the captivity of his people, Jacob shall rejoice, <i>and</i> Israel shall be glad.


--------------------

PSALM 54

To the chief Musician on Neginoth, Maschil, <i>A Psalm</i> of David, when the Ziphims came and said to Saul, Doth not David hide himself with us?

<b>1 </b>Save me, O God, by thy name, and judge me by thy strength.

<b>2 </b>Hear my prayer, O God; give ear to the words of my mouth.

<b>3 </b>For strangers are risen up against me, and oppressors seek after my soul: they have not set God before them. Selah.

<b>4 </b>Behold, God <i>is</i> mine helper: the Lord <i>is</i> with them that uphold my soul.

<b>5 </b>He shall reward evil unto mine enemies: cut them off in thy truth.

<b>6 </b>I will freely sacrifice unto thee: I will praise thy name, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for <i>it is</i> good.

<b>7 </b>For he hath delivered me out of all trouble: and mine eye hath seen <i>his desire</i> upon mine enemies.


--------------------

PSALM 55

To the chief Musician on Neginoth, Maschil, <i>A Psalm</i> of David.

<b>1 </b>Give ear to my prayer, O God; and hide not thyself from my supplication.

<b>2 </b>Attend unto me, and hear me: I mourn in my complaint, and make a noise;

<b>3 </b>Because of the voice of the enemy, because of the oppression of the wicked: for they cast iniquity upon me, and in wrath they hate me.

<b>4 </b>My heart is sore pained within me: and the terrors of death are fallen upon me.

<b>5 </b>Fearfulness and trembling are come upon me, and horror hath overwhelmed me.

<b>6 </b>And I said, Oh that I had wings like a dove! <i>for then</i> would I fly away, and be at rest.

<b>7 </b>Lo, <i>then</i> would I wander far off, <i>and</i> remain in the wilderness. Selah.

<b>8 </b>I would hasten my escape from the windy storm <i>and</i> tempest.

<b>9 </b>Destroy, O Lord, <i>and</i> divide their tongues: for I have seen violence and strife in the city.

<b>10 </b>Day and night they go about it upon the walls thereof: mischief also and sorrow <i>are</i> in the midst of it.

<b>11 </b>Wickedness <i>is</i> in the midst thereof: deceit and guile depart not from her streets.

<b>12 </b>For <i>it was</i> not an enemy <i>that</i> reproached me; then I could have borne <i>it:</i> neither <i>was it</i> he that hated me <i>that</i> did magnify <i>himself</i> against me; then I would have hid myself from him:

<b>13 </b>But <i>it was</i> thou, a man mine equal, my guide, and mine acquaintance.

<b>14 </b>We took sweet counsel together, <i>and</i> walked unto the house of God in company.

<b>15 </b>Let death seize upon them, <i>and</i> let them go down quick into hell: for wickedness <i>is</i> in their dwellings, <i>and</i> among them.

<b>16 </b>As for me, I will call upon God; and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall save me.

<b>17 </b>Evening, and morning, and at noon, will I pray, and cry aloud: and he shall hear my voice.

<b>18 </b>He hath delivered my soul in peace from the battle <i>that was</i> against me: for there were many with me.

<b>19 </b>God shall hear, and afflict them, even he that abideth of old. Selah. Because they have no changes, therefore they fear not God.

<b>20 </b>He hath put forth his hands against such as be at peace with him: he hath broken his covenant.

<b>21 </b><i>The words</i> of his mouth were smoother than butter, but war <i>was</i> in his heart: his words were softer than oil, yet <i>were</i> they drawn swords.

<b>22 </b>Cast thy burden upon the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and he shall sustain thee: he shall never suffer the righteous to be moved.

<b>23 </b>But thou, O God, shalt bring them down into the pit of destruction: bloody and deceitful men shall not live out half their days; but I will trust in thee.


--------------------

PSALM 56

To the chief Musician upon Jonath-elem-rechokim, Michtam of David, when the Philistines took him in Gath.

<b>1 </b>Be merciful unto me, O God: for man would swallow me up; he fighting daily oppresseth me.

<b>2 </b>Mine enemies would daily swallow <i>me</i> up: for <i>they be</i> many that fight against me, O thou most High.

<b>3 </b>What time I am afraid, I will trust in thee.

<b>4 </b>In God I will praise his word, in God I have put my trust; I will not fear what flesh can do unto me.

<b>5 </b>Every day they wrest my words: all their thoughts <i>are</i> against me for evil.

<b>6 </b>They gather themselves together, they hide themselves, they mark my steps, when they wait for my soul.

<b>7 </b>Shall they escape by iniquity? in <i>thine</i> anger cast down the people, O God.

<b>8 </b>Thou tellest my wanderings: put thou my tears into thy bottle: <i>are they</i> not in thy book?

<b>9 </b>When I cry <i>unto thee,</i> then shall mine enemies turn back: this I know; for God <i>is</i> for me.

<b>10 </b>In God will I praise <i>his</i> word: in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will I praise <i>his</i> word.

<b>11 </b>In God have I put my trust: I will not be afraid what man can do unto me.

<b>12 </b>Thy vows <i>are</i> upon me, O God: I will render praises unto thee.

<b>13 </b>For thou hast delivered my soul from death: <i>wilt</i> not <i>thou deliver</i> my feet from falling, that I may walk before God in the light of the living?


--------------------

PSALM 57

To the chief Musician, Al-taschith, Michtam of David, when he fled from Saul in the cave.

<b>1 </b>Be merciful unto me, O God, be merciful unto me: for my soul trusteth in thee: yea, in the shadow of thy wings will I make my refuge, until <i>these</i> calamities be overpast.

<b>2 </b>I will cry unto God most high; unto God that performeth <i>all things</i> for me.

<b>3 </b>He shall send from heaven, and save me <i>from</i> the reproach of him that would swallow me up. Selah. God shall send forth his mercy and his truth.

<b>4 </b>My soul <i>is</i> among lions: <i>and</i> I lie <i>even among</i> them that are set on fire, <i>even</i> the sons of men, whose teeth <i>are</i> spears and arrows, and their tongue a sharp sword.

<b>5 </b>Be thou exalted, O God, above the heavens; <i>let</i> thy glory <i>be</i> above all the earth.

<b>6 </b>They have prepared a net for my steps; my soul is bowed down: they have digged a pit before me, into the midst whereof they are fallen <i>themselves.</i> Selah.

<b>7 </b>My heart is fixed, O God, my heart is fixed: I will sing and give praise.

<b>8 </b>Awake up, my glory; awake, psaltery and harp: I <i>myself</i> will awake early.

<b>9 </b>I will praise thee, O Lord, among the people: I will sing unto thee among the nations.

<b>10 </b>For thy mercy <i>is</i> great unto the heavens, and thy truth unto the clouds.

<b>11 </b>Be thou exalted, O God, above the heavens: <i>let</i> thy glory <i>be</i> above all the earth.


--------------------

PSALM 58

To the chief Musician, Al-taschith, Michtam of David.

<b>1 </b>Do ye indeed speak righteousness, O congregation? do ye judge uprightly, O ye sons of men?

<b>2 </b>Yea, in heart ye work wickedness; ye weigh the violence of your hands in the earth.

<b>3 </b>The wicked are estranged from the womb: they go astray as soon as they be born, speaking lies.

<b>4 </b>Their poison <i>is</i> like the poison of a serpent: <i>they are</i> like the deaf adder <i>that</i> stoppeth her ear;

<b>5 </b>Which will not hearken to the voice of charmers, charming never so wisely.

<b>6 </b>Break their teeth, O God, in their mouth: break out the great teeth of the young lions, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>7 </b>Let them melt away as waters <i>which</i> run continually: <i>when</i> he bendeth <i>his bow to shoot</i> his arrows, let them be as cut in pieces.

<b>8 </b>As a snail <i>which</i> melteth, let <i>every one of them</i> pass away: <i>like</i> the untimely birth of a woman, <i>that</i> they may not see the sun.

<b>9 </b>Before your pots can feel the thorns, he shall take them away as with a whirlwind, both living, and in <i>his</i> wrath.

<b>10 </b>The righteous shall rejoice when he seeth the vengeance: he shall wash his feet in the blood of the wicked.

<b>11 </b>So that a man shall say, Verily <i>there is</i> a reward for the righteous: verily he is a God that judgeth in the earth.


--------------------

PSALM 59

To the chief Musician, Al-taschith, Michtam of David; when Saul sent, and they watched the house to kill him.

<b>1 </b>Deliver me from mine enemies, O my God: defend me from them that rise up against me.

<b>2 </b>Deliver me from the workers of iniquity, and save me from bloody men.

<b>3 </b>For, lo, they lie in wait for my soul: the mighty are gathered against me; not <i>for</i> my transgression, nor <i>for</i> my sin, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>4 </b>They run and prepare themselves without <i>my</i> fault: awake to help me, and behold.

<b>5 </b>Thou therefore, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of hosts, the God of Israel, awake to visit all the heathen: be not merciful to any wicked transgressors. Selah.

<b>6 </b>They return at evening: they make a noise like a dog, and go round about the city.

<b>7 </b>Behold, they belch out with their mouth: swords <i>are</i> in their lips: for who, <i>say they,</i> doth hear?

<b>8 </b>But thou, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, shalt laugh at them; thou shalt have all the heathen in derision.

<b>9 </b><i>Because of</i> his strength will I wait upon thee: for God <i>is</i> my defence.

<b>10 </b>The God of my mercy shall prevent me: God shall let me see <i>my desire</i> upon mine enemies.

<b>11 </b>Slay them not, lest my people forget: scatter them by thy power; and bring them down, O Lord our shield.

<b>12 </b><i>For</i> the sin of their mouth <i>and</i> the words of their lips let them even be taken in their pride: and for cursing and lying <i>which</i> they speak.

<b>13 </b>Consume <i>them</i> in wrath, consume <i>them,</i> that they <i>may</i> not <i>be:</i> and let them know that God ruleth in Jacob unto the ends of the earth. Selah.

<b>14 </b>And at evening let them return; <i>and</i> let them make a noise like a dog, and go round about the city.

<b>15 </b>Let them wander up and down for meat, and grudge if they be not satisfied.

<b>16 </b>But I will sing of thy power; yea, I will sing aloud of thy mercy in the morning: for thou hast been my defence and refuge in the day of my trouble.

<b>17 </b>Unto thee, O my strength, will I sing: for God <i>is</i> my defence, <i>and</i> the God of my mercy.


--------------------

PSALM 60

To the chief Musician upon Shushaneduth, Michtam of David, to teach; when he strove with Aram-naharaim and with Aram-zobah, when Joab returned, and smote of Edom in the valley of salt twelve thousand.

<b>1 </b>O God, thou hast cast us off, thou hast scattered us, thou hast been displeased; O turn thyself to us again.

<b>2 </b>Thou hast made the earth to tremble; thou hast broken it: heal the breaches thereof; for it shaketh.

<b>3 </b>Thou hast shewed thy people hard things: thou hast made us to drink the wine of astonishment.

<b>4 </b>Thou hast given a banner to them that fear thee, that it may be displayed because of the truth. Selah.

<b>5 </b>That thy beloved may be delivered; save <i>with</i> thy right hand, and hear me.

<b>6 </b>God hath spoken in his holiness; I will rejoice, I will divide Shechem, and mete out the valley of Succoth.

<b>7 </b>Gilead <i>is</i> mine, and Manasseh <i>is</i> mine; Ephraim also <i>is</i> the strength of mine head; Judah <i>is</i> my lawgiver;

<b>8 </b>Moab <i>is</i> my washpot; over Edom will I cast out my shoe: Philistia, triumph thou because of me.

<b>9 </b>Who will bring me <i>into</i> the strong city? who will lead me into Edom?

<b>10 </b><i>Wilt</i> not thou, O God, <i>which</i> hadst cast us off? and <i>thou,</i> O God, <i>which</i> didst not go out with our armies?

<b>11 </b>Give us help from trouble: for vain <i>is</i> the help of man.

<b>12 </b>Through God we shall do valiantly: for he <i>it is that</i> shall tread down our enemies.


--------------------

PSALM 61

To the chief Musician upon Neginah, <i>A Psalm</i> of David.

<b>1 </b>Hear my cry, O God; attend unto my prayer.

<b>2 </b>From the end of the earth will I cry unto thee, when my heart is overwhelmed: lead me to the rock <i>that</i> is higher than I.

<b>3 </b>For thou hast been a shelter for me, <i>and</i> a strong tower from the enemy.

<b>4 </b>I will abide in thy tabernacle for ever: I will trust in the covert of thy wings. Selah.

<b>5 </b>For thou, O God, hast heard my vows: thou hast given <i>me</i> the heritage of those that fear thy name.

<b>6 </b>Thou wilt prolong the king’s life: <i>and</i> his years as many generations.

<b>7 </b>He shall abide before God for ever: O prepare mercy and truth, <i>which</i> may preserve him.

<b>8 </b>So will I sing praise unto thy name for ever, that I may daily perform my vows.


--------------------

PSALM 62

To the chief Musician, to Jeduthun, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>Truly my soul waiteth upon God: from him <i>cometh</i> my salvation.

<b>2 </b>He only <i>is</i> my rock and my salvation; <i>he is</i> my defence; I shall not be greatly moved.

<b>3 </b>How long will ye imagine mischief against a man? ye shall be slain all of you: as a bowing wall <i>shall ye be, and as</i> a tottering fence.

<b>4 </b>They only consult to cast <i>him</i> down from his excellency: they delight in lies: they bless with their mouth, but they curse inwardly. Selah.

<b>5 </b>My soul, wait thou only upon God; for my expectation <i>is</i> from him.

<b>6 </b>He only <i>is</i> my rock and my salvation: <i>he is</i> my defence; I shall not be moved.

<b>7 </b>In God <i>is</i> my salvation and my glory: the rock of my strength, <i>and</i> my refuge, <i>is</i> in God.

<b>8 </b>Trust in him at all times; ye people, pour out your heart before him: God <i>is</i> a refuge for us. Selah.

<b>9 </b>Surely men of low degree <i>are</i> vanity, <i>and</i> men of high degree <i>are</i> a lie: to be laid in the balance, they <i>are</i> altogether <i>lighter</i> than vanity.

<b>10 </b>Trust not in oppression, and become not vain in robbery: if riches increase, set not your heart <i>upon them.</i>

<b>11 </b>God hath spoken once; twice have I heard this; that power <i>belongeth</i> unto God.

<b>12 </b>Also unto thee, O Lord, <i>belongeth</i> mercy: for thou renderest to every man according to his work.


--------------------

PSALM 63

A Psalm of David, when he was in the wilderness of Judah.

<b>1 </b>O God, thou <i>art</i> my God; early will I seek thee: my soul thirsteth for thee, my flesh longeth for thee in a dry and thirsty land, where no water is;

<b>2 </b>To see thy power and thy glory, so <i>as</i> I have seen thee in the sanctuary.

<b>3 </b>Because thy lovingkindness <i>is</i> better than life, my lips shall praise thee.

<b>4 </b>Thus will I bless thee while I live: I will lift up my hands in thy name.

<b>5 </b>My soul shall be satisfied as <i>with</i> marrow and fatness; and my mouth shall praise <i>thee</i> with joyful lips:

<b>6 </b>When I remember thee upon my bed, <i>and</i> meditate on thee in the <i>night</i> watches.

<b>7 </b>Because thou hast been my help, therefore in the shadow of thy wings will I rejoice.

<b>8 </b>My soul followeth hard after thee: thy right hand upholdeth me.

<b>9 </b>But those <i>that</i> seek my soul, to destroy <i>it,</i> shall go into the lower parts of the earth.

<b>10 </b>They shall fall by the sword: they shall be a portion for foxes.

<b>11 </b>But the king shall rejoice in God; every one that sweareth by him shall glory: but the mouth of them that speak lies shall be stopped.


--------------------

PSALM 64

To the chief Musician, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>Hear my voice, O God, in my prayer: preserve my life from fear of the enemy.

<b>2 </b>Hide me from the secret counsel of the wicked; from the insurrection of the workers of iniquity:

<b>3 </b>Who whet their tongue like a sword, <i>and</i> bend <i>their bows to shoot</i> their arrows, <i>even</i> bitter words:

<b>4 </b>That they may shoot in secret at the perfect: suddenly do they shoot at him, and fear not.

<b>5 </b>They encourage themselves <i>in</i> an evil matter: they commune of laying snares privily; they say, Who shall see them?

<b>6 </b>They search out iniquities; they accomplish a diligent search: both the inward <i>thought</i> of every one <i>of them,</i> and the heart, <i>is</i> deep.

<b>7 </b>But God shall shoot at them <i>with</i> an arrow; suddenly shall they be wounded.

<b>8 </b>So they shall make their own tongue to fall upon themselves: all that see them shall flee away.

<b>9 </b>And all men shall fear, and shall declare the work of God; for they shall wisely consider of his doing.

<b>10 </b>The righteous shall be glad in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and shall trust in him; and all the upright in heart shall glory.


--------------------

PSALM 65

To the chief Musician, A Psalm <i>and</i> Song of David.

<b>1 </b>Praise waiteth for thee, O God, in Sion: and unto thee shall the vow be performed.

<b>2 </b>O thou that hearest prayer, unto thee shall all flesh come.

<b>3 </b>Iniquities prevail against me: <i>as for</i> our transgressions, thou shalt purge them away.

<b>4 </b>Blessed <i>is the man whom</i> thou choosest, and causest to approach <i>unto thee, that</i> he may dwell in thy courts: we shall be satisfied with the goodness of thy house, <i>even</i> of thy holy temple.

<b>5 </b><i>By</i> terrible things in righteousness wilt thou answer us, O God of our salvation; <i>who art</i> the confidence of all the ends of the earth, and of them that are afar off <i>upon</i> the sea:

<b>6 </b>Which by his strength setteth fast the mountains; <i>being</i> girded with power:

<b>7 </b>Which stilleth the noise of the seas, the noise of their waves, and the tumult of the people.

<b>8 </b>They also that dwell in the uttermost parts are afraid at thy tokens: thou makest the outgoings of the morning and evening to rejoice.

<b>9 </b>Thou visitest the earth, and waterest it: thou greatly enrichest it with the river of God, <i>which</i> is full of water: thou preparest them corn, when thou hast so provided for it.

<b>10 </b>Thou waterest the ridges thereof abundantly: thou settlest the furrows thereof: thou makest it soft with showers: thou blessest the springing thereof.

<b>11 </b>Thou crownest the year with thy goodness; and thy paths drop fatness.

<b>12 </b>They drop <i>upon</i> the pastures of the wilderness: and the little hills rejoice on every side.

<b>13 </b>The pastures are clothed with flocks; the valleys also are covered over with corn; they shout for joy, they also sing.


--------------------

PSALM 66

To the chief Musician, A Song <i>or</i> Psalm.

<b>1 </b>Make a joyful noise unto God, all ye lands:

<b>2 </b>Sing forth the honour of his name: make his praise glorious.

<b>3 </b>Say unto God, How terrible <i>art thou in</i> thy works! through the greatness of thy power shall thine enemies submit themselves unto thee.

<b>4 </b>All the earth shall worship thee, and shall sing unto thee; they shall sing <i>to</i> thy name. Selah.

<b>5 </b>Come and see the works of God: <i>he is</i> terrible <i>in his</i> doing toward the children of men.

<b>6 </b>He turned the sea into dry <i>land:</i> they went through the flood on foot: there did we rejoice in him.

<b>7 </b>He ruleth by his power for ever; his eyes behold the nations: let not the rebellious exalt themselves. Selah.

<b>8 </b>O bless our God, ye people, and make the voice of his praise to be heard:

<b>9 </b>Which holdeth our soul in life, and suffereth not our feet to be moved.

<b>10 </b>For thou, O God, hast proved us: thou hast tried us, as silver is tried.

<b>11 </b>Thou broughtest us into the net; thou laidst affliction upon our loins.

<b>12 </b>Thou hast caused men to ride over our heads; we went through fire and through water: but thou broughtest us out into a wealthy <i>place.</i>

<b>13 </b>I will go into thy house with burnt offerings: I will pay thee my vows,

<b>14 </b>Which my lips have uttered, and my mouth hath spoken, when I was in trouble.

<b>15 </b>I will offer unto thee burnt sacrifices of fatlings, with the incense of rams; I will offer bullocks with goats. Selah.

<b>16 </b>Come <i>and</i> hear, all ye that fear God, and I will declare what he hath done for my soul.

<b>17 </b>I cried unto him with my mouth, and he was extolled with my tongue.

<b>18 </b>If I regard iniquity in my heart, the Lord will not hear <i>me:</i>

<b>19 </b><i>But</i> verily God hath heard <i>me;</i> he hath attended to the voice of my prayer.

<b>20 </b>Blessed <i>be</i> God, which hath not turned away my prayer, nor his mercy from me.


--------------------

PSALM 67

To the chief Musician on Neginoth, A Psalm <i>or</i> Song.

<b>1 </b>God be merciful unto us, and bless us; <i>and</i> cause his face to shine upon us; Selah.

<b>2 </b>That thy way may be known upon earth, thy saving health among all nations.

<b>3 </b>Let the people praise thee, O God; let all the people praise thee.

<b>4 </b>O let the nations be glad and sing for joy: for thou shalt judge the people righteously, and govern the nations upon earth. Selah.

<b>5 </b>Let the people praise thee, O God; let all the people praise thee.

<b>6 </b><i>Then</i> shall the earth yield her increase; <i>and</i> God, <i>even</i> our own God, shall bless us.

<b>7 </b>God shall bless us; and all the ends of the earth shall fear him.


--------------------

PSALM 68

To the chief Musician, A Psalm <i>or</i> Song of David.

<b>1 </b>Let God arise, let his enemies be scattered: let them also that hate him flee before him.

<b>2 </b>As smoke is driven away, <i>so</i> drive <i>them</i> away: as wax melteth before the fire, <i>so</i> let the wicked perish at the presence of God.

<b>3 </b>But let the righteous be glad; let them rejoice before God: yea, let them exceedingly rejoice.

<b>4 </b>Sing unto God, sing praises to his name: extol him that rideth upon the heavens by his name <span class="uppercase">Jah</span>, and rejoice before him.

<b>5 </b>A father of the fatherless, and a judge of the widows, <i>is</i> God in his holy habitation.

<b>6 </b>God setteth the solitary in families: he bringeth out those which are bound with chains: but the rebellious dwell in a dry <i>land.</i>

<b>7 </b>O God, when thou wentest forth before thy people, when thou didst march through the wilderness; Selah:

<b>8 </b>The earth shook, the heavens also dropped at the presence of God: <i>even</i> Sinai itself <i>was moved</i> at the presence of God, the God of Israel.

<b>9 </b>Thou, O God, didst send a plentiful rain, whereby thou didst confirm thine inheritance, when it was weary.

<b>10 </b>Thy congregation hath dwelt therein: thou, O God, hast prepared of thy goodness for the poor.

<b>11 </b>The Lord gave the word: great <i>was</i> the company of those that published <i>it.</i>
