<b>12 </b>Kings of armies did flee apace: and she that tarried at home divided the spoil.

<b>13 </b>Though ye have lien among the pots, <i>yet shall ye be as</i> the wings of a dove covered with silver, and her feathers with yellow gold.

<b>14 </b>When the Almighty scattered kings in it, it was <i>white</i> as snow in Salmon.

<b>15 </b>The hill of God <i>is as</i> the hill of Bashan; an high hill <i>as</i> the hill of Bashan.

<b>16 </b>Why leap ye, ye high hills? <i>this is</i> the hill <i>which</i> God desireth to dwell in; yea, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will dwell <i>in it</i> for ever.

<b>17 </b>The chariots of God <i>are</i> twenty thousand, <i>even</i> thousands of angels: the Lord <i>is</i> among them, <i>as in</i> Sinai, in the holy <i>place.</i>

<b>18 </b>Thou hast ascended on high, thou hast led captivity captive: thou hast received gifts for men; yea, <i>for</i> the rebellious also, that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God might dwell <i>among them.</i>

<b>19 </b>Blessed <i>be</i> the Lord, <i>who</i> daily loadeth us <i>with benefits, even</i> the God of our salvation. Selah.

<b>20 </b><i>He that is</i> our God <i>is</i> the God of salvation; and unto <span class="small-caps">God</span> the Lord <i>belong</i> the issues from death.

<b>21 </b>But God shall wound the head of his enemies, <i>and</i> the hairy scalp of such an one as goeth on still in his trespasses.

<b>22 </b>The Lord said, I will bring again from Bashan, I will bring <i>my people</i> again from the depths of the sea:

<b>23 </b>That thy foot may be dipped in the blood of <i>thine</i> enemies, <i>and</i> the tongue of thy dogs in the same.

<b>24 </b>They have seen thy goings, O God; <i>even</i> the goings of my God, my King, in the sanctuary.

<b>25 </b>The singers went before, the players on instruments <i>followed</i> after; among <i>them were</i> the damsels playing with timbrels.

<b>26 </b>Bless ye God in the congregations, <i>even</i> the Lord, from the fountain of Israel.

<b>27 </b>There <i>is</i> little Benjamin <i>with</i> their ruler, the princes of Judah <i>and</i> their council, the princes of Zebulun, <i>and</i> the princes of Naphtali.

<b>28 </b>Thy God hath commanded thy strength: strengthen, O God, that which thou hast wrought for us.

<b>29 </b>Because of thy temple at Jerusalem shall kings bring presents unto thee.

<b>30 </b>Rebuke the company of spearmen, the multitude of the bulls, with the calves of the people, <i>till every one</i> submit himself with pieces of silver: scatter thou the people <i>that</i> delight in war.

<b>31 </b>Princes shall come out of Egypt; Ethiopia shall soon stretch out her hands unto God.

<b>32 </b>Sing unto God, ye kingdoms of the earth; O sing praises unto the Lord; Selah:

<b>33 </b>To him that rideth upon the heavens of heavens, <i>which were</i> of old; lo, he doth send out his voice, <i>and that</i> a mighty voice.

<b>34 </b>Ascribe ye strength unto God: his excellency <i>is</i> over Israel, and his strength <i>is</i> in the clouds.

<b>35 </b>O God, <i>thou art</i> terrible out of thy holy places: the God of Israel <i>is</i> he that giveth strength and power unto <i>his</i> people. Blessed <i>be</i> God.


--------------------

PSALM 69

To the chief Musician upon Shoshannim, <i>A Psalm</i> of David.

<b>1 </b>Save me, O God; for the waters are come in unto <i>my</i> soul.

<b>2 </b>I sink in deep mire, where <i>there is</i> no standing: I am come into deep waters, where the floods overflow me.

<b>3 </b>I am weary of my crying: my throat is dried: mine eyes fail while I wait for my God.

<b>4 </b>They that hate me without a cause are more than the hairs of mine head: they that would destroy me, <i>being</i> mine enemies wrongfully, are mighty: then I restored <i>that</i> which I took not away.

<b>5 </b>O God, thou knowest my foolishness; and my sins are not hid from thee.

<b>6 </b>Let not them that wait on thee, O Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> of hosts, be ashamed for my sake: let not those that seek thee be confounded for my sake, O God of Israel.

<b>7 </b>Because for thy sake I have borne reproach; shame hath covered my face.

<b>8 </b>I am become a stranger unto my brethren, and an alien unto my mother’s children.

<b>9 </b>For the zeal of thine house hath eaten me up; and the reproaches of them that reproached thee are fallen upon me.

<b>10 </b>When I wept, <i>and chastened</i> my soul with fasting, that was to my reproach.

<b>11 </b>I made sackcloth also my garment; and I became a proverb to them.

<b>12 </b>They that sit in the gate speak against me; and I <i>was</i> the song of the drunkards.

<b>13 </b>But as for me, my prayer <i>is</i> unto thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>in</i> an acceptable time: O God, in the multitude of thy mercy hear me, in the truth of thy salvation.

<b>14 </b>Deliver me out of the mire, and let me not sink: let me be delivered from them that hate me, and out of the deep waters.

<b>15 </b>Let not the waterflood overflow me, neither let the deep swallow me up, and let not the pit shut her mouth upon me.

<b>16 </b>Hear me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for thy lovingkindness <i>is</i> good: turn unto me according to the multitude of thy tender mercies.

<b>17 </b>And hide not thy face from thy servant; for I am in trouble: hear me speedily.

<b>18 </b>Draw nigh unto my soul, <i>and</i> redeem it: deliver me because of mine enemies.

<b>19 </b>Thou hast known my reproach, and my shame, and my dishonour: mine adversaries <i>are</i> all before thee.

<b>20 </b>Reproach hath broken my heart; and I am full of heaviness: and I looked <i>for some</i> to take pity, but <i>there was</i> none; and for comforters, but I found none.

<b>21 </b>They gave me also gall for my meat; and in my thirst they gave me vinegar to drink.

<b>22 </b>Let their table become a snare before them: and <i>that which should have been</i> for <i>their</i> welfare, <i>let it become</i> a trap.

<b>23 </b>Let their eyes be darkened, that they see not; and make their loins continually to shake.

<b>24 </b>Pour out thine indignation upon them, and let thy wrathful anger take hold of them.

<b>25 </b>Let their habitation be desolate; <i>and</i> let none dwell in their tents.

<b>26 </b>For they persecute <i>him</i> whom thou hast smitten; and they talk to the grief of those whom thou hast wounded.

<b>27 </b>Add iniquity unto their iniquity: and let them not come into thy righteousness.

<b>28 </b>Let them be blotted out of the book of the living, and not be written with the righteous.

<b>29 </b>But I <i>am</i> poor and sorrowful: let thy salvation, O God, set me up on high.

<b>30 </b>I will praise the name of God with a song, and will magnify him with thanksgiving.

<b>31 </b><i>This</i> also shall please the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> better than an ox <i>or</i> bullock that hath horns and hoofs.

<b>32 </b>The humble shall see <i>this, and</i> be glad: and your heart shall live that seek God.

<b>33 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> heareth the poor, and despiseth not his prisoners.

<b>34 </b>Let the heaven and earth praise him, the seas, and every thing that moveth therein.

<b>35 </b>For God will save Zion, and will build the cities of Judah: that they may dwell there, and have it in possession.

<b>36 </b>The seed also of his servants shall inherit it: and they that love his name shall dwell therein.


--------------------

PSALM 70

To the chief Musician, <i>A Psalm</i> of David, to bring to remembrance.

<b>1 </b><i>Make haste,</i> O God, to deliver me; make haste to help me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>2 </b>Let them be ashamed and confounded that seek after my soul: let them be turned backward, and put to confusion, that desire my hurt.

<b>3 </b>Let them be turned back for a reward of their shame that say, Aha, aha.

<b>4 </b>Let all those that seek thee rejoice and be glad in thee: and let such as love thy salvation say continually, Let God be magnified.

<b>5 </b>But I <i>am</i> poor and needy: make haste unto me, O God: thou <i>art</i> my help and my deliverer; O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, make no tarrying.


--------------------

PSALM 71

<b>1 </b>In thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, do I put my trust: let me never be put to confusion.

<b>2 </b>Deliver me in thy righteousness, and cause me to escape: incline thine ear unto me, and save me.

<b>3 </b>Be thou my strong habitation, whereunto I may continually resort: thou hast given commandment to save me; for thou <i>art</i> my rock and my fortress.

<b>4 </b>Deliver me, O my God, out of the hand of the wicked, out of the hand of the unrighteous and cruel man.

<b>5 </b>For thou <i>art</i> my hope, O Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>: <i>thou art</i> my trust from my youth.

<b>6 </b>By thee have I been holden up from the womb: thou art he that took me out of my mother’s bowels: my praise <i>shall be</i> continually of thee.

<b>7 </b>I am as a wonder unto many; but thou <i>art</i> my strong refuge.

<b>8 </b>Let my mouth be filled <i>with</i> thy praise <i>and with</i> thy honour all the day.

<b>9 </b>Cast me not off in the time of old age; forsake me not when my strength faileth.

<b>10 </b>For mine enemies speak against me; and they that lay wait for my soul take counsel together,

<b>11 </b>Saying, God hath forsaken him: persecute and take him; for <i>there is</i> none to deliver <i>him.</i>

<b>12 </b>O God, be not far from me: O my God, make haste for my help.

<b>13 </b>Let them be confounded <i>and</i> consumed that are adversaries to my soul; let them be covered <i>with</i> reproach and dishonour that seek my hurt.

<b>14 </b>But I will hope continually, and will yet praise thee more and more.

<b>15 </b>My mouth shall shew forth thy righteousness <i>and</i> thy salvation all the day; for I know not the numbers <i>thereof.</i>

<b>16 </b>I will go in the strength of the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>: I will make mention of thy righteousness, <i>even</i> of thine only.

<b>17 </b>O God, thou hast taught me from my youth: and hitherto have I declared thy wondrous works.

<b>18 </b>Now also when I am old and grayheaded, O God, forsake me not; until I have shewed thy strength unto <i>this</i> generation, <i>and</i> thy power to every one <i>that</i> is to come.

<b>19 </b>Thy righteousness also, O God, <i>is</i> very high, who hast done great things: O God, who <i>is</i> like unto thee!

<b>20 </b><i>Thou,</i> which hast shewed me great and sore troubles, shalt quicken me again, and shalt bring me up again from the depths of the earth.

<b>21 </b>Thou shalt increase my greatness, and comfort me on every side.

<b>22 </b>I will also praise thee with the psaltery, <i>even</i> thy truth, O my God: unto thee will I sing with the harp, O thou Holy One of Israel.

<b>23 </b>My lips shall greatly rejoice when I sing unto thee; and my soul, which thou hast redeemed.

<b>24 </b>My tongue also shall talk of thy righteousness all the day long: for they are confounded, for they are brought unto shame, that seek my hurt.


--------------------

PSALM 72

<i>A Psalm</i> for Solomon.

<b>1 </b>Give the king thy judgments, O God, and thy righteousness unto the king’s son.

<b>2 </b>He shall judge thy people with righteousness, and thy poor with judgment.

<b>3 </b>The mountains shall bring peace to the people, and the little hills, by righteousness.

<b>4 </b>He shall judge the poor of the people, he shall save the children of the needy, and shall break in pieces the oppressor.

<b>5 </b>They shall fear thee as long as the sun and moon endure, throughout all generations.

<b>6 </b>He shall come down like rain upon the mown grass: as showers <i>that</i> water the earth.

<b>7 </b>In his days shall the righteous flourish; and abundance of peace so long as the moon endureth.

<b>8 </b>He shall have dominion also from sea to sea, and from the river unto the ends of the earth.

<b>9 </b>They that dwell in the wilderness shall bow before him; and his enemies shall lick the dust.

<b>10 </b>The kings of Tarshish and of the isles shall bring presents: the kings of Sheba and Seba shall offer gifts.

<b>11 </b>Yea, all kings shall fall down before him: all nations shall serve him.

<b>12 </b>For he shall deliver the needy when he crieth; the poor also, and <i>him</i> that hath no helper.

<b>13 </b>He shall spare the poor and needy, and shall save the souls of the needy.

<b>14 </b>He shall redeem their soul from deceit and violence: and precious shall their blood be in his sight.

<b>15 </b>And he shall live, and to him shall be given of the gold of Sheba: prayer also shall be made for him continually; <i>and</i> daily shall he be praised.

<b>16 </b>There shall be an handful of corn in the earth upon the top of the mountains; the fruit thereof shall shake like Lebanon: and <i>they</i> of the city shall flourish like grass of the earth.

<b>17 </b>His name shall endure for ever: his name shall be continued as long as the sun: and <i>men</i> shall be blessed in him: all nations shall call him blessed.

<b>18 </b>Blessed <i>be</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God, the God of Israel, who only doeth wondrous things.

<b>19 </b>And blessed <i>be</i> his glorious name for ever: and let the whole earth be filled <i>with</i> his glory; Amen, and Amen.

<b>20 </b>The prayers of David the son of Jesse are ended.


--------------------

PSALM 73

A Psalm of Asaph.

<b>1 </b>Truly God <i>is</i> good to Israel, <i>even</i> to such as are of a clean heart.

<b>2 </b>But as for me, my feet were almost gone; my steps had well nigh slipped.

<b>3 </b>For I was envious at the foolish, <i>when</i> I saw the prosperity of the wicked.

<b>4 </b>For <i>there are</i> no bands in their death: but their strength <i>is</i> firm.

<b>5 </b>They <i>are</i> not in trouble <i>as other</i> men; neither are they plagued like <i>other</i> men.

<b>6 </b>Therefore pride compasseth them about as a chain; violence covereth them <i>as</i> a garment.

<b>7 </b>Their eyes stand out with fatness: they have more than heart could wish.

<b>8 </b>They are corrupt, and speak wickedly <i>concerning</i> oppression: they speak loftily.

<b>9 </b>They set their mouth against the heavens, and their tongue walketh through the earth.

<b>10 </b>Therefore his people return hither: and waters of a full <i>cup</i> are wrung out to them.

<b>11 </b>And they say, How doth God know? and is there knowledge in the most High?

<b>12 </b>Behold, these <i>are</i> the ungodly, who prosper in the world; they increase <i>in</i> riches.

<b>13 </b>Verily I have cleansed my heart <i>in</i> vain, and washed my hands in innocency.

<b>14 </b>For all the day long have I been plagued, and chastened every morning.

<b>15 </b>If I say, I will speak thus; behold, I should offend <i>against</i> the generation of thy children.

<b>16 </b>When I thought to know this, it <i>was</i> too painful for me;

<b>17 </b>Until I went into the sanctuary of God; <i>then</i> understood I their end.

<b>18 </b>Surely thou didst set them in slippery places: thou castedst them down into destruction.

<b>19 </b>How are they <i>brought</i> into desolation, as in a moment! they are utterly consumed with terrors.

<b>20 </b>As a dream when <i>one</i> awaketh; <i>so,</i> O Lord, when thou awakest, thou shalt despise their image.

<b>21 </b>Thus my heart was grieved, and I was pricked in my reins.

<b>22 </b>So foolish <i>was</i> I, and ignorant: I was <i>as</i> a beast before thee.

<b>23 </b>Nevertheless I <i>am</i> continually with thee: thou hast holden <i>me</i> by my right hand.

<b>24 </b>Thou shalt guide me with thy counsel, and afterward receive me <i>to</i> glory.

<b>25 </b>Whom have I in heaven <i>but thee?</i> and <i>there is</i> none upon earth <i>that</i> I desire beside thee.

<b>26 </b>My flesh and my heart faileth: <i>but</i> God <i>is</i> the strength of my heart, and my portion for ever.

<b>27 </b>For, lo, they that are far from thee shall perish: thou hast destroyed all them that go a whoring from thee.

<b>28 </b>But <i>it is</i> good for me to draw near to God: I have put my trust in the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>, that I may declare all thy works.


--------------------

PSALM 74

Maschil of Asaph.

<b>1 </b>O God, why hast thou cast <i>us</i> off for ever? <i>why</i> doth thine anger smoke against the sheep of thy pasture?

<b>2 </b>Remember thy congregation, <i>which</i> thou hast purchased of old; the rod of thine inheritance, <i>which</i> thou hast redeemed; this mount Zion, wherein thou hast dwelt.

<b>3 </b>Lift up thy feet unto the perpetual desolations; <i>even</i> all <i>that</i> the enemy hath done wickedly in the sanctuary.

<b>4 </b>Thine enemies roar in the midst of thy congregations; they set up their ensigns <i>for</i> signs.

<b>5 </b><i>A man</i> was famous according as he had lifted up axes upon the thick trees.

<b>6 </b>But now they break down the carved work thereof at once with axes and hammers.

<b>7 </b>They have cast fire into thy sanctuary, they have defiled <i>by casting down</i> the dwelling place of thy name to the ground.

<b>8 </b>They said in their hearts, Let us destroy them together: they have burned up all the synagogues of God in the land.

<b>9 </b>We see not our signs: <i>there is</i> no more any prophet: neither <i>is there</i> among us any that knoweth how long.

<b>10 </b>O God, how long shall the adversary reproach? shall the enemy blaspheme thy name for ever?

<b>11 </b>Why withdrawest thou thy hand, even thy right hand? pluck <i>it</i> out of thy bosom.

<b>12 </b>For God <i>is</i> my King of old, working salvation in the midst of the earth.

<b>13 </b>Thou didst divide the sea by thy strength: thou brakest the heads of the dragons in the waters.

<b>14 </b>Thou brakest the heads of leviathan in pieces, <i>and</i> gavest him <i>to be</i> meat to the people inhabiting the wilderness.

<b>15 </b>Thou didst cleave the fountain and the flood: thou driedst up mighty rivers.

<b>16 </b>The day <i>is</i> thine, the night also <i>is</i> thine: thou hast prepared the light and the sun.

<b>17 </b>Thou hast set all the borders of the earth: thou hast made summer and winter.

<b>18 </b>Remember this, <i>that</i> the enemy hath reproached, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and <i>that</i> the foolish people have blasphemed thy name.

<b>19 </b>O deliver not the soul of thy turtledove unto the multitude <i>of the wicked:</i> forget not the congregation of thy poor for ever.

<b>20 </b>Have respect unto the covenant: for the dark places of the earth are full of the habitations of cruelty.

<b>21 </b>O let not the oppressed return ashamed: let the poor and needy praise thy name.

<b>22 </b>Arise, O God, plead thine own cause: remember how the foolish man reproacheth thee daily.

<b>23 </b>Forget not the voice of thine enemies: the tumult of those that rise up against thee increaseth continually.


--------------------

PSALM 75

To the chief Musician, Al-taschith, A Psalm <i>or</i> Song of Asaph.

<b>1 </b>Unto thee, O God, do we give thanks, <i>unto thee</i> do we give thanks: for <i>that</i> thy name is near thy wondrous works declare.

<b>2 </b>When I shall receive the congregation I will judge uprightly.

<b>3 </b>The earth and all the inhabitants thereof are dissolved: I bear up the pillars of it. Selah.

<b>4 </b>I said unto the fools, Deal not foolishly: and to the wicked, Lift not up the horn:

<b>5 </b>Lift not up your horn on high: speak <i>not with</i> a stiff neck.

<b>6 </b>For promotion <i>cometh</i> neither from the east, nor from the west, nor from the south.

<b>7 </b>But God <i>is</i> the judge: he putteth down one, and setteth up another.

<b>8 </b>For in the hand of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>there is</i> a cup, and the wine is red; it is full of mixture; and he poureth out of the same: but the dregs thereof, all the wicked of the earth shall wring <i>them</i> out, <i>and</i> drink <i>them.</i>

<b>9 </b>But I will declare for ever; I will sing praises to the God of Jacob.

<b>10 </b>All the horns of the wicked also will I cut off; <i>but</i> the horns of the righteous shall be exalted.


--------------------

PSALM 76

To the chief Musician on Neginoth, A Psalm <i>or</i> Song of Asaph.

<b>1 </b>In Judah <i>is</i> God known: his name <i>is</i> great in Israel.

<b>2 </b>In Salem also is his tabernacle, and his dwelling place in Zion.

<b>3 </b>There brake he the arrows of the bow, the shield, and the sword, and the battle. Selah.

<b>4 </b>Thou <i>art</i> more glorious <i>and</i> excellent than the mountains of prey.

<b>5 </b>The stouthearted are spoiled, they have slept their sleep: and none of the men of might have found their hands.

<b>6 </b>At thy rebuke, O God of Jacob, both the chariot and horse are cast into a dead sleep.

<b>7 </b>Thou, <i>even</i> thou, <i>art</i> to be feared: and who may stand in thy sight when once thou art angry?

<b>8 </b>Thou didst cause judgment to be heard from heaven; the earth feared, and was still,

<b>9 </b>When God arose to judgment, to save all the meek of the earth. Selah.

<b>10 </b>Surely the wrath of man shall praise thee: the remainder of wrath shalt thou restrain.

<b>11 </b>Vow, and pay unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God: let all that be round about him bring presents unto him that ought to be feared.

<b>12 </b>He shall cut off the spirit of princes: <i>he is</i> terrible to the kings of the earth.


--------------------

PSALM 77

To the chief Musician, to Jeduthun, A Psalm of Asaph.

<b>1 </b>I cried unto God with my voice, <i>even</i> unto God with my voice; and he gave ear unto me.

<b>2 </b>In the day of my trouble I sought the Lord: my sore ran in the night, and ceased not: my soul refused to be comforted.

<b>3 </b>I remembered God, and was troubled: I complained, and my spirit was overwhelmed. Selah.

<b>4 </b>Thou holdest mine eyes waking: I am so troubled that I cannot speak.

<b>5 </b>I have considered the days of old, the years of ancient times.

<b>6 </b>I call to remembrance my song in the night: I commune with mine own heart: and my spirit made diligent search.

<b>7 </b>Will the Lord cast off for ever? and will he be favourable no more?

<b>8 </b>Is his mercy clean gone for ever? doth <i>his</i> promise fail for evermore?

<b>9 </b>Hath God forgotten to be gracious? hath he in anger shut up his tender mercies? Selah.

<b>10 </b>And I said, This <i>is</i> my infirmity: <i>but I will remember</i> the years of the right hand of the most High.

<b>11 </b>I will remember the works of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: surely I will remember thy wonders of old.

<b>12 </b>I will meditate also of all thy work, and talk of thy doings.

<b>13 </b>Thy way, O God, <i>is</i> in the sanctuary: who <i>is so</i> great a God as <i>our</i> God?

<b>14 </b>Thou <i>art</i> the God that doest wonders: thou hast declared thy strength among the people.

<b>15 </b>Thou hast with <i>thine</i> arm redeemed thy people, the sons of Jacob and Joseph. Selah.

<b>16 </b>The waters saw thee, O God, the waters saw thee; they were afraid: the depths also were troubled.

<b>17 </b>The clouds poured out water: the skies sent out a sound: thine arrows also went abroad.

<b>18 </b>The voice of thy thunder <i>was</i> in the heaven: the lightnings lightened the world: the earth trembled and shook.

<b>19 </b>Thy way <i>is</i> in the sea, and thy path in the great waters, and thy footsteps are not known.

<b>20 </b>Thou leddest thy people like a flock by the hand of Moses and Aaron.


--------------------

PSALM 78

Maschil of Asaph.

<b>1 </b>Give ear, O my people, <i>to</i> my law: incline your ears to the words of my mouth.

<b>2 </b>I will open my mouth in a parable: I will utter dark sayings of old:

<b>3 </b>Which we have heard and known, and our fathers have told us.

<b>4 </b>We will not hide <i>them</i> from their children, shewing to the generation to come the praises of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and his strength, and his wonderful works that he hath done.

<b>5 </b>For he established a testimony in Jacob, and appointed a law in Israel, which he commanded our fathers, that they should make them known to their children:

<b>6 </b>That the generation to come might know <i>them, even</i> the children <i>which</i> should be born; <i>who</i> should arise and declare <i>them</i> to their children:

<b>7 </b>That they might set their hope in God, and not forget the works of God, but keep his commandments:

<b>8 </b>And might not be as their fathers, a stubborn and rebellious generation; a generation <i>that</i> set not their heart aright, and whose spirit was not steadfast with God.

<b>9 </b>The children of Ephraim, <i>being</i> armed, <i>and</i> carrying bows, turned back in the day of battle.

<b>10 </b>They kept not the covenant of God, and refused to walk in his law;

<b>11 </b>And forgat his works, and his wonders that he had shewed them.

<b>12 </b>Marvellous things did he in the sight of their fathers, in the land of Egypt, <i>in</i> the field of Zoan.

<b>13 </b>He divided the sea, and caused them to pass through; and he made the waters to stand as an heap.

<b>14 </b>In the daytime also he led them with a cloud, and all the night with a light of fire.

<b>15 </b>He clave the rocks in the wilderness, and gave <i>them</i> drink as <i>out of</i> the great depths.

<b>16 </b>He brought streams also out of the rock, and caused waters to run down like rivers.

<b>17 </b>And they sinned yet more against him by provoking the most High in the wilderness.

<b>18 </b>And they tempted God in their heart by asking meat for their lust.

<b>19 </b>Yea, they spake against God; they said, Can God furnish a table in the wilderness?

<b>20 </b>Behold, he smote the rock, that the waters gushed out, and the streams overflowed; can he give bread also? can he provide flesh for his people?

<b>21 </b>Therefore the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> heard <i>this,</i> and was wroth: so a fire was kindled against Jacob, and anger also came up against Israel;

<b>22 </b>Because they believed not in God, and trusted not in his salvation:

<b>23 </b>Though he had commanded the clouds from above, and opened the doors of heaven,

<b>24 </b>And had rained down manna upon them to eat, and had given them of the corn of heaven.

<b>25 </b>Man did eat angels’ food: he sent them meat to the full.

<b>26 </b>He caused an east wind to blow in the heaven: and by his power he brought in the south wind.

<b>27 </b>He rained flesh also upon them as dust, and feathered fowls like as the sand of the sea:

<b>28 </b>And he let <i>it</i> fall in the midst of their camp, round about their habitations.

<b>29 </b>So they did eat, and were well filled: for he gave them their own desire;

<b>30 </b>They were not estranged from their lust. But while their meat <i>was</i> yet in their mouths,

<b>31 </b>The wrath of God came upon them, and slew the fattest of them, and smote down the chosen <i>men</i> of Israel.

<b>32 </b>For all this they sinned still, and believed not for his wondrous works.

<b>33 </b>Therefore their days did he consume in vanity, and their years in trouble.

<b>34 </b>When he slew them, then they sought him: and they returned and inquired early after God.

<b>35 </b>And they remembered that God <i>was</i> their rock, and the high God their redeemer.

<b>36 </b>Nevertheless they did flatter him with their mouth, and they lied unto him with their tongues.

<b>37 </b>For their heart was not right with him, neither were they steadfast in his covenant.

<b>38 </b>But he, <i>being</i> full of compassion, forgave <i>their</i> iniquity, and destroyed <i>them</i> not: yea, many a time turned he his anger away, and did not stir up all his wrath.

<b>39 </b>For he remembered that they <i>were but</i> flesh; a wind that passeth away, and cometh not again.

<b>40 </b>How oft did they provoke him in the wilderness, <i>and</i> grieve him in the desert!

<b>41 </b>Yea, they turned back and tempted God, and limited the Holy One of Israel.

<b>42 </b>They remembered not his hand, <i>nor</i> the day when he delivered them from the enemy.

<b>43 </b>How he had wrought his signs in Egypt, and his wonders in the field of Zoan:

<b>44 </b>And had turned their rivers into blood; and their floods, that they could not drink.

<b>45 </b>He sent divers sorts of flies among them, which devoured them; and frogs, which destroyed them.

<b>46 </b>He gave also their increase unto the caterpiller, and their labour unto the locust.

<b>47 </b>He destroyed their vines with hail, and their sycomore trees with frost.

<b>48 </b>He gave up their cattle also to the hail, and their flocks to hot thunderbolts.

<b>49 </b>He cast upon them the fierceness of his anger, wrath, and indignation, and trouble, by sending evil angels <i>among them.</i>

<b>50 </b>He made a way to his anger; he spared not their soul from death, but gave their life over to the pestilence;

<b>51 </b>And smote all the firstborn in Egypt; the chief of <i>their</i> strength in the tabernacles of Ham:

<b>52 </b>But made his own people to go forth like sheep, and guided them in the wilderness like a flock.

<b>53 </b>And he led them on safely, so that they feared not: but the sea overwhelmed their enemies.

<b>54 </b>And he brought them to the border of his sanctuary, <i>even to</i> this mountain, <i>which</i> his right hand had purchased.

<b>55 </b>He cast out the heathen also before them, and divided them an inheritance by line, and made the tribes of Israel to dwell in their tents.

<b>56 </b>Yet they tempted and provoked the most high God, and kept not his testimonies:

<b>57 </b>But turned back, and dealt unfaithfully like their fathers: they were turned aside like a deceitful bow.

<b>58 </b>For they provoked him to anger with their high places, and moved him to jealousy with their graven images.

<b>59 </b>When God heard <i>this,</i> he was wroth, and greatly abhorred Israel:

<b>60 </b>So that he forsook the tabernacle of Shiloh, the tent <i>which</i> he placed among men;

<b>61 </b>And delivered his strength into captivity, and his glory into the enemy’s hand.

<b>62 </b>He gave his people over also unto the sword; and was wroth with his inheritance.

<b>63 </b>The fire consumed their young men; and their maidens were not given to marriage.

<b>64 </b>Their priests fell by the sword; and their widows made no lamentation.

<b>65 </b>Then the Lord awaked as one out of sleep, <i>and</i> like a mighty man that shouteth by reason of wine.

<b>66 </b>And he smote his enemies in the hinder parts: he put them to a perpetual reproach.

<b>67 </b>Moreover he refused the tabernacle of Joseph, and chose not the tribe of Ephraim:

<b>68 </b>But chose the tribe of Judah, the mount Zion which he loved.

<b>69 </b>And he built his sanctuary like high <i>palaces,</i> like the earth which he hath established for ever.

<b>70 </b>He chose David also his servant, and took him from the sheepfolds:

<b>71 </b>From following the ewes great with young he brought him to feed Jacob his people, and Israel his inheritance.

<b>72 </b>So he fed them according to the integrity of his heart; and guided them by the skilfulness of his hands.


--------------------

PSALM 79

A Psalm of Asaph.

<b>1 </b>O God, the heathen are come into thine inheritance; thy holy temple have they defiled; they have laid Jerusalem on heaps.

<b>2 </b>The dead bodies of thy servants have they given <i>to be</i> meat unto the fowls of the heaven, the flesh of thy saints unto the beasts of the earth.

<b>3 </b>Their blood have they shed like water round about Jerusalem; and <i>there was</i> none to bury <i>them.</i>

<b>4 </b>We are become a reproach to our neighbours, a scorn and derision to them that are round about us.

<b>5 </b>How long, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>? wilt thou be angry for ever? shall thy jealousy burn like fire?

<b>6 </b>Pour out thy wrath upon the heathen that have not known thee, and upon the kingdoms that have not called upon thy name.

<b>7 </b>For they have devoured Jacob, and laid waste his dwelling place.

<b>8 </b>O remember not against us former iniquities: let thy tender mercies speedily prevent us: for we are brought very low.

<b>9 </b>Help us, O God of our salvation, for the glory of thy name: and deliver us, and purge away our sins, for thy name’s sake.

<b>10 </b>Wherefore should the heathen say, Where <i>is</i> their God? let him be known among the heathen in our sight <i>by</i> the revenging of the blood of thy servants <i>which is</i> shed.

<b>11 </b>Let the sighing of the prisoner come before thee; according to the greatness of thy power preserve thou those that are appointed to die;

<b>12 </b>And render unto our neighbours sevenfold into their bosom their reproach, wherewith they have reproached thee, O Lord.

<b>13 </b>So we thy people and sheep of thy pasture will give thee thanks for ever: we will shew forth thy praise to all generations.


--------------------

PSALM 80

To the chief Musician upon Shoshannim-Eduth, A Psalm of Asaph.

<b>1 </b>Give ear, O Shepherd of Israel, thou that leadest Joseph like a flock; thou that dwellest <i>between</i> the cherubims, shine forth.

<b>2 </b>Before Ephraim and Benjamin and Manasseh stir up thy strength, and come <i>and</i> save us.

<b>3 </b>Turn us again, O God, and cause thy face to shine; and we shall be saved.

<b>4 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of hosts, how long wilt thou be angry against the prayer of thy people?

<b>5 </b>Thou feedest them with the bread of tears; and givest them tears to drink in great measure.

<b>6 </b>Thou makest us a strife unto our neighbours: and our enemies laugh among themselves.

<b>7 </b>Turn us again, O God of hosts, and cause thy face to shine; and we shall be saved.

<b>8 </b>Thou hast brought a vine out of Egypt: thou hast cast out the heathen, and planted it.

<b>9 </b>Thou preparedst <i>room</i> before it, and didst cause it to take deep root, and it filled the land.

<b>10 </b>The hills were covered with the shadow of it, and the boughs thereof <i>were like</i> the goodly cedars.

<b>11 </b>She sent out her boughs unto the sea, and her branches unto the river.

<b>12 </b>Why hast thou <i>then</i> broken down her hedges, so that all they which pass by the way do pluck her?

<b>13 </b>The boar out of the wood doth waste it, and the wild beast of the field doth devour it.

<b>14 </b>Return, we beseech thee, O God of hosts: look down from heaven, and behold, and visit this vine;

<b>15 </b>And the vineyard which thy right hand hath planted, and the branch <i>that</i> thou madest strong for thyself.

<b>16 </b><i>It is</i> burned with fire, <i>it is</i> cut down: they perish at the rebuke of thy countenance.

<b>17 </b>Let thy hand be upon the man of thy right hand, upon the son of man <i>whom</i> thou madest strong for thyself.

<b>18 </b>So will not we go back from thee: quicken us, and we will call upon thy name.

<b>19 </b>Turn us again, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of hosts, cause thy face to shine; and we shall be saved.


--------------------

PSALM 81

To the chief Musician upon Gittith, <i>A Psalm</i> of Asaph.

<b>1 </b>Sing aloud unto God our strength: make a joyful noise unto the God of Jacob.

<b>2 </b>Take a psalm, and bring hither the timbrel, the pleasant harp with the psaltery.

<b>3 </b>Blow up the trumpet in the new moon, in the time appointed, on our solemn feast day.

<b>4 </b>For this <i>was</i> a statute for Israel, <i>and</i> a law of the God of Jacob.

<b>5 </b>This he ordained in Joseph <i>for</i> a testimony, when he went out through the land of Egypt: <i>where</i> I heard a language <i>that</i> I understood not.

<b>6 </b>I removed his shoulder from the burden: his hands were delivered from the pots.

<b>7 </b>Thou calledst in trouble, and I delivered thee; I answered thee in the secret place of thunder: I proved thee at the waters of Meribah. Selah.

<b>8 </b>Hear, O my people, and I will testify unto thee: O Israel, if thou wilt hearken unto me;

<b>9 </b>There shall no strange god be in thee; neither shalt thou worship any strange god.

<b>10 </b>I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, which brought thee out of the land of Egypt: open thy mouth wide, and I will fill it.

<b>11 </b>But my people would not hearken to my voice; and Israel would none of me.

<b>12 </b>So I gave them up unto their own hearts’ lust: <i>and</i> they walked in their own counsels.

<b>13 </b>Oh that my people had hearkened unto me, <i>and</i> Israel had walked in my ways!

<b>14 </b>I should soon have subdued their enemies, and turned my hand against their adversaries.

<b>15 </b>The haters of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> should have submitted themselves unto him: but their time should have endured for ever.

<b>16 </b>He should have fed them also with the finest of the wheat: and with honey out of the rock should I have satisfied thee.


--------------------

PSALM 82

A Psalm of Asaph.

<b>1 </b>God standeth in the congregation of the mighty; he judgeth among the gods.

<b>2 </b>How long will ye judge unjustly, and accept the persons of the wicked? Selah.

<b>3 </b>Defend the poor and fatherless: do justice to the afflicted and needy.

<b>4 </b>Deliver the poor and needy: rid <i>them</i> out of the hand of the wicked.

<b>5 </b>They know not, neither will they understand; they walk on in darkness: all the foundations of the earth are out of course.

<b>6 </b>I have said, Ye <i>are</i> gods; and all of you <i>are</i> children of the most High.

<b>7 </b>But ye shall die like men, and fall like one of the princes.

<b>8 </b>Arise, O God, judge the earth: for thou shalt inherit all nations.


--------------------

PSALM 83

A Song <i>or</i> Psalm of Asaph.

<b>1 </b>Keep not thou silence, O God: hold not thy peace, and be not still, O God.

<b>2 </b>For, lo, thine enemies make a tumult: and they that hate thee have lifted up the head.

<b>3 </b>They have taken crafty counsel against thy people, and consulted against thy hidden ones.

<b>4 </b>They have said, Come, and let us cut them off from <i>being</i> a nation; that the name of Israel may be no more in remembrance.

<b>5 </b>For they have consulted together with one consent: they are confederate against thee:

<b>6 </b>The tabernacles of Edom, and the Ishmaelites; of Moab, and the Hagarenes;

<b>7 </b>Gebal, and Ammon, and Amalek; the Philistines with the inhabitants of Tyre;

<b>8 </b>Assur also is joined with them: they have holpen the children of Lot. Selah.

<b>9 </b>Do unto them as <i>unto</i> the Midianites; as <i>to</i> Sisera, as <i>to</i> Jabin, at the brook of Kison:

<b>10 </b><i>Which</i> perished at En-dor: they became <i>as</i> dung for the earth.

<b>11 </b>Make their nobles like Oreb, and like Zeeb: yea, all their princes as Zebah, and as Zalmunna:

<b>12 </b>Who said, Let us take to ourselves the houses of God in possession.

<b>13 </b>O my God, make them like a wheel; as the stubble before the wind.

<b>14 </b>As the fire burneth a wood, and as the flame setteth the mountains on fire;

<b>15 </b>So persecute them with thy tempest, and make them afraid with thy storm.

<b>16 </b>Fill their faces with shame; that they may seek thy name, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>17 </b>Let them be confounded and troubled for ever; yea, let them be put to shame, and perish:

<b>18 </b>That <i>men</i> may know that thou, whose name alone <i>is</i> <span class="uppercase">Jehovah</span>, <i>art</i> the most high over all the earth.


--------------------

PSALM 84

To the chief Musician upon Gittith, A Psalm for the sons of Korah.

<b>1 </b>How amiable <i>are</i> thy tabernacles, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts!

<b>2 </b>My soul longeth, yea, even fainteth for the courts of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: my heart and my flesh crieth out for the living God.

<b>3 </b>Yea, the sparrow hath found an house, and the swallow a nest for herself, where she may lay her young, <i>even</i> thine altars, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, my King, and my God.

<b>4 </b>Blessed <i>are</i> they that dwell in thy house: they will be still praising thee. Selah.

<b>5 </b>Blessed <i>is</i> the man whose strength <i>is</i> in thee; in whose heart <i>are</i> the ways <i>of them.</i>

<b>6 </b><i>Who</i> passing through the valley of Baca make it a well; the rain also filleth the pools.

<b>7 </b>They go from strength to strength, <i>every one of them</i> in Zion appeareth before God.

<b>8 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of hosts, hear my prayer: give ear, O God of Jacob. Selah.

<b>9 </b>Behold, O God our shield, and look upon the face of thine anointed.

<b>10 </b>For a day in thy courts <i>is</i> better than a thousand. I had rather be a doorkeeper in the house of my God, than to dwell in the tents of wickedness.

<b>11 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God <i>is</i> a sun and shield: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will give grace and glory: no good <i>thing</i> will he withhold from them that walk uprightly.

<b>12 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, blessed <i>is</i> the man that trusteth in thee.


--------------------

PSALM 85

To the chief Musician, A Psalm for the sons of Korah.

<b>1 </b><span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, thou hast been favourable unto thy land: thou hast brought back the captivity of Jacob.

<b>2 </b>Thou hast forgiven the iniquity of thy people, thou hast covered all their sin. Selah.

<b>3 </b>Thou hast taken away all thy wrath: thou hast turned <i>thyself</i> from the fierceness of thine anger.

<b>4 </b>Turn us, O God of our salvation, and cause thine anger toward us to cease.

<b>5 </b>Wilt thou be angry with us for ever? wilt thou draw out thine anger to all generations?

<b>6 </b>Wilt thou not revive us again: that thy people may rejoice in thee?

<b>7 </b>Shew us thy mercy, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and grant us thy salvation.

<b>8 </b>I will hear what God the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will speak: for he will speak peace unto his people, and to his saints: but let them not turn again to folly.

<b>9 </b>Surely his salvation <i>is</i> nigh them that fear him; that glory may dwell in our land.

<b>10 </b>Mercy and truth are met together; righteousness and peace have kissed <i>each other.</i>

<b>11 </b>Truth shall spring out of the earth; and righteousness shall look down from heaven.

<b>12 </b>Yea, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall give <i>that which is</i> good; and our land shall yield her increase.

<b>13 </b>Righteousness shall go before him; and shall set <i>us</i> in the way of his steps.


--------------------

PSALM 86

A Prayer of David.

<b>1 </b>Bow down thine ear, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, hear me: for I <i>am</i> poor and needy.

<b>2 </b>Preserve my soul; for I <i>am</i> holy: O thou my God, save thy servant that trusteth in thee.

<b>3 </b>Be merciful unto me, O Lord: for I cry unto thee daily.

<b>4 </b>Rejoice the soul of thy servant: for unto thee, O Lord, do I lift up my soul.

<b>5 </b>For thou, Lord, <i>art</i> good, and ready to forgive; and plenteous in mercy unto all them that call upon thee.

<b>6 </b>Give ear, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, unto my prayer; and attend to the voice of my supplications.

<b>7 </b>In the day of my trouble I will call upon thee: for thou wilt answer me.

<b>8 </b>Among the gods <i>there is</i> none like unto thee, O Lord; neither <i>are there any works</i> like unto thy works.

<b>9 </b>All nations whom thou hast made shall come and worship before thee, O Lord; and shall glorify thy name.

<b>10 </b>For thou <i>art</i> great, and doest wondrous things: thou <i>art</i> God alone.

<b>11 </b>Teach me thy way, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; I will walk in thy truth: unite my heart to fear thy name.

<b>12 </b>I will praise thee, O Lord my God, with all my heart: and I will glorify thy name for evermore.

<b>13 </b>For great <i>is</i> thy mercy toward me: and thou hast delivered my soul from the lowest hell.

<b>14 </b>O God, the proud are risen against me, and the assemblies of violent <i>men</i> have sought after my soul; and have not set thee before them.

<b>15 </b>But thou, O Lord, <i>art</i> a God full of compassion, and gracious, longsuffering, and plenteous in mercy and truth.

<b>16 </b>O turn unto me, and have mercy upon me; give thy strength unto thy servant, and save the son of thine handmaid.

<b>17 </b>Shew me a token for good; that they which hate me may see <i>it,</i> and be ashamed: because thou, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, hast holpen me, and comforted me.


--------------------

PSALM 87

A Psalm <i>or</i> Song for the sons of Korah.

<b>1 </b>His foundation <i>is</i> in the holy mountains.

<b>2 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> loveth the gates of Zion more than all the dwellings of Jacob.

<b>3 </b>Glorious things are spoken of thee, O city of God. Selah.

<b>4 </b>I will make mention of Rahab and Babylon to them that know me: behold Philistia, and Tyre, with Ethiopia; this <i>man</i> was born there.

<b>5 </b>And of Zion it shall be said, This and that man was born in her: and the highest himself shall establish her.

<b>6 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall count, when he writeth up the people, <i>that</i> this <i>man</i> was born there. Selah.

<b>7 </b>As well the singers as the players on instruments <i>shall be there:</i> all my springs <i>are</i> in thee.


--------------------

PSALM 88

A Song <i>or</i> Psalm for the sons of Korah, to the chief Musician upon Mahalath Leannoth, Maschil of Heman the Ezrahite.

<b>1 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of my salvation, I have cried day <i>and</i> night before thee:

<b>2 </b>Let my prayer come before thee: incline thine ear unto my cry;

<b>3 </b>For my soul is full of troubles: and my life draweth nigh unto the grave.

<b>4 </b>I am counted with them that go down into the pit: I am as a man <i>that hath</i> no strength:

<b>5 </b>Free among the dead, like the slain that lie in the grave, whom thou rememberest no more: and they are cut off from thy hand.

<b>6 </b>Thou hast laid me in the lowest pit, in darkness, in the deeps.

<b>7 </b>Thy wrath lieth hard upon me, and thou hast afflicted <i>me</i> with all thy waves. Selah.

<b>8 </b>Thou hast put away mine acquaintance far from me; thou hast made me an abomination unto them: <i>I am</i> shut up, and I cannot come forth.

<b>9 </b>Mine eye mourneth by reason of affliction: <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, I have called daily upon thee, I have stretched out my hands unto thee.

<b>10 </b>Wilt thou shew wonders to the dead? shall the dead arise <i>and</i> praise thee? Selah.

<b>11 </b>Shall thy lovingkindness be declared in the grave? <i>or</i> thy faithfulness in destruction?

<b>12 </b>Shall thy wonders be known in the dark? and thy righteousness in the land of forgetfulness?

<b>13 </b>But unto thee have I cried, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and in the morning shall my prayer prevent thee.

<b>14 </b><span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, why castest thou off my soul? <i>why</i> hidest thou thy face from me?

<b>15 </b>I <i>am</i> afflicted and ready to die from <i>my</i> youth up: <i>while</i> I suffer thy terrors I am distracted.

<b>16 </b>Thy fierce wrath goeth over me; thy terrors have cut me off.

<b>17 </b>They came round about me daily like water; they compassed me about together.

<b>18 </b>Lover and friend hast thou put far from me, <i>and</i> mine acquaintance into darkness.


--------------------

PSALM 89

Maschil of Ethan the Ezrahite.

<b>1 </b>I will sing of the mercies of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> for ever: with my mouth will I make known thy faithfulness to all generations.

<b>2 </b>For I have said, Mercy shall be built up for ever: thy faithfulness shalt thou establish in the very heavens.

<b>3 </b>I have made a covenant with my chosen, I have sworn unto David my servant,

<b>4 </b>Thy seed will I establish for ever, and build up thy throne to all generations. Selah.

<b>5 </b>And the heavens shall praise thy wonders, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: thy faithfulness also in the congregation of the saints.

<b>6 </b>For who in the heaven can be compared unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>? <i>who</i> among the sons of the mighty can be likened unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>?

<b>7 </b>God is greatly to be feared in the assembly of the saints, and to be had in reverence of all <i>them that are</i> about him.

<b>8 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of hosts, who <i>is</i> a strong <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> like unto thee? or to thy faithfulness round about thee?

<b>9 </b>Thou rulest the raging of the sea: when the waves thereof arise, thou stillest them.

<b>10 </b>Thou hast broken Rahab in pieces, as one that is slain; thou hast scattered thine enemies with thy strong arm.

<b>11 </b>The heavens <i>are</i> thine, the earth also <i>is</i> thine: <i>as for</i> the world and the fulness thereof, thou hast founded them.

<b>12 </b>The north and the south thou hast created them: Tabor and Hermon shall rejoice in thy name.

<b>13 </b>Thou hast a mighty arm: strong is thy hand, <i>and</i> high is thy right hand.

<b>14 </b>Justice and judgment <i>are</i> the habitation of thy throne: mercy and truth shall go before thy face.

<b>15 </b>Blessed <i>is</i> the people that know the joyful sound: they shall walk, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, in the light of thy countenance.

<b>16 </b>In thy name shall they rejoice all the day: and in thy righteousness shall they be exalted.

<b>17 </b>For thou <i>art</i> the glory of their strength: and in thy favour our horn shall be exalted.

<b>18 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> our defence; and the Holy One of Israel <i>is</i> our king.

<b>19 </b>Then thou spakest in vision to thy holy one, and saidst, I have laid help upon <i>one that is</i> mighty; I have exalted <i>one</i> chosen out of the people.

<b>20 </b>I have found David my servant; with my holy oil have I anointed him:

<b>21 </b>With whom my hand shall be established: mine arm also shall strengthen him.

<b>22 </b>The enemy shall not exact upon him; nor the son of wickedness afflict him.

<b>23 </b>And I will beat down his foes before his face, and plague them that hate him.

<b>24 </b>But my faithfulness and my mercy <i>shall be</i> with him: and in my name shall his horn be exalted.

<b>25 </b>I will set his hand also in the sea, and his right hand in the rivers.

<b>26 </b>He shall cry unto me, Thou <i>art</i> my father, my God, and the rock of my salvation.

<b>27 </b>Also I will make him <i>my</i> firstborn, higher than the kings of the earth.

<b>28 </b>My mercy will I keep for him for evermore, and my covenant shall stand fast with him.

<b>29 </b>His seed also will I make <i>to endure</i> for ever, and his throne as the days of heaven.

<b>30 </b>If his children forsake my law, and walk not in my judgments;

<b>31 </b>If they break my statutes, and keep not my commandments;

<b>32 </b>Then will I visit their transgression with the rod, and their iniquity with stripes.

<b>33 </b>Nevertheless my lovingkindness will I not utterly take from him, nor suffer my faithfulness to fail.

<b>34 </b>My covenant will I not break, nor alter the thing that is gone out of my lips.

<b>35 </b>Once have I sworn by my holiness that I will not lie unto David.

<b>36 </b>His seed shall endure for ever, and his throne as the sun before me.

<b>37 </b>It shall be established for ever as the moon, and <i>as</i> a faithful witness in heaven. Selah.

<b>38 </b>But thou hast cast off and abhorred, thou hast been wroth with thine anointed.

<b>39 </b>Thou hast made void the covenant of thy servant: thou hast profaned his crown <i>by casting it</i> to the ground.

<b>40 </b>Thou hast broken down all his hedges; thou hast brought his strong holds to ruin.

<b>41 </b>All that pass by the way spoil him: he is a reproach to his neighbours.

<b>42 </b>Thou hast set up the right hand of his adversaries; thou hast made all his enemies to rejoice.

<b>43 </b>Thou hast also turned the edge of his sword, and hast not made him to stand in the battle.

<b>44 </b>Thou hast made his glory to cease, and cast his throne down to the ground.

<b>45 </b>The days of his youth hast thou shortened: thou hast covered him with shame. Selah.

<b>46 </b>How long, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>? wilt thou hide thyself for ever? shall thy wrath burn like fire?

<b>47 </b>Remember how short my time is: wherefore hast thou made all men in vain?

<b>48 </b>What man <i>is he that</i> liveth, and shall not see death? shall he deliver his soul from the hand of the grave? Selah.

<b>49 </b>Lord, where <i>are</i> thy former lovingkindnesses, <i>which</i> thou swarest unto David in thy truth?

<b>50 </b>Remember, Lord, the reproach of thy servants; <i>how</i> I do bear in my bosom <i>the reproach of</i> all the mighty people;

<b>51 </b>Wherewith thine enemies have reproached, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; wherewith they have reproached the footsteps of thine anointed.

<b>52 </b>Blessed <i>be</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> for evermore. Amen, and Amen.


--------------------

PSALM 90

A Prayer of Moses the man of God.

<b>1 </b><span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, thou hast been our dwelling place in all generations.

<b>2 </b>Before the mountains were brought forth, or ever thou hadst formed the earth and the world, even from everlasting to everlasting, thou <i>art</i> God.

<b>3 </b>Thou turnest man to destruction; and sayest, Return, ye children of men.

<b>4 </b>For a thousand years in thy sight <i>are but</i> as yesterday when it is past, and <i>as</i> a watch in the night.

<b>5 </b>Thou carriest them away as with a flood; they are <i>as</i> a sleep: in the morning <i>they are</i> like grass <i>which</i> groweth up.

<b>6 </b>In the morning it flourisheth, and groweth up; in the evening it is cut down, and withereth.

<b>7 </b>For we are consumed by thine anger, and by thy wrath are we troubled.

<b>8 </b>Thou hast set our iniquities before thee, our secret <i>sins</i> in the light of thy countenance.

<b>9 </b>For all our days are passed away in thy wrath: we spend our years as a tale <i>that is told.</i>

<b>10 </b>The days of our years <i>are</i> threescore years and ten; and if by reason of strength <i>they be</i> fourscore years, yet <i>is</i> their strength labour and sorrow; for it is soon cut off, and we fly away.

<b>11 </b>Who knoweth the power of thine anger? even according to thy fear, <i>so is</i> thy wrath.

<b>12 </b>So teach <i>us</i> to number our days, that we may apply <i>our</i> hearts unto wisdom.

<b>13 </b>Return, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, how long? and let it repent thee concerning thy servants.

<b>14 </b>O satisfy us early with thy mercy; that we may rejoice and be glad all our days.

<b>15 </b>Make us glad according to the days <i>wherein</i> thou hast afflicted us, <i>and</i> the years <i>wherein</i> we have seen evil.

<b>16 </b>Let thy work appear unto thy servants, and thy glory unto their children.

<b>17 </b>And let the beauty of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God be upon us: and establish thou the work of our hands upon us; yea, the work of our hands establish thou it.


--------------------

PSALM 91

<b>1 </b>He that dwelleth in the secret place of the most High shall abide under the shadow of the Almighty.

<b>2 </b>I will say of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>He is</i> my refuge and my fortress: my God; in him will I trust.

<b>3 </b>Surely he shall deliver thee from the snare of the fowler, <i>and</i> from the noisome pestilence.

<b>4 </b>He shall cover thee with his feathers, and under his wings shalt thou trust: his truth <i>shall be thy</i> shield and buckler.

<b>5 </b>Thou shalt not be afraid for the terror by night; <i>nor</i> for the arrow <i>that</i> flieth by day;

<b>6 </b><i>Nor</i> for the pestilence <i>that</i> walketh in darkness; <i>nor</i> for the destruction <i>that</i> wasteth at noonday.

<b>7 </b>A thousand shall fall at thy side, and ten thousand at thy right hand; <i>but</i> it shall not come nigh thee.

<b>8 </b>Only with thine eyes shalt thou behold and see the reward of the wicked.

<b>9 </b>Because thou hast made the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>which is</i> my refuge, <i>even</i> the most High, thy habitation;

<b>10 </b>There shall no evil befall thee, neither shall any plague come nigh thy dwelling.

<b>11 </b>For he shall give his angels charge over thee, to keep thee in all thy ways.

<b>12 </b>They shall bear thee up in <i>their</i> hands, lest thou dash thy foot against a stone.

<b>13 </b>Thou shalt tread upon the lion and adder: the young lion and the dragon shalt thou trample under feet.

<b>14 </b>Because he hath set his love upon me, therefore will I deliver him: I will set him on high, because he hath known my name.

<b>15 </b>He shall call upon me, and I will answer him: I <i>will be</i> with him in trouble; I will deliver him, and honour him.

<b>16 </b>With long life will I satisfy him, and shew him my salvation.


--------------------

PSALM 92

A Psalm <i>or</i> Song for the sabbath day.

<b>1 </b><i>It is a</i> good <i>thing</i> to give thanks unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and to sing praises unto thy name, O most High:

<b>2 </b>To shew forth thy lovingkindness in the morning, and thy faithfulness every night,

<b>3 </b>Upon an instrument of ten strings, and upon the psaltery; upon the harp with a solemn sound.

<b>4 </b>For thou, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, hast made me glad through thy work: I will triumph in the works of thy hands.

<b>5 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, how great are thy works! <i>and</i> thy thoughts are very deep.

<b>6 </b>A brutish man knoweth not; neither doth a fool understand this.

<b>7 </b>When the wicked spring as the grass, and when all the workers of iniquity do flourish; <i>it is</i> that they shall be destroyed for ever:

<b>8 </b>But thou, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>art most</i> high for evermore.

<b>9 </b>For, lo, thine enemies, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, for, lo, thine enemies shall perish; all the workers of iniquity shall be scattered.

<b>10 </b>But my horn shalt thou exalt like <i>the horn of</i> an unicorn: I shall be anointed with fresh oil.

<b>11 </b>Mine eye also shall see <i>my desire</i> on mine enemies, <i>and</i> mine ears shall hear <i>my desire</i> of the wicked that rise up against me.

<b>12 </b>The righteous shall flourish like the palm tree: he shall grow like a cedar in Lebanon.

<b>13 </b>Those that be planted in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall flourish in the courts of our God.

<b>14 </b>They shall still bring forth fruit in old age; they shall be fat and flourishing;

<b>15 </b>To shew that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> upright: <i>he is</i> my rock, and <i>there is</i> no unrighteousness in him.


--------------------

PSALM 93

<b>1 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> reigneth, he is clothed with majesty; the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> is clothed with strength, <i>wherewith</i> he hath girded himself: the world also is stablished, that it cannot be moved.

<b>2 </b>Thy throne <i>is</i> established of old: thou <i>art</i> from everlasting.

<b>3 </b>The floods have lifted up, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the floods have lifted up their voice; the floods lift up their waves.

<b>4 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> on high <i>is</i> mightier than the noise of many waters, <i>yea, than</i> the mighty waves of the sea.

<b>5 </b>Thy testimonies are very sure: holiness becometh thine house, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, for ever.


--------------------

PSALM 94

<b>1 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God, to whom vengeance belongeth; O God, to whom vengeance belongeth, shew thyself.

<b>2 </b>Lift up thyself, thou judge of the earth: render a reward to the proud.

<b>3 </b><span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, how long shall the wicked, how long shall the wicked triumph?

<b>4 </b><i>How long</i> shall they utter <i>and</i> speak hard things? <i>and</i> all the workers of iniquity boast themselves?

<b>5 </b>They break in pieces thy people, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and afflict thine heritage.

<b>6 </b>They slay the widow and the stranger, and murder the fatherless.

<b>7 </b>Yet they say, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall not see, neither shall the God of Jacob regard <i>it.</i>

<b>8 </b>Understand, ye brutish among the people: and <i>ye</i> fools, when will ye be wise?

<b>9 </b>He that planted the ear, shall he not hear? he that formed the eye, shall he not see?

<b>10 </b>He that chastiseth the heathen, shall not he correct? he that teacheth man knowledge, <i>shall not he know?</i>

<b>11 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> knoweth the thoughts of man, that they <i>are</i> vanity.

<b>12 </b>Blessed <i>is</i> the man whom thou chastenest, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and teachest him out of thy law;

<b>13 </b>That thou mayest give him rest from the days of adversity, until the pit be digged for the wicked.

<b>14 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will not cast off his people, neither will he forsake his inheritance.

<b>15 </b>But judgment shall return unto righteousness: and all the upright in heart shall follow it.

<b>16 </b>Who will rise up for me against the evildoers? <i>or</i> who will stand up for me against the workers of iniquity?

<b>17 </b>Unless the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>had been</i> my help, my soul had almost dwelt in silence.

<b>18 </b>When I said, My foot slippeth; thy mercy, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, held me up.

<b>19 </b>In the multitude of my thoughts within me thy comforts delight my soul.

<b>20 </b>Shall the throne of iniquity have fellowship with thee, which frameth mischief by a law?

<b>21 </b>They gather themselves together against the soul of the righteous, and condemn the innocent blood.

<b>22 </b>But the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> is my defence; and my God <i>is</i> the rock of my refuge.

<b>23 </b>And he shall bring upon them their own iniquity, and shall cut them off in their own wickedness; <i>yea,</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God shall cut them off.


--------------------

PSALM 95

<b>1 </b>O come, let us sing unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: let us make a joyful noise to the rock of our salvation.

<b>2 </b>Let us come before his presence with thanksgiving, and make a joyful noise unto him with psalms.

<b>3 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> a great God, and a great King above all gods.

<b>4 </b>In his hand <i>are</i> the deep places of the earth: the strength of the hills <i>is</i> his also.

<b>5 </b>The sea <i>is</i> his, and he made it: and his hands formed the dry <i>land.</i>

<b>6 </b>O come, let us worship and bow down: let us kneel before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our maker.

<b>7 </b>For he <i>is</i> our God; and we <i>are</i> the people of his pasture, and the sheep of his hand. To day if ye will hear his voice,

<b>8 </b>Harden not your heart, as in the provocation, <i>and</i> as <i>in</i> the day of temptation in the wilderness:

<b>9 </b>When your fathers tempted me, proved me, and saw my work.

<b>10 </b>Forty years long was I grieved with <i>this</i> generation, and said, It <i>is</i> a people that do err in their heart, and they have not known my ways:

<b>11 </b>Unto whom I sware in my wrath that they should not enter into my rest.


--------------------

PSALM 96

<b>1 </b>O sing unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> a new song: sing unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, all the earth.

<b>2 </b>Sing unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, bless his name; shew forth his salvation from day to day.

<b>3 </b>Declare his glory among the heathen, his wonders among all people.

<b>4 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> great, and greatly to be praised: he <i>is</i> to be feared above all gods.

<b>5 </b>For all the gods of the nations <i>are</i> idols: but the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> made the heavens.

<b>6 </b>Honour and majesty <i>are</i> before him: strength and beauty <i>are</i> in his sanctuary.

<b>7 </b>Give unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, O ye kindreds of the people, give unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> glory and strength.

<b>8 </b>Give unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> the glory <i>due unto</i> his name: bring an offering, and come into his courts.

<b>9 </b>O worship the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in the beauty of holiness: fear before him, all the earth.

<b>10 </b>Say among the heathen <i>that</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> reigneth: the world also shall be established that it shall not be moved: he shall judge the people righteously.

<b>11 </b>Let the heavens rejoice, and let the earth be glad; let the sea roar, and the fulness thereof.

<b>12 </b>Let the field be joyful, and all that <i>is</i> therein: then shall all the trees of the wood rejoice

<b>13 </b>Before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for he cometh, for he cometh to judge the earth: he shall judge the world with righteousness, and the people with his truth.


--------------------

PSALM 97

<b>1 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> reigneth; let the earth rejoice; let the multitude of isles be glad <i>thereof.</i>

<b>2 </b>Clouds and darkness <i>are</i> round about him: righteousness and judgment <i>are</i> the habitation of his throne.

<b>3 </b>A fire goeth before him, and burneth up his enemies round about.

<b>4 </b>His lightnings enlightened the world: the earth saw, and trembled.

<b>5 </b>The hills melted like wax at the presence of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, at the presence of the Lord of the whole earth.

<b>6 </b>The heavens declare his righteousness, and all the people see his glory.

<b>7 </b>Confounded be all they that serve graven images, that boast themselves of idols: worship him, all <i>ye</i> gods.

<b>8 </b>Zion heard, and was glad; and the daughters of Judah rejoiced because of thy judgments, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>9 </b>For thou, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>art</i> high above all the earth: thou art exalted far above all gods.

<b>10 </b>Ye that love the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, hate evil: he preserveth the souls of his saints; he delivereth them out of the hand of the wicked.

<b>11 </b>Light is sown for the righteous, and gladness for the upright in heart.

<b>12 </b>Rejoice in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, ye righteous; and give thanks at the remembrance of his holiness.


--------------------

PSALM 98

A Psalm.

<b>1 </b>O sing unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> a new song; for he hath done marvellous things: his right hand, and his holy arm, hath gotten him the victory.

<b>2 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath made known his salvation: his righteousness hath he openly shewed in the sight of the heathen.

<b>3 </b>He hath remembered his mercy and his truth toward the house of Israel: all the ends of the earth have seen the salvation of our God.

<b>4 </b>Make a joyful noise unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, all the earth: make a loud noise, and rejoice, and sing praise.

<b>5 </b>Sing unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with the harp; with the harp, and the voice of a psalm.

<b>6 </b>With trumpets and sound of cornet make a joyful noise before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the King.

<b>7 </b>Let the sea roar, and the fulness thereof; the world, and they that dwell therein.

<b>8 </b>Let the floods clap <i>their</i> hands: let the hills be joyful together

<b>9 </b>Before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for he cometh to judge the earth: with righteousness shall he judge the world, and the people with equity.


--------------------

PSALM 99

<b>1 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> reigneth; let the people tremble: he sitteth <i>between</i> the cherubims; let the earth be moved.

<b>2 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> great in Zion; and he <i>is</i> high above all the people.

<b>3 </b>Let them praise thy great and terrible name; <i>for</i> it <i>is</i> holy.

<b>4 </b>The king’s strength also loveth judgment; thou dost establish equity, thou executest judgment and righteousness in Jacob.

<b>5 </b>Exalt ye the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God, and worship at his footstool; <i>for</i> he <i>is</i> holy.

<b>6 </b>Moses and Aaron among his priests, and Samuel among them that call upon his name; they called upon the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and he answered them.

<b>7 </b>He spake unto them in the cloudy pillar: they kept his testimonies, and the ordinance <i>that</i> he gave them.

<b>8 </b>Thou answeredst them, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God: thou wast a God that forgavest them, though thou tookest vengeance of their inventions.

<b>9 </b>Exalt the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God, and worship at his holy hill; for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God <i>is</i> holy.


--------------------

PSALM 100

A Psalm of praise.

<b>1 </b>Make a joyful noise unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, all ye lands.

<b>2 </b>Serve the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with gladness: come before his presence with singing.

<b>3 </b>Know ye that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> he <i>is</i> God: <i>it is</i> he <i>that</i> hath made us, and not we ourselves; <i>we are</i> his people, and the sheep of his pasture.

<b>4 </b>Enter into his gates with thanksgiving, <i>and</i> into his courts with praise: be thankful unto him, <i>and</i> bless his name.

<b>5 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> good; his mercy <i>is</i> everlasting; and his truth <i>endureth</i> to all generations.


--------------------

PSALM 101

A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>I will sing of mercy and judgment: unto thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, will I sing.

<b>2 </b>I will behave myself wisely in a perfect way. O when wilt thou come unto me? I will walk within my house with a perfect heart.

<b>3 </b>I will set no wicked thing before mine eyes: I hate the work of them that turn aside; <i>it</i> shall not cleave to me.

<b>4 </b>A froward heart shall depart from me: I will not know a wicked <i>person.</i>

<b>5 </b>Whoso privily slandereth his neighbour, him will I cut off: him that hath an high look and a proud heart will not I suffer.

<b>6 </b>Mine eyes <i>shall be</i> upon the faithful of the land, that they may dwell with me: he that walketh in a perfect way, he shall serve me.

<b>7 </b>He that worketh deceit shall not dwell within my house: he that telleth lies shall not tarry in my sight.

<b>8 </b>I will early destroy all the wicked of the land; that I may cut off all wicked doers from the city of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

PSALM 102

A Prayer of the afflicted, when he is overwhelmed, and poureth out his complaint before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>1 </b>Hear my prayer, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and let my cry come unto thee.

<b>2 </b>Hide not thy face from me in the day <i>when</i> I am in trouble; incline thine ear unto me: in the day <i>when</i> I call answer me speedily.

<b>3 </b>For my days are consumed like smoke, and my bones are burned as an hearth.

<b>4 </b>My heart is smitten, and withered like grass; so that I forget to eat my bread.

<b>5 </b>By reason of the voice of my groaning my bones cleave to my skin.

<b>6 </b>I am like a pelican of the wilderness: I am like an owl of the desert.

<b>7 </b>I watch, and am as a sparrow alone upon the house top.

<b>8 </b>Mine enemies reproach me all the day; <i>and</i> they that are mad against me are sworn against me.

<b>9 </b>For I have eaten ashes like bread, and mingled my drink with weeping,

<b>10 </b>Because of thine indignation and thy wrath: for thou hast lifted me up, and cast me down.

<b>11 </b>My days <i>are</i> like a shadow that declineth; and I am withered like grass.

<b>12 </b>But thou, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, shalt endure for ever; and thy remembrance unto all generations.

<b>13 </b>Thou shalt arise, <i>and</i> have mercy upon Zion: for the time to favour her, yea, the set time, is come.

<b>14 </b>For thy servants take pleasure in her stones, and favour the dust thereof.

<b>15 </b>So the heathen shall fear the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and all the kings of the earth thy glory.

<b>16 </b>When the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall build up Zion, he shall appear in his glory.

<b>17 </b>He will regard the prayer of the destitute, and not despise their prayer.

<b>18 </b>This shall be written for the generation to come: and the people which shall be created shall praise the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>19 </b>For he hath looked down from the height of his sanctuary; from heaven did the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> behold the earth;

<b>20 </b>To hear the groaning of the prisoner; to loose those that are appointed to death;

<b>21 </b>To declare the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in Zion, and his praise in Jerusalem;

<b>22 </b>When the people are gathered together, and the kingdoms, to serve the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>23 </b>He weakened my strength in the way; he shortened my days.

<b>24 </b>I said, O my God, take me not away in the midst of my days: thy years <i>are</i> throughout all generations.

<b>25 </b>Of old hast thou laid the foundation of the earth: and the heavens <i>are</i> the work of thy hands.

<b>26 </b>They shall perish, but thou shalt endure: yea, all of them shall wax old like a garment; as a vesture shalt thou change them, and they shall be changed:

<b>27 </b>But thou <i>art</i> the same, and thy years shall have no end.

<b>28 </b>The children of thy servants shall continue, and their seed shall be established before thee.


--------------------

PSALM 103

<i>A Psalm</i> of David.

<b>1 </b>Bless the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, O my soul: and all that is within me, <i>bless</i> his holy name.

<b>2 </b>Bless the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, O my soul, and forget not all his benefits:

<b>3 </b>Who forgiveth all thine iniquities; who healeth all thy diseases;

<b>4 </b>Who redeemeth thy life from destruction; who crowneth thee with lovingkindness and tender mercies;

<b>5 </b>Who satisfieth thy mouth with good <i>things; so that</i> thy youth is renewed like the eagle’s.

<b>6 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> executeth righteousness and judgment for all that are oppressed.

<b>7 </b>He made known his ways unto Moses, his acts unto the children of Israel.

<b>8 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> merciful and gracious, slow to anger, and plenteous in mercy.

<b>9 </b>He will not always chide: neither will he keep <i>his anger</i> for ever.

<b>10 </b>He hath not dealt with us after our sins; nor rewarded us according to our iniquities.

<b>11 </b>For as the heaven is high above the earth, <i>so</i> great is his mercy toward them that fear him.

<b>12 </b>As far as the east is from the west, <i>so</i> far hath he removed our transgressions from us.

<b>13 </b>Like as a father pitieth <i>his</i> children, <i>so</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> pitieth them that fear him.

<b>14 </b>For he knoweth our frame; he remembereth that we <i>are</i> dust.

<b>15 </b><i>As for</i> man, his days <i>are</i> as grass: as a flower of the field, so he flourisheth.

<b>16 </b>For the wind passeth over it, and it is gone; and the place thereof shall know it no more.

<b>17 </b>But the mercy of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> from everlasting to everlasting upon them that fear him, and his righteousness unto children’s children;

<b>18 </b>To such as keep his covenant, and to those that remember his commandments to do them.

<b>19 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath prepared his throne in the heavens; and his kingdom ruleth over all.

<b>20 </b>Bless the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, ye his angels, that excel in strength, that do his commandments, hearkening unto the voice of his word.

<b>21 </b>Bless ye the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, all <i>ye</i> his hosts; <i>ye</i> ministers of his, that do his pleasure.

<b>22 </b>Bless the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, all his works in all places of his dominion: bless the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, O my soul.


--------------------

PSALM 104

<b>1 </b>Bless the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, O my soul. O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God, thou art very great; thou art clothed with honour and majesty.

<b>2 </b>Who coverest <i>thyself</i> with light as <i>with</i> a garment: who stretchest out the heavens like a curtain:

<b>3 </b>Who layeth the beams of his chambers in the waters: who maketh the clouds his chariot: who walketh upon the wings of the wind:

<b>4 </b>Who maketh his angels spirits; his ministers a flaming fire:

<b>5 </b><i>Who</i> laid the foundations of the earth, <i>that</i> it should not be removed for ever.

<b>6 </b>Thou coveredst it with the deep as <i>with</i> a garment: the waters stood above the mountains.

<b>7 </b>At thy rebuke they fled; at the voice of thy thunder they hasted away.

<b>8 </b>They go up by the mountains; they go down by the valleys unto the place which thou hast founded for them.

<b>9 </b>Thou hast set a bound that they may not pass over; that they turn not again to cover the earth.

<b>10 </b>He sendeth the springs into the valleys, <i>which</i> run among the hills.

<b>11 </b>They give drink to every beast of the field: the wild asses quench their thirst.

<b>12 </b>By them shall the fowls of the heaven have their habitation, <i>which</i> sing among the branches.

<b>13 </b>He watereth the hills from his chambers: the earth is satisfied with the fruit of thy works.

<b>14 </b>He causeth the grass to grow for the cattle, and herb for the service of man: that he may bring forth food out of the earth;

<b>15 </b>And wine <i>that</i> maketh glad the heart of man, <i>and</i> oil to make <i>his</i> face to shine, and bread <i>which</i> strengtheneth man’s heart.

<b>16 </b>The trees of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> are full <i>of sap;</i> the cedars of Lebanon, which he hath planted;

<b>17 </b>Where the birds make their nests: <i>as for</i> the stork, the fir trees <i>are</i> her house.

<b>18 </b>The high hills <i>are</i> a refuge for the wild goats; <i>and</i> the rocks for the conies.

<b>19 </b>He appointed the moon for seasons: the sun knoweth his going down.

<b>20 </b>Thou makest darkness, and it is night: wherein all the beasts of the forest do creep <i>forth.</i>

<b>21 </b>The young lions roar after their prey, and seek their meat from God.
