PSALM 120

A Song of degrees.

<b>1 </b>In my distress I cried unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and he heard me.

<b>2 </b>Deliver my soul, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, from lying lips, <i>and</i> from a deceitful tongue.

<b>3 </b>What shall be given unto thee? or what shall be done unto thee, thou false tongue?

<b>4 </b>Sharp arrows of the mighty, with coals of juniper.

<b>5 </b>Woe is me, that I sojourn in Mesech, <i>that</i> I dwell in the tents of Kedar!

<b>6 </b>My soul hath long dwelt with him that hateth peace.

<b>7 </b>I <i>am for</i> peace: but when I speak, they <i>are</i> for war.


--------------------

PSALM 121

A Song of degrees.

<b>1 </b>I will lift up mine eyes unto the hills, from whence cometh my help.

<b>2 </b>My help <i>cometh</i> from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which made heaven and earth.

<b>3 </b>He will not suffer thy foot to be moved: he that keepeth thee will not slumber.

<b>4 </b>Behold, he that keepeth Israel shall neither slumber nor sleep.

<b>5 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> thy keeper: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> thy shade upon thy right hand.

<b>6 </b>The sun shall not smite thee by day, nor the moon by night.

<b>7 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall preserve thee from all evil: he shall preserve thy soul.

<b>8 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall preserve thy going out and thy coming in from this time forth, and even for evermore.


--------------------

PSALM 122

A Song of degrees of David.

<b>1 </b>I was glad when they said unto me, Let us go into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>2 </b>Our feet shall stand within thy gates, O Jerusalem.

<b>3 </b>Jerusalem is builded as a city that is compact together:

<b>4 </b>Whither the tribes go up, the tribes of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, unto the testimony of Israel, to give thanks unto the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>5 </b>For there are set thrones of judgment, the thrones of the house of David.

<b>6 </b>Pray for the peace of Jerusalem: they shall prosper that love thee.

<b>7 </b>Peace be within thy walls, <i>and</i> prosperity within thy palaces.

<b>8 </b>For my brethren and companions’ sakes, I will now say, Peace <i>be</i> within thee.

<b>9 </b>Because of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God I will seek thy good.


--------------------

PSALM 123

A Song of degrees.

<b>1 </b>Unto thee lift I up mine eyes, O thou that dwellest in the heavens.

<b>2 </b>Behold, as the eyes of servants <i>look</i> unto the hand of their masters, <i>and</i> as the eyes of a maiden unto the hand of her mistress; so our eyes <i>wait</i> upon the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God, until that he have mercy upon us.

<b>3 </b>Have mercy upon us, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, have mercy upon us: for we are exceedingly filled with contempt.

<b>4 </b>Our soul is exceedingly filled with the scorning of those that are at ease, <i>and</i> with the contempt of the proud.


--------------------

PSALM 124

A Song of degrees of David.

<b>1 </b>If <i>it had</i> not <i>been</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> who was on our side, now may Israel say;

<b>2 </b>If <i>it had</i> not <i>been</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> who was on our side, when men rose up against us:

<b>3 </b>Then they had swallowed us up quick, when their wrath was kindled against us:

<b>4 </b>Then the waters had overwhelmed us, the stream had gone over our soul:

<b>5 </b>Then the proud waters had gone over our soul.

<b>6 </b>Blessed <i>be</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, who hath not given us <i>as</i> a prey to their teeth.

<b>7 </b>Our soul is escaped as a bird out of the snare of the fowlers: the snare is broken, and we are escaped.

<b>8 </b>Our help <i>is</i> in the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, who made heaven and earth.


--------------------

PSALM 125

A Song of degrees.

<b>1 </b>They that trust in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>shall be</i> as mount Zion, <i>which</i> cannot be removed, <i>but</i> abideth for ever.

<b>2 </b><i>As</i> the mountains <i>are</i> round about Jerusalem, so the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> round about his people from henceforth even for ever.

<b>3 </b>For the rod of the wicked shall not rest upon the lot of the righteous; lest the righteous put forth their hands unto iniquity.

<b>4 </b>Do good, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, unto <i>those that be</i> good, and to <i>them that are</i> upright in their hearts.

<b>5 </b>As for such as turn aside unto their crooked ways, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall lead them forth with the workers of iniquity: <i>but</i> peace <i>shall be</i> upon Israel.


--------------------

PSALM 126

A Song of degrees.

<b>1 </b>When the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> turned again the captivity of Zion, we were like them that dream.

<b>2 </b>Then was our mouth filled with laughter, and our tongue with singing: then said they among the heathen, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath done great things for them.

<b>3 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath done great things for us; <i>whereof</i> we are glad.

<b>4 </b>Turn again our captivity, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, as the streams in the south.

<b>5 </b>They that sow in tears shall reap in joy.

<b>6 </b>He that goeth forth and weepeth, bearing precious seed, shall doubtless come again with rejoicing, bringing his sheaves <i>with him.</i>


--------------------

PSALM 127

A Song of degrees for Solomon.

<b>1 </b>Except the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> build the house, they labour in vain that build it: except the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> keep the city, the watchman waketh <i>but</i> in vain.

<b>2 </b><i>It is</i> vain for you to rise up early, to sit up late, to eat the bread of sorrows: <i>for</i> so he giveth his beloved sleep.

<b>3 </b>Lo, children <i>are</i> an heritage of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: <i>and</i> the fruit of the womb <i>is his</i> reward.

<b>4 </b>As arrows <i>are</i> in the hand of a mighty man; so <i>are</i> children of the youth.

<b>5 </b>Happy <i>is</i> the man that hath his quiver full of them: they shall not be ashamed, but they shall speak with the enemies in the gate.


--------------------

PSALM 128

A Song of degrees.

<b>1 </b>Blessed <i>is</i> every one that feareth the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; that walketh in his ways.

<b>2 </b>For thou shalt eat the labour of thine hands: happy <i>shalt</i> thou <i>be,</i> and <i>it shall be</i> well with thee.

<b>3 </b>Thy wife <i>shall be</i> as a fruitful vine by the sides of thine house: thy children like olive plants round about thy table.

<b>4 </b>Behold, that thus shall the man be blessed that feareth the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>5 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall bless thee out of Zion: and thou shalt see the good of Jerusalem all the days of thy life.

<b>6 </b>Yea, thou shalt see thy children’s children, <i>and</i> peace upon Israel.


--------------------

PSALM 129

A Song of degrees.

<b>1 </b>Many a time have they afflicted me from my youth, may Israel now say:

<b>2 </b>Many a time have they afflicted me from my youth: yet they have not prevailed against me.

<b>3 </b>The plowers plowed upon my back: they made long their furrows.

<b>4 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> righteous: he hath cut asunder the cords of the wicked.

<b>5 </b>Let them all be confounded and turned back that hate Zion.

<b>6 </b>Let them be as the grass <i>upon</i> the housetops, which withereth afore it groweth up:

<b>7 </b>Wherewith the mower filleth not his hand; nor he that bindeth sheaves his bosom.

<b>8 </b>Neither do they which go by say, The blessing of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>be</i> upon you: we bless you in the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

PSALM 130

A Song of degrees.

<b>1 </b>Out of the depths have I cried unto thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>2 </b>Lord, hear my voice: let thine ears be attentive to the voice of my supplications.

<b>3 </b>If thou, <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, shouldest mark iniquities, O Lord, who shall stand?

<b>4 </b>But <i>there is</i> forgiveness with thee, that thou mayest be feared.

<b>5 </b>I wait for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, my soul doth wait, and in his word do I hope.

<b>6 </b>My soul <i>waiteth</i> for the Lord more than they that watch for the morning: <i>I say, more than</i> they that watch for the morning.

<b>7 </b>Let Israel hope in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for with the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>there is</i> mercy, and with him <i>is</i> plenteous redemption.

<b>8 </b>And he shall redeem Israel from all his iniquities.


--------------------

PSALM 131

A Song of degrees of David.

<b>1 </b><span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, my heart is not haughty, nor mine eyes lofty: neither do I exercise myself in great matters, or in things too high for me.

<b>2 </b>Surely I have behaved and quieted myself, as a child that is weaned of his mother: my soul <i>is</i> even as a weaned child.

<b>3 </b>Let Israel hope in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> from henceforth and for ever.


--------------------

PSALM 132

A Song of degrees.

<b>1 </b><span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, remember David, <i>and</i> all his afflictions:

<b>2 </b>How he sware unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>and</i> vowed unto the mighty <i>God</i> of Jacob;

<b>3 </b>Surely I will not come into the tabernacle of my house, nor go up into my bed;

<b>4 </b>I will not give sleep to mine eyes, <i>or</i> slumber to mine eyelids,

<b>5 </b>Until I find out a place for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, an habitation for the mighty <i>God</i> of Jacob.

<b>6 </b>Lo, we heard of it at Ephratah: we found it in the fields of the wood.

<b>7 </b>We will go into his tabernacles: we will worship at his footstool.

<b>8 </b>Arise, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, into thy rest; thou, and the ark of thy strength.

<b>9 </b>Let thy priests be clothed with righteousness; and let thy saints shout for joy.

<b>10 </b>For thy servant David’s sake turn not away the face of thine anointed.

<b>11 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath sworn <i>in</i> truth unto David; he will not turn from it; Of the fruit of thy body will I set upon thy throne.

<b>12 </b>If thy children will keep my covenant and my testimony that I shall teach them, their children shall also sit upon thy throne for evermore.

<b>13 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath chosen Zion; he hath desired <i>it</i> for his habitation.

<b>14 </b>This <i>is</i> my rest for ever: here will I dwell; for I have desired it.

<b>15 </b>I will abundantly bless her provision: I will satisfy her poor with bread.

<b>16 </b>I will also clothe her priests with salvation: and her saints shall shout aloud for joy.

<b>17 </b>There will I make the horn of David to bud: I have ordained a lamp for mine anointed.

<b>18 </b>His enemies will I clothe with shame: but upon himself shall his crown flourish.


--------------------

PSALM 133

A Song of degrees of David.

<b>1 </b>Behold, how good and how pleasant <i>it is</i> for brethren to dwell together in unity!

<b>2 </b><i>It is</i> like the precious ointment upon the head, that ran down upon the beard, <i>even</i> Aaron’s beard: that went down to the skirts of his garments;

<b>3 </b>As the dew of Hermon, <i>and as the dew</i> that descended upon the mountains of Zion: for there the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commanded the blessing, <i>even</i> life for evermore.


--------------------

PSALM 134

A Song of degrees.

<b>1 </b>Behold, bless ye the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, all <i>ye</i> servants of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which by night stand in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>2 </b>Lift up your hands <i>in</i> the sanctuary, and bless the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>3 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that made heaven and earth bless thee out of Zion.


--------------------

PSALM 135

<b>1 </b>Praise ye the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. Praise ye the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; praise <i>him,</i> O ye servants of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>2 </b>Ye that stand in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, in the courts of the house of our God,

<b>3 </b>Praise the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> good: sing praises unto his name; for <i>it is</i> pleasant.

<b>4 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath chosen Jacob unto himself, <i>and</i> Israel for his peculiar treasure.

<b>5 </b>For I know that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> great, and <i>that</i> our Lord <i>is</i> above all gods.

<b>6 </b>Whatsoever the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> pleased, <i>that</i> did he in heaven, and in earth, in the seas, and all deep places.

<b>7 </b>He causeth the vapours to ascend from the ends of the earth; he maketh lightnings for the rain; he bringeth the wind out of his treasuries.

<b>8 </b>Who smote the firstborn of Egypt, both of man and beast.

<b>9 </b><i>Who</i> sent tokens and wonders into the midst of thee, O Egypt, upon Pharaoh, and upon all his servants.

<b>10 </b>Who smote great nations, and slew mighty kings;

<b>11 </b>Sihon king of the Amorites, and Og king of Bashan, and all the kingdoms of Canaan:

<b>12 </b>And gave their land <i>for</i> an heritage, an heritage unto Israel his people.

<b>13 </b>Thy name, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>endureth</i> for ever; <i>and</i> thy memorial, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, throughout all generations.

<b>14 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will judge his people, and he will repent himself concerning his servants.

<b>15 </b>The idols of the heathen <i>are</i> silver and gold, the work of men’s hands.

<b>16 </b>They have mouths, but they speak not; eyes have they, but they see not;

<b>17 </b>They have ears, but they hear not; neither is there <i>any</i> breath in their mouths.

<b>18 </b>They that make them are like unto them: <i>so is</i> every one that trusteth in them.

<b>19 </b>Bless the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, O house of Israel: bless the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, O house of Aaron:

<b>20 </b>Bless the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, O house of Levi: ye that fear the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, bless the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>21 </b>Blessed be the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> out of Zion, which dwelleth at Jerusalem. Praise ye the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

PSALM 136

<b>1 </b>O give thanks unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for <i>he is</i> good: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever.

<b>2 </b>O give thanks unto the God of gods: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever.

<b>3 </b>O give thanks to the Lord of lords: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever.

<b>4 </b>To him who alone doeth great wonders: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever.

<b>5 </b>To him that by wisdom made the heavens: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever.

<b>6 </b>To him that stretched out the earth above the waters: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever.

<b>7 </b>To him that made great lights: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever:

<b>8 </b>The sun to rule by day: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever:

<b>9 </b>The moon and stars to rule by night: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever.

<b>10 </b>To him that smote Egypt in their firstborn: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever:

<b>11 </b>And brought out Israel from among them: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever:

<b>12 </b>With a strong hand, and with a stretched out arm: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever.

<b>13 </b>To him which divided the Red sea into parts: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever:

<b>14 </b>And made Israel to pass through the midst of it: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever:

<b>15 </b>But overthrew Pharaoh and his host in the Red sea: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever.

<b>16 </b>To him which led his people through the wilderness: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever.

<b>17 </b>To him which smote great kings: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever:

<b>18 </b>And slew famous kings: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever:

<b>19 </b>Sihon king of the Amorites: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever:

<b>20 </b>And Og the king of Bashan: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever:

<b>21 </b>And gave their land for an heritage: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever:

<b>22 </b><i>Even</i> an heritage unto Israel his servant: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever.

<b>23 </b>Who remembered us in our low estate: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever:

<b>24 </b>And hath redeemed us from our enemies: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever.

<b>25 </b>Who giveth food to all flesh: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever.

<b>26 </b>O give thanks unto the God of heaven: for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever.


--------------------

PSALM 137

<b>1 </b>By the rivers of Babylon, there we sat down, yea, we wept, when we remembered Zion.

<b>2 </b>We hanged our harps upon the willows in the midst thereof.

<b>3 </b>For there they that carried us away captive required of us a song; and they that wasted us <i>required of us</i> mirth, <i>saying,</i> Sing us <i>one</i> of the songs of Zion.

<b>4 </b>How shall we sing the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s song in a strange land?

<b>5 </b>If I forget thee, O Jerusalem, let my right hand forget <i>her cunning.</i>

<b>6 </b>If I do not remember thee, let my tongue cleave to the roof of my mouth; if I prefer not Jerusalem above my chief joy.

<b>7 </b>Remember, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the children of Edom in the day of Jerusalem; who said, Rase <i>it,</i> rase <i>it, even</i> to the foundation thereof.

<b>8 </b>O daughter of Babylon, who art to be destroyed; happy <i>shall he be,</i> that rewardeth thee as thou hast served us.

<b>9 </b>Happy <i>shall he be,</i> that taketh and dasheth thy little ones against the stones.


--------------------

PSALM 138

<i>A Psalm</i> of David.

<b>1 </b>I will praise thee with my whole heart: before the gods will I sing praise unto thee.

<b>2 </b>I will worship toward thy holy temple, and praise thy name for thy lovingkindness and for thy truth: for thou hast magnified thy word above all thy name.

<b>3 </b>In the day when I cried thou answeredst me, <i>and</i> strengthenedst me <i>with</i> strength in my soul.

<b>4 </b>All the kings of the earth shall praise thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, when they hear the words of thy mouth.

<b>5 </b>Yea, they shall sing in the ways of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for great <i>is</i> the glory of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>6 </b>Though the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>be</i> high, yet hath he respect unto the lowly: but the proud he knoweth afar off.

<b>7 </b>Though I walk in the midst of trouble, thou wilt revive me: thou shalt stretch forth thine hand against the wrath of mine enemies, and thy right hand shall save me.

<b>8 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will perfect <i>that which</i> concerneth me: thy mercy, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>endureth</i> for ever: forsake not the works of thine own hands.


--------------------

PSALM 139

To the chief Musician, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, thou hast searched me, and known <i>me.</i>

<b>2 </b>Thou knowest my downsitting and mine uprising, thou understandest my thought afar off.

<b>3 </b>Thou compassest my path and my lying down, and art acquainted <i>with</i> all my ways.

<b>4 </b>For <i>there is</i> not a word in my tongue, <i>but,</i> lo, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, thou knowest it altogether.

<b>5 </b>Thou hast beset me behind and before, and laid thine hand upon me.

<b>6 </b><i>Such</i> knowledge <i>is</i> too wonderful for me; it is high, I cannot <i>attain</i> unto it.

<b>7 </b>Whither shall I go from thy spirit? or whither shall I flee from thy presence?

<b>8 </b>If I ascend up into heaven, thou <i>art</i> there: if I make my bed in hell, behold, thou <i>art there.</i>

<b>9 </b><i>If</i> I take the wings of the morning, <i>and</i> dwell in the uttermost parts of the sea;

<b>10 </b>Even there shall thy hand lead me, and thy right hand shall hold me.

<b>11 </b>If I say, Surely the darkness shall cover me; even the night shall be light about me.

<b>12 </b>Yea, the darkness hideth not from thee; but the night shineth as the day: the darkness and the light <i>are</i> both alike <i>to thee.</i>

<b>13 </b>For thou hast possessed my reins: thou hast covered me in my mother’s womb.

<b>14 </b>I will praise thee; for I am fearfully <i>and</i> wonderfully made: marvellous <i>are</i> thy works; and <i>that</i> my soul knoweth right well.

<b>15 </b>My substance was not hid from thee, when I was made in secret, <i>and</i> curiously wrought in the lowest parts of the earth.

<b>16 </b>Thine eyes did see my substance, yet being unperfect; and in thy book all <i>my members</i> were written, <i>which</i> in continuance were fashioned, when <i>as yet there was</i> none of them.

<b>17 </b>How precious also are thy thoughts unto me, O God! how great is the sum of them!

<b>18 </b><i>If</i> I should count them, they are more in number than the sand: when I awake, I am still with thee.

<b>19 </b>Surely thou wilt slay the wicked, O God: depart from me therefore, ye bloody men.

<b>20 </b>For they speak against thee wickedly, <i>and</i> thine enemies take <i>thy name</i> in vain.

<b>21 </b>Do not I hate them, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that hate thee? and am not I grieved with those that rise up against thee?

<b>22 </b>I hate them with perfect hatred: I count them mine enemies.

<b>23 </b>Search me, O God, and know my heart: try me, and know my thoughts:

<b>24 </b>And see if <i>there be any</i> wicked way in me, and lead me in the way everlasting.


--------------------

PSALM 140

To the chief Musician, A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>Deliver me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, from the evil man: preserve me from the violent man;

<b>2 </b>Which imagine mischiefs in <i>their</i> heart; continually are they gathered together <i>for</i> war.

<b>3 </b>They have sharpened their tongues like a serpent; adders’ poison <i>is</i> under their lips. Selah.

<b>4 </b>Keep me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, from the hands of the wicked; preserve me from the violent man; who have purposed to overthrow my goings.

<b>5 </b>The proud have hid a snare for me, and cords; they have spread a net by the wayside; they have set gins for me. Selah.

<b>6 </b>I said unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Thou <i>art</i> my God: hear the voice of my supplications, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>7 </b>O <span class="small-caps">God</span> the Lord, the strength of my salvation, thou hast covered my head in the day of battle.

<b>8 </b>Grant not, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the desires of the wicked: further not his wicked device; <i>lest</i> they exalt themselves. Selah.

<b>9 </b><i>As for</i> the head of those that compass me about, let the mischief of their own lips cover them.

<b>10 </b>Let burning coals fall upon them: let them be cast into the fire; into deep pits, that they rise not up again.

<b>11 </b>Let not an evil speaker be established in the earth: evil shall hunt the violent man to overthrow <i>him.</i>

<b>12 </b>I know that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will maintain the cause of the afflicted, <i>and</i> the right of the poor.

<b>13 </b>Surely the righteous shall give thanks unto thy name: the upright shall dwell in thy presence.


--------------------

PSALM 141

A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b><span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, I cry unto thee: make haste unto me; give ear unto my voice, when I cry unto thee.

<b>2 </b>Let my prayer be set forth before thee <i>as</i> incense; <i>and</i> the lifting up of my hands <i>as</i> the evening sacrifice.

<b>3 </b>Set a watch, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, before my mouth; keep the door of my lips.

<b>4 </b>Incline not my heart to <i>any</i> evil thing, to practise wicked works with men that work iniquity: and let me not eat of their dainties.

<b>5 </b>Let the righteous smite me; <i>it shall be</i> a kindness: and let him reprove me; <i>it shall be</i> an excellent oil, <i>which</i> shall not break my head: for yet my prayer also <i>shall be</i> in their calamities.

<b>6 </b>When their judges are overthrown in stony places, they shall hear my words; for they are sweet.

<b>7 </b>Our bones are scattered at the grave’s mouth, as when one cutteth and cleaveth <i>wood</i> upon the earth.

<b>8 </b>But mine eyes <i>are</i> unto thee, O <span class="small-caps">God</span> the Lord: in thee is my trust; leave not my soul destitute.

<b>9 </b>Keep me from the snares <i>which</i> they have laid for me, and the gins of the workers of iniquity.

<b>10 </b>Let the wicked fall into their own nets, whilst that I withal escape.


--------------------

PSALM 142

Maschil of David; A Prayer when he was in the cave.

<b>1 </b>I cried unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with my voice; with my voice unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> did I make my supplication.

<b>2 </b>I poured out my complaint before him; I shewed before him my trouble.

<b>3 </b>When my spirit was overwhelmed within me, then thou knewest my path. In the way wherein I walked have they privily laid a snare for me.

<b>4 </b>I looked on <i>my</i> right hand, and beheld, but <i>there was</i> no man that would know me: refuge failed me; no man cared for my soul.

<b>5 </b>I cried unto thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: I said, Thou <i>art</i> my refuge <i>and</i> my portion in the land of the living.

<b>6 </b>Attend unto my cry; for I am brought very low: deliver me from my persecutors; for they are stronger than I.

<b>7 </b>Bring my soul out of prison, that I may praise thy name: the righteous shall compass me about; for thou shalt deal bountifully with me.


--------------------

PSALM 143

A Psalm of David.

<b>1 </b>Hear my prayer, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, give ear to my supplications: in thy faithfulness answer me, <i>and</i> in thy righteousness.

<b>2 </b>And enter not into judgment with thy servant: for in thy sight shall no man living be justified.

<b>3 </b>For the enemy hath persecuted my soul; he hath smitten my life down to the ground; he hath made me to dwell in darkness, as those that have been long dead.

<b>4 </b>Therefore is my spirit overwhelmed within me; my heart within me is desolate.

<b>5 </b>I remember the days of old; I meditate on all thy works; I muse on the work of thy hands.

<b>6 </b>I stretch forth my hands unto thee: my soul <i>thirsteth</i> after thee, as a thirsty land. Selah.

<b>7 </b>Hear me speedily, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: my spirit faileth: hide not thy face from me, lest I be like unto them that go down into the pit.

<b>8 </b>Cause me to hear thy lovingkindness in the morning; for in thee do I trust: cause me to know the way wherein I should walk; for I lift up my soul unto thee.

<b>9 </b>Deliver me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, from mine enemies: I flee unto thee to hide me.

<b>10 </b>Teach me to do thy will; for thou <i>art</i> my God: thy spirit <i>is</i> good; lead me into the land of uprightness.

<b>11 </b>Quicken me, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, for thy name’s sake: for thy righteousness’ sake bring my soul out of trouble.

<b>12 </b>And of thy mercy cut off mine enemies, and destroy all them that afflict my soul: for I <i>am</i> thy servant.


--------------------

PSALM 144

<i>A Psalm</i> of David.

<b>1 </b>Blessed <i>be</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my strength, which teacheth my hands to war, <i>and</i> my fingers to fight:

<b>2 </b>My goodness, and my fortress; my high tower, and my deliverer; my shield, and <i>he</i> in whom I trust; who subdueth my people under me.

<b>3 </b><span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, what <i>is</i> man, that thou takest knowledge of him! <i>or</i> the son of man, that thou makest account of him!

<b>4 </b>Man is like to vanity: his days <i>are</i> as a shadow that passeth away.

<b>5 </b>Bow thy heavens, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and come down: touch the mountains, and they shall smoke.

<b>6 </b>Cast forth lightning, and scatter them: shoot out thine arrows, and destroy them.

<b>7 </b>Send thine hand from above; rid me, and deliver me out of great waters, from the hand of strange children;

<b>8 </b>Whose mouth speaketh vanity, and their right hand <i>is</i> a right hand of falsehood.

<b>9 </b>I will sing a new song unto thee, O God: upon a psaltery <i>and</i> an instrument of ten strings will I sing praises unto thee.

<b>10 </b><i>It is he</i> that giveth salvation unto kings: who delivereth David his servant from the hurtful sword.

<b>11 </b>Rid me, and deliver me from the hand of strange children, whose mouth speaketh vanity, and their right hand <i>is</i> a right hand of falsehood:

<b>12 </b>That our sons <i>may be</i> as plants grown up in their youth; <i>that</i> our daughters <i>may be</i> as corner stones, polished <i>after</i> the similitude of a palace:

<b>13 </b><i>That</i> our garners <i>may be</i> full, affording all manner of store: <i>that</i> our sheep may bring forth thousands and ten thousands in our streets:

<b>14 </b><i>That</i> our oxen <i>may be</i> strong to labour; <i>that there be</i> no breaking in, nor going out; that <i>there be</i> no complaining in our streets.

<b>15 </b>Happy <i>is that</i> people, that is in such a case: <i>yea,</i> happy <i>is that</i> people, whose God <i>is</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

PSALM 145

David’s <i>Psalm</i> of praise.

<b>1 </b>I will extol thee, my God, O king; and I will bless thy name for ever and ever.

<b>2 </b>Every day will I bless thee; and I will praise thy name for ever and ever.

<b>3 </b>Great <i>is</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and greatly to be praised; and his greatness <i>is</i> unsearchable.

<b>4 </b>One generation shall praise thy works to another, and shall declare thy mighty acts.

<b>5 </b>I will speak of the glorious honour of thy majesty, and of thy wondrous works.

<b>6 </b>And <i>men</i> shall speak of the might of thy terrible acts: and I will declare thy greatness.

<b>7 </b>They shall abundantly utter the memory of thy great goodness, and shall sing of thy righteousness.

<b>8 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> gracious, and full of compassion; slow to anger, and of great mercy.

<b>9 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> good to all: and his tender mercies <i>are</i> over all his works.

<b>10 </b>All thy works shall praise thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and thy saints shall bless thee.

<b>11 </b>They shall speak of the glory of thy kingdom, and talk of thy power;

<b>12 </b>To make known to the sons of men his mighty acts, and the glorious majesty of his kingdom.

<b>13 </b>Thy kingdom <i>is</i> an everlasting kingdom, and thy dominion <i>endureth</i> throughout all generations.

<b>14 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> upholdeth all that fall, and raiseth up all <i>those that be</i> bowed down.

<b>15 </b>The eyes of all wait upon thee; and thou givest them their meat in due season.

<b>16 </b>Thou openest thine hand, and satisfiest the desire of every living thing.

<b>17 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> righteous in all his ways, and holy in all his works.

<b>18 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> nigh unto all them that call upon him, to all that call upon him in truth.

<b>19 </b>He will fulfil the desire of them that fear him: he also will hear their cry, and will save them.

<b>20 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> preserveth all them that love him: but all the wicked will he destroy.

<b>21 </b>My mouth shall speak the praise of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and let all flesh bless his holy name for ever and ever.


--------------------

PSALM 146

<b>1 </b>Praise ye the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. Praise the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, O my soul.

<b>2 </b>While I live will I praise the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: I will sing praises unto my God while I have any being.

<b>3 </b>Put not your trust in princes, <i>nor</i> in the son of man, in whom <i>there is</i> no help.

<b>4 </b>His breath goeth forth, he returneth to his earth; in that very day his thoughts perish.

<b>5 </b>Happy <i>is he</i> that <i>hath</i> the God of Jacob for his help, whose hope <i>is</i> in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his God:

<b>6 </b>Which made heaven, and earth, the sea, and all that therein <i>is:</i> which keepeth truth for ever:

<b>7 </b>Which executeth judgment for the oppressed: which giveth food to the hungry. The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> looseth the prisoners:

<b>8 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> openeth <i>the eyes of</i> the blind: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> raiseth them that are bowed down: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> loveth the righteous:

<b>9 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> preserveth the strangers; he relieveth the fatherless and widow: but the way of the wicked he turneth upside down.

<b>10 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall reign for ever, <i>even</i> thy God, O Zion, unto all generations. Praise ye the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

PSALM 147

<b>1 </b>Praise ye the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for <i>it is</i> good to sing praises unto our God; for <i>it is</i> pleasant; <i>and</i> praise is comely.

<b>2 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> doth build up Jerusalem: he gathereth together the outcasts of Israel.

<b>3 </b>He healeth the broken in heart, and bindeth up their wounds.

<b>4 </b>He telleth the number of the stars; he calleth them all by <i>their</i> names.

<b>5 </b>Great <i>is</i> our Lord, and of great power: his understanding <i>is</i> infinite.

<b>6 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> lifteth up the meek: he casteth the wicked down to the ground.

<b>7 </b>Sing unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with thanksgiving; sing praise upon the harp unto our God:

<b>8 </b>Who covereth the heaven with clouds, who prepareth rain for the earth, who maketh grass to grow upon the mountains.

<b>9 </b>He giveth to the beast his food, <i>and</i> to the young ravens which cry.

<b>10 </b>He delighteth not in the strength of the horse: he taketh not pleasure in the legs of a man.

<b>11 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> taketh pleasure in them that fear him, in those that hope in his mercy.

<b>12 </b>Praise the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, O Jerusalem; praise thy God, O Zion.

<b>13 </b>For he hath strengthened the bars of thy gates; he hath blessed thy children within thee.

<b>14 </b>He maketh peace <i>in</i> thy borders, <i>and</i> filleth thee with the finest of the wheat.

<b>15 </b>He sendeth forth his commandment <i>upon</i> earth: his word runneth very swiftly.

<b>16 </b>He giveth snow like wool: he scattereth the hoarfrost like ashes.

<b>17 </b>He casteth forth his ice like morsels: who can stand before his cold?

<b>18 </b>He sendeth out his word, and melteth them: he causeth his wind to blow, <i>and</i> the waters flow.

<b>19 </b>He sheweth his word unto Jacob, his statutes and his judgments unto Israel.

<b>20 </b>He hath not dealt so with any nation: and <i>as for his</i> judgments, they have not known them. Praise ye the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

PSALM 148

<b>1 </b>Praise ye the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. Praise ye the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> from the heavens: praise him in the heights.

<b>2 </b>Praise ye him, all his angels: praise ye him, all his hosts.

<b>3 </b>Praise ye him, sun and moon: praise him, all ye stars of light.

<b>4 </b>Praise him, ye heavens of heavens, and ye waters that <i>be</i> above the heavens.

<b>5 </b>Let them praise the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for he commanded, and they were created.

<b>6 </b>He hath also stablished them for ever and ever: he hath made a decree which shall not pass.

<b>7 </b>Praise the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> from the earth, ye dragons, and all deeps:

<b>8 </b>Fire, and hail; snow, and vapour; stormy wind fulfilling his word:

<b>9 </b>Mountains, and all hills; fruitful trees, and all cedars:

<b>10 </b>Beasts, and all cattle; creeping things, and flying fowl:

<b>11 </b>Kings of the earth, and all people; princes, and all judges of the earth:

<b>12 </b>Both young men, and maidens; old men, and children:

<b>13 </b>Let them praise the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for his name alone is excellent; his glory <i>is</i> above the earth and heaven.

<b>14 </b>He also exalteth the horn of his people, the praise of all his saints; <i>even</i> of the children of Israel, a people near unto him. Praise ye the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

PSALM 149

<b>1 </b>Praise ye the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. Sing unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> a new song, <i>and</i> his praise in the congregation of saints.

<b>2 </b>Let Israel rejoice in him that made him: let the children of Zion be joyful in their King.

<b>3 </b>Let them praise his name in the dance: let them sing praises unto him with the timbrel and harp.

<b>4 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> taketh pleasure in his people: he will beautify the meek with salvation.

<b>5 </b>Let the saints be joyful in glory: let them sing aloud upon their beds.

<b>6 </b><i>Let</i> the high <i>praises</i> of God <i>be</i> in their mouth, and a twoedged sword in their hand;

<b>7 </b>To execute vengeance upon the heathen, <i>and</i> punishments upon the people;

<b>8 </b>To bind their kings with chains, and their nobles with fetters of iron;

<b>9 </b>To execute upon them the judgment written: this honour have all his saints. Praise ye the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

PSALM 150

<b>1 </b>Praise ye the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. Praise God in his sanctuary: praise him in the firmament of his power.

<b>2 </b>Praise him for his mighty acts: praise him according to his excellent greatness.

<b>3 </b>Praise him with the sound of the trumpet: praise him with the psaltery and harp.

<b>4 </b>Praise him with the timbrel and dance: praise him with stringed instruments and organs.

<b>5 </b>Praise him upon the loud cymbals: praise him upon the high sounding cymbals.

<b>6 </b>Let every thing that hath breath praise the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. Praise ye the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

The Proverbs

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>The proverbs of Solomon the son of David, king of Israel;

<b>2 </b>To know wisdom and instruction; to perceive the words of understanding;

<b>3 </b>To receive the instruction of wisdom, justice, and judgment, and equity;

<b>4 </b>To give subtilty to the simple, to the young man knowledge and discretion.

<b>5 </b>A wise <i>man</i> will hear, and will increase learning; and a man of understanding shall attain unto wise counsels:

<b>6 </b>To understand a proverb, and the interpretation; the words of the wise, and their dark sayings.

<b>7 </b>¶ The fear of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> the beginning of knowledge: <i>but</i> fools despise wisdom and instruction.

<b>8 </b>My son, hear the instruction of thy father, and forsake not the law of thy mother:

<b>9 </b>For they <i>shall be</i> an ornament of grace unto thy head, and chains about thy neck.

<b>10 </b>¶ My son, if sinners entice thee, consent thou not.

<b>11 </b>If they say, Come with us, let us lay wait for blood, let us lurk privily for the innocent without cause:

<b>12 </b>Let us swallow them up alive as the grave; and whole, as those that go down into the pit:

<b>13 </b>We shall find all precious substance, we shall fill our houses with spoil:

<b>14 </b>Cast in thy lot among us; let us all have one purse:

<b>15 </b>My son, walk not thou in the way with them; refrain thy foot from their path:

<b>16 </b>For their feet run to evil, and make haste to shed blood.

<b>17 </b>Surely in vain the net is spread in the sight of any bird.

<b>18 </b>And they lay wait for their <i>own</i> blood; they lurk privily for their <i>own</i> lives.

<b>19 </b>So <i>are</i> the ways of every one that is greedy of gain; <i>which</i> taketh away the life of the owners thereof.

<b>20 </b>¶ Wisdom crieth without; she uttereth her voice in the streets:

<b>21 </b>She crieth in the chief place of concourse, in the openings of the gates: in the city she uttereth her words, <i>saying,</i>

<b>22 </b>How long, ye simple ones, will ye love simplicity? and the scorners delight in their scorning, and fools hate knowledge?

<b>23 </b>Turn you at my reproof: behold, I will pour out my spirit unto you, I will make known my words unto you.

<b>24 </b>¶ Because I have called, and ye refused; I have stretched out my hand, and no man regarded;

<b>25 </b>But ye have set at nought all my counsel, and would none of my reproof:

<b>26 </b>I also will laugh at your calamity; I will mock when your fear cometh;

<b>27 </b>When your fear cometh as desolation, and your destruction cometh as a whirlwind; when distress and anguish cometh upon you.

<b>28 </b>Then shall they call upon me, but I will not answer; they shall seek me early, but they shall not find me:

<b>29 </b>For that they hated knowledge, and did not choose the fear of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>:

<b>30 </b>They would none of my counsel: they despised all my reproof.

<b>31 </b>Therefore shall they eat of the fruit of their own way, and be filled with their own devices.

<b>32 </b>For the turning away of the simple shall slay them, and the prosperity of fools shall destroy them.

<b>33 </b>But whoso hearkeneth unto me shall dwell safely, and shall be quiet from fear of evil.


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>My son, if thou wilt receive my words, and hide my commandments with thee;

<b>2 </b>So that thou incline thine ear unto wisdom, <i>and</i> apply thine heart to understanding;

<b>3 </b>Yea, if thou criest after knowledge, <i>and</i> liftest up thy voice for understanding;

<b>4 </b>If thou seekest her as silver, and searchest for her as <i>for</i> hid treasures;

<b>5 </b>Then shalt thou understand the fear of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and find the knowledge of God.

<b>6 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> giveth wisdom: out of his mouth <i>cometh</i> knowledge and understanding.

<b>7 </b>He layeth up sound wisdom for the righteous: <i>he is</i> a buckler to them that walk uprightly.

<b>8 </b>He keepeth the paths of judgment, and preserveth the way of his saints.

<b>9 </b>Then shalt thou understand righteousness, and judgment, and equity; <i>yea,</i> every good path.

<b>10 </b>¶ When wisdom entereth into thine heart, and knowledge is pleasant unto thy soul;

<b>11 </b>Discretion shall preserve thee, understanding shall keep thee:

<b>12 </b>To deliver thee from the way of the evil <i>man,</i> from the man that speaketh froward things;

<b>13 </b>Who leave the paths of uprightness, to walk in the ways of darkness;

<b>14 </b>Who rejoice to do evil, <i>and</i> delight in the frowardness of the wicked;

<b>15 </b>Whose ways <i>are</i> crooked, and <i>they</i> froward in their paths:

<b>16 </b>To deliver thee from the strange woman, <i>even</i> from the stranger <i>which</i> flattereth with her words;

<b>17 </b>Which forsaketh the guide of her youth, and forgetteth the covenant of her God.

<b>18 </b>For her house inclineth unto death, and her paths unto the dead.

<b>19 </b>None that go unto her return again, neither take they hold of the paths of life.

<b>20 </b>That thou mayest walk in the way of good <i>men,</i> and keep the paths of the righteous.

<b>21 </b>For the upright shall dwell in the land, and the perfect shall remain in it.

<b>22 </b>But the wicked shall be cut off from the earth, and the transgressors shall be rooted out of it.


--------------------

CHAPTER 3

<b>1 </b>My son, forget not my law; but let thine heart keep my commandments:

<b>2 </b>For length of days, and long life, and peace, shall they add to thee.

<b>3 </b>Let not mercy and truth forsake thee: bind them about thy neck; write them upon the table of thine heart:

<b>4 </b>So shalt thou find favour and good understanding in the sight of God and man.

<b>5 </b>¶ Trust in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with all thine heart; and lean not unto thine own understanding.

<b>6 </b>In all thy ways acknowledge him, and he shall direct thy paths.

<b>7 </b>¶ Be not wise in thine own eyes: fear the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and depart from evil.

<b>8 </b>It shall be health to thy navel, and marrow to thy bones.

<b>9 </b>Honour the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with thy substance, and with the firstfruits of all thine increase:

<b>10 </b>So shall thy barns be filled with plenty, and thy presses shall burst out with new wine.

<b>11 </b>¶ My son, despise not the chastening of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; neither be weary of his correction:

<b>12 </b>For whom the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> loveth he correcteth; even as a father the son <i>in whom</i> he delighteth.

<b>13 </b>¶ Happy <i>is</i> the man <i>that</i> findeth wisdom, and the man <i>that</i> getteth understanding.

<b>14 </b>For the merchandise of it <i>is</i> better than the merchandise of silver, and the gain thereof than fine gold.

<b>15 </b>She <i>is</i> more precious than rubies: and all the things thou canst desire are not to be compared unto her.

<b>16 </b>Length of days <i>is</i> in her right hand; <i>and</i> in her left hand riches and honour.

<b>17 </b>Her ways <i>are</i> ways of pleasantness, and all her paths <i>are</i> peace.

<b>18 </b>She <i>is</i> a tree of life to them that lay hold upon her: and happy <i>is every one</i> that retaineth her.

<b>19 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> by wisdom hath founded the earth; by understanding hath he established the heavens.

<b>20 </b>By his knowledge the depths are broken up, and the clouds drop down the dew.

<b>21 </b>¶ My son, let not them depart from thine eyes: keep sound wisdom and discretion:

<b>22 </b>So shall they be life unto thy soul, and grace to thy neck.

<b>23 </b>Then shalt thou walk in thy way safely, and thy foot shall not stumble.

<b>24 </b>When thou liest down, thou shalt not be afraid: yea, thou shalt lie down, and thy sleep shall be sweet.

<b>25 </b>Be not afraid of sudden fear, neither of the desolation of the wicked, when it cometh.

<b>26 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall be thy confidence, and shall keep thy foot from being taken.

<b>27 </b>¶ Withhold not good from them to whom it is due, when it is in the power of thine hand to do <i>it.</i>

<b>28 </b>Say not unto thy neighbour, Go, and come again, and to morrow I will give; when thou hast it by thee.

<b>29 </b>Devise not evil against thy neighbour, seeing he dwelleth securely by thee.

<b>30 </b>¶ Strive not with a man without cause, if he have done thee no harm.

<b>31 </b>¶ Envy thou not the oppressor, and choose none of his ways.

<b>32 </b>For the froward <i>is</i> abomination to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: but his secret <i>is</i> with the righteous.

<b>33 </b>¶ The curse of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> in the house of the wicked: but he blesseth the habitation of the just.

<b>34 </b>Surely he scorneth the scorners: but he giveth grace unto the lowly.

<b>35 </b>The wise shall inherit glory: but shame shall be the promotion of fools.


--------------------

CHAPTER 4

<b>1 </b>Hear, ye children, the instruction of a father, and attend to know understanding.

<b>2 </b>For I give you good doctrine, forsake ye not my law.

<b>3 </b>For I was my father’s son, tender and only <i>beloved</i> in the sight of my mother.

<b>4 </b>He taught me also, and said unto me, Let thine heart retain my words: keep my commandments, and live.

<b>5 </b>Get wisdom, get understanding: forget <i>it</i> not; neither decline from the words of my mouth.

<b>6 </b>Forsake her not, and she shall preserve thee: love her, and she shall keep thee.

<b>7 </b>Wisdom <i>is</i> the principal thing; <i>therefore</i> get wisdom: and with all thy getting get understanding.

<b>8 </b>Exalt her, and she shall promote thee: she shall bring thee to honour, when thou dost embrace her.

<b>9 </b>She shall give to thine head an ornament of grace: a crown of glory shall she deliver to thee.

<b>10 </b>Hear, O my son, and receive my sayings; and the years of thy life shall be many.

<b>11 </b>I have taught thee in the way of wisdom; I have led thee in right paths.

<b>12 </b>When thou goest, thy steps shall not be straitened; and when thou runnest, thou shalt not stumble.

<b>13 </b>Take fast hold of instruction; let <i>her</i> not go: keep her; for she <i>is</i> thy life.

<b>14 </b>¶ Enter not into the path of the wicked, and go not in the way of evil <i>men.</i>

<b>15 </b>Avoid it, pass not by it, turn from it, and pass away.

<b>16 </b>For they sleep not, except they have done mischief; and their sleep is taken away, unless they cause <i>some</i> to fall.

<b>17 </b>For they eat the bread of wickedness, and drink the wine of violence.

<b>18 </b>But the path of the just <i>is</i> as the shining light, that shineth more and more unto the perfect day.

<b>19 </b>The way of the wicked <i>is</i> as darkness: they know not at what they stumble.

<b>20 </b>¶ My son, attend to my words; incline thine ear unto my sayings.

<b>21 </b>Let them not depart from thine eyes; keep them in the midst of thine heart.

<b>22 </b>For they <i>are</i> life unto those that find them, and health to all their flesh.

<b>23 </b>¶ Keep thy heart with all diligence; for out of it <i>are</i> the issues of life.

<b>24 </b>Put away from thee a froward mouth, and perverse lips put far from thee.

<b>25 </b>Let thine eyes look right on, and let thine eyelids look straight before thee.

<b>26 </b>Ponder the path of thy feet, and let all thy ways be established.

<b>27 </b>Turn not to the right hand nor to the left: remove thy foot from evil.


--------------------

CHAPTER 5

<b>1 </b>My son, attend unto my wisdom, <i>and</i> bow thine ear to my understanding:

<b>2 </b>That thou mayest regard discretion, and <i>that</i> thy lips may keep knowledge.

<b>3 </b>¶ For the lips of a strange woman drop <i>as</i> an honeycomb, and her mouth <i>is</i> smoother than oil:

<b>4 </b>But her end is bitter as wormwood, sharp as a twoedged sword.

<b>5 </b>Her feet go down to death; her steps take hold on hell.

<b>6 </b>Lest thou shouldest ponder the path of life, her ways are moveable, <i>that</i> thou canst not know <i>them.</i>

<b>7 </b>Hear me now therefore, O ye children, and depart not from the words of my mouth.

<b>8 </b>Remove thy way far from her, and come not nigh the door of her house:

<b>9 </b>Lest thou give thine honour unto others, and thy years unto the cruel:

<b>10 </b>Lest strangers be filled with thy wealth; and thy labours <i>be</i> in the house of a stranger;

<b>11 </b>And thou mourn at the last, when thy flesh and thy body are consumed,

<b>12 </b>And say, How have I hated instruction, and my heart despised reproof;

<b>13 </b>And have not obeyed the voice of my teachers, nor inclined mine ear to them that instructed me!

<b>14 </b>I was almost in all evil in the midst of the congregation and assembly.

<b>15 </b>¶ Drink waters out of thine own cistern, and running waters out of thine own well.

<b>16 </b>Let thy fountains be dispersed abroad, <i>and</i> rivers of waters in the streets.

<b>17 </b>Let them be only thine own, and not strangers’ with thee.

<b>18 </b>Let thy fountain be blessed: and rejoice with the wife of thy youth.

<b>19 </b><i>Let her be as</i> the loving hind and pleasant roe; let her breasts satisfy thee at all times; and be thou ravished always with her love.

<b>20 </b>And why wilt thou, my son, be ravished with a strange woman, and embrace the bosom of a stranger?

<b>21 </b>For the ways of man <i>are</i> before the eyes of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and he pondereth all his goings.

<b>22 </b>¶ His own iniquities shall take the wicked himself, and he shall be holden with the cords of his sins.

<b>23 </b>He shall die without instruction; and in the greatness of his folly he shall go astray.


--------------------

CHAPTER 6

<b>1 </b>My son, if thou be surety for thy friend, <i>if</i> thou hast stricken thy hand with a stranger,

<b>2 </b>Thou art snared with the words of thy mouth, thou art taken with the words of thy mouth.

<b>3 </b>Do this now, my son, and deliver thyself, when thou art come into the hand of thy friend; go, humble thyself, and make sure thy friend.

<b>4 </b>Give not sleep to thine eyes, nor slumber to thine eyelids.

<b>5 </b>Deliver thyself as a roe from the hand <i>of the hunter,</i> and as a bird from the hand of the fowler.

<b>6 </b>¶ Go to the ant, thou sluggard; consider her ways, and be wise:

<b>7 </b>Which having no guide, overseer, or ruler,

<b>8 </b>Provideth her meat in the summer, <i>and</i> gathereth her food in the harvest.

<b>9 </b>How long wilt thou sleep, O sluggard? when wilt thou arise out of thy sleep?

<b>10 </b><i>Yet</i> a little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to sleep:

<b>11 </b>So shall thy poverty come as one that travelleth, and thy want as an armed man.

<b>12 </b>¶ A naughty person, a wicked man, walketh with a froward mouth.

<b>13 </b>He winketh with his eyes, he speaketh with his feet, he teacheth with his fingers;

<b>14 </b>Frowardness <i>is</i> in his heart, he deviseth mischief continually; he soweth discord.

<b>15 </b>Therefore shall his calamity come suddenly; suddenly shall he be broken without remedy.

<b>16 </b>¶ These six <i>things</i> doth the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hate: yea, seven <i>are</i> an abomination unto him:

<b>17 </b>A proud look, a lying tongue, and hands that shed innocent blood,

<b>18 </b>An heart that deviseth wicked imaginations, feet that be swift in running to mischief,

<b>19 </b>A false witness <i>that</i> speaketh lies, and he that soweth discord among brethren.

<b>20 </b>¶ My son, keep thy father’s commandment, and forsake not the law of thy mother:

<b>21 </b>Bind them continually upon thine heart, <i>and</i> tie them about thy neck.

<b>22 </b>When thou goest, it shall lead thee; when thou sleepest, it shall keep thee; and <i>when</i> thou awakest, it shall talk with thee.

<b>23 </b>For the commandment <i>is</i> a lamp; and the law <i>is</i> light; and reproofs of instruction <i>are</i> the way of life:

<b>24 </b>To keep thee from the evil woman, from the flattery of the tongue of a strange woman.

<b>25 </b>Lust not after her beauty in thine heart; neither let her take thee with her eyelids.

<b>26 </b>For by means of a whorish woman <i>a man is brought</i> to a piece of bread: and the adulteress will hunt for the precious life.

<b>27 </b>Can a man take fire in his bosom, and his clothes not be burned?

<b>28 </b>Can one go upon hot coals, and his feet not be burned?

<b>29 </b>So he that goeth in to his neighbour’s wife; whosoever toucheth her shall not be innocent.

<b>30 </b><i>Men</i> do not despise a thief, if he steal to satisfy his soul when he is hungry;

<b>31 </b>But <i>if</i> he be found, he shall restore sevenfold; he shall give all the substance of his house.

<b>32 </b><i>But</i> whoso committeth adultery with a woman lacketh understanding: he <i>that</i> doeth it destroyeth his own soul.

<b>33 </b>A wound and dishonour shall he get; and his reproach shall not be wiped away.

<b>34 </b>For jealousy <i>is</i> the rage of a man: therefore he will not spare in the day of vengeance.

<b>35 </b>He will not regard any ransom; neither will he rest content, though thou givest many gifts.


--------------------

CHAPTER 7

<b>1 </b>My son, keep my words, and lay up my commandments with thee.

<b>2 </b>Keep my commandments, and live; and my law as the apple of thine eye.

<b>3 </b>Bind them upon thy fingers, write them upon the table of thine heart.

<b>4 </b>Say unto wisdom, Thou <i>art</i> my sister; and call understanding <i>thy</i> kinswoman:

<b>5 </b>That they may keep thee from the strange woman, from the stranger <i>which</i> flattereth with her words.

<b>6 </b>¶ For at the window of my house I looked through my casement,

<b>7 </b>And beheld among the simple ones, I discerned among the youths, a young man void of understanding,

<b>8 </b>Passing through the street near her corner; and he went the way to her house,

<b>9 </b>In the twilight, in the evening, in the black and dark night:

<b>10 </b>And, behold, there met him a woman <i>with</i> the attire of an harlot, and subtil of heart.

<b>11 </b>(She <i>is</i> loud and stubborn; her feet abide not in her house:

<b>12 </b>Now <i>is she</i> without, now in the streets, and lieth in wait at every corner.)

<b>13 </b>So she caught him, and kissed him, <i>and</i> with an impudent face said unto him,

<b>14 </b><i>I have</i> peace offerings with me; this day have I payed my vows.

<b>15 </b>Therefore came I forth to meet thee, diligently to seek thy face, and I have found thee.

<b>16 </b>I have decked my bed with coverings of tapestry, with carved <i>works,</i> with fine linen of Egypt.

<b>17 </b>I have perfumed my bed with myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon.

<b>18 </b>Come, let us take our fill of love until the morning: let us solace ourselves with loves.

<b>19 </b>For the goodman <i>is</i> not at home, he is gone a long journey:

<b>20 </b>He hath taken a bag of money with him, <i>and</i> will come home at the day appointed.

<b>21 </b>With her much fair speech she caused him to yield, with the flattering of her lips she forced him.

<b>22 </b>He goeth after her straightway, as an ox goeth to the slaughter, or as a fool to the correction of the stocks;

<b>23 </b>Till a dart strike through his liver; as a bird hasteth to the snare, and knoweth not that it <i>is</i> for his life.

<b>24 </b>¶ Hearken unto me now therefore, O ye children, and attend to the words of my mouth.

<b>25 </b>Let not thine heart decline to her ways, go not astray in her paths.

<b>26 </b>For she hath cast down many wounded: yea, many strong <i>men</i> have been slain by her.

<b>27 </b>Her house <i>is</i> the way to hell, going down to the chambers of death.


--------------------

CHAPTER 8

<b>1 </b>Doth not wisdom cry? and understanding put forth her voice?

<b>2 </b>She standeth in the top of high places, by the way in the places of the paths.

<b>3 </b>She crieth at the gates, at the entry of the city, at the coming in at the doors.

<b>4 </b>Unto you, O men, I call; and my voice <i>is</i> to the sons of man.

<b>5 </b>O ye simple, understand wisdom: and, ye fools, be ye of an understanding heart.

<b>6 </b>Hear; for I will speak of excellent things; and the opening of my lips <i>shall be</i> right things.

<b>7 </b>For my mouth shall speak truth; and wickedness <i>is</i> an abomination to my lips.

<b>8 </b>All the words of my mouth <i>are</i> in righteousness; <i>there is</i> nothing froward or perverse in them.

<b>9 </b>They <i>are</i> all plain to him that understandeth, and right to them that find knowledge.

<b>10 </b>Receive my instruction, and not silver; and knowledge rather than choice gold.

<b>11 </b>For wisdom <i>is</i> better than rubies; and all the things that may be desired are not to be compared to it.

<b>12 </b>I wisdom dwell with prudence, and find out knowledge of witty inventions.

<b>13 </b>The fear of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> to hate evil: pride, and arrogancy, and the evil way, and the froward mouth, do I hate.

<b>14 </b>Counsel <i>is</i> mine, and sound wisdom: I <i>am</i> understanding; I have strength.

<b>15 </b>By me kings reign, and princes decree justice.

<b>16 </b>By me princes rule, and nobles, <i>even</i> all the judges of the earth.

<b>17 </b>I love them that love me; and those that seek me early shall find me.

<b>18 </b>Riches and honour <i>are</i> with me; <i>yea,</i> durable riches and righteousness.

<b>19 </b>My fruit <i>is</i> better than gold, yea, than fine gold; and my revenue than choice silver.

<b>20 </b>I lead in the way of righteousness, in the midst of the paths of judgment:

<b>21 </b>That I may cause those that love me to inherit substance; and I will fill their treasures.

<b>22 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> possessed me in the beginning of his way, before his works of old.

<b>23 </b>I was set up from everlasting, from the beginning, or ever the earth was.

<b>24 </b>When <i>there were</i> no depths, I was brought forth; when <i>there were</i> no fountains abounding with water.

<b>25 </b>Before the mountains were settled, before the hills was I brought forth:

<b>26 </b>While as yet he had not made the earth, nor the fields, nor the highest part of the dust of the world.

<b>27 </b>When he prepared the heavens, I <i>was</i> there: when he set a compass upon the face of the depth:

<b>28 </b>When he established the clouds above: when he strengthened the fountains of the deep:

<b>29 </b>When he gave to the sea his decree, that the waters should not pass his commandment: when he appointed the foundations of the earth:

<b>30 </b>Then I was by him, <i>as</i> one brought up <i>with him:</i> and I was daily <i>his</i> delight, rejoicing always before him;

<b>31 </b>Rejoicing in the habitable part of his earth; and my delights <i>were</i> with the sons of men.

<b>32 </b>Now therefore hearken unto me, O ye children: for blessed <i>are they that</i> keep my ways.

<b>33 </b>Hear instruction, and be wise, and refuse it not.

<b>34 </b>Blessed <i>is</i> the man that heareth me, watching daily at my gates, waiting at the posts of my doors.

<b>35 </b>For whoso findeth me findeth life, and shall obtain favour of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>36 </b>But he that sinneth against me wrongeth his own soul: all they that hate me love death.


--------------------

CHAPTER 9

<b>1 </b>Wisdom hath builded her house, she hath hewn out her seven pillars:

<b>2 </b>She hath killed her beasts; she hath mingled her wine; she hath also furnished her table.

<b>3 </b>She hath sent forth her maidens: she crieth upon the highest places of the city,

<b>4 </b>Whoso <i>is</i> simple, let him turn in hither: <i>as for</i> him that wanteth understanding, she saith to him,

<b>5 </b>Come, eat of my bread, and drink of the wine <i>which</i> I have mingled.

<b>6 </b>Forsake the foolish, and live; and go in the way of understanding.

<b>7 </b>He that reproveth a scorner getteth to himself shame: and he that rebuketh a wicked <i>man getteth</i> himself a blot.

<b>8 </b>Reprove not a scorner, lest he hate thee: rebuke a wise man, and he will love thee.

<b>9 </b>Give <i>instruction</i> to a wise <i>man,</i> and he will be yet wiser: teach a just <i>man,</i> and he will increase in learning.

<b>10 </b>The fear of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> the beginning of wisdom: and the knowledge of the holy <i>is</i> understanding.

<b>11 </b>For by me thy days shall be multiplied, and the years of thy life shall be increased.

<b>12 </b>If thou be wise, thou shalt be wise for thyself: but <i>if</i> thou scornest, thou alone shalt bear <i>it.</i>

<b>13 </b>¶ A foolish woman <i>is</i> clamorous: <i>she is</i> simple, and knoweth nothing.

<b>14 </b>For she sitteth at the door of her house, on a seat in the high places of the city,

<b>15 </b>To call passengers who go right on their ways:

<b>16 </b>Whoso <i>is</i> simple, let him turn in hither: and <i>as for</i> him that wanteth understanding, she saith to him,

<b>17 </b>Stolen waters are sweet, and bread <i>eaten</i> in secret is pleasant.

<b>18 </b>But he knoweth not that the dead <i>are</i> there; <i>and that</i> her guests <i>are</i> in the depths of hell.


--------------------

CHAPTER 10

<b>1 </b>The proverbs of Solomon. A wise son maketh a glad father: but a foolish son <i>is</i> the heaviness of his mother.

<b>2 </b>Treasures of wickedness profit nothing: but righteousness delivereth from death.

<b>3 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will not suffer the soul of the righteous to famish: but he casteth away the substance of the wicked.

<b>4 </b>He becometh poor that dealeth <i>with</i> a slack hand: but the hand of the diligent maketh rich.

<b>5 </b>He that gathereth in summer <i>is</i> a wise son: <i>but</i> he that sleepeth in harvest <i>is</i> a son that causeth shame.

<b>6 </b>Blessings <i>are</i> upon the head of the just: but violence covereth the mouth of the wicked.

<b>7 </b>The memory of the just <i>is</i> blessed: but the name of the wicked shall rot.

<b>8 </b>The wise in heart will receive commandments: but a prating fool shall fall.

<b>9 </b>He that walketh uprightly walketh surely: but he that perverteth his ways shall be known.

<b>10 </b>He that winketh with the eye causeth sorrow: but a prating fool shall fall.

<b>11 </b>The mouth of a righteous <i>man is</i> a well of life: but violence covereth the mouth of the wicked.

<b>12 </b>Hatred stirreth up strifes: but love covereth all sins.

<b>13 </b>In the lips of him that hath understanding wisdom is found: but a rod <i>is</i> for the back of him that is void of understanding.

<b>14 </b>Wise <i>men</i> lay up knowledge: but the mouth of the foolish <i>is</i> near destruction.

<b>15 </b>The rich man’s wealth <i>is</i> his strong city: the destruction of the poor <i>is</i> their poverty.

<b>16 </b>The labour of the righteous <i>tendeth</i> to life: the fruit of the wicked to sin.

<b>17 </b>He <i>is in</i> the way of life that keepeth instruction: but he that refuseth reproof erreth.

<b>18 </b>He that hideth hatred <i>with</i> lying lips, and he that uttereth a slander, <i>is</i> a fool.

<b>19 </b>In the multitude of words there wanteth not sin: but he that refraineth his lips <i>is</i> wise.

<b>20 </b>The tongue of the just <i>is as</i> choice silver: the heart of the wicked <i>is</i> little worth.

<b>21 </b>The lips of the righteous feed many: but fools die for want of wisdom.

<b>22 </b>The blessing of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, it maketh rich, and he addeth no sorrow with it.

<b>23 </b><i>It is</i> as sport to a fool to do mischief: but a man of understanding hath wisdom.

<b>24 </b>The fear of the wicked, it shall come upon him: but the desire of the righteous shall be granted.

<b>25 </b>As the whirlwind passeth, so <i>is</i> the wicked no <i>more:</i> but the righteous <i>is</i> an everlasting foundation.

<b>26 </b>As vinegar to the teeth, and as smoke to the eyes, so <i>is</i> the sluggard to them that send him.

<b>27 </b>The fear of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> prolongeth days: but the years of the wicked shall be shortened.

<b>28 </b>The hope of the righteous <i>shall be</i> gladness: but the expectation of the wicked shall perish.

<b>29 </b>The way of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> strength to the upright: but destruction <i>shall be</i> to the workers of iniquity.

<b>30 </b>The righteous shall never be removed: but the wicked shall not inhabit the earth.

<b>31 </b>The mouth of the just bringeth forth wisdom: but the froward tongue shall be cut out.

<b>32 </b>The lips of the righteous know what is acceptable: but the mouth of the wicked <i>speaketh</i> frowardness.


--------------------

CHAPTER 11

<b>1 </b>A false balance <i>is</i> abomination to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: but a just weight <i>is</i> his delight.

<b>2 </b><i>When</i> pride cometh, then cometh shame: but with the lowly <i>is</i> wisdom.

<b>3 </b>The integrity of the upright shall guide them: but the perverseness of transgressors shall destroy them.

<b>4 </b>Riches profit not in the day of wrath: but righteousness delivereth from death.

<b>5 </b>The righteousness of the perfect shall direct his way: but the wicked shall fall by his own wickedness.

<b>6 </b>The righteousness of the upright shall deliver them: but transgressors shall be taken in <i>their own</i> naughtiness.

<b>7 </b>When a wicked man dieth, <i>his</i> expectation shall perish: and the hope of unjust <i>men</i> perisheth.

<b>8 </b>The righteous is delivered out of trouble, and the wicked cometh in his stead.

<b>9 </b>An hypocrite with <i>his</i> mouth destroyeth his neighbour: but through knowledge shall the just be delivered.

<b>10 </b>When it goeth well with the righteous, the city rejoiceth: and when the wicked perish, <i>there is</i> shouting.

<b>11 </b>By the blessing of the upright the city is exalted: but it is overthrown by the mouth of the wicked.

<b>12 </b>He that is void of wisdom despiseth his neighbour: but a man of understanding holdeth his peace.

<b>13 </b>A talebearer revealeth secrets: but he that is of a faithful spirit concealeth the matter.

<b>14 </b>Where no counsel <i>is,</i> the people fall: but in the multitude of counsellors <i>there is</i> safety.

<b>15 </b>He that is surety for a stranger shall smart <i>for it:</i> and he that hateth suretiship is sure.

<b>16 </b>A gracious woman retaineth honour: and strong <i>men</i> retain riches.

<b>17 </b>The merciful man doeth good to his own soul: but <i>he that is</i> cruel troubleth his own flesh.

<b>18 </b>The wicked worketh a deceitful work: but to him that soweth righteousness <i>shall be</i> a sure reward.

<b>19 </b>As righteousness <i>tendeth</i> to life: so he that pursueth evil <i>pursueth it</i> to his own death.

<b>20 </b>They that are of a froward heart <i>are</i> abomination to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: but <i>such as are</i> upright in <i>their</i> way <i>are</i> his delight.

<b>21 </b><i>Though</i> hand <i>join</i> in hand, the wicked shall not be unpunished: but the seed of the righteous shall be delivered.

<b>22 </b><i>As</i> a jewel of gold in a swine’s snout, <i>so is</i> a fair woman which is without discretion.

<b>23 </b>The desire of the righteous <i>is</i> only good: <i>but</i> the expectation of the wicked <i>is</i> wrath.

<b>24 </b>There is that scattereth, and yet increaseth; and <i>there is</i> that withholdeth more than is meet, but <i>it tendeth</i> to poverty.

<b>25 </b>The liberal soul shall be made fat: and he that watereth shall be watered also himself.

<b>26 </b>He that withholdeth corn, the people shall curse him: but blessing <i>shall be</i> upon the head of him that selleth <i>it.</i>

<b>27 </b>He that diligently seeketh good procureth favour: but he that seeketh mischief, it shall come unto him.

<b>28 </b>He that trusteth in his riches shall fall: but the righteous shall flourish as a branch.

<b>29 </b>He that troubleth his own house shall inherit the wind: and the fool <i>shall be</i> servant to the wise of heart.

<b>30 </b>The fruit of the righteous <i>is</i> a tree of life; and he that winneth souls <i>is</i> wise.

<b>31 </b>Behold, the righteous shall be recompensed in the earth: much more the wicked and the sinner.


--------------------

CHAPTER 12

<b>1 </b>Whoso loveth instruction loveth knowledge: but he that hateth reproof <i>is</i> brutish.

<b>2 </b>A good <i>man</i> obtaineth favour of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: but a man of wicked devices will he condemn.

<b>3 </b>A man shall not be established by wickedness: but the root of the righteous shall not be moved.

<b>4 </b>A virtuous woman <i>is</i> a crown to her husband: but she that maketh ashamed <i>is</i> as rottenness in his bones.

<b>5 </b>The thoughts of the righteous <i>are</i> right: <i>but</i> the counsels of the wicked <i>are</i> deceit.

<b>6 </b>The words of the wicked <i>are</i> to lie in wait for blood: but the mouth of the upright shall deliver them.

<b>7 </b>The wicked are overthrown, and <i>are</i> not: but the house of the righteous shall stand.

<b>8 </b>A man shall be commended according to his wisdom: but he that is of a perverse heart shall be despised.

<b>9 </b><i>He that is</i> despised, and hath a servant, <i>is</i> better than he that honoureth himself, and lacketh bread.

<b>10 </b>A righteous <i>man</i> regardeth the life of his beast: but the tender mercies of the wicked <i>are</i> cruel.

<b>11 </b>He that tilleth his land shall be satisfied with bread: but he that followeth vain <i>persons is</i> void of understanding.

<b>12 </b>The wicked desireth the net of evil <i>men:</i> but the root of the righteous yieldeth <i>fruit.</i>

<b>13 </b>The wicked is snared by the transgression of <i>his</i> lips: but the just shall come out of trouble.

<b>14 </b>A man shall be satisfied with good by the fruit of <i>his</i> mouth: and the recompence of a man’s hands shall be rendered unto him.

<b>15 </b>The way of a fool <i>is</i> right in his own eyes: but he that hearkeneth unto counsel <i>is</i> wise.

<b>16 </b>A fool’s wrath is presently known: but a prudent <i>man</i> covereth shame.

<b>17 </b><i>He that</i> speaketh truth sheweth forth righteousness: but a false witness deceit.

<b>18 </b>There is that speaketh like the piercings of a sword: but the tongue of the wise <i>is</i> health.

<b>19 </b>The lip of truth shall be established for ever: but a lying tongue <i>is</i> but for a moment.

<b>20 </b>Deceit <i>is</i> in the heart of them that imagine evil: but to the counsellors of peace <i>is</i> joy.

<b>21 </b>There shall no evil happen to the just: but the wicked shall be filled with mischief.

<b>22 </b>Lying lips <i>are</i> abomination to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: but they that deal truly <i>are</i> his delight.

<b>23 </b>A prudent man concealeth knowledge: but the heart of fools proclaimeth foolishness.

<b>24 </b>The hand of the diligent shall bear rule: but the slothful shall be under tribute.

<b>25 </b>Heaviness in the heart of man maketh it stoop: but a good word maketh it glad.

<b>26 </b>The righteous <i>is</i> more excellent than his neighbour: but the way of the wicked seduceth them.

<b>27 </b>The slothful <i>man</i> roasteth not that which he took in hunting: but the substance of a diligent man <i>is</i> precious.

<b>28 </b>In the way of righteousness <i>is</i> life; and <i>in</i> the pathway <i>thereof there is</i> no death.


--------------------

CHAPTER 13

<b>1 </b>A wise son <i>heareth</i> his father’s instruction: but a scorner heareth not rebuke.

<b>2 </b>A man shall eat good by the fruit of <i>his</i> mouth: but the soul of the transgressors <i>shall eat</i> violence.

<b>3 </b>He that keepeth his mouth keepeth his life: <i>but</i> he that openeth wide his lips shall have destruction.

<b>4 </b>The soul of the sluggard desireth, and <i>hath</i> nothing: but the soul of the diligent shall be made fat.

<b>5 </b>A righteous <i>man</i> hateth lying: but a wicked <i>man</i> is loathsome, and cometh to shame.

<b>6 </b>Righteousness keepeth <i>him that is</i> upright in the way: but wickedness overthroweth the sinner.

<b>7 </b>There is that maketh himself rich, yet <i>hath</i> nothing: <i>there is</i> that maketh himself poor, yet <i>hath</i> great riches.

<b>8 </b>The ransom of a man’s life <i>are</i> his riches: but the poor heareth not rebuke.

<b>9 </b>The light of the righteous rejoiceth: but the lamp of the wicked shall be put out.

<b>10 </b>Only by pride cometh contention: but with the well advised <i>is</i> wisdom.

<b>11 </b>Wealth <i>gotten</i> by vanity shall be diminished: but he that gathereth by labour shall increase.

<b>12 </b>Hope deferred maketh the heart sick: but <i>when</i> the desire cometh, <i>it is</i> a tree of life.

<b>13 </b>Whoso despiseth the word shall be destroyed: but he that feareth the commandment shall be rewarded.

<b>14 </b>The law of the wise <i>is</i> a fountain of life, to depart from the snares of death.

<b>15 </b>Good understanding giveth favour: but the way of transgressors <i>is</i> hard.

<b>16 </b>Every prudent <i>man</i> dealeth with knowledge: but a fool layeth open <i>his</i> folly.

<b>17 </b>A wicked messenger falleth into mischief: but a faithful ambassador <i>is</i> health.

<b>18 </b>Poverty and shame <i>shall be to</i> him that refuseth instruction: but he that regardeth reproof shall be honoured.

<b>19 </b>The desire accomplished is sweet to the soul: but <i>it is</i> abomination to fools to depart from evil.

<b>20 </b>He that walketh with wise <i>men</i> shall be wise: but a companion of fools shall be destroyed.

<b>21 </b>Evil pursueth sinners: but to the righteous good shall be repayed.

<b>22 </b>A good <i>man</i> leaveth an inheritance to his children’s children: and the wealth of the sinner <i>is</i> laid up for the just.

<b>23 </b>Much food <i>is in</i> the tillage of the poor: but there is <i>that is</i> destroyed for want of judgment.

<b>24 </b>He that spareth his rod hateth his son: but he that loveth him chasteneth him betimes.

<b>25 </b>The righteous eateth to the satisfying of his soul: but the belly of the wicked shall want.


--------------------

CHAPTER 14

<b>1 </b>Every wise woman buildeth her house: but the foolish plucketh it down with her hands.

<b>2 </b>He that walketh in his uprightness feareth the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: but <i>he that is</i> perverse in his ways despiseth him.

<b>3 </b>In the mouth of the foolish <i>is</i> a rod of pride: but the lips of the wise shall preserve them.

<b>4 </b>Where no oxen <i>are,</i> the crib <i>is</i> clean: but much increase <i>is</i> by the strength of the ox.

<b>5 </b>A faithful witness will not lie: but a false witness will utter lies.

<b>6 </b>A scorner seeketh wisdom, and <i>findeth it</i> not: but knowledge <i>is</i> easy unto him that understandeth.

<b>7 </b>Go from the presence of a foolish man, when thou perceivest not <i>in him</i> the lips of knowledge.

<b>8 </b>The wisdom of the prudent <i>is</i> to understand his way: but the folly of fools <i>is</i> deceit.

<b>9 </b>Fools make a mock at sin: but among the righteous <i>there is</i> favour.

<b>10 </b>The heart knoweth his own bitterness; and a stranger doth not intermeddle with his joy.

<b>11 </b>The house of the wicked shall be overthrown: but the tabernacle of the upright shall flourish.

<b>12 </b>There is a way which seemeth right unto a man, but the end thereof <i>are</i> the ways of death.

<b>13 </b>Even in laughter the heart is sorrowful; and the end of that mirth <i>is</i> heaviness.
