<b>1 </b>Who <i>is</i> as the wise <i>man?</i> and who knoweth the interpretation of a thing? a man’s wisdom maketh his face to shine, and the boldness of his face shall be changed.

<b>2 </b>I <i>counsel thee</i> to keep the king’s commandment, and <i>that</i> in regard of the oath of God.

<b>3 </b>Be not hasty to go out of his sight: stand not in an evil thing; for he doeth whatsoever pleaseth him.

<b>4 </b>Where the word of a king <i>is, there is</i> power: and who may say unto him, What doest thou?

<b>5 </b>Whoso keepeth the commandment shall feel no evil thing: and a wise man’s heart discerneth both time and judgment.

<b>6 </b>¶ Because to every purpose there is time and judgment, therefore the misery of man <i>is</i> great upon him.

<b>7 </b>For he knoweth not that which shall be: for who can tell him when it shall be?

<b>8 </b><i>There is</i> no man that hath power over the spirit to retain the spirit; neither <i>hath he</i> power in the day of death: and <i>there is</i> no discharge in <i>that</i> war; neither shall wickedness deliver those that are given to it.

<b>9 </b>All this have I seen, and applied my heart unto every work that is done under the sun: <i>there is</i> a time wherein one man ruleth over another to his own hurt.

<b>10 </b>And so I saw the wicked buried, who had come and gone from the place of the holy, and they were forgotten in the city where they had so done: this <i>is</i> also vanity.

<b>11 </b>Because sentence against an evil work is not executed speedily, therefore the heart of the sons of men is fully set in them to do evil.

<b>12 </b>¶ Though a sinner do evil an hundred times, and his <i>days</i> be prolonged, yet surely I know that it shall be well with them that fear God, which fear before him:

<b>13 </b>But it shall not be well with the wicked, neither shall he prolong <i>his</i> days, <i>which are</i> as a shadow; because he feareth not before God.

<b>14 </b>There is a vanity which is done upon the earth; that there be just <i>men,</i> unto whom it happeneth according to the work of the wicked; again, there be wicked <i>men,</i> to whom it happeneth according to the work of the righteous: I said that this also <i>is</i> vanity.

<b>15 </b>Then I commended mirth, because a man hath no better thing under the sun, than to eat, and to drink, and to be merry: for that shall abide with him of his labour the days of his life, which God giveth him under the sun.

<b>16 </b>¶ When I applied mine heart to know wisdom, and to see the business that is done upon the earth: (for also <i>there is that</i> neither day nor night seeth sleep with his eyes:)

<b>17 </b>Then I beheld all the work of God, that a man cannot find out the work that is done under the sun: because though a man labour to seek <i>it</i> out, yet he shall not find <i>it;</i> yea further; though a wise <i>man</i> think to know <i>it,</i> yet shall he not be able to find <i>it.</i>


--------------------

CHAPTER 9

<b>1 </b>For all this I considered in my heart even to declare all this, that the righteous, and the wise, and their works, <i>are</i> in the hand of God: no man knoweth either love or hatred <i>by</i> all <i>that is</i> before them.

<b>2 </b>All <i>things come</i> alike to all: <i>there is</i> one event to the righteous, and to the wicked; to the good and to the clean, and to the unclean; to him that sacrificeth, and to him that sacrificeth not: as <i>is</i> the good, so <i>is</i> the sinner; <i>and</i> he that sweareth, as <i>he</i> that feareth an oath.

<b>3 </b>This <i>is</i> an evil among all <i>things</i> that are done under the sun, that <i>there is</i> one event unto all: yea, also the heart of the sons of men is full of evil, and madness <i>is</i> in their heart while they live, and after that <i>they go</i> to the dead.

<b>4 </b>¶ For to him that is joined to all the living there is hope: for a living dog is better than a dead lion.

<b>5 </b>For the living know that they shall die: but the dead know not any thing, neither have they any more a reward; for the memory of them is forgotten.

<b>6 </b>Also their love, and their hatred, and their envy, is now perished; neither have they any more a portion for ever in any <i>thing</i> that is done under the sun.

<b>7 </b>¶ Go thy way, eat thy bread with joy, and drink thy wine with a merry heart; for God now accepteth thy works.

<b>8 </b>Let thy garments be always white; and let thy head lack no ointment.

<b>9 </b>Live joyfully with the wife whom thou lovest all the days of the life of thy vanity, which he hath given thee under the sun, all the days of thy vanity: for that <i>is</i> thy portion in <i>this</i> life, and in thy labour which thou takest under the sun.

<b>10 </b>Whatsoever thy hand findeth to do, do <i>it</i> with thy might; for <i>there is</i> no work, nor device, nor knowledge, nor wisdom, in the grave, whither thou goest.

<b>11 </b>¶ I returned, and saw under the sun, that the race <i>is</i> not to the swift, nor the battle to the strong, neither yet bread to the wise, nor yet riches to men of understanding, nor yet favour to men of skill; but time and chance happeneth to them all.

<b>12 </b>For man also knoweth not his time: as the fishes that are taken in an evil net, and as the birds that are caught in the snare; so <i>are</i> the sons of men snared in an evil time, when it falleth suddenly upon them.

<b>13 </b>¶ This wisdom have I seen also under the sun, and it <i>seemed</i> great unto me:

<b>14 </b><i>There was</i> a little city, and few men within it; and there came a great king against it, and besieged it, and built great bulwarks against it:

<b>15 </b>Now there was found in it a poor wise man, and he by his wisdom delivered the city; yet no man remembered that same poor man.

<b>16 </b>Then said I, Wisdom <i>is</i> better than strength: nevertheless the poor man’s wisdom <i>is</i> despised, and his words are not heard.

<b>17 </b>The words of wise <i>men are</i> heard in quiet more than the cry of him that ruleth among fools.

<b>18 </b>Wisdom <i>is</i> better than weapons of war: but one sinner destroyeth much good.


--------------------

CHAPTER 10

<b>1 </b>Dead flies cause the ointment of the apothecary to send forth a stinking savour: <i>so doth</i> a little folly him that is in reputation for wisdom <i>and</i> honour.

<b>2 </b>A wise man’s heart <i>is</i> at his right hand; but a fool’s heart at his left.

<b>3 </b>Yea also, when he that is a fool walketh by the way, his wisdom faileth <i>him,</i> and he saith to every one <i>that</i> he <i>is</i> a fool.

<b>4 </b>If the spirit of the ruler rise up against thee, leave not thy place; for yielding pacifieth great offences.

<b>5 </b>There is an evil <i>which</i> I have seen under the sun, as an error <i>which</i> proceedeth from the ruler:

<b>6 </b>Folly is set in great dignity, and the rich sit in low place.

<b>7 </b>I have seen servants upon horses, and princes walking as servants upon the earth.

<b>8 </b>He that diggeth a pit shall fall into it; and whoso breaketh an hedge, a serpent shall bite him.

<b>9 </b>Whoso removeth stones shall be hurt therewith; <i>and</i> he that cleaveth wood shall be endangered thereby.

<b>10 </b>If the iron be blunt, and he do not whet the edge, then must he put to more strength: but wisdom <i>is</i> profitable to direct.

<b>11 </b>Surely the serpent will bite without enchantment; and a babbler is no better.

<b>12 </b>The words of a wise man’s mouth <i>are</i> gracious; but the lips of a fool will swallow up himself.

<b>13 </b>The beginning of the words of his mouth <i>is</i> foolishness: and the end of his talk <i>is</i> mischievous madness.

<b>14 </b>A fool also is full of words: a man cannot tell what shall be; and what shall be after him, who can tell him?

<b>15 </b>The labour of the foolish wearieth every one of them, because he knoweth not how to go to the city.

<b>16 </b>¶ Woe to thee, O land, when thy king <i>is</i> a child, and thy princes eat in the morning!

<b>17 </b>Blessed <i>art</i> thou, O land, when thy king <i>is</i> the son of nobles, and thy princes eat in due season, for strength, and not for drunkenness!

<b>18 </b>¶ By much slothfulness the building decayeth; and through idleness of the hands the house droppeth through.

<b>19 </b>¶ A feast is made for laughter, and wine maketh merry: but money answereth all <i>things.</i>

<b>20 </b>¶ Curse not the king, no not in thy thought; and curse not the rich in thy bedchamber: for a bird of the air shall carry the voice, and that which hath wings shall tell the matter.


--------------------

CHAPTER 11

<b>1 </b>Cast thy bread upon the waters: for thou shalt find it after many days.

<b>2 </b>Give a portion to seven, and also to eight; for thou knowest not what evil shall be upon the earth.

<b>3 </b>If the clouds be full of rain, they empty <i>themselves</i> upon the earth: and if the tree fall toward the south, or toward the north, in the place where the tree falleth, there it shall be.

<b>4 </b>He that observeth the wind shall not sow; and he that regardeth the clouds shall not reap.

<b>5 </b>As thou knowest not what <i>is</i> the way of the spirit, <i>nor</i> how the bones <i>do grow</i> in the womb of her that is with child: even so thou knowest not the works of God who maketh all.

<b>6 </b>In the morning sow thy seed, and in the evening withhold not thine hand: for thou knowest not whether shall prosper, either this or that, or whether they both <i>shall be</i> alike good.

<b>7 </b>¶ Truly the light <i>is</i> sweet, and a pleasant <i>thing it is</i> for the eyes to behold the sun:

<b>8 </b>But if a man live many years, <i>and</i> rejoice in them all; yet let him remember the days of darkness; for they shall be many. All that cometh <i>is</i> vanity.

<b>9 </b>¶ Rejoice, O young man, in thy youth; and let thy heart cheer thee in the days of thy youth, and walk in the ways of thine heart, and in the sight of thine eyes: but know thou, that for all these <i>things</i> God will bring thee into judgment.

<b>10 </b>Therefore remove sorrow from thy heart, and put away evil from thy flesh: for childhood and youth <i>are</i> vanity.


--------------------

CHAPTER 12

<b>1 </b>Remember now thy Creator in the days of thy youth, while the evil days come not, nor the years draw nigh, when thou shalt say, I have no pleasure in them;

<b>2 </b>While the sun, or the light, or the moon, or the stars, be not darkened, nor the clouds return after the rain:

<b>3 </b>In the day when the keepers of the house shall tremble, and the strong men shall bow themselves, and the grinders cease because they are few, and those that look out of the windows be darkened,

<b>4 </b>And the doors shall be shut in the streets, when the sound of the grinding is low, and he shall rise up at the voice of the bird, and all the daughters of musick shall be brought low;

<b>5 </b>Also <i>when</i> they shall be afraid of <i>that which is</i> high, and fears <i>shall be</i> in the way, and the almond tree shall flourish, and the grasshopper shall be a burden, and desire shall fail: because man goeth to his long home, and the mourners go about the streets:

<b>6 </b>Or ever the silver cord be loosed, or the golden bowl be broken, or the pitcher be broken at the fountain, or the wheel broken at the cistern.

<b>7 </b>Then shall the dust return to the earth as it was: and the spirit shall return unto God who gave it.

<b>8 </b>¶ Vanity of vanities, saith the preacher; all <i>is</i> vanity.

<b>9 </b>And moreover, because the preacher was wise, he still taught the people knowledge; yea, he gave good heed, and sought out, <i>and</i> set in order many proverbs.

<b>10 </b>The preacher sought to find out acceptable words: and <i>that which was</i> written <i>was</i> upright, <i>even</i> words of truth.

<b>11 </b>The words of the wise <i>are</i> as goads, and as nails fastened <i>by</i> the masters of assemblies, <i>which</i> are given from one shepherd.

<b>12 </b>And further, by these, my son, be admonished: of making many books <i>there is</i> no end; and much study <i>is</i> a weariness of the flesh.

<b>13 </b>¶ Let us hear the conclusion of the whole matter: Fear God, and keep his commandments: for this <i>is</i> the whole <i>duty</i> of man.

<b>14 </b>For God shall bring every work into judgment, with every secret thing, whether <i>it be</i> good, or whether <i>it be</i> evil.


--------------------

<small>The </small>Song of Solomon

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>The song of songs, which <i>is</i> Solomon’s.

<b>2 </b>Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth: for thy love <i>is</i> better than wine.

<b>3 </b>Because of the savour of thy good ointments thy name <i>is as</i> ointment poured forth, therefore do the virgins love thee.

<b>4 </b>Draw me, we will run after thee: the king hath brought me into his chambers: we will be glad and rejoice in thee, we will remember thy love more than wine: the upright love thee.

<b>5 </b>I <i>am</i> black, but comely, O ye daughters of Jerusalem, as the tents of Kedar, as the curtains of Solomon.

<b>6 </b>Look not upon me, because I <i>am</i> black, because the sun hath looked upon me: my mother’s children were angry with me; they made me the keeper of the vineyards; <i>but</i> mine own vineyard have I not kept.

<b>7 </b>Tell me, O thou whom my soul loveth, where thou feedest, where thou makest <i>thy flock</i> to rest at noon: for why should I be as one that turneth aside by the flocks of thy companions?

<b>8 </b>¶ If thou know not, O thou fairest among women, go thy way forth by the footsteps of the flock, and feed thy kids beside the shepherds’ tents.

<b>9 </b>I have compared thee, O my love, to a company of horses in Pharaoh’s chariots.

<b>10 </b>Thy cheeks are comely with rows <i>of jewels,</i> thy neck with chains <i>of gold.</i>

<b>11 </b>We will make thee borders of gold with studs of silver.

<b>12 </b>¶ While the king <i>sitteth</i> at his table, my spikenard sendeth forth the smell thereof.

<b>13 </b>A bundle of myrrh <i>is</i> my wellbeloved unto me; he shall lie all night betwixt my breasts.

<b>14 </b>My beloved <i>is</i> unto me <i>as</i> a cluster of camphire in the vineyards of En-gedi.

<b>15 </b>Behold, thou <i>art</i> fair, my love; behold, thou <i>art</i> fair; thou <i>hast</i> doves’ eyes.

<b>16 </b>Behold, thou <i>art</i> fair, my beloved, yea, pleasant: also our bed <i>is</i> green.

<b>17 </b>The beams of our house <i>are</i> cedar, <i>and</i> our rafters of fir.


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>I <i>am</i> the rose of Sharon, <i>and</i> the lily of the valleys.

<b>2 </b>As the lily among thorns, so <i>is</i> my love among the daughters.

<b>3 </b>As the apple tree among the trees of the wood, so <i>is</i> my beloved among the sons. I sat down under his shadow with great delight, and his fruit <i>was</i> sweet to my taste.

<b>4 </b>He brought me to the banqueting house, and his banner over me <i>was</i> love.

<b>5 </b>Stay me with flagons, comfort me with apples: for I <i>am</i> sick of love.

<b>6 </b>His left hand <i>is</i> under my head, and his right hand doth embrace me.

<b>7 </b>I charge you, O ye daughters of Jerusalem, by the roes, and by the hinds of the field, that ye stir not up, nor awake <i>my</i> love, till he please.

<b>8 </b>¶ The voice of my beloved! behold, he cometh leaping upon the mountains, skipping upon the hills.

<b>9 </b>My beloved is like a roe or a young hart: behold, he standeth behind our wall, he looketh forth at the windows, shewing himself through the lattice.

<b>10 </b>My beloved spake, and said unto me, Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away.

<b>11 </b>For, lo, the winter is past, the rain is over <i>and</i> gone;

<b>12 </b>The flowers appear on the earth; the time of the singing <i>of birds</i> is come, and the voice of the turtle is heard in our land;

<b>13 </b>The fig tree putteth forth her green figs, and the vines <i>with</i> the tender grape give a <i>good</i> smell. Arise, my love, my fair one, and come away.

<b>14 </b>¶ O my dove, <i>that art</i> in the clefts of the rock, in the secret <i>places</i> of the stairs, let me see thy countenance, let me hear thy voice; for sweet <i>is</i> thy voice, and thy countenance <i>is</i> comely.

<b>15 </b>Take us the foxes, the little foxes, that spoil the vines: for our vines <i>have</i> tender grapes.

<b>16 </b>¶ My beloved <i>is</i> mine, and I <i>am</i> his: he feedeth among the lilies.

<b>17 </b>Until the day break, and the shadows flee away, turn, my beloved, and be thou like a roe or a young hart upon the mountains of Bether.


--------------------

CHAPTER 3

<b>1 </b>By night on my bed I sought him whom my soul loveth: I sought him, but I found him not.

<b>2 </b>I will rise now, and go about the city in the streets, and in the broad ways I will seek him whom my soul loveth: I sought him, but I found him not.

<b>3 </b>The watchmen that go about the city found me: <i>to whom I said,</i> Saw ye him whom my soul loveth?

<b>4 </b><i>It was</i> but a little that I passed from them, but I found him whom my soul loveth: I held him, and would not let him go, until I had brought him into my mother’s house, and into the chamber of her that conceived me.

<b>5 </b>I charge you, O ye daughters of Jerusalem, by the roes, and by the hinds of the field, that ye stir not up, nor awake <i>my</i> love, till he please.

<b>6 </b>¶ Who <i>is</i> this that cometh out of the wilderness like pillars of smoke, perfumed with myrrh and frankincense, with all powders of the merchant?

<b>7 </b>Behold his bed, which <i>is</i> Solomon’s; threescore valiant men <i>are</i> about it, of the valiant of Israel.

<b>8 </b>They all hold swords, <i>being</i> expert in war: every man <i>hath</i> his sword upon his thigh because of fear in the night.

<b>9 </b>King Solomon made himself a chariot of the wood of Lebanon.

<b>10 </b>He made the pillars thereof <i>of</i> silver, the bottom thereof <i>of</i> gold, the covering of it <i>of</i> purple, the midst thereof being paved <i>with</i> love, for the daughters of Jerusalem.

<b>11 </b>Go forth, O ye daughters of Zion, and behold king Solomon with the crown wherewith his mother crowned him in the day of his espousals, and in the day of the gladness of his heart.


--------------------

CHAPTER 4

<b>1 </b>Behold, thou <i>art</i> fair, my love; behold, thou <i>art</i> fair; thou <i>hast</i> doves’ eyes within thy locks: thy hair <i>is</i> as a flock of goats, that appear from mount Gilead.

<b>2 </b>Thy teeth <i>are</i> like a flock <i>of sheep that are even</i> shorn, which came up from the washing; whereof every one bear twins, and none <i>is</i> barren among them.

<b>3 </b>Thy lips <i>are</i> like a thread of scarlet, and thy speech <i>is</i> comely: thy temples <i>are</i> like a piece of a pomegranate within thy locks.

<b>4 </b>Thy neck <i>is</i> like the tower of David builded for an armoury, whereon there hang a thousand bucklers, all shields of mighty men.

<b>5 </b>Thy two breasts <i>are</i> like two young roes that are twins, which feed among the lilies.

<b>6 </b>Until the day break, and the shadows flee away, I will get me to the mountain of myrrh, and to the hill of frankincense.

<b>7 </b>Thou <i>art</i> all fair, my love; <i>there is</i> no spot in thee.

<b>8 </b>¶ Come with me from Lebanon, <i>my</i> spouse, with me from Lebanon: look from the top of Amana, from the top of Shenir and Hermon, from the lions’ dens, from the mountains of the leopards.

<b>9 </b>Thou hast ravished my heart, my sister, <i>my</i> spouse; thou hast ravished my heart with one of thine eyes, with one chain of thy neck.

<b>10 </b>How fair is thy love, my sister, <i>my</i> spouse! how much better is thy love than wine! and the smell of thine ointments than all spices!

<b>11 </b>Thy lips, O <i>my</i> spouse, drop <i>as</i> the honeycomb: honey and milk <i>are</i> under thy tongue; and the smell of thy garments <i>is</i> like the smell of Lebanon.

<b>12 </b>A garden inclosed <i>is</i> my sister, <i>my</i> spouse; a spring shut up, a fountain sealed.

<b>13 </b>Thy plants <i>are</i> an orchard of pomegranates, with pleasant fruits; camphire, with spikenard,

<b>14 </b>Spikenard and saffron; calamus and cinnamon, with all trees of frankincense; myrrh and aloes, with all the chief spices:

<b>15 </b>A fountain of gardens, a well of living waters, and streams from Lebanon.

<b>16 </b>¶ Awake, O north wind; and come, thou south; blow upon my garden, <i>that</i> the spices thereof may flow out. Let my beloved come into his garden, and eat his pleasant fruits.


--------------------

CHAPTER 5

<b>1 </b>I am come into my garden, my sister, <i>my</i> spouse: I have gathered my myrrh with my spice; I have eaten my honeycomb with my honey; I have drunk my wine with my milk: eat, O friends; drink, yea, drink abundantly, O beloved.

<b>2 </b>¶ I sleep, but my heart waketh: <i>it is</i> the voice of my beloved that knocketh, <i>saying,</i> Open to me, my sister, my love, my dove, my undefiled: for my head is filled with dew, <i>and</i> my locks with the drops of the night.

<b>3 </b>I have put off my coat; how shall I put it on? I have washed my feet; how shall I defile them?

<b>4 </b>My beloved put in his hand by the hole <i>of the door,</i> and my bowels were moved for him.

<b>5 </b>I rose up to open to my beloved; and my hands dropped <i>with</i> myrrh, and my fingers <i>with</i> sweet smelling myrrh, upon the handles of the lock.

<b>6 </b>I opened to my beloved; but my beloved had withdrawn himself, <i>and</i> was gone: my soul failed when he spake: I sought him, but I could not find him; I called him, but he gave me no answer.

<b>7 </b>The watchmen that went about the city found me, they smote me, they wounded me; the keepers of the walls took away my veil from me.

<b>8 </b>I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, if ye find my beloved, that ye tell him, that I <i>am</i> sick of love.

<b>9 </b>¶ What <i>is</i> thy beloved more than <i>another</i> beloved, O thou fairest among women? what <i>is</i> thy beloved more than <i>another</i> beloved, that thou dost so charge us?

<b>10 </b>My beloved <i>is</i> white and ruddy, the chiefest among ten thousand.

<b>11 </b>His head <i>is as</i> the most fine gold, his locks <i>are</i> bushy, <i>and</i> black as a raven.

<b>12 </b>His eyes <i>are</i> as <i>the eyes</i> of doves by the rivers of waters, washed with milk, <i>and</i> fitly set.

<b>13 </b>His cheeks <i>are</i> as a bed of spices, <i>as</i> sweet flowers: his lips <i>like</i> lilies, dropping sweet smelling myrrh.

<b>14 </b>His hands <i>are as</i> gold rings set with the beryl: his belly <i>is as</i> bright ivory overlaid <i>with</i> sapphires.

<b>15 </b>His legs <i>are as</i> pillars of marble, set upon sockets of fine gold: his countenance <i>is</i> as Lebanon, excellent as the cedars.

<b>16 </b>His mouth <i>is</i> most sweet: yea, he <i>is</i> altogether lovely. This <i>is</i> my beloved, and this <i>is</i> my friend, O daughters of Jerusalem.


--------------------

CHAPTER 6

<b>1 </b>Whither is thy beloved gone, O thou fairest among women? whither is thy beloved turned aside? that we may seek him with thee.

<b>2 </b>My beloved is gone down into his garden, to the beds of spices, to feed in the gardens, and to gather lilies.

<b>3 </b>I <i>am</i> my beloved’s, and my beloved <i>is</i> mine: he feedeth among the lilies.

<b>4 </b>¶ Thou <i>art</i> beautiful, O my love, as Tirzah, comely as Jerusalem, terrible as <i>an army</i> with banners.

<b>5 </b>Turn away thine eyes from me, for they have overcome me: thy hair <i>is</i> as a flock of goats that appear from Gilead.

<b>6 </b>Thy teeth <i>are</i> as a flock of sheep which go up from the washing, whereof every one beareth twins, and <i>there is</i> not one barren among them.

<b>7 </b>As a piece of a pomegranate <i>are</i> thy temples within thy locks.

<b>8 </b>There are threescore queens, and fourscore concubines, and virgins without number.

<b>9 </b>My dove, my undefiled is <i>but</i> one; she <i>is</i> the <i>only</i> one of her mother, she <i>is</i> the choice <i>one</i> of her that bare her. The daughters saw her, and blessed her; <i>yea,</i> the queens and the concubines, and they praised her.

<b>10 </b>¶ Who <i>is</i> she <i>that</i> looketh forth as the morning, fair as the moon, clear as the sun, <i>and</i> terrible as <i>an army</i> with banners?

<b>11 </b>I went down into the garden of nuts to see the fruits of the valley, <i>and</i> to see whether the vine flourished, <i>and</i> the pomegranates budded.

<b>12 </b>Or ever I was aware, my soul made me <i>like</i> the chariots of Amminadib.

<b>13 </b>Return, return, O Shulamite; return, return, that we may look upon thee. What will ye see in the Shulamite? As it were the company of two armies.


--------------------

CHAPTER 7

<b>1 </b>How beautiful are thy feet with shoes, O prince’s daughter! the joints of thy thighs <i>are</i> like jewels, the work of the hands of a cunning workman.

<b>2 </b>Thy navel <i>is like</i> a round goblet, <i>which</i> wanteth not liquor: thy belly <i>is like</i> an heap of wheat set about with lilies.

<b>3 </b>Thy two breasts <i>are</i> like two young roes <i>that are</i> twins.

<b>4 </b>Thy neck <i>is</i> as a tower of ivory; thine eyes <i>like</i> the fishpools in Heshbon, by the gate of Bath-rabbim: thy nose <i>is</i> as the tower of Lebanon which looketh toward Damascus.

<b>5 </b>Thine head upon thee <i>is</i> like Carmel, and the hair of thine head like purple; the king <i>is</i> held in the galleries.

<b>6 </b>How fair and how pleasant art thou, O love, for delights!

<b>7 </b>This thy stature is like to a palm tree, and thy breasts to clusters <i>of grapes.</i>

<b>8 </b>I said, I will go up to the palm tree, I will take hold of the boughs thereof: now also thy breasts shall be as clusters of the vine, and the smell of thy nose like apples;

<b>9 </b>And the roof of thy mouth like the best wine for my beloved, that goeth <i>down</i> sweetly, causing the lips of those that are asleep to speak.

<b>10 </b>¶ I <i>am</i> my beloved’s, and his desire <i>is</i> toward me.

<b>11 </b>Come, my beloved, let us go forth into the field; let us lodge in the villages.

<b>12 </b>Let us get up early to the vineyards; let us see if the vine flourish, <i>whether</i> the tender grape appear, <i>and</i> the pomegranates bud forth: there will I give thee my loves.

<b>13 </b>The mandrakes give a smell, and at our gates <i>are</i> all manner of pleasant <i>fruits,</i> new and old, <i>which</i> I have laid up for thee, O my beloved.


--------------------

CHAPTER 8

<b>1 </b>O that thou <i>wert</i> as my brother, that sucked the breasts of my mother! <i>when</i> I should find thee without, I would kiss thee; yea, I should not be despised.

<b>2 </b>I would lead thee, <i>and</i> bring thee into my mother’s house, <i>who</i> would instruct me: I would cause thee to drink of spiced wine of the juice of my pomegranate.

<b>3 </b>His left hand <i>should be</i> under my head, and his right hand should embrace me.

<b>4 </b>I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, that ye stir not up, nor awake <i>my</i> love, until he please.

<b>5 </b>Who <i>is</i> this that cometh up from the wilderness, leaning upon her beloved? I raised thee up under the apple tree: there thy mother brought thee forth: there she brought thee forth <i>that</i> bare thee.

<b>6 </b>¶ Set me as a seal upon thine heart, as a seal upon thine arm: for love <i>is</i> strong as death; jealousy <i>is</i> cruel as the grave: the coals thereof <i>are</i> coals of fire, <i>which hath</i> a most vehement flame.

<b>7 </b>Many waters cannot quench love, neither can the floods drown it: if a man would give all the substance of his house for love, it would utterly be contemned.

<b>8 </b>¶ We have a little sister, and she hath no breasts: what shall we do for our sister in the day when she shall be spoken for?

<b>9 </b>If she <i>be</i> a wall, we will build upon her a palace of silver: and if she <i>be</i> a door, we will inclose her with boards of cedar.

<b>10 </b>I <i>am</i> a wall, and my breasts like towers: then was I in his eyes as one that found favour.

<b>11 </b>Solomon had a vineyard at Baal-hamon; he let out the vineyard unto keepers; every one for the fruit thereof was to bring a thousand <i>pieces</i> of silver.

<b>12 </b>My vineyard, which <i>is</i> mine, <i>is</i> before me: thou, O Solomon, <i>must have</i> a thousand, and those that keep the fruit thereof two hundred.

<b>13 </b>Thou that dwellest in the gardens, the companions hearken to thy voice: cause me to hear <i>it.</i>

<b>14 </b>¶ Make haste, my beloved, and be thou like to a roe or to a young hart upon the mountains of spices.


--------------------

<small>The Book of the Prophet </small>Isaiah

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>The vision of Isaiah the son of Amoz, which he saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, <i>and</i> Hezekiah, kings of Judah.

<b>2 </b>Hear, O heavens, and give ear, O earth: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath spoken, I have nourished and brought up children, and they have rebelled against me.

<b>3 </b>The ox knoweth his owner, and the ass his master’s crib: <i>but</i> Israel doth not know, my people doth not consider.

<b>4 </b>Ah sinful nation, a people laden with iniquity, a seed of evildoers, children that are corrupters: they have forsaken the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, they have provoked the Holy One of Israel unto anger, they are gone away backward.

<b>5 </b>¶ Why should ye be stricken any more? ye will revolt more and more: the whole head is sick, and the whole heart faint.

<b>6 </b>From the sole of the foot even unto the head <i>there is</i> no soundness in it; <i>but</i> wounds, and bruises, and putrifying sores: they have not been closed, neither bound up, neither mollified with ointment.

<b>7 </b>Your country <i>is</i> desolate, your cities <i>are</i> burned with fire: your land, strangers devour it in your presence, and <i>it is</i> desolate, as overthrown by strangers.

<b>8 </b>And the daughter of Zion is left as a cottage in a vineyard, as a lodge in a garden of cucumbers, as a besieged city.

<b>9 </b>Except the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts had left unto us a very small remnant, we should have been as Sodom, <i>and</i> we should have been like unto Gomorrah.

<b>10 </b>¶ Hear the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, ye rulers of Sodom; give ear unto the law of our God, ye people of Gomorrah.

<b>11 </b>To what purpose <i>is</i> the multitude of your sacrifices unto me? saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: I am full of the burnt offerings of rams, and the fat of fed beasts; and I delight not in the blood of bullocks, or of lambs, or of he goats.

<b>12 </b>When ye come to appear before me, who hath required this at your hand, to tread my courts?

<b>13 </b>Bring no more vain oblations; incense is an abomination unto me; the new moons and sabbaths, the calling of assemblies, I cannot away with; <i>it is</i> iniquity, even the solemn meeting.

<b>14 </b>Your new moons and your appointed feasts my soul hateth: they are a trouble unto me; I am weary to bear <i>them.</i>

<b>15 </b>And when ye spread forth your hands, I will hide mine eyes from you: yea, when ye make many prayers, I will not hear: your hands are full of blood.

<b>16 </b>¶ Wash you, make you clean; put away the evil of your doings from before mine eyes; cease to do evil;

<b>17 </b>Learn to do well; seek judgment, relieve the oppressed, judge the fatherless, plead for the widow.

<b>18 </b>Come now, and let us reason together, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: though your sins be as scarlet, they shall be as white as snow; though they be red like crimson, they shall be as wool.

<b>19 </b>If ye be willing and obedient, ye shall eat the good of the land:

<b>20 </b>But if ye refuse and rebel, ye shall be devoured with the sword: for the mouth of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath spoken <i>it.</i>

<b>21 </b>¶ How is the faithful city become an harlot! it was full of judgment; righteousness lodged in it; but now murderers.

<b>22 </b>Thy silver is become dross, thy wine mixed with water:

<b>23 </b>Thy princes <i>are</i> rebellious, and companions of thieves: every one loveth gifts, and followeth after rewards: they judge not the fatherless, neither doth the cause of the widow come unto them.

<b>24 </b>Therefore saith the Lord, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the mighty One of Israel, Ah, I will ease me of mine adversaries, and avenge me of mine enemies:

<b>25 </b>¶ And I will turn my hand upon thee, and purely purge away thy dross, and take away all thy tin:

<b>26 </b>And I will restore thy judges as at the first, and thy counsellors as at the beginning: afterward thou shalt be called, The city of righteousness, the faithful city.

<b>27 </b>Zion shall be redeemed with judgment, and her converts with righteousness.

<b>28 </b>¶ And the destruction of the transgressors and of the sinners <i>shall be</i> together, and they that forsake the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall be consumed.

<b>29 </b>For they shall be ashamed of the oaks which ye have desired, and ye shall be confounded for the gardens that ye have chosen.

<b>30 </b>For ye shall be as an oak whose leaf fadeth, and as a garden that hath no water.

<b>31 </b>And the strong shall be as tow, and the maker of it as a spark, and they shall both burn together, and none shall quench <i>them.</i>


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>The word that Isaiah the son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem.

<b>2 </b>And it shall come to pass in the last days, <i>that</i> the mountain of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s house shall be established in the top of the mountains, and shall be exalted above the hills; and all nations shall flow unto it.

<b>3 </b>And many people shall go and say, Come ye, and let us go up to the mountain of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to the house of the God of Jacob; and he will teach us of his ways, and we will walk in his paths: for out of Zion shall go forth the law, and the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> from Jerusalem.

<b>4 </b>And he shall judge among the nations, and shall rebuke many people: and they shall beat their swords into plowshares, and their spears into pruninghooks: nation shall not lift up sword against nation, neither shall they learn war any more.

<b>5 </b>O house of Jacob, come ye, and let us walk in the light of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>6 </b>¶ Therefore thou hast forsaken thy people the house of Jacob, because they be replenished from the east, and <i>are</i> soothsayers like the Philistines, and they please themselves in the children of strangers.

<b>7 </b>Their land also is full of silver and gold, neither <i>is there any</i> end of their treasures; their land is also full of horses, neither <i>is there any</i> end of their chariots:

<b>8 </b>Their land also is full of idols; they worship the work of their own hands, that which their own fingers have made:

<b>9 </b>And the mean man boweth down, and the great man humbleth himself: therefore forgive them not.

<b>10 </b>¶ Enter into the rock, and hide thee in the dust, for fear of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and for the glory of his majesty.

<b>11 </b>The lofty looks of man shall be humbled, and the haughtiness of men shall be bowed down, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> alone shall be exalted in that day.

<b>12 </b>For the day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts <i>shall be</i> upon every <i>one that is</i> proud and lofty, and upon every <i>one that is</i> lifted up; and he shall be brought low:

<b>13 </b>And upon all the cedars of Lebanon, <i>that are</i> high and lifted up, and upon all the oaks of Bashan,

<b>14 </b>And upon all the high mountains, and upon all the hills <i>that are</i> lifted up,

<b>15 </b>And upon every high tower, and upon every fenced wall,

<b>16 </b>And upon all the ships of Tarshish, and upon all pleasant pictures.

<b>17 </b>And the loftiness of man shall be bowed down, and the haughtiness of men shall be made low: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> alone shall be exalted in that day.

<b>18 </b>And the idols he shall utterly abolish.

<b>19 </b>And they shall go into the holes of the rocks, and into the caves of the earth, for fear of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and for the glory of his majesty, when he ariseth to shake terribly the earth.

<b>20 </b>In that day a man shall cast his idols of silver, and his idols of gold, which they made <i>each one</i> for himself to worship, to the moles and to the bats;

<b>21 </b>To go into the clefts of the rocks, and into the tops of the ragged rocks, for fear of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and for the glory of his majesty, when he ariseth to shake terribly the earth.

<b>22 </b>Cease ye from man, whose breath <i>is</i> in his nostrils: for wherein is he to be accounted of?


--------------------

CHAPTER 3

<b>1 </b>For, behold, the Lord, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, doth take away from Jerusalem and from Judah the stay and the staff, the whole stay of bread, and the whole stay of water,

<b>2 </b>The mighty man, and the man of war, the judge, and the prophet, and the prudent, and the ancient,

<b>3 </b>The captain of fifty, and the honourable man, and the counsellor, and the cunning artificer, and the eloquent orator.

<b>4 </b>And I will give children <i>to be</i> their princes, and babes shall rule over them.

<b>5 </b>And the people shall be oppressed, every one by another, and every one by his neighbour: the child shall behave himself proudly against the ancient, and the base against the honourable.

<b>6 </b>When a man shall take hold of his brother of the house of his father, <i>saying,</i> Thou hast clothing, be thou our ruler, and <i>let</i> this ruin <i>be</i> under thy hand:

<b>7 </b>In that day shall he swear, saying, I will not be an healer; for in my house <i>is</i> neither bread nor clothing: make me not a ruler of the people.

<b>8 </b>For Jerusalem is ruined, and Judah is fallen: because their tongue and their doings <i>are</i> against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to provoke the eyes of his glory.

<b>9 </b>¶ The shew of their countenance doth witness against them; and they declare their sin as Sodom, they hide <i>it</i> not. Woe unto their soul! for they have rewarded evil unto themselves.

<b>10 </b>Say ye to the righteous, that <i>it shall be</i> well <i>with him:</i> for they shall eat the fruit of their doings.

<b>11 </b>Woe unto the wicked! <i>it shall be</i> ill <i>with him:</i> for the reward of his hands shall be given him.

<b>12 </b>¶ <i>As for</i> my people, children <i>are</i> their oppressors, and women rule over them. O my people, they which lead thee cause <i>thee</i> to err, and destroy the way of thy paths.

<b>13 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> standeth up to plead, and standeth to judge the people.

<b>14 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will enter into judgment with the ancients of his people, and the princes thereof: for ye have eaten up the vineyard; the spoil of the poor <i>is</i> in your houses.

<b>15 </b>What mean ye <i>that</i> ye beat my people to pieces, and grind the faces of the poor? saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> of hosts.

<b>16 </b>¶ Moreover the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> saith, Because the daughters of Zion are haughty, and walk with stretched forth necks and wanton eyes, walking and mincing <i>as</i> they go, and making a tinkling with their feet:

<b>17 </b>Therefore the Lord will smite with a scab the crown of the head of the daughters of Zion, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will discover their secret parts.

<b>18 </b>In that day the Lord will take away the bravery of <i>their</i> tinkling ornaments <i>about their feet,</i> and <i>their</i> cauls, and <i>their</i> round tires like the moon,

<b>19 </b>The chains, and the bracelets, and the mufflers,

<b>20 </b>The bonnets, and the ornaments of the legs, and the headbands, and the tablets, and the earrings,

<b>21 </b>The rings, and nose jewels,

<b>22 </b>The changeable suits of apparel, and the mantles, and the wimples, and the crisping pins,

<b>23 </b>The glasses, and the fine linen, and the hoods, and the veils.

<b>24 </b>And it shall come to pass, <i>that</i> instead of sweet smell there shall be stink; and instead of a girdle a rent; and instead of well set hair baldness; and instead of a stomacher a girding of sackcloth; <i>and</i> burning instead of beauty.

<b>25 </b>Thy men shall fall by the sword, and thy mighty in the war.

<b>26 </b>And her gates shall lament and mourn; and she <i>being</i> desolate shall sit upon the ground.


--------------------

CHAPTER 4

<b>1 </b>And in that day seven women shall take hold of one man, saying, We will eat our own bread, and wear our own apparel: only let us be called by thy name, to take away our reproach.

<b>2 </b>In that day shall the branch of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> be beautiful and glorious, and the fruit of the earth <i>shall be</i> excellent and comely for them that are escaped of Israel.

<b>3 </b>And it shall come to pass, <i>that he that is</i> left in Zion, and <i>he that</i> remaineth in Jerusalem, shall be called holy, <i>even</i> every one that is written among the living in Jerusalem:

<b>4 </b>When the Lord shall have washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion, and shall have purged the blood of Jerusalem from the midst thereof by the spirit of judgment, and by the spirit of burning.

<b>5 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will create upon every dwelling place of mount Zion, and upon her assemblies, a cloud and smoke by day, and the shining of a flaming fire by night: for upon all the glory <i>shall be</i> a defence.

<b>6 </b>And there shall be a tabernacle for a shadow in the daytime from the heat, and for a place of refuge, and for a covert from storm and from rain.


--------------------

CHAPTER 5

<b>1 </b>Now will I sing to my wellbeloved a song of my beloved touching his vineyard. My wellbeloved hath a vineyard in a very fruitful hill:

<b>2 </b>And he fenced it, and gathered out the stones thereof, and planted it with the choicest vine, and built a tower in the midst of it, and also made a winepress therein: and he looked that it should bring forth grapes, and it brought forth wild grapes.

<b>3 </b>And now, O inhabitants of Jerusalem, and men of Judah, judge, I pray you, betwixt me and my vineyard.

<b>4 </b>What could have been done more to my vineyard, that I have not done in it? wherefore, when I looked that it should bring forth grapes, brought it forth wild grapes?

<b>5 </b>And now go to; I will tell you what I will do to my vineyard: I will take away the hedge thereof, and it shall be eaten up; <i>and</i> break down the wall thereof, and it shall be trodden down:

<b>6 </b>And I will lay it waste: it shall not be pruned, nor digged; but there shall come up briers and thorns: I will also command the clouds that they rain no rain upon it.

<b>7 </b>For the vineyard of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts <i>is</i> the house of Israel, and the men of Judah his pleasant plant: and he looked for judgment, but behold oppression; for righteousness, but behold a cry.

<b>8 </b>¶ Woe unto them that join house to house, <i>that</i> lay field to field, till <i>there be</i> no place, that they may be placed alone in the midst of the earth!

<b>9 </b>In mine ears <i>said</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, Of a truth many houses shall be desolate, <i>even</i> great and fair, without inhabitant.

<b>10 </b>Yea, ten acres of vineyard shall yield one bath, and the seed of an homer shall yield an ephah.

<b>11 </b>¶ Woe unto them that rise up early in the morning, <i>that</i> they may follow strong drink; that continue until night, <i>till</i> wine inflame them!

<b>12 </b>And the harp, and the viol, the tabret, and pipe, and wine, are in their feasts: but they regard not the work of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, neither consider the operation of his hands.

<b>13 </b>¶ Therefore my people are gone into captivity, because <i>they have</i> no knowledge: and their honourable men <i>are</i> famished, and their multitude dried up with thirst.

<b>14 </b>Therefore hell hath enlarged herself, and opened her mouth without measure: and their glory, and their multitude, and their pomp, and he that rejoiceth, shall descend into it.

<b>15 </b>And the mean man shall be brought down, and the mighty man shall be humbled, and the eyes of the lofty shall be humbled:

<b>16 </b>But the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts shall be exalted in judgment, and God that is holy shall be sanctified in righteousness.

<b>17 </b>Then shall the lambs feed after their manner, and the waste places of the fat ones shall strangers eat.

<b>18 </b>Woe unto them that draw iniquity with cords of vanity, and sin as it were with a cart rope:

<b>19 </b>That say, Let him make speed, <i>and</i> hasten his work, that we may see <i>it:</i> and let the counsel of the Holy One of Israel draw nigh and come, that we may know <i>it!</i>

<b>20 </b>¶ Woe unto them that call evil good, and good evil; that put darkness for light, and light for darkness; that put bitter for sweet, and sweet for bitter!

<b>21 </b>Woe unto <i>them that are</i> wise in their own eyes, and prudent in their own sight!

<b>22 </b>Woe unto <i>them that are</i> mighty to drink wine, and men of strength to mingle strong drink:

<b>23 </b>Which justify the wicked for reward, and take away the righteousness of the righteous from him!

<b>24 </b>Therefore as the fire devoureth the stubble, and the flame consumeth the chaff, <i>so</i> their root shall be as rottenness, and their blossom shall go up as dust: because they have cast away the law of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, and despised the word of the Holy One of Israel.

<b>25 </b>Therefore is the anger of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> kindled against his people, and he hath stretched forth his hand against them, and hath smitten them: and the hills did tremble, and their carcases <i>were</i> torn in the midst of the streets. For all this his anger is not turned away, but his hand <i>is</i> stretched out still.

<b>26 </b>¶ And he will lift up an ensign to the nations from far, and will hiss unto them from the end of the earth: and, behold, they shall come with speed swiftly:

<b>27 </b>None shall be weary nor stumble among them; none shall slumber nor sleep; neither shall the girdle of their loins be loosed, nor the latchet of their shoes be broken:

<b>28 </b>Whose arrows <i>are</i> sharp, and all their bows bent, their horses’ hoofs shall be counted like flint, and their wheels like a whirlwind:

<b>29 </b>Their roaring <i>shall be</i> like a lion, they shall roar like young lions: yea, they shall roar, and lay hold of the prey, and shall carry <i>it</i> away safe, and none shall deliver <i>it.</i>

<b>30 </b>And in that day they shall roar against them like the roaring of the sea: and if <i>one</i> look unto the land, behold darkness <i>and</i> sorrow, and the light is darkened in the heavens thereof.


--------------------

CHAPTER 6

<b>1 </b>In the year that king Uzziah died I saw also the Lord sitting upon a throne, high and lifted up, and his train filled the temple.

<b>2 </b>Above it stood the seraphims: each one had six wings; with twain he covered his face, and with twain he covered his feet, and with twain he did fly.

<b>3 </b>And one cried unto another, and said, Holy, holy, holy, <i>is</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts: the whole earth <i>is</i> full of his glory.

<b>4 </b>And the posts of the door moved at the voice of him that cried, and the house was filled with smoke.

<b>5 </b>¶ Then said I, Woe <i>is</i> me! for I am undone; because I <i>am</i> a man of unclean lips, and I dwell in the midst of a people of unclean lips: for mine eyes have seen the King, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts.

<b>6 </b>Then flew one of the seraphims unto me, having a live coal in his hand, <i>which</i> he had taken with the tongs from off the altar:

<b>7 </b>And he laid <i>it</i> upon my mouth, and said, Lo, this hath touched thy lips; and thine iniquity is taken away, and thy sin purged.

<b>8 </b>Also I heard the voice of the Lord, saying, Whom shall I send, and who will go for us? Then said I, Here <i>am</i> I; send me.

<b>9 </b>¶ And he said, Go, and tell this people, Hear ye indeed, but understand not; and see ye indeed, but perceive not.

<b>10 </b>Make the heart of this people fat, and make their ears heavy, and shut their eyes; lest they see with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and understand with their heart, and convert, and be healed.

<b>11 </b>Then said I, Lord, how long? And he answered, Until the cities be wasted without inhabitant, and the houses without man, and the land be utterly desolate,

<b>12 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> have removed men far away, and <i>there be</i> a great forsaking in the midst of the land.

<b>13 </b>¶ But yet in it <i>shall be</i> a tenth, and <i>it</i> shall return, and shall be eaten: as a teil tree, and as an oak, whose substance <i>is</i> in them, when they cast <i>their leaves: so</i> the holy seed <i>shall be</i> the substance thereof.


--------------------

CHAPTER 7

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass in the days of Ahaz the son of Jotham, the son of Uzziah, king of Judah, <i>that</i> Rezin the king of Syria, and Pekah the son of Remaliah, king of Israel, went up toward Jerusalem to war against it, but could not prevail against it.

<b>2 </b>And it was told the house of David, saying, Syria is confederate with Ephraim. And his heart was moved, and the heart of his people, as the trees of the wood are moved with the wind.

<b>3 </b>Then said the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto Isaiah, Go forth now to meet Ahaz, thou, and Shear-jashub thy son, at the end of the conduit of the upper pool in the highway of the fuller’s field;

<b>4 </b>And say unto him, Take heed, and be quiet; fear not, neither be fainthearted for the two tails of these smoking firebrands, for the fierce anger of Rezin with Syria, and of the son of Remaliah.

<b>5 </b>Because Syria, Ephraim, and the son of Remaliah, have taken evil counsel against thee, saying,

<b>6 </b>Let us go up against Judah, and vex it, and let us make a breach therein for us, and set a king in the midst of it, <i>even</i> the son of Tabeal:

<b>7 </b>Thus saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>, It shall not stand, neither shall it come to pass.

<b>8 </b>For the head of Syria <i>is</i> Damascus, and the head of Damascus <i>is</i> Rezin; and within threescore and five years shall Ephraim be broken, that it be not a people.

<b>9 </b>And the head of Ephraim <i>is</i> Samaria, and the head of Samaria <i>is</i> Remaliah’s son. If ye will not believe, surely ye shall not be established.

<b>10 </b>¶ Moreover the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake again unto Ahaz, saying,

<b>11 </b>Ask thee a sign of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God; ask it either in the depth, or in the height above.

<b>12 </b>But Ahaz said, I will not ask, neither will I tempt the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>13 </b>And he said, Hear ye now, O house of David; <i>Is it</i> a small thing for you to weary men, but will ye weary my God also?

<b>14 </b>Therefore the Lord himself shall give you a sign; Behold, a virgin shall conceive, and bear a son, and shall call his name Immanuel.

<b>15 </b>Butter and honey shall he eat, that he may know to refuse the evil, and choose the good.

<b>16 </b>For before the child shall know to refuse the evil, and choose the good, the land that thou abhorrest shall be forsaken of both her kings.

<b>17 </b>¶ The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall bring upon thee, and upon thy people, and upon thy father’s house, days that have not come, from the day that Ephraim departed from Judah; <i>even</i> the king of Assyria.

<b>18 </b>And it shall come to pass in that day, <i>that</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall hiss for the fly that <i>is</i> in the uttermost part of the rivers of Egypt, and for the bee that <i>is</i> in the land of Assyria.

<b>19 </b>And they shall come, and shall rest all of them in the desolate valleys, and in the holes of the rocks, and upon all thorns, and upon all bushes.

<b>20 </b>In the same day shall the Lord shave with a razor that is hired, <i>namely,</i> by them beyond the river, by the king of Assyria, the head, and the hair of the feet: and it shall also consume the beard.

<b>21 </b>And it shall come to pass in that day, <i>that</i> a man shall nourish a young cow, and two sheep;

<b>22 </b>And it shall come to pass, for the abundance of milk <i>that</i> they shall give he shall eat butter: for butter and honey shall every one eat that is left in the land.

<b>23 </b>And it shall come to pass in that day, <i>that</i> every place shall be, where there were a thousand vines at a thousand silverlings, it shall <i>even</i> be for briers and thorns.

<b>24 </b>With arrows and with bows shall <i>men</i> come thither; because all the land shall become briers and thorns.

<b>25 </b>And <i>on</i> all hills that shall be digged with the mattock, there shall not come thither the fear of briers and thorns: but it shall be for the sending forth of oxen, and for the treading of lesser cattle.


--------------------

CHAPTER 8

<b>1 </b>Moreover the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, Take thee a great roll, and write in it with a man’s pen concerning Maher-shalal-hash-baz.

<b>2 </b>And I took unto me faithful witnesses to record, Uriah the priest, and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah.

<b>3 </b>And I went unto the prophetess; and she conceived, and bare a son. Then said the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> to me, Call his name Maher-shalal-hash-baz.

<b>4 </b>For before the child shall have knowledge to cry, My father, and my mother, the riches of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria shall be taken away before the king of Assyria.

<b>5 </b>¶ The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake also unto me again, saying,

<b>6 </b>Forasmuch as this people refuseth the waters of Shiloah that go softly, and rejoice in Rezin and Remaliah’s son;

<b>7 </b>Now therefore, behold, the Lord bringeth up upon them the waters of the river, strong and many, <i>even</i> the king of Assyria, and all his glory: and he shall come up over all his channels, and go over all his banks:

<b>8 </b>And he shall pass through Judah; he shall overflow and go over, he shall reach <i>even</i> to the neck; and the stretching out of his wings shall fill the breadth of thy land, O Immanuel.

<b>9 </b>¶ Associate yourselves, O ye people, and ye shall be broken in pieces; and give ear, all ye of far countries: gird yourselves, and ye shall be broken in pieces; gird yourselves, and ye shall be broken in pieces.

<b>10 </b>Take counsel together, and it shall come to nought; speak the word, and it shall not stand: for God <i>is</i> with us.

<b>11 </b>¶ For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake thus to me with a strong hand, and instructed me that I should not walk in the way of this people, saying,

<b>12 </b>Say ye not, A confederacy, to all <i>them to</i> whom this people shall say, A confederacy; neither fear ye their fear, nor be afraid.

<b>13 </b>Sanctify the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts himself; and <i>let</i> him <i>be</i> your fear, and <i>let</i> him <i>be</i> your dread.

<b>14 </b>And he shall be for a sanctuary; but for a stone of stumbling and for a rock of offence to both the houses of Israel, for a gin and for a snare to the inhabitants of Jerusalem.

<b>15 </b>And many among them shall stumble, and fall, and be broken, and be snared, and be taken.

<b>16 </b>Bind up the testimony, seal the law among my disciples.

<b>17 </b>And I will wait upon the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that hideth his face from the house of Jacob, and I will look for him.

<b>18 </b>Behold, I and the children whom the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath given me <i>are</i> for signs and for wonders in Israel from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, which dwelleth in mount Zion.

<b>19 </b>¶ And when they shall say unto you, Seek unto them that have familiar spirits, and unto wizards that peep, and that mutter: should not a people seek unto their God? for the living to the dead?

<b>20 </b>To the law and to the testimony: if they speak not according to this word, <i>it is</i> because <i>there is</i> no light in them.

<b>21 </b>And they shall pass through it, hardly bestead and hungry: and it shall come to pass, that when they shall be hungry, they shall fret themselves, and curse their king and their God, and look upward.

<b>22 </b>And they shall look unto the earth; and behold trouble and darkness, dimness of anguish; and <i>they shall be</i> driven to darkness.


--------------------

CHAPTER 9

<b>1 </b>Nevertheless the dimness <i>shall</i> not <i>be</i> such as <i>was</i> in her vexation, when at the first he lightly afflicted the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali, and afterward did more grievously afflict <i>her by</i> the way of the sea, beyond Jordan, in Galilee of the nations.

<b>2 </b>The people that walked in darkness have seen a great light: they that dwell in the land of the shadow of death, upon them hath the light shined.

<b>3 </b>Thou hast multiplied the nation, <i>and</i> not increased the joy: they joy before thee according to the joy in harvest, <i>and</i> as <i>men</i> rejoice when they divide the spoil.

<b>4 </b>For thou hast broken the yoke of his burden, and the staff of his shoulder, the rod of his oppressor, as in the day of Midian.

<b>5 </b>For every battle of the warrior <i>is</i> with confused noise, and garments rolled in blood; but <i>this</i> shall be with burning <i>and</i> fuel of fire.

<b>6 </b>For unto us a child is born, unto us a son is given: and the government shall be upon his shoulder: and his name shall be called Wonderful, Counsellor, The mighty God, The everlasting Father, The Prince of Peace.

<b>7 </b>Of the increase of <i>his</i> government and peace <i>there shall be</i> no end, upon the throne of David, and upon his kingdom, to order it, and to establish it with judgment and with justice from henceforth even for ever. The zeal of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts will perform this.

<b>8 </b>¶ The Lord sent a word into Jacob, and it hath lighted upon Israel.

<b>9 </b>And all the people shall know, <i>even</i> Ephraim and the inhabitant of Samaria, that say in the pride and stoutness of heart,

<b>10 </b>The bricks are fallen down, but we will build with hewn stones: the sycomores are cut down, but we will change <i>them into</i> cedars.

<b>11 </b>Therefore the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall set up the adversaries of Rezin against him, and join his enemies together;

<b>12 </b>The Syrians before, and the Philistines behind; and they shall devour Israel with open mouth. For all this his anger is not turned away, but his hand <i>is</i> stretched out still.

<b>13 </b>¶ For the people turneth not unto him that smiteth them, neither do they seek the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts.

<b>14 </b>Therefore the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will cut off from Israel head and tail, branch and rush, in one day.

<b>15 </b>The ancient and honourable, he <i>is</i> the head; and the prophet that teacheth lies, he <i>is</i> the tail.

<b>16 </b>For the leaders of this people cause <i>them</i> to err; and <i>they that are</i> led of them <i>are</i> destroyed.

<b>17 </b>Therefore the Lord shall have no joy in their young men, neither shall have mercy on their fatherless and widows: for every one <i>is</i> an hypocrite and an evildoer, and every mouth speaketh folly. For all this his anger is not turned away, but his hand <i>is</i> stretched out still.

<b>18 </b>¶ For wickedness burneth as the fire: it shall devour the briers and thorns, and shall kindle in the thickets of the forest, and they shall mount up <i>like</i> the lifting up of smoke.

<b>19 </b>Through the wrath of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts is the land darkened, and the people shall be as the fuel of the fire: no man shall spare his brother.

<b>20 </b>And he shall snatch on the right hand, and be hungry; and he shall eat on the left hand, and they shall not be satisfied: they shall eat every man the flesh of his own arm:

<b>21 </b>Manasseh, Ephraim; and Ephraim, Manasseh: <i>and</i> they together <i>shall be</i> against Judah. For all this his anger is not turned away, but his hand <i>is</i> stretched out still.


--------------------

CHAPTER 10

<b>1 </b>Woe unto them that decree unrighteous decrees, and that write grievousness <i>which</i> they have prescribed;

<b>2 </b>To turn aside the needy from judgment, and to take away the right from the poor of my people, that widows may be their prey, and <i>that</i> they may rob the fatherless!

<b>3 </b>And what will ye do in the day of visitation, and in the desolation <i>which</i> shall come from far? to whom will ye flee for help? and where will ye leave your glory?

<b>4 </b>Without me they shall bow down under the prisoners, and they shall fall under the slain. For all this his anger is not turned away, but his hand <i>is</i> stretched out still.

<b>5 </b>¶ O Assyrian, the rod of mine anger, and the staff in their hand is mine indignation.

<b>6 </b>I will send him against an hypocritical nation, and against the people of my wrath will I give him a charge, to take the spoil, and to take the prey, and to tread them down like the mire of the streets.

<b>7 </b>Howbeit he meaneth not so, neither doth his heart think so; but <i>it is</i> in his heart to destroy and cut off nations not a few.

<b>8 </b>For he saith, <i>Are</i> not my princes altogether kings?

<b>9 </b><i>Is</i> not Calno as Carchemish? <i>is</i> not Hamath as Arpad? <i>is</i> not Samaria as Damascus?

<b>10 </b>As my hand hath found the kingdoms of the idols, and whose graven images did excel them of Jerusalem and of Samaria;

<b>11 </b>Shall I not, as I have done unto Samaria and her idols, so do to Jerusalem and her idols?

<b>12 </b>Wherefore it shall come to pass, <i>that</i> when the Lord hath performed his whole work upon mount Zion and on Jerusalem, I will punish the fruit of the stout heart of the king of Assyria, and the glory of his high looks.

<b>13 </b>For he saith, By the strength of my hand I have done <i>it,</i> and by my wisdom; for I am prudent: and I have removed the bounds of the people, and have robbed their treasures, and I have put down the inhabitants like a valiant <i>man:</i>

<b>14 </b>And my hand hath found as a nest the riches of the people: and as one gathereth eggs <i>that are</i> left, have I gathered all the earth; and there was none that moved the wing, or opened the mouth, or peeped.

<b>15 </b>Shall the axe boast itself against him that heweth therewith? <i>or</i> shall the saw magnify itself against him that shaketh it? as if the rod should shake <i>itself</i> against them that lift it up, <i>or</i> as if the staff should lift up <i>itself, as if it were</i> no wood.

<b>16 </b>Therefore shall the Lord, the Lord of hosts, send among his fat ones leanness; and under his glory he shall kindle a burning like the burning of a fire.

<b>17 </b>And the light of Israel shall be for a fire, and his Holy One for a flame: and it shall burn and devour his thorns and his briers in one day;

<b>18 </b>And shall consume the glory of his forest, and of his fruitful field, both soul and body: and they shall be as when a standardbearer fainteth.

<b>19 </b>And the rest of the trees of his forest shall be few, that a child may write them.

<b>20 </b>¶ And it shall come to pass in that day, <i>that</i> the remnant of Israel, and such as are escaped of the house of Jacob, shall no more again stay upon him that smote them; but shall stay upon the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the Holy One of Israel, in truth.

<b>21 </b>The remnant shall return, <i>even</i> the remnant of Jacob, unto the mighty God.

<b>22 </b>For though thy people Israel be as the sand of the sea, <i>yet</i> a remnant of them shall return: the consumption decreed shall overflow with righteousness.

<b>23 </b>For the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> of hosts shall make a consumption, even determined, in the midst of all the land.

<b>24 </b>¶ Therefore thus saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> of hosts, O my people that dwellest in Zion, be not afraid of the Assyrian: he shall smite thee with a rod, and shall lift up his staff against thee, after the manner of Egypt.

<b>25 </b>For yet a very little while, and the indignation shall cease, and mine anger in their destruction.

<b>26 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts shall stir up a scourge for him according to the slaughter of Midian at the rock of Oreb: and <i>as</i> his rod <i>was</i> upon the sea, so shall he lift it up after the manner of Egypt.

<b>27 </b>And it shall come to pass in that day, <i>that</i> his burden shall be taken away from off thy shoulder, and his yoke from off thy neck, and the yoke shall be destroyed because of the anointing.

<b>28 </b>He is come to Aiath, he is passed to Migron; at Michmash he hath laid up his carriages:

<b>29 </b>They are gone over the passage: they have taken up their lodging at Geba; Ramah is afraid; Gibeah of Saul is fled.

<b>30 </b>Lift up thy voice, O daughter of Gallim: cause it to be heard unto Laish, O poor Anathoth.

<b>31 </b>Madmenah is removed; the inhabitants of Gebim gather themselves to flee.

<b>32 </b>As yet shall he remain at Nob that day: he shall shake his hand <i>against</i> the mount of the daughter of Zion, the hill of Jerusalem.

<b>33 </b>Behold, the Lord, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, shall lop the bough with terror: and the high ones of stature <i>shall be</i> hewn down, and the haughty shall be humbled.

<b>34 </b>And he shall cut down the thickets of the forest with iron, and Lebanon shall fall by a mighty one.


--------------------

CHAPTER 11

<b>1 </b>And there shall come forth a rod out of the stem of Jesse, and a Branch shall grow out of his roots:

<b>2 </b>And the spirit of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall rest upon him, the spirit of wisdom and understanding, the spirit of counsel and might, the spirit of knowledge and of the fear of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>;

<b>3 </b>And shall make him of quick understanding in the fear of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and he shall not judge after the sight of his eyes, neither reprove after the hearing of his ears:

<b>4 </b>But with righteousness shall he judge the poor, and reprove with equity for the meek of the earth: and he shall smite the earth with the rod of his mouth, and with the breath of his lips shall he slay the wicked.

<b>5 </b>And righteousness shall be the girdle of his loins, and faithfulness the girdle of his reins.

<b>6 </b>The wolf also shall dwell with the lamb, and the leopard shall lie down with the kid; and the calf and the young lion and the fatling together; and a little child shall lead them.

<b>7 </b>And the cow and the bear shall feed; their young ones shall lie down together: and the lion shall eat straw like the ox.

<b>8 </b>And the sucking child shall play on the hole of the asp, and the weaned child shall put his hand on the cockatrice’ den.

<b>9 </b>They shall not hurt nor destroy in all my holy mountain: for the earth shall be full of the knowledge of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, as the waters cover the sea.

<b>10 </b>¶ And in that day there shall be a root of Jesse, which shall stand for an ensign of the people; to it shall the Gentiles seek: and his rest shall be glorious.

<b>11 </b>And it shall come to pass in that day, <i>that</i> the Lord shall set his hand again the second time to recover the remnant of his people, which shall be left, from Assyria, and from Egypt, and from Pathros, and from Cush, and from Elam, and from Shinar, and from Hamath, and from the islands of the sea.

<b>12 </b>And he shall set up an ensign for the nations, and shall assemble the outcasts of Israel, and gather together the dispersed of Judah from the four corners of the earth.

<b>13 </b>The envy also of Ephraim shall depart, and the adversaries of Judah shall be cut off: Ephraim shall not envy Judah, and Judah shall not vex Ephraim.

<b>14 </b>But they shall fly upon the shoulders of the Philistines toward the west; they shall spoil them of the east together: they shall lay their hand upon Edom and Moab; and the children of Ammon shall obey them.

<b>15 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall utterly destroy the tongue of the Egyptian sea; and with his mighty wind shall he shake his hand over the river, and shall smite it in the seven streams, and make <i>men</i> go over dryshod.

<b>16 </b>And there shall be an highway for the remnant of his people, which shall be left, from Assyria; like as it was to Israel in the day that he came up out of the land of Egypt.


--------------------

CHAPTER 12

<b>1 </b>And in that day thou shalt say, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, I will praise thee: though thou wast angry with me, thine anger is turned away, and thou comfortedst me.

<b>2 </b>Behold, God <i>is</i> my salvation; I will trust, and not be afraid: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <span class="uppercase">Jehovah</span> <i>is</i> my strength and <i>my</i> song; he also is become my salvation.

<b>3 </b>Therefore with joy shall ye draw water out of the wells of salvation.

<b>4 </b>And in that day shall ye say, Praise the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, call upon his name, declare his doings among the people, make mention that his name is exalted.

<b>5 </b>Sing unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for he hath done excellent things: this <i>is</i> known in all the earth.

<b>6 </b>Cry out and shout, thou inhabitant of Zion: for great <i>is</i> the Holy One of Israel in the midst of thee.


--------------------

CHAPTER 13

<b>1 </b>The burden of Babylon, which Isaiah the son of Amoz did see.

<b>2 </b>Lift ye up a banner upon the high mountain, exalt the voice unto them, shake the hand, that they may go into the gates of the nobles.

<b>3 </b>I have commanded my sanctified ones, I have also called my mighty ones for mine anger, <i>even</i> them that rejoice in my highness.

<b>4 </b>The noise of a multitude in the mountains, like as of a great people; a tumultuous noise of the kingdoms of nations gathered together: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts mustereth the host of the battle.

<b>5 </b>They come from a far country, from the end of heaven, <i>even</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and the weapons of his indignation, to destroy the whole land.

<b>6 </b>¶ Howl ye; for the day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> at hand; it shall come as a destruction from the Almighty.

<b>7 </b>Therefore shall all hands be faint, and every man’s heart shall melt:

<b>8 </b>And they shall be afraid: pangs and sorrows shall take hold of them; they shall be in pain as a woman that travaileth: they shall be amazed one at another; their faces <i>shall be as</i> flames.

<b>9 </b>Behold, the day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> cometh, cruel both with wrath and fierce anger, to lay the land desolate: and he shall destroy the sinners thereof out of it.

<b>10 </b>For the stars of heaven and the constellations thereof shall not give their light: the sun shall be darkened in his going forth, and the moon shall not cause her light to shine.

<b>11 </b>And I will punish the world for <i>their</i> evil, and the wicked for their iniquity; and I will cause the arrogancy of the proud to cease, and will lay low the haughtiness of the terrible.

<b>12 </b>I will make a man more precious than fine gold; even a man than the golden wedge of Ophir.

<b>13 </b>Therefore I will shake the heavens, and the earth shall remove out of her place, in the wrath of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, and in the day of his fierce anger.

<b>14 </b>And it shall be as the chased roe, and as a sheep that no man taketh up: they shall every man turn to his own people, and flee every one into his own land.

<b>15 </b>Every one that is found shall be thrust through; and every one that is joined <i>unto them</i> shall fall by the sword.

<b>16 </b>Their children also shall be dashed to pieces before their eyes; their houses shall be spoiled, and their wives ravished.

<b>17 </b>Behold, I will stir up the Medes against them, which shall not regard silver; and <i>as for</i> gold, they shall not delight in it.

<b>18 </b><i>Their</i> bows also shall dash the young men to pieces; and they shall have no pity on the fruit of the womb; their eye shall not spare children.

<b>19 </b>¶ And Babylon, the glory of kingdoms, the beauty of the Chaldees’ excellency, shall be as when God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah.

<b>20 </b>It shall never be inhabited, neither shall it be dwelt in from generation to generation: neither shall the Arabian pitch tent there; neither shall the shepherds make their fold there.

<b>21 </b>But wild beasts of the desert shall lie there; and their houses shall be full of doleful creatures; and owls shall dwell there, and satyrs shall dance there.

<b>22 </b>And the wild beasts of the islands shall cry in their desolate houses, and dragons in <i>their</i> pleasant palaces: and her time <i>is</i> near to come, and her days shall not be prolonged.


--------------------

CHAPTER 14

<b>1 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will have mercy on Jacob, and will yet choose Israel, and set them in their own land: and the strangers shall be joined with them, and they shall cleave to the house of Jacob.

<b>2 </b>And the people shall take them, and bring them to their place: and the house of Israel shall possess them in the land of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> for servants and handmaids: and they shall take them captives, whose captives they were; and they shall rule over their oppressors.

<b>3 </b>And it shall come to pass in the day that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall give thee rest from thy sorrow, and from thy fear, and from the hard bondage wherein thou wast made to serve,

<b>4 </b>¶ That thou shalt take up this proverb against the king of Babylon, and say, How hath the oppressor ceased! the golden city ceased!

<b>5 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath broken the staff of the wicked, <i>and</i> the sceptre of the rulers.

<b>6 </b>He who smote the people in wrath with a continual stroke, he that ruled the nations in anger, is persecuted, <i>and</i> none hindereth.

<b>7 </b>The whole earth is at rest, <i>and</i> is quiet: they break forth into singing.

<b>8 </b>Yea, the fir trees rejoice at thee, <i>and</i> the cedars of Lebanon, <i>saying,</i> Since thou art laid down, no feller is come up against us.

<b>9 </b>Hell from beneath is moved for thee to meet <i>thee</i> at thy coming: it stirreth up the dead for thee, <i>even</i> all the chief ones of the earth; it hath raised up from their thrones all the kings of the nations.

<b>10 </b>All they shall speak and say unto thee, Art thou also become weak as we? art thou become like unto us?

<b>11 </b>Thy pomp is brought down to the grave, <i>and</i> the noise of thy viols: the worm is spread under thee, and the worms cover thee.

<b>12 </b>How art thou fallen from heaven, O Lucifer, son of the morning! <i>how</i> art thou cut down to the ground, which didst weaken the nations!

<b>13 </b>For thou hast said in thine heart, I will ascend into heaven, I will exalt my throne above the stars of God: I will sit also upon the mount of the congregation, in the sides of the north:

<b>14 </b>I will ascend above the heights of the clouds; I will be like the most High.

<b>15 </b>Yet thou shalt be brought down to hell, to the sides of the pit.

<b>16 </b>They that see thee shall narrowly look upon thee, <i>and</i> consider thee, <i>saying, Is</i> this the man that made the earth to tremble, that did shake kingdoms;

<b>17 </b><i>That</i> made the world as a wilderness, and destroyed the cities thereof; <i>that</i> opened not the house of his prisoners?

<b>18 </b>All the kings of the nations, <i>even</i> all of them, lie in glory, every one in his own house.

<b>19 </b>But thou art cast out of thy grave like an abominable branch, <i>and as</i> the raiment of those that are slain, thrust through with a sword, that go down to the stones of the pit; as a carcase trodden under feet.

<b>20 </b>Thou shalt not be joined with them in burial, because thou hast destroyed thy land, <i>and</i> slain thy people: the seed of evildoers shall never be renowned.

<b>21 </b>Prepare slaughter for his children for the iniquity of their fathers; that they do not rise, nor possess the land, nor fill the face of the world with cities.

<b>22 </b>For I will rise up against them, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, and cut off from Babylon the name, and remnant, and son, and nephew, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>23 </b>I will also make it a possession for the bittern, and pools of water: and I will sweep it with the besom of destruction, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts.

<b>24 </b>¶ The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts hath sworn, saying, Surely as I have thought, so shall it come to pass; and as I have purposed, <i>so</i> shall it stand:

<b>25 </b>That I will break the Assyrian in my land, and upon my mountains tread him under foot: then shall his yoke depart from off them, and his burden depart from off their shoulders.

<b>26 </b>This <i>is</i> the purpose that is purposed upon the whole earth: and this <i>is</i> the hand that is stretched out upon all the nations.

<b>27 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts hath purposed, and who shall disannul <i>it?</i> and his hand <i>is</i> stretched out, and who shall turn it back?

<b>28 </b>In the year that king Ahaz died was this burden.

<b>29 </b>¶ Rejoice not thou, whole Palestina, because the rod of him that smote thee is broken: for out of the serpent’s root shall come forth a cockatrice, and his fruit <i>shall be</i> a fiery flying serpent.

<b>30 </b>And the firstborn of the poor shall feed, and the needy shall lie down in safety: and I will kill thy root with famine, and he shall slay thy remnant.

<b>31 </b>Howl, O gate; cry, O city; thou, whole Palestina, <i>art</i> dissolved: for there shall come from the north a smoke, and none <i>shall be</i> alone in his appointed times.

<b>32 </b>What shall <i>one</i> then answer the messengers of the nation? That the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath founded Zion, and the poor of his people shall trust in it.


--------------------

CHAPTER 15
