<b>16 </b>O Lord, by these <i>things men</i> live, and in all these <i>things is</i> the life of my spirit: so wilt thou recover me, and make me to live.

<b>17 </b>Behold, for peace I had great bitterness: but thou hast in love to my soul <i>delivered it</i> from the pit of corruption: for thou hast cast all my sins behind thy back.

<b>18 </b>For the grave cannot praise thee, death can <i>not</i> celebrate thee: they that go down into the pit cannot hope for thy truth.

<b>19 </b>The living, the living, he shall praise thee, as I <i>do</i> this day: the father to the children shall make known thy truth.

<b>20 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>was ready</i> to save me: therefore we will sing my songs to the stringed instruments all the days of our life in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>21 </b>For Isaiah had said, Let them take a lump of figs, and lay <i>it</i> for a plaster upon the boil, and he shall recover.

<b>22 </b>Hezekiah also had said, What <i>is</i> the sign that I shall go up to the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>?


--------------------

CHAPTER 39

<b>1 </b>At that time Merodach-baladan, the son of Baladan, king of Babylon, sent letters and a present to Hezekiah: for he had heard that he had been sick, and was recovered.

<b>2 </b>And Hezekiah was glad of them, and shewed them the house of his precious things, the silver, and the gold, and the spices, and the precious ointment, and all the house of his armour, and all that was found in his treasures: there was nothing in his house, nor in all his dominion, that Hezekiah shewed them not.

<b>3 </b>¶ Then came Isaiah the prophet unto king Hezekiah, and said unto him, What said these men? and from whence came they unto thee? And Hezekiah said, They are come from a far country unto me, <i>even</i> from Babylon.

<b>4 </b>Then said he, What have they seen in thine house? And Hezekiah answered, All that <i>is</i> in mine house have they seen: there is nothing among my treasures that I have not shewed them.

<b>5 </b>Then said Isaiah to Hezekiah, Hear the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts:

<b>6 </b>Behold, the days come, that all that <i>is</i> in thine house, and <i>that</i> which thy fathers have laid up in store until this day, shall be carried to Babylon: nothing shall be left, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>7 </b>And of thy sons that shall issue from thee, which thou shalt beget, shall they take away; and they shall be eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon.

<b>8 </b>Then said Hezekiah to Isaiah, Good <i>is</i> the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> which thou hast spoken. He said moreover, For there shall be peace and truth in my days.


--------------------

CHAPTER 40

<b>1 </b>Comfort ye, comfort ye my people, saith your God.

<b>2 </b>Speak ye comfortably to Jerusalem, and cry unto her, that her warfare is accomplished, that her iniquity is pardoned: for she hath received of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s hand double for all her sins.

<b>3 </b>¶ The voice of him that crieth in the wilderness, Prepare ye the way of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, make straight in the desert a highway for our God.

<b>4 </b>Every valley shall be exalted, and every mountain and hill shall be made low: and the crooked shall be made straight, and the rough places plain:

<b>5 </b>And the glory of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall be revealed, and all flesh shall see <i>it</i> together: for the mouth of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath spoken <i>it.</i>

<b>6 </b>The voice said, Cry. And he said, What shall I cry? All flesh <i>is</i> grass, and all the goodliness thereof <i>is</i> as the flower of the field:

<b>7 </b>The grass withereth, the flower fadeth: because the spirit of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> bloweth upon it: surely the people <i>is</i> grass.

<b>8 </b>The grass withereth, the flower fadeth: but the word of our God shall stand for ever.

<b>9 </b>¶ O Zion, that bringest good tidings, get thee up into the high mountain; O Jerusalem, that bringest good tidings, lift up thy voice with strength; lift <i>it</i> up, be not afraid; say unto the cities of Judah, Behold your God!

<b>10 </b>Behold, the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> will come with strong <i>hand,</i> and his arm shall rule for him: behold, his reward <i>is</i> with him, and his work before him.

<b>11 </b>He shall feed his flock like a shepherd: he shall gather the lambs with his arm, and carry <i>them</i> in his bosom, <i>and</i> shall gently lead those that are with young.

<b>12 </b>¶ Who hath measured the waters in the hollow of his hand, and meted out heaven with the span, and comprehended the dust of the earth in a measure, and weighed the mountains in scales, and the hills in a balance?

<b>13 </b>Who hath directed the Spirit of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, or <i>being</i> his counsellor hath taught him?

<b>14 </b>With whom took he counsel, and <i>who</i> instructed him, and taught him in the path of judgment, and taught him knowledge, and shewed to him the way of understanding?

<b>15 </b>Behold, the nations <i>are</i> as a drop of a bucket, and are counted as the small dust of the balance: behold, he taketh up the isles as a very little thing.

<b>16 </b>And Lebanon <i>is</i> not sufficient to burn, nor the beasts thereof sufficient for a burnt offering.

<b>17 </b>All nations before him <i>are</i> as nothing; and they are counted to him less than nothing, and vanity.

<b>18 </b>¶ To whom then will ye liken God? or what likeness will ye compare unto him?

<b>19 </b>The workman melteth a graven image, and the goldsmith spreadeth it over with gold, and casteth silver chains.

<b>20 </b>He that <i>is</i> so impoverished that he hath no oblation chooseth a tree <i>that</i> will not rot; he seeketh unto him a cunning workman to prepare a graven image, <i>that</i> shall not be moved.

<b>21 </b>Have ye not known? have ye not heard? hath it not been told you from the beginning? have ye not understood from the foundations of the earth?

<b>22 </b><i>It is</i> he that sitteth upon the circle of the earth, and the inhabitants thereof <i>are</i> as grasshoppers; that stretcheth out the heavens as a curtain, and spreadeth them out as a tent to dwell in:

<b>23 </b>That bringeth the princes to nothing; he maketh the judges of the earth as vanity.

<b>24 </b>Yea, they shall not be planted; yea, they shall not be sown: yea, their stock shall not take root in the earth: and he shall also blow upon them, and they shall wither, and the whirlwind shall take them away as stubble.

<b>25 </b>To whom then will ye liken me, or shall I be equal? saith the Holy One.

<b>26 </b>Lift up your eyes on high, and behold who hath created these <i>things,</i> that bringeth out their host by number: he calleth them all by names by the greatness of his might, for that <i>he is</i> strong in power; not one faileth.

<b>27 </b>Why sayest thou, O Jacob, and speakest, O Israel, My way is hid from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and my judgment is passed over from my God?

<b>28 </b>¶ Hast thou not known? hast thou not heard, <i>that</i> the everlasting God, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the Creator of the ends of the earth, fainteth not, neither is weary? <i>there is</i> no searching of his understanding.

<b>29 </b>He giveth power to the faint; and to <i>them that have</i> no might he increaseth strength.

<b>30 </b>Even the youths shall faint and be weary, and the young men shall utterly fall:

<b>31 </b>But they that wait upon the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall renew <i>their</i> strength; they shall mount up with wings as eagles; they shall run, and not be weary; <i>and</i> they shall walk, and not faint.


--------------------

CHAPTER 41

<b>1 </b>Keep silence before me, O islands; and let the people renew <i>their</i> strength: let them come near; then let them speak: let us come near together to judgment.

<b>2 </b>Who raised up the righteous <i>man</i> from the east, called him to his foot, gave the nations before him, and made <i>him</i> rule over kings? he gave <i>them</i> as the dust to his sword, <i>and</i> as driven stubble to his bow.

<b>3 </b>He pursued them, <i>and</i> passed safely; <i>even</i> by the way <i>that</i> he had not gone with his feet.

<b>4 </b>Who hath wrought and done <i>it,</i> calling the generations from the beginning? I the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the first, and with the last; I <i>am</i> he.

<b>5 </b>The isles saw <i>it,</i> and feared; the ends of the earth were afraid, drew near, and came.

<b>6 </b>They helped every one his neighbour; and <i>every one</i> said to his brother, Be of good courage.

<b>7 </b>So the carpenter encouraged the goldsmith, <i>and</i> he that smootheth <i>with</i> the hammer him that smote the anvil, saying, It <i>is</i> ready for the sodering: and he fastened it with nails, <i>that</i> it should not be moved.

<b>8 </b>But thou, Israel, <i>art</i> my servant, Jacob whom I have chosen, the seed of Abraham my friend.

<b>9 </b><i>Thou</i> whom I have taken from the ends of the earth, and called thee from the chief men thereof, and said unto thee, Thou <i>art</i> my servant; I have chosen thee, and not cast thee away.

<b>10 </b>¶ Fear thou not; for I <i>am</i> with thee: be not dismayed; for I <i>am</i> thy God: I will strengthen thee; yea, I will help thee; yea, I will uphold thee with the right hand of my righteousness.

<b>11 </b>Behold, all they that were incensed against thee shall be ashamed and confounded: they shall be as nothing; and they that strive with thee shall perish.

<b>12 </b>Thou shalt seek them, and shalt not find them, <i>even</i> them that contended with thee: they that war against thee shall be as nothing, and as a thing of nought.

<b>13 </b>For I the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God will hold thy right hand, saying unto thee, Fear not; I will help thee.

<b>14 </b>Fear not, thou worm Jacob, <i>and</i> ye men of Israel; I will help thee, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and thy redeemer, the Holy One of Israel.

<b>15 </b>Behold, I will make thee a new sharp threshing instrument having teeth: thou shalt thresh the mountains, and beat <i>them</i> small, and shalt make the hills as chaff.

<b>16 </b>Thou shalt fan them, and the wind shall carry them away, and the whirlwind shall scatter them: and thou shalt rejoice in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>and</i> shalt glory in the Holy One of Israel.

<b>17 </b><i>When</i> the poor and needy seek water, and <i>there is</i> none, <i>and</i> their tongue faileth for thirst, I the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will hear them, <i>I</i> the God of Israel will not forsake them.

<b>18 </b>I will open rivers in high places, and fountains in the midst of the valleys: I will make the wilderness a pool of water, and the dry land springs of water.

<b>19 </b>I will plant in the wilderness the cedar, the shittah tree, and the myrtle, and the oil tree; I will set in the desert the fir tree, <i>and</i> the pine, and the box tree together:

<b>20 </b>That they may see, and know, and consider, and understand together, that the hand of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath done this, and the Holy One of Israel hath created it.

<b>21 </b>Produce your cause, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; bring forth your strong <i>reasons</i><i>,</i> saith the King of Jacob.

<b>22 </b>Let them bring <i>them</i> forth, and shew us what shall happen: let them shew the former things, what they <i>be,</i> that we may consider them, and know the latter end of them; or declare us things for to come.

<b>23 </b>Shew the things that are to come hereafter, that we may know that ye <i>are</i> gods: yea, do good, or do evil, that we may be dismayed, and behold <i>it</i> together.

<b>24 </b>Behold, ye <i>are</i> of nothing, and your work of nought: an abomination <i>is he that</i> chooseth you.

<b>25 </b>I have raised up <i>one</i> from the north, and he shall come: from the rising of the sun shall he call upon my name: and he shall come upon princes as <i>upon</i> mortar, and as the potter treadeth clay.

<b>26 </b>Who hath declared from the beginning, that we may know? and beforetime, that we may say, <i>He is</i> righteous? yea, <i>there is</i> none that sheweth, yea, <i>there is</i> none that declareth, yea, <i>there is</i> none that heareth your words.

<b>27 </b>The first <i>shall say</i> to Zion, Behold, behold them: and I will give to Jerusalem one that bringeth good tidings.

<b>28 </b>For I beheld, and <i>there was</i> no man; even among them, and <i>there was</i> no counsellor, that, when I asked of them, could answer a word.

<b>29 </b>Behold, they <i>are</i> all vanity; their works <i>are</i> nothing: their molten images <i>are</i> wind and confusion.


--------------------

CHAPTER 42

<b>1 </b>Behold my servant, whom I uphold; mine elect, <i>in whom</i> my soul delighteth; I have put my spirit upon him: he shall bring forth judgment to the Gentiles.

<b>2 </b>He shall not cry, nor lift up, nor cause his voice to be heard in the street.

<b>3 </b>A bruised reed shall he not break, and the smoking flax shall he not quench: he shall bring forth judgment unto truth.

<b>4 </b>He shall not fail nor be discouraged, till he have set judgment in the earth: and the isles shall wait for his law.

<b>5 </b>¶ Thus saith God the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, he that created the heavens, and stretched them out; he that spread forth the earth, and that which cometh out of it; he that giveth breath unto the people upon it, and spirit to them that walk therein:

<b>6 </b>I the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> have called thee in righteousness, and will hold thine hand, and will keep thee, and give thee for a covenant of the people, for a light of the Gentiles;

<b>7 </b>To open the blind eyes, to bring out the prisoners from the prison, <i>and</i> them that sit in darkness out of the prison house.

<b>8 </b>I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: that <i>is</i> my name: and my glory will I not give to another, neither my praise to graven images.

<b>9 </b>Behold, the former things are come to pass, and new things do I declare: before they spring forth I tell you of them.

<b>10 </b>Sing unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> a new song, <i>and</i> his praise from the end of the earth, ye that go down to the sea, and all that is therein; the isles, and the inhabitants thereof.

<b>11 </b>Let the wilderness and the cities thereof lift up <i>their voice,</i> the villages <i>that</i> Kedar doth inhabit: let the inhabitants of the rock sing, let them shout from the top of the mountains.

<b>12 </b>Let them give glory unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and declare his praise in the islands.

<b>13 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall go forth as a mighty man, he shall stir up jealousy like a man of war: he shall cry, yea, roar; he shall prevail against his enemies.

<b>14 </b>I have long time holden my peace; I have been still, <i>and</i> refrained myself: <i>now</i> will I cry like a travailing woman; I will destroy and devour at once.

<b>15 </b>I will make waste mountains and hills, and dry up all their herbs; and I will make the rivers islands, and I will dry up the pools.

<b>16 </b>And I will bring the blind by a way <i>that</i> they knew not; I will lead them in paths <i>that</i> they have not known: I will make darkness light before them, and crooked things straight. These things will I do unto them, and not forsake them.

<b>17 </b>¶ They shall be turned back, they shall be greatly ashamed, that trust in graven images, that say to the molten images, Ye <i>are</i> our gods.

<b>18 </b>Hear, ye deaf; and look, ye blind, that ye may see.

<b>19 </b>Who <i>is</i> blind, but my servant? or deaf, as my messenger <i>that</i> I sent? who <i>is</i> blind as <i>he that is</i> perfect, and blind as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s servant?

<b>20 </b>Seeing many things, but thou observest not; opening the ears, but he heareth not.

<b>21 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> is well pleased for his righteousness’ sake; he will magnify the law, and make <i>it</i> honourable.

<b>22 </b>But this <i>is</i> a people robbed and spoiled; <i>they are</i> all of them snared in holes, and they are hid in prison houses: they are for a prey, and none delivereth; for a spoil, and none saith, Restore.

<b>23 </b>Who among you will give ear to this? <i>who</i> will hearken and hear for the time to come?

<b>24 </b>Who gave Jacob for a spoil, and Israel to the robbers? did not the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, he against whom we have sinned? for they would not walk in his ways, neither were they obedient unto his law.

<b>25 </b>Therefore he hath poured upon him the fury of his anger, and the strength of battle: and it hath set him on fire round about, yet he knew not; and it burned him, yet he laid <i>it</i> not to heart.


--------------------

CHAPTER 43

<b>1 </b>But now thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that created thee, O Jacob, and he that formed thee, O Israel, Fear not: for I have redeemed thee, I have called <i>thee</i> by thy name; thou <i>art</i> mine.

<b>2 </b>When thou passest through the waters, I <i>will be</i> with thee; and through the rivers, they shall not overflow thee: when thou walkest through the fire, thou shalt not be burned; neither shall the flame kindle upon thee.

<b>3 </b>For I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, the Holy One of Israel, thy Saviour: I gave Egypt <i>for</i> thy ransom, Ethiopia and Seba for thee.

<b>4 </b>Since thou wast precious in my sight, thou hast been honourable, and I have loved thee: therefore will I give men for thee, and people for thy life.

<b>5 </b>Fear not: for I <i>am</i> with thee: I will bring thy seed from the east, and gather thee from the west;

<b>6 </b>I will say to the north, Give up; and to the south, Keep not back: bring my sons from far, and my daughters from the ends of the earth;

<b>7 </b><i>Even</i> every one that is called by my name: for I have created him for my glory, I have formed him; yea, I have made him.

<b>8 </b>¶ Bring forth the blind people that have eyes, and the deaf that have ears.

<b>9 </b>Let all the nations be gathered together, and let the people be assembled: who among them can declare this, and shew us former things? let them bring forth their witnesses, that they may be justified: or let them hear, and say, <i>It is</i> truth.

<b>10 </b>Ye <i>are</i> my witnesses, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and my servant whom I have chosen: that ye may know and believe me, and understand that I <i>am</i> he: before me there was no God formed, neither shall there be after me.

<b>11 </b>I, <i>even</i> I, <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and beside me <i>there is</i> no saviour.

<b>12 </b>I have declared, and have saved, and I have shewed, when <i>there was</i> no strange <i>god</i> among you: therefore ye <i>are</i> my witnesses, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that I <i>am</i> God.

<b>13 </b>Yea, before the day <i>was</i> I <i>am</i> he; and <i>there is</i> none that can deliver out of my hand: I will work, and who shall let it?

<b>14 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, your redeemer, the Holy One of Israel; For your sake I have sent to Babylon, and have brought down all their nobles, and the Chaldeans, whose cry <i>is</i> in the ships.

<b>15 </b>I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, your Holy One, the creator of Israel, your King.

<b>16 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which maketh a way in the sea, and a path in the mighty waters;

<b>17 </b>Which bringeth forth the chariot and horse, the army and the power; they shall lie down together, they shall not rise: they are extinct, they are quenched as tow.

<b>18 </b>¶ Remember ye not the former things, neither consider the things of old.

<b>19 </b>Behold, I will do a new thing; now it shall spring forth; shall ye not know it? I will even make a way in the wilderness, <i>and</i> rivers in the desert.

<b>20 </b>The beast of the field shall honour me, the dragons and the owls: because I give waters in the wilderness, <i>and</i> rivers in the desert, to give drink to my people, my chosen.

<b>21 </b>This people have I formed for myself; they shall shew forth my praise.

<b>22 </b>¶ But thou hast not called upon me, O Jacob; but thou hast been weary of me, O Israel.

<b>23 </b>Thou hast not brought me the small cattle of thy burnt offerings; neither hast thou honoured me with thy sacrifices. I have not caused thee to serve with an offering, nor wearied thee with incense.

<b>24 </b>Thou hast bought me no sweet cane with money, neither hast thou filled me with the fat of thy sacrifices: but thou hast made me to serve with thy sins, thou hast wearied me with thine iniquities.

<b>25 </b>I, <i>even</i> I, <i>am</i> he that blotteth out thy transgressions for mine own sake, and will not remember thy sins.

<b>26 </b>Put me in remembrance: let us plead together: declare thou, that thou mayest be justified.

<b>27 </b>Thy first father hath sinned, and thy teachers have transgressed against me.

<b>28 </b>Therefore I have profaned the princes of the sanctuary, and have given Jacob to the curse, and Israel to reproaches.


--------------------

CHAPTER 44

<b>1 </b>Yet now hear, O Jacob my servant; and Israel, whom I have chosen:

<b>2 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that made thee, and formed thee from the womb, <i>which</i> will help thee; Fear not, O Jacob, my servant; and thou, Jesurun, whom I have chosen.

<b>3 </b>For I will pour water upon him that is thirsty, and floods upon the dry ground: I will pour my spirit upon thy seed, and my blessing upon thine offspring:

<b>4 </b>And they shall spring up <i>as</i> among the grass, as willows by the water courses.

<b>5 </b>One shall say, I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s; and another shall call <i>himself</i> by the name of Jacob; and another shall subscribe <i>with</i> his hand unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and surname <i>himself</i> by the name of Israel.

<b>6 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> the King of Israel, and his redeemer the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; I <i>am</i> the first, and I <i>am</i> the last; and beside me <i>there is</i> no God.

<b>7 </b>And who, as I, shall call, and shall declare it, and set it in order for me, since I appointed the ancient people? and the things that are coming, and shall come, let them shew unto them.

<b>8 </b>Fear ye not, neither be afraid: have not I told thee from that time, and have declared <i>it?</i> ye <i>are</i> even my witnesses. Is there a God beside me? yea, <i>there is</i> no God; I know not <i>any.</i>

<b>9 </b>¶ They that make a graven image <i>are</i> all of them vanity; and their delectable things shall not profit; and they <i>are</i> their own witnesses; they see not, nor know; that they may be ashamed.

<b>10 </b>Who hath formed a god, or molten a graven image <i>that</i> is profitable for nothing?

<b>11 </b>Behold, all his fellows shall be ashamed: and the workmen, they <i>are</i> of men: let them all be gathered together, let them stand up; <i>yet</i> they shall fear, <i>and</i> they shall be ashamed together.

<b>12 </b>The smith with the tongs both worketh in the coals, and fashioneth it with hammers, and worketh it with the strength of his arms: yea, he is hungry, and his strength faileth: he drinketh no water, and is faint.

<b>13 </b>The carpenter stretcheth out <i>his</i> rule; he marketh it out with a line; he fitteth it with planes, and he marketh it out with the compass, and maketh it after the figure of a man, according to the beauty of a man; that it may remain in the house.

<b>14 </b>He heweth him down cedars, and taketh the cypress and the oak, which he strengtheneth for himself among the trees of the forest: he planteth an ash, and the rain doth nourish <i>it.</i>

<b>15 </b>Then shall it be for a man to burn: for he will take thereof, and warm himself; yea, he kindleth <i>it,</i> and baketh bread; yea, he maketh a god, and worshippeth <i>it;</i> he maketh it a graven image, and falleth down thereto.

<b>16 </b>He burneth part thereof in the fire; with part thereof he eateth flesh; he roasteth roast, and is satisfied: yea, he warmeth <i>himself,</i> and saith, Aha, I am warm, I have seen the fire:

<b>17 </b>And the residue thereof he maketh a god, <i>even</i> his graven image: he falleth down unto it, and worshippeth <i>it,</i> and prayeth unto it, and saith, Deliver me; for thou <i>art</i> my god.

<b>18 </b>They have not known nor understood: for he hath shut their eyes, that they cannot see; <i>and</i> their hearts, that they cannot understand.

<b>19 </b>And none considereth in his heart, neither <i>is there</i> knowledge nor understanding to say, I have burned part of it in the fire; yea, also I have baked bread upon the coals thereof; I have roasted flesh, and eaten <i>it:</i> and shall I make the residue thereof an abomination? shall I fall down to the stock of a tree?

<b>20 </b>He feedeth on ashes: a deceived heart hath turned him aside, that he cannot deliver his soul, nor say, <i>Is there</i> not a lie in my right hand?

<b>21 </b>¶ Remember these, O Jacob and Israel; for thou <i>art</i> my servant: I have formed thee; thou <i>art</i> my servant: O Israel, thou shalt not be forgotten of me.

<b>22 </b>I have blotted out, as a thick cloud, thy transgressions, and, as a cloud, thy sins: return unto me; for I have redeemed thee.

<b>23 </b>Sing, O ye heavens; for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath done <i>it:</i> shout, ye lower parts of the earth: break forth into singing, ye mountains, O forest, and every tree therein: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath redeemed Jacob, and glorified himself in Israel.

<b>24 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, thy redeemer, and he that formed thee from the womb, I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that maketh all <i>things;</i> that stretcheth forth the heavens alone; that spreadeth abroad the earth by myself;

<b>25 </b>That frustrateth the tokens of the liars, and maketh diviners mad; that turneth wise <i>men</i> backward, and maketh their knowledge foolish;

<b>26 </b>That confirmeth the word of his servant, and performeth the counsel of his messengers; that saith to Jerusalem, Thou shalt be inhabited; and to the cities of Judah, Ye shall be built, and I will raise up the decayed places thereof:

<b>27 </b>That saith to the deep, Be dry, and I will dry up thy rivers:

<b>28 </b>That saith of Cyrus, <i>He is</i> my shepherd, and shall perform all my pleasure: even saying to Jerusalem, Thou shalt be built; and to the temple, Thy foundation shall be laid.


--------------------

CHAPTER 45

<b>1 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> to his anointed, to Cyrus, whose right hand I have holden, to subdue nations before him; and I will loose the loins of kings, to open before him the two leaved gates; and the gates shall not be shut;

<b>2 </b>I will go before thee, and make the crooked places straight: I will break in pieces the gates of brass, and cut in sunder the bars of iron:

<b>3 </b>And I will give thee the treasures of darkness, and hidden riches of secret places, that thou mayest know that I, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which call <i>thee</i> by thy name, <i>am</i> the God of Israel.

<b>4 </b>For Jacob my servant’s sake, and Israel mine elect, I have even called thee by thy name: I have surnamed thee, though thou hast not known me.

<b>5 </b>¶ I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and <i>there is</i> none else, <i>there is</i> no God beside me: I girded thee, though thou hast not known me:

<b>6 </b>That they may know from the rising of the sun, and from the west, that <i>there is</i> none beside me. I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and <i>there is</i> none else.

<b>7 </b>I form the light, and create darkness: I make peace, and create evil: I the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> do all these <i>things.</i>

<b>8 </b>Drop down, ye heavens, from above, and let the skies pour down righteousness: let the earth open, and let them bring forth salvation, and let righteousness spring up together; I the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> have created it.

<b>9 </b>Woe unto him that striveth with his Maker! <i>Let</i> the potsherd <i>strive</i> with the potsherds of the earth. Shall the clay say to him that fashioneth it, What makest thou? or thy work, He hath no hands?

<b>10 </b>Woe unto him that saith unto <i>his</i> father, What begettest thou? or to the woman, What hast thou brought forth?

<b>11 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the Holy One of Israel, and his Maker, Ask me of things to come concerning my sons, and concerning the work of my hands command ye me.

<b>12 </b>I have made the earth, and created man upon it: I, <i>even</i> my hands, have stretched out the heavens, and all their host have I commanded.

<b>13 </b>I have raised him up in righteousness, and I will direct all his ways: he shall build my city, and he shall let go my captives, not for price nor reward, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts.

<b>14 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, The labour of Egypt, and merchandise of Ethiopia and of the Sabeans, men of stature, shall come over unto thee, and they shall be thine: they shall come after thee; in chains they shall come over, and they shall fall down unto thee, they shall make supplication unto thee, <i>saying,</i> Surely God <i>is</i> in thee; and <i>there is</i> none else, <i>there is</i> no God.

<b>15 </b>Verily thou <i>art</i> a God that hidest thyself, O God of Israel, the Saviour.

<b>16 </b>They shall be ashamed, and also confounded, all of them: they shall go to confusion together <i>that are</i> makers of idols.

<b>17 </b><i>But</i> Israel shall be saved in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> with an everlasting salvation: ye shall not be ashamed nor confounded world without end.

<b>18 </b>For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that created the heavens; God himself that formed the earth and made it; he hath established it, he created it not in vain, he formed it to be inhabited: I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and <i>there is</i> none else.

<b>19 </b>I have not spoken in secret, in a dark place of the earth: I said not unto the seed of Jacob, Seek ye me in vain: I the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> speak righteousness, I declare things that are right.

<b>20 </b>¶ Assemble yourselves and come; draw near together, ye <i>that are</i> escaped of the nations: they have no knowledge that set up the wood of their graven image, and pray unto a god <i>that</i> cannot save.

<b>21 </b>Tell ye, and bring <i>them</i> near; yea, let them take counsel together: who hath declared this from ancient time? <i>who</i> hath told it from that time? <i>have</i> not I the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>? and <i>there is</i> no God else beside me; a just God and a Saviour; <i>there is</i> none beside me.

<b>22 </b>Look unto me, and be ye saved, all the ends of the earth: for I <i>am</i> God, and <i>there is</i> none else.

<b>23 </b>I have sworn by myself, the word is gone out of my mouth <i>in</i> righteousness, and shall not return, That unto me every knee shall bow, every tongue shall swear.

<b>24 </b>Surely, shall <i>one</i> say, in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> have I righteousness and strength: <i>even</i> to him shall <i>men</i> come; and all that are incensed against him shall be ashamed.

<b>25 </b>In the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall all the seed of Israel be justified, and shall glory.


--------------------

CHAPTER 46

<b>1 </b>Bel boweth down, Nebo stoopeth, their idols were upon the beasts, and upon the cattle: your carriages <i>were</i> heavy loaden; <i>they are</i> a burden to the weary <i>beast.</i>

<b>2 </b>They stoop, they bow down together; they could not deliver the burden, but themselves are gone into captivity.

<b>3 </b>¶ Hearken unto me, O house of Jacob, and all the remnant of the house of Israel, which are borne <i>by me</i> from the belly, which are carried from the womb:

<b>4 </b>And <i>even</i> to <i>your</i> old age I <i>am</i> he; and <i>even</i> to hoar hairs will I carry <i>you:</i> I have made, and I will bear; even I will carry, and will deliver <i>you.</i>

<b>5 </b>¶ To whom will ye liken me, and make <i>me</i> equal, and compare me, that we may be like?

<b>6 </b>They lavish gold out of the bag, and weigh silver in the balance, <i>and</i> hire a goldsmith; and he maketh it a god: they fall down, yea, they worship.

<b>7 </b>They bear him upon the shoulder, they carry him, and set him in his place, and he standeth; from his place shall he not remove: yea, <i>one</i> shall cry unto him, yet can he not answer, nor save him out of his trouble.

<b>8 </b>Remember this, and shew yourselves men: bring <i>it</i> again to mind, O ye transgressors.

<b>9 </b>Remember the former things of old: for I <i>am</i> God, and <i>there is</i> none else; <i>I am</i> God, and <i>there is</i> none like me,

<b>10 </b>Declaring the end from the beginning, and from ancient times <i>the things</i> that are not <i>yet</i> done, saying, My counsel shall stand, and I will do all my pleasure:

<b>11 </b>Calling a ravenous bird from the east, the man that executeth my counsel from a far country: yea, I have spoken <i>it,</i> I will also bring it to pass; I have purposed <i>it,</i> I will also do it.

<b>12 </b>¶ Hearken unto me, ye stouthearted, that <i>are</i> far from righteousness:

<b>13 </b>I bring near my righteousness; it shall not be far off, and my salvation shall not tarry: and I will place salvation in Zion for Israel my glory.


--------------------

CHAPTER 47

<b>1 </b>Come down, and sit in the dust, O virgin daughter of Babylon, sit on the ground: <i>there is</i> no throne, O daughter of the Chaldeans: for thou shalt no more be called tender and delicate.

<b>2 </b>Take the millstones, and grind meal: uncover thy locks, make bare the leg, uncover the thigh, pass over the rivers.

<b>3 </b>Thy nakedness shall be uncovered, yea, thy shame shall be seen: I will take vengeance, and I will not meet <i>thee as</i> a man.

<b>4 </b><i>As for</i> our redeemer, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts <i>is</i> his name, the Holy One of Israel.

<b>5 </b>Sit thou silent, and get thee into darkness, O daughter of the Chaldeans: for thou shalt no more be called, The lady of kingdoms.

<b>6 </b>¶ I was wroth with my people, I have polluted mine inheritance, and given them into thine hand: thou didst shew them no mercy; upon the ancient hast thou very heavily laid thy yoke.

<b>7 </b>¶ And thou saidst, I shall be a lady for ever: <i>so</i> that thou didst not lay these <i>things</i> to thy heart, neither didst remember the latter end of it.

<b>8 </b>Therefore hear now this, <i>thou that art</i> given to pleasures, that dwellest carelessly, that sayest in thine heart, I <i>am,</i> and none else beside me; I shall not sit <i>as</i> a widow, neither shall I know the loss of children:

<b>9 </b>But these two <i>things</i> shall come to thee in a moment in one day, the loss of children, and widowhood: they shall come upon thee in their perfection for the multitude of thy sorceries, <i>and</i> for the great abundance of thine enchantments.

<b>10 </b>¶ For thou hast trusted in thy wickedness: thou hast said, None seeth me. Thy wisdom and thy knowledge, it hath perverted thee; and thou hast said in thine heart, I <i>am,</i> and none else beside me.

<b>11 </b>¶ Therefore shall evil come upon thee; thou shalt not know from whence it riseth: and mischief shall fall upon thee; thou shalt not be able to put it off: and desolation shall come upon thee suddenly, <i>which</i> thou shalt not know.

<b>12 </b>Stand now with thine enchantments, and with the multitude of thy sorceries, wherein thou hast laboured from thy youth; if so be thou shalt be able to profit, if so be thou mayest prevail.

<b>13 </b>Thou art wearied in the multitude of thy counsels. Let now the astrologers, the stargazers, the monthly prognosticators, stand up, and save thee from <i>these things</i> that shall come upon thee.

<b>14 </b>Behold, they shall be as stubble; the fire shall burn them; they shall not deliver themselves from the power of the flame: <i>there shall</i> not <i>be</i> a coal to warm at, <i>nor</i> fire to sit before it.

<b>15 </b>Thus shall they be unto thee with whom thou hast laboured, <i>even</i> thy merchants, from thy youth: they shall wander every one to his quarter; none shall save thee.


--------------------

CHAPTER 48

<b>1 </b>Hear ye this, O house of Jacob, which are called by the name of Israel, and are come forth out of the waters of Judah, which swear by the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and make mention of the God of Israel, <i>but</i> not in truth, nor in righteousness.

<b>2 </b>For they call themselves of the holy city, and stay themselves upon the God of Israel; The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts <i>is</i> his name.

<b>3 </b>I have declared the former things from the beginning; and they went forth out of my mouth, and I shewed them; I did <i>them</i> suddenly, and they came to pass.

<b>4 </b>Because I knew that thou <i>art</i> obstinate, and thy neck <i>is</i> an iron sinew, and thy brow brass;

<b>5 </b>I have even from the beginning declared <i>it</i> to thee; before it came to pass I shewed <i>it</i> thee: lest thou shouldest say, Mine idol hath done them, and my graven image, and my molten image, hath commanded them.

<b>6 </b>Thou hast heard, see all this; and will not ye declare <i>it?</i> I have shewed thee new things from this time, even hidden things, and thou didst not know them.

<b>7 </b>They are created now, and not from the beginning; even before the day when thou heardest them not; lest thou shouldest say, Behold, I knew them.

<b>8 </b>Yea, thou heardest not; yea, thou knewest not; yea, from that time <i>that</i> thine ear was not opened: for I knew that thou wouldest deal very treacherously, and wast called a transgressor from the womb.

<b>9 </b>¶ For my name’s sake will I defer mine anger, and for my praise will I refrain for thee, that I cut thee not off.

<b>10 </b>Behold, I have refined thee, but not with silver; I have chosen thee in the furnace of affliction.

<b>11 </b>For mine own sake, <i>even</i> for mine own sake, will I do <i>it:</i> for how should <i>my name</i> be polluted? and I will not give my glory unto another.

<b>12 </b>¶ Hearken unto me, O Jacob and Israel, my called; I <i>am</i> he; I <i>am</i> the first, I also <i>am</i> the last.

<b>13 </b>Mine hand also hath laid the foundation of the earth, and my right hand hath spanned the heavens: <i>when</i> I call unto them, they stand up together.

<b>14 </b>All ye, assemble yourselves, and hear; which among them hath declared these <i>things?</i> The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath loved him: he will do his pleasure on Babylon, and his arm <i>shall be on</i> the Chaldeans.

<b>15 </b>I, <i>even</i> I, have spoken; yea, I have called him: I have brought him, and he shall make his way prosperous.

<b>16 </b>¶ Come ye near unto me, hear ye this; I have not spoken in secret from the beginning; from the time that it was, there <i>am</i> I: and now the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>, and his Spirit, hath sent me.

<b>17 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, thy Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel; I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God which teacheth thee to profit, which leadeth thee by the way <i>that</i> thou shouldest go.

<b>18 </b>O that thou hadst hearkened to my commandments! then had thy peace been as a river, and thy righteousness as the waves of the sea:

<b>19 </b>Thy seed also had been as the sand, and the offspring of thy bowels like the gravel thereof; his name should not have been cut off nor destroyed from before me.

<b>20 </b>¶ Go ye forth of Babylon, flee ye from the Chaldeans, with a voice of singing declare ye, tell this, utter it <i>even</i> to the end of the earth; say ye, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath redeemed his servant Jacob.

<b>21 </b>And they thirsted not <i>when</i> he led them through the deserts: he caused the waters to flow out of the rock for them: he clave the rock also, and the waters gushed out.

<b>22 </b><i>There is</i> no peace, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, unto the wicked.


--------------------

CHAPTER 49

<b>1 </b>Listen, O isles, unto me; and hearken, ye people, from far; The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath called me from the womb; from the bowels of my mother hath he made mention of my name.

<b>2 </b>And he hath made my mouth like a sharp sword; in the shadow of his hand hath he hid me, and made me a polished shaft; in his quiver hath he hid me;

<b>3 </b>And said unto me, Thou <i>art</i> my servant, O Israel, in whom I will be glorified.

<b>4 </b>Then I said, I have laboured in vain, I have spent my strength for nought, and in vain: <i>yet</i> surely my judgment <i>is</i> with the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and my work with my God.

<b>5 </b>¶ And now, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that formed me from the womb <i>to be</i> his servant, to bring Jacob again to him, Though Israel be not gathered, yet shall I be glorious in the eyes of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and my God shall be my strength.

<b>6 </b>And he said, It is a light thing that thou shouldest be my servant to raise up the tribes of Jacob, and to restore the preserved of Israel: I will also give thee for a light to the Gentiles, that thou mayest be my salvation unto the end of the earth.

<b>7 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the Redeemer of Israel, <i>and</i> his Holy One, to him whom man despiseth, to him whom the nation abhorreth, to a servant of rulers, Kings shall see and arise, princes also shall worship, because of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that is faithful, <i>and</i> the Holy One of Israel, and he shall choose thee.

<b>8 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, In an acceptable time have I heard thee, and in a day of salvation have I helped thee: and I will preserve thee, and give thee for a covenant of the people, to establish the earth, to cause to inherit the desolate heritages;

<b>9 </b>That thou mayest say to the prisoners, Go forth; to them that <i>are</i> in darkness, Shew yourselves. They shall feed in the ways, and their pastures <i>shall be</i> in all high places.

<b>10 </b>They shall not hunger nor thirst; neither shall the heat nor sun smite them: for he that hath mercy on them shall lead them, even by the springs of water shall he guide them.

<b>11 </b>And I will make all my mountains a way, and my highways shall be exalted.

<b>12 </b>Behold, these shall come from far: and, lo, these from the north and from the west; and these from the land of Sinim.

<b>13 </b>¶ Sing, O heavens; and be joyful, O earth; and break forth into singing, O mountains: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath comforted his people, and will have mercy upon his afflicted.

<b>14 </b>But Zion said, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath forsaken me, and my Lord hath forgotten me.

<b>15 </b>Can a woman forget her sucking child, that she should not have compassion on the son of her womb? yea, they may forget, yet will I not forget thee.

<b>16 </b>Behold, I have graven thee upon the palms of <i>my</i> hands; thy walls <i>are</i> continually before me.

<b>17 </b>Thy children shall make haste; thy destroyers and they that made thee waste shall go forth of thee.

<b>18 </b>¶ Lift up thine eyes round about, and behold: all these gather themselves together, <i>and</i> come to thee. <i>As</i> I live, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, thou shalt surely clothe thee with them all, as with an ornament, and bind them <i>on thee,</i> as a bride <i>doeth.</i>

<b>19 </b>For thy waste and thy desolate places, and the land of thy destruction, shall even now be too narrow by reason of the inhabitants, and they that swallowed thee up shall be far away.

<b>20 </b>The children which thou shalt have, after thou hast lost the other, shall say again in thine ears, The place <i>is</i> too strait for me: give place to me that I may dwell.

<b>21 </b>Then shalt thou say in thine heart, Who hath begotten me these, seeing I have lost my children, and am desolate, a captive, and removing to and fro? and who hath brought up these? Behold, I was left alone; these, where <i>had</i> they <i>been?</i>

<b>22 </b>Thus saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>, Behold, I will lift up mine hand to the Gentiles, and set up my standard to the people: and they shall bring thy sons in <i>their</i> arms, and thy daughters shall be carried upon <i>their</i> shoulders.

<b>23 </b>And kings shall be thy nursing fathers, and their queens thy nursing mothers: they shall bow down to thee with <i>their</i> face toward the earth, and lick up the dust of thy feet; and thou shalt know that I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for they shall not be ashamed that wait for me.

<b>24 </b>¶ Shall the prey be taken from the mighty, or the lawful captive delivered?

<b>25 </b>But thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Even the captives of the mighty shall be taken away, and the prey of the terrible shall be delivered: for I will contend with him that contendeth with thee, and I will save thy children.

<b>26 </b>And I will feed them that oppress thee with their own flesh; and they shall be drunken with their own blood, as with sweet wine: and all flesh shall know that I the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>am</i> thy Saviour and thy Redeemer, the mighty One of Jacob.


--------------------

CHAPTER 50

<b>1 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Where <i>is</i> the bill of your mother’s divorcement, whom I have put away? or which of my creditors <i>is it</i> to whom I have sold you? Behold, for your iniquities have ye sold yourselves, and for your transgressions is your mother put away.

<b>2 </b>Wherefore, when I came, <i>was there</i> no man? when I called, <i>was there</i> none to answer? Is my hand shortened at all, that it cannot redeem? or have I no power to deliver? behold, at my rebuke I dry up the sea, I make the rivers a wilderness: their fish stinketh, because <i>there is</i> no water, and dieth for thirst.

<b>3 </b>I clothe the heavens with blackness, and I make sackcloth their covering.

<b>4 </b>The Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> hath given me the tongue of the learned, that I should know how to speak a word in season to <i>him that is</i> weary: he wakeneth morning by morning, he wakeneth mine ear to hear as the learned.

<b>5 </b>¶ The Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> hath opened mine ear, and I was not rebellious, neither turned away back.

<b>6 </b>I gave my back to the smiters, and my cheeks to them that plucked off the hair: I hid not my face from shame and spitting.

<b>7 </b>¶ For the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> will help me; therefore shall I not be confounded: therefore have I set my face like a flint, and I know that I shall not be ashamed.

<b>8 </b><i>He is</i> near that justifieth me; who will contend with me? let us stand together: who <i>is</i> mine adversary? let him come near to me.

<b>9 </b>Behold, the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> will help me; who <i>is</i> he <i>that</i> shall condemn me? lo, they all shall wax old as a garment; the moth shall eat them up.

<b>10 </b>¶ Who <i>is</i> among you that feareth the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that obeyeth the voice of his servant, that walketh <i>in</i> darkness, and hath no light? let him trust in the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and stay upon his God.

<b>11 </b>Behold, all ye that kindle a fire, that compass <i>yourselves</i> about with sparks: walk in the light of your fire, and in the sparks <i>that</i> ye have kindled. This shall ye have of mine hand; ye shall lie down in sorrow.


--------------------

CHAPTER 51

<b>1 </b>Hearken to me, ye that follow after righteousness, ye that seek the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: look unto the rock <i>whence</i> ye are hewn, and to the hole of the pit <i>whence</i> ye are digged.

<b>2 </b>Look unto Abraham your father, and unto Sarah <i>that</i> bare you: for I called him alone, and blessed him, and increased him.

<b>3 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall comfort Zion: he will comfort all her waste places; and he will make her wilderness like Eden, and her desert like the garden of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; joy and gladness shall be found therein, thanksgiving, and the voice of melody.

<b>4 </b>¶ Hearken unto me, my people; and give ear unto me, O my nation: for a law shall proceed from me, and I will make my judgment to rest for a light of the people.

<b>5 </b>My righteousness <i>is</i> near; my salvation is gone forth, and mine arms shall judge the people; the isles shall wait upon me, and on mine arm shall they trust.

<b>6 </b>Lift up your eyes to the heavens, and look upon the earth beneath: for the heavens shall vanish away like smoke, and the earth shall wax old like a garment, and they that dwell therein shall die in like manner: but my salvation shall be for ever, and my righteousness shall not be abolished.

<b>7 </b>¶ Hearken unto me, ye that know righteousness, the people in whose heart <i>is</i> my law; fear ye not the reproach of men, neither be ye afraid of their revilings.

<b>8 </b>For the moth shall eat them up like a garment, and the worm shall eat them like wool: but my righteousness shall be for ever, and my salvation from generation to generation.

<b>9 </b>¶ Awake, awake, put on strength, O arm of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; awake, as in the ancient days, in the generations of old. <i>Art</i> thou not it that hath cut Rahab, <i>and</i> wounded the dragon?

<b>10 </b><i>Art</i> thou not it which hath dried the sea, the waters of the great deep; that hath made the depths of the sea a way for the ransomed to pass over?

<b>11 </b>Therefore the redeemed of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall return, and come with singing unto Zion; and everlasting joy <i>shall be</i> upon their head: they shall obtain gladness and joy; <i>and</i> sorrow and mourning shall flee away.

<b>12 </b>I, <i>even</i> I, <i>am</i> he that comforteth you: who <i>art</i> thou, that thou shouldest be afraid of a man <i>that</i> shall die, and of the son of man <i>which</i> shall be made <i>as</i> grass;

<b>13 </b>And forgettest the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy maker, that hath stretched forth the heavens, and laid the foundations of the earth; and hast feared continually every day because of the fury of the oppressor, as if he were ready to destroy? and where <i>is</i> the fury of the oppressor?

<b>14 </b>The captive exile hasteneth that he may be loosed, and that he should not die in the pit, nor that his bread should fail.

<b>15 </b>But I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, that divided the sea, whose waves roared: The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts <i>is</i> his name.

<b>16 </b>And I have put my words in thy mouth, and I have covered thee in the shadow of mine hand, that I may plant the heavens, and lay the foundations of the earth, and say unto Zion, Thou <i>art</i> my people.

<b>17 </b>¶ Awake, awake, stand up, O Jerusalem, which hast drunk at the hand of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> the cup of his fury; thou hast drunken the dregs of the cup of trembling, <i>and</i> wrung <i>them</i> out.

<b>18 </b><i>There is</i> none to guide her among all the sons <i>whom</i> she hath brought forth; neither <i>is there any</i> that taketh her by the hand of all the sons <i>that</i> she hath brought up.

<b>19 </b>These two <i>things</i> are come unto thee; who shall be sorry for thee? desolation, and destruction, and the famine, and the sword: by whom shall I comfort thee?

<b>20 </b>Thy sons have fainted, they lie at the head of all the streets, as a wild bull in a net: they are full of the fury of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the rebuke of thy God.

<b>21 </b>¶ Therefore hear now this, thou afflicted, and drunken, but not with wine:

<b>22 </b>Thus saith thy Lord the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and thy God <i>that</i> pleadeth the cause of his people, Behold, I have taken out of thine hand the cup of trembling, <i>even</i> the dregs of the cup of my fury; thou shalt no more drink it again:

<b>23 </b>But I will put it into the hand of them that afflict thee; which have said to thy soul, Bow down, that we may go over: and thou hast laid thy body as the ground, and as the street, to them that went over.


--------------------

CHAPTER 52

<b>1 </b>Awake, awake; put on thy strength, O Zion; put on thy beautiful garments, O Jerusalem, the holy city: for henceforth there shall no more come into thee the uncircumcised and the unclean.

<b>2 </b>Shake thyself from the dust; arise, <i>and</i> sit down, O Jerusalem: loose thyself from the bands of thy neck, O captive daughter of Zion.

<b>3 </b>For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Ye have sold yourselves for nought; and ye shall be redeemed without money.

<b>4 </b>For thus saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>, My people went down aforetime into Egypt to sojourn there; and the Assyrian oppressed them without cause.

<b>5 </b>Now therefore, what have I here, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that my people is taken away for nought? they that rule over them make them to howl, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and my name continually every day <i>is</i> blasphemed.

<b>6 </b>Therefore my people shall know my name: therefore <i>they shall know</i> in that day that I <i>am</i> he that doth speak: behold, <i>it is</i> I.

<b>7 </b>¶ How beautiful upon the mountains are the feet of him that bringeth good tidings, that publisheth peace; that bringeth good tidings of good, that publisheth salvation; that saith unto Zion, Thy God reigneth!

<b>8 </b>Thy watchmen shall lift up the voice; with the voice together shall they sing: for they shall see eye to eye, when the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall bring again Zion.

<b>9 </b>¶ Break forth into joy, sing together, ye waste places of Jerusalem: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath comforted his people, he hath redeemed Jerusalem.

<b>10 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath made bare his holy arm in the eyes of all the nations; and all the ends of the earth shall see the salvation of our God.

<b>11 </b>¶ Depart ye, depart ye, go ye out from thence, touch no unclean <i>thing</i><i>;</i> go ye out of the midst of her; be ye clean, that bear the vessels of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>12 </b>For ye shall not go out with haste, nor go by flight: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will go before you; and the God of Israel <i>will be</i> your rearward.

<b>13 </b>¶ Behold, my servant shall deal prudently, he shall be exalted and extolled, and be very high.

<b>14 </b>As many were astonied at thee; his visage was so marred more than any man, and his form more than the sons of men:

<b>15 </b>So shall he sprinkle many nations; the kings shall shut their mouths at him: for <i>that</i> which had not been told them shall they see; and <i>that</i> which they had not heard shall they consider.


--------------------

CHAPTER 53

<b>1 </b>Who hath believed our report? and to whom is the arm of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> revealed?

<b>2 </b>For he shall grow up before him as a tender plant, and as a root out of a dry ground: he hath no form nor comeliness; and when we shall see him, <i>there is</i> no beauty that we should desire him.

<b>3 </b>He is despised and rejected of men; a man of sorrows, and acquainted with grief: and we hid as it were <i>our</i> faces from him; he was despised, and we esteemed him not.

<b>4 </b>¶ Surely he hath borne our griefs, and carried our sorrows: yet we did esteem him stricken, smitten of God, and afflicted.

<b>5 </b>But he <i>was</i> wounded for our transgressions, <i>he was</i> bruised for our iniquities: the chastisement of our peace <i>was</i> upon him; and with his stripes we are healed.

<b>6 </b>All we like sheep have gone astray; we have turned every one to his own way; and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath laid on him the iniquity of us all.

<b>7 </b>He was oppressed, and he was afflicted, yet he opened not his mouth: he is brought as a lamb to the slaughter, and as a sheep before her shearers is dumb, so he openeth not his mouth.

<b>8 </b>He was taken from prison and from judgment: and who shall declare his generation? for he was cut off out of the land of the living: for the transgression of my people was he stricken.

<b>9 </b>And he made his grave with the wicked, and with the rich in his death; because he had done no violence, neither <i>was any</i> deceit in his mouth.

<b>10 </b>¶ Yet it pleased the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> to bruise him; he hath put <i>him</i> to grief: when thou shalt make his soul an offering for sin, he shall see <i>his</i> seed, he shall prolong <i>his</i> days, and the pleasure of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall prosper in his hand.

<b>11 </b>He shall see of the travail of his soul, <i>and</i> shall be satisfied: by his knowledge shall my righteous servant justify many; for he shall bear their iniquities.

<b>12 </b>Therefore will I divide him <i>a portion</i> with the great, and he shall divide the spoil with the strong; because he hath poured out his soul unto death: and he was numbered with the transgressors; and he bare the sin of many, and made intercession for the transgressors.


--------------------

CHAPTER 54

<b>1 </b>Sing, O barren, thou <i>that</i> didst not bear; break forth into singing, and cry aloud, thou <i>that</i> didst not travail with child: for more <i>are</i> the children of the desolate than the children of the married wife, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>2 </b>Enlarge the place of thy tent, and let them stretch forth the curtains of thine habitations: spare not, lengthen thy cords, and strengthen thy stakes;

<b>3 </b>For thou shalt break forth on the right hand and on the left; and thy seed shall inherit the Gentiles, and make the desolate cities to be inhabited.

<b>4 </b>Fear not; for thou shalt not be ashamed: neither be thou confounded; for thou shalt not be put to shame: for thou shalt forget the shame of thy youth, and shalt not remember the reproach of thy widowhood any more.

<b>5 </b>For thy Maker <i>is</i> thine husband; the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts <i>is</i> his name; and thy Redeemer the Holy One of Israel; The God of the whole earth shall he be called.

<b>6 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath called thee as a woman forsaken and grieved in spirit, and a wife of youth, when thou wast refused, saith thy God.

<b>7 </b>For a small moment have I forsaken thee; but with great mercies will I gather thee.

<b>8 </b>In a little wrath I hid my face from thee for a moment; but with everlasting kindness will I have mercy on thee, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy Redeemer.

<b>9 </b>For this <i>is as</i> the waters of Noah unto me: for <i>as</i> I have sworn that the waters of Noah should no more go over the earth; so have I sworn that I would not be wroth with thee, nor rebuke thee.

<b>10 </b>For the mountains shall depart, and the hills be removed; but my kindness shall not depart from thee, neither shall the covenant of my peace be removed, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that hath mercy on thee.

<b>11 </b>¶ O thou afflicted, tossed with tempest, <i>and</i> not comforted, behold, I will lay thy stones with fair colours, and lay thy foundations with sapphires.

<b>12 </b>And I will make thy windows of agates, and thy gates of carbuncles, and all thy borders of pleasant stones.

<b>13 </b>And all thy children <i>shall be</i> taught of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and great <i>shall be</i> the peace of thy children.

<b>14 </b>In righteousness shalt thou be established: thou shalt be far from oppression; for thou shalt not fear: and from terror; for it shall not come near thee.

<b>15 </b>Behold, they shall surely gather together, <i>but</i> not by me: whosoever shall gather together against thee shall fall for thy sake.

<b>16 </b>Behold, I have created the smith that bloweth the coals in the fire, and that bringeth forth an instrument for his work; and I have created the waster to destroy.

<b>17 </b>¶ No weapon that is formed against thee shall prosper; and every tongue <i>that</i> shall rise against thee in judgment thou shalt condemn. This <i>is</i> the heritage of the servants of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and their righteousness <i>is</i> of me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

CHAPTER 55

<b>1 </b>Ho, every one that thirsteth, come ye to the waters, and he that hath no money; come ye, buy, and eat; yea, come, buy wine and milk without money and without price.

<b>2 </b>Wherefore do ye spend money for <i>that which is</i> not bread? and your labour for <i>that which</i> satisfieth not? hearken diligently unto me, and eat ye <i>that which is</i> good, and let your soul delight itself in fatness.

<b>3 </b>Incline your ear, and come unto me: hear, and your soul shall live; and I will make an everlasting covenant with you, <i>even</i> the sure mercies of David.

<b>4 </b>Behold, I have given him <i>for</i> a witness to the people, a leader and commander to the people.

<b>5 </b>Behold, thou shalt call a nation <i>that</i> thou knowest not, and nations <i>that</i> knew not thee shall run unto thee because of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, and for the Holy One of Israel; for he hath glorified thee.

<b>6 </b>¶ Seek ye the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> while he may be found, call ye upon him while he is near:

<b>7 </b>Let the wicked forsake his way, and the unrighteous man his thoughts: and let him return unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and he will have mercy upon him; and to our God, for he will abundantly pardon.

<b>8 </b>¶ For my thoughts <i>are</i> not your thoughts, neither <i>are</i> your ways my ways, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>9 </b>For <i>as</i> the heavens are higher than the earth, so are my ways higher than your ways, and my thoughts than your thoughts.

<b>10 </b>For as the rain cometh down, and the snow from heaven, and returneth not thither, but watereth the earth, and maketh it bring forth and bud, that it may give seed to the sower, and bread to the eater:

<b>11 </b>So shall my word be that goeth forth out of my mouth: it shall not return unto me void, but it shall accomplish that which I please, and it shall prosper <i>in the thing</i> whereto I sent it.

<b>12 </b>For ye shall go out with joy, and be led forth with peace: the mountains and the hills shall break forth before you into singing, and all the trees of the field shall clap <i>their</i> hands.

<b>13 </b>Instead of the thorn shall come up the fir tree, and instead of the brier shall come up the myrtle tree: and it shall be to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> for a name, for an everlasting sign <i>that</i> shall not be cut off.


--------------------

CHAPTER 56

<b>1 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Keep ye judgment, and do justice: for my salvation <i>is</i> near to come, and my righteousness to be revealed.

<b>2 </b>Blessed <i>is</i> the man <i>that</i> doeth this, and the son of man <i>that</i> layeth hold on it; that keepeth the sabbath from polluting it, and keepeth his hand from doing any evil.

<b>3 </b>¶ Neither let the son of the stranger, that hath joined himself to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, speak, saying, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath utterly separated me from his people: neither let the eunuch say, Behold, I <i>am</i> a dry tree.

<b>4 </b>For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto the eunuchs that keep my sabbaths, and choose <i>the things</i> that please me, and take hold of my covenant;

<b>5 </b>Even unto them will I give in mine house and within my walls a place and a name better than of sons and of daughters: I will give them an everlasting name, that shall not be cut off.

<b>6 </b>Also the sons of the stranger, that join themselves to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to serve him, and to love the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to be his servants, every one that keepeth the sabbath from polluting it, and taketh hold of my covenant;

<b>7 </b>Even them will I bring to my holy mountain, and make them joyful in my house of prayer: their burnt offerings and their sacrifices <i>shall be</i> accepted upon mine altar; for mine house shall be called an house of prayer for all people.

<b>8 </b>The Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> which gathereth the outcasts of Israel saith, Yet will I gather <i>others</i> to him, beside those that are gathered unto him.

<b>9 </b>¶ All ye beasts of the field, come to devour, <i>yea,</i> all ye beasts in the forest.

<b>10 </b>His watchmen <i>are</i> blind: they are all ignorant, they <i>are</i> all dumb dogs, they cannot bark; sleeping, lying down, loving to slumber.

<b>11 </b>Yea, <i>they are</i> greedy dogs <i>which</i> can never have enough, and they <i>are</i> shepherds <i>that</i> cannot understand: they all look to their own way, every one for his gain, from his quarter.

<b>12 </b>Come ye, <i>say they,</i> I will fetch wine, and we will fill ourselves with strong drink; and to morrow shall be as this day, <i>and</i> much more abundant.


--------------------

CHAPTER 57

<b>1 </b>The righteous perisheth, and no man layeth <i>it</i> to heart: and merciful men <i>are</i> taken away, none considering that the righteous is taken away from the evil <i>to come.</i>

<b>2 </b>He shall enter into peace: they shall rest in their beds, <i>each one</i> walking <i>in</i> his uprightness.

<b>3 </b>¶ But draw near hither, ye sons of the sorceress, the seed of the adulterer and the whore.

<b>4 </b>Against whom do ye sport yourselves? against whom make ye a wide mouth, <i>and</i> draw out the tongue? <i>are</i> ye not children of transgression, a seed of falsehood,

<b>5 </b>Enflaming yourselves with idols under every green tree, slaying the children in the valleys under the clifts of the rocks?

<b>6 </b>Among the smooth <i>stones</i> of the stream <i>is</i> thy portion; they, they <i>are</i> thy lot: even to them hast thou poured a drink offering, thou hast offered a meat offering. Should I receive comfort in these?

<b>7 </b>Upon a lofty and high mountain hast thou set thy bed: even thither wentest thou up to offer sacrifice.

<b>8 </b>Behind the doors also and the posts hast thou set up thy remembrance: for thou hast discovered <i>thyself to another</i> than me, and art gone up; thou hast enlarged thy bed, and made thee <i>a covenant</i> with them; thou lovedst their bed where thou sawest <i>it.</i>

<b>9 </b>And thou wentest to the king with ointment, and didst increase thy perfumes, and didst send thy messengers far off, and didst debase <i>thyself even</i> unto hell.

<b>10 </b>Thou art wearied in the greatness of thy way; <i>yet</i> saidst thou not, There is no hope: thou hast found the life of thine hand; therefore thou wast not grieved.

<b>11 </b>And of whom hast thou been afraid or feared, that thou hast lied, and hast not remembered me, nor laid <i>it</i> to thy heart? have not I held my peace even of old, and thou fearest me not?

<b>12 </b>I will declare thy righteousness, and thy works; for they shall not profit thee.

<b>13 </b>¶ When thou criest, let thy companies deliver thee; but the wind shall carry them all away; vanity shall take <i>them:</i> but he that putteth his trust in me shall possess the land, and shall inherit my holy mountain;

<b>14 </b>And shall say, Cast ye up, cast ye up, prepare the way, take up the stumblingblock out of the way of my people.

<b>15 </b>For thus saith the high and lofty One that inhabiteth eternity, whose name <i>is</i> Holy; I dwell in the high and holy <i>place,</i> with him also <i>that is</i> of a contrite and humble spirit, to revive the spirit of the humble, and to revive the heart of the contrite ones.

<b>16 </b>For I will not contend for ever, neither will I be always wroth: for the spirit should fail before me, and the souls <i>which</i> I have made.

<b>17 </b>For the iniquity of his covetousness was I wroth, and smote him: I hid me, and was wroth, and he went on frowardly in the way of his heart.

<b>18 </b>I have seen his ways, and will heal him: I will lead him also, and restore comforts unto him and to his mourners.

<b>19 </b>I create the fruit of the lips; Peace, peace to <i>him that is</i> far off, and to <i>him that is</i> near, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and I will heal him.

<b>20 </b>But the wicked <i>are</i> like the troubled sea, when it cannot rest, whose waters cast up mire and dirt.

<b>21 </b><i>There is</i> no peace, saith my God, to the wicked.


--------------------

CHAPTER 58

<b>1 </b>Cry aloud, spare not, lift up thy voice like a trumpet, and shew my people their transgression, and the house of Jacob their sins.

<b>2 </b>Yet they seek me daily, and delight to know my ways, as a nation that did righteousness, and forsook not the ordinance of their God: they ask of me the ordinances of justice; they take delight in approaching to God.

<b>3 </b>¶ Wherefore have we fasted, <i>say they,</i> and thou seest not? <i>wherefore</i> have we afflicted our soul, and thou takest no knowledge? Behold, in the day of your fast ye find pleasure, and exact all your labours.

<b>4 </b>Behold, ye fast for strife and debate, and to smite with the fist of wickedness: ye shall not fast as <i>ye do this</i> day, to make your voice to be heard on high.

<b>5 </b>Is it such a fast that I have chosen? a day for a man to afflict his soul? <i>is it</i> to bow down his head as a bulrush, and to spread sackcloth and ashes <i>under him?</i> wilt thou call this a fast, and an acceptable day to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>?

<b>6 </b><i>Is</i> not this the fast that I have chosen? to loose the bands of wickedness, to undo the heavy burdens, and to let the oppressed go free, and that ye break every yoke?

<b>7 </b><i>Is it</i> not to deal thy bread to the hungry, and that thou bring the poor that are cast out to thy house? when thou seest the naked, that thou cover him; and that thou hide not thyself from thine own flesh?

<b>8 </b>¶ Then shall thy light break forth as the morning, and thine health shall spring forth speedily: and thy righteousness shall go before thee; the glory of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall be thy rearward.

<b>9 </b>Then shalt thou call, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall answer; thou shalt cry, and he shall say, Here I <i>am.</i> If thou take away from the midst of thee the yoke, the putting forth of the finger, and speaking vanity;

<b>10 </b>And <i>if</i> thou draw out thy soul to the hungry, and satisfy the afflicted soul; then shall thy light rise in obscurity, and thy darkness <i>be</i> as the noonday:

<b>11 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall guide thee continually, and satisfy thy soul in drought, and make fat thy bones: and thou shalt be like a watered garden, and like a spring of water, whose waters fail not.

<b>12 </b>And <i>they that shall be</i> of thee shall build the old waste places: thou shalt raise up the foundations of many generations; and thou shalt be called, The repairer of the breach, The restorer of paths to dwell in.

<b>13 </b>¶ If thou turn away thy foot from the sabbath, <i>from</i> doing thy pleasure on my holy day; and call the sabbath a delight, the holy of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, honourable; and shalt honour him, not doing thine own ways, nor finding thine own pleasure, nor speaking <i>thine own</i> words:

<b>14 </b>Then shalt thou delight thyself in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and I will cause thee to ride upon the high places of the earth, and feed thee with the heritage of Jacob thy father: for the mouth of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath spoken <i>it.</i>


--------------------

CHAPTER 59

<b>1 </b>Behold, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s hand is not shortened, that it cannot save; neither his ear heavy, that it cannot hear:

<b>2 </b>But your iniquities have separated between you and your God, and your sins have hid <i>his</i> face from you, that he will not hear.

<b>3 </b>For your hands are defiled with blood, and your fingers with iniquity; your lips have spoken lies, your tongue hath muttered perverseness.

<b>4 </b>None calleth for justice, nor <i>any</i> pleadeth for truth: they trust in vanity, and speak lies; they conceive mischief, and bring forth iniquity.

<b>5 </b>They hatch cockatrice’ eggs, and weave the spider’s web: he that eateth of their eggs dieth, and that which is crushed breaketh out into a viper.

<b>6 </b>Their webs shall not become garments, neither shall they cover themselves with their works: their works <i>are</i> works of iniquity, and the act of violence <i>is</i> in their hands.

<b>7 </b>Their feet run to evil, and they make haste to shed innocent blood: their thoughts <i>are</i> thoughts of iniquity; wasting and destruction <i>are</i> in their paths.

<b>8 </b>The way of peace they know not; and <i>there is</i> no judgment in their goings: they have made them crooked paths: whosoever goeth therein shall not know peace.

<b>9 </b>¶ Therefore is judgment far from us, neither doth justice overtake us: we wait for light, but behold obscurity; for brightness, <i>but</i> we walk in darkness.

<b>10 </b>We grope for the wall like the blind, and we grope as if <i>we had</i> no eyes: we stumble at noonday as in the night; <i>we are</i> in desolate places as dead <i>men.</i>

<b>11 </b>We roar all like bears, and mourn sore like doves: we look for judgment, but <i>there is</i> none; for salvation, <i>but</i> it is far off from us.

<b>12 </b>For our transgressions are multiplied before thee, and our sins testify against us: for our transgressions <i>are</i> with us; and <i>as for</i> our iniquities, we know them;

<b>13 </b>In transgressing and lying against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and departing away from our God, speaking oppression and revolt, conceiving and uttering from the heart words of falsehood.

<b>14 </b>And judgment is turned away backward, and justice standeth afar off: for truth is fallen in the street, and equity cannot enter.

<b>15 </b>Yea, truth faileth; and he <i>that</i> departeth from evil maketh himself a prey: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> saw <i>it,</i> and it displeased him that <i>there was</i> no judgment.

<b>16 </b>¶ And he saw that <i>there was</i> no man, and wondered that <i>there was</i> no intercessor: therefore his arm brought salvation unto him; and his righteousness, it sustained him.

<b>17 </b>For he put on righteousness as a breastplate, and an helmet of salvation upon his head; and he put on the garments of vengeance <i>for</i> clothing, and was clad with zeal as a cloak.

<b>18 </b>According to <i>their</i> deeds, accordingly he will repay, fury to his adversaries, recompence to his enemies; to the islands he will repay recompence.

<b>19 </b>So shall they fear the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> from the west, and his glory from the rising of the sun. When the enemy shall come in like a flood, the Spirit of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall lift up a standard against him.

<b>20 </b>¶ And the Redeemer shall come to Zion, and unto them that turn from transgression in Jacob, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>21 </b>As for me, this <i>is</i> my covenant with them, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; My spirit that <i>is</i> upon thee, and my words which I have put in thy mouth, shall not depart out of thy mouth, nor out of the mouth of thy seed, nor out of the mouth of thy seed’s seed, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, from henceforth and for ever.


--------------------

CHAPTER 60

<b>1 </b>Arise, shine; for thy light is come, and the glory of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> is risen upon thee.

<b>2 </b>For, behold, the darkness shall cover the earth, and gross darkness the people: but the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall arise upon thee, and his glory shall be seen upon thee.

<b>3 </b>And the Gentiles shall come to thy light, and kings to the brightness of thy rising.

<b>4 </b>Lift up thine eyes round about, and see: all they gather themselves together, they come to thee: thy sons shall come from far, and thy daughters shall be nursed at <i>thy</i> side.

<b>5 </b>Then thou shalt see, and flow together, and thine heart shall fear, and be enlarged; because the abundance of the sea shall be converted unto thee, the forces of the Gentiles shall come unto thee.

<b>6 </b>The multitude of camels shall cover thee, the dromedaries of Midian and Ephah; all they from Sheba shall come: they shall bring gold and incense; and they shall shew forth the praises of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>7 </b>All the flocks of Kedar shall be gathered together unto thee, the rams of Nebaioth shall minister unto thee: they shall come up with acceptance on mine altar, and I will glorify the house of my glory.

<b>8 </b>Who <i>are</i> these <i>that</i> fly as a cloud, and as the doves to their windows?

<b>9 </b>Surely the isles shall wait for me, and the ships of Tarshish first, to bring thy sons from far, their silver and their gold with them, unto the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, and to the Holy One of Israel, because he hath glorified thee.

<b>10 </b>And the sons of strangers shall build up thy walls, and their kings shall minister unto thee: for in my wrath I smote thee, but in my favour have I had mercy on thee.

<b>11 </b>Therefore thy gates shall be open continually; they shall not be shut day nor night; that <i>men</i> may bring unto thee the forces of the Gentiles, and <i>that</i> their kings <i>may be</i> brought.

<b>12 </b>For the nation and kingdom that will not serve thee shall perish; yea, <i>those</i> nations shall be utterly wasted.
