<b>13 </b>The glory of Lebanon shall come unto thee, the fir tree, the pine tree, and the box together, to beautify the place of my sanctuary; and I will make the place of my feet glorious.

<b>14 </b>The sons also of them that afflicted thee shall come bending unto thee; and all they that despised thee shall bow themselves down at the soles of thy feet; and they shall call thee, The city of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, The Zion of the Holy One of Israel.

<b>15 </b>Whereas thou hast been forsaken and hated, so that no man went through <i>thee,</i> I will make thee an eternal excellency, a joy of many generations.

<b>16 </b>Thou shalt also suck the milk of the Gentiles, and shalt suck the breast of kings: and thou shalt know that I the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>am</i> thy Saviour and thy Redeemer, the mighty One of Jacob.

<b>17 </b>For brass I will bring gold, and for iron I will bring silver, and for wood brass, and for stones iron: I will also make thy officers peace, and thine exactors righteousness.

<b>18 </b>Violence shall no more be heard in thy land, wasting nor destruction within thy borders; but thou shalt call thy walls Salvation, and thy gates Praise.

<b>19 </b>The sun shall be no more thy light by day; neither for brightness shall the moon give light unto thee: but the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall be unto thee an everlasting light, and thy God thy glory.

<b>20 </b>Thy sun shall no more go down; neither shall thy moon withdraw itself: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall be thine everlasting light, and the days of thy mourning shall be ended.

<b>21 </b>Thy people also <i>shall be</i> all righteous: they shall inherit the land for ever, the branch of my planting, the work of my hands, that I may be glorified.

<b>22 </b>A little one shall become a thousand, and a small one a strong nation: I the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will hasten it in his time.


--------------------

CHAPTER 61

<b>1 </b>The Spirit of the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> <i>is</i> upon me; because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath anointed me to preach good tidings unto the meek; he hath sent me to bind up the brokenhearted, to proclaim liberty to the captives, and the opening of the prison to <i>them that are</i> bound;

<b>2 </b>To proclaim the acceptable year of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and the day of vengeance of our God; to comfort all that mourn;

<b>3 </b>To appoint unto them that mourn in Zion, to give unto them beauty for ashes, the oil of joy for mourning, the garment of praise for the spirit of heaviness; that they might be called trees of righteousness, the planting of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that he might be glorified.

<b>4 </b>¶ And they shall build the old wastes, they shall raise up the former desolations, and they shall repair the waste cities, the desolations of many generations.

<b>5 </b>And strangers shall stand and feed your flocks, and the sons of the alien <i>shall be</i> your plowmen and your vinedressers.

<b>6 </b>But ye shall be named the Priests of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: <i>men</i> shall call you the Ministers of our God: ye shall eat the riches of the Gentiles, and in their glory shall ye boast yourselves.

<b>7 </b>¶ For your shame <i>ye shall have</i> double; and <i>for</i> confusion they shall rejoice in their portion: therefore in their land they shall possess the double: everlasting joy shall be unto them.

<b>8 </b>For I the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> love judgment, I hate robbery for burnt offering; and I will direct their work in truth, and I will make an everlasting covenant with them.

<b>9 </b>And their seed shall be known among the Gentiles, and their offspring among the people: all that see them shall acknowledge them, that they <i>are</i> the seed <i>which</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath blessed.

<b>10 </b>I will greatly rejoice in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, my soul shall be joyful in my God; for he hath clothed me with the garments of salvation, he hath covered me with the robe of righteousness, as a bridegroom decketh <i>himself</i> with ornaments, and as a bride adorneth <i>herself</i> with her jewels.

<b>11 </b>For as the earth bringeth forth her bud, and as the garden causeth the things that are sown in it to spring forth; so the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> will cause righteousness and praise to spring forth before all the nations.


--------------------

CHAPTER 62

<b>1 </b>For Zion’s sake will I not hold my peace, and for Jerusalem’s sake I will not rest, until the righteousness thereof go forth as brightness, and the salvation thereof as a lamp <i>that</i> burneth.

<b>2 </b>And the Gentiles shall see thy righteousness, and all kings thy glory: and thou shalt be called by a new name, which the mouth of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall name.

<b>3 </b>Thou shalt also be a crown of glory in the hand of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and a royal diadem in the hand of thy God.

<b>4 </b>Thou shalt no more be termed Forsaken; neither shall thy land any more be termed Desolate: but thou shalt be called Hephzi-bah, and thy land Beulah: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> delighteth in thee, and thy land shall be married.

<b>5 </b>¶ For <i>as</i> a young man marrieth a virgin, <i>so</i> shall thy sons marry thee: and <i>as</i> the bridegroom rejoiceth over the bride, <i>so</i> shall thy God rejoice over thee.

<b>6 </b>I have set watchmen upon thy walls, O Jerusalem, <i>which</i> shall never hold their peace day nor night: ye that make mention of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, keep not silence,

<b>7 </b>And give him no rest, till he establish, and till he make Jerusalem a praise in the earth.

<b>8 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath sworn by his right hand, and by the arm of his strength, Surely I will no more give thy corn <i>to be</i> meat for thine enemies; and the sons of the stranger shall not drink thy wine, for the which thou hast laboured:

<b>9 </b>But they that have gathered it shall eat it, and praise the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and they that have brought it together shall drink it in the courts of my holiness.

<b>10 </b>¶ Go through, go through the gates; prepare ye the way of the people; cast up, cast up the highway; gather out the stones; lift up a standard for the people.

<b>11 </b>Behold, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath proclaimed unto the end of the world, Say ye to the daughter of Zion, Behold, thy salvation cometh; behold, his reward <i>is</i> with him, and his work before him.

<b>12 </b>And they shall call them, The holy people, The redeemed of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and thou shalt be called, Sought out, A city not forsaken.


--------------------

CHAPTER 63

<b>1 </b>Who <i>is</i> this that cometh from Edom, with dyed garments from Bozrah? this <i>that is</i> glorious in his apparel, travelling in the greatness of his strength? I that speak in righteousness, mighty to save.

<b>2 </b>Wherefore <i>art thou</i> red in thine apparel, and thy garments like him that treadeth in the winefat?

<b>3 </b>I have trodden the winepress alone; and of the people <i>there was</i> none with me: for I will tread them in mine anger, and trample them in my fury; and their blood shall be sprinkled upon my garments, and I will stain all my raiment.

<b>4 </b>For the day of vengeance <i>is</i> in mine heart, and the year of my redeemed is come.

<b>5 </b>And I looked, and <i>there was</i> none to help; and I wondered that <i>there was</i> none to uphold: therefore mine own arm brought salvation unto me; and my fury, it upheld me.

<b>6 </b>And I will tread down the people in mine anger, and make them drunk in my fury, and I will bring down their strength to the earth.

<b>7 </b>¶ I will mention the lovingkindnesses of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>and</i> the praises of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, according to all that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath bestowed on us, and the great goodness toward the house of Israel, which he hath bestowed on them according to his mercies, and according to the multitude of his lovingkindnesses.

<b>8 </b>For he said, Surely they <i>are</i> my people, children <i>that</i> will not lie: so he was their Saviour.

<b>9 </b>In all their affliction he was afflicted, and the angel of his presence saved them: in his love and in his pity he redeemed them; and he bare them, and carried them all the days of old.

<b>10 </b>¶ But they rebelled, and vexed his holy Spirit: therefore he was turned to be their enemy, <i>and</i> he fought against them.

<b>11 </b>Then he remembered the days of old, Moses, <i>and</i> his people, <i>saying,</i> Where <i>is</i> he that brought them up out of the sea with the shepherd of his flock? where <i>is</i> he that put his holy Spirit within him?

<b>12 </b>That led <i>them</i> by the right hand of Moses with his glorious arm, dividing the water before them, to make himself an everlasting name?

<b>13 </b>That led them through the deep, as an horse in the wilderness, <i>that</i> they should not stumble?

<b>14 </b>As a beast goeth down into the valley, the Spirit of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> caused him to rest: so didst thou lead thy people, to make thyself a glorious name.

<b>15 </b>¶ Look down from heaven, and behold from the habitation of thy holiness and of thy glory: where <i>is</i> thy zeal and thy strength, the sounding of thy bowels and of thy mercies toward me? are they restrained?

<b>16 </b>Doubtless thou <i>art</i> our father, though Abraham be ignorant of us, and Israel acknowledge us not: thou, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>art</i> our father, our redeemer; thy name <i>is</i> from everlasting.

<b>17 </b>¶ O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, why hast thou made us to err from thy ways, <i>and</i> hardened our heart from thy fear? Return for thy servants’ sake, the tribes of thine inheritance.

<b>18 </b>The people of thy holiness have possessed <i>it</i> but a little while: our adversaries have trodden down thy sanctuary.

<b>19 </b>We are <i>thine:</i> thou never barest rule over them; they were not called by thy name.


--------------------

CHAPTER 64

<b>1 </b>Oh that thou wouldest rend the heavens, that thou wouldest come down, that the mountains might flow down at thy presence,

<b>2 </b>As <i>when</i> the melting fire burneth, the fire causeth the waters to boil, to make thy name known to thine adversaries, <i>that</i> the nations may tremble at thy presence!

<b>3 </b>When thou didst terrible things <i>which</i> we looked not for, thou camest down, the mountains flowed down at thy presence.

<b>4 </b>For since the beginning of the world <i>men</i> have not heard, nor perceived by the ear, neither hath the eye seen, O God, beside thee, <i>what</i> he hath prepared for him that waiteth for him.

<b>5 </b>Thou meetest him that rejoiceth and worketh righteousness, <i>those that</i> remember thee in thy ways: behold, thou art wroth; for we have sinned: in those is continuance, and we shall be saved.

<b>6 </b>But we are all as an unclean <i>thing</i><i>,</i> and all our righteousnesses <i>are</i> as filthy rags; and we all do fade as a leaf; and our iniquities, like the wind, have taken us away.

<b>7 </b>And <i>there is</i> none that calleth upon thy name, that stirreth up himself to take hold of thee: for thou hast hid thy face from us, and hast consumed us, because of our iniquities.

<b>8 </b>But now, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, thou <i>art</i> our father; we <i>are</i> the clay, and thou our potter; and we all <i>are</i> the work of thy hand.

<b>9 </b>¶ Be not wroth very sore, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, neither remember iniquity for ever: behold, see, we beseech thee, we <i>are</i> all thy people.

<b>10 </b>Thy holy cities are a wilderness, Zion is a wilderness, Jerusalem a desolation.

<b>11 </b>Our holy and our beautiful house, where our fathers praised thee, is burned up with fire: and all our pleasant things are laid waste.

<b>12 </b>Wilt thou refrain thyself for these <i>things,</i> O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>? wilt thou hold thy peace, and afflict us very sore?


--------------------

CHAPTER 65

<b>1 </b>I am sought of <i>them that</i> asked not <i>for me;</i> I am found of <i>them that</i> sought me not: I said, Behold me, behold me, unto a nation <i>that</i> was not called by my name.

<b>2 </b>I have spread out my hands all the day unto a rebellious people, which walketh in a way <i>that was</i> not good, after their own thoughts;

<b>3 </b>A people that provoketh me to anger continually to my face; that sacrificeth in gardens, and burneth incense upon altars of brick;

<b>4 </b>Which remain among the graves, and lodge in the monuments, which eat swine’s flesh, and broth of abominable <i>things is in</i> their vessels;

<b>5 </b>Which say, Stand by thyself, come not near to me; for I am holier than thou. These <i>are</i> a smoke in my nose, a fire that burneth all the day.

<b>6 </b>Behold, <i>it is</i> written before me: I will not keep silence, but will recompense, even recompense into their bosom,

<b>7 </b>Your iniquities, and the iniquities of your fathers together, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which have burned incense upon the mountains, and blasphemed me upon the hills: therefore will I measure their former work into their bosom.

<b>8 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, As the new wine is found in the cluster, and <i>one</i> saith, Destroy it not; for a blessing <i>is</i> in it: so will I do for my servants’ sakes, that I may not destroy them all.

<b>9 </b>And I will bring forth a seed out of Jacob, and out of Judah an inheritor of my mountains: and mine elect shall inherit it, and my servants shall dwell there.

<b>10 </b>And Sharon shall be a fold of flocks, and the valley of Achor a place for the herds to lie down in, for my people that have sought me.

<b>11 </b>¶ But ye <i>are</i> they that forsake the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that forget my holy mountain, that prepare a table for that troop, and that furnish the drink offering unto that number.

<b>12 </b>Therefore will I number you to the sword, and ye shall all bow down to the slaughter: because when I called, ye did not answer; when I spake, ye did not hear; but did evil before mine eyes, and did choose <i>that</i> wherein I delighted not.

<b>13 </b>Therefore thus saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>, Behold, my servants shall eat, but ye shall be hungry: behold, my servants shall drink, but ye shall be thirsty: behold, my servants shall rejoice, but ye shall be ashamed:

<b>14 </b>Behold, my servants shall sing for joy of heart, but ye shall cry for sorrow of heart, and shall howl for vexation of spirit.

<b>15 </b>And ye shall leave your name for a curse unto my chosen: for the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> shall slay thee, and call his servants by another name:

<b>16 </b>That he who blesseth himself in the earth shall bless himself in the God of truth; and he that sweareth in the earth shall swear by the God of truth; because the former troubles are forgotten, and because they are hid from mine eyes.

<b>17 </b>¶ For, behold, I create new heavens and a new earth: and the former shall not be remembered, nor come into mind.

<b>18 </b>But be ye glad and rejoice for ever <i>in that</i> which I create: for, behold, I create Jerusalem a rejoicing, and her people a joy.

<b>19 </b>And I will rejoice in Jerusalem, and joy in my people: and the voice of weeping shall be no more heard in her, nor the voice of crying.

<b>20 </b>There shall be no more thence an infant of days, nor an old man that hath not filled his days: for the child shall die an hundred years old; but the sinner <i>being</i> an hundred years old shall be accursed.

<b>21 </b>And they shall build houses, and inhabit <i>them;</i> and they shall plant vineyards, and eat the fruit of them.

<b>22 </b>They shall not build, and another inhabit; they shall not plant, and another eat: for as the days of a tree <i>are</i> the days of my people, and mine elect shall long enjoy the work of their hands.

<b>23 </b>They shall not labour in vain, nor bring forth for trouble; for they <i>are</i> the seed of the blessed of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and their offspring with them.

<b>24 </b>And it shall come to pass, that before they call, I will answer; and while they are yet speaking, I will hear.

<b>25 </b>The wolf and the lamb shall feed together, and the lion shall eat straw like the bullock: and dust <i>shall be</i> the serpent’s meat. They shall not hurt nor destroy in all my holy mountain, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

CHAPTER 66

<b>1 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, The heaven <i>is</i> my throne, and the earth <i>is</i> my footstool: where <i>is</i> the house that ye build unto me? and where <i>is</i> the place of my rest?

<b>2 </b>For all those <i>things</i> hath mine hand made, and all those <i>things</i> have been, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: but to this <i>man</i> will I look, <i>even</i> to <i>him that is</i> poor and of a contrite spirit, and trembleth at my word.

<b>3 </b>He that killeth an ox <i>is as if</i> he slew a man; he that sacrificeth a lamb, <i>as if</i> he cut off a dog’s neck; he that offereth an oblation, <i>as if he offered</i> swine’s blood; he that burneth incense, <i>as if</i> he blessed an idol. Yea, they have chosen their own ways, and their soul delighteth in their abominations.

<b>4 </b>I also will choose their delusions, and will bring their fears upon them; because when I called, none did answer; when I spake, they did not hear: but they did evil before mine eyes, and chose <i>that</i> in which I delighted not.

<b>5 </b>¶ Hear the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, ye that tremble at his word; Your brethren that hated you, that cast you out for my name’s sake, said, Let the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> be glorified: but he shall appear to your joy, and they shall be ashamed.

<b>6 </b>A voice of noise from the city, a voice from the temple, a voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that rendereth recompence to his enemies.

<b>7 </b>Before she travailed, she brought forth; before her pain came, she was delivered of a man child.

<b>8 </b>Who hath heard such a thing? who hath seen such things? Shall the earth be made to bring forth in one day? <i>or</i> shall a nation be born at once? for as soon as Zion travailed, she brought forth her children.

<b>9 </b>Shall I bring to the birth, and not cause to bring forth? saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: shall I cause to bring forth, and shut <i>the womb?</i> saith thy God.

<b>10 </b>Rejoice ye with Jerusalem, and be glad with her, all ye that love her: rejoice for joy with her, all ye that mourn for her:

<b>11 </b>That ye may suck, and be satisfied with the breasts of her consolations; that ye may milk out, and be delighted with the abundance of her glory.

<b>12 </b>For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Behold, I will extend peace to her like a river, and the glory of the Gentiles like a flowing stream: then shall ye suck, ye shall be borne upon <i>her</i> sides, and be dandled upon <i>her</i> knees.

<b>13 </b>As one whom his mother comforteth, so will I comfort you; and ye shall be comforted in Jerusalem.

<b>14 </b>And when ye see <i>this,</i> your heart shall rejoice, and your bones shall flourish like an herb: and the hand of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall be known toward his servants, and <i>his</i> indignation toward his enemies.

<b>15 </b>For, behold, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will come with fire, and with his chariots like a whirlwind, to render his anger with fury, and his rebuke with flames of fire.

<b>16 </b>For by fire and by his sword will the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> plead with all flesh: and the slain of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall be many.

<b>17 </b>They that sanctify themselves, and purify themselves in the gardens behind one <i>tree</i> in the midst, eating swine’s flesh, and the abomination, and the mouse, shall be consumed together, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>18 </b>For I <i>know</i> their works and their thoughts: it shall come, that I will gather all nations and tongues; and they shall come, and see my glory.

<b>19 </b>And I will set a sign among them, and I will send those that escape of them unto the nations, <i>to</i> Tarshish, Pul, and Lud, that draw the bow, <i>to</i> Tubal, and Javan, <i>to</i> the isles afar off, that have not heard my fame, neither have seen my glory; and they shall declare my glory among the Gentiles.

<b>20 </b>And they shall bring all your brethren <i>for</i> an offering unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> out of all nations upon horses, and in chariots, and in litters, and upon mules, and upon swift beasts, to my holy mountain Jerusalem, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, as the children of Israel bring an offering in a clean vessel into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>21 </b>And I will also take of them for priests <i>and</i> for Levites, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>22 </b>For as the new heavens and the new earth, which I will make, shall remain before me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, so shall your seed and your name remain.

<b>23 </b>And it shall come to pass, <i>that</i> from one new moon to another, and from one sabbath to another, shall all flesh come to worship before me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>24 </b>And they shall go forth, and look upon the carcases of the men that have transgressed against me: for their worm shall not die, neither shall their fire be quenched; and they shall be an abhorring unto all flesh.


--------------------

<small>The Book of the Prophet </small>Jeremiah

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>The words of Jeremiah the son of Hilkiah, of the priests that <i>were</i> in Anathoth in the land of Benjamin:

<b>2 </b>To whom the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came in the days of Josiah the son of Amon king of Judah, in the thirteenth year of his reign.

<b>3 </b>It came also in the days of Jehoiakim the son of Josiah king of Judah, unto the end of the eleventh year of Zedekiah the son of Josiah king of Judah, unto the carrying away of Jerusalem captive in the fifth month.

<b>4 </b>Then the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto me, saying,

<b>5 </b>Before I formed thee in the belly I knew thee; and before thou camest forth out of the womb I sanctified thee, <i>and</i> I ordained thee a prophet unto the nations.

<b>6 </b>Then said I, Ah, Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>! behold, I cannot speak: for I <i>am</i> a child.

<b>7 </b>¶ But the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, Say not, I <i>am</i> a child: for thou shalt go to all that I shall send thee, and whatsoever I command thee thou shalt speak.

<b>8 </b>Be not afraid of their faces: for I <i>am</i> with thee to deliver thee, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>9 </b>Then the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> put forth his hand, and touched my mouth. And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, Behold, I have put my words in thy mouth.

<b>10 </b>See, I have this day set thee over the nations and over the kingdoms, to root out, and to pull down, and to destroy, and to throw down, to build, and to plant.

<b>11 </b>¶ Moreover the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto me, saying, Jeremiah, what seest thou? And I said, I see a rod of an almond tree.

<b>12 </b>Then said the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto me, Thou hast well seen: for I will hasten my word to perform it.

<b>13 </b>And the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto me the second time, saying, What seest thou? And I said, I see a seething pot; and the face thereof <i>is</i> toward the north.

<b>14 </b>Then the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, Out of the north an evil shall break forth upon all the inhabitants of the land.

<b>15 </b>For, lo, I will call all the families of the kingdoms of the north, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and they shall come, and they shall set every one his throne at the entering of the gates of Jerusalem, and against all the walls thereof round about, and against all the cities of Judah.

<b>16 </b>And I will utter my judgments against them touching all their wickedness, who have forsaken me, and have burned incense unto other gods, and worshipped the works of their own hands.

<b>17 </b>¶ Thou therefore gird up thy loins, and arise, and speak unto them all that I command thee: be not dismayed at their faces, lest I confound thee before them.

<b>18 </b>For, behold, I have made thee this day a defenced city, and an iron pillar, and brasen walls against the whole land, against the kings of Judah, against the princes thereof, against the priests thereof, and against the people of the land.

<b>19 </b>And they shall fight against thee; but they shall not prevail against thee; for I <i>am</i> with thee, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to deliver thee.


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>Moreover the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came to me, saying,

<b>2 </b>Go and cry in the ears of Jerusalem, saying, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; I remember thee, the kindness of thy youth, the love of thine espousals, when thou wentest after me in the wilderness, in a land <i>that was</i> not sown.

<b>3 </b>Israel <i>was</i> holiness unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>and</i> the firstfruits of his increase: all that devour him shall offend; evil shall come upon them, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>4 </b>Hear ye the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, O house of Jacob, and all the families of the house of Israel:

<b>5 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, What iniquity have your fathers found in me, that they are gone far from me, and have walked after vanity, and are become vain?

<b>6 </b>Neither said they, Where <i>is</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that brought us up out of the land of Egypt, that led us through the wilderness, through a land of deserts and of pits, through a land of drought, and of the shadow of death, through a land that no man passed through, and where no man dwelt?

<b>7 </b>And I brought you into a plentiful country, to eat the fruit thereof and the goodness thereof; but when ye entered, ye defiled my land, and made mine heritage an abomination.

<b>8 </b>The priests said not, Where <i>is</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>? and they that handle the law knew me not: the pastors also transgressed against me, and the prophets prophesied by Baal, and walked after <i>things that</i> do not profit.

<b>9 </b>¶ Wherefore I will yet plead with you, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and with your children’s children will I plead.

<b>10 </b>For pass over the isles of Chittim, and see; and send unto Kedar, and consider diligently, and see if there be such a thing.

<b>11 </b>Hath a nation changed <i>their</i> gods, which <i>are</i> yet no gods? but my people have changed their glory for <i>that which</i> doth not profit.

<b>12 </b>Be astonished, O ye heavens, at this, and be horribly afraid, be ye very desolate, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>13 </b>For my people have committed two evils; they have forsaken me the fountain of living waters, <i>and</i> hewed them out cisterns, broken cisterns, that can hold no water.

<b>14 </b>¶ <i>Is</i> Israel a servant? <i>is</i> he a homeborn <i>slave?</i> why is he spoiled?

<b>15 </b>The young lions roared upon him, <i>and</i> yelled, and they made his land waste: his cities are burned without inhabitant.

<b>16 </b>Also the children of Noph and Tahapanes have broken the crown of thy head.

<b>17 </b>Hast thou not procured this unto thyself, in that thou hast forsaken the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, when he led thee by the way?

<b>18 </b>And now what hast thou to do in the way of Egypt, to drink the waters of Sihor? or what hast thou to do in the way of Assyria, to drink the waters of the river?

<b>19 </b>Thine own wickedness shall correct thee, and thy backslidings shall reprove thee: know therefore and see that <i>it is</i> an evil <i>thing</i> and bitter, that thou hast forsaken the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, and that my fear <i>is</i> not in thee, saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> of hosts.

<b>20 </b>¶ For of old time I have broken thy yoke, <i>and</i> burst thy bands; and thou saidst, I will not transgress; when upon every high hill and under every green tree thou wanderest, playing the harlot.

<b>21 </b>Yet I had planted thee a noble vine, wholly a right seed: how then art thou turned into the degenerate plant of a strange vine unto me?

<b>22 </b>For though thou wash thee with nitre, and take thee much soap, <i>yet</i> thine iniquity is marked before me, saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>.

<b>23 </b>How canst thou say, I am not polluted, I have not gone after Baalim? see thy way in the valley, know what thou hast done: <i>thou art</i> a swift dromedary traversing her ways;

<b>24 </b>A wild ass used to the wilderness, <i>that</i> snuffeth up the wind at her pleasure; in her occasion who can turn her away? all they that seek her will not weary themselves; in her month they shall find her.

<b>25 </b>Withhold thy foot from being unshod, and thy throat from thirst: but thou saidst, There is no hope: no; for I have loved strangers, and after them will I go.

<b>26 </b>As the thief is ashamed when he is found, so is the house of Israel ashamed; they, their kings, their princes, and their priests, and their prophets,

<b>27 </b>Saying to a stock, Thou <i>art</i> my father; and to a stone, Thou hast brought me forth: for they have turned <i>their</i> back unto me, and not <i>their</i> face: but in the time of their trouble they will say, Arise, and save us.

<b>28 </b>But where <i>are</i> thy gods that thou hast made thee? let them arise, if they can save thee in the time of thy trouble: for <i>according to</i> the number of thy cities are thy gods, O Judah.

<b>29 </b>Wherefore will ye plead with me? ye all have transgressed against me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>30 </b>In vain have I smitten your children; they received no correction: your own sword hath devoured your prophets, like a destroying lion.

<b>31 </b>¶ O generation, see ye the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. Have I been a wilderness unto Israel? a land of darkness? wherefore say my people, We are lords; we will come no more unto thee?

<b>32 </b>Can a maid forget her ornaments, <i>or</i> a bride her attire? yet my people have forgotten me days without number.

<b>33 </b>Why trimmest thou thy way to seek love? therefore hast thou also taught the wicked ones thy ways.

<b>34 </b>Also in thy skirts is found the blood of the souls of the poor innocents: I have not found it by secret search, but upon all these.

<b>35 </b>Yet thou sayest, Because I am innocent, surely his anger shall turn from me. Behold, I will plead with thee, because thou sayest, I have not sinned.

<b>36 </b>Why gaddest thou about so much to change thy way? thou also shalt be ashamed of Egypt, as thou wast ashamed of Assyria.

<b>37 </b>Yea, thou shalt go forth from him, and thine hands upon thine head: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath rejected thy confidences, and thou shalt not prosper in them.


--------------------

CHAPTER 3

<b>1 </b>They say, If a man put away his wife, and she go from him, and become another man’s, shall he return unto her again? shall not that land be greatly polluted? but thou hast played the harlot with many lovers; yet return again to me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>2 </b>Lift up thine eyes unto the high places, and see where thou hast not been lien with. In the ways hast thou sat for them, as the Arabian in the wilderness; and thou hast polluted the land with thy whoredoms and with thy wickedness.

<b>3 </b>Therefore the showers have been withholden, and there hath been no latter rain; and thou hadst a whore’s forehead, thou refusedst to be ashamed.

<b>4 </b>Wilt thou not from this time cry unto me, My father, thou <i>art</i> the guide of my youth?

<b>5 </b>Will he reserve <i>his anger</i> for ever? will he keep <i>it</i> to the end? Behold, thou hast spoken and done evil things as thou couldest.

<b>6 </b>¶ The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said also unto me in the days of Josiah the king, Hast thou seen <i>that</i> which backsliding Israel hath done? she is gone up upon every high mountain and under every green tree, and there hath played the harlot.

<b>7 </b>And I said after she had done all these <i>things,</i> Turn thou unto me. But she returned not. And her treacherous sister Judah saw <i>it.</i>

<b>8 </b>And I saw, when for all the causes whereby backsliding Israel committed adultery I had put her away, and given her a bill of divorce; yet her treacherous sister Judah feared not, but went and played the harlot also.

<b>9 </b>And it came to pass through the lightness of her whoredom, that she defiled the land, and committed adultery with stones and with stocks.

<b>10 </b>And yet for all this her treacherous sister Judah hath not turned unto me with her whole heart, but feignedly, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>11 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, The backsliding Israel hath justified herself more than treacherous Judah.

<b>12 </b>¶ Go and proclaim these words toward the north, and say, Return, thou backsliding Israel, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; <i>and</i> I will not cause mine anger to fall upon you: for I <i>am</i> merciful, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>and</i> I will not keep <i>anger</i> for ever.

<b>13 </b>Only acknowledge thine iniquity, that thou hast transgressed against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, and hast scattered thy ways to the strangers under every green tree, and ye have not obeyed my voice, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>14 </b>Turn, O backsliding children, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for I am married unto you: and I will take you one of a city, and two of a family, and I will bring you to Zion:

<b>15 </b>And I will give you pastors according to mine heart, which shall feed you with knowledge and understanding.

<b>16 </b>And it shall come to pass, when ye be multiplied and increased in the land, in those days, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, they shall say no more, The ark of the covenant of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: neither shall it come to mind: neither shall they remember it; neither shall they visit <i>it;</i> neither shall <i>that</i> be done any more.

<b>17 </b>At that time they shall call Jerusalem the throne of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and all the nations shall be gathered unto it, to the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to Jerusalem: neither shall they walk any more after the imagination of their evil heart.

<b>18 </b>In those days the house of Judah shall walk with the house of Israel, and they shall come together out of the land of the north to the land that I have given for an inheritance unto your fathers.

<b>19 </b>But I said, How shall I put thee among the children, and give thee a pleasant land, a goodly heritage of the hosts of nations? and I said, Thou shalt call me, My father; and shalt not turn away from me.

<b>20 </b>¶ Surely <i>as</i> a wife treacherously departeth from her husband, so have ye dealt treacherously with me, O house of Israel, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>21 </b>A voice was heard upon the high places, weeping <i>and</i> supplications of the children of Israel: for they have perverted their way, <i>and</i> they have forgotten the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> their God.

<b>22 </b>Return, ye backsliding children, <i>and</i> I will heal your backslidings. Behold, we come unto thee; for thou <i>art</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God.

<b>23 </b>Truly in vain <i>is salvation hoped for</i> from the hills, <i>and from</i> the multitude of mountains: truly in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God <i>is</i> the salvation of Israel.

<b>24 </b>For shame hath devoured the labour of our fathers from our youth; their flocks and their herds, their sons and their daughters.

<b>25 </b>We lie down in our shame, and our confusion covereth us: for we have sinned against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God, we and our fathers, from our youth even unto this day, and have not obeyed the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God.


--------------------

CHAPTER 4

<b>1 </b>If thou wilt return, O Israel, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, return unto me: and if thou wilt put away thine abominations out of my sight, then shalt thou not remove.

<b>2 </b>And thou shalt swear, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, in truth, in judgment, and in righteousness; and the nations shall bless themselves in him, and in him shall they glory.

<b>3 </b>¶ For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> to the men of Judah and Jerusalem, Break up your fallow ground, and sow not among thorns.

<b>4 </b>Circumcise yourselves to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and take away the foreskins of your heart, ye men of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem: lest my fury come forth like fire, and burn that none can quench <i>it,</i> because of the evil of your doings.

<b>5 </b>Declare ye in Judah, and publish in Jerusalem; and say, Blow ye the trumpet in the land: cry, gather together, and say, Assemble yourselves, and let us go into the defenced cities.

<b>6 </b>Set up the standard toward Zion: retire, stay not: for I will bring evil from the north, and a great destruction.

<b>7 </b>The lion is come up from his thicket, and the destroyer of the Gentiles is on his way; he is gone forth from his place to make thy land desolate; <i>and</i> thy cities shall be laid waste, without an inhabitant.

<b>8 </b>For this gird you with sackcloth, lament and howl: for the fierce anger of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> is not turned back from us.

<b>9 </b>And it shall come to pass at that day, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>that</i> the heart of the king shall perish, and the heart of the princes; and the priests shall be astonished, and the prophets shall wonder.

<b>10 </b>Then said I, Ah, Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>! surely thou hast greatly deceived this people and Jerusalem, saying, Ye shall have peace; whereas the sword reacheth unto the soul.

<b>11 </b>At that time shall it be said to this people and to Jerusalem, A dry wind of the high places in the wilderness toward the daughter of my people, not to fan, nor to cleanse,

<b>12 </b><i>Even</i> a full wind from those <i>places</i> shall come unto me: now also will I give sentence against them.

<b>13 </b>Behold, he shall come up as clouds, and his chariots <i>shall be</i> as a whirlwind: his horses are swifter than eagles. Woe unto us! for we are spoiled.

<b>14 </b>O Jerusalem, wash thine heart from wickedness, that thou mayest be saved. How long shall thy vain thoughts lodge within thee?

<b>15 </b>For a voice declareth from Dan, and publisheth affliction from mount Ephraim.

<b>16 </b>Make ye mention to the nations; behold, publish against Jerusalem, <i>that</i> watchers come from a far country, and give out their voice against the cities of Judah.

<b>17 </b>As keepers of a field, are they against her round about; because she hath been rebellious against me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>18 </b>Thy way and thy doings have procured these <i>things</i> unto thee; this <i>is</i> thy wickedness, because it is bitter, because it reacheth unto thine heart.

<b>19 </b>¶ My bowels, my bowels! I am pained at my very heart; my heart maketh a noise in me; I cannot hold my peace, because thou hast heard, O my soul, the sound of the trumpet, the alarm of war.

<b>20 </b>Destruction upon destruction is cried; for the whole land is spoiled: suddenly are my tents spoiled, <i>and</i> my curtains in a moment.

<b>21 </b>How long shall I see the standard, <i>and</i> hear the sound of the trumpet?

<b>22 </b>For my people <i>is</i> foolish, they have not known me; they <i>are</i> sottish children, and they have none understanding: they <i>are</i> wise to do evil, but to do good they have no knowledge.

<b>23 </b>I beheld the earth, and, lo, <i>it was</i> without form, and void; and the heavens, and they <i>had</i> no light.

<b>24 </b>I beheld the mountains, and, lo, they trembled, and all the hills moved lightly.

<b>25 </b>I beheld, and, lo, <i>there was</i> no man, and all the birds of the heavens were fled.

<b>26 </b>I beheld, and, lo, the fruitful place <i>was</i> a wilderness, and all the cities thereof were broken down at the presence of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>and</i> by his fierce anger.

<b>27 </b>For thus hath the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said, The whole land shall be desolate; yet will I not make a full end.

<b>28 </b>For this shall the earth mourn, and the heavens above be black: because I have spoken <i>it,</i> I have purposed <i>it,</i> and will not repent, neither will I turn back from it.

<b>29 </b>The whole city shall flee for the noise of the horsemen and bowmen; they shall go into thickets, and climb up upon the rocks: every city <i>shall be</i> forsaken, and not a man dwell therein.

<b>30 </b>And <i>when</i> thou <i>art</i> spoiled, what wilt thou do? Though thou clothest thyself with crimson, though thou deckest thee with ornaments of gold, though thou rentest thy face with painting, in vain shalt thou make thyself fair; <i>thy</i> lovers will despise thee, they will seek thy life.

<b>31 </b>For I have heard a voice as of a woman in travail, <i>and</i> the anguish as of her that bringeth forth her first child, the voice of the daughter of Zion, <i>that</i> bewaileth herself, <i>that</i> spreadeth her hands, <i>saying,</i> Woe <i>is</i> me now! for my soul is wearied because of murderers.


--------------------

CHAPTER 5

<b>1 </b>Run ye to and fro through the streets of Jerusalem, and see now, and know, and seek in the broad places thereof, if ye can find a man, if there be <i>any</i> that executeth judgment, that seeketh the truth; and I will pardon it.

<b>2 </b>And though they say, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth; surely they swear falsely.

<b>3 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>are</i> not thine eyes upon the truth? thou hast stricken them, but they have not grieved; thou hast consumed them, <i>but</i> they have refused to receive correction: they have made their faces harder than a rock; they have refused to return.

<b>4 </b>Therefore I said, Surely these <i>are</i> poor; they are foolish: for they know not the way of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>nor</i> the judgment of their God.

<b>5 </b>I will get me unto the great men, and will speak unto them; for they have known the way of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>and</i> the judgment of their God: but these have altogether broken the yoke, <i>and</i> burst the bonds.

<b>6 </b>Wherefore a lion out of the forest shall slay them, <i>and</i> a wolf of the evenings shall spoil them, a leopard shall watch over their cities: every one that goeth out thence shall be torn in pieces: because their transgressions are many, <i>and</i> their backslidings are increased.

<b>7 </b>¶ How shall I pardon thee for this? thy children have forsaken me, and sworn by <i>them that are</i> no gods: when I had fed them to the full, they then committed adultery, and assembled themselves by troops in the harlots’ houses.

<b>8 </b>They were <i>as</i> fed horses in the morning: every one neighed after his neighbour’s wife.

<b>9 </b>Shall I not visit for these <i>things?</i> saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and shall not my soul be avenged on such a nation as this?

<b>10 </b>¶ Go ye up upon her walls, and destroy; but make not a full end: take away her battlements; for they <i>are</i> not the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s.

<b>11 </b>For the house of Israel and the house of Judah have dealt very treacherously against me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>12 </b>They have belied the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and said, <i>It is</i> not he; neither shall evil come upon us; neither shall we see sword nor famine:

<b>13 </b>And the prophets shall become wind, and the word <i>is</i> not in them: thus shall it be done unto them.

<b>14 </b>Wherefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of hosts, Because ye speak this word, behold, I will make my words in thy mouth fire, and this people wood, and it shall devour them.

<b>15 </b>Lo, I will bring a nation upon you from far, O house of Israel, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: it <i>is</i> a mighty nation, it <i>is</i> an ancient nation, a nation whose language thou knowest not, neither understandest what they say.

<b>16 </b>Their quiver <i>is</i> as an open sepulchre, they <i>are</i> all mighty men.

<b>17 </b>And they shall eat up thine harvest, and thy bread, <i>which</i> thy sons and thy daughters should eat: they shall eat up thy flocks and thine herds: they shall eat up thy vines and thy fig trees: they shall impoverish thy fenced cities, wherein thou trustedst, with the sword.

<b>18 </b>Nevertheless in those days, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, I will not make a full end with you.

<b>19 </b>¶ And it shall come to pass, when ye shall say, Wherefore doeth the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God all these <i>things</i> unto us? then shalt thou answer them, Like as ye have forsaken me, and served strange gods in your land, so shall ye serve strangers in a land <i>that is</i> not yours.

<b>20 </b>Declare this in the house of Jacob, and publish it in Judah, saying,

<b>21 </b>Hear now this, O foolish people, and without understanding; which have eyes, and see not; which have ears, and hear not:

<b>22 </b>Fear ye not me? saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: will ye not tremble at my presence, which have placed the sand <i>for</i> the bound of the sea by a perpetual decree, that it cannot pass it: and though the waves thereof toss themselves, yet can they not prevail; though they roar, yet can they not pass over it?

<b>23 </b>But this people hath a revolting and a rebellious heart; they are revolted and gone.

<b>24 </b>Neither say they in their heart, Let us now fear the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God, that giveth rain, both the former and the latter, in his season: he reserveth unto us the appointed weeks of the harvest.

<b>25 </b>¶ Your iniquities have turned away these <i>things,</i> and your sins have withholden good <i>things</i> from you.

<b>26 </b>For among my people are found wicked <i>men:</i> they lay wait, as he that setteth snares; they set a trap, they catch men.

<b>27 </b>As a cage is full of birds, so <i>are</i> their houses full of deceit: therefore they are become great, and waxen rich.

<b>28 </b>They are waxen fat, they shine: yea, they overpass the deeds of the wicked: they judge not the cause, the cause of the fatherless, yet they prosper; and the right of the needy do they not judge.

<b>29 </b>Shall I not visit for these <i>things?</i> saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: shall not my soul be avenged on such a nation as this?

<b>30 </b>¶ A wonderful and horrible thing is committed in the land;

<b>31 </b>The prophets prophesy falsely, and the priests bear rule by their means; and my people love <i>to have it</i> so: and what will ye do in the end thereof?


--------------------

CHAPTER 6

<b>1 </b>O ye children of Benjamin, gather yourselves to flee out of the midst of Jerusalem, and blow the trumpet in Tekoa, and set up a sign of fire in Beth-haccerem: for evil appeareth out of the north, and great destruction.

<b>2 </b>I have likened the daughter of Zion to a comely and delicate <i>woman.</i>

<b>3 </b>The shepherds with their flocks shall come unto her; they shall pitch <i>their</i> tents against her round about; they shall feed every one in his place.

<b>4 </b>Prepare ye war against her; arise, and let us go up at noon. Woe unto us! for the day goeth away, for the shadows of the evening are stretched out.

<b>5 </b>Arise, and let us go by night, and let us destroy her palaces.

<b>6 </b>¶ For thus hath the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts said, Hew ye down trees, and cast a mount against Jerusalem: this <i>is</i> the city to be visited; she <i>is</i> wholly oppression in the midst of her.

<b>7 </b>As a fountain casteth out her waters, so she casteth out her wickedness: violence and spoil is heard in her; before me continually <i>is</i> grief and wounds.

<b>8 </b>Be thou instructed, O Jerusalem, lest my soul depart from thee; lest I make thee desolate, a land not inhabited.

<b>9 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, They shall throughly glean the remnant of Israel as a vine: turn back thine hand as a grapegatherer into the baskets.

<b>10 </b>To whom shall I speak, and give warning, that they may hear? behold, their ear <i>is</i> uncircumcised, and they cannot hearken: behold, the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> is unto them a reproach; they have no delight in it.

<b>11 </b>Therefore I am full of the fury of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; I am weary with holding in: I will pour it out upon the children abroad, and upon the assembly of young men together: for even the husband with the wife shall be taken, the aged with <i>him that is</i> full of days.

<b>12 </b>And their houses shall be turned unto others, <i>with their</i> fields and wives together: for I will stretch out my hand upon the inhabitants of the land, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>13 </b>For from the least of them even unto the greatest of them every one <i>is</i> given to covetousness; and from the prophet even unto the priest every one dealeth falsely.

<b>14 </b>They have healed also the hurt <i>of the daughter</i> of my people slightly, saying, Peace, peace; when <i>there is</i> no peace.

<b>15 </b>Were they ashamed when they had committed abomination? nay, they were not at all ashamed, neither could they blush: therefore they shall fall among them that fall: at the time <i>that</i> I visit them they shall be cast down, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>16 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Stand ye in the ways, and see, and ask for the old paths, where <i>is</i> the good way, and walk therein, and ye shall find rest for your souls. But they said, We will not walk <i>therein.</i>

<b>17 </b>Also I set watchmen over you, <i>saying,</i> Hearken to the sound of the trumpet. But they said, We will not hearken.

<b>18 </b>¶ Therefore hear, ye nations, and know, O congregation, what <i>is</i> among them.

<b>19 </b>Hear, O earth: behold, I will bring evil upon this people, <i>even</i> the fruit of their thoughts, because they have not hearkened unto my words, nor to my law, but rejected it.

<b>20 </b>To what purpose cometh there to me incense from Sheba, and the sweet cane from a far country? your burnt offerings <i>are</i> not acceptable, nor your sacrifices sweet unto me.

<b>21 </b>Therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Behold, I will lay stumblingblocks before this people, and the fathers and the sons together shall fall upon them; the neighbour and his friend shall perish.

<b>22 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Behold, a people cometh from the north country, and a great nation shall be raised from the sides of the earth.

<b>23 </b>They shall lay hold on bow and spear; they <i>are</i> cruel, and have no mercy; their voice roareth like the sea; and they ride upon horses, set in array as men for war against thee, O daughter of Zion.

<b>24 </b>We have heard the fame thereof: our hands wax feeble: anguish hath taken hold of us, <i>and</i> pain, as of a woman in travail.

<b>25 </b>Go not forth into the field, nor walk by the way; for the sword of the enemy <i>and</i> fear <i>is</i> on every side.

<b>26 </b>¶ O daughter of my people, gird <i>thee</i> with sackcloth, and wallow thyself in ashes: make thee mourning, <i>as for</i> an only son, most bitter lamentation: for the spoiler shall suddenly come upon us.

<b>27 </b>I have set thee <i>for</i> a tower <i>and</i> a fortress among my people, that thou mayest know and try their way.

<b>28 </b>They <i>are</i> all grievous revolters, walking with slanders: <i>they are</i> brass and iron; they <i>are</i> all corrupters.

<b>29 </b>The bellows are burned, the lead is consumed of the fire; the founder melteth in vain: for the wicked are not plucked away.

<b>30 </b>Reprobate silver shall <i>men</i> call them, because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath rejected them.


--------------------

CHAPTER 7

<b>1 </b>The word that came to Jeremiah from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying,

<b>2 </b>Stand in the gate of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s house, and proclaim there this word, and say, Hear the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, all <i>ye of</i> Judah, that enter in at these gates to worship the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>3 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of Israel, Amend your ways and your doings, and I will cause you to dwell in this place.

<b>4 </b>Trust ye not in lying words, saying, The temple of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, The temple of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, The temple of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>are</i> these.

<b>5 </b>For if ye throughly amend your ways and your doings; if ye throughly execute judgment between a man and his neighbour;

<b>6 </b><i>If</i> ye oppress not the stranger, the fatherless, and the widow, and shed not innocent blood in this place, neither walk after other gods to your hurt:

<b>7 </b>Then will I cause you to dwell in this place, in the land that I gave to your fathers, for ever and ever.

<b>8 </b>¶ Behold, ye trust in lying words, that cannot profit.

<b>9 </b>Will ye steal, murder, and commit adultery, and swear falsely, and burn incense unto Baal, and walk after other gods whom ye know not;

<b>10 </b>And come and stand before me in this house, which is called by my name, and say, We are delivered to do all these abominations?

<b>11 </b>Is this house, which is called by my name, become a den of robbers in your eyes? Behold, even I have seen <i>it,</i> saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>12 </b>But go ye now unto my place which <i>was</i> in Shiloh, where I set my name at the first, and see what I did to it for the wickedness of my people Israel.

<b>13 </b>And now, because ye have done all these works, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and I spake unto you, rising up early and speaking, but ye heard not; and I called you, but ye answered not;

<b>14 </b>Therefore will I do unto <i>this</i> house, which is called by my name, wherein ye trust, and unto the place which I gave to you and to your fathers, as I have done to Shiloh.

<b>15 </b>And I will cast you out of my sight, as I have cast out all your brethren, <i>even</i> the whole seed of Ephraim.

<b>16 </b>Therefore pray not thou for this people, neither lift up cry nor prayer for them, neither make intercession to me: for I will not hear thee.

<b>17 </b>¶ Seest thou not what they do in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem?

<b>18 </b>The children gather wood, and the fathers kindle the fire, and the women knead <i>their</i> dough, to make cakes to the queen of heaven, and to pour out drink offerings unto other gods, that they may provoke me to anger.

<b>19 </b>Do they provoke me to anger? saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: <i>do they</i> not <i>provoke</i> themselves to the confusion of their own faces?

<b>20 </b>Therefore thus saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>; Behold, mine anger and my fury shall be poured out upon this place, upon man, and upon beast, and upon the trees of the field, and upon the fruit of the ground; and it shall burn, and shall not be quenched.

<b>21 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of Israel; Put your burnt offerings unto your sacrifices, and eat flesh.

<b>22 </b>For I spake not unto your fathers, nor commanded them in the day that I brought them out of the land of Egypt, concerning burnt offerings or sacrifices:

<b>23 </b>But this thing commanded I them, saying, Obey my voice, and I will be your God, and ye shall be my people: and walk ye in all the ways that I have commanded you, that it may be well unto you.

<b>24 </b>But they hearkened not, nor inclined their ear, but walked in the counsels <i>and</i> in the imagination of their evil heart, and went backward, and not forward.

<b>25 </b>Since the day that your fathers came forth out of the land of Egypt unto this day I have even sent unto you all my servants the prophets, daily rising up early and sending <i>them:</i>

<b>26 </b>Yet they hearkened not unto me, nor inclined their ear, but hardened their neck: they did worse than their fathers.

<b>27 </b>Therefore thou shalt speak all these words unto them; but they will not hearken to thee: thou shalt also call unto them; but they will not answer thee.

<b>28 </b>But thou shalt say unto them, This <i>is</i> a nation that obeyeth not the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> their God, nor receiveth correction: truth is perished, and is cut off from their mouth.

<b>29 </b>¶ Cut off thine hair, <i>O Jerusalem,</i> and cast <i>it</i> away, and take up a lamentation on high places; for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath rejected and forsaken the generation of his wrath.

<b>30 </b>For the children of Judah have done evil in my sight, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: they have set their abominations in the house which is called by my name, to pollute it.

<b>31 </b>And they have built the high places of Tophet, which <i>is</i> in the valley of the son of Hinnom, to burn their sons and their daughters in the fire; which I commanded <i>them</i> not, neither came it into my heart.

<b>32 </b>¶ Therefore, behold, the days come, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that it shall no more be called Tophet, nor the valley of the son of Hinnom, but the valley of slaughter: for they shall bury in Tophet, till there be no place.

<b>33 </b>And the carcases of this people shall be meat for the fowls of the heaven, and for the beasts of the earth; and none shall fray <i>them</i> away.

<b>34 </b>Then will I cause to cease from the cities of Judah, and from the streets of Jerusalem, the voice of mirth, and the voice of gladness, the voice of the bridegroom, and the voice of the bride: for the land shall be desolate.


--------------------

CHAPTER 8

<b>1 </b>At that time, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, they shall bring out the bones of the kings of Judah, and the bones of his princes, and the bones of the priests, and the bones of the prophets, and the bones of the inhabitants of Jerusalem, out of their graves:

<b>2 </b>And they shall spread them before the sun, and the moon, and all the host of heaven, whom they have loved, and whom they have served, and after whom they have walked, and whom they have sought, and whom they have worshipped: they shall not be gathered, nor be buried; they shall be for dung upon the face of the earth.

<b>3 </b>And death shall be chosen rather than life by all the residue of them that remain of this evil family, which remain in all the places whither I have driven them, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts.

<b>4 </b>¶ Moreover thou shalt say unto them, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; Shall they fall, and not arise? shall he turn away, and not return?

<b>5 </b>Why <i>then</i> is this people of Jerusalem slidden back by a perpetual backsliding? they hold fast deceit, they refuse to return.

<b>6 </b>I hearkened and heard, <i>but</i> they spake not aright: no man repented him of his wickedness, saying, What have I done? every one turned to his course, as the horse rusheth into the battle.

<b>7 </b>Yea, the stork in the heaven knoweth her appointed times; and the turtle and the crane and the swallow observe the time of their coming; but my people know not the judgment of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>8 </b>How do ye say, We <i>are</i> wise, and the law of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> with us? Lo, certainly in vain made he <i>it;</i> the pen of the scribes <i>is</i> in vain.

<b>9 </b>The wise <i>men</i> are ashamed, they are dismayed and taken: lo, they have rejected the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and what wisdom <i>is</i> in them?

<b>10 </b>Therefore will I give their wives unto others, <i>and</i> their fields to them that shall inherit <i>them:</i> for every one from the least even unto the greatest is given to covetousness, from the prophet even unto the priest every one dealeth falsely.

<b>11 </b>For they have healed the hurt of the daughter of my people slightly, saying, Peace, peace; when <i>there is</i> no peace.

<b>12 </b>Were they ashamed when they had committed abomination? nay, they were not at all ashamed, neither could they blush: therefore shall they fall among them that fall: in the time of their visitation they shall be cast down, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>13 </b>¶ I will surely consume them, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: <i>there shall be</i> no grapes on the vine, nor figs on the fig tree, and the leaf shall fade; and <i>the things that</i> I have given them shall pass away from them.

<b>14 </b>Why do we sit still? assemble yourselves, and let us enter into the defenced cities, and let us be silent there: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God hath put us to silence, and given us water of gall to drink, because we have sinned against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>15 </b>We looked for peace, but no good <i>came; and</i> for a time of health, and behold trouble!

<b>16 </b>The snorting of his horses was heard from Dan: the whole land trembled at the sound of the neighing of his strong ones; for they are come, and have devoured the land, and all that is in it; the city, and those that dwell therein.

<b>17 </b>For, behold, I will send serpents, cockatrices, among you, which <i>will</i> not <i>be</i> charmed, and they shall bite you, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>18 </b>¶ <i>When</i> I would comfort myself against sorrow, my heart <i>is</i> faint in me.

<b>19 </b>Behold the voice of the cry of the daughter of my people because of them that dwell in a far country: <i>Is</i> not the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in Zion? <i>is</i> not her king in her? Why have they provoked me to anger with their graven images, <i>and</i> with strange vanities?

<b>20 </b>The harvest is past, the summer is ended, and we are not saved.

<b>21 </b>For the hurt of the daughter of my people am I hurt; I am black; astonishment hath taken hold on me.

<b>22 </b><i>Is there</i> no balm in Gilead; <i>is there</i> no physician there? why then is not the health of the daughter of my people recovered?


--------------------

CHAPTER 9

<b>1 </b>Oh that my head were waters, and mine eyes a fountain of tears, that I might weep day and night for the slain of the daughter of my people!

<b>2 </b>Oh that I had in the wilderness a lodging place of wayfaring men; that I might leave my people, and go from them! for they <i>be</i> all adulterers, an assembly of treacherous men.

<b>3 </b>And they bend their tongues <i>like</i> their bow <i>for</i> lies: but they are not valiant for the truth upon the earth; for they proceed from evil to evil, and they know not me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>4 </b>Take ye heed every one of his neighbour, and trust ye not in any brother: for every brother will utterly supplant, and every neighbour will walk with slanders.

<b>5 </b>And they will deceive every one his neighbour, and will not speak the truth: they have taught their tongue to speak lies, <i>and</i> weary themselves to commit iniquity.

<b>6 </b>Thine habitation <i>is</i> in the midst of deceit; through deceit they refuse to know me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>7 </b>Therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, Behold, I will melt them, and try them; for how shall I do for the daughter of my people?

<b>8 </b>Their tongue <i>is as</i> an arrow shot out; it speaketh deceit: <i>one</i> speaketh peaceably to his neighbour with his mouth, but in heart he layeth his wait.

<b>9 </b>¶ Shall I not visit them for these <i>things?</i> saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: shall not my soul be avenged on such a nation as this?

<b>10 </b>For the mountains will I take up a weeping and wailing, and for the habitations of the wilderness a lamentation, because they are burned up, so that none can pass through <i>them;</i> neither can <i>men</i> hear the voice of the cattle; both the fowl of the heavens and the beast are fled; they are gone.

<b>11 </b>And I will make Jerusalem heaps, <i>and</i> a den of dragons; and I will make the cities of Judah desolate, without an inhabitant.

<b>12 </b>¶ Who <i>is</i> the wise man, that may understand this? and <i>who is he</i> to whom the mouth of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath spoken, that he may declare it, for what the land perisheth <i>and</i> is burned up like a wilderness, that none passeth through?

<b>13 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> saith, Because they have forsaken my law which I set before them, and have not obeyed my voice, neither walked therein;

<b>14 </b>But have walked after the imagination of their own heart, and after Baalim, which their fathers taught them:

<b>15 </b>Therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of Israel; Behold, I will feed them, <i>even</i> this people, with wormwood, and give them water of gall to drink.

<b>16 </b>I will scatter them also among the heathen, whom neither they nor their fathers have known: and I will send a sword after them, till I have consumed them.

<b>17 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, Consider ye, and call for the mourning women, that they may come; and send for cunning <i>women,</i> that they may come:

<b>18 </b>And let them make haste, and take up a wailing for us, that our eyes may run down with tears, and our eyelids gush out with waters.

<b>19 </b>For a voice of wailing is heard out of Zion, How are we spoiled! we are greatly confounded, because we have forsaken the land, because our dwellings have cast <i>us</i> out.

<b>20 </b>Yet hear the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, O ye women, and let your ear receive the word of his mouth, and teach your daughters wailing, and every one her neighbour lamentation.

<b>21 </b>For death is come up into our windows, <i>and</i> is entered into our palaces, to cut off the children from without, <i>and</i> the young men from the streets.

<b>22 </b>Speak, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Even the carcases of men shall fall as dung upon the open field, and as the handful after the harvestman, and none shall gather <i>them.</i>

<b>23 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Let not the wise <i>man</i> glory in his wisdom, neither let the mighty <i>man</i> glory in his might, let not the rich <i>man</i> glory in his riches:

<b>24 </b>But let him that glorieth glory in this, that he understandeth and knoweth me, that I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> which exercise lovingkindness, judgment, and righteousness, in the earth: for in these <i>things</i> I delight, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>25 </b>¶ Behold, the days come, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that I will punish all <i>them which are</i> circumcised with the uncircumcised;

<b>26 </b>Egypt, and Judah, and Edom, and the children of Ammon, and Moab, and all <i>that are</i> in the utmost corners, that dwell in the wilderness: for all <i>these</i> nations <i>are</i> uncircumcised, and all the house of Israel <i>are</i> uncircumcised in the heart.


--------------------

CHAPTER 10

<b>1 </b>Hear ye the word which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> speaketh unto you, O house of Israel:

<b>2 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Learn not the way of the heathen, and be not dismayed at the signs of heaven; for the heathen are dismayed at them.

<b>3 </b>For the customs of the people <i>are</i> vain: for <i>one</i> cutteth a tree out of the forest, the work of the hands of the workman, with the axe.

<b>4 </b>They deck it with silver and with gold; they fasten it with nails and with hammers, that it move not.

<b>5 </b>They <i>are</i> upright as the palm tree, but speak not: they must needs be borne, because they cannot go. Be not afraid of them; for they cannot do evil, neither also <i>is it</i> in them to do good.

<b>6 </b>Forasmuch as <i>there is</i> none like unto thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; thou <i>art</i> great, and thy name <i>is</i> great in might.

<b>7 </b>Who would not fear thee, O King of nations? for to thee doth it appertain: forasmuch as among all the wise <i>men</i> of the nations, and in all their kingdoms, <i>there is</i> none like unto thee.

<b>8 </b>But they are altogether brutish and foolish: the stock <i>is</i> a doctrine of vanities.

<b>9 </b>Silver spread into plates is brought from Tarshish, and gold from Uphaz, the work of the workman, and of the hands of the founder: blue and purple <i>is</i> their clothing: they <i>are</i> all the work of cunning <i>men.</i>

<b>10 </b>But the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> the true God, he <i>is</i> the living God, and an everlasting king: at his wrath the earth shall tremble, and the nations shall not be able to abide his indignation.

<b>11 </b>Thus shall ye say unto them, The gods that have not made the heavens and the earth, <i>even</i> they shall perish from the earth, and from under these heavens.

<b>12 </b>He hath made the earth by his power, he hath established the world by his wisdom, and hath stretched out the heavens by his discretion.

<b>13 </b>When he uttereth his voice, <i>there is</i> a multitude of waters in the heavens, and he causeth the vapours to ascend from the ends of the earth; he maketh lightnings with rain, and bringeth forth the wind out of his treasures.

<b>14 </b>Every man is brutish in <i>his</i> knowledge: every founder is confounded by the graven image: for his molten image <i>is</i> falsehood, and <i>there is</i> no breath in them.

<b>15 </b>They <i>are</i> vanity, <i>and</i> the work of errors: in the time of their visitation they shall perish.

<b>16 </b>The portion of Jacob <i>is</i> not like them: for he <i>is</i> the former of all <i>things;</i> and Israel <i>is</i> the rod of his inheritance: The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts <i>is</i> his name.

<b>17 </b>¶ Gather up thy wares out of the land, O inhabitant of the fortress.

<b>18 </b>For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Behold, I will sling out the inhabitants of the land at this once, and will distress them, that they may find <i>it so.</i>

<b>19 </b>¶ Woe is me for my hurt! my wound is grievous: but I said, Truly this <i>is</i> a grief, and I must bear it.

<b>20 </b>My tabernacle is spoiled, and all my cords are broken: my children are gone forth of me, and they <i>are</i> not: <i>there is</i> none to stretch forth my tent any more, and to set up my curtains.

<b>21 </b>For the pastors are become brutish, and have not sought the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: therefore they shall not prosper, and all their flocks shall be scattered.

<b>22 </b>Behold, the noise of the bruit is come, and a great commotion out of the north country, to make the cities of Judah desolate, <i>and</i> a den of dragons.

<b>23 </b>¶ O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, I know that the way of man <i>is</i> not in himself: <i>it is</i> not in man that walketh to direct his steps.

<b>24 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, correct me, but with judgment; not in thine anger, lest thou bring me to nothing.

<b>25 </b>Pour out thy fury upon the heathen that know thee not, and upon the families that call not on thy name: for they have eaten up Jacob, and devoured him, and consumed him, and have made his habitation desolate.


--------------------

CHAPTER 11

<b>1 </b>The word that came to Jeremiah from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying,

<b>2 </b>Hear ye the words of this covenant, and speak unto the men of Judah, and to the inhabitants of Jerusalem;

<b>3 </b>And say thou unto them, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel; Cursed <i>be</i> the man that obeyeth not the words of this covenant,

<b>4 </b>Which I commanded your fathers in the day <i>that</i> I brought them forth out of the land of Egypt, from the iron furnace, saying, Obey my voice, and do them, according to all which I command you: so shall ye be my people, and I will be your God:

<b>5 </b>That I may perform the oath which I have sworn unto your fathers, to give them a land flowing with milk and honey, as <i>it is</i> this day. Then answered I, and said, So be it, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>6 </b>Then the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, Proclaim all these words in the cities of Judah, and in the streets of Jerusalem, saying, Hear ye the words of this covenant, and do them.

<b>7 </b>For I earnestly protested unto your fathers in the day <i>that</i> I brought them up out of the land of Egypt, <i>even</i> unto this day, rising early and protesting, saying, Obey my voice.

<b>8 </b>Yet they obeyed not, nor inclined their ear, but walked every one in the imagination of their evil heart: therefore I will bring upon them all the words of this covenant, which I commanded <i>them</i> to do; but they did <i>them</i> not.

<b>9 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, A conspiracy is found among the men of Judah, and among the inhabitants of Jerusalem.

<b>10 </b>They are turned back to the iniquities of their forefathers, which refused to hear my words; and they went after other gods to serve them: the house of Israel and the house of Judah have broken my covenant which I made with their fathers.

<b>11 </b>¶ Therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Behold, I will bring evil upon them, which they shall not be able to escape; and though they shall cry unto me, I will not hearken unto them.

<b>12 </b>Then shall the cities of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem go, and cry unto the gods unto whom they offer incense: but they shall not save them at all in the time of their trouble.

<b>13 </b>For <i>according to</i> the number of thy cities were thy gods, O Judah; and <i>according to</i> the number of the streets of Jerusalem have ye set up altars to <i>that</i> shameful thing, <i>even</i> altars to burn incense unto Baal.

<b>14 </b>Therefore pray not thou for this people, neither lift up a cry or prayer for them: for I will not hear <i>them</i> in the time that they cry unto me for their trouble.

<b>15 </b>What hath my beloved to do in mine house, <i>seeing</i> she hath wrought lewdness with many, and the holy flesh is passed from thee? when thou doest evil, then thou rejoicest.

<b>16 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> called thy name, A green olive tree, fair, <i>and</i> of goodly fruit: with the noise of a great tumult he hath kindled fire upon it, and the branches of it are broken.

<b>17 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, that planted thee, hath pronounced evil against thee, for the evil of the house of Israel and of the house of Judah, which they have done against themselves to provoke me to anger in offering incense unto Baal.

<b>18 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath given me knowledge <i>of it,</i> and I know <i>it:</i> then thou shewedst me their doings.

<b>19 </b>But I <i>was</i> like a lamb <i>or</i> an ox <i>that</i> is brought to the slaughter; and I knew not that they had devised devices against me, <i>saying,</i> Let us destroy the tree with the fruit thereof, and let us cut him off from the land of the living, that his name may be no more remembered.

<b>20 </b>But, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, that judgest righteously, that triest the reins and the heart, let me see thy vengeance on them: for unto thee have I revealed my cause.

<b>21 </b>Therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of the men of Anathoth, that seek thy life, saying, Prophesy not in the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that thou die not by our hand:

<b>22 </b>Therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, Behold, I will punish them: the young men shall die by the sword; their sons and their daughters shall die by famine:

<b>23 </b>And there shall be no remnant of them: for I will bring evil upon the men of Anathoth, <i>even</i> the year of their visitation.


--------------------

CHAPTER 12

<b>1 </b>Righteous <i>art</i> thou, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, when I plead with thee: yet let me talk with thee of <i>thy</i> judgments: Wherefore doth the way of the wicked prosper? <i>wherefore</i> are all they happy that deal very treacherously?

<b>2 </b>Thou hast planted them, yea, they have taken root: they grow, yea, they bring forth fruit: thou <i>art</i> near in their mouth, and far from their reins.

<b>3 </b>But thou, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, knowest me: thou hast seen me, and tried mine heart toward thee: pull them out like sheep for the slaughter, and prepare them for the day of slaughter.

<b>4 </b>How long shall the land mourn, and the herbs of every field wither, for the wickedness of them that dwell therein? the beasts are consumed, and the birds; because they said, He shall not see our last end.
