<b>17 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; Behold, I will send upon them the sword, the famine, and the pestilence, and will make them like vile figs, that cannot be eaten, they are so evil.

<b>18 </b>And I will persecute them with the sword, with the famine, and with the pestilence, and will deliver them to be removed to all the kingdoms of the earth, to be a curse, and an astonishment, and an hissing, and a reproach, among all the nations whither I have driven them:

<b>19 </b>Because they have not hearkened to my words, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which I sent unto them by my servants the prophets, rising up early and sending <i>them;</i> but ye would not hear, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>20 </b>¶ Hear ye therefore the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, all ye of the captivity, whom I have sent from Jerusalem to Babylon:

<b>21 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of Israel, of Ahab the son of Kolaiah, and of Zedekiah the son of Maaseiah, which prophesy a lie unto you in my name; Behold, I will deliver them into the hand of Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon; and he shall slay them before your eyes;

<b>22 </b>And of them shall be taken up a curse by all the captivity of Judah which <i>are</i> in Babylon, saying, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> make thee like Zedekiah and like Ahab, whom the king of Babylon roasted in the fire;

<b>23 </b>Because they have committed villany in Israel, and have committed adultery with their neighbours’ wives, and have spoken lying words in my name, which I have not commanded them; even I know, and <i>am</i> a witness, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>24 </b>¶ <i>Thus</i> shalt thou also speak to Shemaiah the Nehelamite, saying,

<b>25 </b>Thus speaketh the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of Israel, saying, Because thou hast sent letters in thy name unto all the people that <i>are</i> at Jerusalem, and to Zephaniah the son of Maaseiah the priest, and to all the priests, saying,

<b>26 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath made thee priest in the stead of Jehoiada the priest, that ye should be officers in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, for every man <i>that is</i> mad, and maketh himself a prophet, that thou shouldest put him in prison, and in the stocks.

<b>27 </b>Now therefore why hast thou not reproved Jeremiah of Anathoth, which maketh himself a prophet to you?

<b>28 </b>For therefore he sent unto us <i>in</i> Babylon, saying, This <i>captivity is</i> long: build ye houses, and dwell <i>in them;</i> and plant gardens, and eat the fruit of them.

<b>29 </b>And Zephaniah the priest read this letter in the ears of Jeremiah the prophet.

<b>30 </b>¶ Then came the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto Jeremiah, saying,

<b>31 </b>Send to all them of the captivity, saying, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> concerning Shemaiah the Nehelamite; Because that Shemaiah hath prophesied unto you, and I sent him not, and he caused you to trust in a lie:

<b>32 </b>Therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; Behold, I will punish Shemaiah the Nehelamite, and his seed: he shall not have a man to dwell among this people; neither shall he behold the good that I will do for my people, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; because he hath taught rebellion against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

CHAPTER 30

<b>1 </b>The word that came to Jeremiah from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying,

<b>2 </b>Thus speaketh the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of Israel, saying, Write thee all the words that I have spoken unto thee in a book.

<b>3 </b>For, lo, the days come, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that I will bring again the captivity of my people Israel and Judah, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and I will cause them to return to the land that I gave to their fathers, and they shall possess it.

<b>4 </b>¶ And these <i>are</i> the words that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake concerning Israel and concerning Judah.

<b>5 </b>For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; We have heard a voice of trembling, of fear, and not of peace.

<b>6 </b>Ask ye now, and see whether a man doth travail with child? wherefore do I see every man with his hands on his loins, as a woman in travail, and all faces are turned into paleness?

<b>7 </b>Alas! for that day <i>is</i> great, so that none <i>is</i> like it: it <i>is</i> even the time of Jacob’s trouble; but he shall be saved out of it.

<b>8 </b>For it shall come to pass in that day, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, <i>that</i> I will break his yoke from off thy neck, and will burst thy bonds, and strangers shall no more serve themselves of him:

<b>9 </b>But they shall serve the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> their God, and David their king, whom I will raise up unto them.

<b>10 </b>¶ Therefore fear thou not, O my servant Jacob, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; neither be dismayed, O Israel: for, lo, I will save thee from afar, and thy seed from the land of their captivity; and Jacob shall return, and shall be in rest, and be quiet, and none shall make <i>him</i> afraid.

<b>11 </b>For I <i>am</i> with thee, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to save thee: though I make a full end of all nations whither I have scattered thee, yet will I not make a full end of thee: but I will correct thee in measure, and will not leave thee altogether unpunished.

<b>12 </b>For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Thy bruise <i>is</i> incurable, <i>and</i> thy wound <i>is</i> grievous.

<b>13 </b><i>There is</i> none to plead thy cause, that thou mayest be bound up: thou hast no healing medicines.

<b>14 </b>All thy lovers have forgotten thee; they seek thee not; for I have wounded thee with the wound of an enemy, with the chastisement of a cruel one, for the multitude of thine iniquity; <i>because</i> thy sins were increased.

<b>15 </b>Why criest thou for thine affliction? thy sorrow <i>is</i> incurable for the multitude of thine iniquity: <i>because</i> thy sins were increased, I have done these things unto thee.

<b>16 </b>Therefore all they that devour thee shall be devoured; and all thine adversaries, every one of them, shall go into captivity; and they that spoil thee shall be a spoil, and all that prey upon thee will I give for a prey.

<b>17 </b>For I will restore health unto thee, and I will heal thee of thy wounds, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; because they called thee an Outcast, <i>saying,</i> This <i>is</i> Zion, whom no man seeketh after.

<b>18 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; Behold, I will bring again the captivity of Jacob’s tents, and have mercy on his dwellingplaces; and the city shall be builded upon her own heap, and the palace shall remain after the manner thereof.

<b>19 </b>And out of them shall proceed thanksgiving and the voice of them that make merry: and I will multiply them, and they shall not be few; I will also glorify them, and they shall not be small.

<b>20 </b>Their children also shall be as aforetime, and their congregation shall be established before me, and I will punish all that oppress them.

<b>21 </b>And their nobles shall be of themselves, and their governor shall proceed from the midst of them; and I will cause him to draw near, and he shall approach unto me: for who <i>is</i> this that engaged his heart to approach unto me? saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>22 </b>And ye shall be my people, and I will be your God.

<b>23 </b>Behold, the whirlwind of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> goeth forth with fury, a continuing whirlwind: it shall fall with pain upon the head of the wicked.

<b>24 </b>The fierce anger of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall not return, until he have done <i>it,</i> and until he have performed the intents of his heart: in the latter days ye shall consider it.


--------------------

CHAPTER 31

<b>1 </b>At the same time, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, will I be the God of all the families of Israel, and they shall be my people.

<b>2 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, The people <i>which were</i> left of the sword found grace in the wilderness; <i>even</i> Israel, when I went to cause him to rest.

<b>3 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath appeared of old unto me, <i>saying,</i> Yea, I have loved thee with an everlasting love: therefore with lovingkindness have I drawn thee.

<b>4 </b>Again I will build thee, and thou shalt be built, O virgin of Israel: thou shalt again be adorned with thy tabrets, and shalt go forth in the dances of them that make merry.

<b>5 </b>Thou shalt yet plant vines upon the mountains of Samaria: the planters shall plant, and shall eat <i>them</i> as common things.

<b>6 </b>For there shall be a day, <i>that</i> the watchmen upon the mount Ephraim shall cry, Arise ye, and let us go up to Zion unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God.

<b>7 </b>For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; Sing with gladness for Jacob, and shout among the chief of the nations: publish ye, praise ye, and say, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, save thy people, the remnant of Israel.

<b>8 </b>Behold, I will bring them from the north country, and gather them from the coasts of the earth, <i>and</i> with them the blind and the lame, the woman with child and her that travaileth with child together: a great company shall return thither.

<b>9 </b>They shall come with weeping, and with supplications will I lead them: I will cause them to walk by the rivers of waters in a straight way, wherein they shall not stumble: for I am a father to Israel, and Ephraim <i>is</i> my firstborn.

<b>10 </b>¶ Hear the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, O ye nations, and declare <i>it</i> in the isles afar off, and say, He that scattered Israel will gather him, and keep him, as a shepherd <i>doth</i> his flock.

<b>11 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath redeemed Jacob, and ransomed him from the hand of <i>him that was</i> stronger than he.

<b>12 </b>Therefore they shall come and sing in the height of Zion, and shall flow together to the goodness of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, for wheat, and for wine, and for oil, and for the young of the flock and of the herd: and their soul shall be as a watered garden; and they shall not sorrow any more at all.

<b>13 </b>Then shall the virgin rejoice in the dance, both young men and old together: for I will turn their mourning into joy, and will comfort them, and make them rejoice from their sorrow.

<b>14 </b>And I will satiate the soul of the priests with fatness, and my people shall be satisfied with my goodness, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>15 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; A voice was heard in Ramah, lamentation, <i>and</i> bitter weeping; Rahel weeping for her children refused to be comforted for her children, because they <i>were</i> not.

<b>16 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; Refrain thy voice from weeping, and thine eyes from tears: for thy work shall be rewarded, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and they shall come again from the land of the enemy.

<b>17 </b>And there is hope in thine end, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that thy children shall come again to their own border.

<b>18 </b>¶ I have surely heard Ephraim bemoaning himself <i>thus;</i> Thou hast chastised me, and I was chastised, as a bullock unaccustomed <i>to the yoke:</i> turn thou me, and I shall be turned; for thou <i>art</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God.

<b>19 </b>Surely after that I was turned, I repented; and after that I was instructed, I smote upon <i>my</i> thigh: I was ashamed, yea, even confounded, because I did bear the reproach of my youth.

<b>20 </b><i>Is</i> Ephraim my dear son? <i>is he</i> a pleasant child? for since I spake against him, I do earnestly remember him still: therefore my bowels are troubled for him; I will surely have mercy upon him, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>21 </b>Set thee up waymarks, make thee high heaps: set thine heart toward the highway, <i>even</i> the way <i>which</i> thou wentest: turn again, O virgin of Israel, turn again to these thy cities.

<b>22 </b>¶ How long wilt thou go about, O thou backsliding daughter? for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath created a new thing in the earth, A woman shall compass a man.

<b>23 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of Israel; As yet they shall use this speech in the land of Judah and in the cities thereof, when I shall bring again their captivity; The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> bless thee, O habitation of justice, <i>and</i> mountain of holiness.

<b>24 </b>And there shall dwell in Judah itself, and in all the cities thereof together, husbandmen, and they <i>that</i> go forth with flocks.

<b>25 </b>For I have satiated the weary soul, and I have replenished every sorrowful soul.

<b>26 </b>Upon this I awaked, and beheld; and my sleep was sweet unto me.

<b>27 </b>¶ Behold, the days come, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that I will sow the house of Israel and the house of Judah with the seed of man, and with the seed of beast.

<b>28 </b>And it shall come to pass, <i>that</i> like as I have watched over them, to pluck up, and to break down, and to throw down, and to destroy, and to afflict; so will I watch over them, to build, and to plant, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>29 </b>In those days they shall say no more, The fathers have eaten a sour grape, and the children’s teeth are set on edge.

<b>30 </b>But every one shall die for his own iniquity: every man that eateth the sour grape, his teeth shall be set on edge.

<b>31 </b>¶ Behold, the days come, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that I will make a new covenant with the house of Israel, and with the house of Judah:

<b>32 </b>Not according to the covenant that I made with their fathers in the day <i>that</i> I took them by the hand to bring them out of the land of Egypt; which my covenant they brake, although I was an husband unto them, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>:

<b>33 </b>But this <i>shall be</i> the covenant that I will make with the house of Israel; After those days, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, I will put my law in their inward parts, and write it in their hearts; and will be their God, and they shall be my people.

<b>34 </b>And they shall teach no more every man his neighbour, and every man his brother, saying, Know the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for they shall all know me, from the least of them unto the greatest of them, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for I will forgive their iniquity, and I will remember their sin no more.

<b>35 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which giveth the sun for a light by day, <i>and</i> the ordinances of the moon and of the stars for a light by night, which divideth the sea when the waves thereof roar; The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts <i>is</i> his name:

<b>36 </b>If those ordinances depart from before me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>then</i> the seed of Israel also shall cease from being a nation before me for ever.

<b>37 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; If heaven above can be measured, and the foundations of the earth searched out beneath, I will also cast off all the seed of Israel for all that they have done, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>38 </b>¶ Behold, the days come, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that the city shall be built to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> from the tower of Hananeel unto the gate of the corner.

<b>39 </b>And the measuring line shall yet go forth over against it upon the hill Gareb, and shall compass about to Goath.

<b>40 </b>And the whole valley of the dead bodies, and of the ashes, and all the fields unto the brook of Kidron, unto the corner of the horse gate toward the east, <i>shall be</i> holy unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; it shall not be plucked up, nor thrown down any more for ever.


--------------------

CHAPTER 32

<b>1 </b>The word that came to Jeremiah from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in the tenth year of Zedekiah king of Judah, which <i>was</i> the eighteenth year of Nebuchadrezzar.

<b>2 </b>For then the king of Babylon’s army besieged Jerusalem: and Jeremiah the prophet was shut up in the court of the prison, which <i>was</i> in the king of Judah’s house.

<b>3 </b>For Zedekiah king of Judah had shut him up, saying, Wherefore dost thou prophesy, and say, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Behold, I will give this city into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he shall take it;

<b>4 </b>And Zedekiah king of Judah shall not escape out of the hand of the Chaldeans, but shall surely be delivered into the hand of the king of Babylon, and shall speak with him mouth to mouth, and his eyes shall behold his eyes;

<b>5 </b>And he shall lead Zedekiah to Babylon, and there shall he be until I visit him, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: though ye fight with the Chaldeans, ye shall not prosper?

<b>6 </b>¶ And Jeremiah said, The word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto me, saying,

<b>7 </b>Behold, Hanameel the son of Shallum thine uncle shall come unto thee, saying, Buy thee my field that <i>is</i> in Anathoth: for the right of redemption <i>is</i> thine to buy <i>it.</i>

<b>8 </b>So Hanameel mine uncle’s son came to me in the court of the prison according to the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and said unto me, Buy my field, I pray thee, that <i>is</i> in Anathoth, which <i>is</i> in the country of Benjamin: for the right of inheritance <i>is</i> thine, and the redemption <i>is</i> thine; buy <i>it</i> for thyself. Then I knew that this <i>was</i> the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>9 </b>And I bought the field of Hanameel my uncle’s son, that <i>was</i> in Anathoth, and weighed him the money, <i>even</i> seventeen shekels of silver.

<b>10 </b>And I subscribed the evidence, and sealed <i>it,</i> and took witnesses, and weighed <i>him</i> the money in the balances.

<b>11 </b>So I took the evidence of the purchase, <i>both</i> that which was sealed <i>according</i> to the law and custom, and that which was open:

<b>12 </b>And I gave the evidence of the purchase unto Baruch the son of Neriah, the son of Maaseiah, in the sight of Hanameel mine uncle’s <i>son,</i> and in the presence of the witnesses that subscribed the book of the purchase, before all the Jews that sat in the court of the prison.

<b>13 </b>¶ And I charged Baruch before them, saying,

<b>14 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of Israel; Take these evidences, this evidence of the purchase, both which is sealed, and this evidence which is open; and put them in an earthen vessel, that they may continue many days.

<b>15 </b>For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of Israel; Houses and fields and vineyards shall be possessed again in this land.

<b>16 </b>¶ Now when I had delivered the evidence of the purchase unto Baruch the son of Neriah, I prayed unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying,

<b>17 </b>Ah Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>! behold, thou hast made the heaven and the earth by thy great power and stretched out arm, <i>and</i> there is nothing too hard for thee:

<b>18 </b>Thou shewest lovingkindness unto thousands, and recompensest the iniquity of the fathers into the bosom of their children after them: the Great, the Mighty God, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, <i>is</i> his name,

<b>19 </b>Great in counsel, and mighty in work: for thine eyes <i>are</i> open upon all the ways of the sons of men: to give every one according to his ways, and according to the fruit of his doings:

<b>20 </b>Which hast set signs and wonders in the land of Egypt, <i>even</i> unto this day, and in Israel, and among <i>other</i> men; and hast made thee a name, as at this day;

<b>21 </b>And hast brought forth thy people Israel out of the land of Egypt with signs, and with wonders, and with a strong hand, and with a stretched out arm, and with great terror;

<b>22 </b>And hast given them this land, which thou didst swear to their fathers to give them, a land flowing with milk and honey;

<b>23 </b>And they came in, and possessed it; but they obeyed not thy voice, neither walked in thy law; they have done nothing of all that thou commandedst them to do: therefore thou hast caused all this evil to come upon them:

<b>24 </b>Behold the mounts, they are come unto the city to take it; and the city is given into the hand of the Chaldeans, that fight against it, because of the sword, and of the famine, and of the pestilence: and what thou hast spoken is come to pass; and, behold, thou seest <i>it.</i>

<b>25 </b>And thou hast said unto me, O Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>, Buy thee the field for money, and take witnesses; for the city is given into the hand of the Chaldeans.

<b>26 </b>¶ Then came the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto Jeremiah, saying,

<b>27 </b>Behold, I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the God of all flesh: is there any thing too hard for me?

<b>28 </b>Therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; Behold, I will give this city into the hand of the Chaldeans, and into the hand of Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon, and he shall take it:

<b>29 </b>And the Chaldeans, that fight against this city, shall come and set fire on this city, and burn it with the houses, upon whose roofs they have offered incense unto Baal, and poured out drink offerings unto other gods, to provoke me to anger.

<b>30 </b>For the children of Israel and the children of Judah have only done evil before me from their youth: for the children of Israel have only provoked me to anger with the work of their hands, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>31 </b>For this city hath been to me <i>as</i> a provocation of mine anger and of my fury from the day that they built it even unto this day; that I should remove it from before my face,

<b>32 </b>Because of all the evil of the children of Israel and of the children of Judah, which they have done to provoke me to anger, they, their kings, their princes, their priests, and their prophets, and the men of Judah, and the inhabitants of Jerusalem.

<b>33 </b>And they have turned unto me the back, and not the face: though I taught them, rising up early and teaching <i>them,</i> yet they have not hearkened to receive instruction.

<b>34 </b>But they set their abominations in the house, which is called by my name, to defile it.

<b>35 </b>And they built the high places of Baal, which <i>are</i> in the valley of the son of Hinnom, to cause their sons and their daughters to pass through <i>the fire</i> unto Molech; which I commanded them not, neither came it into my mind, that they should do this abomination, to cause Judah to sin.

<b>36 </b>¶ And now therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the God of Israel, concerning this city, whereof ye say, It shall be delivered into the hand of the king of Babylon by the sword, and by the famine, and by the pestilence;

<b>37 </b>Behold, I will gather them out of all countries, whither I have driven them in mine anger, and in my fury, and in great wrath; and I will bring them again unto this place, and I will cause them to dwell safely:

<b>38 </b>And they shall be my people, and I will be their God:

<b>39 </b>And I will give them one heart, and one way, that they may fear me for ever, for the good of them, and of their children after them:

<b>40 </b>And I will make an everlasting covenant with them, that I will not turn away from them, to do them good; but I will put my fear in their hearts, that they shall not depart from me.

<b>41 </b>Yea, I will rejoice over them to do them good, and I will plant them in this land assuredly with my whole heart and with my whole soul.

<b>42 </b>For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; Like as I have brought all this great evil upon this people, so will I bring upon them all the good that I have promised them.

<b>43 </b>And fields shall be bought in this land, whereof ye say, <i>It is</i> desolate without man or beast; it is given into the hand of the Chaldeans.

<b>44 </b>Men shall buy fields for money, and subscribe evidences, and seal <i>them,</i> and take witnesses in the land of Benjamin, and in the places about Jerusalem, and in the cities of Judah, and in the cities of the mountains, and in the cities of the valley, and in the cities of the south: for I will cause their captivity to return, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

CHAPTER 33

<b>1 </b>Moreover the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto Jeremiah the second time, while he was yet shut up in the court of the prison, saying,

<b>2 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> the maker thereof, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that formed it, to establish it; the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> his name;

<b>3 </b>Call unto me, and I will answer thee, and shew thee great and mighty things, which thou knowest not.

<b>4 </b>For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the God of Israel, concerning the houses of this city, and concerning the houses of the kings of Judah, which are thrown down by the mounts, and by the sword;

<b>5 </b>They come to fight with the Chaldeans, but <i>it is</i> to fill them with the dead bodies of men, whom I have slain in mine anger and in my fury, and for all whose wickedness I have hid my face from this city.

<b>6 </b>Behold, I will bring it health and cure, and I will cure them, and will reveal unto them the abundance of peace and truth.

<b>7 </b>And I will cause the captivity of Judah and the captivity of Israel to return, and will build them, as at the first.

<b>8 </b>And I will cleanse them from all their iniquity, whereby they have sinned against me; and I will pardon all their iniquities, whereby they have sinned, and whereby they have transgressed against me.

<b>9 </b>¶ And it shall be to me a name of joy, a praise and an honour before all the nations of the earth, which shall hear all the good that I do unto them: and they shall fear and tremble for all the goodness and for all the prosperity that I procure unto it.

<b>10 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; Again there shall be heard in this place, which ye say <i>shall be</i> desolate without man and without beast, <i>even</i> in the cities of Judah, and in the streets of Jerusalem, that are desolate, without man, and without inhabitant, and without beast,

<b>11 </b>The voice of joy, and the voice of gladness, the voice of the bridegroom, and the voice of the bride, the voice of them that shall say, Praise the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> good; for his mercy <i>endureth</i> for ever: <i>and</i> of them that shall bring the sacrifice of praise into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. For I will cause to return the captivity of the land, as at the first, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>12 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; Again in this place, which is desolate without man and without beast, and in all the cities thereof, shall be an habitation of shepherds causing <i>their</i> flocks to lie down.

<b>13 </b>In the cities of the mountains, in the cities of the vale, and in the cities of the south, and in the land of Benjamin, and in the places about Jerusalem, and in the cities of Judah, shall the flocks pass again under the hands of him that telleth <i>them,</i> saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>14 </b>Behold, the days come, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that I will perform that good thing which I have promised unto the house of Israel and to the house of Judah.

<b>15 </b>¶ In those days, and at that time, will I cause the Branch of righteousness to grow up unto David; and he shall execute judgment and righteousness in the land.

<b>16 </b>In those days shall Judah be saved, and Jerusalem shall dwell safely: and this <i>is the name</i> wherewith she shall be called, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our righteousness.

<b>17 </b>¶ For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; David shall never want a man to sit upon the throne of the house of Israel;

<b>18 </b>Neither shall the priests the Levites want a man before me to offer burnt offerings, and to kindle meat offerings, and to do sacrifice continually.

<b>19 </b>¶ And the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto Jeremiah, saying,

<b>20 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; If ye can break my covenant of the day, and my covenant of the night, and that there should not be day and night in their season;

<b>21 </b><i>Then</i> may also my covenant be broken with David my servant, that he should not have a son to reign upon his throne; and with the Levites the priests, my ministers.

<b>22 </b>As the host of heaven cannot be numbered, neither the sand of the sea measured: so will I multiply the seed of David my servant, and the Levites that minister unto me.

<b>23 </b>Moreover the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came to Jeremiah, saying,

<b>24 </b>Considerest thou not what this people have spoken, saying, The two families which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath chosen, he hath even cast them off? thus they have despised my people, that they should be no more a nation before them.

<b>25 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; If my covenant <i>be</i> not with day and night, <i>and if</i> I have not appointed the ordinances of heaven and earth;

<b>26 </b>Then will I cast away the seed of Jacob, and David my servant, <i>so</i> that I will not take <i>any</i> of his seed <i>to be</i> rulers over the seed of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob: for I will cause their captivity to return, and have mercy on them.


--------------------

CHAPTER 34

<b>1 </b>The word which came unto Jeremiah from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, when Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, and all his army, and all the kingdoms of the earth of his dominion, and all the people, fought against Jerusalem, and against all the cities thereof, saying,

<b>2 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the God of Israel; Go and speak to Zedekiah king of Judah, and tell him, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; Behold, I will give this city into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he shall burn it with fire:

<b>3 </b>And thou shalt not escape out of his hand, but shalt surely be taken, and delivered into his hand; and thine eyes shall behold the eyes of the king of Babylon, and he shall speak with thee mouth to mouth, and thou shalt go to Babylon.

<b>4 </b>Yet hear the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, O Zedekiah king of Judah; Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of thee, Thou shalt not die by the sword:

<b>5 </b><i>But</i> thou shalt die in peace: and with the burnings of thy fathers, the former kings which were before thee, so shall they burn <i>odours</i> for thee; and they will lament thee, <i>saying,</i> Ah lord! for I have pronounced the word, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>6 </b>Then Jeremiah the prophet spake all these words unto Zedekiah king of Judah in Jerusalem,

<b>7 </b>When the king of Babylon’s army fought against Jerusalem, and against all the cities of Judah that were left, against Lachish, and against Azekah: for these defenced cities remained of the cities of Judah.

<b>8 </b>¶ <i>This is</i> the word that came unto Jeremiah from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, after that the king Zedekiah had made a covenant with all the people which <i>were</i> at Jerusalem, to proclaim liberty unto them;

<b>9 </b>That every man should let his manservant, and every man his maidservant, <i>being</i> an Hebrew or an Hebrewess, go free; that none should serve himself of them, <i>to wit,</i> of a Jew his brother.

<b>10 </b>Now when all the princes, and all the people, which had entered into the covenant, heard that every one should let his manservant, and every one his maidservant, go free, that none should serve themselves of them any more, then they obeyed, and let <i>them</i> go.

<b>11 </b>But afterward they turned, and caused the servants and the handmaids, whom they had let go free, to return, and brought them into subjection for servants and for handmaids.

<b>12 </b>¶ Therefore the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came to Jeremiah from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying,

<b>13 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the God of Israel; I made a covenant with your fathers in the day that I brought them forth out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of bondmen, saying,

<b>14 </b>At the end of seven years let ye go every man his brother an Hebrew, which hath been sold unto thee; and when he hath served thee six years, thou shalt let him go free from thee: but your fathers hearkened not unto me, neither inclined their ear.

<b>15 </b>And ye were now turned, and had done right in my sight, in proclaiming liberty every man to his neighbour; and ye had made a covenant before me in the house which is called by my name:

<b>16 </b>But ye turned and polluted my name, and caused every man his servant, and every man his handmaid, whom ye had set at liberty at their pleasure, to return, and brought them into subjection, to be unto you for servants and for handmaids.

<b>17 </b>Therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; Ye have not hearkened unto me, in proclaiming liberty, every one to his brother, and every man to his neighbour: behold, I proclaim a liberty for you, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to the sword, to the pestilence, and to the famine; and I will make you to be removed into all the kingdoms of the earth.

<b>18 </b>And I will give the men that have transgressed my covenant, which have not performed the words of the covenant which they had made before me, when they cut the calf in twain, and passed between the parts thereof,

<b>19 </b>The princes of Judah, and the princes of Jerusalem, the eunuchs, and the priests, and all the people of the land, which passed between the parts of the calf;

<b>20 </b>I will even give them into the hand of their enemies, and into the hand of them that seek their life: and their dead bodies shall be for meat unto the fowls of the heaven, and to the beasts of the earth.

<b>21 </b>And Zedekiah king of Judah and his princes will I give into the hand of their enemies, and into the hand of them that seek their life, and into the hand of the king of Babylon’s army, which are gone up from you.

<b>22 </b>Behold, I will command, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and cause them to return to this city; and they shall fight against it, and take it, and burn it with fire: and I will make the cities of Judah a desolation without an inhabitant.


--------------------

CHAPTER 35

<b>1 </b>The word which came unto Jeremiah from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in the days of Jehoiakim the son of Josiah king of Judah, saying,

<b>2 </b>Go unto the house of the Rechabites, and speak unto them, and bring them into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, into one of the chambers, and give them wine to drink.

<b>3 </b>Then I took Jaazaniah the son of Jeremiah, the son of Habaziniah, and his brethren, and all his sons, and the whole house of the Rechabites;

<b>4 </b>And I brought them into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, into the chamber of the sons of Hanan, the son of Igdaliah, a man of God, which <i>was</i> by the chamber of the princes, which <i>was</i> above the chamber of Maaseiah the son of Shallum, the keeper of the door:

<b>5 </b>And I set before the sons of the house of the Rechabites pots full of wine, and cups, and I said unto them, Drink ye wine.

<b>6 </b>But they said, We will drink no wine: for Jonadab the son of Rechab our father commanded us, saying, Ye shall drink no wine, <i>neither</i> ye, nor your sons for ever:

<b>7 </b>Neither shall ye build house, nor sow seed, nor plant vineyard, nor have <i>any:</i> but all your days ye shall dwell in tents; that ye may live many days in the land where ye <i>be</i> strangers.

<b>8 </b>Thus have we obeyed the voice of Jonadab the son of Rechab our father in all that he hath charged us, to drink no wine all our days, we, our wives, our sons, nor our daughters;

<b>9 </b>Nor to build houses for us to dwell in: neither have we vineyard, nor field, nor seed:

<b>10 </b>But we have dwelt in tents, and have obeyed, and done according to all that Jonadab our father commanded us.

<b>11 </b>But it came to pass, when Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon came up into the land, that we said, Come, and let us go to Jerusalem for fear of the army of the Chaldeans, and for fear of the army of the Syrians: so we dwell at Jerusalem.

<b>12 </b>¶ Then came the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto Jeremiah, saying,

<b>13 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of Israel; Go and tell the men of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem, Will ye not receive instruction to hearken to my words? saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>14 </b>The words of Jonadab the son of Rechab, that he commanded his sons not to drink wine, are performed; for unto this day they drink none, but obey their father’s commandment: notwithstanding I have spoken unto you, rising early and speaking; but ye hearkened not unto me.

<b>15 </b>I have sent also unto you all my servants the prophets, rising up early and sending <i>them,</i> saying, Return ye now every man from his evil way, and amend your doings, and go not after other gods to serve them, and ye shall dwell in the land which I have given to you and to your fathers: but ye have not inclined your ear, nor hearkened unto me.

<b>16 </b>Because the sons of Jonadab the son of Rechab have performed the commandment of their father, which he commanded them; but this people hath not hearkened unto me:

<b>17 </b>Therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of hosts, the God of Israel; Behold, I will bring upon Judah and upon all the inhabitants of Jerusalem all the evil that I have pronounced against them: because I have spoken unto them, but they have not heard; and I have called unto them, but they have not answered.

<b>18 </b>¶ And Jeremiah said unto the house of the Rechabites, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of Israel; Because ye have obeyed the commandment of Jonadab your father, and kept all his precepts, and done according unto all that he hath commanded you:

<b>19 </b>Therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of Israel; Jonadab the son of Rechab shall not want a man to stand before me for ever.


--------------------

CHAPTER 36

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass in the fourth year of Jehoiakim the son of Josiah king of Judah, <i>that</i> this word came unto Jeremiah from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, saying,

<b>2 </b>Take thee a roll of a book, and write therein all the words that I have spoken unto thee against Israel, and against Judah, and against all the nations, from the day I spake unto thee, from the days of Josiah, even unto this day.

<b>3 </b>It may be that the house of Judah will hear all the evil which I purpose to do unto them; that they may return every man from his evil way; that I may forgive their iniquity and their sin.

<b>4 </b>Then Jeremiah called Baruch the son of Neriah: and Baruch wrote from the mouth of Jeremiah all the words of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which he had spoken unto him, upon a roll of a book.

<b>5 </b>And Jeremiah commanded Baruch, saying, I <i>am</i> shut up; I cannot go into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>:

<b>6 </b>Therefore go thou, and read in the roll, which thou hast written from my mouth, the words of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in the ears of the people in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s house upon the fasting day: and also thou shalt read them in the ears of all Judah that come out of their cities.

<b>7 </b>It may be they will present their supplication before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and will return every one from his evil way: for great <i>is</i> the anger and the fury that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath pronounced against this people.

<b>8 </b>And Baruch the son of Neriah did according to all that Jeremiah the prophet commanded him, reading in the book the words of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s house.

<b>9 </b>And it came to pass in the fifth year of Jehoiakim the son of Josiah king of Judah, in the ninth month, <i>that</i> they proclaimed a fast before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> to all the people in Jerusalem, and to all the people that came from the cities of Judah unto Jerusalem.

<b>10 </b>Then read Baruch in the book the words of Jeremiah in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, in the chamber of Gemariah the son of Shaphan the scribe, in the higher court, at the entry of the new gate of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s house, in the ears of all the people.

<b>11 </b>¶ When Michaiah the son of Gemariah, the son of Shaphan, had heard out of the book all the words of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>,

<b>12 </b>Then he went down into the king’s house, into the scribe’s chamber: and, lo, all the princes sat there, <i>even</i> Elishama the scribe, and Delaiah the son of Shemaiah, and Elnathan the son of Achbor, and Gemariah the son of Shaphan, and Zedekiah the son of Hananiah, and all the princes.

<b>13 </b>Then Michaiah declared unto them all the words that he had heard, when Baruch read the book in the ears of the people.

<b>14 </b>Therefore all the princes sent Jehudi the son of Nethaniah, the son of Shelemiah, the son of Cushi, unto Baruch, saying, Take in thine hand the roll wherein thou hast read in the ears of the people, and come. So Baruch the son of Neriah took the roll in his hand, and came unto them.

<b>15 </b>And they said unto him, Sit down now, and read it in our ears. So Baruch read <i>it</i> in their ears.

<b>16 </b>Now it came to pass, when they had heard all the words, they were afraid both one and other, and said unto Baruch, We will surely tell the king of all these words.

<b>17 </b>And they asked Baruch, saying, Tell us now, How didst thou write all these words at his mouth?

<b>18 </b>Then Baruch answered them, He pronounced all these words unto me with his mouth, and I wrote <i>them</i> with ink in the book.

<b>19 </b>Then said the princes unto Baruch, Go, hide thee, thou and Jeremiah; and let no man know where ye be.

<b>20 </b>¶ And they went in to the king into the court, but they laid up the roll in the chamber of Elishama the scribe, and told all the words in the ears of the king.

<b>21 </b>So the king sent Jehudi to fetch the roll: and he took it out of Elishama the scribe’s chamber. And Jehudi read it in the ears of the king, and in the ears of all the princes which stood beside the king.

<b>22 </b>Now the king sat in the winterhouse in the ninth month: and <i>there was a fire</i> on the hearth burning before him.

<b>23 </b>And it came to pass, <i>that</i> when Jehudi had read three or four leaves, he cut it with the penknife, and cast <i>it</i> into the fire that <i>was</i> on the hearth, until all the roll was consumed in the fire that <i>was</i> on the hearth.

<b>24 </b>Yet they were not afraid, nor rent their garments, <i>neither</i> the king, nor any of his servants that heard all these words.

<b>25 </b>Nevertheless Elnathan and Delaiah and Gemariah had made intercession to the king that he would not burn the roll: but he would not hear them.

<b>26 </b>But the king commanded Jerahmeel the son of Hammelech, and Seraiah the son of Azriel, and Shelemiah the son of Abdeel, to take Baruch the scribe and Jeremiah the prophet: but the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hid them.

<b>27 </b>¶ Then the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came to Jeremiah, after that the king had burned the roll, and the words which Baruch wrote at the mouth of Jeremiah, saying,

<b>28 </b>Take thee again another roll, and write in it all the former words that were in the first roll, which Jehoiakim the king of Judah hath burned.

<b>29 </b>And thou shalt say to Jehoiakim king of Judah, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; Thou hast burned this roll, saying, Why hast thou written therein, saying, The king of Babylon shall certainly come and destroy this land, and shall cause to cease from thence man and beast?

<b>30 </b>Therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of Jehoiakim king of Judah; He shall have none to sit upon the throne of David: and his dead body shall be cast out in the day to the heat, and in the night to the frost.

<b>31 </b>And I will punish him and his seed and his servants for their iniquity; and I will bring upon them, and upon the inhabitants of Jerusalem, and upon the men of Judah, all the evil that I have pronounced against them; but they hearkened not.

<b>32 </b>¶ Then took Jeremiah another roll, and gave it to Baruch the scribe, the son of Neriah; who wrote therein from the mouth of Jeremiah all the words of the book which Jehoiakim king of Judah had burned in the fire: and there were added besides unto them many like words.


--------------------

CHAPTER 37

<b>1 </b>And king Zedekiah the son of Josiah reigned instead of Coniah the son of Jehoiakim, whom Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon made king in the land of Judah.

<b>2 </b>But neither he, nor his servants, nor the people of the land, did hearken unto the words of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which he spake by the prophet Jeremiah.

<b>3 </b>And Zedekiah the king sent Jehucal the son of Shelemiah and Zephaniah the son of Maaseiah the priest to the prophet Jeremiah, saying, Pray now unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God for us.

<b>4 </b>Now Jeremiah came in and went out among the people: for they had not put him into prison.

<b>5 </b>Then Pharaoh’s army was come forth out of Egypt: and when the Chaldeans that besieged Jerusalem heard tidings of them, they departed from Jerusalem.

<b>6 </b>¶ Then came the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto the prophet Jeremiah, saying,

<b>7 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the God of Israel; Thus shall ye say to the king of Judah, that sent you unto me to inquire of me; Behold, Pharaoh’s army, which is come forth to help you, shall return to Egypt into their own land.

<b>8 </b>And the Chaldeans shall come again, and fight against this city, and take it, and burn it with fire.

<b>9 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; Deceive not yourselves, saying, The Chaldeans shall surely depart from us: for they shall not depart.

<b>10 </b>For though ye had smitten the whole army of the Chaldeans that fight against you, and there remained <i>but</i> wounded men among them, <i>yet</i> should they rise up every man in his tent, and burn this city with fire.

<b>11 </b>¶ And it came to pass, that when the army of the Chaldeans was broken up from Jerusalem for fear of Pharaoh’s army,

<b>12 </b>Then Jeremiah went forth out of Jerusalem to go into the land of Benjamin, to separate himself thence in the midst of the people.

<b>13 </b>And when he was in the gate of Benjamin, a captain of the ward <i>was</i> there, whose name <i>was</i> Irijah, the son of Shelemiah, the son of Hananiah; and he took Jeremiah the prophet, saying, Thou fallest away to the Chaldeans.

<b>14 </b>Then said Jeremiah, <i>It is</i> false; I fall not away to the Chaldeans. But he hearkened not to him: so Irijah took Jeremiah, and brought him to the princes.

<b>15 </b>Wherefore the princes were wroth with Jeremiah, and smote him, and put him in prison in the house of Jonathan the scribe: for they had made that the prison.

<b>16 </b>¶ When Jeremiah was entered into the dungeon, and into the cabins, and Jeremiah had remained there many days;

<b>17 </b>Then Zedekiah the king sent, and took him out: and the king asked him secretly in his house, and said, Is there <i>any</i> word from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>? And Jeremiah said, There is: for, said he, thou shalt be delivered into the hand of the king of Babylon.

<b>18 </b>Moreover Jeremiah said unto king Zedekiah, What have I offended against thee, or against thy servants, or against this people, that ye have put me in prison?

<b>19 </b>Where <i>are</i> now your prophets which prophesied unto you, saying, The king of Babylon shall not come against you, nor against this land?

<b>20 </b>Therefore hear now, I pray thee, O my lord the king: let my supplication, I pray thee, be accepted before thee; that thou cause me not to return to the house of Jonathan the scribe, lest I die there.

<b>21 </b>Then Zedekiah the king commanded that they should commit Jeremiah into the court of the prison, and that they should give him daily a piece of bread out of the bakers’ street, until all the bread in the city were spent. Thus Jeremiah remained in the court of the prison.


--------------------

CHAPTER 38

<b>1 </b>Then Shephatiah the son of Mattan, and Gedaliah the son of Pashur, and Jucal the son of Shelemiah, and Pashur the son of Malchiah, heard the words that Jeremiah had spoken unto all the people, saying,

<b>2 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, He that remaineth in this city shall die by the sword, by the famine, and by the pestilence: but he that goeth forth to the Chaldeans shall live; for he shall have his life for a prey, and shall live.

<b>3 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, This city shall surely be given into the hand of the king of Babylon’s army, which shall take it.

<b>4 </b>Therefore the princes said unto the king, We beseech thee, let this man be put to death: for thus he weakeneth the hands of the men of war that remain in this city, and the hands of all the people, in speaking such words unto them: for this man seeketh not the welfare of this people, but the hurt.

<b>5 </b>Then Zedekiah the king said, Behold, he <i>is</i> in your hand: for the king <i>is</i> not <i>he that</i> can do <i>any</i> thing against you.

<b>6 </b>Then took they Jeremiah, and cast him into the dungeon of Malchiah the son of Hammelech, that <i>was</i> in the court of the prison: and they let down Jeremiah with cords. And in the dungeon <i>there was</i> no water, but mire: so Jeremiah sunk in the mire.

<b>7 </b>¶ Now when Ebed-melech the Ethiopian, one of the eunuchs which was in the king’s house, heard that they had put Jeremiah in the dungeon; the king then sitting in the gate of Benjamin;

<b>8 </b>Ebed-melech went forth out of the king’s house, and spake to the king, saying,

<b>9 </b>My lord the king, these men have done evil in all that they have done to Jeremiah the prophet, whom they have cast into the dungeon; and he is like to die for hunger in the place where he is: for <i>there is</i> no more bread in the city.

<b>10 </b>Then the king commanded Ebed-melech the Ethiopian, saying, Take from hence thirty men with thee, and take up Jeremiah the prophet out of the dungeon, before he die.

<b>11 </b>So Ebed-melech took the men with him, and went into the house of the king under the treasury, and took thence old cast clouts and old rotten rags, and let them down by cords into the dungeon to Jeremiah.

<b>12 </b>And Ebed-melech the Ethiopian said unto Jeremiah, Put now <i>these</i> old cast clouts and rotten rags under thine armholes under the cords. And Jeremiah did so.

<b>13 </b>So they drew up Jeremiah with cords, and took him up out of the dungeon: and Jeremiah remained in the court of the prison.

<b>14 </b>¶ Then Zedekiah the king sent, and took Jeremiah the prophet unto him into the third entry that <i>is</i> in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and the king said unto Jeremiah, I will ask thee a thing; hide nothing from me.

<b>15 </b>Then Jeremiah said unto Zedekiah, If I declare <i>it</i> unto thee, wilt thou not surely put me to death? and if I give thee counsel, wilt thou not hearken unto me?

<b>16 </b>So Zedekiah the king sware secretly unto Jeremiah, saying, <i>As</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> liveth, that made us this soul, I will not put thee to death, neither will I give thee into the hand of these men that seek thy life.

<b>17 </b>Then said Jeremiah unto Zedekiah, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the God of hosts, the God of Israel; If thou wilt assuredly go forth unto the king of Babylon’s princes, then thy soul shall live, and this city shall not be burned with fire; and thou shalt live, and thine house:

<b>18 </b>But if thou wilt not go forth to the king of Babylon’s princes, then shall this city be given into the hand of the Chaldeans, and they shall burn it with fire, and thou shalt not escape out of their hand.

<b>19 </b>And Zedekiah the king said unto Jeremiah, I am afraid of the Jews that are fallen to the Chaldeans, lest they deliver me into their hand, and they mock me.

<b>20 </b>But Jeremiah said, They shall not deliver <i>thee.</i> Obey, I beseech thee, the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which I speak unto thee: so it shall be well unto thee, and thy soul shall live.

<b>21 </b>But if thou refuse to go forth, this <i>is</i> the word that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath shewed me:

<b>22 </b>And, behold, all the women that are left in the king of Judah’s house <i>shall be</i> brought forth to the king of Babylon’s princes, and those <i>women</i> shall say, Thy friends have set thee on, and have prevailed against thee: thy feet are sunk in the mire, <i>and</i> they are turned away back.

<b>23 </b>So they shall bring out all thy wives and thy children to the Chaldeans: and thou shalt not escape out of their hand, but shalt be taken by the hand of the king of Babylon: and thou shalt cause this city to be burned with fire.

<b>24 </b>¶ Then said Zedekiah unto Jeremiah, Let no man know of these words, and thou shalt not die.

<b>25 </b>But if the princes hear that I have talked with thee, and they come unto thee, and say unto thee, Declare unto us now what thou hast said unto the king, hide it not from us, and we will not put thee to death; also what the king said unto thee:

<b>26 </b>Then thou shalt say unto them, I presented my supplication before the king, that he would not cause me to return to Jonathan’s house, to die there.

<b>27 </b>Then came all the princes unto Jeremiah, and asked him: and he told them according to all these words that the king had commanded. So they left off speaking with him; for the matter was not perceived.

<b>28 </b>So Jeremiah abode in the court of the prison until the day that Jerusalem was taken: and he was <i>there</i> when Jerusalem was taken.


--------------------

CHAPTER 39

<b>1 </b>In the ninth year of Zedekiah king of Judah, in the tenth month, came Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon and all his army against Jerusalem, and they besieged it.

<b>2 </b><i>And</i> in the eleventh year of Zedekiah, in the fourth month, the ninth <i>day</i> of the month, the city was broken up.

<b>3 </b>And all the princes of the king of Babylon came in, and sat in the middle gate, <i>even</i> Nergal-sharezer, Samgar-nebo, Sarsechim, Rab-saris, Nergal-sharezer, Rab-mag, with all the residue of the princes of the king of Babylon.

<b>4 </b>¶ And it came to pass, <i>that</i> when Zedekiah the king of Judah saw them, and all the men of war, then they fled, and went forth out of the city by night, by the way of the king’s garden, by the gate betwixt the two walls: and he went out the way of the plain.

<b>5 </b>But the Chaldeans’ army pursued after them, and overtook Zedekiah in the plains of Jericho: and when they had taken him, they brought him up to Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon to Riblah in the land of Hamath, where he gave judgment upon him.

<b>6 </b>Then the king of Babylon slew the sons of Zedekiah in Riblah before his eyes: also the king of Babylon slew all the nobles of Judah.

<b>7 </b>Moreover he put out Zedekiah’s eyes, and bound him with chains, to carry him to Babylon.

<b>8 </b>¶ And the Chaldeans burned the king’s house, and the houses of the people, with fire, and brake down the walls of Jerusalem.

<b>9 </b>Then Nebuzar-adan the captain of the guard carried away captive into Babylon the remnant of the people that remained in the city, and those that fell away, that fell to him, with the rest of the people that remained.

<b>10 </b>But Nebuzar-adan the captain of the guard left of the poor of the people, which had nothing, in the land of Judah, and gave them vineyards and fields at the same time.

<b>11 </b>¶ Now Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon gave charge concerning Jeremiah to Nebuzar-adan the captain of the guard, saying,

<b>12 </b>Take him, and look well to him, and do him no harm; but do unto him even as he shall say unto thee.

<b>13 </b>So Nebuzar-adan the captain of the guard sent, and Nebushasban, Rab-saris, and Nergal-sharezer, Rab-mag, and all the king of Babylon’s princes;

<b>14 </b>Even they sent, and took Jeremiah out of the court of the prison, and committed him unto Gedaliah the son of Ahikam the son of Shaphan, that he should carry him home: so he dwelt among the people.

<b>15 </b>¶ Now the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto Jeremiah, while he was shut up in the court of the prison, saying,

<b>16 </b>Go and speak to Ebed-melech the Ethiopian, saying, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of Israel; Behold, I will bring my words upon this city for evil, and not for good; and they shall be <i>accomplished</i> in that day before thee.

<b>17 </b>But I will deliver thee in that day, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and thou shalt not be given into the hand of the men of whom thou <i>art</i> afraid.

<b>18 </b>For I will surely deliver thee, and thou shalt not fall by the sword, but thy life shall be for a prey unto thee: because thou hast put thy trust in me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

CHAPTER 40

<b>1 </b>The word that came to Jeremiah from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, after that Nebuzar-adan the captain of the guard had let him go from Ramah, when he had taken him being bound in chains among all that were carried away captive of Jerusalem and Judah, which were carried away captive unto Babylon.

<b>2 </b>And the captain of the guard took Jeremiah, and said unto him, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God hath pronounced this evil upon this place.

<b>3 </b>Now the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath brought <i>it,</i> and done according as he hath said: because ye have sinned against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and have not obeyed his voice, therefore this thing is come upon you.

<b>4 </b>And now, behold, I loose thee this day from the chains which <i>were</i> upon thine hand. If it seem good unto thee to come with me into Babylon, come; and I will look well unto thee: but if it seem ill unto thee to come with me into Babylon, forbear: behold, all the land <i>is</i> before thee: whither it seemeth good and convenient for thee to go, thither go.

<b>5 </b>Now while he was not yet gone back, <i>he said,</i> Go back also to Gedaliah the son of Ahikam the son of Shaphan, whom the king of Babylon hath made governor over the cities of Judah, and dwell with him among the people: or go wheresoever it seemeth convenient unto thee to go. So the captain of the guard gave him victuals and a reward, and let him go.

<b>6 </b>Then went Jeremiah unto Gedaliah the son of Ahikam to Mizpah; and dwelt with him among the people that were left in the land.

<b>7 </b>¶ Now when all the captains of the forces which <i>were</i> in the fields, <i>even</i> they and their men, heard that the king of Babylon had made Gedaliah the son of Ahikam governor in the land, and had committed unto him men, and women, and children, and of the poor of the land, of them that were not carried away captive to Babylon;

<b>8 </b>Then they came to Gedaliah to Mizpah, even Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, and Johanan and Jonathan the sons of Kareah, and Seraiah the son of Tanhumeth, and the sons of Ephai the Netophathite, and Jezaniah the son of a Maachathite, they and their men.

<b>9 </b>And Gedaliah the son of Ahikam the son of Shaphan sware unto them and to their men, saying, Fear not to serve the Chaldeans: dwell in the land, and serve the king of Babylon, and it shall be well with you.

<b>10 </b>As for me, behold, I will dwell at Mizpah to serve the Chaldeans, which will come unto us: but ye, gather ye wine, and summer fruits, and oil, and put <i>them</i> in your vessels, and dwell in your cities that ye have taken.

<b>11 </b>Likewise when all the Jews that <i>were</i> in Moab, and among the Ammonites, and in Edom, and that <i>were</i> in all the countries, heard that the king of Babylon had left a remnant of Judah, and that he had set over them Gedaliah the son of Ahikam the son of Shaphan;

<b>12 </b>Even all the Jews returned out of all places whither they were driven, and came to the land of Judah, to Gedaliah, unto Mizpah, and gathered wine and summer fruits very much.

<b>13 </b>¶ Moreover Johanan the son of Kareah, and all the captains of the forces that <i>were</i> in the fields, came to Gedaliah to Mizpah,

<b>14 </b>And said unto him, Dost thou certainly know that Baalis the king of the Ammonites hath sent Ishmael the son of Nethaniah to slay thee? But Gedaliah the son of Ahikam believed them not.

<b>15 </b>Then Johanan the son of Kareah spake to Gedaliah in Mizpah secretly, saying, Let me go, I pray thee, and I will slay Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, and no man shall know <i>it:</i> wherefore should he slay thee, that all the Jews which are gathered unto thee should be scattered, and the remnant in Judah perish?

<b>16 </b>But Gedaliah the son of Ahikam said unto Johanan the son of Kareah, Thou shalt not do this thing: for thou speakest falsely of Ishmael.


--------------------

CHAPTER 41

<b>1 </b>Now it came to pass in the seventh month, <i>that</i> Ishmael the son of Nethaniah the son of Elishama, of the seed royal, and the princes of the king, even ten men with him, came unto Gedaliah the son of Ahikam to Mizpah; and there they did eat bread together in Mizpah.

<b>2 </b>Then arose Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, and the ten men that were with him, and smote Gedaliah the son of Ahikam the son of Shaphan with the sword, and slew him, whom the king of Babylon had made governor over the land.

<b>3 </b>Ishmael also slew all the Jews that were with him, <i>even</i> with Gedaliah, at Mizpah, and the Chaldeans that were found there, <i>and</i> the men of war.

<b>4 </b>And it came to pass the second day after he had slain Gedaliah, and no man knew <i>it,</i>

<b>5 </b>That there came certain from Shechem, from Shiloh, and from Samaria, <i>even</i> fourscore men, having their beards shaven, and their clothes rent, and having cut themselves, with offerings and incense in their hand, to bring <i>them</i> to the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>6 </b>And Ishmael the son of Nethaniah went forth from Mizpah to meet them, weeping all along as he went: and it came to pass, as he met them, he said unto them, Come to Gedaliah the son of Ahikam.

<b>7 </b>And it was <i>so,</i> when they came into the midst of the city, that Ishmael the son of Nethaniah slew them, <i>and cast them</i> into the midst of the pit, he, and the men that <i>were</i> with him.

<b>8 </b>But ten men were found among them that said unto Ishmael, Slay us not: for we have treasures in the field, of wheat, and of barley, and of oil, and of honey. So he forbare, and slew them not among their brethren.

<b>9 </b>Now the pit wherein Ishmael had cast all the dead bodies of the men, whom he had slain because of Gedaliah, <i>was</i> it which Asa the king had made for fear of Baasha king of Israel: <i>and</i> Ishmael the son of Nethaniah filled it with <i>them that were</i> slain.

<b>10 </b>Then Ishmael carried away captive all the residue of the people that <i>were</i> in Mizpah, <i>even</i> the king’s daughters, and all the people that remained in Mizpah, whom Nebuzar-adan the captain of the guard had committed to Gedaliah the son of Ahikam: and Ishmael the son of Nethaniah carried them away captive, and departed to go over to the Ammonites.

<b>11 </b>¶ But when Johanan the son of Kareah, and all the captains of the forces that <i>were</i> with him, heard of all the evil that Ishmael the son of Nethaniah had done,

<b>12 </b>Then they took all the men, and went to fight with Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, and found him by the great waters that <i>are</i> in Gibeon.

<b>13 </b>Now it came to pass, <i>that</i> when all the people which <i>were</i> with Ishmael saw Johanan the son of Kareah, and all the captains of the forces that <i>were</i> with him, then they were glad.

<b>14 </b>So all the people that Ishmael had carried away captive from Mizpah cast about and returned, and went unto Johanan the son of Kareah.

<b>15 </b>But Ishmael the son of Nethaniah escaped from Johanan with eight men, and went to the Ammonites.

<b>16 </b>Then took Johanan the son of Kareah, and all the captains of the forces that <i>were</i> with him, all the remnant of the people whom he had recovered from Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, from Mizpah, after <i>that</i> he had slain Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, <i>even</i> mighty men of war, and the women, and the children, and the eunuchs, whom he had brought again from Gibeon:

<b>17 </b>And they departed, and dwelt in the habitation of Chimham, which is by Beth-lehem, to go to enter into Egypt,

<b>18 </b>Because of the Chaldeans: for they were afraid of them, because Ishmael the son of Nethaniah had slain Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, whom the king of Babylon made governor in the land.


--------------------

CHAPTER 42

<b>1 </b>Then all the captains of the forces, and Johanan the son of Kareah, and Jezaniah the son of Hoshaiah, and all the people from the least even unto the greatest, came near,

<b>2 </b>And said unto Jeremiah the prophet, Let, we beseech thee, our supplication be accepted before thee, and pray for us unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God, <i>even</i> for all this remnant; (for we are left <i>but</i> a few of many, as thine eyes do behold us:)

<b>3 </b>That the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God may shew us the way wherein we may walk, and the thing that we may do.

<b>4 </b>Then Jeremiah the prophet said unto them, I have heard <i>you;</i> behold, I will pray unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God according to your words; and it shall come to pass, <i>that</i> whatsoever thing the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall answer you, I will declare <i>it</i> unto you; I will keep nothing back from you.

<b>5 </b>Then they said to Jeremiah, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> be a true and faithful witness between us, if we do not even according to all things for the which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God shall send thee to us.

<b>6 </b>Whether <i>it be</i> good, or whether <i>it be</i> evil, we will obey the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God, to whom we send thee; that it may be well with us, when we obey the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God.

<b>7 </b>¶ And it came to pass after ten days, that the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto Jeremiah.

<b>8 </b>Then called he Johanan the son of Kareah, and all the captains of the forces which <i>were</i> with him, and all the people from the least even to the greatest,

<b>9 </b>And said unto them, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the God of Israel, unto whom ye sent me to present your supplication before him;

<b>10 </b>If ye will still abide in this land, then will I build you, and not pull <i>you</i> down, and I will plant you, and not pluck <i>you</i> up: for I repent me of the evil that I have done unto you.

<b>11 </b>Be not afraid of the king of Babylon, of whom ye are afraid; be not afraid of him, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for I <i>am</i> with you to save you, and to deliver you from his hand.

<b>12 </b>And I will shew mercies unto you, that he may have mercy upon you, and cause you to return to your own land.

<b>13 </b>¶ But if ye say, We will not dwell in this land, neither obey the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God,

<b>14 </b>Saying, No; but we will go into the land of Egypt, where we shall see no war, nor hear the sound of the trumpet, nor have hunger of bread; and there will we dwell:

<b>15 </b>And now therefore hear the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, ye remnant of Judah; Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of Israel; If ye wholly set your faces to enter into Egypt, and go to sojourn there;

<b>16 </b>Then it shall come to pass, <i>that</i> the sword, which ye feared, shall overtake you there in the land of Egypt, and the famine, whereof ye were afraid, shall follow close after you there in Egypt; and there ye shall die.

<b>17 </b>So shall it be with all the men that set their faces to go into Egypt to sojourn there; they shall die by the sword, by the famine, and by the pestilence: and none of them shall remain or escape from the evil that I will bring upon them.

<b>18 </b>For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of Israel; As mine anger and my fury hath been poured forth upon the inhabitants of Jerusalem; so shall my fury be poured forth upon you, when ye shall enter into Egypt: and ye shall be an execration, and an astonishment, and a curse, and a reproach; and ye shall see this place no more.

<b>19 </b>¶ The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath said concerning you, O ye remnant of Judah; Go ye not into Egypt: know certainly that I have admonished you this day.

<b>20 </b>For ye dissembled in your hearts, when ye sent me unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, saying, Pray for us unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God; and according unto all that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God shall say, so declare unto us, and we will do <i>it.</i>

<b>21 </b>And <i>now</i> I have this day declared <i>it</i> to you; but ye have not obeyed the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, nor any <i>thing</i> for the which he hath sent me unto you.

<b>22 </b>Now therefore know certainly that ye shall die by the sword, by the famine, and by the pestilence, in the place whither ye desire to go <i>and</i> to sojourn.


--------------------

CHAPTER 43

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass, <i>that</i> when Jeremiah had made an end of speaking unto all the people all the words of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> their God, for which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> their God had sent him to them, <i>even</i> all these words,

<b>2 </b>Then spake Azariah the son of Hoshaiah, and Johanan the son of Kareah, and all the proud men, saying unto Jeremiah, Thou speakest falsely: the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God hath not sent thee to say, Go not into Egypt to sojourn there:

<b>3 </b>But Baruch the son of Neriah setteth thee on against us, for to deliver us into the hand of the Chaldeans, that they might put us to death, and carry us away captives into Babylon.

<b>4 </b>So Johanan the son of Kareah, and all the captains of the forces, and all the people, obeyed not the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to dwell in the land of Judah.

<b>5 </b>But Johanan the son of Kareah, and all the captains of the forces, took all the remnant of Judah, that were returned from all nations, whither they had been driven, to dwell in the land of Judah;

<b>6 </b><i>Even</i> men, and women, and children, and the king’s daughters, and every person that Nebuzar-adan the captain of the guard had left with Gedaliah the son of Ahikam the son of Shaphan, and Jeremiah the prophet, and Baruch the son of Neriah.

<b>7 </b>So they came into the land of Egypt: for they obeyed not the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: thus came they <i>even</i> to Tahpanhes.

<b>8 </b>¶ Then came the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto Jeremiah in Tahpanhes, saying,

<b>9 </b>Take great stones in thine hand, and hide them in the clay in the brickkiln, which <i>is</i> at the entry of Pharaoh’s house in Tahpanhes, in the sight of the men of Judah;

<b>10 </b>And say unto them, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of Israel; Behold, I will send and take Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon, my servant, and will set his throne upon these stones that I have hid; and he shall spread his royal pavilion over them.

<b>11 </b>And when he cometh, he shall smite the land of Egypt, <i>and deliver</i> such <i>as are</i> for death to death; and such <i>as are</i> for captivity to captivity; and such <i>as are</i> for the sword to the sword.

<b>12 </b>And I will kindle a fire in the houses of the gods of Egypt; and he shall burn them, and carry them away captives: and he shall array himself with the land of Egypt, as a shepherd putteth on his garment; and he shall go forth from thence in peace.

<b>13 </b>He shall break also the images of Beth-shemesh, that <i>is</i> in the land of Egypt; and the houses of the gods of the Egyptians shall he burn with fire.


--------------------

CHAPTER 44

<b>1 </b>The word that came to Jeremiah concerning all the Jews which dwell in the land of Egypt, which dwell at Migdol, and at Tahpanhes, and at Noph, and in the country of Pathros, saying,

<b>2 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of Israel; Ye have seen all the evil that I have brought upon Jerusalem, and upon all the cities of Judah; and, behold, this day they <i>are</i> a desolation, and no man dwelleth therein,

<b>3 </b>Because of their wickedness which they have committed to provoke me to anger, in that they went to burn incense, <i>and</i> to serve other gods, whom they knew not, <i>neither</i> they, ye, nor your fathers.

<b>4 </b>Howbeit I sent unto you all my servants the prophets, rising early and sending <i>them,</i> saying, Oh, do not this abominable thing that I hate.

<b>5 </b>But they hearkened not, nor inclined their ear to turn from their wickedness, to burn no incense unto other gods.

<b>6 </b>Wherefore my fury and mine anger was poured forth, and was kindled in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem; and they are wasted <i>and</i> desolate, as at this day.

<b>7 </b>Therefore now thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the God of hosts, the God of Israel; Wherefore commit ye <i>this</i> great evil against your souls, to cut off from you man and woman, child and suckling, out of Judah, to leave you none to remain;

<b>8 </b>In that ye provoke me unto wrath with the works of your hands, burning incense unto other gods in the land of Egypt, whither ye be gone to dwell, that ye might cut yourselves off, and that ye might be a curse and a reproach among all the nations of the earth?

<b>9 </b>Have ye forgotten the wickedness of your fathers, and the wickedness of the kings of Judah, and the wickedness of their wives, and your own wickedness, and the wickedness of your wives, which they have committed in the land of Judah, and in the streets of Jerusalem?

<b>10 </b>They are not humbled <i>even</i> unto this day, neither have they feared, nor walked in my law, nor in my statutes, that I set before you and before your fathers.

<b>11 </b>¶ Therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of Israel; Behold, I will set my face against you for evil, and to cut off all Judah.

<b>12 </b>And I will take the remnant of Judah, that have set their faces to go into the land of Egypt to sojourn there, and they shall all be consumed, <i>and</i> fall in the land of Egypt; they shall <i>even</i> be consumed by the sword <i>and</i> by the famine: they shall die, from the least even unto the greatest, by the sword and by the famine: and they shall be an execration, <i>and</i> an astonishment, and a curse, and a reproach.

<b>13 </b>For I will punish them that dwell in the land of Egypt, as I have punished Jerusalem, by the sword, by the famine, and by the pestilence:

<b>14 </b>So that none of the remnant of Judah, which are gone into the land of Egypt to sojourn there, shall escape or remain, that they should return into the land of Judah, to the which they have a desire to return to dwell there: for none shall return but such as shall escape.

<b>15 </b>¶ Then all the men which knew that their wives had burned incense unto other gods, and all the women that stood by, a great multitude, even all the people that dwelt in the land of Egypt, in Pathros, answered Jeremiah, saying,

<b>16 </b><i>As for</i> the word that thou hast spoken unto us in the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, we will not hearken unto thee.

<b>17 </b>But we will certainly do whatsoever thing goeth forth out of our own mouth, to burn incense unto the queen of heaven, and to pour out drink offerings unto her, as we have done, we, and our fathers, our kings, and our princes, in the cities of Judah, and in the streets of Jerusalem: for <i>then</i> had we plenty of victuals, and were well, and saw no evil.

<b>18 </b>But since we left off to burn incense to the queen of heaven, and to pour out drink offerings unto her, we have wanted all <i>things,</i> and have been consumed by the sword and by the famine.

<b>19 </b>And when we burned incense to the queen of heaven, and poured out drink offerings unto her, did we make her cakes to worship her, and pour out drink offerings unto her, without our men?

<b>20 </b>¶ Then Jeremiah said unto all the people, to the men, and to the women, and to all the people which had given him <i>that</i> answer, saying,
