<b>13 </b>When Ephraim saw his sickness, and Judah <i>saw</i> his wound, then went Ephraim to the Assyrian, and sent to king Jareb: yet could he not heal you, nor cure you of your wound.

<b>14 </b>For I <i>will be</i> unto Ephraim as a lion, and as a young lion to the house of Judah: I, <i>even</i> I, will tear and go away; I will take away, and none shall rescue <i>him.</i>

<b>15 </b>¶ I will go <i>and</i> return to my place, till they acknowledge their offence, and seek my face: in their affliction they will seek me early.


--------------------

CHAPTER 6

<b>1 </b>Come, and let us return unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for he hath torn, and he will heal us; he hath smitten, and he will bind us up.

<b>2 </b>After two days will he revive us: in the third day he will raise us up, and we shall live in his sight.

<b>3 </b>Then shall we know, <i>if</i> we follow on to know the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: his going forth is prepared as the morning; and he shall come unto us as the rain, as the latter <i>and</i> former rain unto the earth.

<b>4 </b>¶ O Ephraim, what shall I do unto thee? O Judah, what shall I do unto thee? for your goodness <i>is</i> as a morning cloud, and as the early dew it goeth away.

<b>5 </b>Therefore have I hewed <i>them</i> by the prophets; I have slain them by the words of my mouth: and thy judgments <i>are as</i> the light <i>that</i> goeth forth.

<b>6 </b>For I desired mercy, and not sacrifice; and the knowledge of God more than burnt offerings.

<b>7 </b>But they like men have transgressed the covenant: there have they dealt treacherously against me.

<b>8 </b>Gilead <i>is</i> a city of them that work iniquity, <i>and is</i> polluted with blood.

<b>9 </b>And as troops of robbers wait for a man, <i>so</i> the company of priests murder in the way by consent: for they commit lewdness.

<b>10 </b>I have seen an horrible thing in the house of Israel: there <i>is</i> the whoredom of Ephraim, Israel is defiled.

<b>11 </b>Also, O Judah, he hath set an harvest for thee, when I returned the captivity of my people.


--------------------

CHAPTER 7

<b>1 </b>When I would have healed Israel, then the iniquity of Ephraim was discovered, and the wickedness of Samaria: for they commit falsehood; and the thief cometh in, <i>and</i> the troop of robbers spoileth without.

<b>2 </b>And they consider not in their hearts <i>that</i> I remember all their wickedness: now their own doings have beset them about; they are before my face.

<b>3 </b>They make the king glad with their wickedness, and the princes with their lies.

<b>4 </b>They <i>are</i> all adulterers, as an oven heated by the baker, <i>who</i> ceaseth from raising after he hath kneaded the dough, until it be leavened.

<b>5 </b>In the day of our king the princes have made <i>him</i> sick with bottles of wine; he stretched out his hand with scorners.

<b>6 </b>For they have made ready their heart like an oven, whiles they lie in wait: their baker sleepeth all the night; in the morning it burneth as a flaming fire.

<b>7 </b>They are all hot as an oven, and have devoured their judges; all their kings are fallen: <i>there is</i> none among them that calleth unto me.

<b>8 </b>Ephraim, he hath mixed himself among the people; Ephraim is a cake not turned.

<b>9 </b>Strangers have devoured his strength, and he knoweth <i>it</i> not: yea, gray hairs are here and there upon him, yet he knoweth not.

<b>10 </b>And the pride of Israel testifieth to his face: and they do not return to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> their God, nor seek him for all this.

<b>11 </b>¶ Ephraim also is like a silly dove without heart: they call to Egypt, they go to Assyria.

<b>12 </b>When they shall go, I will spread my net upon them; I will bring them down as the fowls of the heaven; I will chastise them, as their congregation hath heard.

<b>13 </b>Woe unto them! for they have fled from me: destruction unto them! because they have transgressed against me: though I have redeemed them, yet they have spoken lies against me.

<b>14 </b>And they have not cried unto me with their heart, when they howled upon their beds: they assemble themselves for corn and wine, <i>and</i> they rebel against me.

<b>15 </b>Though I have bound <i>and</i> strengthened their arms, yet do they imagine mischief against me.

<b>16 </b>They return, <i>but</i> not to the most High: they are like a deceitful bow: their princes shall fall by the sword for the rage of their tongue: this <i>shall be</i> their derision in the land of Egypt.


--------------------

CHAPTER 8

<b>1 </b><i>Set</i> the trumpet to thy mouth. <i>He shall come</i> as an eagle against the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, because they have transgressed my covenant, and trespassed against my law.

<b>2 </b>Israel shall cry unto me, My God, we know thee.

<b>3 </b>Israel hath cast off <i>the thing that is</i> good: the enemy shall pursue him.

<b>4 </b>They have set up kings, but not by me: they have made princes, and I knew <i>it</i> not: of their silver and their gold have they made them idols, that they may be cut off.

<b>5 </b>¶ Thy calf, O Samaria, hath cast <i>thee</i> off; mine anger is kindled against them: how long <i>will it be</i> ere they attain to innocency?

<b>6 </b>For from Israel <i>was</i> it also: the workman made it; therefore it <i>is</i> not God: but the calf of Samaria shall be broken in pieces.

<b>7 </b>For they have sown the wind, and they shall reap the whirlwind: it hath no stalk: the bud shall yield no meal: if so be it yield, the strangers shall swallow it up.

<b>8 </b>Israel is swallowed up: now shall they be among the Gentiles as a vessel wherein <i>is</i> no pleasure.

<b>9 </b>For they are gone up to Assyria, a wild ass alone by himself: Ephraim hath hired lovers.

<b>10 </b>Yea, though they have hired among the nations, now will I gather them, and they shall sorrow a little for the burden of the king of princes.

<b>11 </b>Because Ephraim hath made many altars to sin, altars shall be unto him to sin.

<b>12 </b>I have written to him the great things of my law, <i>but</i> they were counted as a strange thing.

<b>13 </b>They sacrifice flesh <i>for</i> the sacrifices of mine offerings, and eat <i>it; but</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> accepteth them not; now will he remember their iniquity, and visit their sins: they shall return to Egypt.

<b>14 </b>For Israel hath forgotten his Maker, and buildeth temples; and Judah hath multiplied fenced cities: but I will send a fire upon his cities, and it shall devour the palaces thereof.


--------------------

CHAPTER 9

<b>1 </b>Rejoice not, O Israel, for joy, as <i>other</i> people: for thou hast gone a whoring from thy God, thou hast loved a reward upon every cornfloor.

<b>2 </b>The floor and the winepress shall not feed them, and the new wine shall fail in her.

<b>3 </b>They shall not dwell in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s land; but Ephraim shall return to Egypt, and they shall eat unclean <i>things</i> in Assyria.

<b>4 </b>They shall not offer wine <i>offerings</i> to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, neither shall they be pleasing unto him: their sacrifices <i>shall be</i> unto them as the bread of mourners; all that eat thereof shall be polluted: for their bread for their soul shall not come into the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>5 </b>What will ye do in the solemn day, and in the day of the feast of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>?

<b>6 </b>For, lo, they are gone because of destruction: Egypt shall gather them up, Memphis shall bury them: the pleasant <i>places</i> for their silver, nettles shall possess them: thorns <i>shall be</i> in their tabernacles.

<b>7 </b>The days of visitation are come, the days of recompence are come; Israel shall know <i>it:</i> the prophet <i>is</i> a fool, the spiritual man <i>is</i> mad, for the multitude of thine iniquity, and the great hatred.

<b>8 </b>The watchman of Ephraim <i>was</i> with my God: <i>but</i> the prophet <i>is</i> a snare of a fowler in all his ways, <i>and</i> hatred in the house of his God.

<b>9 </b>They have deeply corrupted <i>themselves,</i> as in the days of Gibeah: <i>therefore</i> he will remember their iniquity, he will visit their sins.

<b>10 </b>I found Israel like grapes in the wilderness; I saw your fathers as the firstripe in the fig tree at her first time: <i>but</i> they went to Baal-peor, and separated themselves unto <i>that</i> shame; and <i>their</i> abominations were according as they loved.

<b>11 </b><i>As for</i> Ephraim, their glory shall fly away like a bird, from the birth, and from the womb, and from the conception.

<b>12 </b>Though they bring up their children, yet will I bereave them, <i>that there shall</i> not <i>be</i> a man <i>left:</i> yea, woe also to them when I depart from them!

<b>13 </b>Ephraim, as I saw Tyrus, <i>is</i> planted in a pleasant place: but Ephraim shall bring forth his children to the murderer.

<b>14 </b>Give them, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: what wilt thou give? give them a miscarrying womb and dry breasts.

<b>15 </b>All their wickedness <i>is</i> in Gilgal: for there I hated them: for the wickedness of their doings I will drive them out of mine house, I will love them no more: all their princes <i>are</i> revolters.

<b>16 </b>Ephraim is smitten, their root is dried up, they shall bear no fruit: yea, though they bring forth, yet will I slay <i>even</i> the beloved <i>fruit</i> of their womb.

<b>17 </b>My God will cast them away, because they did not hearken unto him: and they shall be wanderers among the nations.


--------------------

CHAPTER 10

<b>1 </b>Israel <i>is</i> an empty vine, he bringeth forth fruit unto himself: according to the multitude of his fruit he hath increased the altars; according to the goodness of his land they have made goodly images.

<b>2 </b>Their heart is divided; now shall they be found faulty: he shall break down their altars, he shall spoil their images.

<b>3 </b>For now they shall say, We have no king, because we feared not the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; what then should a king do to us?

<b>4 </b>They have spoken words, swearing falsely in making a covenant: thus judgment springeth up as hemlock in the furrows of the field.

<b>5 </b>The inhabitants of Samaria shall fear because of the calves of Beth-aven: for the people thereof shall mourn over it, and the priests thereof <i>that</i> rejoiced on it, for the glory thereof, because it is departed from it.

<b>6 </b>It shall be also carried unto Assyria <i>for</i> a present to king Jareb: Ephraim shall receive shame, and Israel shall be ashamed of his own counsel.

<b>7 </b><i>As for</i> Samaria, her king is cut off as the foam upon the water.

<b>8 </b>The high places also of Aven, the sin of Israel, shall be destroyed: the thorn and the thistle shall come up on their altars; and they shall say to the mountains, Cover us; and to the hills, Fall on us.

<b>9 </b>O Israel, thou hast sinned from the days of Gibeah: there they stood: the battle in Gibeah against the children of iniquity did not overtake them.

<b>10 </b><i>It is</i> in my desire that I should chastise them; and the people shall be gathered against them, when they shall bind themselves in their two furrows.

<b>11 </b>And Ephraim <i>is as</i> an heifer <i>that is</i> taught, <i>and</i> loveth to tread out <i>the corn;</i> but I passed over upon her fair neck: I will make Ephraim to ride; Judah shall plow, <i>and</i> Jacob shall break his clods.

<b>12 </b>Sow to yourselves in righteousness, reap in mercy; break up your fallow ground: for <i>it is</i> time to seek the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, till he come and rain righteousness upon you.

<b>13 </b>Ye have plowed wickedness, ye have reaped iniquity; ye have eaten the fruit of lies: because thou didst trust in thy way, in the multitude of thy mighty men.

<b>14 </b>Therefore shall a tumult arise among thy people, and all thy fortresses shall be spoiled, as Shalman spoiled Beth-arbel in the day of battle: the mother was dashed in pieces upon <i>her</i> children.

<b>15 </b>So shall Beth-el do unto you because of your great wickedness: in a morning shall the king of Israel utterly be cut off.


--------------------

CHAPTER 11

<b>1 </b>When Israel <i>was</i> a child, then I loved him, and called my son out of Egypt.

<b>2 </b><i>As</i> they called them, so they went from them: they sacrificed unto Baalim, and burned incense to graven images.

<b>3 </b>I taught Ephraim also to go, taking them by their arms; but they knew not that I healed them.

<b>4 </b>I drew them with cords of a man, with bands of love: and I was to them as they that take off the yoke on their jaws, and I laid meat unto them.

<b>5 </b>¶ He shall not return into the land of Egypt, but the Assyrian shall be his king, because they refused to return.

<b>6 </b>And the sword shall abide on his cities, and shall consume his branches, and devour <i>them,</i> because of their own counsels.

<b>7 </b>And my people are bent to backsliding from me: though they called them to the most High, none at all would exalt <i>him.</i>

<b>8 </b>How shall I give thee up, Ephraim? <i>how</i> shall I deliver thee, Israel? how shall I make thee as Admah? <i>how</i> shall I set thee as Zeboim? mine heart is turned within me, my repentings are kindled together.

<b>9 </b>I will not execute the fierceness of mine anger, I will not return to destroy Ephraim: for I <i>am</i> God, and not man; the Holy One in the midst of thee: and I will not enter into the city.

<b>10 </b>They shall walk after the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: he shall roar like a lion: when he shall roar, then the children shall tremble from the west.

<b>11 </b>They shall tremble as a bird out of Egypt, and as a dove out of the land of Assyria: and I will place them in their houses, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>12 </b>Ephraim compasseth me about with lies, and the house of Israel with deceit: but Judah yet ruleth with God, and is faithful with the saints.


--------------------

CHAPTER 12

<b>1 </b>Ephraim feedeth on wind, and followeth after the east wind: he daily increaseth lies and desolation; and they do make a covenant with the Assyrians, and oil is carried into Egypt.

<b>2 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath also a controversy with Judah, and will punish Jacob according to his ways; according to his doings will he recompense him.

<b>3 </b>¶ He took his brother by the heel in the womb, and by his strength he had power with God:

<b>4 </b>Yea, he had power over the angel, and prevailed: he wept, and made supplication unto him: he found him <i>in</i> Beth-el, and there he spake with us;

<b>5 </b>Even the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of hosts; the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> his memorial.

<b>6 </b>Therefore turn thou to thy God: keep mercy and judgment, and wait on thy God continually.

<b>7 </b>¶ <i>He is</i> a merchant, the balances of deceit <i>are</i> in his hand: he loveth to oppress.

<b>8 </b>And Ephraim said, Yet I am become rich, I have found me out substance: <i>in</i> all my labours they shall find none iniquity in me that <i>were</i> sin.

<b>9 </b>And I <i>that am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God from the land of Egypt will yet make thee to dwell in tabernacles, as in the days of the solemn feast.

<b>10 </b>I have also spoken by the prophets, and I have multiplied visions, and used similitudes, by the ministry of the prophets.

<b>11 </b><i>Is there</i> iniquity <i>in</i> Gilead? surely they are vanity: they sacrifice bullocks in Gilgal; yea, their altars <i>are</i> as heaps in the furrows of the fields.

<b>12 </b>And Jacob fled into the country of Syria, and Israel served for a wife, and for a wife he kept <i>sheep.</i>

<b>13 </b>And by a prophet the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> brought Israel out of Egypt, and by a prophet was he preserved.

<b>14 </b>Ephraim provoked <i>him</i> to anger most bitterly: therefore shall he leave his blood upon him, and his reproach shall his Lord return unto him.


--------------------

CHAPTER 13

<b>1 </b>When Ephraim spake trembling, he exalted himself in Israel; but when he offended in Baal, he died.

<b>2 </b>And now they sin more and more, and have made them molten images of their silver, <i>and</i> idols according to their own understanding, all of it the work of the craftsmen: they say of them, Let the men that sacrifice kiss the calves.

<b>3 </b>Therefore they shall be as the morning cloud, and as the early dew that passeth away, as the chaff <i>that</i> is driven with the whirlwind out of the floor, and as the smoke out of the chimney.

<b>4 </b>Yet I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God from the land of Egypt, and thou shalt know no god but me: for <i>there is</i> no saviour beside me.

<b>5 </b>¶ I did know thee in the wilderness, in the land of great drought.

<b>6 </b>According to their pasture, so were they filled; they were filled, and their heart was exalted; therefore have they forgotten me.

<b>7 </b>Therefore I will be unto them as a lion: as a leopard by the way will I observe <i>them:</i>

<b>8 </b>I will meet them as a bear <i>that is</i> bereaved <i>of her whelps,</i> and will rend the caul of their heart, and there will I devour them like a lion: the wild beast shall tear them.

<b>9 </b>¶ O Israel, thou hast destroyed thyself; but in me <i>is</i> thine help.

<b>10 </b>I will be thy king: where <i>is any other</i> that may save thee in all thy cities? and thy judges of whom thou saidst, Give me a king and princes?

<b>11 </b>I gave thee a king in mine anger, and took <i>him</i> away in my wrath.

<b>12 </b>The iniquity of Ephraim <i>is</i> bound up; his sin <i>is</i> hid.

<b>13 </b>The sorrows of a travailing woman shall come upon him: he <i>is</i> an unwise son; for he should not stay long in <i>the place of</i> the breaking forth of children.

<b>14 </b>I will ransom them from the power of the grave; I will redeem them from death: O death, I will be thy plagues; O grave, I will be thy destruction: repentance shall be hid from mine eyes.

<b>15 </b>¶ Though he be fruitful among <i>his</i> brethren, an east wind shall come, the wind of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall come up from the wilderness, and his spring shall become dry, and his fountain shall be dried up: he shall spoil the treasure of all pleasant vessels.

<b>16 </b>Samaria shall become desolate; for she hath rebelled against her God: they shall fall by the sword: their infants shall be dashed in pieces, and their women with child shall be ripped up.


--------------------

CHAPTER 14

<b>1 </b>O Israel, return unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God; for thou hast fallen by thine iniquity.

<b>2 </b>Take with you words, and turn to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: say unto him, Take away all iniquity, and receive <i>us</i> graciously: so will we render the calves of our lips.

<b>3 </b>Asshur shall not save us; we will not ride upon horses: neither will we say any more to the work of our hands, <i>Ye are</i> our gods: for in thee the fatherless findeth mercy.

<b>4 </b>¶ I will heal their backsliding, I will love them freely: for mine anger is turned away from him.

<b>5 </b>I will be as the dew unto Israel: he shall grow as the lily, and cast forth his roots as Lebanon.

<b>6 </b>His branches shall spread, and his beauty shall be as the olive tree, and his smell as Lebanon.

<b>7 </b>They that dwell under his shadow shall return; they shall revive <i>as</i> the corn, and grow as the vine: the scent thereof <i>shall be</i> as the wine of Lebanon.

<b>8 </b>Ephraim <i>shall say,</i> What have I to do any more with idols? I have heard <i>him,</i> and observed him: I <i>am</i> like a green fir tree. From me is thy fruit found.

<b>9 </b>Who <i>is</i> wise, and he shall understand these <i>things?</i> prudent, and he shall know them? for the ways of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>are</i> right, and the just shall walk in them: but the transgressors shall fall therein.


--------------------

Joel

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>The word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that came to Joel the son of Pethuel.

<b>2 </b>Hear this, ye old men, and give ear, all ye inhabitants of the land. Hath this been in your days, or even in the days of your fathers?

<b>3 </b>Tell ye your children of it, and <i>let</i> your children <i>tell</i> their children, and their children another generation.

<b>4 </b>That which the palmerworm hath left hath the locust eaten; and that which the locust hath left hath the cankerworm eaten; and that which the cankerworm hath left hath the caterpiller eaten.

<b>5 </b>Awake, ye drunkards, and weep; and howl, all ye drinkers of wine, because of the new wine; for it is cut off from your mouth.

<b>6 </b>For a nation is come up upon my land, strong, and without number, whose teeth <i>are</i> the teeth of a lion, and he hath the cheek teeth of a great lion.

<b>7 </b>He hath laid my vine waste, and barked my fig tree: he hath made it clean bare, and cast <i>it</i> away; the branches thereof are made white.

<b>8 </b>¶ Lament like a virgin girded with sackcloth for the husband of her youth.

<b>9 </b>The meat offering and the drink offering is cut off from the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; the priests, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s ministers, mourn.

<b>10 </b>The field is wasted, the land mourneth; for the corn is wasted: the new wine is dried up, the oil languisheth.

<b>11 </b>Be ye ashamed, O ye husbandmen; howl, O ye vinedressers, for the wheat and for the barley; because the harvest of the field is perished.

<b>12 </b>The vine is dried up, and the fig tree languisheth; the pomegranate tree, the palm tree also, and the apple tree, <i>even</i> all the trees of the field, are withered: because joy is withered away from the sons of men.

<b>13 </b>Gird yourselves, and lament, ye priests: howl, ye ministers of the altar: come, lie all night in sackcloth, ye ministers of my God: for the meat offering and the drink offering is withholden from the house of your God.

<b>14 </b>¶ Sanctify ye a fast, call a solemn assembly, gather the elders <i>and</i> all the inhabitants of the land <i>into</i> the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, and cry unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>,

<b>15 </b>Alas for the day! for the day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> at hand, and as a destruction from the Almighty shall it come.

<b>16 </b>Is not the meat cut off before our eyes, <i>yea,</i> joy and gladness from the house of our God?

<b>17 </b>The seed is rotten under their clods, the garners are laid desolate, the barns are broken down; for the corn is withered.

<b>18 </b>How do the beasts groan! the herds of cattle are perplexed, because they have no pasture; yea, the flocks of sheep are made desolate.

<b>19 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to thee will I cry: for the fire hath devoured the pastures of the wilderness, and the flame hath burned all the trees of the field.

<b>20 </b>The beasts of the field cry also unto thee: for the rivers of waters are dried up, and the fire hath devoured the pastures of the wilderness.


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>Blow ye the trumpet in Zion, and sound an alarm in my holy mountain: let all the inhabitants of the land tremble: for the day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> cometh, for <i>it is</i> nigh at hand;

<b>2 </b>A day of darkness and of gloominess, a day of clouds and of thick darkness, as the morning spread upon the mountains: a great people and a strong; there hath not been ever the like, neither shall be any more after it, <i>even</i> to the years of many generations.

<b>3 </b>A fire devoureth before them; and behind them a flame burneth: the land <i>is</i> as the garden of Eden before them, and behind them a desolate wilderness; yea, and nothing shall escape them.

<b>4 </b>The appearance of them <i>is</i> as the appearance of horses; and as horsemen, so shall they run.

<b>5 </b>Like the noise of chariots on the tops of mountains shall they leap, like the noise of a flame of fire that devoureth the stubble, as a strong people set in battle array.

<b>6 </b>Before their face the people shall be much pained: all faces shall gather blackness.

<b>7 </b>They shall run like mighty men; they shall climb the wall like men of war; and they shall march every one on his ways, and they shall not break their ranks:

<b>8 </b>Neither shall one thrust another; they shall walk every one in his path: and <i>when</i> they fall upon the sword, they shall not be wounded.

<b>9 </b>They shall run to and fro in the city; they shall run upon the wall, they shall climb up upon the houses; they shall enter in at the windows like a thief.

<b>10 </b>The earth shall quake before them; the heavens shall tremble: the sun and the moon shall be dark, and the stars shall withdraw their shining:

<b>11 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall utter his voice before his army: for his camp <i>is</i> very great: for <i>he is</i> strong that executeth his word: for the day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> great and very terrible; and who can abide it?

<b>12 </b>¶ Therefore also now, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, turn ye <i>even</i> to me with all your heart, and with fasting, and with weeping, and with mourning:

<b>13 </b>And rend your heart, and not your garments, and turn unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God: for he <i>is</i> gracious and merciful, slow to anger, and of great kindness, and repenteth him of the evil.

<b>14 </b>Who knoweth <i>if</i> he will return and repent, and leave a blessing behind him; <i>even</i> a meat offering and a drink offering unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God?

<b>15 </b>¶ Blow the trumpet in Zion, sanctify a fast, call a solemn assembly:

<b>16 </b>Gather the people, sanctify the congregation, assemble the elders, gather the children, and those that suck the breasts: let the bridegroom go forth of his chamber, and the bride out of her closet.

<b>17 </b>Let the priests, the ministers of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, weep between the porch and the altar, and let them say, Spare thy people, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and give not thine heritage to reproach, that the heathen should rule over them: wherefore should they say among the people, Where <i>is</i> their God?

<b>18 </b>¶ Then will the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> be jealous for his land, and pity his people.

<b>19 </b>Yea, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will answer and say unto his people, Behold, I will send you corn, and wine, and oil, and ye shall be satisfied therewith: and I will no more make you a reproach among the heathen:

<b>20 </b>But I will remove far off from you the northern <i>army,</i> and will drive him into a land barren and desolate, with his face toward the east sea, and his hinder part toward the utmost sea, and his stink shall come up, and his ill savour shall come up, because he hath done great things.

<b>21 </b>¶ Fear not, O land; be glad and rejoice: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will do great things.

<b>22 </b>Be not afraid, ye beasts of the field: for the pastures of the wilderness do spring, for the tree beareth her fruit, the fig tree and the vine do yield their strength.

<b>23 </b>Be glad then, ye children of Zion, and rejoice in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God: for he hath given you the former rain moderately, and he will cause to come down for you the rain, the former rain, and the latter rain in the first <i>month.</i>

<b>24 </b>And the floors shall be full of wheat, and the fats shall overflow with wine and oil.

<b>25 </b>And I will restore to you the years that the locust hath eaten, the cankerworm, and the caterpiller, and the palmerworm, my great army which I sent among you.

<b>26 </b>And ye shall eat in plenty, and be satisfied, and praise the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, that hath dealt wondrously with you: and my people shall never be ashamed.

<b>27 </b>And ye shall know that I <i>am</i> in the midst of Israel, and <i>that</i> I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God, and none else: and my people shall never be ashamed.

<b>28 </b>¶ And it shall come to pass afterward, <i>that</i> I will pour out my spirit upon all flesh; and your sons and your daughters shall prophesy, your old men shall dream dreams, your young men shall see visions:

<b>29 </b>And also upon the servants and upon the handmaids in those days will I pour out my spirit.

<b>30 </b>And I will shew wonders in the heavens and in the earth, blood, and fire, and pillars of smoke.

<b>31 </b>The sun shall be turned into darkness, and the moon into blood, before the great and the terrible day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> come.

<b>32 </b>And it shall come to pass, <i>that</i> whosoever shall call on the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall be delivered: for in mount Zion and in Jerusalem shall be deliverance, as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath said, and in the remnant whom the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall call.


--------------------

CHAPTER 3

<b>1 </b>For, behold, in those days, and in that time, when I shall bring again the captivity of Judah and Jerusalem,

<b>2 </b>I will also gather all nations, and will bring them down into the valley of Jehoshaphat, and will plead with them there for my people and <i>for</i> my heritage Israel, whom they have scattered among the nations, and parted my land.

<b>3 </b>And they have cast lots for my people; and have given a boy for an harlot, and sold a girl for wine, that they might drink.

<b>4 </b>Yea, and what have ye to do with me, O Tyre, and Zidon, and all the coasts of Palestine? will ye render me a recompence? and if ye recompense me, swiftly <i>and</i> speedily will I return your recompence upon your own head;

<b>5 </b>Because ye have taken my silver and my gold, and have carried into your temples my goodly pleasant things:

<b>6 </b>The children also of Judah and the children of Jerusalem have ye sold unto the Grecians, that ye might remove them far from their border.

<b>7 </b>Behold, I will raise them out of the place whither ye have sold them, and will return your recompence upon your own head:

<b>8 </b>And I will sell your sons and your daughters into the hand of the children of Judah, and they shall sell them to the Sabeans, to a people far off: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath spoken <i>it.</i>

<b>9 </b>¶ Proclaim ye this among the Gentiles; Prepare war, wake up the mighty men, let all the men of war draw near; let them come up:

<b>10 </b>Beat your plowshares into swords, and your pruninghooks into spears: let the weak say, I <i>am</i> strong.

<b>11 </b>Assemble yourselves, and come, all ye heathen, and gather yourselves together round about: thither cause thy mighty ones to come down, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>12 </b>Let the heathen be wakened, and come up to the valley of Jehoshaphat: for there will I sit to judge all the heathen round about.

<b>13 </b>Put ye in the sickle, for the harvest is ripe: come, get you down; for the press is full, the fats overflow; for their wickedness <i>is</i> great.

<b>14 </b>Multitudes, multitudes in the valley of decision: for the day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> near in the valley of decision.

<b>15 </b>The sun and the moon shall be darkened, and the stars shall withdraw their shining.

<b>16 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> also shall roar out of Zion, and utter his voice from Jerusalem; and the heavens and the earth shall shake: but the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>will be</i> the hope of his people, and the strength of the children of Israel.

<b>17 </b>So shall ye know that I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God dwelling in Zion, my holy mountain: then shall Jerusalem be holy, and there shall no strangers pass through her any more.

<b>18 </b>¶ And it shall come to pass in that day, <i>that</i> the mountains shall drop down new wine, and the hills shall flow with milk, and all the rivers of Judah shall flow with waters, and a fountain shall come forth of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and shall water the valley of Shittim.

<b>19 </b>Egypt shall be a desolation, and Edom shall be a desolate wilderness, for the violence <i>against</i> the children of Judah, because they have shed innocent blood in their land.

<b>20 </b>But Judah shall dwell for ever, and Jerusalem from generation to generation.

<b>21 </b>For I will cleanse their blood <i>that</i> I have not cleansed: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> dwelleth in Zion.


--------------------

Amos

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>The words of Amos, who was among the herdmen of Tekoa, which he saw concerning Israel in the days of Uzziah king of Judah, and in the days of Jeroboam the son of Joash king of Israel, two years before the earthquake.

<b>2 </b>And he said, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will roar from Zion, and utter his voice from Jerusalem; and the habitations of the shepherds shall mourn, and the top of Carmel shall wither.

<b>3 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; For three transgressions of Damascus, and for four, I will not turn away <i>the punishment</i> thereof; because they have threshed Gilead with threshing instruments of iron:

<b>4 </b>But I will send a fire into the house of Hazael, which shall devour the palaces of Ben-hadad.

<b>5 </b>I will break also the bar of Damascus, and cut off the inhabitant from the plain of Aven, and him that holdeth the sceptre from the house of Eden: and the people of Syria shall go into captivity unto Kir, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>6 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; For three transgressions of Gaza, and for four, I will not turn away <i>the punishment</i> thereof; because they carried away captive the whole captivity, to deliver <i>them</i> up to Edom:

<b>7 </b>But I will send a fire on the wall of Gaza, which shall devour the palaces thereof:

<b>8 </b>And I will cut off the inhabitant from Ashdod, and him that holdeth the sceptre from Ashkelon, and I will turn mine hand against Ekron: and the remnant of the Philistines shall perish, saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>.

<b>9 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; For three transgressions of Tyrus, and for four, I will not turn away <i>the punishment</i> thereof; because they delivered up the whole captivity to Edom, and remembered not the brotherly covenant:

<b>10 </b>But I will send a fire on the wall of Tyrus, which shall devour the palaces thereof.

<b>11 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; For three transgressions of Edom, and for four, I will not turn away <i>the punishment</i> thereof; because he did pursue his brother with the sword, and did cast off all pity, and his anger did tear perpetually, and he kept his wrath for ever:

<b>12 </b>But I will send a fire upon Teman, which shall devour the palaces of Bozrah.

<b>13 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; For three transgressions of the children of Ammon, and for four, I will not turn away <i>the punishment</i> thereof; because they have ripped up the women with child of Gilead, that they might enlarge their border:

<b>14 </b>But I will kindle a fire in the wall of Rabbah, and it shall devour the palaces thereof, with shouting in the day of battle, with a tempest in the day of the whirlwind:

<b>15 </b>And their king shall go into captivity, he and his princes together, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; For three transgressions of Moab, and for four, I will not turn away <i>the punishment</i> thereof; because he burned the bones of the king of Edom into lime:

<b>2 </b>But I will send a fire upon Moab, and it shall devour the palaces of Kerioth: and Moab shall die with tumult, with shouting, <i>and</i> with the sound of the trumpet:

<b>3 </b>And I will cut off the judge from the midst thereof, and will slay all the princes thereof with him, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>4 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; For three transgressions of Judah, and for four, I will not turn away <i>the punishment</i> thereof; because they have despised the law of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and have not kept his commandments, and their lies caused them to err, after the which their fathers have walked:

<b>5 </b>But I will send a fire upon Judah, and it shall devour the palaces of Jerusalem.

<b>6 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; For three transgressions of Israel, and for four, I will not turn away <i>the punishment</i> thereof; because they sold the righteous for silver, and the poor for a pair of shoes;

<b>7 </b>That pant after the dust of the earth on the head of the poor, and turn aside the way of the meek: and a man and his father will go in unto the <i>same</i> maid, to profane my holy name:

<b>8 </b>And they lay <i>themselves</i> down upon clothes laid to pledge by every altar, and they drink the wine of the condemned <i>in</i> the house of their god.

<b>9 </b>¶ Yet destroyed I the Amorite before them, whose height <i>was</i> like the height of the cedars, and he <i>was</i> strong as the oaks; yet I destroyed his fruit from above, and his roots from beneath.

<b>10 </b>Also I brought you up from the land of Egypt, and led you forty years through the wilderness, to possess the land of the Amorite.

<b>11 </b>And I raised up of your sons for prophets, and of your young men for Nazarites. <i>Is it</i> not even thus, O ye children of Israel? saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>12 </b>But ye gave the Nazarites wine to drink; and commanded the prophets, saying, Prophesy not.

<b>13 </b>Behold, I am pressed under you, as a cart is pressed <i>that is</i> full of sheaves.

<b>14 </b>Therefore the flight shall perish from the swift, and the strong shall not strengthen his force, neither shall the mighty deliver himself:

<b>15 </b>Neither shall he stand that handleth the bow; and <i>he that is</i> swift of foot shall not deliver <i>himself:</i> neither shall he that rideth the horse deliver himself.

<b>16 </b>And <i>he that is</i> courageous among the mighty shall flee away naked in that day, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

CHAPTER 3

<b>1 </b>Hear this word that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath spoken against you, O children of Israel, against the whole family which I brought up from the land of Egypt, saying,

<b>2 </b>You only have I known of all the families of the earth: therefore I will punish you for all your iniquities.

<b>3 </b>Can two walk together, except they be agreed?

<b>4 </b>Will a lion roar in the forest, when he hath no prey? will a young lion cry out of his den, if he have taken nothing?

<b>5 </b>Can a bird fall in a snare upon the earth, where no gin <i>is</i> for him? shall <i>one</i> take up a snare from the earth, and have taken nothing at all?

<b>6 </b>Shall a trumpet be blown in the city, and the people not be afraid? shall there be evil in a city, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath not done <i>it?</i>

<b>7 </b>Surely the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> will do nothing, but he revealeth his secret unto his servants the prophets.

<b>8 </b>The lion hath roared, who will not fear? the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> hath spoken, who can but prophesy?

<b>9 </b>¶ Publish in the palaces at Ashdod, and in the palaces in the land of Egypt, and say, Assemble yourselves upon the mountains of Samaria, and behold the great tumults in the midst thereof, and the oppressed in the midst thereof.

<b>10 </b>For they know not to do right, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, who store up violence and robbery in their palaces.

<b>11 </b>Therefore thus saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>; An adversary <i>there shall be</i> even round about the land; and he shall bring down thy strength from thee, and thy palaces shall be spoiled.

<b>12 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; As the shepherd taketh out of the mouth of the lion two legs, or a piece of an ear; so shall the children of Israel be taken out that dwell in Samaria in the corner of a bed, and in Damascus <i>in</i> a couch.

<b>13 </b>Hear ye, and testify in the house of Jacob, saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>, the God of hosts,

<b>14 </b>That in the day that I shall visit the transgressions of Israel upon him I will also visit the altars of Beth-el: and the horns of the altar shall be cut off, and fall to the ground.

<b>15 </b>And I will smite the winter house with the summer house; and the houses of ivory shall perish, and the great houses shall have an end, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

CHAPTER 4

<b>1 </b>Hear this word, ye kine of Bashan, that <i>are</i> in the mountain of Samaria, which oppress the poor, which crush the needy, which say to their masters, Bring, and let us drink.

<b>2 </b>The Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> hath sworn by his holiness, that, lo, the days shall come upon you, that he will take you away with hooks, and your posterity with fishhooks.

<b>3 </b>And ye shall go out at the breaches, every <i>cow at that which is</i> before her; and ye shall cast <i>them</i> into the palace, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>4 </b>¶ Come to Beth-el, and transgress; at Gilgal multiply transgression; and bring your sacrifices every morning, <i>and</i> your tithes after three years:

<b>5 </b>And offer a sacrifice of thanksgiving with leaven, and proclaim <i>and</i> publish the free offerings: for this liketh you, O ye children of Israel, saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>.

<b>6 </b>¶ And I also have given you cleanness of teeth in all your cities, and want of bread in all your places: yet have ye not returned unto me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>7 </b>And also I have withholden the rain from you, when <i>there were</i> yet three months to the harvest: and I caused it to rain upon one city, and caused it not to rain upon another city: one piece was rained upon, and the piece whereupon it rained not withered.

<b>8 </b>So two <i>or</i> three cities wandered unto one city, to drink water; but they were not satisfied: yet have ye not returned unto me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>9 </b>I have smitten you with blasting and mildew: when your gardens and your vineyards and your fig trees and your olive trees increased, the palmerworm devoured <i>them:</i> yet have ye not returned unto me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>10 </b>I have sent among you the pestilence after the manner of Egypt: your young men have I slain with the sword, and have taken away your horses; and I have made the stink of your camps to come up unto your nostrils: yet have ye not returned unto me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>11 </b>I have overthrown <i>some</i> of you, as God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah, and ye were as a firebrand plucked out of the burning: yet have ye not returned unto me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>12 </b>Therefore thus will I do unto thee, O Israel: <i>and</i> because I will do this unto thee, prepare to meet thy God, O Israel.

<b>13 </b>For, lo, he that formeth the mountains, and createth the wind, and declareth unto man what <i>is</i> his thought, that maketh the morning darkness, and treadeth upon the high places of the earth, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, The God of hosts, <i>is</i> his name.


--------------------

CHAPTER 5

<b>1 </b>Hear ye this word which I take up against you, <i>even</i> a lamentation, O house of Israel.

<b>2 </b>The virgin of Israel is fallen; she shall no more rise: she is forsaken upon her land; <i>there is</i> none to raise her up.

<b>3 </b>For thus saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>; The city that went out <i>by</i> a thousand shall leave an hundred, and that which went forth <i>by</i> an hundred shall leave ten, to the house of Israel.

<b>4 </b>¶ For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto the house of Israel, Seek ye me, and ye shall live:

<b>5 </b>But seek not Beth-el, nor enter into Gilgal, and pass not to Beer-sheba: for Gilgal shall surely go into captivity, and Beth-el shall come to nought.

<b>6 </b>Seek the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and ye shall live; lest he break out like fire in the house of Joseph, and devour <i>it,</i> and <i>there be</i> none to quench <i>it</i> in Beth-el.

<b>7 </b>Ye who turn judgment to wormwood, and leave off righteousness in the earth,

<b>8 </b><i>Seek him</i> that maketh the seven stars and Orion, and turneth the shadow of death into the morning, and maketh the day dark with night: that calleth for the waters of the sea, and poureth them out upon the face of the earth: The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> his name:

<b>9 </b>That strengtheneth the spoiled against the strong, so that the spoiled shall come against the fortress.

<b>10 </b>They hate him that rebuketh in the gate, and they abhor him that speaketh uprightly.

<b>11 </b>Forasmuch therefore as your treading <i>is</i> upon the poor, and ye take from him burdens of wheat: ye have built houses of hewn stone, but ye shall not dwell in them; ye have planted pleasant vineyards, but ye shall not drink wine of them.

<b>12 </b>For I know your manifold transgressions and your mighty sins: they afflict the just, they take a bribe, and they turn aside the poor in the gate <i>from their right.</i>

<b>13 </b>Therefore the prudent shall keep silence in that time; for it <i>is</i> an evil time.

<b>14 </b>Seek good, and not evil, that ye may live: and so the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the God of hosts, shall be with you, as ye have spoken.

<b>15 </b>Hate the evil, and love the good, and establish judgment in the gate: it may be that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God of hosts will be gracious unto the remnant of Joseph.

<b>16 </b>Therefore the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the God of hosts, the Lord, saith thus; Wailing <i>shall be</i> in all streets; and they shall say in all the highways, Alas! alas! and they shall call the husbandman to mourning, and such as are skilful of lamentation to wailing.

<b>17 </b>And in all vineyards <i>shall be</i> wailing: for I will pass through thee, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>18 </b>Woe unto you that desire the day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>! to what end <i>is</i> it for you? the day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> darkness, and not light.

<b>19 </b>As if a man did flee from a lion, and a bear met him; or went into the house, and leaned his hand on the wall, and a serpent bit him.

<b>20 </b><i>Shall</i> not the day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>be</i> darkness, and not light? even very dark, and no brightness in it?

<b>21 </b>¶ I hate, I despise your feast days, and I will not smell in your solemn assemblies.

<b>22 </b>Though ye offer me burnt offerings and your meat offerings, I will not accept <i>them:</i> neither will I regard the peace offerings of your fat beasts.

<b>23 </b>Take thou away from me the noise of thy songs; for I will not hear the melody of thy viols.

<b>24 </b>But let judgment run down as waters, and righteousness as a mighty stream.

<b>25 </b>Have ye offered unto me sacrifices and offerings in the wilderness forty years, O house of Israel?

<b>26 </b>But ye have borne the tabernacle of your Moloch and Chiun your images, the star of your god, which ye made to yourselves.

<b>27 </b>Therefore will I cause you to go into captivity beyond Damascus, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, whose name <i>is</i> The God of hosts.


--------------------

CHAPTER 6

<b>1 </b>Woe to them <i>that are</i> at ease in Zion, and trust in the mountain of Samaria, <i>which are</i> named chief of the nations, to whom the house of Israel came!

<b>2 </b>Pass ye unto Calneh, and see; and from thence go ye to Hamath the great: then go down to Gath of the Philistines: <i>be they</i> better than these kingdoms? or their border greater than your border?

<b>3 </b>Ye that put far away the evil day, and cause the seat of violence to come near;

<b>4 </b>That lie upon beds of ivory, and stretch themselves upon their couches, and eat the lambs out of the flock, and the calves out of the midst of the stall;

<b>5 </b>That chant to the sound of the viol, <i>and</i> invent to themselves instruments of musick, like David;

<b>6 </b>That drink wine in bowls, and anoint themselves with the chief ointments: but they are not grieved for the affliction of Joseph.

<b>7 </b>¶ Therefore now shall they go captive with the first that go captive, and the banquet of them that stretched themselves shall be removed.

<b>8 </b>The Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> hath sworn by himself, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> the God of hosts, I abhor the excellency of Jacob, and hate his palaces: therefore will I deliver up the city with all that is therein.

<b>9 </b>And it shall come to pass, if there remain ten men in one house, that they shall die.

<b>10 </b>And a man’s uncle shall take him up, and he that burneth him, to bring out the bones out of the house, and shall say unto him that <i>is</i> by the sides of the house, <i>Is there</i> yet <i>any</i> with thee? and he shall say, No. Then shall he say, Hold thy tongue: for we may not make mention of the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>11 </b>For, behold, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> commandeth, and he will smite the great house with breaches, and the little house with clefts.

<b>12 </b>¶ Shall horses run upon the rock? will <i>one</i> plow <i>there</i> with oxen? for ye have turned judgment into gall, and the fruit of righteousness into hemlock:

<b>13 </b>Ye which rejoice in a thing of nought, which say, Have we not taken to us horns by our own strength?

<b>14 </b>But, behold, I will raise up against you a nation, O house of Israel, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> the God of hosts; and they shall afflict you from the entering in of Hemath unto the river of the wilderness.


--------------------

CHAPTER 7

<b>1 </b>Thus hath the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> shewed unto me; and, behold, he formed grasshoppers in the beginning of the shooting up of the latter growth; and, lo, <i>it was</i> the latter growth after the king’s mowings.

<b>2 </b>And it came to pass, <i>that</i> when they had made an end of eating the grass of the land, then I said, O Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>, forgive, I beseech thee: by whom shall Jacob arise? for he <i>is</i> small.

<b>3 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> repented for this: It shall not be, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>4 </b>¶ Thus hath the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> shewed unto me: and, behold, the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> called to contend by fire, and it devoured the great deep, and did eat up a part.

<b>5 </b>Then said I, O Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>, cease, I beseech thee: by whom shall Jacob arise? for he <i>is</i> small.

<b>6 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> repented for this: This also shall not be, saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>.

<b>7 </b>¶ Thus he shewed me: and, behold, the Lord stood upon a wall <i>made</i> by a plumbline, with a plumbline in his hand.

<b>8 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, Amos, what seest thou? And I said, A plumbline. Then said the Lord, Behold, I will set a plumbline in the midst of my people Israel: I will not again pass by them any more:

<b>9 </b>And the high places of Isaac shall be desolate, and the sanctuaries of Israel shall be laid waste; and I will rise against the house of Jeroboam with the sword.

<b>10 </b>¶ Then Amaziah the priest of Beth-el sent to Jeroboam king of Israel, saying, Amos hath conspired against thee in the midst of the house of Israel: the land is not able to bear all his words.

<b>11 </b>For thus Amos saith, Jeroboam shall die by the sword, and Israel shall surely be led away captive out of their own land.

<b>12 </b>Also Amaziah said unto Amos, O thou seer, go, flee thee away into the land of Judah, and there eat bread, and prophesy there:

<b>13 </b>But prophesy not again any more at Beth-el: for it <i>is</i> the king’s chapel, and it <i>is</i> the king’s court.

<b>14 </b>¶ Then answered Amos, and said to Amaziah, I <i>was</i> no prophet, neither <i>was</i> I a prophet’s son; but I <i>was</i> an herdman, and a gatherer of sycomore fruit:

<b>15 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> took me as I followed the flock, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, Go, prophesy unto my people Israel.

<b>16 </b>¶ Now therefore hear thou the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: Thou sayest, Prophesy not against Israel, and drop not <i>thy word</i> against the house of Isaac.

<b>17 </b>Therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; Thy wife shall be an harlot in the city, and thy sons and thy daughters shall fall by the sword, and thy land shall be divided by line; and thou shalt die in a polluted land: and Israel shall surely go into captivity forth of his land.


--------------------

CHAPTER 8

<b>1 </b>Thus hath the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> shewed unto me: and behold a basket of summer fruit.

<b>2 </b>And he said, Amos, what seest thou? And I said, A basket of summer fruit. Then said the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto me, The end is come upon my people of Israel; I will not again pass by them any more.

<b>3 </b>And the songs of the temple shall be howlings in that day, saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>: <i>there shall be</i> many dead bodies in every place; they shall cast <i>them</i> forth with silence.

<b>4 </b>¶ Hear this, O ye that swallow up the needy, even to make the poor of the land to fail,

<b>5 </b>Saying, When will the new moon be gone, that we may sell corn? and the sabbath, that we may set forth wheat, making the ephah small, and the shekel great, and falsifying the balances by deceit?

<b>6 </b>That we may buy the poor for silver, and the needy for a pair of shoes; <i>yea,</i> and sell the refuse of the wheat?

<b>7 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath sworn by the excellency of Jacob, Surely I will never forget any of their works.

<b>8 </b>Shall not the land tremble for this, and every one mourn that dwelleth therein? and it shall rise up wholly as a flood; and it shall be cast out and drowned, as <i>by</i> the flood of Egypt.

<b>9 </b>And it shall come to pass in that day, saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>, that I will cause the sun to go down at noon, and I will darken the earth in the clear day:

<b>10 </b>And I will turn your feasts into mourning, and all your songs into lamentation; and I will bring up sackcloth upon all loins, and baldness upon every head; and I will make it as the mourning of an only <i>son,</i> and the end thereof as a bitter day.

<b>11 </b>¶ Behold, the days come, saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>, that I will send a famine in the land, not a famine of bread, nor a thirst for water, but of hearing the words of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>:

<b>12 </b>And they shall wander from sea to sea, and from the north even to the east, they shall run to and fro to seek the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and shall not find <i>it.</i>

<b>13 </b>In that day shall the fair virgins and young men faint for thirst.

<b>14 </b>They that swear by the sin of Samaria, and say, Thy god, O Dan, liveth; and, The manner of Beer-sheba liveth; even they shall fall, and never rise up again.


--------------------

CHAPTER 9

<b>1 </b>I saw the Lord standing upon the altar: and he said, Smite the lintel of the door, that the posts may shake: and cut them in the head, all of them; and I will slay the last of them with the sword: he that fleeth of them shall not flee away, and he that escapeth of them shall not be delivered.

<b>2 </b>Though they dig into hell, thence shall mine hand take them; though they climb up to heaven, thence will I bring them down:

<b>3 </b>And though they hide themselves in the top of Carmel, I will search and take them out thence; and though they be hid from my sight in the bottom of the sea, thence will I command the serpent, and he shall bite them:

<b>4 </b>And though they go into captivity before their enemies, thence will I command the sword, and it shall slay them: and I will set mine eyes upon them for evil, and not for good.

<b>5 </b>And the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> of hosts <i>is</i> he that toucheth the land, and it shall melt, and all that dwell therein shall mourn: and it shall rise up wholly like a flood; and shall be drowned, as <i>by</i> the flood of Egypt.

<b>6 </b><i>It is</i> he that buildeth his stories in the heaven, and hath founded his troop in the earth; he that calleth for the waters of the sea, and poureth them out upon the face of the earth: The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> his name.

<b>7 </b><i>Are</i> ye not as children of the Ethiopians unto me, O children of Israel? saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. Have not I brought up Israel out of the land of Egypt? and the Philistines from Caphtor, and the Syrians from Kir?

<b>8 </b>Behold, the eyes of the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> <i>are</i> upon the sinful kingdom, and I will destroy it from off the face of the earth; saving that I will not utterly destroy the house of Jacob, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>9 </b>For, lo, I will command, and I will sift the house of Israel among all nations, like as <i>corn</i> is sifted in a sieve, yet shall not the least grain fall upon the earth.

<b>10 </b>All the sinners of my people shall die by the sword, which say, The evil shall not overtake nor prevent us.

<b>11 </b>¶ In that day will I raise up the tabernacle of David that is fallen, and close up the breaches thereof; and I will raise up his ruins, and I will build it as in the days of old:

<b>12 </b>That they may possess the remnant of Edom, and of all the heathen, which are called by my name, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that doeth this.

<b>13 </b>Behold, the days come, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that the plowman shall overtake the reaper, and the treader of grapes him that soweth seed; and the mountains shall drop sweet wine, and all the hills shall melt.

<b>14 </b>And I will bring again the captivity of my people of Israel, and they shall build the waste cities, and inhabit <i>them;</i> and they shall plant vineyards, and drink the wine thereof; they shall also make gardens, and eat the fruit of them.

<b>15 </b>And I will plant them upon their land, and they shall no more be pulled up out of their land which I have given them, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God.


--------------------

Obadiah

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>The vision of Obadiah. Thus saith the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> concerning Edom; We have heard a rumour from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and an ambassador is sent among the heathen, Arise ye, and let us rise up against her in battle.

<b>2 </b>Behold, I have made thee small among the heathen: thou art greatly despised.

<b>3 </b>¶ The pride of thine heart hath deceived thee, thou that dwellest in the clefts of the rock, whose habitation <i>is</i> high; that saith in his heart, Who shall bring me down to the ground?

<b>4 </b>Though thou exalt <i>thyself</i> as the eagle, and though thou set thy nest among the stars, thence will I bring thee down, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>5 </b>If thieves came to thee, if robbers by night, (how art thou cut off!) would they not have stolen till they had enough? if the grapegatherers came to thee, would they not leave <i>some</i> grapes?

<b>6 </b>How are <i>the things</i> of Esau searched out! <i>how</i> are his hidden things sought up!

<b>7 </b>All the men of thy confederacy have brought thee <i>even</i> to the border: the men that were at peace with thee have deceived thee, <i>and</i> prevailed against thee; <i>they that eat</i> thy bread have laid a wound under thee: <i>there is</i> none understanding in him.

<b>8 </b>Shall I not in that day, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, even destroy the wise <i>men</i> out of Edom, and understanding out of the mount of Esau?

<b>9 </b>And thy mighty <i>men,</i> O Teman, shall be dismayed, to the end that every one of the mount of Esau may be cut off by slaughter.

<b>10 </b>¶ For <i>thy</i> violence against thy brother Jacob shame shall cover thee, and thou shalt be cut off for ever.

<b>11 </b>In the day that thou stoodest on the other side, in the day that the strangers carried away captive his forces, and foreigners entered into his gates, and cast lots upon Jerusalem, even thou <i>wast</i> as one of them.

<b>12 </b>But thou shouldest not have looked on the day of thy brother in the day that he became a stranger; neither shouldest thou have rejoiced over the children of Judah in the day of their destruction; neither shouldest thou have spoken proudly in the day of distress.

<b>13 </b>Thou shouldest not have entered into the gate of my people in the day of their calamity; yea, thou shouldest not have looked on their affliction in the day of their calamity, nor have laid <i>hands</i> on their substance in the day of their calamity;

<b>14 </b>Neither shouldest thou have stood in the crossway, to cut off those of his that did escape; neither shouldest thou have delivered up those of his that did remain in the day of distress.

<b>15 </b>For the day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> near upon all the heathen: as thou hast done, it shall be done unto thee: thy reward shall return upon thine own head.

<b>16 </b>For as ye have drunk upon my holy mountain, <i>so</i> shall all the heathen drink continually, yea, they shall drink, and they shall swallow down, and they shall be as though they had not been.

<b>17 </b>¶ But upon mount Zion shall be deliverance, and there shall be holiness; and the house of Jacob shall possess their possessions.

<b>18 </b>And the house of Jacob shall be a fire, and the house of Joseph a flame, and the house of Esau for stubble, and they shall kindle in them, and devour them; and there shall not be <i>any</i> remaining of the house of Esau; for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath spoken <i>it.</i>

<b>19 </b>And <i>they of</i> the south shall possess the mount of Esau; and <i>they of</i> the plain the Philistines: and they shall possess the fields of Ephraim, and the fields of Samaria: and Benjamin <i>shall possess</i> Gilead.

<b>20 </b>And the captivity of this host of the children of Israel <i>shall possess</i> that of the Canaanites, <i>even</i> unto Zarephath; and the captivity of Jerusalem, which <i>is</i> in Sepharad, shall possess the cities of the south.

<b>21 </b>And saviours shall come up on mount Zion to judge the mount of Esau; and the kingdom shall be the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s.


--------------------

Jonah

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>Now the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto Jonah the son of Amittai, saying,

<b>2 </b>Arise, go to Nineveh, that great city, and cry against it; for their wickedness is come up before me.

<b>3 </b>But Jonah rose up to flee unto Tarshish from the presence of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and went down to Joppa; and he found a ship going to Tarshish: so he paid the fare thereof, and went down into it, to go with them unto Tarshish from the presence of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>4 </b>¶ But the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> sent out a great wind into the sea, and there was a mighty tempest in the sea, so that the ship was like to be broken.

<b>5 </b>Then the mariners were afraid, and cried every man unto his god, and cast forth the wares that <i>were</i> in the ship into the sea, to lighten <i>it</i> of them. But Jonah was gone down into the sides of the ship; and he lay, and was fast asleep.

<b>6 </b>So the shipmaster came to him, and said unto him, What meanest thou, O sleeper? arise, call upon thy God, if so be that God will think upon us, that we perish not.

<b>7 </b>And they said every one to his fellow, Come, and let us cast lots, that we may know for whose cause this evil <i>is</i> upon us. So they cast lots, and the lot fell upon Jonah.

<b>8 </b>Then said they unto him, Tell us, we pray thee, for whose cause this evil <i>is</i> upon us; What <i>is</i> thine occupation? and whence comest thou? what <i>is</i> thy country? and of what people <i>art</i> thou?

<b>9 </b>And he said unto them, I <i>am</i> an Hebrew; and I fear the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, the God of heaven, which hath made the sea and the dry <i>land.</i>

<b>10 </b>Then were the men exceedingly afraid, and said unto him, Why hast thou done this? For the men knew that he fled from the presence of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, because he had told them.

<b>11 </b>¶ Then said they unto him, What shall we do unto thee, that the sea may be calm unto us? for the sea wrought, and was tempestuous.

<b>12 </b>And he said unto them, Take me up, and cast me forth into the sea; so shall the sea be calm unto you: for I know that for my sake this great tempest <i>is</i> upon you.

<b>13 </b>Nevertheless the men rowed hard to bring <i>it</i> to the land; but they could not: for the sea wrought, and was tempestuous against them.

<b>14 </b>Wherefore they cried unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and said, We beseech thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, we beseech thee, let us not perish for this man’s life, and lay not upon us innocent blood: for thou, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, hast done as it pleased thee.

<b>15 </b>So they took up Jonah, and cast him forth into the sea: and the sea ceased from her raging.

<b>16 </b>Then the men feared the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> exceedingly, and offered a sacrifice unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and made vows.

<b>17 </b>¶ Now the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> had prepared a great fish to swallow up Jonah. And Jonah was in the belly of the fish three days and three nights.


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>Then Jonah prayed unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his God out of the fish’s belly,

<b>2 </b>And said, I cried by reason of mine affliction unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and he heard me; out of the belly of hell cried I, <i>and</i> thou heardest my voice.

<b>3 </b>For thou hadst cast me into the deep, in the midst of the seas; and the floods compassed me about: all thy billows and thy waves passed over me.

<b>4 </b>Then I said, I am cast out of thy sight; yet I will look again toward thy holy temple.

<b>5 </b>The waters compassed me about, <i>even</i> to the soul: the depth closed me round about, the weeds were wrapped about my head.

<b>6 </b>I went down to the bottoms of the mountains; the earth with her bars <i>was</i> about me for ever: yet hast thou brought up my life from corruption, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God.

<b>7 </b>When my soul fainted within me I remembered the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and my prayer came in unto thee, into thine holy temple.

<b>8 </b>They that observe lying vanities forsake their own mercy.

<b>9 </b>But I will sacrifice unto thee with the voice of thanksgiving; I will pay <i>that</i> that I have vowed. Salvation <i>is</i> of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>10 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> spake unto the fish, and it vomited out Jonah upon the dry <i>land.</i>


--------------------

CHAPTER 3

<b>1 </b>And the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto Jonah the second time, saying,

<b>2 </b>Arise, go unto Nineveh, that great city, and preach unto it the preaching that I bid thee.

<b>3 </b>So Jonah arose, and went unto Nineveh, according to the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>. Now Nineveh was an exceeding great city of three days’ journey.

<b>4 </b>And Jonah began to enter into the city a day’s journey, and he cried, and said, Yet forty days, and Nineveh shall be overthrown.

<b>5 </b>¶ So the people of Nineveh believed God, and proclaimed a fast, and put on sackcloth, from the greatest of them even to the least of them.

<b>6 </b>For word came unto the king of Nineveh, and he arose from his throne, and he laid his robe from him, and covered <i>him</i> with sackcloth, and sat in ashes.

<b>7 </b>And he caused <i>it</i> to be proclaimed and published through Nineveh by the decree of the king and his nobles, saying, Let neither man nor beast, herd nor flock, taste any thing: let them not feed, nor drink water:

<b>8 </b>But let man and beast be covered with sackcloth, and cry mightily unto God: yea, let them turn every one from his evil way, and from the violence that <i>is</i> in their hands.

<b>9 </b>Who can tell <i>if</i> God will turn and repent, and turn away from his fierce anger, that we perish not?

<b>10 </b>¶ And God saw their works, that they turned from their evil way; and God repented of the evil, that he had said that he would do unto them; and he did <i>it</i> not.


--------------------

CHAPTER 4

<b>1 </b>But it displeased Jonah exceedingly, and he was very angry.

<b>2 </b>And he prayed unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and said, I pray thee, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>was</i> not this my saying, when I was yet in my country? Therefore I fled before unto Tarshish: for I knew that thou <i>art</i> a gracious God, and merciful, slow to anger, and of great kindness, and repentest thee of the evil.

<b>3 </b>Therefore now, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, take, I beseech thee, my life from me; for <i>it is</i> better for me to die than to live.

<b>4 </b>¶ Then said the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Doest thou well to be angry?

<b>5 </b>So Jonah went out of the city, and sat on the east side of the city, and there made him a booth, and sat under it in the shadow, till he might see what would become of the city.

<b>6 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God prepared a gourd, and made <i>it</i> to come up over Jonah, that it might be a shadow over his head, to deliver him from his grief. So Jonah was exceeding glad of the gourd.

<b>7 </b>But God prepared a worm when the morning rose the next day, and it smote the gourd that it withered.

<b>8 </b>And it came to pass, when the sun did arise, that God prepared a vehement east wind; and the sun beat upon the head of Jonah, that he fainted, and wished in himself to die, and said, <i>It is</i> better for me to die than to live.

<b>9 </b>And God said to Jonah, Doest thou well to be angry for the gourd? And he said, I do well to be angry, <i>even</i> unto death.

<b>10 </b>Then said the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, Thou hast had pity on the gourd, for the which thou hast not laboured, neither madest it grow; which came up in a night, and perished in a night:

<b>11 </b>And should not I spare Nineveh, that great city, wherein are more than sixscore thousand persons that cannot discern between their right hand and their left hand; and <i>also</i> much cattle?


--------------------

Micah

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>The word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that came to Micah the Morasthite in the days of Jotham, Ahaz, <i>and</i> Hezekiah, kings of Judah, which he saw concerning Samaria and Jerusalem.

<b>2 </b>Hear, all ye people; hearken, O earth, and all that therein is: and let the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> be witness against you, the Lord from his holy temple.

<b>3 </b>For, behold, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> cometh forth out of his place, and will come down, and tread upon the high places of the earth.

<b>4 </b>And the mountains shall be molten under him, and the valleys shall be cleft, as wax before the fire, <i>and</i> as the waters <i>that are</i> poured down a steep place.

<b>5 </b>For the transgression of Jacob <i>is</i> all this, and for the sins of the house of Israel. What <i>is</i> the transgression of Jacob? <i>is it</i> not Samaria? and what <i>are</i> the high places of Judah? <i>are they</i> not Jerusalem?

<b>6 </b>Therefore I will make Samaria as an heap of the field, <i>and</i> as plantings of a vineyard: and I will pour down the stones thereof into the valley, and I will discover the foundations thereof.

<b>7 </b>And all the graven images thereof shall be beaten to pieces, and all the hires thereof shall be burned with the fire, and all the idols thereof will I lay desolate: for she gathered <i>it</i> of the hire of an harlot, and they shall return to the hire of an harlot.

<b>8 </b>Therefore I will wail and howl, I will go stripped and naked: I will make a wailing like the dragons, and mourning as the owls.

<b>9 </b>For her wound <i>is</i> incurable; for it is come unto Judah; he is come unto the gate of my people, <i>even</i> to Jerusalem.

<b>10 </b>¶ Declare ye <i>it</i> not at Gath, weep ye not at all: in the house of Aphrah roll thyself in the dust.

<b>11 </b>Pass ye away, thou inhabitant of Saphir, having thy shame naked: the inhabitant of Zaanan came not forth in the mourning of Beth-ezel; he shall receive of you his standing.

<b>12 </b>For the inhabitant of Maroth waited carefully for good: but evil came down from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto the gate of Jerusalem.

<b>13 </b>O thou inhabitant of Lachish, bind the chariot to the swift beast: she <i>is</i> the beginning of the sin to the daughter of Zion: for the transgressions of Israel were found in thee.

<b>14 </b>Therefore shalt thou give presents to Moresheth-gath: the houses of Achzib <i>shall be</i> a lie to the kings of Israel.

<b>15 </b>Yet will I bring an heir unto thee, O inhabitant of Mareshah: he shall come unto Adullam the glory of Israel.

<b>16 </b>Make thee bald, and poll thee for thy delicate children; enlarge thy baldness as the eagle; for they are gone into captivity from thee.


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>Woe to them that devise iniquity, and work evil upon their beds! when the morning is light, they practise it, because it is in the power of their hand.

<b>2 </b>And they covet fields, and take <i>them</i> by violence; and houses, and take <i>them</i> away: so they oppress a man and his house, even a man and his heritage.

<b>3 </b>Therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; Behold, against this family do I devise an evil, from which ye shall not remove your necks; neither shall ye go haughtily: for this time <i>is</i> evil.

<b>4 </b>¶ In that day shall <i>one</i> take up a parable against you, and lament with a doleful lamentation, <i>and</i> say, We be utterly spoiled: he hath changed the portion of my people: how hath he removed <i>it</i> from me! turning away he hath divided our fields.

<b>5 </b>Therefore thou shalt have none that shall cast a cord by lot in the congregation of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>6 </b>Prophesy ye not, <i>say they to them that</i> prophesy: they shall not prophesy to them, <i>that</i> they shall not take shame.

<b>7 </b>¶ O <i>thou that art</i> named the house of Jacob, is the spirit of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> straitened? <i>are</i> these his doings? do not my words do good to him that walketh uprightly?

<b>8 </b>Even of late my people is risen up as an enemy: ye pull off the robe with the garment from them that pass by securely as men averse from war.

<b>9 </b>The women of my people have ye cast out from their pleasant houses; from their children have ye taken away my glory for ever.

<b>10 </b>Arise ye, and depart; for this <i>is</i> not <i>your</i> rest: because it is polluted, it shall destroy <i>you,</i> even with a sore destruction.

<b>11 </b>If a man walking in the spirit and falsehood do lie, <i>saying,</i> I will prophesy unto thee of wine and of strong drink; he shall even be the prophet of this people.

<b>12 </b>¶ I will surely assemble, O Jacob, all of thee; I will surely gather the remnant of Israel; I will put them together as the sheep of Bozrah, as the flock in the midst of their fold: they shall make great noise by reason of <i>the multitude of</i> men.

<b>13 </b>The breaker is come up before them: they have broken up, and have passed through the gate, and are gone out by it: and their king shall pass before them, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> on the head of them.


--------------------

CHAPTER 3

<b>1 </b>And I said, Hear, I pray you, O heads of Jacob, and ye princes of the house of Israel; <i>Is it</i> not for you to know judgment?

<b>2 </b>Who hate the good, and love the evil; who pluck off their skin from off them, and their flesh from off their bones;

<b>3 </b>Who also eat the flesh of my people, and flay their skin from off them; and they break their bones, and chop them in pieces, as for the pot, and as flesh within the caldron.

<b>4 </b>Then shall they cry unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, but he will not hear them: he will even hide his face from them at that time, as they have behaved themselves ill in their doings.

<b>5 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> concerning the prophets that make my people err, that bite with their teeth, and cry, Peace; and he that putteth not into their mouths, they even prepare war against him.

<b>6 </b>Therefore night <i>shall be</i> unto you, that ye shall not have a vision; and it shall be dark unto you, that ye shall not divine; and the sun shall go down over the prophets, and the day shall be dark over them.

<b>7 </b>Then shall the seers be ashamed, and the diviners confounded: yea, they shall all cover their lips; for <i>there is</i> no answer of God.

<b>8 </b>¶ But truly I am full of power by the spirit of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and of judgment, and of might, to declare unto Jacob his transgression, and to Israel his sin.

<b>9 </b>Hear this, I pray you, ye heads of the house of Jacob, and princes of the house of Israel, that abhor judgment, and pervert all equity.

<b>10 </b>They build up Zion with blood, and Jerusalem with iniquity.
