<b>11 </b>The heads thereof judge for reward, and the priests thereof teach for hire, and the prophets thereof divine for money: yet will they lean upon the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and say, <i>Is</i> not the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> among us? none evil can come upon us.

<b>12 </b>Therefore shall Zion for your sake be plowed <i>as</i> a field, and Jerusalem shall become heaps, and the mountain of the house as the high places of the forest.


--------------------

CHAPTER 4

<b>1 </b>But in the last days it shall come to pass, <i>that</i> the mountain of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall be established in the top of the mountains, and it shall be exalted above the hills; and people shall flow unto it.

<b>2 </b>And many nations shall come, and say, Come, and let us go up to the mountain of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and to the house of the God of Jacob; and he will teach us of his ways, and we will walk in his paths: for the law shall go forth of Zion, and the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> from Jerusalem.

<b>3 </b>¶ And he shall judge among many people, and rebuke strong nations afar off; and they shall beat their swords into plowshares, and their spears into pruninghooks: nation shall not lift up a sword against nation, neither shall they learn war any more.

<b>4 </b>But they shall sit every man under his vine and under his fig tree; and none shall make <i>them</i> afraid: for the mouth of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts hath spoken <i>it.</i>

<b>5 </b>For all people will walk every one in the name of his god, and we will walk in the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God for ever and ever.

<b>6 </b>In that day, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, will I assemble her that halteth, and I will gather her that is driven out, and her that I have afflicted;

<b>7 </b>And I will make her that halted a remnant, and her that was cast far off a strong nation: and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall reign over them in mount Zion from henceforth, even for ever.

<b>8 </b>¶ And thou, O tower of the flock, the strong hold of the daughter of Zion, unto thee shall it come, even the first dominion; the kingdom shall come to the daughter of Jerusalem.

<b>9 </b>Now why dost thou cry out aloud? <i>is there</i> no king in thee? is thy counsellor perished? for pangs have taken thee as a woman in travail.

<b>10 </b>Be in pain, and labour to bring forth, O daughter of Zion, like a woman in travail: for now shalt thou go forth out of the city, and thou shalt dwell in the field, and thou shalt go <i>even</i> to Babylon; there shalt thou be delivered; there the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall redeem thee from the hand of thine enemies.

<b>11 </b>¶ Now also many nations are gathered against thee, that say, Let her be defiled, and let our eye look upon Zion.

<b>12 </b>But they know not the thoughts of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, neither understand they his counsel: for he shall gather them as the sheaves into the floor.

<b>13 </b>Arise and thresh, O daughter of Zion: for I will make thine horn iron, and I will make thy hoofs brass: and thou shalt beat in pieces many people: and I will consecrate their gain unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and their substance unto the Lord of the whole earth.


--------------------

CHAPTER 5

<b>1 </b>Now gather thyself in troops, O daughter of troops: he hath laid siege against us: they shall smite the judge of Israel with a rod upon the cheek.

<b>2 </b>But thou, Beth-lehem Ephratah, <i>though</i> thou be little among the thousands of Judah, <i>yet</i> out of thee shall he come forth unto me <i>that is</i> to be ruler in Israel; whose goings forth <i>have been</i> from of old, from everlasting.

<b>3 </b>Therefore will he give them up, until the time <i>that</i> she which travaileth hath brought forth: then the remnant of his brethren shall return unto the children of Israel.

<b>4 </b>¶ And he shall stand and feed in the strength of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, in the majesty of the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> his God; and they shall abide: for now shall he be great unto the ends of the earth.

<b>5 </b>And this <i>man</i> shall be the peace, when the Assyrian shall come into our land: and when he shall tread in our palaces, then shall we raise against him seven shepherds, and eight principal men.

<b>6 </b>And they shall waste the land of Assyria with the sword, and the land of Nimrod in the entrances thereof: thus shall he deliver <i>us</i> from the Assyrian, when he cometh into our land, and when he treadeth within our borders.

<b>7 </b>And the remnant of Jacob shall be in the midst of many people as a dew from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, as the showers upon the grass, that tarrieth not for man, nor waiteth for the sons of men.

<b>8 </b>¶ And the remnant of Jacob shall be among the Gentiles in the midst of many people as a lion among the beasts of the forest, as a young lion among the flocks of sheep: who, if he go through, both treadeth down, and teareth in pieces, and none can deliver.

<b>9 </b>Thine hand shall be lifted up upon thine adversaries, and all thine enemies shall be cut off.

<b>10 </b>And it shall come to pass in that day, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, that I will cut off thy horses out of the midst of thee, and I will destroy thy chariots:

<b>11 </b>And I will cut off the cities of thy land, and throw down all thy strong holds:

<b>12 </b>And I will cut off witchcrafts out of thine hand; and thou shalt have no <i>more</i> soothsayers:

<b>13 </b>Thy graven images also will I cut off, and thy standing images out of the midst of thee; and thou shalt no more worship the work of thine hands.

<b>14 </b>And I will pluck up thy groves out of the midst of thee: so will I destroy thy cities.

<b>15 </b>And I will execute vengeance in anger and fury upon the heathen, such as they have not heard.


--------------------

CHAPTER 6

<b>1 </b>Hear ye now what the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> saith; Arise, contend thou before the mountains, and let the hills hear thy voice.

<b>2 </b>Hear ye, O mountains, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s controversy, and ye strong foundations of the earth: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath a controversy with his people, and he will plead with Israel.

<b>3 </b>O my people, what have I done unto thee? and wherein have I wearied thee? testify against me.

<b>4 </b>For I brought thee up out of the land of Egypt, and redeemed thee out of the house of servants; and I sent before thee Moses, Aaron, and Miriam.

<b>5 </b>O my people, remember now what Balak king of Moab consulted, and what Balaam the son of Beor answered him from Shittim unto Gilgal; that ye may know the righteousness of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>6 </b>¶ Wherewith shall I come before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>and</i> bow myself before the high God? shall I come before him with burnt offerings, with calves of a year old?

<b>7 </b>Will the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> be pleased with thousands of rams, <i>or</i> with ten thousands of rivers of oil? shall I give my firstborn <i>for</i> my transgression, the fruit of my body <i>for</i> the sin of my soul?

<b>8 </b>He hath shewed thee, O man, what <i>is</i> good; and what doth the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> require of thee, but to do justly, and to love mercy, and to walk humbly with thy God?

<b>9 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s voice crieth unto the city, and <i>the man of</i> wisdom shall see thy name: hear ye the rod, and who hath appointed it.

<b>10 </b>¶ Are there yet the treasures of wickedness in the house of the wicked, and the scant measure <i>that is</i> abominable?

<b>11 </b>Shall I count <i>them</i> pure with the wicked balances, and with the bag of deceitful weights?

<b>12 </b>For the rich men thereof are full of violence, and the inhabitants thereof have spoken lies, and their tongue <i>is</i> deceitful in their mouth.

<b>13 </b>Therefore also will I make <i>thee</i> sick in smiting thee, in making <i>thee</i> desolate because of thy sins.

<b>14 </b>Thou shalt eat, but not be satisfied; and thy casting down <i>shall be</i> in the midst of thee; and thou shalt take hold, but shalt not deliver; and <i>that</i> which thou deliverest will I give up to the sword.

<b>15 </b>Thou shalt sow, but thou shalt not reap; thou shalt tread the olives, but thou shalt not anoint thee with oil; and sweet wine, but shalt not drink wine.

<b>16 </b>¶ For the statutes of Omri are kept, and all the works of the house of Ahab, and ye walk in their counsels; that I should make thee a desolation, and the inhabitants thereof an hissing: therefore ye shall bear the reproach of my people.


--------------------

CHAPTER 7

<b>1 </b>Woe is me! for I am as when they have gathered the summer fruits, as the grapegleanings of the vintage: <i>there is</i> no cluster to eat: my soul desired the firstripe fruit.

<b>2 </b>The good <i>man</i> is perished out of the earth: and <i>there is</i> none upright among men: they all lie in wait for blood; they hunt every man his brother with a net.

<b>3 </b>¶ That they may do evil with both hands earnestly, the prince asketh, and the judge <i>asketh</i> for a reward; and the great <i>man,</i> he uttereth his mischievous desire: so they wrap it up.

<b>4 </b>The best of them <i>is</i> as a brier: the most upright <i>is sharper</i> than a thorn hedge: the day of thy watchmen <i>and</i> thy visitation cometh; now shall be their perplexity.

<b>5 </b>¶ Trust ye not in a friend, put ye not confidence in a guide: keep the doors of thy mouth from her that lieth in thy bosom.

<b>6 </b>For the son dishonoureth the father, the daughter riseth up against her mother, the daughter in law against her mother in law; a man’s enemies <i>are</i> the men of his own house.

<b>7 </b>Therefore I will look unto the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; I will wait for the God of my salvation: my God will hear me.

<b>8 </b>¶ Rejoice not against me, O mine enemy: when I fall, I shall arise; when I sit in darkness, the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>shall be</i> a light unto me.

<b>9 </b>I will bear the indignation of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, because I have sinned against him, until he plead my cause, and execute judgment for me: he will bring me forth to the light, <i>and</i> I shall behold his righteousness.

<b>10 </b>Then <i>she that is</i> mine enemy shall see <i>it,</i> and shame shall cover her which said unto me, Where is the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God? mine eyes shall behold her: now shall she be trodden down as the mire of the streets.

<b>11 </b><i>In</i> the day that thy walls are to be built, <i>in</i> that day shall the decree be far removed.

<b>12 </b><i>In</i> that day <i>also</i> he shall come even to thee from Assyria, and <i>from</i> the fortified cities, and from the fortress even to the river, and from sea to sea, and <i>from</i> mountain to mountain.

<b>13 </b>Notwithstanding the land shall be desolate because of them that dwell therein, for the fruit of their doings.

<b>14 </b>¶ Feed thy people with thy rod, the flock of thine heritage, which dwell solitarily <i>in</i> the wood, in the midst of Carmel: let them feed <i>in</i> Bashan and Gilead, as in the days of old.

<b>15 </b>According to the days of thy coming out of the land of Egypt will I shew unto him marvellous <i>things.</i>

<b>16 </b>¶ The nations shall see and be confounded at all their might: they shall lay <i>their</i> hand upon <i>their</i> mouth, their ears shall be deaf.

<b>17 </b>They shall lick the dust like a serpent, they shall move out of their holes like worms of the earth: they shall be afraid of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> our God, and shall fear because of thee.

<b>18 </b>Who <i>is</i> a God like unto thee, that pardoneth iniquity, and passeth by the transgression of the remnant of his heritage? he retaineth not his anger for ever, because he delighteth <i>in</i> mercy.

<b>19 </b>He will turn again, he will have compassion upon us; he will subdue our iniquities; and thou wilt cast all their sins into the depths of the sea.

<b>20 </b>Thou wilt perform the truth to Jacob, <i>and</i> the mercy to Abraham, which thou hast sworn unto our fathers from the days of old.


--------------------

Nahum

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>The burden of Nineveh. The book of the vision of Nahum the Elkoshite.

<b>2 </b>God <i>is</i> jealous, and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> revengeth; the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> revengeth, and <i>is</i> furious; the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will take vengeance on his adversaries, and he reserveth <i>wrath</i> for his enemies.

<b>3 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> slow to anger, and great in power, and will not at all acquit <i>the wicked:</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>hath</i> his way in the whirlwind and in the storm, and the clouds <i>are</i> the dust of his feet.

<b>4 </b>He rebuketh the sea, and maketh it dry, and drieth up all the rivers: Bashan languisheth, and Carmel, and the flower of Lebanon languisheth.

<b>5 </b>The mountains quake at him, and the hills melt, and the earth is burned at his presence, yea, the world, and all that dwell therein.

<b>6 </b>Who can stand before his indignation? and who can abide in the fierceness of his anger? his fury is poured out like fire, and the rocks are thrown down by him.

<b>7 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> good, a strong hold in the day of trouble; and he knoweth them that trust in him.

<b>8 </b>But with an overrunning flood he will make an utter end of the place thereof, and darkness shall pursue his enemies.

<b>9 </b>What do ye imagine against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>? he will make an utter end: affliction shall not rise up the second time.

<b>10 </b>For while <i>they be</i> folden together <i>as</i> thorns, and while they are drunken <i>as</i> drunkards, they shall be devoured as stubble fully dry.

<b>11 </b>There is <i>one</i> come out of thee, that imagineth evil against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, a wicked counsellor.

<b>12 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; Though <i>they be</i> quiet, and likewise many, yet thus shall they be cut down, when he shall pass through. Though I have afflicted thee, I will afflict thee no more.

<b>13 </b>For now will I break his yoke from off thee, and will burst thy bonds in sunder.

<b>14 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath given a commandment concerning thee, <i>that</i> no more of thy name be sown: out of the house of thy gods will I cut off the graven image and the molten image: I will make thy grave; for thou art vile.

<b>15 </b>Behold upon the mountains the feet of him that bringeth good tidings, that publisheth peace! O Judah, keep thy solemn feasts, perform thy vows: for the wicked shall no more pass through thee; he is utterly cut off.


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>He that dasheth in pieces is come up before thy face: keep the munition, watch the way, make <i>thy</i> loins strong, fortify <i>thy</i> power mightily.

<b>2 </b>For the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath turned away the excellency of Jacob, as the excellency of Israel: for the emptiers have emptied them out, and marred their vine branches.

<b>3 </b>The shield of his mighty men is made red, the valiant men <i>are</i> in scarlet: the chariots <i>shall be</i> with flaming torches in the day of his preparation, and the fir trees shall be terribly shaken.

<b>4 </b>The chariots shall rage in the streets, they shall justle one against another in the broad ways: they shall seem like torches, they shall run like the lightnings.

<b>5 </b>He shall recount his worthies: they shall stumble in their walk; they shall make haste to the wall thereof, and the defence shall be prepared.

<b>6 </b>The gates of the rivers shall be opened, and the palace shall be dissolved.

<b>7 </b>And Huzzab shall be led away captive, she shall be brought up, and her maids shall lead <i>her</i> as with the voice of doves, tabering upon their breasts.

<b>8 </b>But Nineveh <i>is</i> of old like a pool of water: yet they shall flee away. Stand, stand, <i>shall they cry;</i> but none shall look back.

<b>9 </b>Take ye the spoil of silver, take the spoil of gold: for <i>there is</i> none end of the store <i>and</i> glory out of all the pleasant furniture.

<b>10 </b>She is empty, and void, and waste: and the heart melteth, and the knees smite together, and much pain <i>is</i> in all loins, and the faces of them all gather blackness.

<b>11 </b>Where <i>is</i> the dwelling of the lions, and the feedingplace of the young lions, where the lion, <i>even</i> the old lion, walked, <i>and</i> the lion’s whelp, and none made <i>them</i> afraid?

<b>12 </b>The lion did tear in pieces enough for his whelps, and strangled for his lionesses, and filled his holes with prey, and his dens with ravin.

<b>13 </b>Behold, I <i>am</i> against thee, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, and I will burn her chariots in the smoke, and the sword shall devour thy young lions: and I will cut off thy prey from the earth, and the voice of thy messengers shall no more be heard.


--------------------

CHAPTER 3

<b>1 </b>Woe to the bloody city! it <i>is</i> all full of lies <i>and</i> robbery; the prey departeth not;

<b>2 </b>The noise of a whip, and the noise of the rattling of the wheels, and of the pransing horses, and of the jumping chariots.

<b>3 </b>The horseman lifteth up both the bright sword and the glittering spear: and <i>there is</i> a multitude of slain, and a great number of carcases; and <i>there is</i> none end of <i>their</i> corpses; they stumble upon their corpses:

<b>4 </b>Because of the multitude of the whoredoms of the wellfavoured harlot, the mistress of witchcrafts, that selleth nations through her whoredoms, and families through her witchcrafts.

<b>5 </b>Behold, I <i>am</i> against thee, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; and I will discover thy skirts upon thy face, and I will shew the nations thy nakedness, and the kingdoms thy shame.

<b>6 </b>And I will cast abominable filth upon thee, and make thee vile, and will set thee as a gazingstock.

<b>7 </b>And it shall come to pass, <i>that</i> all they that look upon thee shall flee from thee, and say, Nineveh is laid waste: who will bemoan her? whence shall I seek comforters for thee?

<b>8 </b>Art thou better than populous No, that was situate among the rivers, <i>that had</i> the waters round about it, whose rampart <i>was</i> the sea, <i>and</i> her wall <i>was</i> from the sea?

<b>9 </b>Ethiopia and Egypt <i>were</i> her strength, and <i>it was</i> infinite; Put and Lubim were thy helpers.

<b>10 </b>Yet <i>was</i> she carried away, she went into captivity: her young children also were dashed in pieces at the top of all the streets: and they cast lots for her honourable men, and all her great men were bound in chains.

<b>11 </b>Thou also shalt be drunken: thou shalt be hid, thou also shalt seek strength because of the enemy.

<b>12 </b>All thy strong holds <i>shall be like</i> fig trees with the firstripe figs: if they be shaken, they shall even fall into the mouth of the eater.

<b>13 </b>Behold, thy people in the midst of thee <i>are</i> women: the gates of thy land shall be set wide open unto thine enemies: the fire shall devour thy bars.

<b>14 </b>Draw thee waters for the siege, fortify thy strong holds: go into clay, and tread the mortar, make strong the brickkiln.

<b>15 </b>There shall the fire devour thee; the sword shall cut thee off, it shall eat thee up like the cankerworm: make thyself many as the cankerworm, make thyself many as the locusts.

<b>16 </b>Thou hast multiplied thy merchants above the stars of heaven: the cankerworm spoileth, and flieth away.

<b>17 </b>Thy crowned <i>are</i> as the locusts, and thy captains as the great grasshoppers, which camp in the hedges in the cold day, <i>but</i> when the sun ariseth they flee away, and their place is not known where they <i>are.</i>

<b>18 </b>Thy shepherds slumber, O king of Assyria: thy nobles shall dwell <i>in the dust:</i> thy people is scattered upon the mountains, and no man gathereth <i>them.</i>

<b>19 </b><i>There is</i> no healing of thy bruise; thy wound is grievous: all that hear the bruit of thee shall clap the hands over thee: for upon whom hath not thy wickedness passed continually?


--------------------

Habakkuk

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>The burden which Habakkuk the prophet did see.

<b>2 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, how long shall I cry, and thou wilt not hear! <i>even</i> cry out unto thee <i>of</i> violence, and thou wilt not save!

<b>3 </b>Why dost thou shew me iniquity, and cause <i>me</i> to behold grievance? for spoiling and violence <i>are</i> before me: and there are <i>that</i> raise up strife and contention.

<b>4 </b>Therefore the law is slacked, and judgment doth never go forth: for the wicked doth compass about the righteous; therefore wrong judgment proceedeth.

<b>5 </b>¶ Behold ye among the heathen, and regard, and wonder marvellously: for <i>I</i> will work a work in your days, <i>which</i> ye will not believe, though it be told <i>you.</i>

<b>6 </b>For, lo, I raise up the Chaldeans, <i>that</i> bitter and hasty nation, which shall march through the breadth of the land, to possess the dwellingplaces <i>that are</i> not theirs.

<b>7 </b>They <i>are</i> terrible and dreadful: their judgment and their dignity shall proceed of themselves.

<b>8 </b>Their horses also are swifter than the leopards, and are more fierce than the evening wolves: and their horsemen shall spread themselves, and their horsemen shall come from far; they shall fly as the eagle <i>that</i> hasteth to eat.

<b>9 </b>They shall come all for violence: their faces shall sup up <i>as</i> the east wind, and they shall gather the captivity as the sand.

<b>10 </b>And they shall scoff at the kings, and the princes shall be a scorn unto them: they shall deride every strong hold; for they shall heap dust, and take it.

<b>11 </b>Then shall <i>his</i> mind change, and he shall pass over, and offend, <i>imputing</i> this his power unto his god.

<b>12 </b>¶ <i>Art</i> thou not from everlasting, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God, mine Holy One? we shall not die. O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, thou hast ordained them for judgment; and, O mighty God, thou hast established them for correction.

<b>13 </b><i>Thou art</i> of purer eyes than to behold evil, and canst not look on iniquity: wherefore lookest thou upon them that deal treacherously, <i>and</i> holdest thy tongue when the wicked devoureth <i>the man that is</i> more righteous than he?

<b>14 </b>And makest men as the fishes of the sea, as the creeping things, <i>that have</i> no ruler over them?

<b>15 </b>They take up all of them with the angle, they catch them in their net, and gather them in their drag: therefore they rejoice and are glad.

<b>16 </b>Therefore they sacrifice unto their net, and burn incense unto their drag; because by them their portion <i>is</i> fat, and their meat plenteous.

<b>17 </b>Shall they therefore empty their net, and not spare continually to slay the nations?


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>I will stand upon my watch, and set me upon the tower, and will watch to see what he will say unto me, and what I shall answer when I am reproved.

<b>2 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> answered me, and said, Write the vision, and make <i>it</i> plain upon tables, that he may run that readeth it.

<b>3 </b>For the vision <i>is</i> yet for an appointed time, but at the end it shall speak, and not lie: though it tarry, wait for it; because it will surely come, it will not tarry.

<b>4 </b>Behold, his soul <i>which</i> is lifted up is not upright in him: but the just shall live by his faith.

<b>5 </b>¶ Yea also, because he transgresseth by wine, <i>he is</i> a proud man, neither keepeth at home, who enlargeth his desire as hell, and <i>is</i> as death, and cannot be satisfied, but gathereth unto him all nations, and heapeth unto him all people:

<b>6 </b>Shall not all these take up a parable against him, and a taunting proverb against him, and say, Woe to him that increaseth <i>that which is</i> not his! how long? and to him that ladeth himself with thick clay!

<b>7 </b>Shall they not rise up suddenly that shall bite thee, and awake that shall vex thee, and thou shalt be for booties unto them?

<b>8 </b>Because thou hast spoiled many nations, all the remnant of the people shall spoil thee; because of men’s blood, and <i>for</i> the violence of the land, of the city, and of all that dwell therein.

<b>9 </b>¶ Woe to him that coveteth an evil covetousness to his house, that he may set his nest on high, that he may be delivered from the power of evil!

<b>10 </b>Thou hast consulted shame to thy house by cutting off many people, and hast sinned <i>against</i> thy soul.

<b>11 </b>For the stone shall cry out of the wall, and the beam out of the timber shall answer it.

<b>12 </b>¶ Woe to him that buildeth a town with blood, and stablisheth a city by iniquity!

<b>13 </b>Behold, <i>is it</i> not of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts that the people shall labour in the very fire, and the people shall weary themselves for very vanity?

<b>14 </b>For the earth shall be filled with the knowledge of the glory of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, as the waters cover the sea.

<b>15 </b>¶ Woe unto him that giveth his neighbour drink, that puttest thy bottle to <i>him,</i> and makest <i>him</i> drunken also, that thou mayest look on their nakedness!

<b>16 </b>Thou art filled with shame for glory: drink thou also, and let thy foreskin be uncovered: the cup of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s right hand shall be turned unto thee, and shameful spewing <i>shall be</i> on thy glory.

<b>17 </b>For the violence of Lebanon shall cover thee, and the spoil of beasts, <i>which</i> made them afraid, because of men’s blood, and for the violence of the land, of the city, and of all that dwell therein.

<b>18 </b>¶ What profiteth the graven image that the maker thereof hath graven it; the molten image, and a teacher of lies, that the maker of his work trusteth therein, to make dumb idols?

<b>19 </b>Woe unto him that saith to the wood, Awake; to the dumb stone, Arise, it shall teach! Behold, it <i>is</i> laid over with gold and silver, and <i>there is</i> no breath at all in the midst of it.

<b>20 </b>But the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> in his holy temple: let all the earth keep silence before him.


--------------------

CHAPTER 3

<b>1 </b>A prayer of Habakkuk the prophet upon Shigionoth.

<b>2 </b>O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, I have heard thy speech, <i>and</i> was afraid: O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, revive thy work in the midst of the years, in the midst of the years make known; in wrath remember mercy.

<b>3 </b>God came from Teman, and the Holy One from mount Paran. Selah. His glory covered the heavens, and the earth was full of his praise.

<b>4 </b>And <i>his</i> brightness was as the light; he had horns <i>coming</i> out of his hand: and there <i>was</i> the hiding of his power.

<b>5 </b>Before him went the pestilence, and burning coals went forth at his feet.

<b>6 </b>He stood, and measured the earth: he beheld, and drove asunder the nations; and the everlasting mountains were scattered, the perpetual hills did bow: his ways <i>are</i> everlasting.

<b>7 </b>I saw the tents of Cushan in affliction: <i>and</i> the curtains of the land of Midian did tremble.

<b>8 </b>Was the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> displeased against the rivers? <i>was</i> thine anger against the rivers? <i>was</i> thy wrath against the sea, that thou didst ride upon thine horses <i>and</i> thy chariots of salvation?

<b>9 </b>Thy bow was made quite naked, <i>according</i> to the oaths of the tribes, <i>even thy</i> word. Selah. Thou didst cleave the earth with rivers.

<b>10 </b>The mountains saw thee, <i>and</i> they trembled: the overflowing of the water passed by: the deep uttered his voice, <i>and</i> lifted up his hands on high.

<b>11 </b>The sun <i>and</i> moon stood still in their habitation: at the light of thine arrows they went, <i>and</i> at the shining of thy glittering spear.

<b>12 </b>Thou didst march through the land in indignation, thou didst thresh the heathen in anger.

<b>13 </b>Thou wentest forth for the salvation of thy people, <i>even</i> for salvation with thine anointed; thou woundedst the head out of the house of the wicked, by discovering the foundation unto the neck. Selah.

<b>14 </b>Thou didst strike through with his staves the head of his villages: they came out as a whirlwind to scatter me: their rejoicing <i>was</i> as to devour the poor secretly.

<b>15 </b>Thou didst walk through the sea with thine horses, <i>through</i> the heap of great waters.

<b>16 </b>When I heard, my belly trembled; my lips quivered at the voice: rottenness entered into my bones, and I trembled in myself, that I might rest in the day of trouble: when he cometh up unto the people, he will invade them with his troops.

<b>17 </b>¶ Although the fig tree shall not blossom, neither <i>shall</i> fruit <i>be</i> in the vines; the labour of the olive shall fail, and the fields shall yield no meat; the flock shall be cut off from the fold, and <i>there shall be</i> no herd in the stalls:

<b>18 </b>Yet I will rejoice in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, I will joy in the God of my salvation.

<b>19 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> God <i>is</i> my strength, and he will make my feet like hinds’ <i>feet,</i> and he will make me to walk upon mine high places. To the chief singer on my stringed instruments.


--------------------

Zephaniah

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>The word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> which came unto Zephaniah the son of Cushi, the son of Gedaliah, the son of Amariah, the son of Hizkiah, in the days of Josiah the son of Amon, king of Judah.

<b>2 </b>I will utterly consume all <i>things</i> from off the land, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>3 </b>I will consume man and beast; I will consume the fowls of the heaven, and the fishes of the sea, and the stumblingblocks with the wicked; and I will cut off man from off the land, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>4 </b>I will also stretch out mine hand upon Judah, and upon all the inhabitants of Jerusalem; and I will cut off the remnant of Baal from this place, <i>and</i> the name of the Chemarims with the priests;

<b>5 </b>And them that worship the host of heaven upon the housetops; and them that worship <i>and</i> that swear by the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and that swear by Malcham;

<b>6 </b>And them that are turned back from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and <i>those</i> that have not sought the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, nor inquired for him.

<b>7 </b>Hold thy peace at the presence of the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span>: for the day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> at hand: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath prepared a sacrifice, he hath bid his guests.

<b>8 </b>And it shall come to pass in the day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s sacrifice, that I will punish the princes, and the king’s children, and all such as are clothed with strange apparel.

<b>9 </b>In the same day also will I punish all those that leap on the threshold, which fill their masters’ houses with violence and deceit.

<b>10 </b>And it shall come to pass in that day, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>that there shall be</i> the noise of a cry from the fish gate, and an howling from the second, and a great crashing from the hills.

<b>11 </b>Howl, ye inhabitants of Maktesh, for all the merchant people are cut down; all they that bear silver are cut off.

<b>12 </b>And it shall come to pass at that time, <i>that</i> I will search Jerusalem with candles, and punish the men that are settled on their lees: that say in their heart, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> will not do good, neither will he do evil.

<b>13 </b>Therefore their goods shall become a booty, and their houses a desolation: they shall also build houses, but not inhabit <i>them;</i> and they shall plant vineyards, but not drink the wine thereof.

<b>14 </b>The great day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> near, <i>it is</i> near, and hasteth greatly, <i>even</i> the voice of the day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: the mighty man shall cry there bitterly.

<b>15 </b>That day <i>is</i> a day of wrath, a day of trouble and distress, a day of wasteness and desolation, a day of darkness and gloominess, a day of clouds and thick darkness,

<b>16 </b>A day of the trumpet and alarm against the fenced cities, and against the high towers.

<b>17 </b>And I will bring distress upon men, that they shall walk like blind men, because they have sinned against the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: and their blood shall be poured out as dust, and their flesh as the dung.

<b>18 </b>Neither their silver nor their gold shall be able to deliver them in the day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s wrath; but the whole land shall be devoured by the fire of his jealousy: for he shall make even a speedy riddance of all them that dwell in the land.


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>Gather yourselves together, yea, gather together, O nation not desired;

<b>2 </b>Before the decree bring forth, <i>before</i> the day pass as the chaff, before the fierce anger of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> come upon you, before the day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s anger come upon you.

<b>3 </b>Seek ye the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, all ye meek of the earth, which have wrought his judgment; seek righteousness, seek meekness: it may be ye shall be hid in the day of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s anger.

<b>4 </b>¶ For Gaza shall be forsaken, and Ashkelon a desolation: they shall drive out Ashdod at the noon day, and Ekron shall be rooted up.

<b>5 </b>Woe unto the inhabitants of the sea coast, the nation of the Cherethites! the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> against you; O Canaan, the land of the Philistines, I will even destroy thee, that there shall be no inhabitant.

<b>6 </b>And the sea coast shall be dwellings <i>and</i> cottages for shepherds, and folds for flocks.

<b>7 </b>And the coast shall be for the remnant of the house of Judah; they shall feed thereupon: in the houses of Ashkelon shall they lie down in the evening: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> their God shall visit them, and turn away their captivity.

<b>8 </b>¶ I have heard the reproach of Moab, and the revilings of the children of Ammon, whereby they have reproached my people, and magnified <i>themselves</i> against their border.

<b>9 </b>Therefore <i>as</i> I live, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, the God of Israel, Surely Moab shall be as Sodom, and the children of Ammon as Gomorrah, <i>even</i> the breeding of nettles, and saltpits, and a perpetual desolation: the residue of my people shall spoil them, and the remnant of my people shall possess them.

<b>10 </b>This shall they have for their pride, because they have reproached and magnified <i>themselves</i> against the people of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts.

<b>11 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>will be</i> terrible unto them: for he will famish all the gods of the earth; and <i>men</i> shall worship him, every one from his place, <i>even</i> all the isles of the heathen.

<b>12 </b>¶ Ye Ethiopians also, ye <i>shall be</i> slain by my sword.

<b>13 </b>And he will stretch out his hand against the north, and destroy Assyria; and will make Nineveh a desolation, <i>and</i> dry like a wilderness.

<b>14 </b>And flocks shall lie down in the midst of her, all the beasts of the nations: both the cormorant and the bittern shall lodge in the upper lintels of it; <i>their</i> voice shall sing in the windows; desolation <i>shall be</i> in the thresholds: for he shall uncover the cedar work.

<b>15 </b>This <i>is</i> the rejoicing city that dwelt carelessly, that said in her heart, I <i>am,</i> and <i>there is</i> none beside me: how is she become a desolation, a place for beasts to lie down in! every one that passeth by her shall hiss, <i>and</i> wag his hand.


--------------------

CHAPTER 3

<b>1 </b>Woe to her that is filthy and polluted, to the oppressing city!

<b>2 </b>She obeyed not the voice; she received not correction; she trusted not in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; she drew not near to her God.

<b>3 </b>Her princes within her <i>are</i> roaring lions; her judges <i>are</i> evening wolves; they gnaw not the bones till the morrow.

<b>4 </b>Her prophets <i>are</i> light <i>and</i> treacherous persons: her priests have polluted the sanctuary, they have done violence to the law.

<b>5 </b>The just <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> in the midst thereof; he will not do iniquity: every morning doth he bring his judgment to light, he faileth not; but the unjust knoweth no shame.

<b>6 </b>I have cut off the nations: their towers are desolate; I made their streets waste, that none passeth by: their cities are destroyed, so that there is no man, that there is none inhabitant.

<b>7 </b>I said, Surely thou wilt fear me, thou wilt receive instruction; so their dwelling should not be cut off, howsoever I punished them: but they rose early, <i>and</i> corrupted all their doings.

<b>8 </b>¶ Therefore wait ye upon me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, until the day that I rise up to the prey: for my determination <i>is</i> to gather the nations, that I may assemble the kingdoms, to pour upon them mine indignation, <i>even</i> all my fierce anger: for all the earth shall be devoured with the fire of my jealousy.

<b>9 </b>For then will I turn to the people a pure language, that they may all call upon the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, to serve him with one consent.

<b>10 </b>From beyond the rivers of Ethiopia my suppliants, <i>even</i> the daughter of my dispersed, shall bring mine offering.

<b>11 </b>In that day shalt thou not be ashamed for all thy doings, wherein thou hast transgressed against me: for then I will take away out of the midst of thee them that rejoice in thy pride, and thou shalt no more be haughty because of my holy mountain.

<b>12 </b>I will also leave in the midst of thee an afflicted and poor people, and they shall trust in the name of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>13 </b>The remnant of Israel shall not do iniquity, nor speak lies; neither shall a deceitful tongue be found in their mouth: for they shall feed and lie down, and none shall make <i>them</i> afraid.

<b>14 </b>¶ Sing, O daughter of Zion; shout, O Israel; be glad and rejoice with all the heart, O daughter of Jerusalem.

<b>15 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath taken away thy judgments, he hath cast out thine enemy: the king of Israel, <i>even</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, <i>is</i> in the midst of thee: thou shalt not see evil any more.

<b>16 </b>In that day it shall be said to Jerusalem, Fear thou not: <i>and to</i> Zion, Let not thine hands be slack.

<b>17 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> thy God in the midst of thee <i>is</i> mighty; he will save, he will rejoice over thee with joy; he will rest in his love, he will joy over thee with singing.

<b>18 </b>I will gather <i>them that are</i> sorrowful for the solemn assembly, <i>who</i> are of thee, <i>to whom</i> the reproach of it <i>was</i> a burden.

<b>19 </b>Behold, at that time I will undo all that afflict thee: and I will save her that halteth, and gather her that was driven out; and I will get them praise and fame in every land where they have been put to shame.

<b>20 </b>At that time will I bring you <i>again,</i> even in the time that I gather you: for I will make you a name and a praise among all people of the earth, when I turn back your captivity before your eyes, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

Haggai

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>In the second year of Darius the king, in the sixth month, in the first day of the month, came the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> by Haggai the prophet unto Zerubbabel the son of Shealtiel, governor of Judah, and to Joshua the son of Josedech, the high priest, saying,

<b>2 </b>Thus speaketh the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, saying, This people say, The time is not come, the time that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s house should be built.

<b>3 </b>Then came the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> by Haggai the prophet, saying,

<b>4 </b><i>Is it</i> time for you, O ye, to dwell in your ceiled houses, and this house <i>lie</i> waste?

<b>5 </b>Now therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; Consider your ways.

<b>6 </b>Ye have sown much, and bring in little; ye eat, but ye have not enough; ye drink, but ye are not filled with drink; ye clothe you, but there is none warm; and he that earneth wages earneth wages <i>to put it</i> into a bag with holes.

<b>7 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; Consider your ways.

<b>8 </b>Go up to the mountain, and bring wood, and build the house; and I will take pleasure in it, and I will be glorified, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>9 </b>Ye looked for much, and, lo, <i>it came</i> to little; and when ye brought <i>it</i> home, I did blow upon it. Why? saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts. Because of mine house that <i>is</i> waste, and ye run every man unto his own house.

<b>10 </b>Therefore the heaven over you is stayed from dew, and the earth is stayed <i>from</i> her fruit.

<b>11 </b>And I called for a drought upon the land, and upon the mountains, and upon the corn, and upon the new wine, and upon the oil, and upon <i>that</i> which the ground bringeth forth, and upon men, and upon cattle, and upon all the labour of the hands.

<b>12 </b>¶ Then Zerubbabel the son of Shealtiel, and Joshua the son of Josedech, the high priest, with all the remnant of the people, obeyed the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> their God, and the words of Haggai the prophet, as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> their God had sent him, and the people did fear before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>13 </b>Then spake Haggai the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s messenger in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s message unto the people, saying, I <i>am</i> with you, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>14 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> stirred up the spirit of Zerubbabel the son of Shealtiel, governor of Judah, and the spirit of Joshua the son of Josedech, the high priest, and the spirit of all the remnant of the people; and they came and did work in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, their God,

<b>15 </b>In the four and twentieth day of the sixth month, in the second year of Darius the king.


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>In the seventh <i>month,</i> in the one and twentieth <i>day</i> of the month, came the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> by the prophet Haggai, saying,

<b>2 </b>Speak now to Zerubbabel the son of Shealtiel, governor of Judah, and to Joshua the son of Josedech, the high priest, and to the residue of the people, saying,

<b>3 </b>Who <i>is</i> left among you that saw this house in her first glory? and how do ye see it now? <i>is it</i> not in your eyes in comparison of it as nothing?

<b>4 </b>Yet now be strong, O Zerubbabel, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and be strong, O Joshua, son of Josedech, the high priest; and be strong, all ye people of the land, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and work: for I <i>am</i> with you, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts:

<b>5 </b><i>According to</i> the word that I covenanted with you when ye came out of Egypt, so my spirit remaineth among you: fear ye not.

<b>6 </b>For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; Yet once, it <i>is</i> a little while, and I will shake the heavens, and the earth, and the sea, and the dry <i>land;</i>

<b>7 </b>And I will shake all nations, and the desire of all nations shall come: and I will fill this house with glory, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts.

<b>8 </b>The silver <i>is</i> mine, and the gold <i>is</i> mine, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts.

<b>9 </b>The glory of this latter house shall be greater than of the former, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts: and in this place will I give peace, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts.

<b>10 </b>¶ In the four and twentieth <i>day</i> of the ninth <i>month,</i> in the second year of Darius, came the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> by Haggai the prophet, saying,

<b>11 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; Ask now the priests <i>concerning</i> the law, saying,

<b>12 </b>If one bear holy flesh in the skirt of his garment, and with his skirt do touch bread, or pottage, or wine, or oil, or any meat, shall it be holy? And the priests answered and said, No.

<b>13 </b>Then said Haggai, If <i>one that is</i> unclean by a dead body touch any of these, shall it be unclean? And the priests answered and said, It shall be unclean.

<b>14 </b>Then answered Haggai, and said, So <i>is</i> this people, and so <i>is</i> this nation before me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and so <i>is</i> every work of their hands; and that which they offer there <i>is</i> unclean.

<b>15 </b>And now, I pray you, consider from this day and upward, from before a stone was laid upon a stone in the temple of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>:

<b>16 </b>Since those <i>days</i> were, when <i>one</i> came to an heap of twenty <i>measures,</i> there were <i>but</i> ten: when <i>one</i> came to the pressfat for to draw out fifty <i>vessels</i> out of the press, there were <i>but</i> twenty.

<b>17 </b>I smote you with blasting and with mildew and with hail in all the labours of your hands; yet ye <i>turned</i> not to me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>18 </b>Consider now from this day and upward, from the four and twentieth day of the ninth <i>month, even</i> from the day that the foundation of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>’s temple was laid, consider <i>it.</i>

<b>19 </b>Is the seed yet in the barn? yea, as yet the vine, and the fig tree, and the pomegranate, and the olive tree, hath not brought forth: from this day will I bless <i>you.</i>

<b>20 </b>¶ And again the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto Haggai in the four and twentieth <i>day</i> of the month, saying,

<b>21 </b>Speak to Zerubbabel, governor of Judah, saying, I will shake the heavens and the earth;

<b>22 </b>And I will overthrow the throne of kingdoms, and I will destroy the strength of the kingdoms of the heathen; and I will overthrow the chariots, and those that ride in them; and the horses and their riders shall come down, every one by the sword of his brother.

<b>23 </b>In that day, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, will I take thee, O Zerubbabel, my servant, the son of Shealtiel, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and will make thee as a signet: for I have chosen thee, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts.


--------------------

Zechariah

CHAPTER 1

<b>1 </b>In the eighth month, in the second year of Darius, came the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto Zechariah, the son of Berechiah, the son of Iddo the prophet, saying,

<b>2 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath been sore displeased with your fathers.

<b>3 </b>Therefore say thou unto them, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; Turn ye unto me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, and I will turn unto you, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts.

<b>4 </b>Be ye not as your fathers, unto whom the former prophets have cried, saying, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; Turn ye now from your evil ways, and <i>from</i> your evil doings: but they did not hear, nor hearken unto me, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>5 </b>Your fathers, where <i>are</i> they? and the prophets, do they live for ever?

<b>6 </b>But my words and my statutes, which I commanded my servants the prophets, did they not take hold of your fathers? and they returned and said, Like as the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts thought to do unto us, according to our ways, and according to our doings, so hath he dealt with us.

<b>7 </b>¶ Upon the four and twentieth day of the eleventh month, which <i>is</i> the month Sebat, in the second year of Darius, came the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto Zechariah, the son of Berechiah, the son of Iddo the prophet, saying,

<b>8 </b>I saw by night, and behold a man riding upon a red horse, and he stood among the myrtle trees that <i>were</i> in the bottom; and behind him <i>were there</i> red horses, speckled, and white.

<b>9 </b>Then said I, O my lord, what <i>are</i> these? And the angel that talked with me said unto me, I will shew thee what these <i>be.</i>

<b>10 </b>And the man that stood among the myrtle trees answered and said, These <i>are they</i> whom the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath sent to walk to and fro through the earth.

<b>11 </b>And they answered the angel of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that stood among the myrtle trees, and said, We have walked to and fro through the earth, and, behold, all the earth sitteth still, and is at rest.

<b>12 </b>¶ Then the angel of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> answered and said, O <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, how long wilt thou not have mercy on Jerusalem and on the cities of Judah, against which thou hast had indignation these threescore and ten years?

<b>13 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> answered the angel that talked with me <i>with</i> good words <i>and</i> comfortable words.

<b>14 </b>So the angel that communed with me said unto me, Cry thou, saying, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; I am jealous for Jerusalem and for Zion with a great jealousy.

<b>15 </b>And I am very sore displeased with the heathen <i>that are</i> at ease: for I was but a little displeased, and they helped forward the affliction.

<b>16 </b>Therefore thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; I am returned to Jerusalem with mercies: my house shall be built in it, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, and a line shall be stretched forth upon Jerusalem.

<b>17 </b>Cry yet, saying, Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; My cities through prosperity shall yet be spread abroad; and the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall yet comfort Zion, and shall yet choose Jerusalem.

<b>18 </b>¶ Then lifted I up mine eyes, and saw, and behold four horns.

<b>19 </b>And I said unto the angel that talked with me, What <i>be</i> these? And he answered me, These <i>are</i> the horns which have scattered Judah, Israel, and Jerusalem.

<b>20 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shewed me four carpenters.

<b>21 </b>Then said I, What come these to do? And he spake, saying, These <i>are</i> the horns which have scattered Judah, so that no man did lift up his head: but these are come to fray them, to cast out the horns of the Gentiles, which lifted up <i>their</i> horn over the land of Judah to scatter it.


--------------------

CHAPTER 2

<b>1 </b>I lifted up mine eyes again, and looked, and behold a man with a measuring line in his hand.

<b>2 </b>Then said I, Whither goest thou? And he said unto me, To measure Jerusalem, to see what <i>is</i> the breadth thereof, and what <i>is</i> the length thereof.

<b>3 </b>And, behold, the angel that talked with me went forth, and another angel went out to meet him,

<b>4 </b>And said unto him, Run, speak to this young man, saying, Jerusalem shall be inhabited <i>as</i> towns without walls for the multitude of men and cattle therein:

<b>5 </b>For I, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, will be unto her a wall of fire round about, and will be the glory in the midst of her.

<b>6 </b>¶ Ho, ho, <i>come forth,</i> and flee from the land of the north, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for I have spread you abroad as the four winds of the heaven, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>7 </b>Deliver thyself, O Zion, that dwellest <i>with</i> the daughter of Babylon.

<b>8 </b>For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; After the glory hath he sent me unto the nations which spoiled you: for he that toucheth you toucheth the apple of his eye.

<b>9 </b>For, behold, I will shake mine hand upon them, and they shall be a spoil to their servants: and ye shall know that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts hath sent me.

<b>10 </b>¶ Sing and rejoice, O daughter of Zion: for, lo, I come, and I will dwell in the midst of thee, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>11 </b>And many nations shall be joined to the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in that day, and shall be my people: and I will dwell in the midst of thee, and thou shalt know that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts hath sent me unto thee.

<b>12 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall inherit Judah his portion in the holy land, and shall choose Jerusalem again.

<b>13 </b>Be silent, O all flesh, before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: for he is raised up out of his holy habitation.


--------------------

CHAPTER 3

<b>1 </b>And he shewed me Joshua the high priest standing before the angel of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and Satan standing at his right hand to resist him.

<b>2 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto Satan, The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> rebuke thee, O Satan; even the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> that hath chosen Jerusalem rebuke thee: <i>is</i> not this a brand plucked out of the fire?

<b>3 </b>Now Joshua was clothed with filthy garments, and stood before the angel.

<b>4 </b>And he answered and spake unto those that stood before him, saying, Take away the filthy garments from him. And unto him he said, Behold, I have caused thine iniquity to pass from thee, and I will clothe thee with change of raiment.

<b>5 </b>And I said, Let them set a fair mitre upon his head. So they set a fair mitre upon his head, and clothed him with garments. And the angel of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> stood by.

<b>6 </b>And the angel of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> protested unto Joshua, saying,

<b>7 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; If thou wilt walk in my ways, and if thou wilt keep my charge, then thou shalt also judge my house, and shalt also keep my courts, and I will give thee places to walk among these that stand by.

<b>8 </b>Hear now, O Joshua the high priest, thou, and thy fellows that sit before thee: for they <i>are</i> men wondered at: for, behold, I will bring forth my servant the <span class="uppercase">Branch</span>.

<b>9 </b>For behold the stone that I have laid before Joshua; upon one stone <i>shall be</i> seven eyes: behold, I will engrave the graving thereof, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, and I will remove the iniquity of that land in one day.

<b>10 </b>In that day, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, shall ye call every man his neighbour under the vine and under the fig tree.


--------------------

CHAPTER 4

<b>1 </b>And the angel that talked with me came again, and waked me, as a man that is wakened out of his sleep,

<b>2 </b>And said unto me, What seest thou? And I said, I have looked, and behold a candlestick all <i>of</i> gold, with a bowl upon the top of it, and his seven lamps thereon, and seven pipes to the seven lamps, which <i>are</i> upon the top thereof:

<b>3 </b>And two olive trees by it, one upon the right <i>side</i> of the bowl, and the other upon the left <i>side</i> thereof.

<b>4 </b>So I answered and spake to the angel that talked with me, saying, What <i>are</i> these, my lord?

<b>5 </b>Then the angel that talked with me answered and said unto me, Knowest thou not what these be? And I said, No, my lord.

<b>6 </b>Then he answered and spake unto me, saying, This <i>is</i> the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> unto Zerubbabel, saying, Not by might, nor by power, but by my spirit, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts.

<b>7 </b>Who <i>art</i> thou, O great mountain? before Zerubbabel <i>thou shalt become</i> a plain: and he shall bring forth the headstone <i>thereof with</i> shoutings, <i>crying,</i> Grace, grace unto it.

<b>8 </b>Moreover the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto me, saying,

<b>9 </b>The hands of Zerubbabel have laid the foundation of this house; his hands shall also finish it; and thou shalt know that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts hath sent me unto you.

<b>10 </b>For who hath despised the day of small things? for they shall rejoice, and shall see the plummet in the hand of Zerubbabel <i>with</i> those seven; they <i>are</i> the eyes of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, which run to and fro through the whole earth.

<b>11 </b>¶ Then answered I, and said unto him, What <i>are</i> these two olive trees upon the right <i>side</i> of the candlestick and upon the left <i>side</i> thereof?

<b>12 </b>And I answered again, and said unto him, What <i>be these</i> two olive branches which through the two golden pipes empty the golden <i>oil</i> out of themselves?

<b>13 </b>And he answered me and said, Knowest thou not what these <i>be?</i> And I said, No, my lord.

<b>14 </b>Then said he, These <i>are</i> the two anointed ones, that stand by the Lord of the whole earth.


--------------------

CHAPTER 5

<b>1 </b>Then I turned, and lifted up mine eyes, and looked, and behold a flying roll.

<b>2 </b>And he said unto me, What seest thou? And I answered, I see a flying roll; the length thereof <i>is</i> twenty cubits, and the breadth thereof ten cubits.

<b>3 </b>Then said he unto me, This <i>is</i> the curse that goeth forth over the face of the whole earth: for every one that stealeth shall be cut off <i>as</i> on this side according to it; and every one that sweareth shall be cut off <i>as</i> on that side according to it.

<b>4 </b>I will bring it forth, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, and it shall enter into the house of the thief, and into the house of him that sweareth falsely by my name: and it shall remain in the midst of his house, and shall consume it with the timber thereof and the stones thereof.

<b>5 </b>¶ Then the angel that talked with me went forth, and said unto me, Lift up now thine eyes, and see what <i>is</i> this that goeth forth.

<b>6 </b>And I said, What <i>is</i> it? And he said, This <i>is</i> an ephah that goeth forth. He said moreover, This <i>is</i> their resemblance through all the earth.

<b>7 </b>And, behold, there was lifted up a talent of lead: and this <i>is</i> a woman that sitteth in the midst of the ephah.

<b>8 </b>And he said, This <i>is</i> wickedness. And he cast it into the midst of the ephah; and he cast the weight of lead upon the mouth thereof.

<b>9 </b>Then lifted I up mine eyes, and looked, and, behold, there came out two women, and the wind <i>was</i> in their wings; for they had wings like the wings of a stork: and they lifted up the ephah between the earth and the heaven.

<b>10 </b>Then said I to the angel that talked with me, Whither do these bear the ephah?

<b>11 </b>And he said unto me, To build it an house in the land of Shinar: and it shall be established, and set there upon her own base.


--------------------

CHAPTER 6

<b>1 </b>And I turned, and lifted up mine eyes, and looked, and, behold, there came four chariots out from between two mountains; and the mountains <i>were</i> mountains of brass.

<b>2 </b>In the first chariot <i>were</i> red horses; and in the second chariot black horses;

<b>3 </b>And in the third chariot white horses; and in the fourth chariot grisled and bay horses.

<b>4 </b>Then I answered and said unto the angel that talked with me, What <i>are</i> these, my lord?

<b>5 </b>And the angel answered and said unto me, These <i>are</i> the four spirits of the heavens, which go forth from standing before the Lord of all the earth.

<b>6 </b>The black horses which <i>are</i> therein go forth into the north country; and the white go forth after them; and the grisled go forth toward the south country.

<b>7 </b>And the bay went forth, and sought to go that they might walk to and fro through the earth: and he said, Get you hence, walk to and fro through the earth. So they walked to and fro through the earth.

<b>8 </b>Then cried he upon me, and spake unto me, saying, Behold, these that go toward the north country have quieted my spirit in the north country.

<b>9 </b>¶ And the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto me, saying,

<b>10 </b>Take of <i>them of</i> the captivity, <i>even</i> of Heldai, of Tobijah, and of Jedaiah, which are come from Babylon, and come thou the same day, and go into the house of Josiah the son of Zephaniah;

<b>11 </b>Then take silver and gold, and make crowns, and set <i>them</i> upon the head of Joshua the son of Josedech, the high priest;

<b>12 </b>And speak unto him, saying, Thus speaketh the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, saying, Behold the man whose name <i>is</i> The <span class="uppercase">Branch</span>; and he shall grow up out of his place, and he shall build the temple of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>:

<b>13 </b>Even he shall build the temple of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and he shall bear the glory, and shall sit and rule upon his throne; and he shall be a priest upon his throne: and the counsel of peace shall be between them both.

<b>14 </b>And the crowns shall be to Helem, and to Tobijah, and to Jedaiah, and to Hen the son of Zephaniah, for a memorial in the temple of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>15 </b>And they <i>that are</i> far off shall come and build in the temple of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and ye shall know that the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts hath sent me unto you. And <i>this</i> shall come to pass, if ye will diligently obey the voice of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> your God.


--------------------

CHAPTER 7

<b>1 </b>And it came to pass in the fourth year of king Darius, <i>that</i> the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto Zechariah in the fourth <i>day</i> of the ninth month, <i>even</i> in Chisleu;

<b>2 </b>When they had sent unto the house of God Sherezer and Regem-melech, and their men, to pray before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>,

<b>3 </b><i>And</i> to speak unto the priests which <i>were</i> in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, and to the prophets, saying, Should I weep in the fifth month, separating myself, as I have done these so many years?

<b>4 </b>¶ Then came the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts unto me, saying,

<b>5 </b>Speak unto all the people of the land, and to the priests, saying, When ye fasted and mourned in the fifth and seventh <i>month,</i> even those seventy years, did ye at all fast unto me, <i>even</i> to me?

<b>6 </b>And when ye did eat, and when ye did drink, did not ye eat <i>for yourselves,</i> and drink <i>for yourselves?</i>

<b>7 </b><i>Should ye</i> not <i>hear</i> the words which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> hath cried by the former prophets, when Jerusalem was inhabited and in prosperity, and the cities thereof round about her, when <i>men</i> inhabited the south and the plain?

<b>8 </b>¶ And the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> came unto Zechariah, saying,

<b>9 </b>Thus speaketh the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, saying, Execute true judgment, and shew mercy and compassions every man to his brother:

<b>10 </b>And oppress not the widow, nor the fatherless, the stranger, nor the poor; and let none of you imagine evil against his brother in your heart.

<b>11 </b>But they refused to hearken, and pulled away the shoulder, and stopped their ears, that they should not hear.

<b>12 </b>Yea, they made their hearts <i>as</i> an adamant stone, lest they should hear the law, and the words which the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts hath sent in his spirit by the former prophets: therefore came a great wrath from the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts.

<b>13 </b>Therefore it is come to pass, <i>that</i> as he cried, and they would not hear; so they cried, and I would not hear, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts:

<b>14 </b>But I scattered them with a whirlwind among all the nations whom they knew not. Thus the land was desolate after them, that no man passed through nor returned: for they laid the pleasant land desolate.


--------------------

CHAPTER 8

<b>1 </b>Again the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts came <i>to me,</i> saying,

<b>2 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; I was jealous for Zion with great jealousy, and I was jealous for her with great fury.

<b>3 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; I am returned unto Zion, and will dwell in the midst of Jerusalem: and Jerusalem shall be called a city of truth; and the mountain of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts the holy mountain.

<b>4 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; There shall yet old men and old women dwell in the streets of Jerusalem, and every man with his staff in his hand for very age.

<b>5 </b>And the streets of the city shall be full of boys and girls playing in the streets thereof.

<b>6 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; If it be marvellous in the eyes of the remnant of this people in these days, should it also be marvellous in mine eyes? saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts.

<b>7 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; Behold, I will save my people from the east country, and from the west country;

<b>8 </b>And I will bring them, and they shall dwell in the midst of Jerusalem: and they shall be my people, and I will be their God, in truth and in righteousness.

<b>9 </b>¶ Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; Let your hands be strong, ye that hear in these days these words by the mouth of the prophets, which <i>were</i> in the day <i>that</i> the foundation of the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts was laid, that the temple might be built.

<b>10 </b>For before these days there was no hire for man, nor any hire for beast; neither <i>was there any</i> peace to him that went out or came in because of the affliction: for I set all men every one against his neighbour.

<b>11 </b>But now I <i>will</i> not <i>be</i> unto the residue of this people as in the former days, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts.

<b>12 </b>For the seed <i>shall be</i> prosperous; the vine shall give her fruit, and the ground shall give her increase, and the heavens shall give their dew; and I will cause the remnant of this people to possess all these <i>things.</i>

<b>13 </b>And it shall come to pass, <i>that</i> as ye were a curse among the heathen, O house of Judah, and house of Israel; so will I save you, and ye shall be a blessing: fear not, <i>but</i> let your hands be strong.

<b>14 </b>For thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; As I thought to punish you, when your fathers provoked me to wrath, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts, and I repented not:

<b>15 </b>So again have I thought in these days to do well unto Jerusalem and to the house of Judah: fear ye not.

<b>16 </b>¶ These <i>are</i> the things that ye shall do; Speak ye every man the truth to his neighbour; execute the judgment of truth and peace in your gates:

<b>17 </b>And let none of you imagine evil in your hearts against his neighbour; and love no false oath: for all these <i>are things</i> that I hate, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>18 </b>¶ And the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts came unto me, saying,

<b>19 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; The fast of the fourth <i>month,</i> and the fast of the fifth, and the fast of the seventh, and the fast of the tenth, shall be to the house of Judah joy and gladness, and cheerful feasts; therefore love the truth and peace.

<b>20 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; <i>It shall</i> yet <i>come to pass,</i> that there shall come people, and the inhabitants of many cities:

<b>21 </b>And the inhabitants of one <i>city</i> shall go to another, saying, Let us go speedily to pray before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>, and to seek the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts: I will go also.

<b>22 </b>Yea, many people and strong nations shall come to seek the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts in Jerusalem, and to pray before the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>23 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts; In those days <i>it shall come to pass,</i> that ten men shall take hold out of all languages of the nations, even shall take hold of the skirt of him that is a Jew, saying, We will go with you: for we have heard <i>that</i> God <i>is</i> with you.


--------------------

CHAPTER 9

<b>1 </b>The burden of the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> in the land of Hadrach, and Damascus <i>shall be</i> the rest thereof: when the eyes of man, as of all the tribes of Israel, <i>shall be</i> toward the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>2 </b>And Hamath also shall border thereby; Tyrus, and Zidon, though it be very wise.

<b>3 </b>And Tyrus did build herself a strong hold, and heaped up silver as the dust, and fine gold as the mire of the streets.

<b>4 </b>Behold, the Lord will cast her out, and he will smite her power in the sea; and she shall be devoured with fire.

<b>5 </b>Ashkelon shall see <i>it,</i> and fear; Gaza also <i>shall see it,</i> and be very sorrowful, and Ekron; for her expectation shall be ashamed; and the king shall perish from Gaza, and Ashkelon shall not be inhabited.

<b>6 </b>And a bastard shall dwell in Ashdod, and I will cut off the pride of the Philistines.

<b>7 </b>And I will take away his blood out of his mouth, and his abominations from between his teeth: but he that remaineth, even he, <i>shall be</i> for our God, and he shall be as a governor in Judah, and Ekron as a Jebusite.

<b>8 </b>And I will encamp about mine house because of the army, because of him that passeth by, and because of him that returneth: and no oppressor shall pass through them any more: for now have I seen with mine eyes.

<b>9 </b>¶ Rejoice greatly, O daughter of Zion; shout, O daughter of Jerusalem: behold, thy King cometh unto thee: he <i>is</i> just, and having salvation; lowly, and riding upon an ass, and upon a colt the foal of an ass.

<b>10 </b>And I will cut off the chariot from Ephraim, and the horse from Jerusalem, and the battle bow shall be cut off: and he shall speak peace unto the heathen: and his dominion <i>shall be</i> from sea <i>even</i> to sea, and from the river <i>even</i> to the ends of the earth.

<b>11 </b>As for thee also, by the blood of thy covenant I have sent forth thy prisoners out of the pit wherein <i>is</i> no water.

<b>12 </b>¶ Turn you to the strong hold, ye prisoners of hope: even to day do I declare <i>that</i> I will render double unto thee;

<b>13 </b>When I have bent Judah for me, filled the bow with Ephraim, and raised up thy sons, O Zion, against thy sons, O Greece, and made thee as the sword of a mighty man.

<b>14 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall be seen over them, and his arrow shall go forth as the lightning: and the Lord <span class="small-caps">God</span> shall blow the trumpet, and shall go with whirlwinds of the south.

<b>15 </b>The <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts shall defend them; and they shall devour, and subdue with sling stones; and they shall drink, <i>and</i> make a noise as through wine; and they shall be filled like bowls, <i>and</i> as the corners of the altar.

<b>16 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> their God shall save them in that day as the flock of his people: for <i>they shall be as</i> the stones of a crown, lifted up as an ensign upon his land.

<b>17 </b>For how great <i>is</i> his goodness, and how great <i>is</i> his beauty! corn shall make the young men cheerful, and new wine the maids.


--------------------

CHAPTER 10

<b>1 </b>Ask ye of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> rain in the time of the latter rain; <i>so</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> shall make bright clouds, and give them showers of rain, to every one grass in the field.

<b>2 </b>For the idols have spoken vanity, and the diviners have seen a lie, and have told false dreams; they comfort in vain: therefore they went their way as a flock, they were troubled, because <i>there was</i> no shepherd.

<b>3 </b>Mine anger was kindled against the shepherds, and I punished the goats: for the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> of hosts hath visited his flock the house of Judah, and hath made them as his goodly horse in the battle.

<b>4 </b>Out of him came forth the corner, out of him the nail, out of him the battle bow, out of him every oppressor together.

<b>5 </b>¶ And they shall be as mighty <i>men,</i> which tread down <i>their enemies</i> in the mire of the streets in the battle: and they shall fight, because the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> <i>is</i> with them, and the riders on horses shall be confounded.

<b>6 </b>And I will strengthen the house of Judah, and I will save the house of Joseph, and I will bring them again to place them; for I have mercy upon them: and they shall be as though I had not cast them off: for I <i>am</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> their God, and will hear them.

<b>7 </b>And <i>they of</i> Ephraim shall be like a mighty <i>man,</i> and their heart shall rejoice as through wine: yea, their children shall see <i>it,</i> and be glad; their heart shall rejoice in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>8 </b>I will hiss for them, and gather them; for I have redeemed them: and they shall increase as they have increased.

<b>9 </b>And I will sow them among the people: and they shall remember me in far countries; and they shall live with their children, and turn again.

<b>10 </b>I will bring them again also out of the land of Egypt, and gather them out of Assyria; and I will bring them into the land of Gilead and Lebanon; and <i>place</i> shall not be found for them.

<b>11 </b>And he shall pass through the sea with affliction, and shall smite the waves in the sea, and all the deeps of the river shall dry up: and the pride of Assyria shall be brought down, and the sceptre of Egypt shall depart away.

<b>12 </b>And I will strengthen them in the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; and they shall walk up and down in his name, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.


--------------------

CHAPTER 11

<b>1 </b>Open thy doors, O Lebanon, that the fire may devour thy cedars.

<b>2 </b>Howl, fir tree; for the cedar is fallen; because the mighty are spoiled: howl, O ye oaks of Bashan; for the forest of the vintage is come down.

<b>3 </b>¶ <i>There is</i> a voice of the howling of the shepherds; for their glory is spoiled: a voice of the roaring of young lions; for the pride of Jordan is spoiled.

<b>4 </b>Thus saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> my God; Feed the flock of the slaughter;

<b>5 </b>Whose possessors slay them, and hold themselves not guilty: and they that sell them say, Blessed <i>be</i> the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>; for I am rich: and their own shepherds pity them not.

<b>6 </b>For I will no more pity the inhabitants of the land, saith the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>: but, lo, I will deliver the men every one into his neighbour’s hand, and into the hand of his king: and they shall smite the land, and out of their hand I will not deliver <i>them.</i>

<b>7 </b>And I will feed the flock of slaughter, <i>even</i> you, O poor of the flock. And I took unto me two staves; the one I called Beauty, and the other I called Bands; and I fed the flock.

<b>8 </b>Three shepherds also I cut off in one month; and my soul lothed them, and their soul also abhorred me.

<b>9 </b>Then said I, I will not feed you: that that dieth, let it die; and that that is to be cut off, let it be cut off; and let the rest eat every one the flesh of another.

<b>10 </b>¶ And I took my staff, <i>even</i> Beauty, and cut it asunder, that I might break my covenant which I had made with all the people.

<b>11 </b>And it was broken in that day: and so the poor of the flock that waited upon me knew that it <i>was</i> the word of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>12 </b>And I said unto them, If ye think good, give <i>me</i> my price; and if not, forbear. So they weighed for my price thirty <i>pieces</i> of silver.

<b>13 </b>And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, Cast it unto the potter: a goodly price that I was prised at of them. And I took the thirty <i>pieces</i> of silver, and cast them to the potter in the house of the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span>.

<b>14 </b>Then I cut asunder mine other staff, <i>even</i> Bands, that I might break the brotherhood between Judah and Israel.

<b>15 </b>¶ And the <span class="small-caps">Lord</span> said unto me, Take unto thee yet the instruments of a foolish shepherd.

<b>16 </b>For, lo, I will raise up a shepherd in the land, <i>which</i> shall not visit those that be cut off, neither shall seek the young one, nor heal that that is broken, nor feed that that standeth still: but he shall eat the flesh of the fat, and tear their claws in pieces.
